headline: Stop Trying to Be Productive
abstract: The internet wants you to believe you aren’t doing enough with all that “extra time” you have now. But staying inside and attending to basic needs is plenty.
lead_paragraph: When Dave Kyu, 34, an arts administrator in Philadelphia, realized that he would be working from home for the foreseeable future, he began to fantasize about the projects he could now complete around the house.

headline: With Baseball Benched, These Movies Make Good Relievers
abstract: Here are the best features involving a diamond field from the last 50 years.
lead_paragraph: Opening Day has come and gone, and there’s no sign when Major League Baseball will return with new games. But fans needn’t despair. You could watch all 18½ hours of the director Ken Burns’s definitive 1994 documentary “Baseball,” streaming for free on the PBS website (and the four-hour 2010 sequel, “The Tenth Inning,” on Amazon Prime). Or you can catch a Murderers’ Row of great baseball features readily accessible online. Here, in alphabetical order, are my picks for the 10 best of the last 50 years.

headline: Waxahatchee’s Katie Crutchfield Is Out of the Storm, Cleareyed
abstract: The 31-year-old singer and songwriter’s new album, “Saint Cloud,” has a cleaner sound and some of her most evocative lyrics.
lead_paragraph: “American Weekend,” the bracing first album the songwriter Katie Crutchfield released as Waxahatchee, was “a result of a snowstorm, a visceral stupor, and a personal breakthrough,” she wrote in the liner notes. Stranded for a week in her parents’ home near Alabama’s Waxahatchee Creek, she found out in winter 2011 what so many of us are learning right now: that self-isolation can lead to heightened emotions, antic spurts of creativity and relentless self-scrutiny.

headline: How Coronavirus Is Affecting Surrogacy, Foster Care and Adoption
abstract: The pandemic is not just impacting parents and pregnant people — all prospective parents are facing new challenges.
lead_paragraph: Covid-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, has upended life for those who are or hope to become pregnant in the United States. Fertility doctors have indefinitely postponed all advanced fertility treatments, and some major hospitals in hard-hit areas are trying to ban partners and doulas from delivery rooms.

headline: Patient Has Virus and Serious Cancer. Should Doctors Withhold Ventilator?
abstract: With a looming shortage of equipment for coronavirus patients in New York City, doctors say they may soon need to make difficult choices.
lead_paragraph: One patient had lymphoma and heart failure. Another was 85 years old with metastatic cancer. A third was 83 and had dementia and lung disease. All were critically ill with the coronavirus, and, a doctor said, all were hooked up to ventilators in recent weeks at a major Manhattan hospital.

headline: Former Hulu Boss Will Lead WarnerMedia, Home of HBO and CNN
abstract: Just before the start of HBO Max, AT&T names Jason Kilar as the head of its entertainment and news unit. He replaces John Stankey, who remains AT&T’s president.
lead_paragraph: AT&T announced on Wednesday that it would bring in the former head of Hulu to lead WarnerMedia, the news and entertainment division that includes HBO, CNN and the Warner Bros. movie studio.

headline: Late-Night TV Is Back: No Studios, No Audiences, No Problems (Mostly)
abstract: Forced to improvise, hosts have returned with radically stripped down productions made from home. Can they keep it feeling fresh — and their kids out of the frame?
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, Samantha Bee was filming a segment for her TBS late-night series, “Full Frontal With Samantha Bee,” when she encountered a complication she had never dealt with before.

headline: Democrats Fear for Their Convention. For Republicans, ‘The Show Must Go On.’
abstract: As the virus disrupts the campaign, G.O.P. officials are taking their cue from President Trump, while Joe Biden said “it’s hard to envision” the Democrats holding an in-person convention in July.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Taking their cue from President Trump, Republicans at every level of the party are pushing ahead with plans to put on their national convention this summer and provide Mr. Trump the kind of gauzy coronation he seeks.

headline: We’re Not Wired to Be This Alone
abstract: Digital chats and virtual cocktails can lift our longing only so much.
lead_paragraph: When the lockdown began — the orders to avoid travel, to avoid friends, to “shelter in place,” to shrink our worlds to the slightest physical dimensions endurable — my first impression was of how quickly and ingeniously we adapted. Abracadabra: Classrooms went online. Physicians and therapists used Zoom to see patients. Happy hour happened on FaceTime.

headline: In Stressful Times, Make Stress Work for You
abstract: Research shows we can actually use stress to improve our health and well-being. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: These are stressful times. As a result of coronavirus and the disease it causes, Covid-19, millions of Americans aren’t just worried about their health, but also about their livelihoods and their futures. At the same time, warnings abound that stress itself is bad for our health and might even make us more susceptible to the illness. The irony is obvious.

headline: Pokémon, Stay
abstract: For almost four years, I’ve been playing a game that brings players out into the world. What happens when the world goes away?
lead_paragraph: I am a little figure on a big green map.

headline: Japan’s climate plan sends ‘wrong signal’
abstract: Also this week, a bright spot in locked-down cities
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Iran Says U.S. Sanctions Are Taking Lives. U.S. Officials Disagree.
abstract: Iran, devastated by the coronavirus, is asking the U.S. to lift sanctions on humanitarian grounds. U.S. officials say sanctions aren’t to blame; Iran is.
lead_paragraph: As Iran struggles with a devastating coronavirus outbreak, a broken economy and a severe shortage of medical equipment, it says that American trade sanctions are taking Iranian lives and has called for the United States to lift them on humanitarian grounds.

headline: Taking Baths May Be Good for Your Heart
abstract: Daily baths reduced the risk of heart disease and stroke.
lead_paragraph: Taking frequent baths may reduce the risk for cardiovascular disease, new research suggests.

headline: How Are You Feeling? Surveys Aim to Detect Covid-19 Hot Spots Early
abstract: Scientists have persuaded Britons and Israelis to fill out questionnaires about their health, to get ahead of the coronavirus by getting resources to the right place. The U.S. is next.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Teams of epidemiologists and computer scientists on three continents have started mass population surveys to try to get ahead of the coronavirus and ensure that scarce diagnostic tests, and even scarcer ventilators, are sent where they can do the most good.

headline: George Preti, 75, Dies; Studied Bodily Odors as Biological Clues
abstract: In his “bizarre niche” of science, he sought to weaponize odors as a means to sniff out disease, even using dogs to do so.
lead_paragraph: George Preti, an organic chemist who devoted his career to studying bodily odors and how they can be weaponized in detecting disease, died on March 3 in Hatboro, Pa. He was 75.

headline: 44 Texas Students Have Coronavirus After Spring Break Trip
abstract: A group of about 70 students from the University of Texas at Austin celebrated spring break in Mexico, then returned to find that dozens had tested positive.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Two weeks ago, amid the coronavirus pandemic, about 70 students from the University of Texas at Austin partied in Mexico on spring break. The students, all in their 20s, flew on a chartered plane to Cabo San Lucas, and some returned on separate commercial flights to Texas.

headline: 12 Family-Friendly Nature Documentaries
abstract: “March of the Penguins,” “Monkey Kingdom” and more illuminate the wonders of our planet from the safety of your couch.
lead_paragraph: Children under quarantine are enjoying an excess of “screen time,” if only to give their overtaxed parents a break. But there’s no reason they can’t learn a few things in the process. These nature documentaries have educational value for the whole family, while also offering a chance to experience the great outdoors from inside your living room.

headline: Dr. James T. Goodrich, Who Operated on Conjoined Twins, Dies at 73
abstract: Dr. Goodrich led teams that did a series of celebrated surgeries. He was a victim of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Coronavirus Patients Betrayed by Their Own Immune Systems
abstract: A “cytokine storm” becomes an all-too-frequent phenomenon, particularly among the young. But treatments are being tested.
lead_paragraph: The 42-year-old man arrived at a hospital in Paris on March 17 with a fever, cough and the “ground glass opacities” in both lungs that are a trademark of infection with the new coronavirus.

headline: This Shakshuka Is Great With Just About Any Cheese
abstract: Out of feta? You can top this saucy, eggy North African dish with mozzarella, Gouda, even Monterey Jack.
lead_paragraph: Shakshuka sprinkled liberally with feta is one of my favorite versions of the tomato-y North African egg dish. But since feta isn’t in my stockpile at the moment, I tried it with mozzarella, and it was just as appealing. What it lacked in salty funkiness, it made up for in stretchy gooeyness.

headline: ‘Joy in the Grief’: Musicians Are Making Art in a Pandemic
abstract: With performances on hold because of the coronavirus, what are artists like Barbra Streisand and Michael Tilson Thomas working on at home?
lead_paragraph: Many classical artists have had barely a week off in their careers. But with performances now on hold worldwide for months to come, what creative projects are they working on? These are edited excerpts from their conversations with Joshua Barone, Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim, Anthony Tommasini, Seth Colter Walls and Zachary Woolfe.

headline: The Rev. Joseph O’Hare, Resourceful President of Fordham, Dies at 89
abstract: He transformed the university into a national institution and played a major civic role as the overseer of New York City’s public campaign finance law.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Joseph A. O’Hare, who as the longest-serving president of Fordham University transformed it into a national institution and applied the moral rectitude of his clerical collar to civic reform in New York City, died on Sunday in the Bronx. He was 89.

headline: Climate Progress Stalls Again, Thanks to Trump’s New Auto Rules
abstract: He’s walking back a major effort to slow global warming.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s rollback on Tuesday of stringent automobile mileage and emissions standards torpedoes the biggest single step any nation has taken to fight the climate crisis. In dispensing with Obama-era rules in the name of imaginary regulatory reform, he will damage the health of the planet, our pocketbooks and even the very auto industry he thinks will benefit.

headline: Auto Sales Plummet in First Quarter as Coronavirus Keeps Buyers Away
abstract: After a strong first two months of the year, sales tumbled in March as Americans stayed home.
lead_paragraph: Automakers reported a plunge on Wednesday in new-vehicle sales as fear of the coronavirus and stay-at-home orders kept consumers from dealerships, adding to the troubles of the country’s largest manufacturing sector.

headline: When Humans Are Sheltered in Place, Wild Animals Will Play
abstract: Goats in Wales; coyotes in San Francisco; rats, rats, everywhere: With much of the world staying home to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, animals have ventured out where normally the presence of people would keep them away.
lead_paragraph: Under the cover of night, in their feathered, silken, cream-colored coats, they trotted into Llandudno, a seaside town in Wales.

headline: One of Europe’s Most Polluted Towns Stages a Noisy Revolt
abstract: Residents of Fos-sur-Mer accepted a trade-off for decades: good jobs for foul air. But when the health costs became impossible to ignore, they went to court, a groundbreaking move in France.
lead_paragraph: FOS-SUR-MER, France — The line of giant chimneys ceaselessly belching smoke in the air stretches to the horizon in one of the most polluted industrial zones in Europe.

headline: Jobless Claims Hit 3.3 Million in the Last Report. This Week’s Will Probably Be Worse.
abstract: An analysis of Google search data suggests that last week’s unemployment claims could surpass 5 million.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of Google search data suggests that last week’s unemployment claims could surpass 5 million.

headline: A Reader Looking for Remedies Thinks Back to Other Difficult Times
abstract: The current crisis is hard for readers even though, for many, it has come with the unexpected gift of free time and nowhere to be.
lead_paragraph: I was newly living in London in the summer of 1995 when my husband had a stroke that left him partially paralyzed down his left side and, for a time, barely able to talk. I was 31. We had been married for just two months.

headline: Animals, Sex and Guns? Eric Goode Knew ‘Tiger King’ Had Potential
abstract: Goode, who directed the Netflix series with Rebecca Chaiklin, talked about its creation and its unexpected success during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When he set out to investigate the inner world of exotic animal breeders, Eric Goode had no idea he would end up making the hit Netflix series “Tiger King: Murder, Mayhem and Madness.”

headline: Florida Governor, at Long Last, Orders Residents to Stay Home to Avoid Coronavirus
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis said the decision corresponded with the “national pause” effectively recommended by the White House.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Florida’s coronavirus cases kept ballooning, especially in the dense neighborhoods of Miami and Fort Lauderdale. Hospitals in Fort Myers and Naples begged for donations of masks and other protective equipment. Young people started to die.

headline: How to Make Bread at Any Skill Level
abstract: Whether you’ve been baking sourdough for years and want to hone your skills, or you’re just trying to find your footing, we have recipes for you.
lead_paragraph: Bread baking is a journey, and an extremely rewarding one at that. With each loaf, you’ll watch your skills grow and develop, and you’ll gain a keen understanding of the process. As you get better, you’ll know what to look for, and how to read your dough’s cues (it’s alive, after all!).

headline: The Reason for an Israeli Curfew: Palestinian Terrorism
abstract: The Anti-Defamation League cites the toll in Israeli lives from suicide bombers in 2002. Also: Jerry Falwell Jr.; the Pandemic board game; struggling young mothers; reading plays out loud.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Acupuncture May Ease Migraines
abstract: A Chinese study found that acupuncture reduced the number of headache attacks in migraine sufferers.
lead_paragraph: Acupuncture may provide benefits for easing migraine headaches, researchers report.

headline: ‘Boys Are Boys and Girls Are Girls’: Idaho Is First State to Bar Some Transgender Athletes
abstract: Student-athletes from elementary school age through college may have to consent to sex testing in order to compete.
lead_paragraph: Idaho has become the first state in the United States to bar transgender girls from participating in girls’ and women’s sports and to legalize the practice of asking girls and women to undergo sex testing in order to compete.

headline: Hilda Churchill, 108, Dies; Survived Wars and the 1918 Pandemic
abstract: The Spanish flu struck her entire family and killed her baby sister a century ago. She died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Hilda Churchill survived the Great War, the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic that claimed her baby sister, and World War II, but eight days before her 109th birthday she became Britain’s oldest recorded victim of the coronavirus.

headline: How 2 Very Different Los Angeles Hospitals Are Facing Coronavirus
abstract: One is a top-ranked research hospital that draws celebrities and royalty. The other serves some of the city’s most vulnerable communities. Neither says it has the equipment it will need when virus cases surge.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One is a top-ranked research hospital in West Los Angeles, with buildings named after Steven Spielberg and Barbra Streisand. Its hallways are hung with works by Picasso, Miro and Warhol, part of a 4,000-piece collection of donated art. Hollywood celebrities and royalty vie to recover in its first-come, first-served luxury suites.

headline: How to Donate Your N95 Masks to New York Doctors
abstract: Medical professionals on the front lines in New York and its suburbs are facing a shortage of masks and other personal protection equipment. Here are easy ways residents can donate supplies.
lead_paragraph: As coronavirus cases continue to soar in and around New York, doctors, nurses and others on the front lines say their supplies of medical-grade N95 and surgical masks are rapidly dwindling, with the worst of the epidemic yet to come.

headline: These Coronavirus Exposures Might Be the Most Dangerous
abstract: As with any other poison, viruses are usually deadlier in larger amounts.
lead_paragraph: Li Wenliang, the doctor in China who raised early awareness of the new coronavirus, died of the virus in February at 34. His death was shocking not only because of his role in publicizing the developing epidemic but also — given that young people do not have a high risk of dying from Covid-19 — because of his age.

headline: The Case for a Rent Moratorium
abstract: We need another aid bill. Elected officials have a responsibility to stabilize both communities and the housing market.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the U.S. Senate approved a $2.2 trillion coronavirus stimulus package. It includes many important elements, such as expanded unemployment benefits, and emergency aid for small businesses and hospitals hit hard by the crisis. This is a step in the right direction, but it is not enough.

headline: Manolis Glezos Dies at 97; Tore Down Nazi Flag Over Athens
abstract: He became a national hero in the Greek resistance for a daring feat atop the Acropolis. He later endured prison and exile and pursued a leftist political career.
lead_paragraph: Manolis Glezos, a Greek resistance fighter who became a national hero after he and a friend tore down the Nazi flag that waved over the Acropolis when the Germans occupied Athens in 1941, died on Monday in Athens. He was 97.

headline: Notion, Maker of Collaboration Software, Raises $50 Million
abstract: While many start-ups grapple with the fallout from the pandemic, this San Francisco company raised more cash to survive.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The spread of the coronavirus has meant feast or famine for technology start-ups. While many are cutting staff and slashing costs as they reel from the outbreak’s fallout, others have experienced a surge in demand.

headline: The Masters on Halloween? Golf Weighs Tradition Against the Calendar
abstract: The five different governing bodies of golf’s most prestigious tournaments are considering unconventional concessions in order to salvage the season.
lead_paragraph: If golf’s biggest events are to be salvaged this year, the game’s leaders must find an uncommon wellspring of creativity and flexibility. The first two men’s Grand Slam events of the year, the Masters and the P.G.A. Championship, have already been postponed indefinitely, and the schedules for the two others, the United States and British Opens, are teetering as the coronavirus increasingly alters lives around the globe.

headline: Why a Pandemic Is Bringing Out Our Best Online
abstract: Welcome to On Tech, a daily newsletter on how technology is changing all of our lives — for better or worse.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome! The pandemic has turned everything we know upside down, and we are relying on technology more than ever to work, go to school, stay informed, entertain ourselves and stay connected to people we love.

headline: The Weeknd’s Gleamy, Seamy Pop Returns
abstract: On “After Hours,” the singer’s border-crossing big-tent ambitions reach new heights.
lead_paragraph: Pop music — what’s left of it anyway — is a hodgepodge of styles and moods. A landing place for any number of likely and unlikely approaches more than a big flashing-red target, the way it was two or four decades ago. Even the poppiest stars of the day tend to filter their ambition through reluctance, which leaves a clear path for the Weeknd, an unlikely preservationist of mega-pop’s grand ambitions. No current pop star is more invested in the idea of pop’s majesty, its iridescent gloom, its exultant relief.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in April
abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for April.
lead_paragraph: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.

headline: Global Recession, Coronavirus, Face Masks: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Protect the Doctors and Nurses Who Are Protecting Us
abstract: They need immunity from lawsuits and prosecution for triage decisions.
lead_paragraph: Our health care system is on the cusp of a crisis not seen before. A ventilator shortage is coming, if it’s not already here. Hospitals, physicians and nurses are likely to face a terrible choice: Should they withdraw or withhold ventilators from some patients so that others with better odds of survival might benefit from the machines?

headline: Making Art During a Pandemic: Theaters Seek and Share Mini-Plays
abstract: Nonprofits around the country plan to commission works of no longer than 10 minutes that can be read or performed by people sheltering in place.
lead_paragraph: They took their new jobs less than two years ago: a diverse group of ambitious arts administrators eager to see how their ideas and dreams might influence theaters around the country.

headline: Trump’s ‘Lack of Leadership’ During the Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: Readers contrast the president’s statements with the facts and urge a national stay-at-home edict.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Remembering Coronavirus Victims: Tell Us About People You Knew.
abstract: The pandemic has claimed people from all walks of life, knowing no boundaries.
lead_paragraph: A school principal, a nurse, an actor. A Tony-winning playwright, a pediatric neurosurgeon, a jazz pianist. The coronavirus epidemic is an undiscriminating reaper. It has brought death to all walks of life, all economic backgrounds, all races and all the continents.

headline: ‘It’s Just So Devastating’: For Crestfallen Gymnasts, an Olympic Dream Deferred
abstract: Female gymnasts often compete at younger ages than their Olympic peers and have a far more concentrated opportunity at the top. Into that intense world dropped the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: MyKayla Skinner, a gymnast on the United States national team, fought to finish her workout.

headline: Coronavirus Delays Key Global Climate Talks
abstract: This year’s United Nations-sponsored climate talks, widely regarded as the most important climate meeting of the last four years, were postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This year’s United Nations-sponsored climate talks, widely regarded as the most important climate meeting of the past four years, were postponed on Wednesday because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Why State and Local Debt Is Fraught Territory for the Fed
abstract: The central bank is weighing what it can do to help local bond markets. Here’s why Democrats’ big ask — direct purchases — is so tough.
lead_paragraph: Rhode Island will miss out on $300 million in revenue in March and early April as coronavirus delays income tax filings, while shuttered casinos cost state coffers another $1 million per day. Expenses, meantime, are through the roof — the state spent $7 million on ventilators on Monday alone.

headline: It’s the Official Start to the 2020 Census. But No One Counted On a Pandemic.
abstract: The Census Bureau faced enormous hurdles in transforming the census for the digital age. The coronavirus epidemic upended a huge part of its plans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This was the year the Census Bureau was primed for a gargantuan task — remaking the census of nearly 330 million Americans for the digital age at a time of enormous national division and obstacles to an accurate count.

headline: Prepare for War or Fight Coronavirus? U.S. Military Battles Competing Instincts
abstract: The Navy has so far refused to completely evacuate the Theodore Roosevelt, an aircraft carrier where 93 service members have been confirmed to be infected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the hallmarks of the United States military is its ability to project power around the world, often under the banner of slogans intended to strike fear in its adversaries. “Ready to fight tonight” for U.S. troops in South Korea; “America’s 911” for the Marine Corps expeditionary units at sea; the list goes on.

headline: Pro-Trump Super PAC to Spend $10 Million on Attack Ads Against Biden
abstract: The ads bought by the group, America First, will air in three Rust Belt states that were pivotal to President Trump’s victory in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The super PAC supporting President Trump’s re-election is planning a $10 million advertising spree to attack former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in three Rust Belt states that were crucial to the president’s 2016 victory, officials with the group said on Wednesday.

headline: Some Coronavirus Patients Show Signs of Brain Ailments
abstract: Doctors have observed neurological symptoms, including confusion, stroke and seizures, in a small subset of Covid-19 patients.
lead_paragraph: Neurologists around the world say that a small subset of patients with Covid-19 are developing serious impairments of the brain.

headline: Man Wanted in Triple Killing Is Arrested After Armed Standoff on Florida Highway
abstract: The authorities said that Caesar Zamien Lamar Crockett Jr. had kidnapped his 2-year-old son after fatally shooting three family members in Macon, Ga., on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of killing three family members and kidnapping his young son in Georgia surrendered to the police on Wednesday night after an armed standoff that snarled traffic for several hours on a Florida highway, the authorities said.

headline: Needy Will Face Hurdles to Getting Coronavirus Stimulus
abstract: The Treasury reversed guidance that would have required millions of Social Security recipients to file returns, but many other low-income people will have to submit them.
lead_paragraph: In the sweeping economic recovery package that Congress passed last week, the federal government promised payments of up to $1,200 to most American adults, including those with little income or none at all.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: In the Midst of the Coronavirus Pandemic, People Share Their Love Stories
abstract: How has coronavirus impacted relationships? People around the world answer.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Cuomo Is a Media Hero in the Pandemic. De Blasio Is a Scapegoat.
abstract: The mayor of New York, who is often disdainful of the media, has become an irresistible punching bag.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York called me this morning a little out of breath, feet pounding in the background, on his daily walk in Prospect Park. It’s the kind of stubbornly pointless personal ritual his critics in the media find incredibly annoying — couldn’t he just stay home at Gracie Mansion and clap for health care workers like his neighbors?

headline: Trump Rebuffs Demands to Lift Tariffs as Economy Falters
abstract: The calls by corporate leaders have intensified as the coronavirus inflicts financial pain, but President Trump has argued that the levies do not hurt American companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump continues to resist calls from hundreds of companies to drop tariffs he has placed on foreign goods, arguing that the levies do not impose costs on American companies, despite economic evidence to the contrary.

headline: ‘We Are the Silent First Responders’: The Workers Who Make America Work
abstract: Exposed and afraid but determined, workers who have no choice but to confront the pandemic describe their changed world in their own words.
lead_paragraph: Exposed and afraid but determined, workers who have no choice but to confront the pandemic describe their changed world in their own words.

headline: This Puerto Rican Sculptor Meets Disaster With Spirit
abstract: Watching the coronavirus crisis take hold, Daniel Lind-Ramos, a powerful storyteller, filled notebooks with carnival, medical and spiritual imagery.
lead_paragraph: For the artist Daniel Lind-Ramos, a local hero in Puerto Rico whose altarlike assemblage sculptures of everyday objects have belatedly found acclaim on the mainland, the past month was to have been a celebration of his new visibility, which began with last year’s Whitney Biennial.

headline: Get Unstuck When You Feel You Don’t Have Time to Do Anything
abstract: Most of us feel we’re so busy we don’t have time to start on our dream (or everyday) projects. Here’s how to find the time.
lead_paragraph: You’re doing great and feeling on top of your work. You pretty much know what to get done, have a sense of momentum and aren’t avoiding projects.

headline: Lorena Borjas, Transgender Immigrant Activist, Dies at 59
abstract: She helped transgender women in Queens contend with human trafficking, health issues and possible deportation. Her death was attributed to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: ‘Infrastructure Week’ Returns as Trump and Democrats Eye Post-Virus Jobs Plan
abstract: Democrats and President Trump are discussing a multitrillion-dollar infrastructure plan that could create thousands of jobs to salve an economy battered by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Congress and the White House contemplate the next phase of the government response to the coronavirus pandemic and its economic toll, Democrats and President Trump are increasingly raising the prospect of enacting a multitrillion-dollar infrastructure plan that could create thousands of jobs.

headline: Juggling Lessons From Katie Porter
abstract: The congresswoman is pushing for oversight of the bailout as she self-quarantines with three kids.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Coronavirus, Recession, ‘Tiger King’: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Adam Schlesinger, Songwriter for Rock, Film and the Stage, Dies at 52
abstract: He made suburban characters shine in Fountains of Wayne songs and brought pop-rock perfection to the film “That Thing You Do!” He died of coronavirus complications.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: T-Mobile Closes Merger With Sprint, and a Wireless Giant Is Born
abstract: The new T-Mobile will have over 100 million customers and plans to take on AT&T and Verizon.
lead_paragraph: A new wireless giant has entered the scene.

headline: Well, at Least Trump Hasn’t …
abstract: Always look on the bright side of life.
lead_paragraph: Let’s try to look on the bright side of coronavirus politics. OK, that sounds ridiculous. Let’s look on a less neurosis-inducing side.

headline: A Ventilator Stockpile, With One Hitch: Thousands Do Not Work
abstract: While President Trump has assured states that thousands of ventilators remain at the ready, thousands more are in storage, unmaintained or otherwise unusable.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has repeatedly assured Americans that the federal government is holding 10,000 ventilators in reserve to ship to the hardest-hit hospitals around the nation as they struggle to keep the most critically ill patients alive.

headline: Retailers Under Growing Pressure to Let Workers Wear Masks
abstract: Restrictions that follow current C.D.C. guidelines have become a source of tension at many stores supplying essential goods during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: At Office Depot, employees have been told that they cannot wear masks in the store. Some Walgreens workers say they were also discouraged from wearing them. Many other large retailers, including Target, have started to allow masks, but are leaving it up to employees to procure their own supplies.

headline: Kevin Thomas Duffy, U.S. Judge in Terrorism Cases, Dies at 87
abstract: An independent-minded jurist, he oversaw the World Trade Center bombing trial and another involving a plot to down jetliners. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Loeffler’s Wealth Becomes a Risk as Rivals Charge She Profited on the Coronavirus
abstract: Millions of dollars in stock trades by the freshman senator have drawn intense scrutiny for potential insider trading, and it could reshape a contested Senate race in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Georgia’s governor picked Kelly Loeffler, a little-known Atlanta businesswoman, to fill the state’s vacant Senate seat late last year, her vast personal wealth and ability to fund her own campaign were top selling points for Republicans.

headline: Devin Nunes Says Decision to Cancel School in California Was ‘Overkill’
abstract: Mr. Nunes, a Republican representative from California, urged the country to start getting people back to work in one to two weeks despite the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The top Republican on the House Intelligence Committee this week criticized closing schools in his home state, California, as “way overkill” — even as President Trump came to a reckoning over the number of people who could die during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: ‘I Do Fear for My Staff,’ a Doctor Said. He Lost His Job.
abstract: Health care professionals are being punished for protecting themselves, and us.
lead_paragraph: Doctors and nurses responding to the Covid-19 pandemic are the superheroes of our age, putting themselves at risk to save the lives of others.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Florida issued a statewide stay-at-home order. Plus, new developments in drug trials.
lead_paragraph: Experts have long been eyeing Florida as a ticking time bomb in the coronavirus pandemic, because it has so many older residents (a quarter of the population is over 60), and it gets so many visitors from around the world (125 million annually), especially at this time of year.

headline: A Month of Coronavirus in New York City: See the Hardest-Hit Areas
abstract: New data released by the city shows that lower-income neighborhoods have been most affected by the virus.
lead_paragraph: New data released by the city shows that lower-income neighborhoods have been most affected by the virus.

headline: Friend Who Trump Says Has Coronavirus Is a New York Developer
abstract: Stanley Chera, 78, is hospitalized and believed to be in a coma.
lead_paragraph: For another time on Wednesday, President Trump somberly described a personal connection to the coronavirus as he discussed the effects of the pandemic at his daily briefing with his virus task force.

headline: Remembering the Neediest During the Coronavirus Pandemic
abstract: Through The Times’s Neediest Cases Fund, a new relief campaign will support organizations on the front lines of serving those affected by the virus.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Alarm, Denial, Blame: The Pro-Trump Media’s Coronavirus Distortion
abstract: Sean Hannity, Rush Limbaugh and other right-wing commentators turned a pandemic into a battle of us vs. them — the kind of battle President Trump has waged for much of his life.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 27, two days after the first reported case of the coronavirus spreading inside a community in the United States, Candace Owens was underwhelmed. “Now we’re all going to die from Coronavirus,” she wrote sarcastically to her two million Twitter followers, blaming a “doomsday cult” of liberal paranoia for the growing anxiety over the outbreak.

headline: Cooped-Up Children Lose Refuge as N.Y.C. Playgrounds Are Closed
abstract: Governor orders shutdown of playgrounds and basketball courts to maintain social distancing, but parks remain open.
lead_paragraph: All New York City’s playgrounds were ordered shut on Wednesday to slow the spread of the coronavirus — a move that led to scenes of crying children shaking locked gates, even as other parkgoers called the measure long overdue.

headline: The Many Times It’s Been ‘Infrastructure Week’ in Washington
abstract: Since President Trump vowed to tackle infrastructure during the 2016 campaign, it has been an elusive, bipartisan goal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the moment President Trump made his 2016 campaign pledge to start a $1 trillion effort to rebuild the United States’ roads and bridges, infrastructure has become a constant motif of his presidency: his unfulfilled boasts about cutting big bipartisan deals, his quest for distractions from disastrous news cycles and his inability to tackle the nation’s pressing issues.

headline: Peter Beard, Photographer Who Makes His Art From Nature’s, Is Missing
abstract: Mr. Beard, who is 82 and has dementia, was last seen walking on Tuesday near his home in Montauk, according to the authorities there.
lead_paragraph: Police on Long Island were searching Wednesday for the photographer Peter Beard, known for creating elaborate collages from documentary images of Africa, after he disappeared on Tuesday afternoon from his home in Montauk, N.Y.

headline: Trump Warns Iran of Heightened Retaliation for Any Attacks on U.S. Troops
abstract: Democratic leaders cautioned the president privately that he must consult lawmakers before taking military action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump warned Iran on Wednesday against using its proxy forces to attack American troops, vowing to retaliate by going “up the food chain,” a hint that the American military was considering a more direct strike on Iranian forces.

headline: How U.S. Coronavirus Diagnoses Are Lagging Behind the Outbreak
abstract: Data from the C.D.C. shows when patients who tested positive for coronavirus first started feeling symptoms, giving a clearer picture of the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Data from the C.D.C. shows when patients who tested positive for coronavirus first started feeling symptoms, giving a clearer picture of the outbreak.

headline: SoftBank Won’t Buy $3 Billion in WeWork Stock
abstract: The move is a blow to shareholders like Adam Neumann, the company’s co-founder, and venture capital firms that had hoped to cash out of the troubled office space company.
lead_paragraph: SoftBank has decided it will not buy $3 billion in WeWork stock from other shareholders, a board committee of the office space company said Wednesday night, dealing a blow to shareholders, including Adam Neumann, the company’s co-founder and former chief executive, who had hoped to sell their stock.

headline: About 2 Million Guns Were Sold in the U.S. as Virus Fears Spread
abstract: Americans bought about two million guns last month, according to a New York Times analysis of federal data.
lead_paragraph: Americans bought about two million guns last month, according to a New York Times analysis of federal data.

headline: Home Depot Halts Sales of N95 Masks Amid Shortage, Company Says
abstract: The retailer said it had redirected shipments of the masks to health care providers and emergency responders.
lead_paragraph: Home Depot has ordered all 2,300 of its stores in North America to stop sales of N95 masks to try to free them up for those on the front lines of the coronavirus emergency response, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Fancy-Schmancy
abstract: Evan Mahnken is acting all superior … or is he?
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Readers probably don’t think of us this way, but The New York Times prizes plain writing. There are certainly occasions when complex verbiage is called for, but in general, writers are encouraged — through gentle, collegial encouragement, and the occasional cattle prod — to make their points clearly and simply.

headline: The Racial Time Bomb in the Covid-19 Crisis
abstract: Pre-existing health conditions leave one group particularly vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Early Monday morning the email arrived. The subject line began, “ALARM AT THE GATE,” written in all caps. Someone had died. That is always what that phrasing means.

headline: 12 Fraught Hours With E.M.T.s in a City Under Siege
abstract: Special units of emergency medical workers in Paterson, N.J., respond to 911 calls for suspected coronavirus, entering homes and putting themselves at risk.
lead_paragraph: PATERSON, N.J. — “Back up, sir!” shouted Kenny Kiefer, a Fire Department battalion chief, his N95 mask muffling his words.

headline: Ellis Marsalis, Jazz Pianist and Music Family Patriarch, Dies at 85
abstract: The father of Wynton and Branford Marsalis and a prominent performer and educator, he succumbed to complications of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: After Threats, Anthony Fauci to Receive Enhanced Personal Security
abstract: Dr. Fauci has become a target of online conspiracy theorists after advocating social distancing rules.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s leading expert on infectious diseases, who has become a regular at President Trump’s coronavirus briefings, will receive enhanced personal security after receiving threats following his repeated pleas for Americans to help slow the spread of the deadly pandemic, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: April 2, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 2, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about asymptomatic coronavirus cases and potential changes to federal guidelines on wearing masks misstated the location of a choir that developed many cases of coronavirus infection. It was in Mount Vernon, Wash., north of Seattle, not in Seattle.

headline: ‘The Magicians’ Showrunners: Behind the Series Finale
abstract: As they cast their final spell, Sera Gamble and John McNamara discuss what was and what might have been for Fillory and its inhabitants.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for Wednesday night’s episode of “The Magicians.”

headline: Real Estate Spring Buying Season Could Be ‘Catastrophic’
abstract: A strong start to the year for property sales in Manhattan was erased by the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: In spite of market headwinds, overpriced apartments and legislative obstacles, New York’s residential real estate market was on an improbable upward swing for most of the first quarter.

headline: White House Debates How Far to Go on Face Mask Guidelines
abstract: The coordinator of the coronavirus response emphasized that social distancing was still the most important step people could take. Critical medicines are running low, and nearly 10 million Americans have lost their jobs.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read our global live coverage on the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: Small-Business Relief Effort ‘a Mess’
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: Biden Calls for Democratic Convention to Be Delayed Because of Virus
abstract: The former vice president said the convention should be moved from mid-July to August, becoming the most prominent Democrat to urge such a postponement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday night called for moving the Democratic National Convention from mid-July to August, making him the most prominent member of his party to say the convention must be rescheduled because of the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Coronavirus, Global Recession, Wimbledon: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Hobby Lobby Defies Stay-at-Home Orders by Reopening Some Stores
abstract: Authorities in two states sent cease-and-desist letters to the craft store chain.
lead_paragraph: The arts-and-crafts chain Hobby Lobby was accused of defying stay-at-home orders in at least four states during the coronavirus outbreak, prompting officials to take action against the retailer.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘The Virtues’ and ‘Blinded by the Light’
abstract: A British mini-series has its stateside debut on Topic. And the Bruce Springsteen musical drama “Blinded by the Light” airs on HBO Signature.
lead_paragraph: THE VIRTUES Stream on Topic. By the time the kettle wails, Joseph is crying. It’s a couple of minutes into “The Virtues,” and Joseph (Stephen Graham), an Irishman living in England, is readying for a final meal with his ex, his son and his ex’s new partner, before those three leave to start a new life in Australia. That is the foundation of this four-part mini-series, the latest project from the British filmmaker Shane Meadows. “The Virtues,” written by Meadows and Jack Thorne, delves into loneliness, sexual abuse and trauma. It follows Joseph on a path of despair — and eventual reconciliation.

headline: Word + Quiz: parlous
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Trevor Noah Thinks Trump May Have Started Reading the News
abstract: If the president’s alarmed about the virus, we should really be worried, said Noah: “This is the same dude who stared at an eclipse like it was a Magic Eye painting.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: They All Retired Before They Hit 40. Then This Happened.
abstract: The stock market wasn’t going to create wealth forever. So what about the FIRE movement?
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Eric Richard was in Bali, Indonesia, enjoying the tropical weather and carefree life of a retiree. Last summer, at 29, Mr. Richard had quit his job as a corporate operations manager to become a “digital nomad.”

headline: Looking Back
abstract: What story could this image tell?
lead_paragraph: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: Coronavirus Is Making the Public Pension Crisis Even Worse
abstract: The pandemic has handed the funds big losses after they ramped up their appetite for risk over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: For years, the country’s public pension plans have faced a yawning gap between what they owe and what they can pay.

headline: The Apocalypse as an ‘Unveiling’: What Religion Teaches Us About the End Times
abstract: For people of many faiths, and even none at all, it can feel lately like the end of the world is near.
lead_paragraph: Shamain Webster, who lives in the suburbs outside of Dallas, has seen the signs of a coming apocalypse for a while now, just as the Bible foretold.

headline: In Slum at Epicenter of Duterte’s Drug Crackdown, Fear and Love Coexist
abstract: At the height of President Rodrigo Duterte’s anti-crime campaign, as many as five people a night were killed in Market Three, a Manila slum whose residents rely only on one another.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The fishing is best on nights like this when the moon is a sliver in the sky, and at midnight in the Philippines’ largest fishing port, the atmosphere was frenetic.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For People of Many Religions, Crisis Has Signs of Apocalypse
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 2, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Apocalypse is a flexible script.”

headline: As Stages Go Dark, Companies Stumble
abstract: Several French theater companies, closed in the coronavirus outbreak, have rushed to put content online. Much of it is underwhelming.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The 17th-century philosopher Blaise Pascal once wrote: “The sole cause of people’s unhappiness is that they do not know how to stay quietly in their rooms.” Yet at a time when much of the world has been forced to hunker down, French theater-makers are fighting to fill the void by making noise online.

headline: Oprah’s Book Club Dropped Her Novel. It Still Became a Best Seller.
abstract: Kate Elizabeth Russell’s publication experience has been the best of times and the worst of times. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: MY DARK DEBUT Kate Elizabeth Russell worked on her first novel for 18 years — through high school, college, a master’s program, while earning a Ph.D. in creative writing from the University of Kansas and beyond. It took “about five months of constant querying” to find an agent, but then William Morrow quickly snapped up the manuscript for an impressive sum in 2018. Rights were sold in 27 countries. “My Dark Vanessa,” which explores a sexual relationship between a 15-year-old student and her teacher through a #MeToo lens, was hailed as one of the most anticipated books of 2020.

headline: Where America Didn’t Stay Home Even as the Virus Spread
abstract: People in Florida and elsewhere continued to travel widely during the week of March 23, potentially exposing more people to the coronavirus, phone data shows.
lead_paragraph: People in Florida and elsewhere continued to travel widely during the week of March 23, potentially exposing more people to the coronavirus, phone data shows.

headline: Dance This Mess Around: When Georgia Recreated Rock ’n’ Roll
abstract: In “Cool Town,” Grace Elizabeth Hale tells the story of R.E.M., the B-52’s and the musical city of Athens.
lead_paragraph: COOL TOWN

headline: Beverly Jenkins Really Needs to Buy More Bookcases
abstract: “Nothing in my life is organized, especially not my books.”
lead_paragraph: “Nothing in my life is organized, especially not my books,” says the romance novelist, whose most recent book is “On the Corner of Hope and Main.”

headline: Poem: Bad Sons Anonymous
abstract: Virgil Suárez examines the mixed brew of childhood memory, exile, ornithology, contrasts and conflicts that build a life.
lead_paragraph: We were all sons and daughters who ostensibly learned simple ethical codes: Thou shalt not tell a lie. Thou shalt not beat your child. What mirrors, then, held up to whom? In his captivating new book, “The Painted Bunting’s Last Molt,” Virgil Suárez examines the mixed brew of childhood memory, exile, ornithology, contrasts and conflicts that build a life. His eye remains tuned to details, turning them over like shining geodes. The darkly humorous twists of “Bad Sons Anonymous” remind us that it’s never just one clear story. Poem Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: A Renter Realizes He Can Do Better Than Manhattan. Which of These Homes Did He Choose?
abstract: Seeking to escape the turbulence of Hell’s Kitchen for a bigger, quieter space, a writer surveys his outer-borough options. Here’s where he wound up.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to escape the turbulence of Hell’s Kitchen for a bigger, quieter space, a writer surveys his outer-borough options. Here’s where he wound up.

headline: ‘It’s a Pretty Big Bummer’: Olympic Dreams on Hold
abstract: The Times asked Olympic and Paralympic athletes from around the world to make videos about the postponed Summer Games, and what life is like stuck at home. Here’s what they told us.
lead_paragraph: The Times asked Olympic and Paralympic athletes from around the world to make videos about the postponed Summer Games, and what life is like stuck at home. Here’s what they told us.

headline: What Italian Pediatricians Can Tell Us
abstract: “We are all facing something new and unknown, and also rapidly changing, for which we don’t have durable protocols,” one wrote.
lead_paragraph: Last week I took part in an online conversation in which a large group of American pediatricians listened as some of our colleagues from Italy talked about pediatrics in the coronavirus crisis, because what they are dealing with there is what we will be dealing with here very soon.

headline: ‘Lazy Susan’ Review: She Just Keeps Spinning in Place
abstract: This comedy, directed by Nick Peet, features Sean Hayes as the title character who tends to lean on rather than lean in.
lead_paragraph: The title of this movie isn’t kidding. To answer your first question, “How lazy is this Susan?” here’s how lazy: While slumped on her sofa, she squeezes ketchup packets into her navel, creating a receptacle in which to dip her takeout French fries.

headline: My Grandmother Knew a Secret: Survival Can Be Stored in a Jar
abstract: She always made too much food and counted her wealth in jars of preserved fruit.
lead_paragraph: RICHLAND, Pa. — I’m great at feeding people, but I’ve never mastered portion control. I joke that it’s inherited, that I always make too much because written in my genome is the fear that there won’t be enough to go around. That’s never happened; I’ve always had the luxury of a full shopping cart.

headline: High Blood Pressure of Pregnancy Tied to Developmental Problems in Children
abstract: Pre-eclampsia was associated with a slightly increased risk of epilepsy, autism and other neurodevelopmental problems in offspring.
lead_paragraph: Pre-eclampsia — the high blood pressure of pregnancy — can be harmful and even fatal to the mother. Now a new study suggests that children exposed to pre-eclampsia may be at increased risk for a number of developmental problems.

headline: Is the Coronavirus Pandemic Bringing Your Extended Family Closer Together?
abstract: Are you FaceTiming with grandparents, Zooming with cousins or doing virtual family check-ins more often than usual?
lead_paragraph: Is your immediate family feeling anxious about the well-being and health of your grandparents, older relatives or extended family? Or vice versa: Is your extended family worried about you?

headline: The President vs. the Governors
abstract: And how should Joe Biden campaign amid the coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: In a Pandemic, Do Doctors Still Have a Duty to Treat?
abstract: We have obligations as professionals — but also as husbands, wives, parents and children.
lead_paragraph: It is a question being asked in hospitals across the country: What is the duty to treat in a viral pandemic, particularly one in which health workers are getting infected and there is a dearth of personal protective equipment?

headline: There Is an Antidote to Our Fear. It’s Called Leadership.
abstract: President Trump called himself a “wartime” president. But he has failed the most essential test: delivering the truth.
lead_paragraph: Since the coronavirus upended our lives, there’s a number that has been haunting me: 70 percent. That’s what experts believe could be the proportion of Americans ultimately infected with the virus. It was also, in the autumn of 2004, the estimated casualty rate of killed or wounded for my platoon as we prepared for the assault into Falluja, the largest battle of the Iraq war. Then, “70 percent” was like a code word for my fears. Fear is a virus, too, spreading person to person. I could feel fear spread through our ranks in much the same way I can feel it spread across America right now. In a crisis, like a pandemic or a war, there is an antidote for this kind of fear: leadership.

headline: How to Make Your Work-Neighbors Be Quiet (In 3 Lies or Less)
abstract: We’ve been getting a lot of feedback that your neighbors are too loud. That’s lie No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

headline: U.S. and Europe: How Do the Outbreak Patterns Compare?
abstract: Bleak figures from Western Europe may offer a preview of what coronavirus death tallies will look like in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The United States now leads the world by many measures of the coronavirus outbreak, whether it’s a dubious distinction like the largest number of confirmed cases or a more positive one, like total coronavirus tests.

headline: In Sudden Shift, U.S. and China Seek to Cooperate
abstract: Several of President Trump’s top aides are advising him to work with China on the coronavirus pandemic, but national security officials are skeptical the truce will hold.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For weeks, President Trump and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo forcefully used the controversial terms “Chinese virus” and “Wuhan virus” in public and said they intended to hold Beijing responsible for the crippling coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Building an L.G.B.T.Q. Political Pipeline
abstract: Those left out of the decision-making room must have a viable path forward.
lead_paragraph: I’ll never forget sitting alone in my unfurnished one-room apartment in July 1984. Fresh out of college, my fear of four more years of a Reagan presidency was mollified by the inspiration I felt seeing Geraldine Ferraro accept the nomination for vice president at the Democratic convention.

headline: Some Alternatives for the Bored Gamer
abstract: Suffering from game burnout? We’ve got suggestions for all types of game enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: With so many of us stuck at home, gamers included, there is bound to be burnout. For those players who are over their usual go-to’s, here are some alternatives in the major gaming genres, suggested by New York Times editors and reporters.

headline: Trump Is Politicizing the Pandemic. Governors Can Fight Back.
abstract: States need the federal government, and that has allowed Mr. Trump to indulge his worst tendencies.
lead_paragraph: As the Trump administration has floundered in the face of the coronavirus pandemic, the nation’s governors have tried to step into the breach.

headline: New York City Deploys 45 Mobile Morgues as Virus Strains Funeral Homes
abstract: “When you overwhelm the health system, you also overwhelm the death system,” one funeral director said.
lead_paragraph: New York City has already set up 45 new mobile morgues. Local crematories are now allowed to work around the clock. At one Brooklyn hospital, the in-house morgue was filled to capacity on Tuesday. The next day, the nursing staff ran out of body bags.

headline: Richard Prince: This Ain’t No Retrospective, It’s a Rodeo
abstract: A new book looks at the figure of the American cowboy through the outlaw lens of Mr. Prince, an artist known for his sly borrowings.
lead_paragraph: Photography and the mythos of the American cowboy have been lassoed together almost from birth. Even when they weren’t working hand in hand, they were often in close company. The most famous showdown in the Old West, the gunfight at the O.K. Corral, took place not at the corral but six doors down in front of the photography studio of Camillus Fly. He was too busy ducking to take a picture but ran out with a Henry rifle as the shots died away and disarmed Billy Clanton, one of the outlaws in a gang called — yes — the Cowboys.

headline: No Masks, Disinfectant or Soap. This Is Detention Amid a Pandemic.
abstract: Asylum seekers must be released before it is too late.
lead_paragraph: I am a translator and interpreter for asylum seekers held at the South Texas Family Residential Center in Dilley, Texas, and elsewhere in the country. I had never imagined that there could be more urgency around the work I do. The detainees I talk to are afraid of being deported, or being held indefinitely. Some are sick over being separated from their children, and unable to protect them from harm. Over the past few days, those concerns are increasingly being eclipsed by the fear of being infected with the coronavirus and dying alone in jail.

headline: Empty Hotels. Idled Tour Buses. The Pandemic Is Devastating Tourism.
abstract: Millions are losing their jobs and economies are suffering as once-bustling tourist sites give way to eerie emptiness. The Caribbean is suffering a particularly heavy blow.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — There were major hurricanes, and the global financial crisis of 2008. There was 9/11, and an array of regional health scares, from SARS to Zika.

headline: Inside Kim Kardashian’s Prison-Reform Machine
abstract: In two years, the reality TV star has become a force in criminal justice, all while continuing to sell body-sculpting undergarments and plugging diet products on Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Kim Kardashian West breezed into a steakhouse in Washington, D.C., last month, wearing a bright white outfit with a giant fabric flower on the lapel. Technically, it was a pantsuit, but tighter and more fabulous than its Beltway cousins.

headline: Ex-Wife Sick. Daughter Sick. 3 Friends Dead. Everyone Knows Someone.
abstract: The growing number of coronavirus cases and deaths have touched family and social circles across New York City, making the invisible threat seem far more real.
lead_paragraph: A New York City Housing Authority retiree ticked off his running tally: an ex-wife sick, a daughter sick, and three old friends dead. In Queens, a young poet learned a friend’s parents are in the hospital, one on a ventilator.

headline: When the Tokyo Olympics Went Missing
abstract: The 1940 Games, scheduled for Japan, were returned to the I.O.C. because of a war against China and political infighting, rather than a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The exhibits in the Japan Olympic Museum in central Tokyo, near the new $1.4 billion national stadium, are devoted primarily to the history of the Olympics and Japan’s participation, most notably in 1964, when Tokyo last hosted the Summer Games.

headline: Staying Sober During a Lockdown
abstract: Alcoholics Anonymous meetings have moved from musty church basements to laptop screens in quarantine. Do they still work?
lead_paragraph: In a Zoom meeting of Alcoholics Anonymous last week, a waifish figure with rheumy eyes assumed the center of the computer screen.

headline: Will We Lose a Generation of Designers?
abstract: Independent clothing designers are the essence of American fashion, but a stimulus plan may not save them.
lead_paragraph: You might not know Batsheva Hay, Christopher John Rogers and Carly Cushnie. They are emerging independent designers based in New York with relatively small namesake companies.

headline: Farmworkers, Mostly Undocumented, Become ‘Essential’ During Pandemic
abstract: Immigrant field workers have been told to keep working despite stay-at-home directives, and given letters attesting to their “critical” role in feeding the country.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Like legions of immigrant farmworkers, Nancy Silva for years has done the grueling work of picking fresh fruit that Americans savor, all the while afraid that one day she could lose her livelihood because she is in the country illegally.

headline: How Will Joe Biden Find His Joe Biden?
abstract: Joe Biden and his associates are consulting allies, Eric Holder and Barack Obama as he weighs his options — including a woman of color — for the Democratic candidate for vice president.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has spoken with former President Barack Obama about the process of selecting a running mate.

headline: 36 Hours in … Wherever You Are
abstract: Our first reader-generated itinerary: a weekend of traveling you can do from home.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has published its popular 36 Hours column for nearly 20 years, helping readers plan weekends in far-flung destinations all over the world.

headline: What New York Looked Like During the 1918 Flu Pandemic
abstract: The Spanish flu raced through crowded tenements and neighborhoods, killing more than 20,000 New Yorkers. But it could have been much worse.
lead_paragraph: The wire arrived in New York City from an incoming ship at sea, announcing that 10 of its passengers and 11 crew members were ill. So a team of doctors and officials waited at a Brooklyn pier to greet the Norwegian vessel Bergensfjord and, with it, the first cases in the city of the deadliest pandemic in modern human history.

headline: Why Are So Many More Men Dying from Coronavirus?
abstract: The disproportionate toll this virus is taking on males isn’t an anomaly. When it comes to survival, men are the weaker sex.
lead_paragraph: As coronavirus continues its spread across borders, oceans and continents, there is a perplexing piece of data that has so far evaded a proper explanation: It’s still early, but in almost every country that we have numbers for, more men than women are dying from the virus.

headline: City Is Short on Supplies as Death Toll Nears 1,400
abstract: The death toll in the city is nearing 1,400, and supplies are still badly needed.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Coronavirus, Jobs, Ellis Marsalis Jr.: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Pakistani Court Overturns Conviction in 2002 Killing of Daniel Pearl
abstract: The court found there was sufficient evidence to convict Ahmed Omar Sheikh of abducting Mr. Pearl, a Wall Street Journal reporter, but not of killing him.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani court on Thursday overturned the murder conviction and death sentence of Ahmed Omar Sheikh, a British-born militant who had been convicted of masterminding the 2002 abduction and killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, lawyers said.

headline: A Brooklyn Artist Adjusts to Making Art in Solitude
abstract: Lesley Dill usually works with six to eight assistants, but now she is alone with the hundreds of yards of fabric she uses for her mixed-media art.
lead_paragraph: Lesley Dill, a mixed-media artist who has had more than 100 solo exhibitions, works in a 300-square-foot studio in her apartment in an Art Deco tower in Downtown Brooklyn that she shares with her husband, Edward Robbins, a journalist and filmmaker.

headline: German Accent, Italian Flair: How Audi Taught Lamborghini Quality
abstract: Eye-popping prices and horsepower were matched with reliability after Audi stepped in to buy the maker of exotic sports cars. A ride in the Huracán erases all doubts.
lead_paragraph: Before Lamborghini was Lamborghini, before it made exotic cars with pulse-quickening engines and stratospheric price tags, and before it ever dreamed of building an S.U.V., its founder built much more down-to-earth vehicles: tractors.

headline: A Conversation With Dr. Anthony Fauci
abstract: “We are in a war. I mean, I actually think this is exactly what generals or leaders in real, you know, violent combat wars feel.”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: E.U. Court Rules 3 Countries Violated Deal on Refugee Quotas
abstract: Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic failed to live up to their end of an agreement to distribute 160,000 asylum seekers who had arrived in Greece and Italy, the court said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Court of Justice ruled on Thursday that Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic had violated their obligations by refusing to take in their fair share of asylum seekers at the height of the refugee crisis in 2015.

headline: Coronavirus Layoffs Are Hitting Start-Ups Hard
abstract: Job losses are steep in many corners of the corporate world, but they’ve pummeled start-ups — which are often pushed to grow fast or die — with particular ferocity.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: ‘The Other Lamb’ Review: Flock Therapy
abstract: A young woman begins to question the foundations of her religious sect in this visually stunning yet shallow feminist fable.
lead_paragraph: Photographed like a dream and experienced like a nightmare, the religious cult at the center of “The Other Lamb” looks idyllic on the outside, but, like the bird’s carcass stumbled upon by the film’s heroine, is teeming with maggots inside.

headline: ‘Coffee & Kareem’ Review: Good Cop, Kid Cop?
abstract: Or just a bad cop movie?
lead_paragraph: No one likes when their parent begins dating someone new, and Kareem Manning (Terrence Little Gardenhigh), the pint-size pseudo-policeman in the agonizingly humorless Netflix cop comedy “Coffee & Kareem,” is no exception. But his reaction to learning that his mother, Vanessa (Taraji P. Henson), is dating a loser cop (Ed Helms, who is also credited as a producer) — requesting that local drug dealers put a hit on his mom’s new boyfriend — might be considered fairly extreme. Now, that bumbling police officer, James Coffee, recently demoted to handling traffic after allowing a Detroit drug dealer (Ronreaco Lee) to get away during a sting operation, has to prove to Vanessa his worth both as a romantic partner and a possible father figure for her son. Additionally, Coffee must show that he’s more than a weak, poor, uncool white guy to the 12-year-old Kareem, who aspires to become a rapper and wears an outsized form of young braggadocio.

headline: ‘Clover’ Review: A Crime Goes Wrong, and You Can Guess the Rest
abstract: Every character in this comic thriller, from a cartoonish mob boss to two bumbling brothers, is familiar, and so are its bullet-ridden scenes.
lead_paragraph: Jon Abrahams’s comic thriller, “Clover,” strains for the mob intrigue of Martin Scorsese and the rapturous, bloody stylization of Quentin Tarantino. It’s chock-full of gore and expletive-laden banter, but lacks the key ingredients to make it worthy of its influences: original ideas and a strong script.

headline: ‘Almost Love’ Review: Schooled in Romance, but Missing Class
abstract: This ensemble comedy treats class solidarity as the love that dare not speak its name.
lead_paragraph: In the comedy “Almost Love,” romance springs from a love of one’s class. The movie follows a group of 30-something New Yorkers who support one another through various stages of relationships. Ensconced in their close-knit circle, they chatter, deeming which partners are perfect and which ones deserve the boot. But the one subject these chatty characters never touch is class, despite their obvious obsession with it.

headline: ‘Slay the Dragon’ Review: Vote Early, Vote Often. It Won’t Matter.
abstract: How lawmakers gerrymander districts to protect themselves from voters’ wrath — and what the legislative consequences are.
lead_paragraph: “Slay the Dragon” begins with a subject that might seem counterintuitive for a documentary on gerrymandering: the Flint, Mich., water crisis. The movie lays out a timeline of state legislative actions that led to the decision that contaminated the city’s water supply. It persuasively argues that the crisis never would have happened without gerrymandering, which had allowed legislators to shield themselves from voters’ wrath.

headline: On Politics: How Will the Economy Be Rebuilt?
abstract: Soaring unemployment and dreams of an infrastructure program: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump reading his notes at Wednesday’s coronavirus briefing at the White House.

headline: N.Y.C. Death Toll Tops 1,500 as Cuomo Warns on Ventilators
abstract: The governor said the state was using the machines for coronavirus patients at a rate that would exhaust its stockpile in just six days.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Friday’s live coverage.]

headline: Women Dominate Booker International Prize Shortlist
abstract: Yoko Ogawa of Japan and Fernanda Melchor of Mexico are among the authors in the running for the prestigious translated literature award.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For the second year running, most of the shortlisted novels for the International Booker Prize are by women. The contenders for the award, arguably the most significant prize for literature translated into English, were announced in London on Thursday.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘D.I.Y. Coronavirus Solutions Are Gaining Steam’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how from Ireland to Seattle, makers and engineers are creating open-source versions of much-needed medical equipment.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “D.I.Y. Coronavirus Solutions Are Gaining Steam”

headline: A Feature on Zoom Secretly Displayed Data From People’s LinkedIn Profiles
abstract: After an inquiry from Times reporters, Zoom said it would disable a data-mining feature that could be used to snoop on participants during meetings without their knowledge.
lead_paragraph: For Americans sheltering at home during the coronavirus pandemic, the Zoom videoconferencing platform has become a lifeline, enabling millions of people to easily keep in touch with family members, friends, students, teachers and work colleagues.

headline: A Widening Toll on Jobs: ‘This Thing Is Going to Come for Us All’
abstract: After the initial impact of shutdowns on a few industries, the coronavirus pandemic is leaving a much broader swath of unemployment.
lead_paragraph: A staggering 6.6 million people applied for unemployment benefits last week as the coronavirus outbreak ravaged nearly every corner of the American economy, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

headline: Florida, Finally
abstract: The state will go on lockdown, far too late.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Ships With Coronavirus-Stricken Passengers Dock in Florida
abstract: The Zaandam cruise ship and a second vessel, the Rotterdam, moored at a Fort Lauderdale port after a lengthy ordeal at sea. Ambulances were standing by to transport sick passengers.
lead_paragraph: KEY WEST, Fla. — The vacation the passengers had imagined, a luxurious two-week voyage along the coast of South America to the southernmost tip of the hemisphere, turned into something else entirely.

headline: My City Friends Want to Wait Out the Virus in My Suburban Home
abstract: How do I tell them no?
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, before Covid-19 exploded in New York, a close friend asked if she and her husband could leave Manhattan and stay with us at our home in Bergen County, N.J. It was a tough question to have asked of me, but I decided it was the right thing to do. I told my friend they could come. For other reasons, they didn’t. Now, she’s asked again. They’re really scared! I’m not sure what to do. My husband has asthma, they would have to share a bathroom with my cranky 19-year-old son, and I am helping my elderly mother who lives nearby (contact-free). Any advice?

headline: How Do Lower Mortgage Rates Affect Your Buying Power?
abstract: Low interest rates should bolster home sales, but other factors can get in the way, the coronavirus among them.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to contain the economic damage inflicted by the coronavirus pandemic, the Federal Reserve in March slashed interest rates by half a percentage point — its largest one-time cut since the 2008 financial crisis. In theory, that should encourage banks to offer lower mortgage rates and bring more expensive homes within reach of more buyers. But it doesn’t always work that way.

headline: The T List: Five things We Recommend This Week
abstract: A magazine in which art meets wrestling — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Amazon Pushes Into Making Video Games, Not Just Streaming Their Play
abstract: The internet giant is investing hundreds of millions of dollars in the effort, with its first original game, Crucible, to be released next month.
lead_paragraph: Opening a new front in the campaign to dominate digital entertainment, Amazon is investing hundreds of millions of dollars into becoming a leading creator and distributor of video games.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This weeks properties are on the Upper West Side, in Sunset Park, Brooklyn and in Riverdale, the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: This weeks properties are on the Upper West Side, in Sunset Park, Brooklyn and in Riverdale, the Bronx.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Sunset Park, on the Upper West Side, and in Riverdale.
