headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are in Montvale, N.J., and in Larchmont, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Montvale, N.J., and in Larchmont, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are in Montvale, N.J., and in Larchmont, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Unproven Stem Cell Therapy Gets OK for Testing in Coronavirus Patients
abstract: The treatment, which has been promoted by President Trump’s personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, will begin early-stage clinical trials.
lead_paragraph: An experimental stem cell therapy derived from human placentas will begin early testing in patients with the coronavirus, a New Jersey biotech company said Thursday.

headline: Teaching Your Kids to Be Safe Online: A Hasty Primer
abstract: The coronavirus has relaxed many parents’ stances on communication apps. Here are some ground rules.
lead_paragraph: If you had asked me two months ago how I felt about digital media as a parent, I would have had an answer ready: Our kids, I would have said, won’t own devices or touch social media until age 13. I probably would have launched into a tirade about how young brains can’t handle the complex rules of digital citizenship, after which you probably would have wanted to smack me with a smartphone.

headline: Under Modi, India’s Press Is Not So Free Anymore
abstract: India’s government has pressured advertisers and even shut down channels to shape the information that 1.3 billion Indians receive. It’s part of a wider assault on dissent.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Media One anchorman Vinesh Kunhiraman went on air as usual on March 6, ready to tell the station’s five million viewers in India’s Kerala State about the death anniversary of a beloved comedian and the latest news on the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Is Construction an ‘Essential Business’? in California?
abstract: Thursday: Cities are struggling with ways to keep workers safe as they build homes. Also: A child psychiatrist offers advice.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Cleaning Your Home: Good. Accidentally Poisoning Yourself: Bad.
abstract: Improper use of cleaning supplies at home can be dangerous to your health — even deadly.
lead_paragraph: As meticulously cleaning our homes becomes a national pastime, it’s important to remember that many of the cleaning agents we use can be hazardous when used incorrectly. Spraying yourself or others with Lysol, or mixing cleaning products together, are just two examples of the countless ways to use your cleaning supplies incorrectly — and dangerously. Here are some guidelines to help keep you and your family safe.

headline: David Tennant Craves Old English Dinners and Cigarettes After Sex
abstract: The band, that is. Tennant, whose mini-series “Deadwater Fell” arrives April 6, also puts Tim Minchin and “Succession” on his list of essentials.
lead_paragraph: Every so often a moody British thriller, set in an impossibly idyllic village harboring dark secrets, is anointed the new “Broadchurch.”

headline: Dancing With Myself: How Artists Stay in Shape Without a Stage
abstract: With the coronavirus pandemic putting live shows on hold, performers are adapting how they practice.
lead_paragraph: For most performing artists, the daily routine is roughly the same: rehearse, perform, rinse and repeat.

headline: Bucky Pizzarelli, Master of the Jazz Guitar, Is Dead at 94
abstract: He became a mainstay of the New York jazz scene, often performing with his celebrated son John. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Caesars in U.K. Is Fined for Allowing Problem Gamblers to Keep Betting
abstract: British authorities said the casino company failed to prevent money laundering and allowed people who had asked not to be served to lose tens of thousands of pounds.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s gambling authorities have ordered Caesars Entertainment to pay a record fine of $16 million for failing to prevent money laundering and for allowing people with gambling problems to lose huge amounts over repeated visits to its casinos.

headline: My Partner Works in an Amazon Warehouse. I’m Worried — and Proud.
abstract: Disrobing in the hallway, dodging hugs and fretting over our children’s safety. This is our family’s new normal.
lead_paragraph: “No, honey! You can’t hug Daddy yet!” I frantically tell my 5-year-old son, grabbing him just in time as he runs toward our front door to welcome his father home from work. “He has to wash the bad germs off first, OK?”

headline: Flight of the Influencers
abstract: Doctors warn that sharing decisions to leave metropolitan areas for smaller towns on social media might encourage followers to disregard public health guidelines.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus outbreak continues to spread across the United States, many influencers are using their platforms to educate their followers about symptoms and testing, and to encourage them to stay inside.

headline: Why Won’t My Building Tell Me if a Resident Has Coronavirus?
abstract: Some property owners and building managers are informing residents when a neighbor has tested positive. But they don’t have to.
lead_paragraph: Q: Last week, I received a notice from the managing agent of my Upper Manhattan co-op that a resident had tested positive for coronavirus. The management company would not disclose where in the building the resident lives, or if the person used any building amenities before testing positive. Then, today, we received an updated notice: Going forward, the managing agent will no longer inform us of reported cases in the building. Can they really keep this information from us?

headline: Teenagers in The Times: March 2020
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Here is the March edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.

headline: 13 Uplifting Documentaries on Netflix
abstract: Find stories of overlooked artists in the music industry, a Hollywood starlet who was also an inventor, athletes who summit a mountain and more.
lead_paragraph: Watching documentaries is an excellent way to stay informed about what’s really happening in the world: from unsolved murders to political corruption to quietly escalating global crises. But nonfiction films don’t have to be total bummers. For those Netflix subscribers who love docs — but who just can’t imagine sitting through something heavy right now — here’s a list of enlightening, entertaining and even uplifting documentaries, to brighten up your darker days.

headline: Engineer Crashes Train Near Hospital Ship in Los Angeles
abstract: No one was injured and the ship, sent to bolster the health care system during the coronavirus outbreak, was not damaged. The man told the authorities he had suspicions about the ship’s reason for docking.
lead_paragraph: The U.S.N.S. Mercy, a Navy hospital ship, arrived at the Port of Los Angeles on Friday to bolster a health care system that officials worry could be overwhelmed by a surge in coronavirus patients.

headline: How Far Should Police Go in Enforcing Coronavirus Lockdowns?
abstract: Around the world, police forces are testing how far to go in punishing ordinary behavior. But how should policing work when it’s not clear what is banned?
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — With much of the globe under stay-at-home orders, police officers are becoming the enforcers of a new coronavirus code that demands what humans naturally resist: complete isolation and obedience.

headline: ‘The Fields Heal Everyone’: Post-Soviet Leaders’ Coronavirus Denial
abstract: The heads of several former Soviet republics have persisted in playing down the severity of the coronavirus pandemic, with some also promoting unproven folk remedies.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The leaders of several former Soviet republics in Central Asia and elsewhere are still denying the severity of the coronavirus pandemic, weeks after most other governments abandoned that approach.

headline: Missing the Theater? Trade Playbills for These Novels
abstract: Two theater critics suggest some of their favorite books about the theater, giving us portals to a world that is now forbidden.
lead_paragraph: Theater, at its simplest, requires an actor and an audience. And in this strange moment, that’s a very tall order. Scripts are available, of course, and filmed performance, too. But if you are missing not only plays themselves, but the ephemera that surrounds them — the cramped seats and the rustling wrappers, the marquee lights and the scrum at the stage door — you might lose yourself in a novel of the theater, instead.

headline: Banks Warn of ‘Overwhelming’ Demand and Messy Start for Small Business Loans
abstract: The government has promised to lend $349 billion to small businesses starting Friday, but banks and owners have no idea how it will play out.
lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]

headline: Protect Your Home Against the Onslaught
abstract: With your family at home 24 hours a day, consider these tips to keep your appliances functioning, the mess to a minimum and the clutter at bay.
lead_paragraph: As millions of Americans hunker down at home for yet another week of social separation, a new reality is sinking in: All that bread baking and crafts translate to an overwhelming amount of wear and tear on our homes.

headline: How Jerome Powell’s Unconventional Career Path Prepared Him for This Crisis
abstract: His winding career path now seems to be a strength, not a weakness.
lead_paragraph: When Jerome H. Powell was nominated to lead the Federal Reserve in late 2017, there was some tut-tutting about his seemingly unusual background for the job.

headline: Democrats Postpone Convention, and a Test of Wills With Republicans Looms
abstract: The move is the biggest disruption to the political calendar so far because of the coronavirus, but could give Joe Biden, the likely presidential nominee, a lift heading into the fall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Democratic National Committee on Thursday postponed its presidential convention because of the coronavirus, moving it from mid-July to mid-August, and making it the largest political event to be upended by the public health crisis sweeping the country.

headline: Tom Brady Reportedly Moves Into Derek Jeter’s Tampa Estate
abstract: The home has seven bedrooms, nine bathrooms, two boat lifts and now six Super Bowl rings.
lead_paragraph: If you’re Tom Brady, you suddenly need a place to live in the Tampa area. And if you’re Tom Brady, a one-bedroom is probably not an option.

headline: Predictions for the Coronavirus Stock Market
abstract: A Nobel laureate is cautiously positive about the market for the long run but worries about how long that will need to be.
lead_paragraph: One prediction seems solid: The coronavirus epidemic will get much worse in the United States in coming weeks. But where the stock market is heading is much less certain.

headline: Touting Virus Cure, ‘Simple Country Doctor’ Becomes a Right-Wing Star
abstract: How Dr. Vladimir Zelenko’s claims for his coronavirus treatment spread from a New York village all the way to President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Last month, residents of Kiryas Joel, a New York village of 35,000 Hasidic Jews roughly an hour’s drive from Manhattan, began hearing about a promising treatment for the coronavirus that had been rippling through their community.

headline: How to Cook Root Vegetables? Roast and Pair With Chickpeas and Yogurt
abstract: Make a meal out of just about any root vegetable by rounding it out with a bit more protein and luscious creamy texture.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to my tried-and-true farm share, the root vegetables in my pantry have been piling up lately, threatening to overtake the pasta. So, I decided that now was a good time to roast some carrots and sweet potatoes for lunch, along with some canned chickpeas because they all go so well together. Hearty, comforting, easy — and very flavorful thanks to a creamy, garlicky, cumin-spiked yogurt — it was just what I needed to keep supplies in check.

headline: Scientists Find 2 Mating Flies Trapped in Prehistoric Amber
abstract: The discovery was part of a haul of unusual fossils recovered from sites across Australia and New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: Amber, or fossil tree resin, exists in rock layers all over the world. But for some reason, paleontologists never found much of it in Australia or New Zealand.

headline: Gerald Freedman, Prolific Stage Director, Dies at 92
abstract: Among his credits were musicals, operas and the original production of “Hair.” He influenced numerous actors’ careers as an educator.
lead_paragraph: Gerald Freedman, who directed countless plays, operas and musicals, including the original “Hair” in 1967 and more than a dozen Broadway productions, died on March 17 at his home in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 92.

headline: 3 Art Gallery Shows to Explore From Home
abstract: Galleries and museums are getting creative about presenting work online during the coronavirus crisis. Here are some shows worth viewing virtually.
lead_paragraph: I learned of the artist Ida Kohlmeyer (1912-97) primarily as a teacher at Newcomb College, the women’s college at Tulane University in New Orleans, from one of her former students, the Post-Minimalist shape-shifter Lynda Benglis. In the 1970s Kohlmeyer developed a style of multihued pictographs, usually organized on a grid. Pleasantly derivative, they suggested well-behaved Joan Snyder paintings. Kohlmeyer seemed to be a journeyman artist who kept up with the latest trends; had a good color sense and a solid touch; but who never put the pedal to the metal to find out what she could do that no other artist could.

headline: The Virus Comes for Democracy
abstract: Strongmen think they know the cure for Covid-19. Are they right?
lead_paragraph: China and some of its acolytes are pointing to Beijing’s success in coming to grips with the coronavirus pandemic as a strong case for authoritarian rule.

headline: Adam Schlesinger’s 30 Essential Songs
abstract: Hear tracks from Fountains of Wayne, “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend” and more — plus a tune written about the power-pop dynamo, who died of the coronavirus at 52.
lead_paragraph: The shelf life of a power-pop band is short. The Knack had an album and a half. Big Star had three. The Raspberries catalog could make for a fantastic first half of a CD.

headline: Nursing Home Linked to 37 Coronavirus Deaths Faces Fine of $600,000
abstract: Federal and Washington State officials found failures at Life Care Center of Kirkland during the coronavirus outbreak that spread through the facility.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A nursing home linked to dozens of coronavirus deaths in the Seattle area faces a fine of more than $600,000 and other sanctions after federal and state inspectors found a range of problems in how the facility handled the outbreak.

headline: Do Tea Drinkers Live Longer?
abstract: Each one-cup increase in daily tea consumption was tied to a 4 percent decrease of dying from cardiovascular disease.
lead_paragraph: Drinking tea may lower your risk of cardiovascular disease.

headline: Dr. John Murray, Pioneering Lung Expert, Dies at 92
abstract: Internationally recognized in pulmonology, he helped define acute respiratory distress syndrome, a condition that led to his death, attributed to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: April 2020
abstract: At least 350 pro-government forces and 66 civilians were killed in Afghanistan this month.
lead_paragraph: At least 88 pro-government forces and 16 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week. The deadliest attack took place in Badghis Province, where the Taliban attacked security outposts in Qala-e-Naw, the provincial capital, killing 13 local police officers and taking eight others prisoner. Local officials claimed that two Taliban fighters were also killed in the battle, and the insurgents captured one of the outposts and seized the weapons and equipment inside. In Samangan Province, the Taliban attacked the Pusqul area of Dara-e-Suf Bala District, killing nine pro-government militia members and wounding nine others before capturing the outpost and seizing the equipment.

headline: The Alternate Aesthetic Realities of ‘Tiger King’
abstract: The exotic-animal keepers of Netflix’s hit true-crime series seem to be remaking themselves in the image of their animal compatriots.
lead_paragraph: Of all the shocks in the new Netflix true-crime series “Tiger King: Murder, Mayhem and Madness” — and they are myriad — few are more singular, more head-tiltingly odd than the scenes in which the show’s protagonists, particularly the sideshow zoo captain Joe Exotic, interact with animals.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Bus Ridership in Metropolitan Areas
abstract: Where did the bus riders go?
lead_paragraph: The interactive graph above, showing the bus ridership among the 15 largest transit agencies for 2011 to 2020, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. The graph below shows bus ridership for four additional cities.

headline: President’s Campaign Calls Sessions ‘Delusional’ for Tying Himself to Trump
abstract: In an unusual letter, President Trump’s campaign said that Jeff Sessions, who is running to reclaim his Senate seat in Alabama, was misleading the public.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s campaign is demanding that Jeff Sessions, the former Attorney General, stop attaching himself to the president in his effort to win back his old Senate seat in Alabama, after Mr. Sessions distributed a campaign mailer that mentioned the president 22 times.

headline: When Reality Is Scary Enough, These Movies Are Safe Nightmares
abstract: Films like “Contagion” feel a little too real these days. So we’re looking at movies guaranteed to be too far-fetched to ever come true. (Let’s hope.)
lead_paragraph: It may sound counterintuitive, but watching horror films isn’t just about feeling scared. It’s also about feeling safe. Scary movies assure our brains that the terror is happening there, not here. They’re chilling security blankets.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The new normal still doesn’t feel normal, exactly. But judging from conversations with friends and family, a lot of us are starting to settle into some kind of routine. If yours includes reading — and I hope it does — might we suggest these recent books?

headline: Coronavirus Coping: Novak Djokovic Is Playing Tennis With Frying Pans
abstract: Promotion and relegation concerns abound as soccer and rugby leagues consider canceling. In better news, Enes Kanter is cooking up a storm.
lead_paragraph: As cancellations reach deeper into the summer, it is becoming clearer that some sports leagues will never finish their seasons. That leaves the thorny question of how to resolve those competitions.

headline: F.D.A. Relaxes Blood Donation Guidelines for Gay Men and Others
abstract: The agency reduced its recommended deferral period for male donors who have had sex with another man to three months, down from one year.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Thursday that it was significantly loosening its recommendations for blood donations from gay and bisexual men, reducing the amount of time men who have had sex with men should wait before they give blood to three months from one year in hopes of ameliorating a drastic drop in supply during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A Stay-at-Home Whiskey Project: The Infinity Bottle
abstract: Enthusiasts around the world post their personal blends of various whiskeys to social media under the hashtag “infinitybottle.”
lead_paragraph: Josh Peters had been doing it for years, but didn’t know it had a name. Whenever one of his bottles of whiskey dwindled to its last ounce or two, he would pour it into another bottle that held the remains of other whiskeys.

headline: When Silly Start-Ups Falter, We All Lose
abstract: The pandemic is devastating start-ups. This matters in ways we can’t always see.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Coronavirus Advice: Wear a Mask. Here’s How.
abstract: Two psychiatrists urge the public to overcome any hesitation, and a surgeon gives advice on how to wear a mask. Other readers offer a D.I.Y. tip and a historical note.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Students Are Saying About Public Preschool, Staying Healthy and Being Trapped Inside
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers if they thought public preschool should be a right, what they are doing to stay healthy and sane during the pandemic, and to share stories, poems and memoirs about being trapped inside.

headline: Never Given a Close Look to Hitchcock? Start Here
abstract: “Rope” is mostly known for appearing as if it were a single take, but in fact it’s an absorbing thriller that will help you appreciate the master.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Hitchcock may seem like an odd choice for this column, which purports to recommend entry points for movie genres you don’t get or directors who seem difficult. Hitchcock, by contrast, could easily be considered the most famous director who ever lived. His run from 1958 to 1963 alone — “Vertigo,” “North by Northwest,” “Psycho,” “The Birds” — consists exclusively of films that almost everyone knows.

headline: Review: In Apple’s ‘Home Before Dark,’ a True Cub Reporter
abstract: Brooklynn Prince of “The Florida Project” plays a crusading journalist who happens to be 9 years old in a family drama based on a real-life story of precociousness.
lead_paragraph: “Home Before Dark,” the latest series from Apple TV Plus, belongs to a small and specific group: shows that are worth watching because of a child actor.

headline: Five Swipes on Exercising Outdoors
abstract: How safe is it to exercise outdoors during the coronavirus outbreak? We asked the experts.
lead_paragraph: How safe is it to exercise outdoors during the coronavirus outbreak? We asked the experts.

headline: No Live Sports on TV? Consumers Want a Refund
abstract: Some providers break out sports fees on bills. With seasons on pause because of the coronavirus, it’s another reminder to customers of what they’re paying for but not getting.
lead_paragraph: Joyce Sanz recently called Comcast hoping to reduce the $164 each month her family pays for cable television and internet. An after-school program manager at an elementary school in Miami, Sanz wanted to trim expenses in case the economic fallout related to the coronavirus pandemic lasts months.

headline: ‘I’m Scared’: Wisconsin Election Puts Poll Workers at Risk of Virus
abstract: The state plans to hold its elections on Tuesday, thrusting thousands of clerks and poll workers, many of them older or with health conditions, onto the pandemic’s front lines.
lead_paragraph: Angie Copas has high blood pressure and asthma, and her job as clerk for the village of Mattoon, Wis., does not provide health insurance. For weeks, voters have streamed into her office to request or cast absentee ballots, and she has no protective equipment, sanitizer or disinfectant wipes.

headline: U.N. Security Council ‘Missing In Action’ in Coronavirus Fight
abstract: The leader of the U.N. has called the pandemic the biggest international threat in the 75-year history of the organization, but its most powerful body has yet to take action.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the United Nations has called the coronavirus pandemic the most challenging crisis since the organization’s founding after World War II. But the Security Council, its most powerful arm, has been conspicuously silent.

headline: Viewing Party! Let’s All Watch ‘His Girl Friday’ Together
abstract: Hello, Hildy! Hello, Walter. Hello, Viewing Party friends!
lead_paragraph: Hello, fellow film lovers!

headline: Trying to Teach During the Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: Let us know how the change to online instruction has affected you and your students.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus crisis is altering life as we know it, and forcing teachers across the country (and around the world) to move to online instruction.

headline: Delicious Vinyl
abstract: We examine when culture from our past — like the 20-year-old comedy “High Fidelity,” — gets reborn … as “High Fidelity.”
lead_paragraph: Not all reboots deserve to exist. Lots of them aren’t even things we want.

headline: Trump’s Company Seeks to Ease Financial Crunch as Coronavirus Takes Toll
abstract: As companies nationwide look for relief, the Trump Organization has talked with Deutsche Bank and a Florida county about delaying payments on some loans and other obligations.
lead_paragraph: All over the country, businesses large and small are seeking breathing room from their lenders, landlords and business partners as they face the financial fallout from the coronavirus crisis.

headline: Life as a College Student During the Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: Let us know how the change to online instruction has affected you.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus crisis is altering life as we know it, and forcing colleges and universities across the country (and around the world) to move to online-only instruction.

headline: How to Keep Ourselves Safe in Public Spaces
abstract: Readers suggest precautions for use of elevators and supermarkets to minimize the risks of exposure.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: F.D.A. Approves First Coronavirus Antibody Test in U.S.
abstract: Such a test may help scientists learn how widespread the infection is, and how long people remain immune after recovering.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved a new test for coronavirus antibodies, the first for use in the United States.

headline: Wearing Masks Must Be a National Policy
abstract: Even homemade face coverings provide some protection, especially when many people who have the coronavirus show no symptoms.
lead_paragraph: The most important new policy the government can implement to contain the spread of Covid-19 is to immediately recommend that everyone wear masks or face-coverings in public — #masksforall.

headline: The Surprising Intimacy of the Live-Streamed Funeral
abstract: Because of the coronavirus, memorial services are moving online, where mourners find that collective grief is still possible.
lead_paragraph: When Candida Rifkind got the call on March 14 that her Aunt Cecilia had died, she realized she couldn’t attend the funeral. The rapid spread of the coronavirus was making international travel more uncertain than ever. Just a day earlier, the United States had blocked most European visitors from entering its borders. Ms. Rifkind, an English professor who lives in Winnipeg, Manitoba, didn’t want to risk it. (Canada and the United States closed their borders to each other the next week.)

headline: Messages From Quarantine
abstract: In the age of coronavirus, the only way you can see Milan is to fly through it.
lead_paragraph: In the age of coronavirus, the only way you can see Milan is to fly through it.

headline: The Only Way You Can See Milan Is to Fly Through It
abstract: Here’s what it’s like in a coronavirus red zone.
lead_paragraph: How do you safely document a country that’s entirely under lockdown? Last week, these Milanese filmmakers found a way. The short documentary above was shot with a drone flown through the shuttered neighborhoods of Milan — capturing life unfolding from windows, balconies and roofs. While confined to their homes, quarantined residents shared their evolving hopes and fears over WhatsApp audio messages. The result is an elusive chronicle of an epicenter of the global coronavirus pandemic — one that in many ways has foretold the future for other countries navigating this new reality around the world.

headline: There’s a Pandemic. Is This a Time for Tommy John Surgery?
abstract: Decisions to schedule operations for pitchers like Noah Syndergaard of the Mets and Chris Sale of the Red Sox have caused debate.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you work for a Major League Baseball team and your star pitcher has a torn ulnar collateral ligament, the kind of elbow injury requiring Tommy John surgery. It will be at least 12 to 18 months before he pitches again, and the longer he pushes off the operation, the longer you will be without him.

headline: Detroit Is Mourning
abstract: With a spike in coronavirus cases, many of us are left wondering why.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Dwight Jones, my high school basketball coach, died on Monday from the coronavirus. He had devoted 50 years of his life to helping young men and women, using his quick wit to get his point across.

headline: Religious Exemption From Florida’s Stay-at-Home Order
abstract: A reader criticizes Gov. Ron DeSantis. Also: The shortage of ventilators; preparing for death.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Contribute to Our Coronavirus Reporting
abstract: Do you have information that could help our reporters, or a story to share?
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic is an unprecedented event in modern history. That's why our reporters and editors want to hear about your experiences. Right now, we’re looking for stories related to several specific topics listed below. We also welcome you to join our ongoing reporting efforts for future stories on other topics.

headline: Film Club: ‘‘It’s a Pretty Big Bummer’: Olympic Dreams on Hold’
abstract: How do you deal with the disappointment of a dream postponed?
lead_paragraph: “‘It’s a Pretty Big Bummer’: Olympic Dreams on Hold” is a five-minute film that touches on themes of hopes and dreams, disappointment and resiliency. The Times asked Olympic and Paralympic athletes from around the world to make videos about the postponed Summer Games, and what life is like stuck at home. Here’s what they told us.

headline: Things to Do in N.Y.C. This Weekend While Staying Inside
abstract: A weekly guide to maintaining a social life while social distancing.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks into life under mandated social distancing, New Yorkers have been adjusting to this new reality by moving their social lives online.

headline: How Are You Observing Passover During the Coronavirus Outbreak?
abstract: We would like to hear how you are adapting your plans for Passover during a time when families and communities are usually together.
lead_paragraph: [Updated: Thank you for your submissions. You can read a selection of them here.]

headline: The World’s Great Photographers, Many Stuck Inside, Have Snapped
abstract: Stephen Shore, Catherine Opie, Todd Hido and others have turned to Instagram to cure ‘corona claustrophobia’ or show how life has changed. They talk about their quarantine pics.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the good news: You now have a sharper camera in your pocket than professional photographers could dream of 30 years ago. Here’s the bad news: You can only shoot from your apartment.

headline: Turning the Tables, Russia Sends Virus Aid to U.S.
abstract: A planeload of coronavirus aid to New York was a propaganda coup for the Kremlin — tempered by an intensifying epidemic at home.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In the early 1990s, amid the poverty-ridden collapse of the Soviet Union, American food aid in the form of a flood of cheap chicken thighs — Russians called them “Bush legs” — symbolized the humiliating downfall of a superpower.

headline: What Pregnant Women Should Know About Coronavirus
abstract: The risks, so far, seem no greater than for anyone else, but the research is thin and only applies to later stage of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: [This article is part of the developing coronavirus coverage, and was updated on March 26. Go here for the latest on the coronavirus.]

headline: Music, Theater and More to Experience at Home This Weekend
abstract: Our writers offer suggestions for what to watch, read or listen to while we’re housebound.
lead_paragraph: Karlheinz Stockhausen’s experimental seven-opera cycle, known collectively as “Licht” (“Light”), had a big year in 2019: The Holland Festival presented excerpts from each opera; the French company Le Balcon performed the entire second entry, “Samstag aus Licht” (“Saturday From Light”), which depicts the death and resurrection of Stockhausen’s Lucifer character. That production is now viewable at the Philharmonie de Paris’s website.

headline: Essential Drug Supplies for Virus Patients Are Running Low
abstract: Medicines to alleviate breathing difficulty, relieve pain and sedate coronavirus patients are in very high demand, depleting stock around the country.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, as hospitals confront a harrowing surge in coronavirus cases, they are also beginning to report shortages of critical medications — especially those desperately needed to ease the disease’s assault on patients’ respiratory systems.

headline: As the Coronavirus Rages, Birthday Parties Celebrate Life in Isolation
abstract: Drive-by parties, cakes left on porches and toasts raised on Zoom: Birthdays are both joyful and poignant as many look for ways to celebrate while social distancing.
lead_paragraph: It was just before 8 a.m. on March 19 when Alexondra Purnomo, a schoolteacher in Rome, decided that all rules were off. She was under coronavirus lockdown, but it was her birthday.

headline: Your Nose Itches. Is It Allergies, Flu or the Coronavirus?
abstract: Seasonal allergy symptoms differ from those caused by viral infections like influenza or the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has made a free e-book with answers your coronavirus questions. It features more than two dozen chapters on how you can reduce your risk, what you can do to protect others, what scientists have learned, what to do if you’re worried about the stock market and more. You can download it on Apple Books and elsewhere. Below is an excerpt.

headline: C.I.A. Hunts for Authentic Virus Totals in China, Dismissing Government Tallies
abstract: Intelligence officials have told the White House for weeks that China has vastly understated the spread of the coronavirus and the damage the pandemic has done.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. has been warning the White House since at least early February that China has vastly understated its coronavirus infections and that its count could not be relied upon as the United States compiles predictive models to fight the virus, according to current and former intelligence officials.

headline: Kushner Puts Himself in Middle of White House’s Chaotic Coronavirus Response
abstract: President Trump’s son-in-law has become a central player in the administration’s effort to curb the pandemic. But critics say he is part of the problem.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Peter T. Gaynor, the federal government’s top emergency manager, was about to go on television last week to announce that he would use wartime production powers to ensure the manufacture of about 60,000 desperately needed coronavirus test kits.

headline: Labor Fight Collides With the Pandemic at Trader Joe’s
abstract: The chain has aggressively opposed unionization efforts among its employees, who have been critical of its response to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: On March 23, as the coronavirus pandemic put grocery workers on the front lines of a public health crisis, Trader Joe’s sent a memo to store managers encouraging them to relay a message to employees: Joining a union might be a bad idea.

headline: Wine Deliveries: What Are the Options?
abstract: Under Covid-19 protocols, where can you look now for alcoholic beverages? It depends on how fast you need them and how selective a consumer you are.
lead_paragraph: Since most of the nation began living in coronavirus quarantine, retail wine sales have shot up. In the latest data available, wine sales in dollars were up 66 percent in the week ending March 21, from the same week a year ago, according to Nielsen.

headline: Fear of Rejection Is Costing You Money
abstract: And what to do if you want to see long-term financial gains.
lead_paragraph: Rejection is an experience I’m quite familiar with. As a freelance writer, sending pitches and being told “no” — if I’m lucky enough to get a response at all — is part of my daily routine. This past holiday season, I received one rejection the day after Christmas and two more the day after New Year’s Day. Happy holidays to me, right?

headline: As Tekashi69 Is Released, Inmates Fearing Coronavirus Ask, ‘Why Not Me?’
abstract: The rapper will serve the final four months of his two-year term in home confinement. High-profile inmates like Bill Cosby and R. Kelly are arguing for home confinement too, so far without success.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Tekashi69 walked out of a federal prison on Thursday, four months short of his two-year term, thanks to a nationwide effort to stem coronavirus outbreak risks at jails and prisons, which health advocates fear might become a tinder box for infections.

headline: Coronavirus, Global Tourism, India’s Free Press: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: In Australia, the authorities have threatened people sitting alone drinking coffee with six months of jail; in the Philippines, President Rodrigo Duterte ordered the police to shoot anyone who “causes commotion” after protesters demanded food.

headline: One Hospital’s Last Resort to Protect Doctors: Yankee Rain Ponchos
abstract: The hospital, in the Bronx, said the ponchos were intended as a gift to weary workers, but several staffers said they were told to use them as protective equipment.
lead_paragraph: When a doctor at one of New York City’s top hospitals arrived for work on Tuesday night, she found the following items in the bag of protective equipment that she received: a mask, an eye shield — and, in place of the usual medical gown, a plastic white-and-navy New York Yankees poncho, the kind available for purchase on rainy game days.

headline: New York’s New Soup Kitchen Has an Upscale Address: Eleven Madison Park
abstract: A group called Rethink has teamed up with the Michelin-starred restaurant to feed New Yorkers in need.
lead_paragraph: In the days before New Yorkers stayed home and people still touched their faces without dread, Matt Jozwiak was preparing to help.

headline: Navy Removes Captain of Aircraft Carrier Stricken by Coronavirus
abstract: In a letter that leaked to the news media, the captain described what he said were the Navy’s failures to provide the resources to combat the virus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Navy removed the captain of the stricken aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt on Thursday, only days after he implored his superior officers for more help as a coronavirus outbreak spread aboard the ship.

headline: Pape Diouf, Former President of Marseille Soccer Club, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Diouf, who died of the coronavirus, was the first black president of Marseille, a notoriously difficult club to run. He was also a gifted orator and a defender of the club’s passionate fan base.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Peter Gatien, the ’90s ‘Club King,’ Wants His Final Say
abstract: The Limelight and Tunnel are long gone. But the story of their vilified owner is still being written.
lead_paragraph: “Thoughts flash in your mind of incredible nights here, whether it was Jay-Z, or Junior Vasquez, or the thousands of people inside and outside, waiting in line,” said Peter Gatien, the nightclub impresario who lorded over the 1990s club scene in New York City.

headline: Arianne Caoili, Chess Master, Is Dead at 33
abstract: A former model, she stood out in the chess world for her glamour in what is often thought of as an unglamorous game.
lead_paragraph: Arianne Caoili, a chess master and a prominent figure both in the chess world and in Armenia, where she lived, died on Monday in Yerevan, the country’s capital. She was 33.

headline: DeVos Weighs Waivers for Special Education. Parents Are Worried.
abstract: The $2 trillion coronavirus law could give the education secretary the power to waive special education rules as school districts struggle to teach all their students online.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tucked away in the $2 trillion coronavirus stabilization bill is a provision that allows Education Secretary Betsy DeVos to seek congressional approval to waive parts of the federal special education law while schools combat the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Ailing N.R.A. Finds New Rallying Cry: Keep Gun Shops Open
abstract: Amid the coronavirus pandemic, the group has retooled its message and sued New York State to keep gun stores open.
lead_paragraph: Faced with budget pressures and an invigorated gun control movement, the National Rifle Association has found a new cause amid the pandemic — fighting to keep gun stores open as its fund-raising appeals depict the government’s coronavirus response as a threat to Second Amendment rights.

headline: 15 Wines Under $15: Inexpensive Bottles for Stay-at-Home Drinking
abstract: These intriguing wines are sometimes quirky and often unusual. All are delightful, whether with a meal tonight or as gifts to those who could use one.
lead_paragraph: Where I live in Manhattan, wine retailers appear to be experiencing a sales boom, even though many shops are in delivery- or pickup-only mode.

headline: Love ‘Tiger King’? You’ll Love These Books, Too
abstract: Dip into a bizarre true-crime chronicle or a novel that evokes the campy, oddball world of the Netflix documentary series.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve finished tearing through all seven episodes of the hit show “Tiger King” and you’re looking for more, we’ve got some reading suggestions.

headline: How to Take Care of Your Hair at Home
abstract: Professional advice on maintenance — and Zoom-friendly styling — for when you can’t get to a salon.
lead_paragraph: Because of stay-at-home orders and the closure of those businesses deemed nonessential, most, if not all of us, are unlikely to see the inside of a hair salon in the near future, which means taking matters into our own hands. But this period can be used to repair heat-damaged tresses, learn styling techniques and establish better habits for the future. Below, tips on how to handle haircuts (spoiler: don’t do it) and maintain color at home.

headline: After Lost Months, Britain Vows to Catch Up on Virus Testing
abstract: The health secretary, who just emerged from isolation after contracting the coronavirus, vowed that Britain would conduct 100,000 tests a day by the end of April, a tenfold increase.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Prime Minister Boris Johnson spoke to the British people from isolation on Wednesday, still suffering his own bout of the coronavirus, he said the key to overcoming the pandemic was more testing. “This is how we will unlock the coronavirus puzzle,” he said in a shaky, hand-held video.

headline: From Afar, Congress Moves to Oversee Trump Coronavirus Response
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced she would move to form a special committee to scrutinize the Trump administration’s response, including how more than $2 trillion in federal relief money is being spent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi, moving aggressively to scrutinize the Trump administration’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic, said Thursday that she would seek to create a special bipartisan committee to oversee all aspects of the government’s response, including how it distributes more than $2 trillion in emergency aid.

headline: The Covid-19 Slump Has Arrived
abstract: But we’re already botching the response.
lead_paragraph: Over a normal two-week period we’d expect around half a million U.S. workers to file claims for unemployment insurance. Over the past two weeks we’ve seen almost 10 million filings. We’re facing an incredible economic catastrophe.

headline: Mental Health in the Age of the Coronavirus
abstract: The struggle between fear and comfort.
lead_paragraph: Would you do us a favor? Would you be willing to describe how the coronavirus is affecting your mental health? Is the combination of isolation and existential stress making you feel more depressed and anxious? Or is the family togetherness and the pause from normal life giving you a greater sense of belonging and equilibrium? How would you describe your psychological state? What are you doing to cope? If you’re a mental health worker, what are you seeing out there?

headline: Skull Fossils in Cave Show Mix of Human Relatives Roamed South Africa
abstract: The excavation found the oldest known Homo erectus, a direct ancestor of our species, living around the same time as other extinct hominins.
lead_paragraph: Nestled in South Africa’s Cradle of Humankind, the Drimolen paleocave is an amphitheater hosting the remains of ancient ancestors of humans. Most famous among the hominins found there are Orpheus and Eurydice, a pair of Paranthropus robustus unearthed in 1994 and named after the lovers from Greek mythology. They are just two of more than 160 fossilized specimens of our extinct early relatives dug up at the roofless cave.

headline: How to Cook a Coronavirus
abstract: New York Times Food editors and writers share their ideas for getting by and finding joy through food during hard times.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: 7 Ways to Explore the Math of the Coronavirus Using The New York Times
abstract: Graphs and data are everywhere as we try to better understand this pandemic and all its related health, economic and social consequences.
lead_paragraph: The daily news of the coronavirus is filled with mathematics: rates and data, charts and graphs, projections and probabilities. Mathematical and statistical literacy are fundamental to understanding our current crisis. Here are seven ways students and teachers can use New York Times resources to engage with the mathematics of the Covid-19 pandemic.

headline: Trump Administration Officials Weigh How Far to Go on Recommending Masks
abstract: The expected change in position reflects concern over a worrisome rate of infection spread by people with no symptoms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is close to  recommending that all Americans wear cloth masks if they go out in public, a change in position that reflects new concerns that the coronavirus is being spread by infected people who have no symptoms and new data suggesting the United States is not yet slowing the rate of infections.

headline: The Other Front-Line Workers
abstract: Ezzie Dominguez worked as a nanny in Denver. With that job gone, she’s cleaning hospitals at night.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Employers in the U.S. are laying off workers at an unheard-of rate as the outbreak plunges the economy into a deep freeze.
lead_paragraph: U.S. employers are laying off workers at an unheard-of clip as the coronavirus outbreak plunges the economy into a deep freeze. Some 6.6 million people filed new unemployment insurance claims last week — nearly 20 times a typical week’s tally.

headline: What If We Have to Decide Who Gets a Ventilator?
abstract: Thinking about the choices we could have to make as we treat patients with the coronavirus breaks my heart.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — I was not sure what to say.

headline: There’s Only One Thing Stopping Trump From Deporting Health Care Workers
abstract: If the Supreme Court affirms the administration’s termination of DACA, thousands of vital health care workers could be deported.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on the Supreme Court’s decision on President Trump and DACA.]

abstract: Check out a very adult cartoon and a strangely prescient episode of “High Maintenance,” or dig into a bona fide classic.
lead_paragraph: Want more recommendations on what to watch? Sign up for our Watching newsletter to have them delivered straight to your inbox.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to Plotting to Attack White House With Anti-Tank Missile
abstract: Hasher Jallal Taheb, 23, also targeted the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument, the Lincoln Memorial and a synagogue, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia man who sought to obtain an anti-tank missile pleaded guilty this week to plotting terrorist attacks on the White House, the Statue of Liberty and other landmarks, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Trump Administration Scales Back Paid Leave in Coronavirus Relief Law
abstract: In new guidance, the Labor Department effectively exempted many small businesses from a new requirement to provide paid leave to employees affected by the crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has substantially scaled back paid leave requirements for employers that were created by a new coronavirus relief law, effectively exempting many small businesses in a move that infuriated lawmakers who had fought to expand the benefit.

headline: The 1,000-Bed Comfort Was Supposed to Aid New York. It Has 20 Patients.
abstract: “It’s a joke,” said a top hospital executive, whose facilities are packed with coronavirus patients.
lead_paragraph: Such were the expectations for the Navy hospital ship U.S.N.S. Comfort that when it chugged into New York Harbor this week, throngs of people, momentarily forgetting the strictures of social distancing, crammed together along Manhattan’s west side to catch a glimpse.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in April
abstract: Our picks for April, including ‘Community,’ ‘Extraction,’ and ‘Never Have I Ever’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for April.

headline: Putting Jared Kushner In Charge Is Utter Madness
abstract: Trump’s son-in-law has no business running the coronavirus response.

headline: Trump Promotes Oil Deal That May Not Exist
abstract: The president’s optimism for a deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia to reduce production and a Saudi call for talks send crude prices skyrocketing, but Moscow showed little enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When oil prices crashed in early March after a dispute between Russia and Saudi Arabia, President Trump put a positive spin on the news. “Good for the consumer, gasoline prices coming down!” he wrote on Twitter as markets tumbled. On Tuesday, Mr. Trump said that falling gasoline prices amounted to “the greatest tax cut we’ve ever given.”

headline: ‘We Can’t Spend What We Don’t Have’: Virus Strikes N.Y. Budget
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the Legislature agreed to a $177 billion budget that also included another change to the state’s bail laws.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — With the coronavirus outbreak racing through the state, sickening thousands of New Yorkers each day and draining the state economy, the Legislature on Friday was forced to pass a $177 billion budget that was laden with uncertainties.

headline: We Get, and Give, Lots of Bad Advice. Here’s How to Stop.
abstract: One of the most effective ways to get better advice is to give it.
lead_paragraph: When we turn to others for advice on major career decisions, they sometimes steer us in the wrong direction. Warren Buffett’s father, along with his mentor, discouraged him from entering the securities business. Walt Disney’s brother and wife both tried to talk him out of making “Snow White.” And last summer, when I polled my Twitter followers about the worst career advice they had received, Monica Lewinsky’s response went viral. She had been told that “an internship at the white house will be amazing on your resume.”

headline: What Might End a Wrestling Match
abstract: Joe Deeney throws us a curveball.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Wait, what day is it? It’s becoming harder to keep track since I’ve been working from home. But we have a theme on … it’s Friday, right?

headline: How Australians Seek Connection in Isolation
abstract: From virtual birthday parties to distanced neighborhood listening sessions, people are finding new ways to be together while alone.
lead_paragraph: Every couple of days for the past few weeks, I have clambered onto my roof from the small patio on our second floor. I hoist up a pillow, our pet parrot Chobi in his cage, and a couple of beers or a glass of wine. Then I peer over the lip of the roof, and into the backyard of the house across the alleyway, where a friendly face is waiting.

headline: A Hoarder’s Huge Stockpile of Masks and Gloves Will Now Go to Doctors and Nurses, F.B.I. Says
abstract: The stockpile, slated for medical personnel in New York and New Jersey, includes 192,000 N95 respirators, 130,000 surgical masks and nearly 600,000 medical-grade gloves, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a million medical-grade masks and gloves that were seized this week from a Brooklyn man who was charged with lying to federal agents about price-gouging will go to medical workers in New York and New Jersey, the authorities said Thursday.

headline: Ken Shimura, Comedian Whose Sketches Delighted Japan, Dies at 70
abstract: His slapstick humor, physical comedy and naïve persona made him a household name in the country for decades.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Corrections: April 3, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 3, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the spread of coronavirus through asymptomatic cases misstated the location of a choir that developed many cases of coronavirus infection. It was in Mount Vernon, Wash., north of Seattle, not in Seattle. The article also provided an imprecise distinction for the new coronavirus. Its covert spread set off a pandemic in ways other coronaviruses did not; it was not the first virus other than influenza to cause a pandemic. And because of an editing error, it misstated the day of an interview with Dr. Robert Redfield of the C.D.C. The interview occurred on Monday, not Tuesday.

headline: Quote of the Day: Unrivaled Job Losses Accelerate Across U.S.
abstract: Quote of the Day for Friday, April 3, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “In a moment, I became both jobless and homeless.”

headline: Relationships Move Fast on a Slow Cargo Ship
abstract: For our 10th date, we crossed the ocean on a freighter. Turns out isolation can have surprising benefits for new love. (You can’t walk away.)
lead_paragraph: Liz and I were on a cargo ship in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean with the sun setting and a light wind. The scene resembled one of those retirement brochures in which a couple stares wistfully across the open sea and into their future — except she and I barely knew each other. It was our 10th date.

headline: C.D.C. Recommends Wearing Masks in Public; Trump Says, ‘I’m Choosing Not to Do It’

headline: To Safeguard Its Future, Tennis Seeks Unity. Even With the French Open.
abstract: As play is delayed to at least mid-July, small tournaments and many players are at risk of significant financial losses, and the French Open’s unilateral rescheduling has added to the chaos.
lead_paragraph: With tennis shut down amid the coronavirus pandemic, the game is still playing for its future as Roger Federer practices trick shots in the snow against a wall at home in Switzerland.

headline: They’re Keeping The Times Humming, From Home
abstract: Developers, technicians, systems analysts and many other employees are working remotely to maintain the flow of information to readers.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Invisible Life’ and ‘Home Before Dark’
abstract: An acclaimed Brazilian drama hits Amazon. And a new family series debuts on Apple TV Plus.
lead_paragraph: INVISIBLE LIFE (2019) Stream on Amazon. Two inseparable sisters are torn apart in “Invisible Life,” a drama from the Brazilian director Karim Aïnouz. Based on a popular novel by Martha Batalha and set in early 1950s Rio de Janeiro, the film begins by introducing the siblings, their tight relationship and their differing desires. Guida (Julia Stockler) has fallen for a Greek sailor; Eurídice (Carol Duarte) wants to pursue a career as a pianist. Then Guida elopes, Eurídice is pushed to marry and it becomes unclear whether the sisters will ever see each other again. That separation is largely due to their father, who lies to keep them apart. The film won the Un Certain Regard award at the Cannes Film Festival last year, and has done well with critics. In his review for The New York Times, Glenn Kenny called it “a modern melodrama that’s proud to be one,” adding that the film’s “mix of vivid period detail and raw frankness about sexuality and poverty and women’s oppression is heady and bracing; its depiction of female friendship and love is pointedly ferocious.”

headline: For This N.B.A. Rookie, Reality TV Is an Escape That Feels Like Home
abstract: Rui Hachimura, a Washington Wizards forward, has found comfort and meaning in the hit Japanese reality show “Terrace House.”
lead_paragraph: Long before he began feeding his obsession and even found himself sitting next to its hosts, Rui Hachimura didn’t understand all the fuss about the Japanese reality television show “Terrace House.” His high school teammates in Japan had tried hard to get him on board.

headline: Home Cooking
abstract: Have you become a social distancing chef?
lead_paragraph: Thanks to recent world events, many of us are spending a lot more time indoors with family. And some are falling back on a surefire method of bonding: cooking and eating together.

headline: Virus’s Toll on N.Y. Police: 1 in 6 Officers Is Out Sick
abstract: “It’s a worst-case scenario across the board,” one sergeant said. The virus has strained the Police Department even as it has been asked to help enforce rules to slow its spread.
lead_paragraph: One out of every six New York City police officers is out sick or in quarantine. A veteran detective and seven civilian workers have died from the disease caused by the coronavirus. And two chiefs and the deputy commissioner in charge of counterterrorism are among more than 1,500 others in the department who have been infected.

headline: Take Government Aid? We’ll See, Some Businesses Say
abstract: Executives at Boeing, for one, have indicated that they might not accept money authorized by the stimulus if they dislike the terms.
lead_paragraph: Grants, low-interest loans and other government support might seem like manna for businesses under financial strain. But some chief executives and corporate boards might balk at the offer of billions of dollars in aid to help them ride out the coronavirus pandemic and keep the economy from sliding into a deep recession.

headline: Dozens Missing After Ferry in Solomon Islands Defies Cyclone Warning
abstract: Officials said surging seas appeared to throw people overboard in the early morning hours.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Dozens of people are missing and feared dead in the Solomon Islands after being washed from a ferry making a dangerous journey through heaving seas caused by Cyclone Harold.

lead_paragraph: As the virus continues to spread throughout the nation, an analysis of cellphone data shows that those in the wealthiest areas have been able to reduce their movements more than those in the poorest areas.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Other Americans’ and ‘Bringing Down the Colonel’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: BOY SWALLOWS UNIVERSE, by Trent Dalton. (HarperPerennial, 464 pp., $16.99.) A mysterious voice on the red phone in his family’s secret escape room adds a dose of magical realism to the Australian journalist Dalton’s debut novel — a mix of romance, suspense, organized crime and humor that our reviewer, Amelia Lester, called “thrilling.”

headline: The Doctor Came to Save Lives. The Co-op Board Told Him to Get Lost.

lead_paragraph: At the end of seven hours in mask, gown and gloves at Bellevue Hospital Center on Monday, Dr. Richard Levitan finally had a chance to look at his phone.

headline: This Togetherness Is Temporary
abstract: Just as I was getting a little wistful about my teens leaving the nest, we find ourselves confined in the nest together.

headline: I Never Used My Computer on the Sabbath — Until the Coronavirus
abstract: The pandemic is inspiring a rabbi to appreciate the Jewish practice of Shabbat in new ways.
lead_paragraph: Two Saturdays ago was the first time I used my computer on Shabbat in over 20 years. I was leading and participating in my congregation’s Zoom Minyan — our Cyber Shul.

headline: What Happens if America’s 2.5 Million Farmworkers Get Sick?
abstract: Their cramped living and working conditions threaten their health and the nation’s food supply.
lead_paragraph: A century ago in “The Jungle,” Upton Sinclair wrote about how the teeming tenements and meatpacking houses where workers lived and labored were perfect breeding grounds for tuberculosis as it swept the country.

headline: The Unemployment Rate Is Probably Around 13 Percent
abstract: It’s almost certainly at its highest level since the Great Depression. Here’s how we estimated it.
lead_paragraph: The jobless rate today is almost certainly higher than at any point since the Great Depression. We think it’s around 13 percent and rising at a speed unmatched in American history.

headline: How Can You Social Distance When You Share a Toilet With Your Neighbor?
abstract: In places like South Africa, the severity of the epidemic will be linked to  poverty, gender inequality and violent conflict.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — Gita Ramjee, a renowned virologist who worked relentlessly to prevent H.I.V. infection in women in South Africa, died on Tuesday of Covid-19-related complications. Professor Ramjee, 49, who had recently returned to Durban from London, was the fifth person to have died of the coronavirus in the country, where more than 1,300 infections have been reported.

headline: Making the Most of Staying at Home
abstract: Traveling for pleasure is out for now, and many of us are stuck at home day in, day out. Here are some ideas for taking those lemons and getting some joy out of them.
lead_paragraph: Nobody’s traveling for fun right now, and a lot of people are spending all day, every day, cooped up at home. You may, of course, be working your regular hours in a home office or at the kitchen table, but when you’re not, you could try to make the best of the situation. Here are the ways that Wirecutter editors are keeping busy (or at least sane) during their off-work hours while stuck at home.

headline: How a Pharmacist on the Front Lines Spends Her Sundays
abstract: ‘This is my community,’ said Chia Liang of a Walgreens in Queens, where she started as an intern 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Chia Liang is a pharmacist manager at the Walgreens in Jackson Heights, Queens, near one of the neighborhoods hit hardest by the coronavirus. Her Sunday shift there, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., has remained one of the few details of her day that has not changed in recent weeks. Ms. Liang, 31, lives with her husband, Adam, 34, a car mechanic, and Cody, their Maltese, in a two-family home in Elmhurst, Queens, where she grew up. Her parents and younger brother live downstairs.

headline: Video Games to Play With Your Kids That Won’t Drive You Crazy
abstract: Look at it as an opportunity to connect and build relationships with your children by doing something together.
lead_paragraph: You’ve binge-watched “Paw Patrol.” You’ve sat through “Frozen II” a dozen times. There must be something better — more interactive and fun — to do with your kids while stuck at home. Look at it as an opportunity to connect and build relationships with your children by doing something together: playing video games. The trick, of course, is finding ones that you actually want to play without driving yourself crazy.

headline: U.S. Commanders Cite Pandemic as They Pull Back Elite Units Around the World
abstract: The move means the withdrawal of Special Operations troops from some conflict zones and shuttering longstanding missions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American military commanders are using the restrictions imposed by the spread of the coronavirus to reshape the deployment of Special Operations troops all over the world, according to military officials. The decisions mean the withdrawal of elite commandos from some conflict zones and shuttering longstanding missions.

headline: The Journalists Changing Roles During the Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: Reporters and editors are relying on past experience to serve new roles created to cover the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The Men and Women Who Run Toward the Dying
abstract: Meet the New York City chaplains praying for coronavirus patients.
lead_paragraph: Few run toward the dying. Even fewer run toward the contagious.

headline: Cuomo Emerges as ‘Trump Whisperer’ During Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: Using flattery and indirect attacks, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has nurtured a working relationship with President Trump.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, it should have been a softball question lobbed from a friendly source.

headline: Plan B: a Front Porch Wedding
abstract: Julie Samuels and Joe Hillyer scrambled to organize a wedding after canceling their original plans because of Covid-19. Their Montclair, N.J., community quickly responded.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus started making its way through New Jersey, Julie Samuels and Joe Hillyer had planned a simple town hall wedding with just witnesses, followed by an intimate dinner at home.

headline: It’s High Time We Fought This Virus the American Way
abstract: The administration has all the authority it needs to produce medical supplies and prepare for a potential vaccine.
lead_paragraph: Every Marine knows better than to pull a knife in a gunfight. But so far, that appears to be the federal government’s approach to battling Covid-19. The president has “invoked” the Defense Production Act, but the government has not used the full authority of the act. There is a difference between invoking a law and using it, just as there is a difference between talk and action.

headline: The Coronavirus Test Is Too Hard for Trump
abstract: The president joins Herbert Hoover and James Buchanan as a leader who failed when it mattered most.
lead_paragraph: The list of presidential failures is long and varied. But when it comes to failure in the face of an external force — a natural disaster or an economic meltdown — it is difficult to find anything as catastrophic as President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, even at this early stage of the crisis.

headline: ‘This Isn’t a Dry Run’: How to Be Ready for More Financial Pain
abstract: Classic investment strategies are performing about as well as expected — but they may be too painful to bear. If so, says our columnist, make adjustments now.
lead_paragraph: When thousands of people are sick and dying, the stock market isn’t the world’s most pressing problem. It may even be unseemly to worry about it at all.

headline: Why Is Getting a Refund From an Online Travel Agency So Hard?
abstract: Booking sites are scrambling to handle an unprecedented number of cancellation requests, and many customers say they are falling short.
lead_paragraph: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.

headline: How to Get Books When Bookstores and Libraries Are Closed
abstract: Even for people who have lost jobs or income during the coronavirus epidemic, there are books and reading material available online for free.
lead_paragraph: Readers who are used to spending their weekends in bookstores or libraries may be experiencing literary withdrawal. Many of these spaces have closed to mitigate the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Zoom Galas and Vlogging
abstract: How Larry Milstein, Jill Kargman and Nicky Hilton Rothschild are hunkering down.
lead_paragraph: With the New York gala circuit on hiatus because of the coronavirus outbreak, here is how some patrons and society figures are spending their time — and money — while self-isolated. (Interviews have been edited.)

headline: How One Manhattan Co-op Copes with Coronavirus
abstract: Managing an apartment complex means stocking up on disinfectants, ramping up the cleaning schedule and urging residents to stop chatting with the doormen.
lead_paragraph: Until early March, Harry Konjuvca, the resident manager of a prewar co-op in the East 50s, had never heard of Zep.

headline: The Bronx Zoo Is Also Empty, but the Animals Don’t Mind
abstract: The zoo is closed, but essential staff still arrive to care for the roughly 6,000 animals. They don’t seem too upset by the privacy.
lead_paragraph: If a sea lion claps at the Bronx Zoo, and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?

headline: Getting Tipsy at Home in Your Underwear
abstract: A Finnish tradition known as “pantsdrunk” is gaining favor with Americans stuck at home.
lead_paragraph: The Finns have a tradition of getting drunk at home in their underwear. It’s so commonplace there is a word for it, “kalsarikännit,” as well as two emojis: a man in gray underwear with pint of beer, and a woman in a polka-dot slip with a glass of red wine.

headline: For Those With O.C.D., a Threat That Is Both Heightened and Familiar
abstract: For people who have been diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder, the coronavirus pandemic creates blurry lines between safety and compulsion.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak has turned many of us into nervous germophobes, seeking to protect ourselves from infection by washing our hands methodically and frequently, avoiding unnecessary contact with so called high-touch surfaces and methodically sanitizing packages, our homes and our bodies.

headline: How Tech’s Lobbyists Are Using the Pandemic to Make Gains
abstract: Silicon Valley hasn’t suffered from the same financial devastation as other industries. Tech companies still have an agenda to push.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, lobbying groups representing advertising giants like Google and Facebook asked California’s attorney general to wait to enforce the state’s new online privacy rules given the coronavirus ripping around the world.

headline: Children Are Hunting Teddy Bears During the Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: See that stuffed animal in the window? It’s part of a game meant to entertain children (and adults) during a prolonged period of lockdowns and social distancing. How many can you spot?
lead_paragraph: With her school closed, her city quiet and her country under lockdown, Stevie-Lee Tiller, 13, is stuck at home with her parents and three siblings.

headline: Meet the Xenobots, Virtual Creatures Brought to Life
abstract: Computer scientists and biologists have teamed up to make a new class of living robotics that challenge the boundary between digital and biological.
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass. — If the last few decades of progress in artificial intelligence and in molecular biology hooked up, their love child — a class of life unlike anything that has ever lived — might resemble the dark specks doing lazy laps around a petri dish in a laboratory at Tufts University.

headline: What It’s Like to Run for Congress Without Health Insurance During a Pandemic
abstract: Uninsured candidates must take extra care to protect their health as they campaign amid the coronavirus outbreak: “What if something does happen to me?”
lead_paragraph: In the past week and a half, Cori Bush has been hospitalized twice with shortness of breath, sore throat, fatigue, loss of taste and a headache.

headline: Peaks, Testing, Lockdowns: How Coronavirus Vocabulary Causes Confusion
abstract: Officials often use similar words when describing the pandemic, but they are not always talking about the same thing, making global comparisons less useful.
lead_paragraph: Making sense of the coronavirus pandemic requires getting up to speed on semantics as much as epidemiology.

headline: Bad News Wrapped in Protein: Inside the Coronavirus Genome
abstract: The virus injects a tiny but remarkably complex strand of RNA into infected cells.
lead_paragraph: The virus injects a tiny but remarkably complex strand of RNA into infected cells.

headline: Of the Virus and God, Orange Peels and the Party
abstract: A mother and daughter write through distance and disease, searching for the other’s love.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — My mother believes that God and the Chinese Communist Party will defeat the novel coronavirus.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
abstract: The city death toll topped 1,500 as the governor warned of soon exhausting the ventilator stockpile.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Coronavirus, Masks, Jobs: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Stranded Abroad, Americans Ask: Why Weren’t We Warned Sooner?
abstract: As the coronavirus spreads, American tourists say the State Department was slow to inform citizens of the challenges in returning home.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Ana Pautler, a trekker from San Francisco, was partway up a Himalayan mountain trail in Nepal when she noticed something peculiar: People were turning around.

headline: Working From Your Childhood Bedroom
abstract: For some millennials, sheltering in place means moving home to their parents’ house.
lead_paragraph: Even before coronavirus prompted a stay-at-home order for New York City, Dana Shakarchy, 33, decided to flee her apartment on the Upper West Side for her childhood home in Great Neck.

headline: The Return of the Governor
abstract: Once considered bit players on the national stage, governors are emerging as some of the most prominent political voices in the coronavirus crisis.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: ‘I Refuse to Be Repentant’: The Woman Challenging Uganda’s Ruler
abstract: Stella Nyanzi mixes profanity and bawdy humor with razor-sharp political insights to criticize the country’s autocratic president.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — The tears began flowing immediately after Stella Nyanzi began to speak.

headline: Myanmar Journalists Who Quoted Rebel Spokesman Face Arrest
abstract: The authorities detained one editor and were seeking two others after they published stories on the rebel Arakan Army. Their news websites were also blocked.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — In a new crackdown on free speech, the Myanmar authorities have arrested a prominent editor on terrorism charges for publishing an interview with a rebel army spokesman, and on Friday they were seeking two more editors on similar charges.

headline: The Business Leaders Trump Asks for Advice on the Coronavirus
abstract: President Trump is taking advice on his administration’s coronavirus response from a wide range of people, but he trusts some more than others.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: What Unites the Right and Left? Coronavirus Anxiety
abstract: Stark political differences on the crisis are rapidly closing, driven by life experiences and increasing attention by leaders of both parties.
lead_paragraph: Pandemics are not partisan.

headline: Maryland’s Governor, a Republican, Is Willing to Spar With Trump for Supplies
abstract: Larry Hogan is head of the National Governors Association and charged with representing state leaders who fear they’re unprepared to fight the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Larry Hogan was annoyed. On a conference call, Mr. Hogan, the Republican governor of Maryland, had just learned that several South Korean companies were ready to ship more coronavirus test kits to his state. But they were stymied because the Food and Drug Administration had not yet approved their use.

headline: A Civil War, Then the Long Limbo of Life as a Refugee
abstract: In Victoria Jamieson’s “When Stars Are Scattered,” a Somali boy pines for his mother and cares for his little brother with hope and humor during 15 years in a refugee camp.
lead_paragraph: Late in WHEN STARS ARE SCATTERED (Dial Books for Young Readers, 264 pp., $20.99; ages 9 to 12), 17-year-old Omar Mohamed is asked to write a paper on “What It Means to Be a Refugee” for what he complains must be the 20th time since he started school six years earlier. Consider this fantastic graphic novel to be his 21st — and definitive — word on the subject. Written and illustrated by the Newbery Honor winner Victoria Jamieson (“Roller Girl”), based on extensive interviews with Mohamed, now a U.S. citizen who aids refugee resettlement, the book chronicles young Omar’s real-life experiences during the 15 years he spent in the U.N.-run Dadaab camp in Kenya.

headline: N.Y. Virus Deaths Double in Three Days to Almost 3,000
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday that there had been 562 deaths due to the virus over the previous 24 hours, a higher toll than the state saw in the first 27 days of March.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus was taking lives at a devastating pace in New York on Friday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said, with deaths nearly doubling in just three days, from 1,550 on Tuesday to 2,935 on Friday.

headline: European Soccer Teams Get Clarity and a Warning
abstract: European soccer leaders have written to teams and leagues to map out a plan to return to action in July and August, warning there would be consequences should leagues abandon seasons unilaterally.
lead_paragraph: European soccer leaders have told teams to plan for a return to action in July and August and issued a threat by suggesting leagues that cancel the season face the risk of their teams being barred from the Champions League.

headline: Conversation Starters That Have Nothing to Do With the Coronavirus
