abstract: It’s important to stay informed on the latest pandemic news, but you may find yourself wanting to have a chat or four about non-coronavirus things.
lead_paragraph: If it feels as if almost every conversation you have, whether with co-workers or loved ones, veers toward talk of the coronavirus, you’re not alone with that thought. The outbreak has upended people’s lives and livelihoods around the world. Hearing constant updates about the news and worrying developments of friends and family can feel overwhelming.

headline: What Are Some Ways to “Travel” Without Traveling During the Pandemic?
abstract: What can you do over a weekend, wherever you are in the world (even if you are homebound)?
lead_paragraph: Do you love to travel? Do you seek out new experiences and adventures?

headline: The Imperative of Personal Sacrifice, Today and During World War II
abstract: Are Americans as willing to making sacrifices today in response to the coronavirus, compared to in the 1940s? A historian explains.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: E.P.A. Threatens Legal Action Against Sellers of Fake Coronavirus Cleaners
abstract: The federal government is asking online retailers to take unregistered products that falsely claim protection from coronavirus off the market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency warned Friday that disinfectants and sanitizers falsely claiming to protect against the coronavirus are flooding the market and threatened legal action against retailers that sell unregistered products.

headline: Decade of Job Growth Comes to an End, Undone by a Pandemic
abstract: After an expansion that added 22 million to U.S. payrolls, March registered a loss, and worse is yet to come.
lead_paragraph: The longest stretch of American job creation on record came to a halt last month, the Labor Department reported Friday, another reflection of the coronavirus pandemic that has brought the economy to a virtual standstill.

headline: You Have an Extra 3 Months to File Your Taxes. Should You Wait?
abstract: If you’re owed a refund, it may be better to file quickly. You can also file your return now but wait until July 15 to pay any taxes owed.
lead_paragraph: The government has granted everyone an extra three months to file — and pay — their 2019 federal income taxes because of the coronavirus turmoil. Whew! It helps to have wiggle room in uncertain times.

headline: For Small-Business Owners, Hard Decisions Become Personal
abstract: As entrepreneurs determine how to keep their businesses afloat, some choices could seriously harm employees who have worked for them for years.
lead_paragraph: Meganne Wecker got a sense in January of the economic blow coming to her family’s furniture business from her suppliers in China.

headline: How to Hold an Awards Show in a Pandemic
abstract: Major prizes have been postponed or canceled because of the coronavirus outbreak, but one organization showed that a ceremony could still be done. Even down to the red carpet interviews.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dara O’Briain, an Irish comedian, appeared in a tuxedo on a YouTube live stream on Thursday night and announced the start of the 2020 BAFTA Games Awards, celebrating the best video games of the past year.

headline: Mixing Your Own Hand Sanitizer?
abstract: Recipes circulating on social media say it’s simple. But the end result is not like the real thing, and it may not be effective at killing germs.
lead_paragraph: Until a few months ago, most of us didn’t give hand sanitizer much thought. Now it’s sold out around the world, prompting a variety of do-it-yourself recipes that are designed to be mixed up in a home kitchen.

headline: What Would It Take to Eradicate Coronavirus in California?
abstract: Friday: A conversation with the official who led the rollout of the nation’s first shelter-in-place order.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Two More Big Sales at 220 Central Park South
abstract: The condos, though, had been in contract years before the coronavirus outbreak. Going forward, fewer sales are expected to be recorded in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Several high-priced luxury homes that were under contract before the coronavirus outbreak have closed in March, including the biggest sale so far this year — another full-floor aerie at 220 Central Park South. But sales are expected to plummet in the weeks ahead as the pandemic continues to take its toll on the New York region.

headline: How to Navigate Public Spaces and More
abstract: Tips on etiquette as we all learn how to stay distant but kind.
lead_paragraph: We have never experienced a lockdown like this. Public and personal spaces have been transformed almost overnight. With so many new rules to follow, it’s understandable to feel destabilized. But we should still strive to be our best selves as we go about our day.

headline: Where to Donate to Bolster a Quieted Arts Scene
abstract: With exhibition and performance spaces shuttered, artists are relying on the generosity of patrons.
lead_paragraph: As we enter April, caring for those sick with Covid-19 and preventing others from becoming so remains the priority in New York City, as in the rest of the country. But how can we look out for others particularly affected by the crisis? Citywide closures of nonessential services have devastated the arts at every level: Exhibition and performance spaces have shuttered indefinitely, and thousands of New Yorkers working in creative industries, many of them freelancers, have seen their livelihoods disappear with no assurances about when they’ll be able to work again. Many of these people also work in bars and restaurants, the closures of which threaten to change the face of the industry forever — the longer a restaurant stays closed, restaurateurs will tell you, the harder it will be to reopen.

headline: It’s Bedlam in the Mask Market, as Profiteers Out-Hustle Good Samaritans
abstract: Hospitals, governments, do-gooders and hucksters are all competing. Scams and prices are soaring.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Susan Houghtelling, a hospital supply-chain manager in upstate New York, was facing a shortfall of medical supplies when her inbox suddenly flooded with offers.

headline: Does Covid-19 Hit Women and Men Differently? U.S. Isn’t Keeping Track
abstract: Data from other countries shows that more men are dying from the virus than women — a discrepancy that should inform the response and vaccine research in the U.S. But it isn’t.
lead_paragraph: — Caroline Criado Perez, author of “Invisible Women”

headline: Behind the Cover: On the Job
abstract: For this issue, a look at those who have no choice but to report to work during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Making Children Save Up for Lego Hogwarts
abstract: Forcing kids to earn their toys? In this economy?
lead_paragraph: Dana writes: Our kids really wanted the big Lego Hogwarts set. So my husband and I bought it, planning to stash it away until they saved enough money to pay for it. It’s four months later, and they haven’t saved any money. But now we’re sheltering in place. I suggested that Lego Hogwarts could be deployed in case of emergency boredom. His response? “They’d better start saving money.”

headline: Seeing Abortion Laws From a Teenager’s Point of View
abstract: Eliza Hittman explains how she came to make her timely odyssey “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” the unusual movie about abortion rights that makes bureaucracy the villain.
lead_paragraph: Before writing her new movie, “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” about the odyssey of a 17-year-old girl in present-day Pennsylvania seeking a legal abortion, the director Eliza Hittman embarked on a journey of her own. Hittman makes movies of quietly operatic intensity about vulnerable characters in unremarkable places. To find their narratives, she begins in the field, exploring prospective locations like a sculptor wandering a quarry.

headline: How Do You Make a Film for a Museum and Pornhub? Ask Leilah Weinraub
abstract: The director captured the utopia that was Shakedown, a strip club catering to black lesbians. The result was a radically intimate documentary suited to both platforms.
lead_paragraph: The moment Leilah Weinraub stepped into Shakedown, a roving lesbian strip club in Los Angeles, she was hooked. It was the winter of 2002, she was a recent college graduate, and Shakedown, which was part of a scene that catered to black lesbians, offered a tantalizing new community. “I had never been in a lesbian space that was full before,” Weinraub said. She immediately breezed her way into serving as house photographer for the parties.

headline: Troubled Turf: The Photographs of An-My Le
abstract: From Vietnam to the U.S.-Mexico border, an artist blurs the boundaries between photojournalism and fiction.
lead_paragraph: If you step back far enough, there is no outside to war. Or so suggests An-My Le, whose harrowingly quiet, wide-angled photographs highlight battle re-enactors, active military personnel and sites of conflicts, both real and simulated. They are featured in “On Contested Terrain,” a revelatory career survey at the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh, through July 26. (While the museum is temporarily closed because of the coronavirus, a video tour and selected images are online at cmoa.org.)

headline: ‘A Seismic Shock’: Jittery Companies Pull Back on Ads During Pandemic
abstract: Blank billboards and canceled online ads signal an industry in crisis as the coronavirus spreads. “There are things happening that we’ve never seen before,” one marketing executive said.
lead_paragraph: The billboard was blank.

headline: William Frankland, Pioneering Allergist, Dies at 108
abstract: One of the top allergists of the 20th century, Dr. Frankland, who died of the coronavirus, helped legions of hay fever sneezers by publicizing pollen counts. Among his patients was Saddam Hussein.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: This Brooklyn Landlord Just Canceled Rent for Hundreds of Tenants
abstract: Mario Salerno, who has 18 apartment buildings, said he did not want renters to stress about their payment during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A few days after losing his job in March, Paul Gentile was throwing away trash outside his Brooklyn apartment building when he noticed a new sign hanging near the front door.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make happiness out of what you have: a matzo lasagna, cheese Danishes, or even a rich two-layer chocolate cake.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You had enough of beans, of stressed-out breadmaking, of weird lunchtime sandwiches and these new morning rituals that have sprung up like daffodils through the loam? It’s been five days of work at the kitchen table, on the couch, in the basement, wherever you can perch where, in my case, there’s not a child in virtual school or a spouse on a video call, a cat stretched out in the sun, the dog looking ready, again, for a walk. Then dinner, say pizza chicken (above), hastily prepared just as it was before the coronavirus came, and served too late, before everyone tips into bed to start all over again in the gray light of morning. Five days of this at least.

headline: How an Eye Surgeon Got a Picture of This Rare Pastel Bird
abstract: The elusive South Philippine dwarf kingfisher is difficult to photograph, and there were no known photographs of its fledglings.
lead_paragraph: On March 11, Dr. Miguel David De Leon — a vitreoretinal surgeon in Mindanao, the southern island of the Philippines — worked a full morning at the medical center. When he got home, “I was exhausted,” he said. But he pulled it together, lugged his camera an hour uphill and clambered into his bird hide.

headline: Bill Withers, Who Sang ‘Lean on Me’ and ‘Ain’t No Sunshine,’ Dies at 81
abstract: A three-time Grammy Award winner, he had a string of much-covered hits in the 1970s but had not released an album since 1985.
lead_paragraph: Bill Withers, a onetime Navy aircraft mechanic who, after teaching himself to play the guitar, wrote some of the most memorable and often-covered songs of the 1970s, including “Lean on Me,” “Ain’t No Sunshine” and “Use Me,” died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Is It Like the Flu? Is It a Major Threat? Trump’s Changing Coronavirus Message
abstract: After initially downplaying the potential severity of the coronavirus pandemic and sharing false and misleading information, President Trump has changed his position on key aspects of the crisis. Here are five examples.
lead_paragraph: After initially downplaying the potential severity of the coronavirus pandemic and sharing false and misleading information, President Trump has changed his position on key aspects of the crisis. Here are five examples.

headline: Five Signs of Failure
abstract: No. 1: No sign of a flattening curve.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Carlota’s World: What Children Can Teach Us During the Coronavirus Crisis
abstract: No talking face to face, no hugging or kissing can become an unhealthy habit for this generation. They would be missing the sweetest things about being human.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The door of Carlota’s room is ajar, so I peek inside to see what she’s doing. She’s sitting upright at her desk with her laptop in front of her. On the screen are a dozen of her schoolmates, all of them, like Carlota, participating in a virtual class. I can tell that their teacher is leading the lesson from her home — I’m pretty sure they’re discussing fractions and decimals — but Carlota and her friends are following closely along as if she were talking to them in person.

headline: As Virus Threatens Orchestras, Trade Group Taps a New Leader
abstract: The League of American Orchestras chose Simon Woods, who left the Los Angeles Philharmonic abruptly last September, as its next chief executive.
lead_paragraph: With arts organizations reeling from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, and bracing for worse, the League of American Orchestras has chosen a new leader to help guide its field through a bruising period. The league announced on Friday that Simon Woods, a longtime orchestra administrator, would be its next chief executive.

headline: Gita Ramjee, a Leading AIDS Researcher, Dies at 63
abstract: Working in South Africa, she led studies and drug trials, hoping to overcome not only H.I.V. but also cultural barriers to stopping its spread. She died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: What We Pretend to Know About the Coronavirus Could Kill Us
abstract: Today’s propaganda is tomorrow’s truth, and vice versa.
lead_paragraph: Other than a vaccine or an extra 500,000 ventilators, tests and hospital beds, reliable information is the best weapon we have against Covid-19. It allows us to act uniformly and decisively to flatten the curve. In an ideal pandemic scenario, sound information is produced by experts and travels quickly to the public.

headline: U.K. Backs Off Medical Rationing Plan as Coronavirus Rages
abstract: Britain has long offered public guidance on when to deny lifesaving treatment but has hesitated with the coronavirus. Many worry that decisions may harm the poor, the aged and people with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Denying lifesaving care to conserve public resources is nothing new for Britain’s National Health Service.

headline: Stashed in the Marsh, Left in the Road: Victims Pile Up in Four New Crime Novels
abstract: In Marilyn Stasio’s latest column, the body count is high and the murderers more cunning than ever.
lead_paragraph: The voices of the dead tell the unhappy story of PLEASE SEE US (Gallery, 341 pp., $26.99), Caitlin Mullen’s spellbinding debut novel about a series of murders in Atlantic City. When the narrative opens, there are two dead women sprawled in the marsh behind the Sunset Motel. By the end of the story, there will be seven of these Jane Does, all victims of a killer who targets prostitutes, the most disposable of women.

headline: Crisis Gives Fake Cops an Opening to Exploit
abstract: Police impersonators with phony badges and flashing blue lights are taking advantage of quarantine rules to defraud or harass people across the country, the authorities warn.
lead_paragraph: In Lodi, Calif., a man wearing a “tactical-type vest” stopped a man in a park and told him he was violating curfew and needed to hand over $1,000 or go to jail.

headline: ‘We Didn’t Sign Up for This’: Amazon Workers on the Front Lines
abstract: Employees want more wipes and less crowding in sanitized warehouses.
lead_paragraph: As if in the darkest children’s fable ever told, the undisputed winner of the current plague turns out to be the man who already had everything, the king whose empire appears intent on consuming the entire map. This week Jeff Bezos, the richest man on earth, saw the year’s first financial quarter close with Amazon stock up more than 5 percent, trading at $1,950 a share, during a period in which the Dow had its worst overall quarter since 1987.

headline: Trying to Adapt to Remote Learning
abstract: Readers discuss the challenges for both teachers and students.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Women’s Open Postponed Until December
abstract: The event, originally slated for early June, is the third women’s golf major tournament to be rescheduled. The decision may augur a decision from the U.S. Golf Association on the men’s Open.
lead_paragraph: The United States Golf Association postponed the 75th United States Women’s Open from early June to mid-December on Friday, a notable sign that golf’s governing bodies are seriously weighing dates late this year as they scramble to reschedule an ever-expanding list of postponed women’s and men’s events.

headline: Pete Buttigieg’s Next Move: A PAC Called Win the Era
abstract: Donors have been told that the group will support candidates, specifically in down-ballot races, it hopes will become future leaders.
lead_paragraph: Pete Buttigieg, who rose from obscurity to narrowly win the Iowa caucuses before dropping out of the Democratic presidential primary last month, has taken some of the first steps toward outlining his post-campaign future.

headline: Everything Is Negotiable in This Asparagus Salad
abstract: You could use any kind of nuts or semifirm cheese in this nutty, cheesy bright spring salad. You could even lose the asparagus.
lead_paragraph: Judging by the pinking of my neighborhood in cherry and magnolia blossoms, Covid-19 can’t stop spring. And this means vegetables like ramps, green garlic and asparagus have been making their way into the markets, bringing a needed relief from those wintry pantry staples we’ve all been relying on. I may have to wait on a snaking line six feet away from the person ahead of me to get some, but it will be thrilling when I do.

headline: A Coffee C.E.O.’s Pandemic Diary: ‘We Want to Still Provide an Escape’
abstract: Nick Stone, the founder of Bluestone Lane, says he is determined to see glimpses of humanity in a “devastating, absolutely devastating” crisis.
lead_paragraph: A month ago, Nick Stone had a $50 million coffee business, with dozens of cafes in bustling downtowns.

headline: Trump Seeks to Block 3M Mask Exports and Grab Masks From Its Overseas Customers
abstract: The move would significantly expand the American government’s reach and reverse President Trump’s hesitant use of the Defense Production Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is using a Korean War-era law to redirect to the United States surgical masks manufactured by 3M in other countries as part of a heated pressure campaign to force the Minnesota company to cut off sales of surgical masks abroad.

headline: The Governor Who Dissed New Yorkers
abstract: I just hate it when my fellow Italian-Americans squabble.
lead_paragraph: When every other Democrat in America was swooning over Andrew Cuomo, Gina Raimondo was sparring with him.

headline: Join a Musical Meditation Bringing Together Hundreds Worldwide
abstract: Every Saturday in April, anyone can be part of a global performance of Pauline Oliveros’s “Tuning Meditation” over Zoom.
lead_paragraph: As I entered the Zoom session last Saturday, I recognized some faces. The flutist Claire Chase. The pianist Conrad Tao. The violinist Carla Kihlstedt. The vocalist Gelsey Bell. Over the years, I had reviewed all these musicians from my critic’s perch in darkened concert halls and underground music clubs.

headline: Anything for Dinner Is OK
abstract: Sometimes it’s nice to cook what you want: Hopefully, that’s chicken piccata, spicy sheet-pan sausage and squash, or an easy tagliatelle.
lead_paragraph: Hello, Five Weeknight Dishes readers. Of all the new kitchen responsibilities I currently have, cleaning ingredients with bleach solution and disinfectant is the hardest to wrap my mind around. We don’t have to worry about screen time, but we do have to worry about salad? All of this is very time-consuming and upsetting, and anything you decide to do about dinner is OK right now.

headline: You’re Quarantined and Your Kid Runs Out of Books to Read
abstract: Aron Nels Steinke, author of the “Mr. Wolf’s Class” series, describes the very real problem of a bibliophilic kid in this coronavirus moment.

headline: What to Do if Your Day Care Is Still Open
abstract: And what to do if it isn’t. (For starters: Pay them if you can, but don’t fret if you can’t.)
lead_paragraph: Every morning when Inna Keselman goes to work as a neurologist at the University of California, Los Angeles, she drops her 3-year-old son off at a day care center located on campus. It’s the same routine that she had before the Covid-19 pandemic.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: E.M.T.s under siege. A submerged forest. Egypt’s female lion tamers. 36 hours wherever you are. Alison Roman’s Seder table. Jared Kushner. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Finding a new normal under your own roof? We’re all trying, right? Trying to do right by our families and neighbors. Trying not to touch our faces. Trying to forge a new routine. Trying to keep our heads up, when there’s so much dragging us down. Trying is all we can do, so carry on, and read some amazing journalism while you are at it.

headline: With Virus Surge, Dermatologists and Orthopedists Are Drafted for the E.R.
abstract: Specialists who haven’t worked an intensive care shift in years are being pressed into duty as coronavirus cases overwhelm New York’s hospitals.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest hospital networks in New York has given its doctors an ultimatum: either help deal with the coronavirus crush, or stay home without pay.

headline: Lawsuits Swell as Owners, From Gun Shops to Golf Courses, Demand to Open
abstract: Orders to stay home and to shutter businesses because of the coronavirus are being challenged nationwide on the grounds they deny Americans their constitutional rights.
lead_paragraph: Blueberry Hill Public Golf Course & Lounge became a community institution almost the day it opened in western Pennsylvania in 1961, with one generation of players succeeding the next on the wooded, undulating course bordering the Allegheny National Forest.

headline: Love Letter: Dating in the Middle of the Atlantic Ocean
abstract: And: a front porch wedding.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: Mavis Staples’s Soulful Solidarity, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Moses Sumney, Troye Sivan, Sonic Boom and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: How to Thrive in Online Life
abstract: A video game pro tells us to embrace the mess of our pandemic lives.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Let This One-Bowl Poundcake Soothe You
abstract: Citrus-scented and speckled with cornmeal, this cake is excellent toasted and buttered for breakfast.
lead_paragraph: Is it cake time yet?

headline: At Margaret Atwood’s Prompting, Canada Launches Virtual Book Tours
abstract: Canada’s National Arts Center is using streaming video for authors to promote their spring and summer titles to a nation stuck indoors by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Margaret Atwood is launching an online series that she hopes will help Canada’s writers sell books to a nation of shut-ins. But even she has not been immune to the headaches plaguing many people as they attempt to communicate during the global pandemic.

headline: Marie’s Is Closed, but Its ‘Dominatrix’ Pianist Still Takes Requests
abstract: With a piano and a camera, Franca Vercelloni of Marie’s Crisis Cafe continues to play for the bar’s show-tune singalongs on social media.
lead_paragraph: The first Saturday in March now seems like a decade ago. New Yorkers were not yet sheltering at home to slow the spread of the coronavirus, and on that night Franca Vercelloni was more immediately concerned with taming the noisy crowd at Marie’s Crisis, the storied Greenwich Village piano bar known for show-tune singalongs.

headline: How to Meditate Outdoors With Us Right Now
abstract: An exercise to help your body release the stress of constantly bracing for a disaster.
lead_paragraph: An exercise to help your body release the stress of constantly bracing for a disaster.

headline: Pakistan Rearrests 4 Men in Daniel Pearl Case
abstract: After a provincial court overturned the men’s convictions in the American journalist’s kidnapping and death, Pakistani officials moved quickly to appeal to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: The Pakistani authorities said Friday that four men had been rearrested in the abduction and killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl after a court overturned their convictions just the day before. The government will appeal their acquittals to Pakistan’s Supreme Court, officials said.

headline: As Supermarkets Feel Hazardous and Sparse, Small Farms Deliver
abstract: In Los Angeles, some community-supported agriculture services have seen their membership triple in just a few weeks.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For over a decade, Jennifer Field Piette has put together boxes of local fruits, vegetables and various pantry staples from California — Koda Farms rice, pale blue pastured eggs, crusty loaves of sourdough — and delivered them to people’s doorsteps in Los Angeles.

headline: Bonus Pay for Hazardous Duty
abstract: A reader says the low-paid workers who are keeping things running and shelves stocked during the crisis deserve special compensation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Parenting When the Family Is Locked Inside
abstract: The clinical psychologist Lisa Damour discusses the specific challenges of raising teenagers during the pandemic, and Dwight Garner asks Pamela Paul about putting together the Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: A Mediterranean-Inspired Menu to Keep You Going All Day
abstract: Savory spiced oats, chicken salad pita and spicy meatballs: These recipes offer a trip abroad, via your pantry.
lead_paragraph: Even though spring has arrived, with daffodils popping up and trees in blossom, it’s still mostly cold and damp on the East Coast. It makes a person want to head for warmer climes.

headline: Film Treasures, Streaming Courtesy of the Library of Congress
abstract: The astonishment of riches includes up-close looks at our history in hundreds of films. And they’re all free.
lead_paragraph: One of the world’s oldest films, “Sneeze,” is a gift that keeps on giving. Shot in 1894 and about as long as an achoo, it shows a mustachioed gent emitting a single sneeze, a kerchief clutched in one hand. The film was made by W.K.L. Dickson and the sneeze delivered by Fred Ott. Working in Thomas Edison’s New Jersey studio, they gave us the first celluloid sneeze, an open-mouth exhalation that was meant to be humorous but today seems ominous. Cover your mouth! I yelled when I looked at it again.

headline: Now’s a Good Time to Teach Your Kids to Play on Their Own
abstract: Independent play is a skill your kids will use for the rest of their lives — and a way to claim some time for yourself during quarantine.
lead_paragraph: “When I was a kid, there was lots and lots of free play with no parental interaction. My kids cannot be alone for five minutes. WHERE DID WE GO WRONG?”

headline: Review: In ‘World on Fire,’ War Is the Virus
abstract: PBS’s “Masterpiece” offers a World War II drama without generals or prime ministers or führers, just a lot of ordinary people muddling through.
lead_paragraph: PBS announced last summer that it would be showing “World on Fire,” so it can’t be accused of capitalizing on current events. Congratulate it instead on its good timing: a sweeping drama about people’s responses to the approach of a potentially world-destroying virus, in this case Nazism.

headline: ‘Zoombombing’ Becomes a Dangerous Organized Effort
abstract: Zoom, the videoconferencing app, has become a target for harassment and abuse coordinated in private off-platform chats.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, as schools, businesses, support groups and millions of individuals have adopted Zoom as a meeting platform in an increasingly remote world, reports of “Zoombombing” or “Zoom raiding” by uninvited participants have become frequent.

headline: Half the World Is on Lockdown. For Sports? More Like 99 Percent.
abstract: What follows is the sum total of sporting events being held on our planet. Plus, a really fast cyclist on Zwift.
lead_paragraph: As the host of the 2020, we mean the 2021, Summer Games, Japan has drawn an outsize share of attention during the coronavirus pandemic. While it did shut down some events as early as February, and closed schools in March, it was slower to adopt some other mitigation efforts like working from home and social distancing, in part because its infection rates seemed low.

headline: Bill de Blasio: We Need All Medical Workers on the Front Lines
abstract: Our city and all cities need the federal government to enlist all doctors and health workers, and mobilize them in a way we’ve never seen.
lead_paragraph: There is no historical comparison for what our country is going through.

headline: Some Big Investors Smell Profit in Virus-Plagued Companies
abstract: Hedge funds and private equity firms are plotting to lend to companies struggling with the fallout from the pandemic, or even buy stakes in them.
lead_paragraph: The recent misfortune of American businesses — many of which are struggling to raise cash to stay afloat — is creating new moneymaking opportunities for hedge funds and private equity firms, big investors that have been relatively unscathed by the pandemic.

headline: Single Parents Are Struggling, but Enduring, Through the Pandemic
abstract: NYT Parenting readers share their stories.
lead_paragraph: When the governor of Virginia announced that schools would remain closed through the end of the academic year because of the coronavirus pandemic, Edrenna Johnson started crying. She took that afternoon off work and ate brownies with her 5-year-old, wondering how she was going to get through three more months of working from home and taking care of her son on her own. Johnson thought she had found a balance, until her son came up to her while she was on a work call and whispered, “Mommy, I miss you,” in her ear. She felt deflated.

headline: The Fed Got a Big Pile of Cash to Help the Economy. Who Will Benefit?
abstract: As the coronavirus sends the economy into a free fall, the Federal Reserve will keep credit flowing with an array of programs. But some details are fuzzy.
lead_paragraph: As unemployment skyrockets and businesses struggle to cover rent and payroll, the odds are rising that short-term layoffs turn into long-term joblessness as employers shut down. At its worst, the United States could fall into an economic depression.

headline: China Pushes for Quiet Burials as Coronavirus Death Toll Is Questioned
abstract: Officials are ​trying to curb expressions of grief and control the narrative​ amid doubts about the official number of deaths in China.
lead_paragraph: Liu Pei’en held the small wooden box that contained his father’s remains. Only two months ago, he had helplessly clutched his father’s frail hand as the elderly man took his last breath, and the pain was still raw. He wept.

headline: ‘Stress-Free’: Coronavirus Aid Flows Quickly to Berlin’s Self-Employed
abstract: Within days, Germany’s capital distributed money to 150,000 artists, shop owners, hairdressers and other small-business owners and freelancers to cover basic expenses.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Germany shut down public life to halt the spread of the new coronavirus last month, Laurenz Bostedt, a freelance photographer, watched as one contract after another was canceled, until his entire expected income had disappeared.

headline: An I.C.U. Nurse’s Coronavirus Diary
abstract: I’ve started to refer to the time before this as peace time. Because this feels like a war.
lead_paragraph: I’m awake before my alarm goes off. I make coffee, wash my face and put deodorant on twice. The deodorant is never enough to stop the sweat and smell, but I try. My husband and kids are still asleep. I try to eat. My stomach turns as I imagine what today will bring, though of course I know. It’s always variations on the same theme: Critically ill patients who all have been given the same diagnosis, Covid-19.

headline: Prisons Breed the Coronavirus. We Can Safely Free Thousands of Inmates.
abstract: Nonviolent offenders, the medically vulnerable and those near the end of their sentences should be released. Those who remain deserve much better medical care.
lead_paragraph: Here is an email from a woman in Alabama to Katie Rosenfeld, a civil rights lawyer in New York, pleading for help for a loved one incarcerated inside an Alabama state prison where the coronavirus is beginning to spread:

headline: Why I Tried to Save My Father, My Dictator
abstract: Once you see your father as vulnerable, you don’t forget it.
lead_paragraph: My father, an undocumented immigrant from Ecuador, used to take me to water parks every summer back when he could drive. He did it because commercials for water parks were featured prominently on local television and they depicted children acting carefree and wild and I was not carefree or wild and it weighed on him, so he insisted I try.

headline: Captain Crozier Is a Hero
abstract: Theodore Roosevelt, my great-grandfather, would agree.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Capt. Brett Crozier, the commander of the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, sent a letter to the Navy pleading for permission to unload his crew, including scores of sailors sickened with Covid-19, in Guam, where it was docked. The Pentagon had been dragging its feet, and the situation on the ship was growing dire.

headline: Former Queens Museum Director to Lead Leslie-Lohman Museum
abstract: Laura Raicovich will lead the museum on an interim basis, replacing Gonzalo Casals, New York City’s new Cultural Affairs Commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Laura Raicovich may have proved too radical for the Queens Museum, where she was politically outspoken during her three years as president and executive director there before she stepped down in 2018.

headline: Corona Beer to Halt Production Amid Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: The suspension was announced days after the Mexican government ordered nonessential businesses to close.
lead_paragraph: Corona beer has become a temporary victim of the coronavirus.

headline: How to Help Your Relationship Survive a Lockdown
abstract: Coronavirus-related anxiety is real and causing serious damage to our partnerships. Here are some tips to ease the strain.
lead_paragraph: The strain that the coronavirus is putting on our lives is immense. And it is affecting most relationships in some way. As a licensed psychotherapist specializing in relationship therapy, I’ve received many emails and calls in the past few weeks from concerned people worrying that their relationships were not going to make it.

headline: Patricia Bosworth, Actress-Turned-Author, Dies at 86
abstract: She gave up the stage for the writing life, publishing biographies of some famous friends and two powerful memoirs. She died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: 2 Members of Kennedy Family Are Feared Dead After Canoe Overturned
abstract: Maeve Kennedy Townsend McKean, a granddaughter of Robert F. Kennedy, and her 8-year-old son were last seen in the Chesapeake Bay on Thursday, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: The search for two members of the Kennedy family whose canoe overturned in strong winds in the Chesapeake Bay on Thursday has “turned from rescue to recovery,” the family said in a statement on Friday night.

headline: Have You Been Separated from Your Family Because of Coronavirus?
abstract: We want to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: People who are presumed to have coronavirus are being asked to self-quarantine. Medical workers need to take special precautions when coming home from work at the end of the day. For parents of young children, these scenarios create new challenges at home. If you have had to separate from your family, or if you live with someone who has, we want to hear your story.

headline: Nur Hassan Hussein, Former Prime Minister of Somalia, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Hussein, who died after testing positive for coronavirus, led his country’s government during a crucial transitional period.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Coronavirus Sweeps Through a San Antonio Nursing Home
abstract: The virus infected 67 of the facility’s 84 residents, killing one, with several infected employees working at other facilities in Texas.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A coronavirus outbreak at a San Antonio nursing home has infected 67 of the facility’s 84 residents, killing one, the largest spread of the virus at a Texas long-term care facility, city and county officials said on Friday.

headline: Dapper Dan’s Grandson Sews His Own Gucci
abstract: Akil Loving has worked in his grandfather’s atelier since high school, making duds for Diddy and Pharrell.
lead_paragraph: Name: Akil Loving

headline: During a Pandemic, an Unanticipated Problem: Out-of-Work Health Workers
abstract: Across the country, plunging revenues from canceled nonemergency medical appointments have forced hospitals to furlough or cut the pay of doctors, nurses and other staff.
lead_paragraph: As hospitals across the country brace for an onslaught of coronavirus patients, doctors, nurses and other health care workers — even in emerging hot spots — are being furloughed, reassigned or told they must take pay cuts.

headline: The Navy Fired the Captain of the Theodore Roosevelt. See How the Crew Responded.
abstract: The rousing show of support provided another gripping scene to emerge from the coronavirus pandemic: the rank and file cheering a boss they viewed as putting their safety ahead of his career.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a send-off for the ages, with hundreds of sailors aboard the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt cheering Capt. Brett E. Crozier, the commander who sacrificed his naval career by writing a letter to his superiors demanding more help as the novel coronavirus spread through the ship.

headline: How a Bouncy Ball Changed the Way I See the World
abstract: What I miss most now, sheltering in place, are the dog walks where a SuperBall can stop time in its tracks.
lead_paragraph: In the stillness and noise of the M.R.I., I picture what the magnet is doing to my brain. I imagine hydrogen protons aligning along and against the direction of its field. Bursts of radio waves challenge their orientation, generating signals that are rendered into images. Other than the sting of the contrast agent, the momentary changes in nuclear spin feel like nothing. “Twenty-five more minutes,” the radiologist says through the plastic headphones. Usually, I fall asleep.

headline: Why Talking About Our Problems Helps So Much (and How to Do It)
abstract: There’s more to the age-old advice to just “talk it out” than there seems. Here’s some of the evidence that explains why it is so helpful.
lead_paragraph: When your car breaks down, you either know how to fix it or how to find someone who can. Emotions, on the other hand, are a little harder to fix. There is no wrench you can grab or repair shop you can take your feelings to. But you do have one tool in your kit you can always use: talking about your feelings. Even just speaking about your feelings out loud to another person can help. So why do we avoid it or believe it doesn’t work?

headline: Russian Doctor Detained After Challenging Virus Figures
abstract: The police held overnight an outspoken Russian doctor, Anastasia Vasilieva, who was trying to deliver masks to an impoverished rural town.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian authorities detained the leader of an independent doctors’ union, an outspoken critic of the Kremlin who has dismissed as “lies” the country’s low official numbers for coronavirus infections.

headline: How to Remove Your Acrylics or Gels at Home
abstract: Yes, removing your acrylic nails is tedious. But you’ve probably got some time on your hands.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, at-home gel removal is unexplored territory. To help you navigate the task, we consulted two nail artists, Brittney Boyce and Lisa Logan, for advice. Here, the right way to remove the four most common types of long-lasting manicure — soft gels, hard gels, acrylics and dip powder nails — quickly and safely.

headline: Trump Picks McConnell Protégé for Influential Appeals Court Seat
abstract: The American Bar Association had rated the new nominee, Judge Justin Walker, as unqualified, but he has strong conservative support
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday nominated Judge Justin Walker, a protégé of Senator Mitch McConnell, to a vacancy on the influential United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, touching off what is likely to be a contentious confirmation fight in the Senate.

headline: A Gift From Gallaghers: Aged Steaks for First Responders
abstract: On Friday, the New York steakhouse opened its famed front-window meat locker to police officers and firefighters.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you see when you walk into Gallaghers Steakhouse, a 93-year-old restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, is steak. In the glass-paneled meat locker in the steakhouse’s front window are cut after cut of prime beef — a Fort Knox of meat, tagged and aging.

headline: F.D.A. to Allow Use of KN95 Masks Approved by China
abstract: The masks are almost identical in performance to the N95 masks that hospitals and other institutions are struggling to find.
lead_paragraph: With doctors, nurses and other health care workers facing acute shortages of protective masks, the Food and Drug Administration announced on Friday that it will allow use of a more widely available mask that meets Chinese standards instead of American ones.

headline: Trump Says Hospitals Will Be Paid for Treating Uninsured Coronavirus Patients
abstract: Critics say that the plan may not go to hospitals in the states hit the hardest so far and that it fails to address the problems of uninsured people more generally.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration plans to use money from the recent stimulus bills to pay hospitals for treatment of uninsured coronavirus patients. It says the plan is more efficient than reopening enrollment in the Obamacare markets to achieve the same goal.

headline: National Security Court Orders Deeper Look at 29 F.B.I. Wiretap Applications
abstract: The rare public order follows an inspector general’s findings of pervasive problems with how the bureau has prepared applications to wiretap people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A secretive court that oversees national security surveillance ordered the F.B.I. on Friday to conduct a searching review of 29 wiretap applications in terrorism and espionage investigations, after an inspector general uncovered pervasive problems with how the bureau prepared them.

headline: Can an Old Vaccine Stop the New Coronavirus?
abstract: A tuberculosis vaccine invented a century ago is cheap and safe, and seems to bolster the body’s immune system.
lead_paragraph: A vaccine that was developed a hundred years ago to fight the tuberculosis scourge in Europe is now being tested against the coronavirus by scientists eager to find a quick way to protect health care workers, among others.

headline: FEMA, Racing to Provide Virus Relief, Is Running Short on Front-Line Staff
abstract: The agency leading the   coronavirus response nationwide is facing a staffing crunch and has closed its training facilities to avoid spreading the virus, officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Emergency Management Agency, the office leading the federal government’s coronavirus response nationwide, is running short of employees who are trained in some of its most important front-line jobs, according to interviews with current and former officials.

headline: ‘Everything Is Always Keep Changing’
abstract: Cheryl Strayed calls the author George Saunders to talk through the uncertainties of this moment.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Holdout States Resist Calls for Stay-at-Home Orders: ‘What Are You Waiting For?’
abstract: A small number of states in the Midwest and the South are under growing pressure to order all residents to stay at home to fight the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A surge in coronavirus deaths in the United States has prompted the vast majority of governors to order their residents to stay home, but a small number of states are resisting increasingly urgent calls to shut down.

headline: Coronavirus, Masks, Bill Withers: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How to Pass Time in a Pandemic
abstract: Ten writers recommend diversions, and new ways to think about the necessary chores of home life.
lead_paragraph: Well, we’re in it for the long haul. As self-isolation and quarantine continue on — as the hours lose their edges, as the days start to blend together — we may find ourselves looking for new ways to pass the time, since some of us, suddenly, have so much of it. Nearly every week for the past five years or so, The Times Magazine has published a Letter of Recommendation: a column that, in its own way, suggests new things for readers to try. These articles have run the gamut — writers have extolled the virtues of Lent and Nikes, biting your nails and having a cocktail at lunch — but we’ve pulled together some of our favorite ones that can be experienced entirely indoors. Here are some TV shows to watch, games to play, activities to undertake and, we hope, opportunities to take your mind off things, if only for a few minutes.

headline: Life, Covid-Free, After 22 Days in the Hospital
abstract: Mark Frilot, and his wife, Heaven, became ambassadors of a sort — of the seriousness of coronavirus — to their conservative Louisiana community.
lead_paragraph: After 22 days in the hospital, fighting for his life, Mark Frilot is going home.

headline: Frenzy and Desperation as Small Businesses Grab for Government Aid
abstract: A $349 billion program to throw them a financial lifeline got off to a rocky start on Friday as the U.S. economy continued to seize up.
lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]

headline: Harriet Glickman, Who Pushed ‘Peanuts’ to Add a Black Character, Dies at 93
abstract: In 1968, at her urging, Charles M. Schulz added Franklin Armstrong to his enormously popular comic strip as a way to promote racial equality.
lead_paragraph: Harriet Glickman, who in 1968 persuaded Charles M. Schulz, the creator of “Peanuts,” to add an African-American character to his roster of Charlie Brown, Snoopy and the rest of the gang, died on March 27 at her home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. She was 93.

headline: Stop Using Toilet Paper
abstract: Why are we hoarding it when experts agree that rinsing with water is more sanitary and environmentally sound?
lead_paragraph: While the coronavirus pandemic is affecting us all differently depending on where we live, our financial situation and our basic health, one universal is the difficulty finding toilet paper.

headline: What Happens if Congress Cannot Assemble to Do Its Work?
abstract: As Covid-19 makes social distancing a matter of life and death, a growing number of lawmakers are pushing the idea of remote voting.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus crisis gets better, it will get worse: more death, more economic pain — and therefore more need for Congress to adopt relief measures for the American people.

headline: You Shouldn’t Have to Risk Your Life to Vote
abstract: Holding a primary election in a pandemic, as Wisconsin plans to do on Tuesday, will suppress turnout and endanger public health.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, hundreds of thousands of voters in Wisconsin will be forced to choose between exercising their constitutional right to vote and safeguarding their own lives, not to mention the lives of their loved ones, their neighbors and poll workers across the state.

headline: Calling Dr. Fauci
abstract: Our interview with the nation’s top infectious disease specialist.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, our team has talked about trying to interview Dr. Anthony Fauci, our guest on Thursday’s show, about the coronavirus pandemic. He’s a unique figure in this crisis: a 30-year student of global epidemics, from H.I.V. to H1N1; a member of President Trump’s coronavirus task force; and one of two doctors, along with Dr. Deborah Birx, assigned by the White House to explain this emergency to the public through daily briefings and interviews.

headline: How Do You Make a Less Toxic Blue Dye? Start With Red Beets
abstract: Usually these root vegetables cause pink stains, but with a little bit of chemistry, Brazilian researchers found they could produce another hue.
lead_paragraph: Blue is the color of clear skies and open water. It conjures calm. But it’s not easy being blue. It’s not the easiest color to make, either.

headline: In the American South, a Perfect Storm Is Gathering
abstract: In states with many uninsured citizens, few hospitals and leaders who have not required citizens to stay home, a disaster is looming.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — On March 22, when Nashville’s mayor John Cooper closed nonessential businesses here, it was a terrible blow to companies and shops still reeling from the tornado that tore through Middle Tennessee on Super Tuesday. Small businesses struggle in the best of times, and a one-two punch like that — a natural disaster followed by a lethal pandemic — will almost certainly force some of them to close for good.

headline: A Debate Over Masks Uncovers Deep White House Divisions
abstract: The Trump administration remains deeply divided over whether to tell all Americans to cover their faces in public to stop the spread of coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Friday that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was urging all Americans to wear a mask when they leave their homes, but he immediately undercut the message by repeatedly calling the recommendation voluntary and promising that he would not wear one himself.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The C.D.C. advised all Americans, even those who appear to be healthy, to wear a mask when they leave home.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advised all Americans — even people who appear to be healthy — to cover their face with a mask or a scarf when they leave home to help slow the spread of the coronavirus in the United States.

headline: Are Countries Flattening the Curve for the Coronavirus?
abstract: These charts show the pandemic’s trajectory in each nation. New cases appear to be leveling off in some places, but they may still be far from a slowdown.
lead_paragraph: These charts show the pandemic’s trajectory in each nation. New cases appear to be leveling off in some places, but they may still be far from a slowdown.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Toll Soars to Nearly 3,000 as State Pleads for Aid
abstract: “It is hard to put fully into words what we are all grappling with as we navigate our way through this pandemic,” a hospital official said.
lead_paragraph: New York, the increasingly battered epicenter of the nation’s coronavirus outbreak, on Friday reported its highest number of deaths in a single day, prompting state officials to beg the rest of the United States for assistance and to enact an emergency order designed to stave off medical catastrophe.

headline: Covid-19: A Look Back From 2025
abstract: In which the coronavirus has changed almost everything.

headline: Does My County Have an Epidemic? Estimates Show Hidden Transmission
abstract: Even counties that have few reported cases probably already have sustained, undetected outbreaks, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: Even counties that have few reported cases probably already have sustained, undetected outbreaks, a study finds.

headline: Tensions Persist Between Trump and Medical Advisers Over the Coronavirus
abstract: The president’s public refusal to wear a mask was the latest way he has cast doubt on their recommendations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rarely has the schism between President Trump and his own public health advisers over the coronavirus pandemic been put on display quite so starkly. Even as he announced a new federal recommendation on Friday that Americans wear masks when out in public, he immediately disavowed it: “I am choosing not to do it.”

headline: Coronavirus Models Offer the Big Picture, Not the Details of What May Come
abstract: Ontario and British Columbia have both released their projections about what the pandemic will bring. But, like a weather forecast, they are ever-shifting predictions.
lead_paragraph: Ontario followed British Columbia on Friday by releasing its projections for what may lie ahead in those provinces with the coronavirus.

headline: A Bit of Relief: Introducing ‘Sugar Calling’
abstract: In this excerpt from a new Times podcast, Cheryl Strayed calls up author George Saunders, her old friend and mentor.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: There Is No Way Out but Through
abstract: We are connected to one another and to generations past and future.
lead_paragraph: My sister, who lives in London, has been passing lockdown time going through old slides of my father’s, discovered last year. Every now and then she sends me a grainy or mildewed photograph, a message in a bottle from across the ocean. The pandemic has prompted a universal time of reflection. The past, more present, is the new field of exploration, absent movement.

headline: Administration Turns to Private Firms to Help Process Small Business Aid
abstract: The Small Business Administration is hiring companies, some with political connections, to ensure it can handle the flood of applications for help in the wake of the economy’s stall.
lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]

headline: Make T Something | Mary Ping
abstract: The designer Mary Ping devises a crafty accessory using just six objects (plus one wild-card pick).
lead_paragraph: The designer Mary Ping devises a crafty accessory using just six objects (plus one wild-card pick).

headline: Operate On With a Beam
abstract: Don’t worry, this Yacob Yonas puzzle won’t hurt a bit.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We’ve seen Yacob Yonas’s work before, but only in collaboration. Today’s grid is fairly quick and sunny for a Saturday, but there are several good new terms, and I could see the configuration making problems for solvers if anyone got stumped in a corner. Maybe I just got lucky? There’s certainly a lot to like in the cluing, some wry humor and some interesting bits and pieces. That LAB sneaked up on me!

headline: Rangers Prospect K’Andre Miller Faces Racial Abuse in a Team Video Chat
abstract: After the chat, the Rangers and the N.H.L. condemned the repeated use of a slur by a hacker.
lead_paragraph: K’Andre Miller, a top prospect for the Rangers, was repeatedly subjected to a racial slur when a team-sponsored online video chat was hacked on Friday.

headline: Trump to Fire Intelligence Watchdog Who Had Key Role in Ukraine Complaint
abstract: The president notified lawmakers late on Friday, saying he had lost confidence in the inspector general for the intelligence community.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is firing the intelligence community inspector general whose insistence on telling lawmakers about a whistle-blower complaint about his dealings with Ukraine triggered impeachment proceedings last fall, the president told lawmakers in a letter late Friday.

headline: Corrections: April 4, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 4, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about President Trump’s support for a possible oil deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia misstated the amount of the recent stimulus package. It was $2.2 trillion, not $2.2 billion.

headline: Barr Expands Early Release of Inmates at Prisons Seeing More Coronavirus Cases
abstract: The attorney general directed the Bureau of Prisons to prioritize the early release of some prisoners from federal correctional institutions in Louisiana, Connecticut and Ohio.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr ordered the Bureau of Prisons on Friday to expand the group of federal inmates eligible for early release and to prioritize those at three facilities where known coronavirus cases have grown precipitously, as the virus threatens to overwhelm prison medical facilities and nearby hospitals.

headline: Trump Warns of ‘a Lot of Death’ While Also Revisiting Easter Sunday Services
abstract: President Trump warns of what could be “the toughest week,” while also saying he would like to consider relaxing social distancing rules for Easter services.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read our global live coverage on the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Good Boys’ and ‘Money Heist’
abstract: A raunchy comedy comes to HBO, while a Spanish crime series returns on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: GOOD BOYS (2019) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg, the producers behind comedies like “Superbad,” “Sausage Party” and “This Is the End,” lend their irreverent, slapstick brand to this R-rated comedy. When sixth grader Max (Jacob Tremblay) gets invited to a party where he may run into his crush, he sets out on learning how to kiss with the help of his best friends, Lucas (Keith L. Williams) and Thor (Brady Noon). The trouble starts when they spy on the teenage girls next door with Max’s father’s drone. What follows is one misadventure after another, involving drugs, sex toys, frat boys and a whole lot of cursing. “Good Boys” opened to generally positive reviews last summer. Most critics praised the young leads but said the movie relied too heavily on crass humor — which may not sit well with those who think foul-mouthed children can only be so funny.

headline: Soccer’s Coming Storm
abstract: Players who won’t take pay cuts. Clubs seeking government handouts. Coronavirus is exposing the schisms that will trouble soccer, a world with plenty of money but little trust, long after the crisis abates.
lead_paragraph: Sign up for Rory Smith’s weekly newsletter on world soccer (and, for the foreseeable future, quite a few other topics) at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: The $200 Million the Olympics Postponement Took From Team U.S.A.
abstract: The Summer Olympics in Tokyo have been postponed a year. That means nearly $200 million in funding, which American athletes depend on for living and training expenses, likely won’t arrive until next August.
lead_paragraph: Wallace Spearmon, a two-time Olympian in track and field, got what he wanted when the International Olympic Committee finally bowed to pressure from athletes and national Olympic organizations and postponed the 2020 Tokyo Games for a year.

headline: Telemedicine Arrives in the U.K.: ‘10 Years of Change in One Week’
abstract: With the coronavirus pandemic turning doctors’ offices into no-go zones, family physicians are now doing many of their consultations online or by telephone.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A housebound 92-year-old man had red, throbbing legs. A younger patient was complaining of a lump in his armpit. And the self-isolating residents of a nursing home needed checkups.

headline: Memories of the 1918 Pandemic From Those Who Survived
abstract: Oral histories tell the stories of “garages full of caskets” during an influenza strain that killed at least a half-million Americans.
lead_paragraph: Nearly everyone who survived the 1918 flu pandemic, which claimed at least half a million American lives, has since died. But their memories, preserved in oral history interviews, shed light on its indelible impact. Bustling major cities and rural towns were brought to their knees, as transportation, law enforcement, commerce and civic life were wiped out.

headline: For the Asking, Quarantine-Approved Dates
abstract: For couples who are self-quarantined together or practicing social distancing apart because of the coronavirus, dancing, cooking and gaming are just a few ways to spend some quality time.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Ellie Reed, 19, of Oxfordshire, England, drove about 10 miles to the home of her boyfriend, Jordan Cadman, where their Domino’s Pizza delivery would soon arrive — a pepperoni and sweet corn pie for her, and a Texas BBQ pie for him. Then, in separate cars, the couple drove another five miles to a canal, parked about six feet from one another, rolled down their windows and ate together, yet apart.

headline: How a Chinese-American Novelist Wrote Herself Into the Wild West
abstract: C Pam Zhang’s debut, “How Much of These Hills Is Gold,” is one of several new or forthcoming books by Asian-American writers set in a period that historically hasn’t recognized them.
lead_paragraph: The day in 2015 that C Pam Zhang was laid off from her first job out of college, she celebrated with friends at the park, then promptly made plans to move to Bangkok.

headline: Modi Denies India Is Targeting Muslims. We Found a Different Reality.
abstract: How can someone who’s lived for years as a citizen of India suddenly be declared illegal? Whistle-blowers told us how Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party is making Muslims stateless.
lead_paragraph: How can someone who’s lived for years as a citizen of India suddenly be declared illegal? Whistle-blowers told us how Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party is making Muslims stateless.

headline: He Needs Jobless Benefits. He Was Told to Find a Fax Machine.
abstract: Thousands of newly unemployed New Yorkers desperate to stay afloat are being frustrated by the state’s 1970s-era technology.
lead_paragraph: Mohammed Saiful Islam got a taste of how antiquated the technology that runs New York State’s unemployment-insurance system is when he had to go to a Staples store in the middle of a pandemic to fax his pay stubs to Albany.

headline: When the Face of America Falls Ill: A Virus’s Toll on Diplomats
abstract: State Department employees are vulnerable and stressed by the coronavirus as it sweeps around the world, prompting thousands of American citizens to return to the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The symptoms were more annoying than alarming: A dry cough, achiness and then sniffles developed a few days after Andrew Young, the American ambassador to Burkina Faso, met with government officials and aid organizations to discuss how to protect the West African nation from the coronavirus.

headline: Can You Lead in a Pandemic Without Picking Sides? Greg Abbott Is Trying
abstract: The Texas governor hasn’t defied President Trump, like some of his fellow Republican governors have. He also hasn’t ignored public health recommendations. He’s aiming for crisis management that doesn’t rock the boat.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, in a public service announcement filmed in his wood-paneled office, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas gestured toward his most recent executive order propped up in front of him, one that Democrats, health care professionals, and a growing number of Republicans in the state had been clamoring for. Beginning that day, he said, all Texans were required to “stay at home, except to provide essential services or do essential things, like going to the grocery store.”

headline: ‘Muslims Are Foreigners’: Inside India’s Campaign to Decide Who Is a Citizen
abstract: Tribunal members in the state of Assam say they felt pressured to declare Muslims noncitizens as the government seeks to expel illegal migrants. Some politicians have vowed to take the process nationwide.
lead_paragraph: JORHAT, India — For nearly two years, Mamoni Rajkumari, a lawyer, spent her days deciding who was an Indian citizen and who was not, as part of a tribunal reviewing suspected foreigners in the state of Assam. Then, she says, she was dismissed for not declaring enough Muslims to be noncitizens.

headline: The Killer Flu of 1918: A Philadelphia Story
abstract: The brutal toll taken by the flu that claimed 20,000 lives in the city has not been forgotten as Philadelphia braces for the worst of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — At Sunday family dinners, the grandchildren would beg to hear that story again, the one about her twins in the baby carriage, and one of them was dead, and what did she do. This was when Sarah Jane Anderson would add to the collective memory of a Philadelphia nightmare.

headline: In Italy, Going Back to Work May Depend on Having the Right Antibodies
abstract: Weighing an idea that might once have been relegated to science fiction, Italy once again finds itself in the unfortunate vanguard of Western democracies grappling with the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: ROME — There is a growing sense in Italy that the worst may have passed. The weeks of locking down the country, center of the world’s deadliest coronavirus outbreak, may be starting to pay off, as officials announced this week that the numbers of new infections had plateaued.

headline: Larry David, Master of His Quarantine
abstract: Who better than the father of “Seinfeld” and “Curb Your Enthusiasm” to guide us through the thicket of being together, alone?
lead_paragraph: Our lives now depend on staying home and doing nothing.

headline: College Made Them Feel Equal. The Virus Exposed How Unequal Their Lives Are.
abstract: When they were all in the same dorms and eating the same dining hall food, the disparities in students’ backgrounds weren’t as clear as they are over video chat.
lead_paragraph: The political science class was called “Forced Migration and Refugees.” Students read accounts of migrants fleeing broken economies and seeking better futures, of life plans drastically altered and the political forces that made it all seem necessary.

headline: The Growing Culture of Secrecy at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The war court where the men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks are on trial operates under classification rules that are inconsistent, complex and sometimes absurd.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: ‘Dear Customers’: These Are the Emotional Store Signs of a Closed New York
abstract: From newly darkened storefronts, businesses offered a few last words of empathy, resolve and humor.
lead_paragraph: All along the empty streets of Manhattan, the messages reach out from the newly darkened storefronts. The notes express empathy, resolve, concern, even humor — a reflection of New York’s spirit.

headline: Photos: In Rural Towns and on Remote Farms, the Virus Creeps In
abstract: In places where social distancing was already a way of life, the relentless pandemic has begun to reshape the economy.
lead_paragraph: John Maley’s 28,000-acre ranch sits on the eastern edge of Steens Mountain Wilderness, a sprawling high desert in a remote corner of southeastern Oregon that’s thick in season with sagebrush, juniper and mountain mahogany.

headline: U.K. Labour Party Has a New Leader: Keir Starmer
abstract: Mr. Starmer will have to battle for visibility at a time when the coronavirus crisis is eclipsing all other news and Prime Minister Boris Johnson is commanding the headlines.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Keir Starmer first emerged in early January as the front-runner to lead Britain’s Labour Party, the best he could hope for, it seemed, was to spend years in the political wilderness, opposing a Conservative prime minister, Boris Johnson, who won a landslide majority in Parliament.

headline: A German Exception? Why the Country’s Coronavirus Death Rate Is Low
abstract: The pandemic has hit Germany hard, with more than 100,000 people infected. But the percentage of fatal cases has been remarkably low compared to those in many neighboring countries.
lead_paragraph: They call them corona taxis: Medics outfitted in protective gear, driving around the empty streets of Heidelberg to check on patients who are at home, five or six days into being sick with the coronavirus.

headline: The Rise of Virtual Races
abstract: Runners may be running alone, but they can still feel as if they’re part of a larger group.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: How to Keep Kids Safe Online
abstract: A hasty primer. And, more new Parenting stories.
lead_paragraph: I barely knew that Facebook’s Messenger Kids app existed before the pandemic. We are pretty open to devices in my household, but if you had asked me about it, I would have said that my 7-year-old could wait a few more years to enter the social media ThunderDome. But that was before she had been separated from all her friends for the foreseeable future.

headline: Coronavirus Hot Spots Emerging Near New York City
abstract: Governor Cuomo compared a jump in coronavirus cases on Long Island to “a fire spreading,” and New Jersey announced an additional 200 deaths due to the virus since Friday.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Sunday’s live coverage.]

headline: 2 Killed in Knife Attack in French Town Under Lockdown
abstract: A Sudanese man was detained as a suspect in the attack on bystanders in Romans-sur-Isère in what officials described as potentially a terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In what was described as a potential terrorist attack, a knife-wielding man killed two people and wounded five others on Saturday morning in a town in southern France with only a few shops open under a national lockdown to stem the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: 430,000 People Have Traveled From China to U.S. Since Coronavirus Surfaced
abstract: There were 1,300 direct flights to 17 cities before President Trump’s travel restrictions. Since then, nearly 40,000 Americans and other authorized travelers have made the trip, some this past week and many with spotty screening.
lead_paragraph: Since Chinese officials disclosed the outbreak of a mysterious pneumonialike illness to international health officials on New Year’s Eve, at least 430,000 people have arrived in the United States on direct flights from China, including nearly 40,000 in the two months after President Trump imposed restrictions on such travel, according to an analysis of data collected in both countries.

headline: How Black Girls Get Pushed Out of School
abstract: The debate about the school-to-prison pipeline has largely been centered on boys. Meet the author and academic who has worked to change that.
lead_paragraph: The tiny voice sent shock waves across the nation. “What are those for?” the 6-year-old girl asked the police officer who pulled out zip ties that he would soon fasten around her wrists.

headline: A Tennis Coach Was Abusing Minors. Should the Sport’s Federation Have Known?
abstract: The United States Tennis Association has asserted it can police itself when it comes to abuse cases. The story of one coach raises doubts.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Calif. — At a meeting in Chicago in September 2014, the head of the United States Olympic Committee took note that  a new initiative to protect athletes from abusers had support from every sport’s governing body except one: the United States Tennis Association.

headline: Just When They’re Needed Most, Clinics for the Poor Face Drastic Cutbacks
abstract: Clinics that treat the poor and uninsured are facing hard times just when they are most needed. The coronavirus pandemic has depleted their revenues.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Providers of health care in the nation’s poorest neighborhoods are used to toiling below the radar, treating chronic diseases and other ravages of poverty in places many Americans never see.

headline: Edward Feightner, Test Pilot and World War II Ace, Dies at 100
abstract: Admiral Feightner played a leading role in the development of the Navy’s postwar jets.
lead_paragraph: Rear Adm. Edward L. Feightner, a Navy air ace of World War II who shot down nine Japanese planes while flying propeller-driven fighters, then played a prominent role in the testing and development of postwar Navy jets, died on Wednesday in Coeur d’Alene, Idaho. He was 100.

headline: 31 Slow Cooker Recipes to Cook All Day
abstract: Slow cooker white bean Parmesan soup, BBQ pulled pork, and many more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Here are more than two dozen recipes to cook in the slow cooker while you’re doing other things — or nothing at all! You could make white bean Parmesan soup (above), chicken tortellini tomato soup, BBQ pulled pork, or any of the recipes in the collection below.

headline: Bill Withers’s 10 Overlooked Songs
abstract: The soulful singer with a gift for writing understated classics has died at 81. Beyond his hits (“Lean on Me,” “Ain’t No Sunshine”) is a trove of lesser-known gems.
lead_paragraph: Bill Withers always sounded like he was strumming the guitar from a seat at his kitchen table — or maybe, at his most luxurious, an easy chair in the living room.

headline: OPEC Meeting Is Delayed as Saudi and Russian Tensions Flare
abstract: The meeting, planned for Monday, had buoyed hopes for a quick deal to end the turmoil in oil markets.
lead_paragraph: A meeting planned for Monday between officials of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Russia and other oil producers, which had buoyed hopes for a deal to end the turmoil in energy markets, has been put off, according to two OPEC delegates.

headline: How Many Coronavirus Cases Are in Each California County?
abstract: Saturday: A special edition of California Today.
lead_paragraph: (Here’s the sign-up, if you don’t already get California Today delivered to your inbox.)

headline: A Quarantined Uber Driver’s Quest for Paid Sick Leave
abstract: Zachary Frenette spent about two weeks fighting to get help under a new Uber policy. It worked, but only after he got the news media involved.
lead_paragraph: Zachary Frenette likes working as an Uber driver in Phoenix. He is a top-rated driver who often chats with his customers on their trips.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Andy Kravis makes his cryptic debut in comedic collaboration with Andrew J. Ries.
lead_paragraph: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Most of the Puns and Anagrams puzzles we get now are from Andrew J. Ries, who does a bang-up job with them, but I was happy to see the addition of Andy Kravis to the mix. He and another constructor, Natan Last, run a class at the Jewish Association Serving the Aging that teaches crossword construction and produces occasional daily crossword grids for the Times that are always hilarious and quirky. Today’s puzzle has some class-clown elements that make me think of those puzzles, and Mr. Kravis.

headline: Keeping Bill Withers Alive
abstract: The three-time Grammy Award winning artist has died. In this moment of isolation, I wanted to see him alive again. And I did.
lead_paragraph: Even before a pandemic caused this endless ache for the community of the outside world; before the puddles on my city block no longer reflected the buzzy lights from open shops at night; and before I spoke to everyone I loved through a parade of various screens (“Zooms,” “Hangouts,” “FaceTimes”), I had gotten in the habit of watching old concert videos in the mornings.

headline: The Hollowness of ‘This, Too, Shall Pass’
abstract: Black women have been telling one another that things will get better for generations. Then came the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not sure if I should go to dance class,” my niece said. This was on March 14, when it still seemed possible that life could return to normal. She is in middle school and has gone to the same Saturday dance class for nearly a decade. She spoke casually, but we knew what she meant. She wasn’t sure, for the first time, whether it was safe.

headline: What You Should Know Before You Need a Ventilator
abstract: It breaks my heart that patients who will get sick enough to need them won’t know what desperate situations they face.
lead_paragraph: Day by day, as the number of Covid-19 deaths soar, we see more clearly that many of us will not survive this storm.

headline: The Military Should Airlift New York City’s Coronavirus Patients
abstract: Its hospitals are overcrowded and other cities have capacity.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the start of the Cold War, the Soviets blockaded the roads, railways and canals leading to West Berlin in 1948. Overnight, some two million people were cut off from food and fuel. The Western allies panicked, but under the leadership of President Harry Truman, the crisis was solved with the Berlin Airlift.

headline: On the Streets of Los Angeles
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has highlighted how vulnerable the homeless population is.
