headline: What Will Tomorrow’s Workplace Bring? More Elbow Room, for Starters
abstract: The pandemic may result in fundamental changes, altering how office buildings are designed. In the short term, expect more hand sanitizer and less “hot-desking.”
lead_paragraph: Many Americans are weeks, if not months, from returning to their offices and regaining a semblance of a normal workday. Given the recent layoff and furlough announcements, many are wondering whether they will even have a job after the dust settles.

headline: Tiny Digital Businesses Play Key Role in Local Economies, Study Says
abstract: A new study examines the millions of small digital businesses. They could help many communities weather the economic blow from the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.

headline: Japan Declared a Coronavirus Emergency. Is It Too Late?
abstract: Some medical experts said the move amounted to a tacit admission that the approach the country had adopted for months was no longer working.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For months, Japan has confounded the world by reporting a relatively low rate of coronavirus infections without imposing the kind of stringent measures used by other nations.

headline: Why a California Lawmaker Is Pushing to Change Plasma Donation Rules
abstract: Tuesday: Scott Wiener, a state senator, is calling on the F.D.A. to end what he said are discriminatory restrictions on gay and bisexual men.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Cardinal Pell’s Acquittal Was as Opaque as His Sexual Abuse Trial
abstract: Critics argue that Australia’s courts exhibited a penchant for secrecy and insular decision-making that resembled the Roman Catholic Church’s flawed response to sexual abuse within its ranks.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Cardinal George Pell walked out of prison on Tuesday after Australia’s highest court reversed his 2018 conviction for molesting two choirboys decades earlier — liberating the most senior Roman Catholic cleric to ever face trial over child sexual abuse.

headline: Weekly News Quiz for Students: C.D.C. Recommendation, Jobless Claims, N.C.A.A.
abstract: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

headline: Embracing the Uncertainties
abstract: While the unknowns about coronavirus abound, a new study finds we ‘can handle the truth.’
lead_paragraph: These are, safe to say, uncertain times.

headline: How to Celebrate a Birthday During the Coronavirus Shutdown
abstract: Stay-at-home orders don’t have to put a damper on your special day.
lead_paragraph: It became clear in mid-March that my birthday plans for the end of the month had to be canceled. After a quick self-pity session my focus shifted from what I’d be losing (happy hour with my friends at my favorite dim sum spot, a haircut with my favorite stylist, a massage) to what I could control about the day. After all, my birthday may have been marred by the coronavirus shutdown, but with the great pain being experienced by the world, now also felt like a great time to celebrate life.

headline: It Came From Outside Our Solar System and Now It’s Breaking Up
abstract: Comet Borisov, only the second interstellar object spotted by astronomers, shed at least one big chunk as it rounded our sun.
lead_paragraph: It came from beyond our solar system. But the sun wasn’t content to let it leave in peace, or in one piece.

headline: ‘The Addams Family’ Musical Was Panned. Then It Became a Hit.
abstract: A rare show that retooled and flourished after its New York debut, the musical, a decade later, has endured in schools and through international productions.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway reviews for “The Addams Family” were gruesome — the kind of notices that, in theory, could kill a show.

headline: Acting Navy Secretary Resigns After Outcry Over Criticism of Virus-Stricken Crew
abstract: Thomas B. Modly’s departure is the latest in a string of events that engulfed the Navy in a public relations disaster.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thomas B. Modly, the acting Navy secretary, resigned Tuesday after his bungled response to an outbreak of the novel coronavirus aboard the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt engulfed the Navy in a command crisis and a public relations disaster.

headline: Meet Your Meme Lords
abstract: A small team at the Library of Congress is archiving internet culture as fast as it can (now, from home).
lead_paragraph: Future researchers can rest easy: Know Your Meme, Urban Dictionary, Creepypasta and Cute Overload have all been preserved by the Library of Congress. So has the band website for They Might Be Giants and the entire published output of The Toast, the humor site that shut down in 2016.

headline: The Obie Awards Go Online. The Money Saved Goes to Artists.
abstract: Because of the coronavirus pandemic, the annual ceremony honoring Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway theater will be digital-only for the first time since being established in 1956.
lead_paragraph: The Obie Awards, an annual ceremony honoring the best New York theater work performed Off and Off Off Broadway, will go virtual this year, forced online by the coronavirus pandemic that has caused the cancellation of in-person gatherings.

headline: Crew Member Aboard U.S.N.S. Comfort Is Infected With Coronavirus
abstract: The news was the latest setback in the ship’s troubled mission to New York.
lead_paragraph: A crew member aboard the Navy hospital ship U.S.N.S. Comfort tested positive for the coronavirus, and several others have gone into isolation, the Navy said on Tuesday, the latest setback in the ship’s troubled mission to New York to assist in the response to the pandemic.

headline: Easter Delivery From Adam Leonti’s Latest Project
abstract: Sofia’s Panificio e Vino was to open last month, but with the pandemic, it started with a holiday menu for takeout and delivery.
lead_paragraph: This is not the time to embark on a new restaurant project. But Adam Leonti, whose recent career has had its share of disruptive events, is forging ahead with one.

headline: Dua Lipa’s Unplanned, Uncertain, Unprecedented Album Launch
abstract: The English pop star spent years preparing to release her anticipated second LP, “Future Nostalgia.” Should she — and could she — do it during a pandemic?
lead_paragraph: Dua Lipa looked away from the camera and covered her face with a manicured hand. “I really didn’t want to do this,” she half-whispered. She failed to muffle a major sniffle.

headline: Is This the Most Virus-Proof Job in the World?
abstract: Pro video game streamers are used to spending their days in isolation. And a huge new audience is at home to watch them play.
lead_paragraph: Ben Lupo sat in his basement in Omaha one recent afternoon, trying to kill a brigade of heavily armed Russians before they killed him.

headline: Trump Has a New Press Secretary Who Knows How to Defend Him
abstract: Kayleigh McEnany, his campaign spokeswoman, replaces Stephanie Grisham, who had the job for nine months, and will return to Melania Trump’s staff.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In President Trump’s early days in the White House, Kayleigh McEnany made a name for herself by defending him on CNN, a network where he has few allies. As a Trump campaign aide, she became a fixture at his political rallies. And on Tuesday, she was named White House press secretary, capping a journey toward the center of the president’s orbit.

headline: How to Prevent ‘Zoombombing’ in a Few Easy Steps
abstract: There are a few things you can do to make your video conferences more secure.
lead_paragraph: As Zoom’s user base has grown in recent weeks, reports of “Zoombombing,” or “Zoom raiding,” have spread across the internet.

headline: Ramen (and Udon) Available for Home
abstract: These spots across New York City are offering noodle dishes for takeout and delivery. Just order the noodles on the side.
lead_paragraph: Instant ramen is one thing. What sets serious ramen apart is the deeply flavored, long-simmered broth, infusing all the components — vegetables, meats, eggs, tofu, seasonings and of course, noodles — with soulful richness. But even if you have ample time for leisurely cooking, would you have a pot of tonkotsu broth bubbling away with pork bones on the back of the stove for many hours, or the right cut of pork belly for marinating, simmering and making chashu, to say nothing of slices of Japanese rice cake? The alternative is ordering ramen from the experts, for delivery or pickup. Consider requesting that the noodles be packed separately, so you can boil them in your kitchen and add them to the dishes. Here are some ramen places — and udon specialists — that provide noodles to enjoy at home:

headline: ‘How Much of These Hills Is Gold,’ by C Pam Zhang: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “How Much of These Hills Is Gold,” by C Pam Zhang
lead_paragraph: Ba dies in the night, prompting them to seek two silver dollars.

headline: Outdoor Oysters and Beer? Still on Ice, With Summer Nowhere in Sight
abstract: Warm-weather food businesses are putting their plans, and many of their workers, on hold.
lead_paragraph: The Sherman Zwicker, a 78-year-old wooden fishing schooner, returned to New York City at the end of March after spending the winter in dry dock in Connecticut, having parts of its hull replanked by shipwrights at the Mystic Seaport Museum. With some fresh paint, a new awning and a load of supplies, the schooner would be ready to cruise to Pier 25 in Hudson River Park, where every year since 2014 it has operated as an outdoor oyster bar called Grand Banks.

headline: With Games Paused, Sports Companies Shift to Making Medical Supplies
abstract: Formula One teams are producing CPAP machines for patients, while several sporting goods businesses are making personal protective equipment for health care workers.
lead_paragraph: At a pub in London last month, shortly before Britain ordered its citizens to stay home, a small group of life savers shared drinks. It included Rebecca Shipley, a professor of health care engineering at University College London, her U.C.L. colleague, Tim Baker, a former racecar engineer, and some intensive care unit physicians.

headline: A Home Version of Trisha Brown’s ‘Roof Piece,’ No Roof Required
abstract: Communication across distance is the essential component of this 1971 dance, Brown’s company has found. You and your friends can try, too.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be a big year for the Trisha Brown Dance Company, founded 50 years ago. In early March, the troupe flew to France to begin a sold-out anniversary tour. The first few shows went great. Then came the wave of coronavirus cancellations, and the dancers found themselves on the last American Airlines flight from Paris to New York.

headline: Blowtorch of the Gods Captured by Black Hole Image Makers
abstract: Astronomers have given us a look into the engine compartment of a quasar.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers said Tuesday that they had for the first time seen a black hole spitting fire from the heart of a distant quasar. The work, by the same team that produced the first image of a black hole last year, illuminates the workings of one of the mysterious fountains of energy that dot deepest space and have tantalized astronomers with their ferocious energies ever since they were discovered more than 50 years ago.

headline: Albert Petrocelli, Fire Chief Who Lost a Son on 9/11, Dies at 73
abstract: He and a firefighter son answered the call when terrorists attacked the World Trade Center; another son died there. Mr. Petrocelli had the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: It’s a TikTok! No, It’s a Song! Drake and the Viral Feedback Loop
abstract: “Toosie Slide” is one of a few new hip-hop songs that weren’t songs first — they were ideas spreading on social media.
lead_paragraph: Drake’s new single “Toosie Slide” was released on Friday, but that’s only if you think of a song’s release in an old-fashioned way — which is to say, a full song and an accompanying official video put out by the artist himself.

headline: Who the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: In a sense, the game of golf was almost beside the point for the Hall of Famer ISAO Aoki. He took up the game as a way to see the world. It paid off in more ways than one: “Mr. Aoki won 71 times around the world on six different tours, and in 2004 became the first Japanese male golfer to be inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame,” according to the World Golf Hall of Fame.

headline: Coronavirus Puts to the Fore an Improbable U.K. Leader: Dominic Raab
abstract: With Prime Minister Boris Johnson in intensive care, the untested foreign secretary is for now guiding Britain through one of its greatest peacetime crises.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last year, when the stalemate over Brexit was dominating the agenda, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain appointed Dominic Raab, the foreign secretary, as his deputy and next-in-line.

headline: China Ends Wuhan Lockdown, but Normal Life Is a Distant Dream
abstract: In the city where the coronavirus outbreak was first reported, the reopening of outbound travel won’t end hard times, wariness or confinement.
lead_paragraph: China on Wednesday ended its lockdown of Wuhan, the city where the coronavirus first emerged and a potent symbol in a pandemic that has killed tens of thousands of people, shaken the global economy and thrown daily life into upheaval across the planet.

headline: Passover Under Lockdown: Israeli Jews Revise the Rituals
abstract: Why is this night different from all other nights? Israelis celebrate a festival of freedom under isolation and shelter-in-place orders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Singing outdoors. Participating remotely in a relative’s Zoom Seder. Leaving apartment doors open so solitary neighbors can hear the recitations.

headline: 12 Places to Watch Dance Online
abstract: If you’ve ever wanted to learn more about dance, now is a good time to explore. Here are some places to begin.
lead_paragraph: Dance is a medium best experienced in person, but it can be inaccessible: You have to show up at a certain place and time, often with an expensive ticket in hand.

headline: Afghan Prisoner Swap Hits Wall as Taliban Pull Out of Talks
abstract: Discussions with insurgents in Kabul unraveled as Afghan officials refused to include senior Taliban commanders in the first batch of prisoners to be released.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A week of talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban on a prisoner swap — seen as crucial to preserving a fragile peace deal between the insurgents and the United States — appeared to be collapsing on Tuesday, as Taliban leaders ordered their team to pull out of the discussions.

headline: How to Look Good on Camera, According to Tom Ford
abstract: A master class in lighting for your next video conference.
lead_paragraph: Put the computer up on a stack of books so the camera is slightly higher than your head. Say, about the top of your head. And then point it down into your eyes.

headline: Paris Installs a Curfew on Outdoor Sports
abstract: Plus: Could sporting events be held on islands without fans? The National Rugby League in Australia, the Big3 and the U.F.C. are considering it.
lead_paragraph: Like many cities, Paris has lost a little bit of its magic during the coronavirus lockdown, with cafes, theaters and shops closed.

headline: Five Swipes on Stress Management
abstract: Here are three steps to help you harness stress to improve your health and well-being.
lead_paragraph: Here are three steps to help you harness stress to improve your health and well-being.

headline: Kids Won’t Stop Fighting? A Bouncer, a Therapist and a Referee Have Advice
abstract: These conflict resolution experts know how to stop fights before and after they start. But would their techniques work on my brawling twins?
lead_paragraph: What do a bar bouncer, kindergarten teacher, hockey referee, marriage and family therapist, and police officer all have in common? They know how to break up a fight.

headline: Garlicky Braised Greens for When That Vegetable Craving Hits
abstract: This brothy, flavorful dish may be just what you’re looking for after all those baking projects and beans.
lead_paragraph: A big bowl of garlicky, soupy greens is what I craved today, probably my body’s natural response to all the poundcake and cookies I’ve been obsessively baking. So I took a deep breath, looked out the window at the blossoming trees, and cooked something green.

headline: ‘What Rhymes With Purell?’ Franglais Rappers Push Language Boundaries in Quebec
abstract: Critics in Montreal say hip-hop artists mixing French and English are threatening the future of the French language in the majority Francophone province.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — As pungent pot smoke filled the air in a bunkerlike, dimly lit basement recording studio in Montreal, the Quebec rapper Snail Kid pondered a question befitting these pandemic times: What word rhymes with Purell?

headline: Passover Goes On, With Screens
abstract: Religious families lean on technology this month to recreate disrupted rituals.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Boris Johnson vs. the Coronavirus
abstract: With the prime minister of Britain in intensive care, Covid-19 has created a vacuum.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Boris Johnson’s war with the coronavirus has turned personal. When the prime minister was admitted to intensive care with severe symptoms on Monday night, it was a reminder to Britons that like it or not, we are all in this together.

headline: Trump Ousts Pandemic Spending Watchdog Known for Independence
abstract: The official had been leading the office of the inspector general for the Pentagon. In removing him from that role, the president stripped him of his pandemic relief oversight duties as well.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump moved on Tuesday to oust the leader of a new watchdog panel charged with overseeing how his administration spends trillions of taxpayer dollars in coronavirus pandemic relief, the latest step in an abruptly unfolding White House power play against semi-independent inspectors general across the government.

headline: How a Luxury Hotel on Billionaires’ Row Became a Dorm for Hospital Workers
abstract: The Four Seasons reinvented itself in a matter of days.
lead_paragraph: Just a few weeks ago, it was typical for personal assistants to make reservations for thousand-dollar rooms at the Four Seasons Hotel New York for their high-profile bosses.

headline: Special April Challenge: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Month?
abstract: Explore NYTimes.com and tell us what you read, watched or listened to and why. Times judges will then pick favorite responses to honor.
lead_paragraph: Update, May 14: Judges have selected their favorite comments.

headline: 21 Things Teenagers Can Do With a New York Times Subscription
abstract: From April 6 to July 6, The Times is providing free digital access to all high school students and teachers in the United States. If you’ve never explored NYTimes.com before, here are some things we offer that might surprise you.
lead_paragraph: Update, Sept. 2020: Students in U.S. high schools can get free digital access to The New York Times until Sept. 2021.

headline: China Investigates Critic of Xi’s Coronavirus Response
abstract: The decision to investigate the tycoon, Ren Zhiqiang, reflects broad unease in the government about growing criticism of its early efforts to conceal the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese Communist Party said on Tuesday that it was investigating an outspoken property tycoon who accused China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, of having mishandled the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: They Turned Out to Vote in Wisconsin During a Health Crisis. Here’s Why.
abstract: Voters in Milwaukee and across the state braved long lines and a risk of illness. Many said they wanted their voices to be heard. But for some, the potential health risk was too great.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — After days of legal wrangling, partisan mudslinging and grave warnings from public health professionals, Wisconsin forged ahead with its elections on Tuesday, the first state to hold in-person voting during the height of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: F.A.Q. on Coronavirus Relief for Small Businesses, Freelancers and More
abstract: Many small companies and nonprofits are eligible for federal grants and low-interest loans. But red tape abounds.
lead_paragraph: The federal stimulus bills enacted last month, including a bipartisan $2 trillion economic relief plan, offer help for the millions of American small businesses affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Why Wisconsin Republicans Insisted on an Election in a Pandemic
abstract: Mask-wearing voters in endless lines. Five polling places instead of 180. Voting amid the coronavirus crisis is full of challenges — and connected to G.O.P. efforts to limit who gets a ballot in the state.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s mess of an election in Wisconsin is the culmination of a decade of efforts by state Republicans to make voting harder, redraw legislative boundaries and dilute the power of voters in the state’s urban centers.

headline: Ecuador’s Former President Convicted on Corruption Charges
abstract: The outcome of Rafael Correa’s closely watched trial is likely to affect Ecuador’s political landscape for years to come.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — A top court in Ecuador on Tuesday convicted Rafael Correa, the country’s former president, on corruption charges and sentenced him to eight years in prison, a blow to a charismatic yet divisive leader and his hopes to lead the nation again.

headline: Kennedy Center Drops Furlough of Musicians as They Accept Pay Cuts
abstract: The furloughs at the National Symphony Orchestra had drawn the ire of the musicians’ union and some lawmakers, and will now be replaced by a 35 percent pay cut.
lead_paragraph: The National Symphony Orchestra’s musicians will be receiving pay cuts, but will not be furloughed, under a new deal hammered out between their union and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, where they perform.

headline: Are You an Essential Worker? Share Your Video
abstract: The New York Times Video desk is seeking videos from people who are essential workers, such as grocery store employees, delivery people and bus drivers.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has led officials around the world to issue stay-at-home orders for millions of people, causing major disruptions to the global economy and working habits.

headline: What We Tell Children When the World Seems Unsafe
abstract: We have to teach the safety drills for our time, summon our often precarious reserves of courage and find our lullabies where we can.
lead_paragraph: This is about the song my mother used to sing, “Shake Hands With Your Air Raid Warden.” It’s about living through scary times with children, and what you tell them when the world does not seem like a safe place. And of course, it’s about my mother, and maybe about her generation, which certainly grew up through scary times, and about thinking of our own children, all of them, their childhoods interrupted — at any age — by Covid-19 and by our own scary times.

headline: In Wisconsin, Putting Lives at Risk to Vote
abstract: Readers express dismay at the decision of state officials and the Supreme Court to go ahead with Tuesday’s primary and local elections.

headline: Trump’s Advocacy of Unproven Drug for Coronavirus
abstract: Readers discuss whether hydroxychloroquine should be used despite lack of proper clinical trials.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘I Just Need the Comfort’: Processed Foods Make a Pandemic Comeback
abstract: Shoppers, moved by nostalgia and hunting for longer shelf lives, are returning to old standbys like Chef Boyardee and Campbell’s soup.
lead_paragraph: Just a few months ago, Sue Smith considered herself a healthy eater. She ate salads with kale and quinoa. She counted calories. She eliminated processed sugar from her diet. She avoided dairy products.

headline: Wuhan, Boris Johnson, Japan’s Virus Emergency: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Robert Barth, a Pioneer of Deep-Sea Diving, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Barth was the sole “aquanaut” to play a major role in all four stages of the Navy’s landmark program to open the depths to long-term habitation.
lead_paragraph: The hatch would not open.

headline: I’ve Been in Prison. Sheltering in Place Is Terrifying.
abstract: Some think incarceration prepared us for the pandemic. But lots of us are trying not to freak out.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A few months after I got out of prison, a car pulled up outside my apartment. I panicked. It was white, with a dark stripe down the side: a patrol car. Surely, I thought, this was it.

headline: I Hope My Neighbor Plays Beyoncé Tonight
abstract: In coronavirus quarantine, the music coming through the thin walls is keeping me sane.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know most of the neighbors in my four-story apartment building, but I can hear them. Often, these sounds are annoying: doors slamming, the incessant beep from a neglected fire alarm battery, a family quarrel in the hallway, overhead thuds that wake me up at night.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Dumbest Fight I’ve Ever Been In’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Big fight today before grocery shopping about the proper way to load knives into the dishwasher. A small yet pivotal moment in our shelter-at-home lives. Do we cause a scene in the Trader Joe’s line? Do we forgo collaboration on the grocery list? It’s drizzling, gray. The people behind us are a little too close. He’s wearing the jacket that my father gave him. I laugh, pull him toward me, say, “This is the dumbest fight I’ve ever been in.” He nods, kisses me. If we have to be stuck, at least we’re stuck together. — Madison Olivieri

headline: Lessons From the Plagues, Painted for Passover
abstract: The artist Zoya Cherkassky evokes Jewish life in the shtetl in her new virtual exhibition.
lead_paragraph: In quarantine at her home in Tel Aviv last month, the artist Zoya Cherkassky came across a YouTube video of a wedding ceremony held in a Jewish cemetery just outside the city during the early days of the coronavirus outbreak. She learned that such “plague weddings” had evolved in the 19th century across Eastern Europe as a ritual to ward off cholera epidemics.

headline: Turkey Orders All Citizens to Wear Masks as Infections Rise
abstract: Resisting a total lockdown, Turkey has introduced gradual restrictions but sought to keep industry and construction working.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey has ordered all citizens to wear masks when shopping or visiting crowded public places and announced that it will deliver masks to every family, free of charge, as coronavirus infections increase in the country of 80 million.

headline: One Theater Tries an Alternative to Cancellation: An All-Audio Season.
abstract: Bobby Cannavale, Carla Gugino and Audra McDonald will still perform for the Williamstown Theater Festival this summer, but their shows will be on Audible, not onstage.
lead_paragraph: The Williamstown Theater Festival has been grappling with the same dilemma facing every performing arts organization during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic: Public health concerns have made it difficult to imagine — or plan — an ordinary summer.

headline: Quinn the Quarantine Fox Wants You to Be Safe at Home
abstract: The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission created a coronavirus mascot to help prevent additional emergency room trips.
lead_paragraph: The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission is charged with protecting buyers from the dangers of household items, issuing recalls and teaching people how to avoid common, life-threatening emergencies like kitchen fires and ingesting poisonous cleaners.

headline: Don’t Play Favorites in Doling Out Supplies to States
abstract: Readers worry that politics will get in the way of providing essential equipment to the states that need it most. Also: Betting on Mike Pence; the new fuel economy rule.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: He Made Brooklyn Comedy a Scene. But His Life Took a Different Turn.
abstract: The stand-up Eugene Mirman gave many stars their start, yet he didn’t follow them to L.A. Instead, he stayed on the East Coast to be near family through the death of his wife.
lead_paragraph: Over the last couple of weeks, the comedian Eugene Mirman, star of the new documentary “It Started as a Joke,” has added a much-needed dose of absurdist wit to Twitter feeds with his “Daily Quarantine Routine.” No. 12 begins: “7am: Wake up, churn butter wrong and throw it out. 8am: Make a list of other things to fear once this is over. 12pm: Lunch of boob-shaped pasta thrown at you by drunk bachelorettes from a party trolley 2 years ago.”

headline: Fiction Podcasts to Get Lost In
abstract: Give the screen a rest and embrace a bingeable audio drama.
lead_paragraph: Long before Ben Hammersley coined the portmanteau “podcast” to describe the “webcasting” of audio files through digital syndication — and before true crime, current events and talk shows seemed to colonize the fledgling industry — audio was used to tell a good fictional story.

headline: Philharmonic Players, Fired on Misconduct Grounds, Are Reinstated
abstract: The firings of Liang Wang and Matthew Muckey, over allegations of unspecified sexual misconduct, were overruled by an independent arbitrator.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic has been forced by an arbitrator to reinstate two players it fired over allegations of unspecified sexual misconduct, the orchestra said on Monday night.

headline: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces New Grants
abstract: The agency, which recently received $75 million as part of the coronavirus stimulus package, announces new funding for 224 projects across the country.
lead_paragraph: A documentary about the singer and civil rights activist Marian Anderson, a museum exhibition dedicated to Norman Rockwell’s “The Four Freedoms,” a digital archive dedicated to Walt Whitman and a dictionary of dialects spoken by the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians are among the 224 projects across the country to receive new grants from the National Endowment of the Humanities.

headline: Can Drugs Help Us Focus? Casey Schwartz, You Better Watch Your Speed
abstract: In “Attention: A Love Story,” a journalist seeks to turn her relationship with Adderall into a broader examination of the science behind human concentration.
lead_paragraph: The 19th century harbored a fad for feats of attention — “ostentatious learning,” they were called. The naturalist Charles Bonnet famously spent 21 days contemplating a single aphid. The entomologist René Antoine Ferchault de Réaumur once tallied 84,000 bees leaving a hive.

headline: National Poetry Month Celebrations Go Online
abstract: Open mics, workshops and other gatherings have gone digital because of the coronavirus. Here are some of the goings-on, and archives to check out.
lead_paragraph: April is National Poetry Month. Even though writers and audiences can’t gather in person because of the coronavirus, verse is happening on Facebook or Zoom, in people’s notebooks and in our earbuds. Some highlights are a sound artist who is making an audio collage of haikus about the pandemic, weekly book release readings from Copper Canyon Press, and the option to book a live video call with a poet through the Poetry Society of New York.

headline: Trump’s Inspector General Has Expressed Dim Views of Congressional Oversight
abstract: Brian D. Miller, the White House lawyer tapped to oversee Treasury’s $500 billion bailout, rebuffed a request for information during impeachment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amid the blur of President Trump’s impeachment proceedings in December, the Government Accountability Office received a terse message from the White House regarding its investigation into why security aid to Ukraine was withheld.

headline: Sandra Santos-Vizcaino, Beloved Brooklyn Teacher, Dies at 54
abstract: The longtime educator is believed to be the first public-school teacher in New York City, the nation’s largest school district, to die of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: For scores of children and parents, being assigned to Sandra Santos-Vizcaino’s third-grade classroom at Public School 9 in Brooklyn felt like winning the lottery.

headline: Small Business Aid Program Stretches Agency to Its Limits
abstract: The Small Business Administration is not equipped to handle the demand for emergency loans. It is trying to fix aging systems, but the delays are rattling banks and small businesses.
lead_paragraph: Five days after the start of a $349 billion emergency effort to get money into the hands of small businesses, the agency at the heart of the program is emerging as its biggest bottleneck.

headline: Wuhan Reopens After Coronavirus Lockdown
abstract: Wuhan, China, had been sealed off since late January in an effort to limit the coronavirus outbreak’s spread. The city’s recovery could dictate how other places move forward.
lead_paragraph: Wuhan, China, had been sealed off since late January in an effort to limit the coronavirus outbreak’s spread. The city’s recovery could dictate how other places move forward.

headline: Yves Tumor Redefines Rock Stardom, Body on the Line
abstract: The musician known for a constantly shifting sound moves a little closer to standard pop on the new album “Heaven to a Tortured Mind,” but remains a master of anarchic energy.
lead_paragraph: In Texas last month before the coronavirus shut down touring, one fan at an Yves Tumor concert got a little too excited. “He bit me on my neck!” said the musician (real name: Sean Bowie) by phone. “I was signing his album after the show and was like, ‘Why did you bite me? There’s a pandemic going on.’ He said he just wanted to know what I tasted like.”

headline: Rulings on Wisconsin Election Raise Questions About Judicial Partisanship
abstract: Some legal scholars said the decisions by the state and U.S. supreme courts could undermine confidence in the rule of law. Others said they were the product of judicial philosophy, not partisanship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of extraordinary rulings on Monday, the highest courts in Wisconsin and the nation split along ideological lines to reject Democratic efforts to defer voting in Tuesday’s elections in the state given the coronavirus pandemic. Election law experts said the stark divisions in the rulings did not bode well for faith in the rule of law and American democracy.

headline: Judy Drucker, Who Brought Miami Top-Notch Music, Dies at 91
abstract: She presented musicians, opera singers and dancers. “I don’t think of Judy as” an impresario, Itzhak Perlman said. “I think of her as a friend.”
lead_paragraph: Judy Drucker, a South Florida impresario who for decades brought the stars of concert music, opera and dance to Miami, elevating the city’s cultural scene with inexhaustible enthusiasm and self-confidence, died on March 30 at a care facility in Miami. She was 91.

headline: Wisconsin Election Results: Live Presidential Primary 2020
abstract: Detailed results and maps from the Wisconsin presidential primary election.
lead_paragraph: Detailed results and maps from the Wisconsin presidential primary election.

headline: Their Grandmother Left by Ambulance. Then They Could Not Find Her.
abstract: “I believe she passed away,” said a relative who led the family’s increasingly frantic search. “But where?”
lead_paragraph: The emergency medical technicians who rushed into Maria Correa’s room in protective gear found a pulse. They told the family in Queens that they were taking her to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, one of many health care facilities in New York City overwhelmed by the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Anita Fial, Who Carried the Banner of Exotic Food, Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Fial worked to burnish the reputation of mangoes, avocados, radishes and celery, among other produce.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn isn’t famous for exotic fruits and vegetables, but it produced Anita Fial who, as a home economist and marketing expert, helped make Florida sweet corn, Mexican mangoes and avocados staples at green grocers. She even helped revive the demand for radishes and celery.

headline: Idelle Weber, Who Stretched the Meaning of Pop Art, Dies at 88
abstract: One of the few women involved in the Pop Art movement, she captured the anonymity of corporate life in silhouettes. She later turned to realism.
lead_paragraph: Idelle Weber, an artist who cast a critical eye on midcentury American consumerism with Pop art silhouettes of corporate workers and photorealist paintings of trash, died on March 23 in Los Angeles. She was 88.

headline: How to Edit Your Own Writing
abstract: Writing is hard, but don’t overlook the difficulty — and the importance — of editing your own work before letting others see it. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: The secret to good writing is good editing. It’s what separates hastily written, randomly punctuated, incoherent rants from learned polemics and op-eds, and cringe-worthy fan fiction from a critically acclaimed novel. By the time this article is done, I’ll have edited and rewritten each line at least a few times. Here’s how to start editing your own work.

headline: Quibi, the Incredible Shrinking TV Set
abstract: The mobile content app could be a place for innovation, but its first set of scripted shows looks like traditional television in miniature.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I saw on Quibi was a cross-promotional ad for Charmin. A bright blue papa bear, presumably sitting on the toilet, told an impatient cub that he’d be with him after a Quibi. Maybe two. I had to think about that for a minute, which is a long time when you’re on Quibi.

headline: David Driskell, 88, Pivotal Champion of African-American Art, Dies
abstract: An artist himself, Professor Driskell recognized the role of black artists in the broader story of American art. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: When Will There Be a Treatment for the Coronavirus?
abstract: A vaccine may not be our only hope.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Privacy Cannot Be a Casualty of the Coronavirus
abstract: Many Americans now rely on digital tools to work remotely and stay connected. They shouldn’t have to sacrifice their privacy to use them.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans, sheltering in their homes from the coronavirus, have turned to communications platforms like Zoom, Google Hangouts and Facebook Messenger in order to work or stay connected to friends and family. Free and easy to use, the services are gobbling up record numbers of new users.

headline: The Restaurants and Stores Trying to Maintain New York Traditions
abstract: Many of Manhattan’s neighborhood institutions have served their loyal customers for decades without interruption. Now, they’re having to find new ways to survive.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

headline: Families With Food Allergies Struggle With Bare Shelves
abstract: As the coronavirus spreads and locked-down communities stock up, products needed by allergy sufferers are increasingly hard to come by.
lead_paragraph: Like many Americans these days, Lisa M. Delmont is kept up at night by worry. But for Ms. Delmont, it’s the empty grocery store shelves that bring on dread.

headline: Coronavirus, Wisconsin, Pandas: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Jack Dorsey Vows to Donate $1 Billion to Fight the Coronavirus
abstract: The founder of Twitter and Square said he was putting nearly a third of his total wealth toward the effort.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jack Dorsey, the chief executive of Twitter and Square, said on Tuesday that he planned to donate $1 billion, or just under a third of his total wealth, to relief programs related to the coronavirus, in one of the more significant efforts by a tech billionaire to fight the pandemic.

headline: ‘Thanking God for My Breath’: Dispatch From New York’s Frontline
abstract: An E.R. doctor predicted the chaos that Covid-19 would unleash long before it was declared a pandemic. Then she came down with it herself.
lead_paragraph: — Dr. Dara Kass, associate professor of emergency medicine at Columbia University Medical Center

headline: With Demand Soaring, Congress Weighs Adding $250 Billion in Small-Business Aid
abstract: Less than two weeks after enactment of a $2 trillion stimulus plan, the Trump administration is asking for a fresh infusion of funds to help businesses survive the economic damage of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rushing to shore up a $2 trillion economic stimulus effort that is already under strain, Congress could move as early as this week to approve another $250 billion in aid for small businesses, after the Trump administration asked for additional funds to support an overwhelming demand for help.

headline: New Battle for Those on Coronavirus Front Lines: Child Custody
abstract: Doctors, firefighters and others who risk exposure to Covid-19 are being taken to court by ex-spouses who want to keep them away from their children.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Dr. Bertha Mayorquin, a New Jersey physician, told her soon-to-be ex-husband that there was a change in plans. After two weeks of providing treatment by video as a precaution against the coronavirus, she would resume seeing patients in person.

headline: In N.Y.C., the Coronavirus Is Killing Men at Twice the Rate of Women
abstract: More men also are infected than women, and they are hospitalized more frequently, new data show. A similar pattern was seen in China.
lead_paragraph: In its inexorable spread across New York City, the coronavirus is exacting a greater toll on men than women. Not only are men infected in greater numbers, new data show, but they are also dying at nearly twice the rate of women.

headline: No Trading Floor? No Problem. A Financial Firm Quarantines at the Four Seasons.
abstract: Shutdown orders in New York and Chicago prompted Citadel Securities to set up a makeshift trading floor at the resort in Palm Beach, Fla.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Ah, to be quarantined inside a luxury beachfront hotel. Ocean views. Poolside cabanas. A makeshift financial trading floor.

headline: Trump Is the Wartime President We Have (Not the One We Need)
abstract: He should start leading with the decency and resolve that we deserve. I’m not holding my breath.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump declared himself a “wartime president” just three weeks ago. On Twitter, he proclaimed “WE WILL WIN THIS WAR.” At last, he seemed to grasp the gravity of the Covid-19 crisis facing the world. Bluster aside, Mr. Trump is correct: This is war, the most consequential since World War II, and he is in charge.

headline: Ira Einhorn, Counterculture Guru and Murderer, Dies in Prison at 79
abstract: He preached peace, love and environmentalism. Then he killed his girlfriend, stuffed her body in a steamer trunk and fled to Europe.
lead_paragraph: Ira Einhorn was the darling of Philadelphia’s counterculture in the 1960s and ’70s. A charismatic and flamboyant personality, he preached peace, love and environmentalism, and became a sought-after liaison in helping the city’s civic establishment grasp the upheavals in society.

headline: Drop the Curtain on the Trump Follies
abstract: Why does the nation need to be subjected to the president’s daily carnival of misinformation, preening and political venom?
lead_paragraph: Even as the Trump administration slowly finds its footing in the war against Covid-19, one high-profile element of its response remains stubbornly awful: President Trump’s performance in the daily news briefings on the pandemic.

headline: Bubby Locked Her Memories Away. One Passover Released Them.
abstract: ‘I remember my father, before the war, hanging a matzo on the wall,’ my wife’s grandmother murmured, entranced. Suddenly, there sat a young Polish child.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — By the time I married into the family, Bubby Bella’s reticence was pronounced. A survivor of Nazi genocide, Bubby had resolutely overcome it, posturing under large-brimmed hats while ordering egg rolls and lo mein in Philadelphia’s northeast.

headline: Some People Got to Vote Today
abstract: It’s Election Day in Wisconsin. But many voters told us about how they weren’t able to vote.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.

headline: What if the Most Important Election of Our Lifetimes Was the Last One?
abstract: Wisconsin voters may have risked their health to make it to the polls in a pandemic. But lately, it’s feeling as though 2016, not 2020, remains the most pivotal political moment.
lead_paragraph: Politics runs on superlative: the best plan, the biggest rally, the most votes.

headline: Voting in Wisconsin During a Pandemic: Lines, Masks and Plenty of Fear
abstract: Wisconsin’s primary showed an electoral system stretched to the breaking point by the coronavirus crisis, as people weighed the health risks against their desire to vote.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Even before voting began, there were lines outside polling locations that stretched for several blocks. Some poll workers wore hazmat suits. Nearly every voter wore a face mask, removing it only to make small talk that reflected a combination of determination and grim humor about the extraordinary experience of voting amid a deadly pandemic.

headline: 3 Killed and 1 Wounded in Tennessee Truck Stop Stabbing Spree
abstract: The suspect, Idris Abdus-Salaam, 33, of Durham, N.C., was shot and killed by a law enforcement officer, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A truck driver went on a stabbing spree Tuesday morning at a highway truck stop in eastern Tennessee, killing three employees and wounding a customer before he was fatally shot by a law enforcement officer, the authorities said.

headline: Watch: Scenes From the Wisconsin Elections
abstract: Voters faced long lines, confusion and risk of infection as Wisconsin’s elections, including presidential primaries, took place in spite of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Voters faced long lines, confusion and risk of infection as Wisconsin’s elections, including presidential primaries, took place in spite of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Pandemic’s Missing Data
abstract: We desperately need to release the statistics on race and ethnicity.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s leading expert on infectious diseases, acknowledged at a news conference that he expects black people will continue to die of the coronavirus at disproportionate rates.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: China eased its lockdown of Wuhan, and Wisconsin went on with its elections.
lead_paragraph: Figures from several American states and cities show a disturbing trend: The coronavirus is disproportionately infecting and killing black people.

headline: U.F.C. 249, Skirting Coronavirus Limits, Is Set for Tribal Land in California
abstract: The move for a card that includes a highly anticipated fight involving Tony Ferguson is an end run around state regulators and nationwide public health guidelines.
lead_paragraph: The Ultimate Fighting Championship plans to hold a pay-per-view event on tribal land in Central California this month, an attempted end run around widespread federal and state guidelines against holding large gatherings during the coronavirus pandemic, according to three people familiar with the decision.

headline: Trump Attacks W.H.O. Over Criticisms of U.S. Approach to Coronavirus
abstract: In effect, the president sought to blame the group for the very missteps and failures that have been leveled at him and his administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump lashed out on Tuesday at the World Health Organization, choosing a new political enemy to attack and threatening to withhold funding from a premier health institution even as a deadly virus ravages nations around the globe.

headline: John Prine, Who Chronicled the Human Condition in Song, Dies at 73
abstract: A singer and songwriter with a raspy voice and a gift for offbeat humor, he was revered by his peers, including Bob Dylan. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Winging It
abstract: Sam Buchbinder strikes a common note.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — We all need to take good care of ourselves these days, myself included, so I’m going to make the next few columns short ones and take some time to reset and refresh. I’m going to ask you all to help each other through the solving in the comments and play nicely together.

headline: The Life and Death Shift
abstract: We photographed the medical workers on the front lines in northern Italy. These are their stories.
lead_paragraph: We photographed the medical workers on the front lines in northern Italy. These are their stories.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Bringing Both Mother Tongues to the Mic
abstract: Quotation of the Day for April 8, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Without French, Montreal would be Pittsburgh.”

headline: Corrections: April 8, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 8, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about President Trump’s aggressive advocacy of a malaria drug for the treatment of coronavirus patients incorrectly described a financial firm. Fisher Asset Management is an investment company, not a mutual fund company.

headline: 14 Days With a Quarantine Tracker Wristband: Does It Even Work?
abstract: Hong Kong’s bracelets seem to obliterate the temptation to go outside, even if they appear to be just a simple piece of paper.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The images looked benign: a hand dangling chopsticks over a bowl of soup, a young man giving a thumbs up, a woman reclining in a bed at Ikea.

headline: Saudi Arabia Declares Cease-Fire in Yemen, Citing Fears of Coronavirus: Live Updates
abstract: The head of the World Health Organization warned that politicizing the coronavirus pandemic would result in “many more body bags.”
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our live global coverage on the coronavirus epidemic.

headline: Coronavirus, Boris Johnson, Wuhan: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Wall Street Rallies as Investors Focus on the Recovery
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Parasite’ and ‘Modern Family’
abstract: “Parasite” hits Hulu. And “Modern Family” airs its final episode on ABC.
lead_paragraph: PARASITE (2019) Stream on Hulu; rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. The South Korean filmmaker Bong Joon Ho won an armful of Oscars for “Parasite,” a comedic thriller that this year became the first film not in English to earn the Academy Award for best picture. The movie takes aim at social stratification: Set in South Korea, it centers on a poor family whose members begin working for a wealthy one. Their story, first comic, then shocking, involves tutoring, deception and pizza. In her review for The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the film “brilliant and deeply unsettling.” She wrote that Bong “creates specific spaces and faces — outer seamlessly meets inner here — that are in service to universal ideas about human dignity, class, life itself.”

headline: Coronavirus Was Slow to Spread to Rural America. Not Anymore.
abstract: A late-arriving wave of illness could overwhelm rural communities that are older, poorer and sicker than much of the country.
lead_paragraph: A late-arriving wave of illness could overwhelm rural communities that are older, poorer and sicker than much of the country.

headline: Word + Quiz: bonanza
abstract: This word has appeared in 98 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Late Night Says Wisconsin’s Voting Day Is a ‘Coronavirus All-You-Can-Eat Buffet’
abstract: “I guess it’s the Wisconsin way of showing New Hampshire that you can live free and die,” Stephen Colbert joked of Wisconsin’s voting.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Stuck in Paradise
abstract: Where would you want to be stranded?
lead_paragraph: A couple from South Africa found themselves stranded on their honeymoon in the Maldives after their country closed its borders to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: How Delays and Unheeded Warnings Hindered New York’s Virus Fight
abstract: The federal response was chaotic. Even so, the state’s and city’s own initial efforts failed to keep pace with the outbreak, The Times found.
lead_paragraph: A 39-year-old woman took Flight 701 from Doha, Qatar, to John F. Kennedy International Airport in late February, the final leg of her trip home to New York City from Iran.

headline: India Savors a Rare Upside to Coronavirus: Clean Air
abstract: Delhi residents are stunned by how blue the sky really is as a strict lockdown cuts back drastically on air pollution.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — There are countless downsides to the world’s getting walloped by the coronavirus and being put under severe lockdown.

headline: Here’s How Those Hot Jigsaw Puzzles Are Made
abstract: The coronavirus has sent businesses racing as demand surges past levels seen at Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Stewart once called the world of jigsaw puzzles a “secret society.” There were always high-profile fans, like Hugh Jackman, but most only whispered about their passion.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘College Made Them Feel Equal. The Virus Exposed How Unequal Their Lives Are.’
abstract: In this lesson, students will read about how the pandemic has affected one college class. Then they will reflect about what, if anything, the coronavirus crisis could mean for society and equality.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “College Made Them Feel Equal. The Virus Exposed How Unequal Their Lives Are.” by Nicholas Casey

headline: China’s Coronavirus Battle Is Waning. Its Propaganda Fight Is Not.
abstract: After the pandemic subsides, whether Beijing is praised or pilloried could determine the fate of its ambitions for global leadership.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For months the Chinese government’s propaganda machine had been fending off criticism of Beijing’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, and finally, it seemed to be finding an audience. Voices from the World Health Organization to the Serbian government to the rapper Cardi B hailed China’s approach as decisive and responsible.

headline: As Europe Confronts the Coronavirus, What Shape Will Solidarity Take?
abstract: Contentious talks over how to help economies decimated by the virus have become a pivotal political moment for the world’s richest bloc of nations.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As a poorer, battered south asks a richer, frugal north for solidarity, you’d be forgiven for thinking the coronavirus is throwing Europe back into last decade’s economic catastrophe. You’d be wrong. This time is set to be far worse.

headline: How Coronavirus at Rikers Puts All of N.Y.C. at Risk
abstract: Officials have promised a mass release of inmates from city jails to slow the spread of coronavirus. Critics say the government isn’t moving fast enough.
lead_paragraph: Officials have promised a mass release of inmates from city jails to slow the spread of coronavirus. Critics say the government isn’t moving fast enough.

headline: Craft-Brewed Hand Sanitizer
abstract: There’s a dire need for medical and other supplies for hospitals. Some unexpected businesses are stepping up to help.
lead_paragraph: There’s a dire need for medical and other supplies for hospitals. Some unexpected businesses are stepping up to help.

headline: Studies Show N.Y. Outbreak Originated in Europe
abstract: The C.D.C. outlined how essential employees can go back to work even if they have been exposed. Scientists warn that the virus might not fade in warm weather.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our live national updates and global coverage on the coronavirus epidemic.

headline: ‘Notes From an Apocalypse’ Is a Timely Tour of Preparing for the Worst
abstract: Mark O’Connell visited tricked-out bunkers, wilderness reserves, space-colonizing conferences and other places where people are getting ready for the end of the world as we know it.
lead_paragraph: When Mark O’Connell began to work on his new book, “Notes From an Apocalypse,” four years ago, he was already thinking hard about the end times. “I was obsessed with the future, an obsession that manifested as an inability to conceive of there being any kind of future at all,” he writes. “Personal, professional and political anxieties had coalesced into a consuming apprehension of imminent catastrophe.” Widening inequality, surging nationalism, burning forests, melting ice caps: He describes an overwhelming sense of foreboding, the fear that whatever civilizational edifice has been erected was on the verge of total collapse.

headline: Craft-Brewed Hand Sanitizer
abstract: There’s a dire need for masks and gowns and other supplies. Some unexpected businesses are stepping up to help.
lead_paragraph: With worrisome shortages of medical supplies, businesses around the country are manufacturing things they wouldn’t normally be making — everything from face masks to hand sanitizer.

headline: Feeling Down? Anxious? Hostile? A 4-Day-a-Week Exercise Regimen May Help
abstract: A regular workout was shown to ease depression and lift moods.
lead_paragraph: During these trying times, exercise could provide indispensable mental-health support for many of us, according to a timely new study. The study finds that among a generally healthy but sedentary group of adults in their 20s, 30s and 40s, working out lowers levels of depression, hostility and other negative feelings.

headline: Don’t Blame New Orleans, and Don’t Forget It
abstract: The rest of the country is giving us a hard time about having Mardi Gras. But Louisiana didn’t have a single confirmed Covid-19 case then.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — One recent afternoon, Mama, ready to run some errands, clips herself into the passenger seat of my Volkswagen sedan, disposable purple gloves on her hands, a dim glint in her eye.

headline: Hotels Open as ‘Comforting Refuge’ for Health Care Workers
abstract: Hotels, some high-end, that have closed in recent weeks because of the coronavirus  have reopened as lodgings for workers on the front line.
lead_paragraph: Days after closing for the first time in its 200-year-history, Claridge’s, the storied luxury hotel in London’s Mayfair district reopened on April 3 to 40 doctors, nurses and other National Health Service workers responding to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A Billion People Live in Slums. Can They Survive the Virus?
abstract: The most important factor in enabling the spread of pandemics in slums is the neglect of these marginalized populations by governing elites.
lead_paragraph: Although the coronavirus was spread around the world by people who could afford to travel by airplanes and cruise ships, the virus now threatens the socially invisible and forgotten communities of urban slums.

headline: In the Battle Against the Machines, She’s Holding Her Ground
abstract: Ellie Leonard’s transcription business has thrived, despite the arrival of automated services and advancing A.I. technology.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: Fear and Frustration Rise as Virus Spikes in Jewish Enclaves
abstract: Rockland County, N.Y., currently has the highest per capita rate of coronavirus infection in New York State.
lead_paragraph: About 25 miles northwest of New York City, local authorities have been waging a losing battle to curb the coronavirus outbreak: Rockland County has the highest per capita rate of infection in the state, and among the highest in the nation.

headline: They Think of Your Coronavirus Questions, Then Search for the Answers
abstract: Service journalism has become an important part of The Times’s coverage of the pandemic. The editors coordinating that effort are doing so from home.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: 41 Transit Workers Dead: Crisis Takes Staggering Toll on Subways
abstract: The M.T.A. has been criticized for its response to the outbreak. Now a staffing shortage has made it difficult to keep even a diminished system running.
lead_paragraph: At least 41 transit workers have died, and more than 6,000 more have fallen sick or self-quarantined. Crew shortages have caused over 800 subway delays and forced 40 percent of train trips to be canceled in a single day. On one line the average wait time, usually a few minutes, ballooned to as high as 40 minutes.

headline: Pharmaceutical Profits and Public Health Are Not Incompatible
abstract: We need the capital and creativity of the private sector to take on the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The rapid spread of the coronavirus has revived a decades-old debate over pharmaceutical policy, with both sides doubling down on long-held views. Advocates for broader drug access insist that pharmaceutical companies must not be allowed to reap large profits from Covid-19 vaccines and treatments. Free-market true believers — including officials in the Trump administration — argue that pharmaceutical businesses must be allowed to set prices beyond some patients’ reach.

headline: Don’t Let Trump’s Cult of Personality Make Covid-19 Worse
abstract: The coronavirus crisis has taken the personalized presidency to an insidious new level.
lead_paragraph: The politicization of everything corrodes social and constitutional life. That is especially so when the locus of politics is loyalty or opposition to whomever is president. The coronavirus pandemic may mark the first time it started killing people.

headline: The Leaders Who Passed the Coronavirus Test
abstract: California, Ohio and Washington moved early to slow the virus. Here’s what other states can learn from them.

headline: College Chatbots, With Names Like Iggy and Pounce, Are Here to Help
abstract: Schools are elevating the use of virtual assistants whose speed and tone can simulate text conversations.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: Artists Explore A.I., With Some Deep Unease
abstract: Coming shows involve artificial intelligence, but underlying them is a concern: “What are we unleashing?”
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: Bernie Sanders Only Had Eyes for One Wing of the Democratic Party
abstract: But actually there are three, which helps explain why he had to drop out of the race on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Once the mainstream of the Democratic Party’s electorate settled on a candidate to support in this year’s campaign, however flawed Joe Biden may be, Bernie Sanders’s call for a revolution overturning the current American variant of capitalism no longer had a chance. On Wednesday, Sanders finally capitulated to political reality and withdrew from the race. In doing so, he claimed that “Few would deny that over the course of the past five years our movement has won the ideological struggle.”

headline: Nikki Haley: Focus on Your Governor, Not Trump
abstract: Governors complaining about the president are, in some cases, attempting to distract from their own failures.
lead_paragraph: Overheated critics of President Trump accuse him of being an authoritarian. Of not caring about checks and balances, civil rights, and constitutional limits on executive power. And yet, today, many of these same critics demand that he nationalize supply chains, deploy the military on our shores and shut down every town in America. It’s a curious thing.

headline: You Can’t Spell Creative Without A.I.
abstract: Advances in software applications that process human language lie at the heart of the debate over whether computer technologies will enhance or even substitute for human creativity.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: What’s Your Pet Saying? These Machines Know
abstract: New technology in streaming cameras can flag unusual behavior or suggest why the dog might be barking.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: Denim, as a Crime-Solving Tool, Has Holes
abstract: A forensic technique that involves matching patterns on bluejeans is highly inaccurate, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Charles Barbee and three co-defendants were convicted of robbing two banks in Spokane, Wash., and setting off bombs in the office of a local newspaper and a Planned Parenthood clinic. One key piece of evidence from the trial was a security-camera photo that showed an alternating dark-and-light pattern along a seam of one of the robber’s bluejeans. Richard Vorder Bruegge, an F.B.I. forensic scientist, told the jury that the visual features of the jeans in the photograph, particularly the dark-and-light “bar code” pattern, matched a pair that had been seized from the house of one of the suspects: Charles Barbee.

headline: Why Coronavirus Conspiracy Theories Flourish. And Why It Matters.
abstract: Unseen villains. Top-secret cures. In their quest for reassurance during the pandemic, many people are worsening more than just their own anxiety.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has given rise to a flood of conspiracy theories, disinformation and propaganda, eroding public trust and undermining health officials in ways that could elongate and even outlast the pandemic.

headline: What’s Wrong With Butterflies Raised in Captivity?
abstract: A study suggests that monarchs bred by enthusiasts were less fit than those that started as caterpillars in the wild.
lead_paragraph: Monarch butterflies look delicate, but they need to be super-tough to survive their annual migrations. The monarchs of eastern North America may travel thousands of miles to their winter home in Mexico’s Sierra Madre mountains. And, increasingly, they’re not making it, a problem that has been blamed on habitat loss, climate change and pesticides.

headline: The Passover Rules Bend, if Just for One Pandemic
abstract: During the holiday, many observant Jews get rid of bread and beans, pasta and rice. But that’s exactly the stuff that gets you through self-isolation.
lead_paragraph: During the coronavirus outbreak, people have stocked up on shelf-stable items like beans, pasta and bread to sustain them through weeks of staying at home.

headline: Is My Takeout Risking Lives or Saving Restaurants?
abstract: Online orders and no-contact pickup can be an economic lifeline, but someone still has to make the food.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The very small, mundane things that have become dangerous in the context of the pandemic are the ones I miss the most — a kiss on the cheek from a friend meeting me at a crowded bar, a packed car ride to the beach, a hot cheese pizza carried home in a cardboard box.

headline: When a Gaming Fantasy Is Eerily Close to Reality
abstract: Plague Inc. has been around for eight years. In the coronavirus crisis, it’s tapping into fears but also offering comfort.
lead_paragraph: The British video game developer James Vaughan, 33, knows what to expect when a really bad flu season or a novel disease like Covid-19 makes headlines. His 2012 video game Plague Inc., which challenges players to spread contagion around the world, surges in popularity.

headline: Thanks to A.I., Machines Get a Taste for the Right Kinds of Food
abstract: Machines are being trained to consider food the way a cook might, with attention to variations in shape and seasonality and qualities like sweetness or texture.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: 5 Movies to Watch if You Have Trouble With Technology
abstract: These films creatively show the good and the not-so-good of the relationship between smart machines and humans.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: NASA’s ‘Worm’ Logo Will Return to Space
abstract: The new old logo, dropped in the 1990s in favor of a more vintage brand, will adorn a SpaceX rocket that is to carry astronauts to the space station in May.
lead_paragraph: It was designed for NASA in the 1970s, and it hasn’t been back to space since the 1990s. But in 2020, it will head to orbit once more.

headline: The U.S.N.S. Comfort Is Now Taking Covid-19 Patients. Here’s What to Expect.
abstract: The Navy ship’s mission in New York now comes with a new level of complexity, raising questions about whether it’s equipped for the task.
lead_paragraph: Before the U.S. Navy hospital ship Comfort steamed up the East Coast from Virginia and docked at Manhattan’s Pier 90 to help the embattled city’s overwhelmed health care system, the floating hospital and its sister vessel, the U.S.N.S. Mercy, had for years operated quietly on the peripheries of American naval power, supporting humanitarian efforts and offering medical care to those in need.

headline: For H.I.V. Survivors, a Feeling of Weary Déjà Vu
abstract: Some of them are now senior citizens: vulnerable again, mistrustful of government directives about coronavirus and unable to organize.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, a spring breaker in Miami became a symbol of Gen Z denialism when he spoke to CBS News and said that coronavirus wasn’t going to get in the way of his partying.

headline: Computers Already Learn From Us. But Can They Teach Themselves?
abstract: Scientists are exploring approaches that would help machines develop their own sort of common sense.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: Raising a Glass, Remotely
abstract: You can’t go to the vineyard, but some of Napa and Sonoma’s best wineries are letting you buy a bottle, then participate in streamed tastings.
lead_paragraph: If you are bored with your at-home cache of pinot grigio and merlot, Sonoma County and Napa Valley vintners can rescue you with remote tastings that combine virtual guidance with real-world wine consumption.

headline: 31% Can’t Pay the Rent: ‘It’s Only Going to Get Worse’
abstract: As the economic shutdown pares tenants’ incomes, April payments have been reduced, deferred or withheld. Some landlords see their property at risk.
lead_paragraph: First it was the waitress whose restaurant closed. Then the waiter, the bartender, the substitute teacher, the hairdresser, the tattoo artist and the Walgreens manager.

headline: Cuomo, Fauci, Birx: The New Influencers
abstract: This is what authority looks like today.
lead_paragraph: There is currently a petition, on change.org, to nominate Dr. Anthony Fauci, the 79-year-old director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the country’s coronavirus medical expert, as People magazine’s Sexiest Man Alive. By the evening of April 7, it had over 11,500 signatures. Dr. Fauci’s face, with his small wire-rim glasses and neatly parted gray hair, has been commemorated on sweatshirts, knee socks and mugs.

headline: A.I. Is Helping Scientists Understand an Ocean’s Worth of Data
abstract: Machine-learning applications are proving to be especially useful to the scientific community studying the planet’s largest bodies of water.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: Want to Be Better at Sports? Listen to the Machines
abstract: The pattern-recognizing power of machine learning is affecting players, teams, sports medicine and even betting.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Artificial Intelligence special report, which focuses on how the technology continues to evolve and affect our lives.

headline: Cruise Lines Were Shut Out of the Stimulus. Here’s Why.
abstract: The hard-hit sector of the travel industry was left out of the $2 trillion stimulus package. Century-old tax provisions help explain what happened.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on March 27 signed into law the $2 trillion stimulus package designed to save millions of jobs and bail out companies devastated by the coronavirus. But when the dust settled, one hard-hit sector of the travel industry was left on the sidelines: the major cruise lines.

headline: ‘I’m in High School Again’: Virus Sends College Students Home to Parents, and Their Rules
abstract: Their college campuses closed, crestfallen students have journeyed back to their childhood bedrooms — and to chores, revived sibling rivalries and curfews.
lead_paragraph: Fights over who gets to control the television. Arguments that the music is too loud. Notes taped to doors, ordering parents to keep out.

headline: ‘That Is What We Do’: The Power of Passover and Tradition Across Generations
abstract: Jewish families on Wednesday will again recount the 10 plagues from the Book of Exodus. Only this year will be a little different.
lead_paragraph: Religious ritual holds power not only because it connects people gathered in one space — it also connects people across time.

headline: The Magic of Empty Streets
abstract: Social distancing gives us a rare chance to fix cities.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — We’re in week four of sheltering in place here (it feels like week 40). It’s a completely unfamiliar situation in so many ways. As someone who has lived in cities her whole adult life, for me it’s especially strange to experience a time when all the things I love are no longer available. Nearly everything is closed — restaurants and shops, libraries and museums, and of course all schools. All nonessential workers are under a mandatory work-from-home order.

headline: The East River Waterfront Dazzles. Take a Virtual Tour.
abstract: With views of the water, skyline, bridges and piers, the promenade encapsulates New York’s history. Our critic walks with the architect Deborah Berke.
lead_paragraph: New York’s perimeter, where the land meets the rivers and the harbor, has always been the city’s beating heart.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
abstract: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut see single-day spikes in deaths from the coronavirus, and even those may represent undercounts as more die at home.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Happy 30th Anniversary, ‘Twin Peaks.’ Go Down the Rabbit Hole.
abstract: The owls are not what they seem, the log does not judge and the coffee is damn fine. Here’s a reading guide to The Times’s coverage of a most mysterious television series.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, on April 8, 1990, one of television’s most influential series premiered: “Twin Peaks.” There’s something timeless about the series, which arrived at the cusp of one decade and channeled several others. With its combination of high-pitched soap opera and low-frequency supernatural hum, “Twin Peaks” was always bound to be one of the weirder shows ever to air on American television.

headline: Coronavirus, John Prine, Wisconsin: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Crisis Inside the Navy
abstract: How the pandemic pitted a top captain against the head of the service, upending the chain of command and resulting in a public relations disaster.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Making Passover, Easter and Ramadan Digital This Year
abstract: We can make digital gatherings meaningful. But it takes work.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to think about if you’re trying to transform your annual in-person holiday into a digital experience. It can be done! But it’s going to take some work.

headline: How We Gather Digitally Now
abstract: Birthdays. Funerals. Prom. Passover. How do we do it?
lead_paragraph: Hello! We’re all trying to keep human gatherings meaningful in an age of isolation. You can keep up with our new podcast “Together Apart” on Apple or Spotify. Our host is Priya Parker, a professional conflict facilitator and the author of “The Art of Gathering: How We Meet and Why It Matters.” We asked Priya to talk to us about how to make sense of holiday gatherings this week.

headline: How I Learned to Build My Own Foundation
abstract: When change is a constant, a strategy for putting together jigsaw puzzles helped one woman find the solid ground under her feet.
lead_paragraph: My family moves frequently.
