While we’ve generally stayed in the New England area, we either outgrow a house or want to see if another part of the region will be more conducive to our environmental allergies. I measure life events by which house I was living in at the time (“Oh, high school graduation? That was in the house where my bedroom had pink walls.”)

headline: Explosion at Berlin’s Humboldt Forum Puts Delayed Opening in Doubt
abstract: A blast on the construction site of the troubled museum project damaged the building and injured a worker.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It has been rocked by protests and beset by technical delays. And, on Wednesday, the Humboldt Forum, the huge new museum under construction in the center of Berlin, suffered another blow.

headline: The Day the Running Statues Donned Masks
abstract: A former Boston Marathon champion put a mask on a running statue, thinking it might deliver a message of health. Then he thought, what if all the running statues had masks?
lead_paragraph: Amby Burfoot, the 1968 Boston Marathon men’s champion, was running along the Mystic River on Saturday morning near his home in Connecticut when his brother, Gary, floated the idea of putting a mask on the statue of John J. Kelley, who won Boston in 1957.

headline: On Politics: Trump Pushes Out a Watchdog
abstract: A purge accelerates and Wisconsin holds an anxious vote: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Voters lined up on the sidewalk and in their cars outside Milwaukee Marshall High School on Tuesday.

headline: Jack Dorsey Ups the Ante on Coronavirus Donations
abstract: Corporate leaders are increasingly announcing big gifts, or taking pay cuts, to help respond to the pandemic — and to keep the political heat off.
lead_paragraph: Our next DealBook Debrief conference call will be held on April 9 at 11 a.m. Eastern. More details below. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: Trump Slammed the W.H.O. Over Coronavirus. He’s Not Alone.
abstract: Critics say the World Health Organization was too trusting of China and did not push it on its early missteps. But supporters say the agency’s powers over any government are limited.
lead_paragraph: President Trump unleashed a tirade against the World Health Organization on Tuesday, accusing it of acting too slowly to sound the alarm about the coronavirus. It was not the first time in this pandemic that the global health body has faced such criticism.

headline: Bleak Records in N.Y. and N.J., but Leaders See Coronavirus Curve Flattening
abstract: There were 779 virus-related deaths in the state in the past 24 hours, Governor Cuomo said. It was the highest one-day total yet.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Thursday’s live coverage.]

headline: They Played Sports at the Highest Level. Now Their Job Is to Save Lives.
abstract: Hayley Wickenheiser, who won four Olympic gold medals as a hockey player, is now a medical student and among the elite athletes using their skills and platforms to fight the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The four-time Olympic gold medalist Hayley Wickenheiser of Canada was around 10 years old when she first had the idea of being both a professional hockey player and a doctor. Wickenheiser, now 41, grew up in Shaunavon, Saskatchewan, a town of fewer than 2,000 people and less than two square miles in size. A young girl in the area had been severely injured after getting hit by a grocery delivery van.

headline: Trump’s Power Play
abstract: While the virus has our attention …
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Germany Prepares for Soccer’s Return
abstract: With players back practicing, the Bundesliga is set to become the first of Europe’s major leagues to return to action, with plans for spectator-free games starting in early May.
lead_paragraph: Germany is ahead of the curve. While other European soccer leagues are engulfed in uncertainty and damaging pay disputes between clubs and player unions, in Germany there is order and a cleareyed strategy to restart its league, which like others around the world was brought to a halt by the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Crying in Your Car Counts as Self-Care
abstract: Ways to find headroom and even joy right now.
lead_paragraph: One highlight of my week was crying in the car on my way to the grocery store. That sounds bleak as hell, but let me explain. I was alone, with no one asking me to do anything for 15 solid minutes, listening to music of my choosing that was in no way affiliated with Disney.

headline: A Call With Katie Porter: ‘This Is Not a Partisan Crisis’
abstract: Wednesday: The representative from Orange County talks about how the pandemic hit California early. Also: A remembrance of a “cowboy.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Heroine of This Korean Best Seller Is Extremely Ordinary. That’s the Point.
abstract: “Kim Jiyoung, Born 1982,” a surprise hit when it was published, ignited what Cho Nam-Joo called “a public debate” around gender and inequality.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jiyoung, the exceptionally average protagonist of Cho Nam-Joo’s novel, is 33, living on the outskirts of Seoul with her husband and infant daughter. She is exhausted by the monotony of cooking, cleaning and child-rearing, and vaguely resentful that she gave up her job at a marketing agency.

headline: What You Get for $600,000
abstract: A 1910 Tudor in Louisville, Ky.; a vacation home on Cape Cod; and a 1920 colonial outside Duluth, Minn.
lead_paragraph: A 1910 Tudor in Louisville, Ky.; a vacation home on Cape Cod; and a 1920 colonial outside Duluth, Minn.

headline: $600,000 Homes in Kentucky, Massachusetts and Minnesota
abstract: A 1910 Tudor in Louisville, a vacation home on Cape Cod and a 1920 colonial outside Duluth.
lead_paragraph: This home is in the Original Highlands neighborhood, two and a half miles southeast of downtown Louisville. Known for its concentration of restaurants and lively nightlife, the area has historic, eclectic homes and is about a mile west of Cherokee Park, a 409-acre green space designed by Frederick Law Olmsted.

headline: Eight U.K. Doctors Died From Coronavirus. All Were Immigrants.
abstract: In a country where anti-immigrant sentiment gave rise to the Brexit movement, Britain’s health care system depends heavily on foreign doctors, who are now on the front lines fighting the epidemic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The eight men moved to Britain from different corners of its former empire, all of them doctors or doctors-to-be, becoming foot soldiers in the effort to build a free universal health service after World War II.

headline: Uber and Lyft Drivers Face Hurdles to Stimulus Bill Benefits
abstract: Gig workers seemingly eligible for unemployment pay because of the pandemic have met roadblocks to filing. Some fault Labor Department rules.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the Senate approved a huge stimulus bill in late March that made gig workers and other contractors eligible for unemployment assistance during the coronavirus pandemic, Uber’s chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, rejoiced on Twitter.

headline: A Quiet Acre in Todos Santos, Mexico
abstract: This property with two cottages, near the coast in the art-centric town of Todos Santos, is listed for $595,000.
lead_paragraph: This property with two cottages, near the coast in the art-centric town of Todos Santos, is listed for $595,000.

headline: House Hunting in Mexico: A Balinese-Style Compound for $595,000
abstract: The artsy town of Todos Santos has long been a quiet alternative to the resorts of Los Cabos, but new demand and development is raising its profile.
lead_paragraph: This one-acre property with two Balinese-style cottages is in the art-centric town of Todos Santos, Mexico, on the southwestern coast of the Baja California Peninsula, near the Pacific Ocean.

headline: How NOT to Wear a Mask
abstract: Wearing a face mask takes some getting used to. To get the most benefit, you need to avoid these common mistakes.
lead_paragraph: Almost overnight, masks in a variety of colors, styles and materials have appeared on the faces of people around us. While it’s good news that many people are doing their part to slow the spread of coronavirus, the bad news is that many people are wearing their masks wrong.

headline: What TV Should I Watch After Netflix’s ‘Unorthodox’?
abstract: Our television critic answers your questions and offers guidance on what to watch next.
lead_paragraph: I am one of many who are suddenly unemployed. This feels like the perfect time to embark on a several-seasons-long journey or pick up something that takes a little extra getting used to. Is this the time to start watching “ER”? — Kelsey

headline: The N.B.A. Should Crown a Champion. But Will the Title Count?
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein explores why some of the league’s biggest stars can’t just wait until next year to try to win a championship.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: Some of Europe, ‘Walking a Tightrope,’ Will Loosen Coronavirus Restrictions
abstract: Looking for a return to normal may be misplaced. Instead, the next phase is about learning how to live with the virus, possibly for a long time.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Austria is allowing small shops to resume business after Easter. Denmark is reopening nurseries and primary schools. The Czech Republic is planning to lift a travel ban.

headline: You Can Adapt It All
abstract: We’ve got recipes for strawberry granola, five-ingredient miso pasta and an asparagus salad with pistachios and pecorino, all ready for your interpretation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Passover begins this evening, and we’re in the middle of Easter week, but celebrations of rebirth and spring joyousness are going to be difficult this year, with everyone locked down and self-isolated.

headline: A Rube Goldberg Hand-Washing Contraption? The Race Is On
abstract: The cartoonist’s granddaughter is holding a bar-of-soap competition that encourages families to work collaboratively. Video submissions are due May 31.
lead_paragraph: As if we weren’t already spending enough time washing our hands to keep the coronavirus at bay, the process could get a lot more complicated — and comic — if Jennifer George has her way.

headline: Coronavirus and the Cancer Patient
abstract: My patients’ immune systems are so exquisitely fragile that it doesn’t take much to catch an infection that could kill them.
lead_paragraph: I miss the intimacy, and the innocence, of my visits with patients.

headline: Broadway Will Remain Closed at Least Until June, and Probably Longer
abstract: The 41 Broadway theaters have been closed since March 12, and industry leaders are aware that large gatherings may be among the last forms of activity to resume when the pandemic eases.
lead_paragraph: Broadway will remain closed for at least another two months, industry leaders said Wednesday, as they formally acknowledged what has been widely known: that their initial target of reopening in mid-April has become impossible because of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A World Track and Field Championships in Oregon. In 2022.
abstract: The event was supposed to take place in 2021. Then the Olympics were postponed a year.
lead_paragraph: The ripple effects from moving the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo to next summer continue to alter the sports calendar. The world track and field championships, scheduled for Eugene, Ore., in 2021, were postponed on Wednesday until July 2022.

headline: Democrats Have Found a Coronavirus Bright Spot. Her Name Is Earnestine.
abstract: A little-known House staff aide who moderates Democrats’ conference calls has become an audible ray of sunshine for lawmakers, with a cheery affect that lightens grim deliberations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress grappling with how to respond to the coronavirus pandemic have few reasons to smile these days. But House Democrats have found one, and her name is Earnestine.

headline: Bernie Sanders Drops Out of 2020 Democratic Race for President
abstract: Mr. Sanders, a democratic socialist making his second run for the White House, withdrew after a series of losses to Joseph R. Biden Jr., who emerges as the presumptive nominee for the general election.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont ended his presidential candidacy on Wednesday, concluding a quest that elevated him as a standard-bearer of American liberalism and clearing the way for a general election between the presumptive Democratic nominee, Joseph R. Biden Jr., and President Trump at a time of national crisis.

headline: E.U. Court Rules Poland Must Suspend Disciplinary Panel for Judges
abstract: It was another setback for the governing party’s bid to control the courts, which European officials called a grave threat to Poland’s democracy.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The European Union’s highest court introduced measures on Wednesday to halt Poland’s widely criticized disciplinary regime for judges, the latest blow in a yearslong battle with the country’s governing Law and Justice party over what critics denounce as attempts to erode the independence of the judiciary.

headline: Biden vs. Trump: The General Election Is Here, and Transformed
abstract: The coronavirus crisis means many questions remain about how the 2020 race will proceed, but the top of the ticket is now clear.
lead_paragraph: The 2020 general election has begun — kind of.

headline: A New Album Reflects a Composer’s Stubborn Versatility
abstract: Paul Dessau, who collaborated with Bertolt Brecht and Walt Disney, is relatively obscure in part because he diverged from musical trends.
lead_paragraph: After a difficult period of exile in the United States that lasted much of the 1940s, Bertolt Brecht was ready to work with kindred spirits again. And in the composer Paul Dessau, he recognized a fellow burr under the saddle.

headline: Race, Pollution and the Coronavirus
abstract: Also this week: How to be ready for overlapping disasters
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. New this month, for the 50th anniversary of Earth Day, The New York Times is bringing you The Greenhouse, a digital event series on climate change. Join us on our first live video call this Friday at 11:30 a.m. Eastern, where Times climate journalists Hannah Fairfield, Somini Sengupta, Nadja Popovich and John Schwartz will discuss climate in the age of the coronavirus.

headline: American Ballet Theater Cancels Spring Season at Met Opera House
abstract: Canceling the Met season, the company’s executive director said, is “akin to the cancellation of the Olympics for those athletes.”
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater announced on Wednesday that its coming season at the Metropolitan Opera House was canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic. The company estimates that loss of the Met season, along with previously canceled tour performances — in Chicago, Detroit, Durham, N.C., and Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates — will cost it $18 million in revenue.

headline: Google Makes Stadia Gaming Service Free
abstract: The $130 entry fee is being waived indefinitely, as interest in playing video games surges during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Google is removing the $130 entry fee for its Stadia cloud gaming service indefinitely, the company said on Wednesday, making free high-end video games available to just about anyone with a computer during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Are Adults Living With Parents Making the Pandemic More Deadly?
abstract: Social scientists are debating a contentious theory that may help explain why the coronavirus appears to be more deadly in Italy and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Francesco Moro cannot say with certainty how his 65-year-old father contracted the coronavirus, but he figures it has something to do with the fact that he and his older brother both fell ill a week earlier. Though the two sons are grown, they live with their parents in a modest home outside Bergamo, the epicenter of the Italian outbreak.

headline: The Lesson We Are Learning From Zoom
abstract: The popular app offered the simplest path to videoconferencing in a pandemic. That doesn’t make it the right path to take.
lead_paragraph: Ever since many of us started working from home in the coronavirus pandemic, I’ve been invited to countless gatherings taking place on Zoom, the videoconferencing app. Virtual happy hours, work meetings, dinners, you name it.

headline: Don’t Expect a Quarantine Baby Boom
abstract: Not only do disasters have little effect, if any, on birthrates, the coronavirus pandemic will probably discourage couples from having children, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Any time people are stuck at home for blizzards, shutdowns and blackouts, the speculation seems to start: Will there be a baby boom in nine months?

headline: The Unholy Alliance of Trump and Dr. Oz
abstract: They’re pandemic partners, and that’s double trouble.
lead_paragraph: Of course President Trump is getting advice about the pandemic from Mehmet Oz, and of course Dr. Oz is eager to provide it. They’re a match made in ratings-obsessed heaven.

headline: Share Your Story and Photos From the Coronavirus Front Lines Around the World
abstract: We want to hear from the doctors, nurses and health care workers around the world risking their lives to save us from the coronavirus pandemic. What makes you do what you do?
lead_paragraph: Emergency room doctors drenched in sweat and critical care nurses scrambling for protective equipment have quickly come to personify the heroism and tragedy of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: What Can We Learn From the Art of Pandemics Past?
abstract: From the playground game ring-around-the-rosy to the short stories of Edgar Allan Poe, the scars of illnesses throughout history are still visible today.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic hit, we began gathering around the hearths of our screens, for news, or in solidarity with friends and family, for the cold solace of a cocktail-hour booze-Zoom, even for preschool, the grid of domestic scenes and small, hopeful faces meant to relieve us of our isolation somehow only succeeding in reinforcing it. (Even those of us who tend naturally toward solitary endeavors find ourselves running low on interiority these days.) Under normal circumstances, illness is a largely private event; even a common disease is suffered individually. But a pandemic isolates us collectively, as the grid illustrates almost too perfectly; we aren’t alone in our loneliness. When we Zoom, we “connect” along our metaphoric edges. We’ve existed in such grids for a while without really acknowledging it, one might argue, imprisoned in our small geometries of perspective. Grid life seems all too easy a metaphor for a society stripped bare, exposed for what it has become. But that’s the thing about the grid; live with it long enough and one forgets it’s there, until the next catastrophe.

headline: Coronavirus Invades Saudi Inner Sanctum
abstract: More than six weeks after Saudi Arabia reported its first case, the coronavirus is striking at the heart of the kingdom’s sprawling royal family.
lead_paragraph: The senior Saudi prince who is governor of Riyadh is in intensive care with the coronavirus. Several dozen other members of the royal family have been sickened as well. And doctors at the elite hospital that treats Al-Saud clan members are preparing as many as 500 beds for an expected influx of other royals and those closest to them, according to an internal “high alert” sent out by hospital officials.

headline: ‘Never Seen Anything Like It’: Cars Line Up for Miles at Food Banks
abstract: Millions are flooding a charitable system that was never intended to handle a nationwide crisis.
lead_paragraph: In Omaha, a food pantry that typically serves as few as 100 people saw 900 show up on a single day. In Jonesboro, Ark., after a powerful tornado struck, a food bank received less than half the donations it expected because nervous families held on to what they had. And in Washington State and Louisiana, the National Guard has been called in to help pack food boxes and ensure that the distributions run smoothly.

headline: Europe’s Big Economies Brace for Sharpest Drop Since World War II
abstract: Germany and France are a harbinger of how bad it’s about to get as countries weigh the cost of coronavirus-induced lockdowns against the prospect of an extended recession.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Cavernous factories devoid of workers. Cranes frozen in midair over construction sites. Millions of people confined to their homes, spending a fraction of what they used to before the coronavirus hit.

headline: Pearl Jam and Green Day Are Still Going Strong. But Can They Evolve?
abstract: Both bands started in the 1990s and have arena-sized followings today. On new albums, they take vastly different approaches than they have in the past.
lead_paragraph: In ordinary times, Pearl Jam and Green Day would both be on the road right now. Pearl Jam has just released “Gigaton,” its first studio album since 2013, and was set to headline arenas. Green Day’s 2020 album has a title that appears in family newspapers as “Father of All…,” and the band booked an international stadium tour — archly titled the Hella Mega Tour — as a nostalgia-tinged triple bill with a fellow 1990s band, Weezer, and Fall Out Boy, whose debut album appeared in 2001.

headline: The Pandemic Feeds Tech Companies’ Power
abstract: Our online habits are changing, likely for good. This could make tech companies even more muscular.
lead_paragraph: We need technology to keep us supplied, connected and informed in this pandemic. And these changes may stick with us. Are we giving too much power to tech companies now — and possibly forever?

headline: Another Way to See the Recession: Power Usage Is Way Down
Bernie Sanders Was Right
abstract: Goodbye to an honest man’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders has ended his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination, which is a tragedy, because he was right about virtually everything. He was right from the very beginning, when he advocated a total overhaul of the American health care system in the 1970s. He remains right now, as a pandemic stresses the meager resources of millions of citizens to their breaking point, and possibly to their death. He was right when he seemed to be the only alarmist in a political climate of complacency. He is right now that he’s the only politician unsurprised to see drug companies profiteering from a lethal plague with Congress’s help. In politics, as in life, being right isn’t necessarily rewarded. But at least there’s some dignity in it.

headline: Read Bernie Sanders’s Full Speech on Ending His Campaign
abstract: “While this campaign is coming to an end, our movement is not,” Mr. Sanders said in a video address on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: After Senator Bernie Sanders dropped out of the Democratic presidential race on Wednesday, he addressed supporters in a live stream from his home in Burlington, Vt.

headline: Angry Fans Say First the Concerts Were Canceled, Then the Refunds
abstract: Ticket vendors are being criticized for treating the thousands of live events that were called off as postponements, on which some do not offer refunds.
lead_paragraph: Tami Combs, a 58-year-old yoga instructor from Indiana, bought concert tickets to see the Rolling Stones, Elton John, Chicago and Sturgill Simpson this year.

headline: Microloans, Seen as Salvation for Poor Women, Trap Many in Debt
abstract: In Jordan, an unregulated microloan industry offers easy money. But with no way to repay loans, many women end up buried in debt, or in prison.
lead_paragraph: RUSSEIFA, Jordan — Five years ago, Amira Hawamdeh took out a loan for $423 to buy buttons and yarn to make purses and sweaters, and winter blankets to sell to her neighbors.

headline: ‘Roll Up Your Sleeves, Girls’
abstract: Cheryl Strayed calls the writer Margaret Atwood to talk about hard times, pansies and eight decades of getting it done.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Lynx Numbers Are in Decline in the West
abstract: While the federal government weighs taking the Canada lynx off the list of threatened species, a new study points to reduced populations in Washington State, Colorado and Montana.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the U.S. government has considered removing protections for the Canada lynx, which has been listed as a threatened species.

headline: Anne Bass, 78, Arts Patron and Peerless Gardener, Dies
abstract: A leading philanthropist, she championed, without fanfare, the New York City Ballet and numerous art museums. She also loved her dahlias.
lead_paragraph: Anne Hendricks Bass, the arts patron who helped raise the profile of ballet in the United States, harking back to an era when art was viewed as a vehicle for beauty and moral uplift, died on April 1 at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.

headline: Many Dermatology Practices Stay Open, Ignoring Public Health Pleas
abstract: Despite guidelines urging telemedicine to slow the spread of coronavirus infections, a number of dermatology offices are promoting in-person visits, including with special senior hours.
lead_paragraph: Though public health officials are urging medical practices to use virtual patient visits to help slow the spread of the coronavirus, a surprising number of dermatology offices, many of them owned by private equity investment firms, remain open for in-person skin checks and other nonurgent services.

headline: Help Comes Hard for the Orchestra With No Home
abstract: The Mahler Chamber Orchestra’s musicians, split across 14 countries, are dependent on support from their local governments to make ends meet during the coronavirus crisis.
lead_paragraph: Michiel Commandeur, a Dutch violinist, sounded surprisingly upbeat when he said his income had fallen to zero since the coronavirus pandemic began.

headline: Baking During Quarantine as an Act of Faith
abstract: I always have a batch or two of French cheese puffs in the freezer, even if it might be a while until I have friends over.
lead_paragraph: When I started cooking, I would spend hours during the week thinking about what I wanted to make over the weekend, and then I would spend the weekend making it. Every Saturday I shopped along a stretch of Ninth Avenue around the Port Authority Bus Terminal, in Manhattan. In those years, it wasn’t the best part of town, but to me, an adventurous fledging cook, the small shops were as thrilling as a grand bazaar. There was a spice shop where I could buy saffron by the pinch for paella and risotto. A store where I bought handmade phyllo to make spanakopita and baklava. There was a fishmonger who sold everything that went into a bouillabaisse, including an assortment of heads and bones to make the broth, and a butcher who learned about charcuterie in France after the war. He made pâtés like the ones I saw in Gourmet magazine, and had duck confit and sausages for cassoulet; I bought the classic beans — creamy white ones from Tarbes — at a market opposite the terminal. That’s also where I got the rice for the risotto.

headline: As Pandemic Imperils Elections, Democrats Clash With Trump on Voting Changes
abstract: Republicans, led by President Trump, are resisting broader voting access measures pushed by Democrats, which they see as threats to their election prospects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A showdown is taking shape in Congress over how far Washington should go in expanding voting access to respond to the coronavirus pandemic, with Democrats pressing to add new options for voters and President Trump and Republicans resisting changes they say could harm their election prospects in November.

headline: A Dip for All Your Wilting Herbs
abstract: In a perfect world, this snack would have tarragon, mint and chives, but it also works just as well with parsley and cilantro, or even arugula.
lead_paragraph: Even before the pandemic, I spent a good portion of my time working from home, which means I’m well practiced in the art of snacking more or less continuously from midafternoon until dinnertime. (Being so close to the kitchen naturally makes one very hungry.)

headline: John Prine’s 15 Essential Songs
abstract: He showed how much humor you could put in a song and still be taken seriously. The singer and songwriter died of complications of Covid-19 at 73.
lead_paragraph: John Prine was an Army veteran walking a U.S. Postal Service beat in Chicago and writing songs on the side when Kris Kristofferson heard him and helped spread the word about Prine’s gifts. Pretty soon, he resigned as a letter carrier; his supervisor snickered, “You’ll be back.” Nearly 50 years later, this January, he was given a lifetime achievement Grammy for his contributions to songwriting. The singing mailman almost always had the last laugh.

headline: Wells Fargo’s Growth Cap Eased to Aid Small-Business Crisis
abstract: The Federal Reserve said Wells Fargo could expand its balance sheet beyond a roughly $2 trillion cap, but only to lend to struggling businesses.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve made another move to try to expand small business owners’ access to emergency loans on Wednesday when it temporarily lifted a growth restriction it had imposed on Wells Fargo two years ago after the bank’s fake-account scandal.

headline: The 10 Funniest Movies on Netflix
abstract: We certainly could use a laugh. Here are some comedy options that just might put a smile on your face.
lead_paragraph: “Laughter is the best medicine.” “We could all use an escape right now.” “I just want to turn my brain off.” Clichés all, but some things become cliché because they’re true — and right now, while we’re all cooped up in varying states of worry for the foreseeable future, there are worse ideas than queuing up a comedy and taking your mind off … well, everything.

headline: Fed Emergency Rate Cuts Came as Economy Turned ‘Profoundly Uncertain’
abstract: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, and his colleagues slashed interest rates to near zero on March 15, and meeting minutes show why.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials found themselves staring down a “profoundly uncertain” economic outlook, on top of a financial market meltdown, when they chose to slash interest rates to near zero in mid-March.

headline: Syria Used Chemical Weapons 3 Times in One Week, Watchdog Says
abstract: An investigative team from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons accused the Syrian government of launching three chemical attacks on one village in 2017.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An investigative team with the international group that monitors compliance with the chemical weapons ban accused the Syrian government on Wednesday of having launched three chemical weapons attacks on one village in northern Syria in March 2017, sickening scores of people.

headline: 86-Year-Old Is Killed in E.R. Over Social Distancing
abstract: The woman became disoriented and grabbed the IV pole of another patient, who shoved her and caused a fatal head wound, officials said.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday afternoon in late March, as the coronavirus pandemic flooded hospitals across New York City with desperately ill people, an 86-year-old lost her bearings and started wandering the emergency room at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Congress Needs a Plan to Confront the Coronavirus. I Have One.
abstract: Government action is essential to save lives and to rescue our economy. Let’s get back to work.

headline: Please, Don’t Intentionally Infect Yourself. Signed, an Epidemiologist.
abstract: Here are seven reasons your “coronavirus party” is a bad idea.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus continues to spread, epidemiologists like me are starting to field a remarkable question: Would people be better off if they just contracted the virus and got it over with? I’ve heard rumblings about people avoiding physical distancing or hosting a version of “chickenpox parties,” where noninfected people mingle with an infected person in an effort to catch the virus.

headline: Coronavirus Turns Urban Life’s Roar to Whisper on World’s Seismographs
abstract: Geoscientists are getting a clearer picture of what’s going on beneath our feet as lockdowns keep many of us at home.
lead_paragraph: Seismometers may be built to detect earthquakes, but their mechanical ears hear so much more: hurricanes thundering hundreds of miles away and meteoroids exploding in the skies on the other side of the planet. Even the everyday hum of humanity — people moving about on cars, trains and planes — has a seismically detectable heartbeat.

headline: Hal Willner, Music Producer Who Melded Styles, Dies at 64
abstract: He was best known for assembling diverse casts of performers to play a slightly off-center body of work, and for obliterating the lines between genres.
lead_paragraph: Hal Willner had a dream of connecting musicians who couldn’t possibly work together to play music that didn’t obviously suit them, and he somehow made it all work, creating albums and concerts that obliterated the lines between rock, jazz, country and soul, or between the mainstream and the avant-garde. And then on Tuesday, the experiment came to an end.

headline: From a 5th-Place Finish to Here: A Timeline of Joe Biden’s Comeback
abstract: Before the Iowa caucuses in February, Mr. Biden’s campaign seemed in danger of collapsing. Now he is the presumptive Democratic nominee. Here’s how he turned things around.
lead_paragraph: For much of 2019, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was a steady and certain presence near the front of the Democratic presidential race. No amount of speed bumps — verbal gaffes, criticism of his long record as a Washington politician, even attacks from Republicans over his son’s dealings in Ukraine — could dislodge him from that position, much less sink his candidacy.

headline: Why Black Americans Are Hit Harder by the Coronavirus
abstract: How systemic inequality is playing out in the pandemic. Also: Sanctions on Iran; the changing face of grief; domestic abuse in the immigrant community; social distancing on sidewalks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ecuador Gives Glimpse Into Pandemic’s Impact on Latin America
abstract: In Guayaquil, Ecuador’s biggest city, a surge in deaths has overwhelmed health care and burial services. Scenes of bodies on sidewalks and desperate families serve as a warning for the region.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — Bodies left out on sidewalks. The authorities struggling to keep track of deaths. Funeral parlors, out of coffins, using cardboard boxes made by companies that usually package bananas and shrimp.

headline: Matt Reeves on ‘The Batman,’ ‘Tales From the Loop’ and Other Surreal Worlds
abstract: The filmmaker and producer talks about the personal stamp he tries to put on his work and what the comic-book vigilante has in common with “Klute.”
lead_paragraph: These are unusual times for everyone, including Matt Reeves. Best known as the director of sci-fi action films like “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” and as a creator of TV’s “Felicity,” he’s returning to television as an executive producer of the Amazon series “Tales From the Loop.”

headline: Trump Is Pushing a False Argument on Vote-by-Mail Fraud. Here Are the Facts.
abstract: As the coronavirus pandemic accelerates a national trend toward voting by mail, experts say it can be conducted safely, despite Republican claims of corruption.
lead_paragraph: With concerns mounting over how the country can conduct elections during a pandemic and Democrats pressing for alternatives to in-person voting, President Trump has begun pushing a false argument that has circulated among conservatives for years — that voting by mail is a recipe for fraud.

headline: Poachers Kill More Rhinos as Coronavirus Halts Tourism to Africa
abstract: Threatened and endangered animals may become additional casualties of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The past few weeks have not been easy for Nico Jacobs, founder of Rhino 911, a nonprofit that provides emergency helicopter transport for rhinoceroses in need of rescue in South Africa. That’s because times are much worse for the rhinos.

headline: Dow Jones Chief, William Lewis, to Step Down
abstract: Mr. Lewis, who is also the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said he was leaving the company in “strong financial shape.”
lead_paragraph: William Lewis, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal and chief executive of its parent company, Dow Jones, said that he would leave the roles he had held since 2014.

headline: Trade Forecast, Bernie Sanders, India’s Air: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Let us help you start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Zoom Rushes to Improve Privacy for Consumers Flooding Its Service
abstract: The features that allowed companies to hop on videoconferences also made it easy for trolls to hijack meetings and harass students.
lead_paragraph: Over the last month, the Zoom videoconferencing service has emerged as the communication lifeline of the coronavirus pandemic. But the convenience fueling Zoom’s explosive popularity has come at a price.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Exit, and Joe Biden’s Task Ahead
abstract: Readers encourage the senator to urge his avid fans to support Joe Biden, and react to Thomas L. Friedman’s column about a Biden bipartisan cabinet.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: More Coronavirus Vaccines and Treatments Move Toward Human Trials
abstract: Just three months after the start of the coronavirus pandemic, several biotech companies are beginning trials of promising vaccines and treatments.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic spreads at unprecedented rates, invading the lungs of people of all ages, ethnicities and medical histories, companies are ratcheting up their efforts to fight the disease with accelerated schedules for creating new vaccines, and beginning clinical trials for potential treatments.

headline: Linda Tripp, Key Figure in Clinton Impeachment, Dies at 70
abstract: She gave over her secretly recorded conversations with Monica Lewinsky to an independent prosecutor, a pivot point in his investigation of the president.
lead_paragraph: Linda Tripp, the former White House and Pentagon employee whose secret audiotapes of Monica Lewinsky led to the impeachment of President Bill Clinton in 1998, died on Wednesday. She was 70.

headline: Your Friendly Tech Bro Might Be Looking for a Loan
abstract: Many venture capitalists don’t want to attract pitchfork anger from those who think the well-to-do of tech should permanently social distance themselves from stimulus money.
lead_paragraph: How does an entrepreneur take a loan from the government to avoid layoffs when his company’s snack lounge has free kombucha on tap?

headline: Saudi Arabia Declares Cease-Fire in Yemen, Citing Fears of Coronavirus
abstract: If it sticks, the cease-fire would be the first nationwide truce in five years of war in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia on Wednesday announced that the kingdom and its allies would observe a unilateral cease-fire in the war in Yemen starting at noon on Thursday, a move that could pave the way for ending the brutal five-year-old conflict.

headline: Oil Markets Are a Mess. Can World Leaders Straighten Them Out?
abstract: Finding a solution that preserves jobs and bolsters fragile economies won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: Usually it’s the world’s major oil-producing countries that step in when a big drop in prices roils the oil market. But these are not normal times.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Daniel Radcliffe Reads ‘Somewhere Inside, a Path to Empathy’
abstract: The “Harry Potter” star reads an essay about a midlife diagnosis of Asperger’s syndrome.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Pandemic Intervention Models
abstract: How might different lengths of interventions impact the coronavirus crisis in the United States?
lead_paragraph: These graphs, showing models of how interventions like social distancing, school and business closings, hospital support and diagnostic testing might impact the pandemic in the United States, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com.

headline: Summer Heat May Not Diminish Coronavirus Strength
abstract: A new report, sent to the White House science adviser, says the country should not rely on warm weather to stop contagion.
lead_paragraph: The homebound and virus-wary across the Northern Hemisphere, from President Trump to cooped-up schoolchildren, have clung to the possibility that the coronavirus pandemic will fade in hot weather, as some viral diseases do.

headline: My Long, Unending Journey to Find Perfect Office Equipment
abstract: Ergonomics are important, but remember, there’s no one solution for everybody.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, I started working from home full time. Within just a few months, I threw my back out from sitting all day at a home office thrown together from what I had on hand. That event kicked off a quest to find office equipment that would be a bit easier on my spine. I expected the quest to consist of a trip to the store. Instead, it’s been years of learning what good posture really entails.

headline: Bernie Sanders Drops Out
abstract: What does Sanders’s exit mean for the movement he’s generated?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: What Does Wellness Mean Now?
abstract: How to think about self-care during uncertain times.
lead_paragraph: We spend a lot of our days chatting with each other about things we see online, trying to make sense of it all. This week in the Styles newsletter, Wait …, Amanda Hess, a critic-at-large, and Jenna Wortham, a staff writer for the Magazine and a host of the podcast “Still Processing,” discuss the wellness industry and their self-care routines.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Coronavirus, Passover: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Volunteers Rushed to Help New York Hospitals. They Found a Bottleneck.
abstract: When New York called for volunteers to help fight the coronavirus, 90,000 people responded. The hard part? Getting them into hospitals.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called for medical workers around the country to come to New York last month and join the fight against the coronavirus, Bevin Strickland was ready to help.

headline: Under Fire for Trades, Kelly Loeffler Says She Will Divest From Individual Stocks
abstract: The Georgia senator again defended her investments, denying accusations that she has tried to profit from the coronavirus crisis using inside information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seeking to move past allegations that she has tried to profit from the coronavirus crisis, Senator Kelly Loeffler, Republican of Georgia, announced on Wednesday that she and her husband would divest from all individual stocks and move their money into mutual and exchange-traded funds.

headline: Body of Second Kennedy Family Member Is Recovered From Chesapeake Bay
abstract: The discovery of 8-year-old Gideon McKean’s body came six days after he and his mother, Maeve Kennedy Townsend McKean, went missing in a canoe. Her body was found Monday.
lead_paragraph: The body of an 8-year-old grandson of former Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend of Maryland, who went missing with his mother in a canoe last week, was recovered in the Chesapeake Bay on Wednesday, two days after his mother’s body was found, the authorities said.

headline: Watching Virus Spread Back Home, Some Americans in Africa Stay Put
abstract: With the U.S. now leading the world in Covid-19 cases, its health care system fraying and economy faltering, some Americans abroad see their country in an unsettling light.
lead_paragraph: Mask shortages in hospitals. Inadequate coronavirus testing. Medical supplies flown in from overseas. And an international charity setting up a field hospital in Central Park.

headline: Now Comes the Hard Part for Joe Biden
abstract: Having become the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, he and his allies are aiming to win over Bernie Sanders’s younger, more liberal voters and unify the party.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. capped off his stunning political comeback on Wednesday, overcoming two failed presidential bids and months of organizational, fund-raising and messaging struggles to become the presumptive Democratic nominee. But the challenge of uniting the party around him is just beginning.

headline: How to Make Whipped Coffee
abstract: Dalgona coffee is having a moment on social media. Here’s how you can prepare it for yourself at home.
lead_paragraph: You may have seen it on Instagram or TikTok: a creamy, two-toned coffee drink amid the posts of push-up challenges, men growing mustaches and calls to draw a vegetable with your nose.

headline: Ahmed Ismail Hussein, Venerable Somali Musician, Dies at 91
abstract: Famously known as the “King of Oud,” Mr. Hussein was considered one of the giants of modern Somali music. He had the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: A Rush to Stocks, Driven by Bargains and Bravery
abstract: The S&P 500 is up 23 percent from its low last month. Opportunistic buyers are seeking bargains, while short-sellers are paradoxically helping amplify the rally.
lead_paragraph: Millions more are filing for unemployment benefits every week. The consumer spending that carries the economy is at a standstill. Small businesses are scrambling for loans to stay afloat.

headline: Chicago’s Jail Is Top U.S. Hot Spot as Virus Spreads Behind Bars
abstract: At least 1,324 confirmed coronavirus cases are tied to prisons and jails across the United States, according to data tracked by The Times, including at least 32 deaths.
lead_paragraph: It started small. On March 23, two inmates in the sprawling Cook County jail, one of the nation’s largest, were placed in isolation cells after testing positive for the coronavirus. In a little over two weeks, the virus exploded behind bars, infecting more than 350 people.

headline: Hacienda Santa Fe
abstract: Hacienda Santa Fe
lead_paragraph: Hacienda Santa Fe

headline: ‘It’s Hit Our Front Door’: Homes for the Disabled See a Surge of Covid-19
abstract: Caregivers for people with special needs are reeling as the coronavirus preys on the most vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: The call came on March 24. Bob McGuire, the executive director of CP Nassau, a nonprofit group that cares for the developmentally disabled, received a report from a four-story, colonnaded building in Bayville, N.Y., that houses several dozen residents with severe disabilities ranging from cerebral palsy to autism. For many of them, discussions of social distancing or hand washing are moot.

headline: How It Ended for Sanders
abstract: It wasn’t the Democratic establishment that defeated him. It was the ceiling on his support.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: In Trump’s Marathon Briefings, the Answers and the Message Are Often Contradictory
abstract: The president does not need adversaries to dispute his statements. He does that all by himself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump left little room for doubt. “We’re going to put a hold on money spent to the W.H.O.,” he said, referring to the World Health Organization. “We’re going to put a very powerful hold on it.”

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: As the virus tears through New York, it’s spreading through rural America, too.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus struck the U.S. first on the West Coast, but hardest in New York, where at least 6,268 people have died since the state’s first positive test on March 1. “The bad news isn’t just bad,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday. “The bad news is actually terrible.”

headline: Paul Kasmin, Gallerist Who Ruled a Mini-Empire of Art, Dies at 60
abstract: With his eclectic range and loyalty to living artists, one didn’t know what to expect on walking into one of his New York galleries.
lead_paragraph: Paul Kasmin, a British-born art dealer who established a small gallery empire in New York that was both loyal to an eclectic cohort of living artists and dedicated to presenting a distinctive range of historical material, died on March 23 at his home in Millbrook, N.Y. He was 60.

headline: New York’s Paramedics, on the Front Lines and Forgotten
abstract: Give these critical emergency workers the equipment they need and the pay they deserve.
lead_paragraph: Christell Cadet, a New York Fire Department paramedic, loves her job.

headline: Small-Business Aid Bill Faces Delay as Democrats Seek More Funds
abstract: Democrats say the $250 billion requested by the Trump administration for loans for the businesses will not pass unless money is included for hospitals and state and local governments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new debate broke out on Wednesday over the next infusion of federal dollars needed to bolster an economy battered by the coronavirus pandemic, as Democrats pressed to add money for hospitals and state and local governments to an emergency infusion of $250 billion requested by the Trump administration to help distressed small businesses.

headline: Where the Promise of Bernie Sanders Goes Now
abstract: The 2020 campaign was a great moment for his message, less so for him as the messenger. Mr. Sanders and Joe Biden now have to figure out what comes next for an agenda that matters to millions.
lead_paragraph: The Bernie Sanders campaign was built on big promises. There was the promise of affordable health care, the promise of free college, the promise of a higher minimum wage.

headline: Dana White Says U.F.C. 249 Is Being Cautious. Is That Good Enough?
abstract: The nearby hospital isn’t planning for the fights. The host tribe had closed its casino because of the coronavirus. And some legal experts think the highly anticipated event could still be shut down.
lead_paragraph: Dana White, the Ultimate Fighting Championship president, has insisted that his plans for a 12-fight mixed martial arts showcase this month will be safer for participants than staying at home or going to the grocery store during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Europe Poised to Repeat Austerity Mistakes in Coronavirus Response
abstract: Its rich north and poorer south need solidarity in response to an unprecedented crisis.
lead_paragraph: The European Union is ill suited for crisis. Its 27 members are happy to feed at the common trough in sunny times, but storms tend to turn them into squabbling rivals. The financial collapse of 2008 and the following refugee crisis are memorable for their bitter recriminations and disunity. It’s all happening again over Covid-19, this time amplified by fear and death on a continent struggling with half of the world’s 1.4 million confirmed cases.

headline: Why Republicans Are So Afraid of Vote-by-Mail
abstract: Public health officials recommend absentee ballots to keep people safe. But President Trump and his party, without evidence, portray expanded voting measures as ripe for fraud.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and his Republican allies are launching an aggressive strategy to fight what many of the administration’s own health officials view as one of the most effective ways to make voting safer amid the deadly spread of Covid-19: the expanded use of mail-in ballots.

headline: Optimism Is Less Distant as Global Coronavirus Battle Rages On
abstract: Scientists say drastic shifts in behavior appear to be having an effect in the pandemic, though they say the death toll will continue to mount and caution against drawing any sweeping conclusions.
lead_paragraph: The world began this week to see small but encouraging signs that concerted efforts to drastically change human behavior — to suspend daily routines by staying at home — are slowing the insidious spread of the novel coronavirus, which has killed tens of thousands and sickened more than a million others across several continents.

headline: Virus Is Twice as Deadly for Black and Latino People Than Whites in N.Y.C.
abstract: Officials revealed that disparity on Wednesday as they announced that 779 more people in the state had died of the virus, the second straight day that deaths spiked to new highs.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus is killing black and Latino people in New York City at twice the rate that it is killing white people, according to preliminary data released on Wednesday by the city.

headline: He Said, She Said, We Said, You Said
abstract: On Day Infinity of the lockdown, our critics and readers watched Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell fast-talk through “His Girl Friday.” Here’s what happened.
lead_paragraph: For the latest Weekend Watch Party, our critics cued up “His Girl Friday,” Howard Hawks’s fast-paced 1940 newspaper comedy about a big-city editor and the ace reporter who also happens to be his ex-wife. The romantic, journalistic and political high jinks that drive the picture defy easy summary, but there are a lot of spoilers here. The two leading players — Rosalind Russell as Hildy Johnson and Cary Grant as Walter Burns — have a lot to say. As did our own newsroom motormouths and, of course, the soul of any paper, printed or digital — you, our readers.

headline: Watch This: ‘Glow’ and ‘Damages’
abstract: Something serious and something fun for your midweek pick-me-up.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter, aimed at your needs, desires and tastes. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Disney Plus Racks Up 50 Million Subscribers in 5 Months
abstract: The Hollywood colossus has been crippled by the pandemic. Its upstart streaming service is one exception.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney has taken an especially hard hit from the pandemic, with its theme parks shuttered, movies postponed and ESPN cable channel without live sports to televise.

headline: Focus the Covid-19 Fight in Black Cities
abstract: Let’s concentrate on where the need has been shown to be greatest.
lead_paragraph: This is less of a newspaper column for general readers than an open letter to public health officials in America — a missive, really: Figure out if majority-black cities are suffering more than others, and if so focus a significant part of your fight against the coronavirus, both resources and research, there.

headline: C.D.C. Releases Early Demographic Snapshot of Worst Coronavirus Cases
abstract: The agency’s study of hospitalizations for Covid-19 in March shows heightened numbers for those with underlying conditions, men and African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: On March 1, there were 88 confirmed cases of the coronavirus in the United States. By month’s end, there were more than 170,000. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has compiled data on people who were hospitalized from the virus during that month to get a clearer demographic picture of infected patients who have required the most serious medical care.

headline: Trump Hates Having Too Many Voters
abstract: Suddenly, the White House loves Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: So. It’s all settled. Joe Biden versus Donald Trump. We’ve got the candidates for the 2020 presidential race, people. Now all we have to do is make sure we have an election.

headline: Mississippi State Football Coach Must Visit Civil Rights Museum After Noose Tweet
abstract: Mike Leach shared a meme on Twitter of an older white woman under quarantine knitting a noose for her husband. He later removed the post.
lead_paragraph: The first-year football coach at Mississippi State University has been reprimanded and must visit a civil rights museum after he recently shared a meme on Twitter of a woman knitting a noose, the university’s athletic director said this week.

headline: Most New York Coronavirus Cases Came From Europe, Genomes Show
abstract: Travelers seeded multiple cases starting as early as mid-February, genomes show.
lead_paragraph: New research indicates that the coronavirus began to circulate in the New York area by mid-February, weeks before the first confirmed case, and that travelers brought in the virus mainly from Europe, not Asia.

headline: Method of Communication
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners hides in plain sight.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Just a reminder that my columns are truncated this week. Please help one another with the tricky clues, and things should be back where they belong on Monday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Sanders Ends Bid As Biden Gets Set to Battle Trump
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “While this campaign is coming to an end, our movement is not.”

headline: Corrections: April 9, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An On This Day in History item on Monday about an antiwar demonstration in New York in 1969 misstated the type of conscription that was instituted that year. It was the draft lottery, not the draft.

headline: E.U. Officials Agree to Deal to Soften Coronavirus’s Economic Blow
abstract: The ministers were unable to reach an agreement on issuing joint bonds, known as “corona-bonds.” Critics say their €540 billion loan package does too little for Spain and Italy.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our live global coverage on the coronavirus epidemic.

headline: Coronavirus, Bernie Sanders, European Union: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Chynna, Model-Turned-Hip-Hop Artist, Dies at 25
abstract: The rapper, whose full name was Chynna Rogers, performed with ASAP Rocky’s hip-hop collective ASAP Mob.
lead_paragraph: Chynna, the hip-hop artist who first turned heads on the modeling runway and then with her talent as a rapper, died on Wednesday in her native Philadelphia. She was 25.

headline: OPEC Talks to Cut Oil Production Disappoint Traders
abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Never Rarely Sometimes Always’ and ‘Shaq Life’
abstract: Eliza Hittman’s newly released drama is available for digital rental. And “Shaq Life” debuts on TNT.
lead_paragraph: NEVER RARELY SOMETIMES ALWAYS (2020) Rent on Amazon, Fandango Now, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. A teenager goes on a subtly perilous journey to terminate her pregnancy in “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” the latest feature from the filmmaker Eliza Hittman. The movie follows Autumn (Sidney Flanigan), a 17-year-old who can’t get an abortion in her central Pennsylvania hometown without parental permission, which isn’t in the cards for her. So she takes a bus to New York, where she can have the procedure without permission. But the city presents its own host of challenges. Manohla Dargis called the movie a “low-key knockout” in her review for The Times. “Hittman is telling a story,” Dargis added, “but she’s also making a quietly fierce argument about female sovereignty.”

headline: Poem: Fiction Versus Nonfiction
abstract: Lois Beardslee's poetry examines myths and mysteries, contemplating traditional stereotypes around indigenous communities, in a matter-of-fact and personal tone.
lead_paragraph: One question students often ask visiting writers: “Is this true, or is it made-up?” But can there ever be a single answer? In Lois Beardslee’s deeply engaging new poetry collection, “Words Like Thunder,” she examines myths and mysteries, contemplating traditional stereotypes around indigenous communities, particularly around the Great Lakes region, illuminating stories and attitudes. Her tone is matter-of-fact and personal, as in this poem. With a text richly packed with facts, tales and voices we all need to know more about, she slices through categorizations and refreshes truth. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Premier League Clubs and Players Are at War. Both Are Losing.
abstract: For three weeks, the world’s richest soccer league has been consumed by a debate over whether players, or clubs, should bear the cost of the coronavirus crisis. It has turned so toxic the schism may be hard to heal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — By Saturday afternoon, after three weeks of impasse, after hearing their morals questioned by politicians and witnessing their clubs start to line up for government bailouts, the players of the Premier League decided to take matters into their own hands.

headline: Word + Quiz: demotic
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Bernie Sanders Makes His First Post-Dropout Appearance on ‘The Late Show’
abstract: “Bernie Sanders is saying Bernie Sanders can’t win?” Stephen Colbert joked Wednesday. “Man, he is going to catch hell from Bernie Sanders supporters.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Music Notes
abstract: What do you think this image is saying?
lead_paragraph: What is this image saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: What Happened to Jane Austen’s Brother … and Other Letters
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: These Young Renters Wanted a Starter Apartment in Manhattan for a Reasonable Price. Here’s What They Found.
abstract: Diplomas in hand, two Mississippi roommates headed north to ‘figure something out’ in New York City. Which of these options did they choose?
lead_paragraph: Diplomas in hand, two Mississippi roommates headed north to ‘figure something out’ in New York City. Which of these options did they choose?

headline: The Nobel-Winning Economist Who Wants You to Read More Fiction
abstract: “I would encourage anyone interested in understanding the Great Depression or mid-19th century Britain to turn to Steinbeck or Dickens.”
lead_paragraph: “I would encourage anyone interested in understanding the Great Depression or mid-19th century Britain to turn to Steinbeck or Dickens,” says Joseph E. Stiglitz, whose book “People, Power, and Profits” will be out in paperback soon.

headline: Jen Gotch Is Not a Therapist, but She Knows How to Cope
abstract: The retail guru and best-selling author of “The Upside of Being Down” shares practical advice for readers and ruminators.
lead_paragraph: TRY THIS AT HOME Jen Gotch has a message for people who feel alone in this season of social isolation and coronavirus dread: “I’ve been training for this for years and still feel all the things everyone is feeling.”

headline: Sweating to the Oldies. Or Sitting?
abstract: An array of workout videos from over the decades that you can enjoy even from (maybe especially from) the comfort of your couch.
lead_paragraph: Most of our workouts are at home now. Which is why it’s an ideal time to get lost in the wild world of the vintage exercise video.

headline: You and Your Kids Can’t Stand Each Other. Now What?
abstract: When you’re on lockdown together and things run off the rails, it’s time for a family meeting.
lead_paragraph: Some conflict is normal in a family. When we’re quarantined together around the clock for days on end, with everyone affected by a range of stresses, it’s practically inevitable. And the way we talk to one another about our conflicts can often make them worse.

headline: Looking at the History of Viruses and Public Opinion
abstract: In 1999, David Papineau wrote for the Book Review about “Flu,” Gina Kolata’s book about the 1918 influenza pandemic and the hunt for the virus that caused it.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, David Papineau wrote for the Book Review about “Flu,” Gina Kolata’s book about the 1918 influenza pandemic and the hunt for the virus that caused it.

headline: After Years of Anticipation, Final Fantasy VII Fans Get Their Reboot
abstract: The original, released 23 years ago, sold more than 11 million copies and inspired spinoffs, animated movies and fan fiction. The bar is high for the new game, which will drop Friday.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, the idea of a remake for the beloved video game Final Fantasy VII seemed as outlandish as your neighbor’s son’s best friend’s uncle actually working for Nintendo.

headline: The Coronavirus Derails Marina Abramovic’s Maria Callas Opera
abstract: “7 Deaths of Maria Callas” should have been the culmination of a 60-year obsession. Now its future is uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Marina Abramovic has pulled off some crazy feats.

headline: Trouble Focusing? Not Sleeping? You May Be Grieving
abstract: “It’s normal and natural to not be able to just go on as usual.”
lead_paragraph: I couldn’t understand, at first, why I was having such trouble writing. In early March, following the advice of public-health experts, my husband and I had isolated ourselves with his septuagenarian parents, thinking that we could help them. At the end of each quiet day, I sat buzzing with terror but strangely listless, having accomplished very little. Until recently, I traveled a lot for work: Since publishing my first novel, I’ve often been on the road for speaking, teaching and other book-related gigs.

headline: Why the Wealthy Fear Pandemics
abstract: The coronavirus, like other plagues before it, could shift the balance between rich and poor.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1347, rat fleas carrying bubonic plague entered Italy on a few ships from the Black Sea. Over the next four years, a pandemic tore through Europe and the Middle East. Panic spread, as the lymph nodes in victims’ armpits and groins swelled into buboes, black blisters covered their bodies, fevers soared and organs failed. Perhaps a third of Europe’s people perished.

headline: Listen. Relax. Sleep Can Boost Your Immunity.
abstract: Using guided relaxation tapes soothed my insomnia, and may help you now.
lead_paragraph: If the coronavirus is dominating your thoughts by day, perhaps it is also keeping you up at night. Sleeping well during a pandemic might not seem like a top priority, but it should be: Sleep is one of the most effective ways to prepare your body to fight infection.

headline: The Humble Phone Call Has Made a Comeback
abstract: The volume of phone calls has surged more than internet use as people want to hear each other’s voices in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Alyssa MacKenzie, 32, rarely used her smartphone to make phone calls, apart from the occasional conversation for her work as a disability rights advocate.

headline: The Challenge of Social Distancing in Hasidic Communities
abstract: The very things that make the place I grew up in unique and beautiful may contribute to the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: My mother is a Hasidic woman with 12 children, close to a hundred grandchildren, and many great-grandchildren. Passover 2020 will be the first time she will recite the Ma Nishtana — the four questions of the Haggadah, traditionally asked by the youngest child at the table — herself. She will serve her incomparable chicken soup and egg noodles, fermented borscht with warm potatoes, and falsche fish made of a mixture of ground chicken and turkey only to my father. While the coronavirus sweeps through the world, her dining-room table that seats 12 and extends for 14 or more will host a party of two.

headline: Can Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden Unite the Democratic Party?
abstract: If the last stretch of the Sanders campaign was any indication, a focus on defeating President Trump — “a matter of life and death” — could do it.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — In what now feels like a faded postcard from an antiquated universe, Senator Bernie Sanders was wrapping up one of his last, elbow-flailing rallies in front of a few thousand supporters at the University of Michigan. It was late on a Sunday afternoon in early March, a few days before the coronavirus would effectively shelter the 2020 presidential campaign in place, with Mr. Sanders stuck in the runner-up position.

headline: The America We Need
abstract: How to make the nation more just, less fragile — and more free.
lead_paragraph: From some of its darkest hours, the United States has emerged stronger and more resilient.

headline: Transit Has Been Battered by Coronavirus. What’s Ahead May Be Worse.
abstract: “The number of scenarios that we have to plan for is staggering.”
lead_paragraph: Fare revenue has vanished across the country as transit riders have. Even those essential workers still taking the bus or train aren’t generating much money for agencies strained by the coronavirus pandemic. Many systems have moved to free service, or stopped policing fares. It’s just too risky for bus drivers if anyone comes near the farebox a foot away.

headline: The Supreme Court Fails Us
abstract: The five conservative justices refused to extend the deadline for absentee ballots in Wisconsin in the middle of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court just met its first test of the coronavirus era. It failed, spectacularly.

headline: Flying via a Smaller Airport? It May Take a While
abstract: Passengers looking to fly to and from regional airports are feeling the brunt of airline cuts even more than those in bigger hubs, with many cancellations and circuitous routes.
lead_paragraph: Cathy Cichowski was trying to get from Halifax, Nova Scotia, to San Antonio, where her job in a hospital involves workplace safety. She came to Canada to say goodbye to her terminally ill mother but was desperately needed back at the hospital, where one of her tasks is helping make sure nurses’ masks are appropriately fitted.

headline: The U.S. Approach to Public Health: Neglect, Panic, Repeat
abstract: Time to give new life to an old idea: A strong public health system is the best guarantor of good health.
lead_paragraph: A once-in-a-century public health crisis is unfolding, and the richest country in the world is struggling to mount an effective response. Hospitals don’t have enough gowns or masks to protect doctors and nurses, nor enough intensive care beds to treat the surge of patients. Laboratories don’t have the equipment to diagnose cases quickly or in bulk, and state and local health departments across the country don’t have the manpower to track the disease’s spread. Perhaps worst of all, urgent messages about the importance of social distancing and the need for temporary shutdowns have been muddied by politics.

headline: Fighting Trump’s Falsehoods
abstract: Plus, discerning social distance.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: We Were Planning an Inequality Project. Then History Lurched.
abstract: Times Opinion will be arguing its way to some proposals for how America can emerge stronger from this crisis.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I polled my colleagues in Times Opinion about what subjects they thought we should focus on in 2020. The overwhelming answer was that we should bear down on how inequality of wealth and income was distorting American society.

headline: Traveling by Ear: 13 Podcasts for Wandering Souls
abstract: Close your eyes and be transported to Mexico, Italy, Montana and beyond. All you have to do is listen.
lead_paragraph: For most travelers nowadays, home is the only destination. Yet thanks to some imaginative podcasts, you can still explore the world. The following were selected because rather than focus on such things as miles and points, they’re transportive — rife with the sounds of cities and wilderness, conversations with creative thinkers, and ways to change your life through adventure and language learning. So don some noise-cancelling headphones and pick your favorite audio platform (Spotify, Apple Podcasts, Google Podcasts). Soon you’ll be hearing birdsong in Tuscany, rain falling in the English countryside, and wind rustling trees in Paris as you ride a scooter along the Champs-Élysées.

headline: A Group Picture That Just Had to Be Weird
abstract: All it took to capture the essence of Al Yankovic for a Times Magazine photo shoot was 232 fans in wigs, mustaches, aviator glasses and Hawaiian shirts (accordions optional).
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The Weirdly Enduring Appeal of Weird Al Yankovic
abstract: National economies collapse; species go extinct; political movements rise and fizzle. But — somehow, for some reason — Weird Al keeps rocking.

headline: In Scramble for Coronavirus Supplies, Rich Countries Push Poor Aside
abstract: Developing nations in Latin America and Africa cannot find enough materials and equipment to test for coronavirus, partly because the United States and Europe are outspending them.
lead_paragraph: Crates of masks snatched from cargo planes on airport tarmacs. Countries paying triple the market price to outbid others. Accusations of “modern piracy” against governments trying to secure medical supplies for their own people.

headline: What New York Looks Like Now: A Photo Journey
abstract: Makeshift hospitals and morgues, some in unexpected places, make the consequences of coronavirus unescapable.
lead_paragraph: The sirens seem endless. Even for New York. They cut through the silent streets, reminding us that the crisis we are facing is no longer an abstract idea. No longer contained to TV screens or even the hospital a few blocks away.

headline: While the World Spends on Coronavirus Bailouts, China Holds Back
abstract: Beijing has tried to protect jobs and spur lending, but it may have to do more to get its huge, damaged and incredibly complex economy going again.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The world is opening its wallet to fight the  effects of the coronavirus outbreak. The United States unveiled a $2 trillion rescue package. European countries have announced their own spending blitz, and Japan approved a nearly $1 trillion economic stimulus plan.

headline: Checkpoints, Curfews, Airlifts: Virus Rips Through Navajo Nation
abstract: The coronavirus is tearing across the largest Native American reservation in the United States. Facing a spike in deaths, Navajo officials are scrambling to respond.
lead_paragraph: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz. — When Chad Yazzie joined the Navajo Police Department just a few months ago, he expected to issue speeding tickets or break up the occasional fistfight.

headline: Jobless Claims Surpass 16 Million; Aid Package Stalls in Senate
abstract: The virus is sickening workers at chicken and beef processing plants, and 799 New Yorkers were killed — a single-day record for the state.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our live national updates and global coverage on the coronavirus epidemic.

headline: Record Virus Deaths for a Second Day
abstract: Deaths from the coronavirus spiked to new highs in both New York and New Jersey on Wednesday.
