lead_paragraph: President Trump and Joe Biden begin the general election campaign locked in a highly competitive contest that remains fought along the lines of the 2016 presidential election, according to national and battleground state polls.

headline: Why Am I Having Weird Dreams Lately?
abstract: Because we all are. But know this: You can program your dreams.
lead_paragraph: The question of whether “anyone else” has “been having” strange dreams (“lately”) is perennially popular online. It is a spooky yet comforting query: Has anyone else stumbled onto possible evidence that the universe possesses a finite metaphysical infrastructure occasionally detected by the subconscious?

headline: The Clarity That Comes With Hard Times
abstract: My worries over small things recede in a crisis.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Some time in the last two weeks I stopped finding pandemic jokes funny. All I can think about anymore are the thousands of people who have already died, or the millions who have lost their jobs, or the many others who go to work terrified of getting sick. Domestic violence is skyrocketing. The social safety net is in tatters. No matter how funny the joke, it’s hard to laugh at a time of suffering so widespread, of mortality so close at hand.

headline: Are We All in This Together?
abstract: The pandemic has helpfully scrambled how we value everyone’s economic and social roles.
lead_paragraph: Mobilizing to confront the pandemic and, eventually, to reconstruct the shattered economy, requires not only medical and economic expertise but also moral and political renewal. We need to ask a basic question that we have evaded over these last decades: What do we owe one another as citizens?

headline: Monday’s Live-Streaming Events: Elizabeth Marvel Discussing Shakespeare and Jason Robert Brown in Concert
abstract: Appointment viewing is back. Find out what online events to look for today, and when to tune in.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the best events happening Friday through Sunday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern Standard). Updated daily.

headline: We Need to Talk About What Coronavirus Recoveries Look Like
abstract: They’re a lot more complicated than most people realize.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since I was hospitalized for the coronavirus, the same question has flooded my email inbox, texts and direct messages: Are you better yet? I don’t yet know how to answer. While the widespread support from friends, family and strangers has been very heartwarming, I’ve also struggled to reconcile the genuine happiness expressed at my improving condition with my own lingering symptoms, confusion about contagion, and anxieties about relapse.

headline: Damage From OxyContin Continues to Be Revealed
abstract: Research shows Purdue Pharma focused its marketing in states with lighter prescription regulation, with deadly consequences.
lead_paragraph: OxyContin, and the aggressive, misleading way that Purdue Pharma marketed it, might have been even more damaging than previously understood.

headline: Their Calling Was to Lay Hands on the Sick. Then Came the Coronavirus.
abstract: How the pandemic transformed the lives and ministry of eight Manhattan friars, and what their example can teach the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Vincent Dyer, a 45-year-old Catholic friar, begins his days now in a sealed nursing home in Manhattan. He celebrates Mass in an empty chapel. The service is broadcast over closed-circuit television into residents’ rooms. “And I preach,” he told me, “because the people are listening,” even though there are no eyes in the chapel to reflect recognition, and no heads to bow in thanks. “I say a prayer of spiritual communion, because they can’t physically receive the sacrament.”

headline: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Has Never Spoken to Joe Biden. Here’s What She Would Say.
abstract: In an interview, Ms. Ocasio-Cortez said she intended to support the presumptive Democratic nominee, but the “process of coming together should be uncomfortable for everyone involved.”
lead_paragraph: The progressive wing of the Democratic Party fell flat in this year’s presidential primary, and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez knows it.

headline: Why We Desperately Need Oversight of the Coronavirus Stimulus Spending
abstract: Rigorous watchdogs can ensure that vast amounts of taxpayer money aren’t lost to fraud or handed out as political favors.
lead_paragraph: More than $2 trillion is about to head out the door, committed in a single news release last week by the Federal Reserve Board. In that release, the Federal Reserve announced how it and the Treasury Department intend to leverage just a portion of the $454 billion that Congress gave the department in the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act, known as the CARES Act, with the potential of trillions more in lending to come.

headline: Cupid in Quarantine: What Brain Science Can Teach Us About Love
abstract: A global tragedy has forced us into full-time togetherness. Here’s how couples can rekindle romantic love and grow together rather than apart.
lead_paragraph: Long ago, my man and I agreed to do what’s called “Living Apart Together,” or LAT. Even if we ever marry, I intend to keep my pad in Manhattan and spend a couple nights there alone every week.

headline: I Was Fired Because of the Coronavirus
abstract: Domestic workers need your help. And you need ours.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For the past year, I have cared for a 95-year-old woman. I went to her family’s home, watched TV with her, talked to her and gave her medication. We shared stories. I made her food: bread with butter or peanut butter. Noodle soup was her favorite. We made each other laugh.

headline: Just What Older People Didn’t Need: More Isolation
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic could sharpen the health risks of loneliness. But there are ways to connect.
lead_paragraph: At midmorning, Lisa Carfagna, a marketing staffer for the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan, took a brief break from working at home on Long Island and called the Rubins on the Upper East Side.

headline: Foreign Doctors Could Help Fight Coronavirus. But U.S. Blocks Many.
abstract: Nurses and doctors are ensnared by red tape and visa rules that prevent them from working in U.S. hospitals, where they are needed to respond to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Visa and airline ticket in hand, a Filipina nurse named Maria checked in recently for her flight from London to the United States, where a job awaited her as an intensive care nurse at a North Carolina hospital on the front lines of the coronavirus crisis.

headline: The Coronavirus Stimulus Is Playing Hard to Get
abstract: Why do we make it so difficult for people to receive unemployment and other forms of relief?
lead_paragraph: Kaula Carr’s job in Arizona disappeared in March when the restaurant where she worked laid off staff members in response to the coronavirus crisis.

headline: Big Business Pledged Gentler Capitalism. It’s Not Happening in a Pandemic.
abstract: C.E.O.s who signed a celebrated Business Roundtable document, promising to elevate worker interests, are now resorting to furloughs.
lead_paragraph: Last August, the chief executives of 181 of America’s largest corporations signed a document pledging their commitment to run their companies for the benefit of workers and communities, and not just for shareholders.

headline: The Art (and Awkwardness) of a Virtual Haircut
abstract: My husband’s hair was looking shaggy. So were my bangs. A hairstylist came to our rescue — or did she? — over video chat.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — More than 20 days into San Francisco’s shelter-in-place orders, with hair salons and barbershops closed, I was resigned to growing out my bangs. But my husband, Matt, who had gone almost two months without a cut, began threatening to shave his head.

headline: He Makes Physics Funny
abstract: If “The Future Adventures of Schrödinger’s Cat” or “Pavlov’s Household” rings a bell, you may already be in the mind of Tom Gauld.
lead_paragraph: Tom Gauld’s drawings have always had a cerebral bent. One of the Scottish cartoonist's most famous New Yorker covers is of a woman reading in a room filled with impossibly tall towers of books. It looks like a fantasy.

headline: Apollo 13’s Astronauts Survived Disaster 50 Years Ago. Could It Happen Again?
abstract: A trip to the moon later this decade should be safer, but it won’t be safe.
lead_paragraph: Apollo 13 almost killed three NASA astronauts.

headline: Missives From My Locked-Down Friends, From Siberia to Samarkand
abstract: The people I met as the 52 Places Traveler were suddenly just as close as my friends down the street, so I reached out to my global community.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy day in November I dropped a postcard into the “international” slot outside the post office in Greymouth, a quiet town on the western coast of New Zealand’s South Island. It was perhaps the most ambitious of the 145 postcards I sent in 2019, not because of its content, but because of how it would test the global postal system.

headline: Who Is Immune to the Coronavirus?
abstract: Important decisions about this question are being made, as they must be, based on only glimmers of data.
lead_paragraph: Among the many uncertainties that remain about Covid-19 is how the human immune system responds to infection and what that means for the spread of the disease. Immunity after any infection can range from lifelong and complete to nearly nonexistent. So far, however, only the first glimmers of data are available about immunity to SARS-CoV-2, the coronavirus that causes Covid-19.

headline: When Will Life Be Normal Again? We Just Don’t Know
abstract: As some enter a month or more of lockdown, we have more questions than answers.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans have been living under lockdown for a month or more. We’re all getting antsy. The president is talking about a “light at the end of the tunnel.” People are looking for hope and reasons to plan a return to something — anything — approximating normalcy. Experts are starting to speculate on what lifting restrictions will look like. Despite the relentless, heroic work of doctors and scientists around the world, there’s so much we don’t know.

headline: Trump Insists He Has ‘Total’ Authority to Supersede Governors
abstract: State leaders on both coasts are starting to debate how and when to reopen. The closure of a major meat processing plant could affect the nation’s food supply.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our  latest coverage of the coronavirus epidemic.

headline: Coronavirus, Anthony Fauci, Tornadoes: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Mayor and Governor Disagree Over School Closure
abstract: A dispute between Mayor Bill de Blasio and Governor Andrew M. Cuomo created uncertainty about when city schools could reopen.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: How Much Do You Know About Zambia?
abstract: Can you find Zambia on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with a population of about 17 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Zambia on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with a population of about 17 million people?

headline: Voices of the Pandemic
abstract: Screaming children, worried employees, sick parents and anxious grocery shoppers: This is a peek inside our new world.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Quarantine as a Shared Experience
abstract: Some families are sheltering in place together as a way to balance child care and work demands — at home or farther afield.
lead_paragraph: With schools closed and the streets empty across the country because of the coronavirus pandemic, many parents are spending their days tethered to their homes, trying to think up activities to occupy their children. If the parents are also working, the struggle can be even harder. But some families have come up with a solution: shared quarantine.

headline: Why Trump is Pushing for Higher Oil Prices
abstract: Low prices have battered U.S. energy companies, putting the president in the unfamiliar position of coordinating with OPEC instead of criticizing it.
lead_paragraph: Starting tomorrow, we will be holding a special call every Tuesday for entrepreneurs and other business leaders about the day-to-day challenges of running a business during the pandemic. The DealBook Helpline will feature experts from a variety of fields to answer your most pressing questions. Sign up here for the April 13 call, at 11 a.m. Eastern. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: On Politics: How Trump Fell Short on the Coronavirus
abstract: An investigation found many early warnings of the virus’s threat: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Socialists of America, an increasingly influential grass-roots group that backed both of Bernie Sanders’s presidential runs, will not be supporting Biden in November.

headline: ‘Worst Is Over,’ Cuomo Says as 7 States Ally to Reopen Economy
abstract: The announcement of a team effort to ease restrictions that have halted most aspects of life coincided with hopefuls signs about the coronavirus’s spread.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Tuesday’s live coverage.]

headline: Why You Should Start a Coronavirus Diary
abstract: It’ll help you organize your thoughts during these difficult times, and may help educate future generations.
lead_paragraph: On March 16, Ruth Franklin of Brooklyn tweeted: “Today has been quiet, sort of, so far. Take a moment and make some notes about what’s happening. Call it your Coronavirus diary, your plague journal, whatever. It’s important. Later, you will want a record.”

headline: Putin’s Long War Against American Science
abstract: A decade of health disinformation promoted by President Vladimir Putin of Russia has sown wide confusion, hurt major institutions and encouraged the spread of deadly illnesses.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 3, soon after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus to be a global health emergency, an obscure Twitter account in Moscow began retweeting an American blog. It said the pathogen was a germ weapon designed to incapacitate and kill. The headline called the evidence “irrefutable” even though top scientists had already debunked that claim and declared the novel virus to be natural.

headline: Wisconsin Election Results: What to Watch For
abstract: Nearly a week after voters in the state went to the polls in the middle of a pandemic, results from an important Wisconsin Supreme Court race and the presidential primary will arrive.
lead_paragraph: The lines were long. Voters wore masks and gloves. And nearly a week after Wisconsin had people go to the polls in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic — despite closing hundreds of precincts — the results are expected to arrive on Monday evening.

headline: China Limited the Mekong’s Flow. Other Countries Suffered a Drought.
abstract: New research show that Beijing’s engineers appear to have directly caused the record low levels of water in Thailand, Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — As China was stricken by the coronavirus in late February, its foreign minister addressed a concerned crowd in Laos, where farmers and fishers across the Mekong River region were contending with the worst drought in living memory.

headline: Trump’s Role in the Death Toll
abstract: He was warned, again and again.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: What Acts of Kindness Have You Heard About or Participated In During Coronavirus?
abstract: During this crisis people and groups have delivered free groceries, canceled rent for tenants and called to check in on seniors. How might helping others also benefit oneself?
lead_paragraph: In “The Science of Helping Out” Tara Parker-Pope argues, “During a crisis, the people who cope best are those who help others.” Does that concept resonate with you? Have you ever received any personal benefits by helping others?

headline: What You Get for $450,000 in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern house in Palm Desert, a remodeled ranch house in the San Joaquin Valley and a 1922 Craftsman-style house in Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: A midcentury-modern house in Palm Desert, a remodeled ranch house in the San Joaquin Valley and a 1922 Craftsman-style house in Sacramento.

headline: $450,000 Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern house in Palm Desert, a remodeled ranch house in the San Joaquin Valley and a 1922 Craftsman-style house in Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: Just over two hours east of Los Angeles, Palm Desert is a city in the Coachella Valley popular with fans of midcentury-modern aesthetics. In addition to its plentiful midcentury homes, the area (along with nearby Palm Springs) is home to a number of antiques stores specializing in 1950s and 1960s furnishings.

headline: Pay Cuts Come to Condé Nast, the Glossy Publisher of Vogue and Vanity Fair
abstract: The pandemic’s fallout has put “significant financial pressure” on a company known for its lavishness.
lead_paragraph: Condé Nast, the most glittering of all magazine publishers, is the latest media casualty of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Why California’s Community Health Clinics Are Vital, but Hurting
abstract: Monday: A look at the clinics that care for some of California’s most vulnerable patients.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Coronavirus Fears Terrify and Impoverish Migrants in the Persian Gulf
abstract: Millions of migrant workers in Gulf countries have found themselves locked down, laid off and stranded, with no place to turn for help.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Qatar has locked down tens of thousands of migrant workers in a crowded neighborhood, raising fears it will become a coronavirus hotbed. Companies in Saudi Arabia have told foreign laborers to stay home — then stopped paying them. In Kuwait, an actress said on TV that migrants should be thrown out “into the desert.”

headline: How to Cook Now
abstract: Feed your family, or just yourself. We have recipes for whatever situation you’re in.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I miss restaurants. I miss the bustle of them when everyone in them is in sync, from the customers in the dining room to the cooks in the kitchen, the hosts and captains and servers seeing around corners, hospitality phasers set to stun. I miss the clatter and hum, the music of conversation, the sense of possibility. I miss the people-watching, and the food.

headline: In Rural Japan, a 370-Year-Old Tradition Falls to One Child
abstract: Every year, students in a mountain village spend months preparing for an elaborate Kabuki performance. An aging society has put their show — and their school — in jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: SHITARA, Japan — More than three centuries of tradition rest on Mao Takeshita’s narrow shoulders.

headline: 5 Fast Pastas for Long Days
abstract: These recipes come together in the time it takes for the noodles to cook.
lead_paragraph: Some people are perfecting their laminated pastry, their sourdough boules or, at the very least, simmering through their stash of dried beans.

headline: On ‘The New Abnormal,’ the Strokes Flip Nostalgia Toward the Future
abstract: The band’s sixth album, produced by Rick Rubin, makes clear that the group never intended to reincarnate garage rock or proto-punk.
lead_paragraph: Even when the Strokes were a brand-new band, nostalgia was a big part of their appeal. “In many ways, they’ll miss the good old days/Someday,” Julian Casablancas sang on “Someday” from the Strokes’s 2001 debut album, “Is This It.” At the time, the Strokes were already being hailed as a second — maybe third or fourth — coming of a terse, hardheaded, jaded but hopped-up New York City rock lineage running from the Velvet Underground through the New York Dolls and the Ramones.

headline: Israel Sauz, Gas-Station Worker and New Father, Dies at 22
abstract: He graduated from high school in Tulsa, Okla., four years ago. He worked at QuikTrip and his son was born a month ago. Then he died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Lila Fenwick, Who Broke a Barrier at Harvard Law, Dies at 87
abstract: She was the first black female graduate of the school and went on to a career at the United Nations; she also was a major supporter of sickle cell research. She was a victim of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here

headline: Onaje Allan Gumbs, Musically Ecumenical Pianist, Is Dead at 70
abstract: As a musician, composer and arranger, Mr. Gumbs was a close collaborator with stars across musical styles.
lead_paragraph: Onaje Allan Gumbs, whose expansive talents as a pianist, composer and arranger made him a trusted right-hand man for stars across musical styles, died on April 6 in Yonkers, N.Y. He was 70.

headline: The Food Expiration Dates You Should Actually Follow
abstract: The first thing you should know? The dates, as we know them, have nothing to do with safety. J. Kenji López-Alt explains.
lead_paragraph: With most of us quarantined in our homes, chances are you’ve been reacquainting yourself with the forgotten spices and fusty beans from the depths of your pantry. But how fusty is too fusty? When is the right time to throw something out? And what about fresh ingredients? If I’m trying to keep supermarket trips to a minimum, how long can my eggs, dairy and produce keep?

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The Saturday, April 11 puzzle by Erik Agard and Wyna Liu was difficult for many solvers, but one of the clues that tripped people up the most was “Rectangle on a staff” (A rectangle? On what kind of staff?).

headline: A Salad for When You’re Out of Lettuce
abstract: This starchy grain bowl makes use of those sturdy vegetables in your fridge.
lead_paragraph: All those long-lasting, juicy vegetables in my fridge — the celery, radishes, fennel, turnips, carrots — have come in handy these past weeks (four, but, hey, who’s counting?). They’ve kept me rich in salad when the lettuces run out between market runs.

headline: How the ‘Greatest Rock and Roll Band in the World’ Got Its Logo
abstract: On the 50th anniversary of his famous “tongue and lips” emblem for the Rolling Stones, John Pasche says he had no expectations it would become so famous, or lucrative.
lead_paragraph: It began life as a tiny emblem, something to adorn a 45 r.p.m. single or the band’s letterhead. It quickly became ubiquitous and, ultimately, the most famous logo in rock ’n’ roll. Over 50 years, the legendary “tongue and lips” of the Rolling Stones has been emblazoned on everything from T-shirts and lighters to stage sets, appearing in countless variations throughout the decades. And while many who love it are fans of the band, the logo has in many ways transcended the Stones. But when it was commissioned in April 1970 its designer, John Pasche, had little idea how popular — and lucrative — it would become.

headline: As Reality TV Reunions Go Virtual, What About the Fights?
abstract: Castmates, prepare to yell into your Zoom.
lead_paragraph: Much like some of your work meetings (if you’re lucky enough to have a job, let alone one that allows you to work from home), most spin classes and nearly all sex work, another great American institution is moving online because of the coronavirus.

headline: Navarro Calls Medical Experts ‘Tone Deaf’ Over Coronavirus Shutdown
abstract: President Trump’s trade adviser warned that a prolonged shutdown of nonessential commerce could pose a more dire long-term health threat to the United States than the virus itself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the White House debates when and how to reopen the economy, one emerging argument is that an extended shutdown could pose a more dire long-term health threat to the United States than the coronavirus itself.

headline: Trump Re-Election Efforts Raise $212 Million for First Quarter of 2020
abstract: The big fund-raising haul, even in a quarter that ended as the coronavirus upended the economy, is another indicator of the president’s cash advantage heading into the general election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s re-election campaign and the Republican National Committee said Monday they had raised $212 million in the first three months of 2020, a signal that despite a global pandemic that has put a halt on high-dollar fund-raising events, Mr. Trump’s operation has continued to raise money at a brisk clip.

headline: We’re Shopping a Ton Online. Let’s Be Conscientious About It
abstract: How we shop during the pandemic could have big consequences.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Anger Erupts in China After Teen Says Guardian Repeatedly Raped Her
abstract: An 18-year-old has accused a prominent lawyer of sexually abusing her for years. The case has become a pivotal test for China’s fledgling #MeToo movement.
lead_paragraph: At 14 years old, she was sent by her mother to live with a successful businessman in Beijing, who was supposed to serve as her caretaker and guardian. Instead, over the course of several years, she says, he repeatedly raped her and held her in his home against her will.

headline: Venezuela’s Maduro, Used to Crises, Faces His Toughest One Yet
abstract: A pandemic and a seismic shift in global oil markets have shaken the country, posing a severe new test for the president just as he seemed to be tightening his hold on power.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Only a month ago, President Nicolás Maduro seemed to be consolidating his autocratic rule. The opposition was fading into irrelevance, international pressure was waning and the country’s devastating economic woes were finally easing, if only a bit.

headline: Trump’s Slow Response to the Coronavirus Pandemic
abstract: “The case can be made that, among industrialized countries, the United States has had the worst overall response,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 3 Vans, 6 Coolers, a Plane, a Storm and 2 Labs: A Nasal Swab’s Journey
abstract: The backlog for Covid-19 testing in New Jersey and other parts of the country is getting worse, not better. From the nose of a patient in a mile-long line to a phone call days later, bottlenecks thwart its progress.
lead_paragraph: PARAMUS, N.J. — The lines start forming the night before, as people with glassy eyes and violent coughs try to get tested for the virus. In the darkness, they park their cars, cut their engines and try to sleep.

headline: A Virtual HORSE Competition? B-O-R-I-N-G
abstract: A rather uneventful game of HORSE involving pro players, plus 100 straight volleys, baseball in Taiwan, and training for a Swedish soccer team.
lead_paragraph: Current and former N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. players competed in a virtual game of HORSE Sunday night on ESPN. The result? An air ball.

headline: Tenderness With the Dead
abstract: A reader says this will be the true measure of how we respond to the pandemic. Also: A son with autism finds his place; airlines need to collect passenger information.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Guide to Donating Clothes Today
abstract: Good news: you can get ready now. Bad news: you may have to wait.
lead_paragraph: If this is the time when you usually do your spring cleaning, we have good and bad news for you. The good news: You can still organize and purge items from your closet. The bad news: You will have to hold on to most of them until shelter-in-place orders are lifted. Following are guidelines for how to proceed and the status of the largest national organizations (which ones you choose to support because of religious or political affiliations are up to you).

headline: Sam Clayton Jr., Sound Engineer With a Global Ear, Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Clayton, who died of the coronavirus, worked with reggae musicians from Jamaica and countries far from the music’s birthplace.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Driver Kyle Larson Suspended After Using Racial Slur
abstract: NASCAR suspended the driver Kyle Larson indefinitely after he used a racial slur during a live stream of a virtual auto race. His team also suspended him without pay.
lead_paragraph: NASCAR suspended the driver Kyle Larson indefinitely on Monday after he used a racial slur during a live stream of a virtual auto race.

headline: The Supreme Court Will Hear Arguments by Phone. The Public Can Listen In.
abstract: For the first time, the nation’s highest court will open a live audio feed as it hears arguments in 10 sets of cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would hear arguments by telephone over six days in May. In a major break with tradition, the court said it would for the first time allow live remote access to audio of the arguments.

headline: Police Chief Accused of Linking Deputy’s Covid-19 Death to ‘Homosexual Events’
abstract: The police chief in Davie, Fla., has been placed on leave after suggesting that a Broward County sheriff’s deputy died from the coronavirus because he was gay, according to a complaint.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A Florida police chief has been replaced after a police union said he berated his officers and told them that a sheriff’s deputy had died from the coronavirus because he was a “homosexual who attended homosexual events.”

headline: Putin’s Bleak Covid-19 Admission: ‘We Don’t Have Much to Brag About’
abstract: Russia’s president acknowledged that his country risks being overwhelmed by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The head of Russia’s coronavirus task force, Tatyana Golikova, assured President Vladimir V. Putin in mid-March that the country was ready to take on the pandemic. From masks to ventilators, she said, Russia’s hospitals had everything they needed to weather the crisis.

headline: Bernie Sanders Endorses Joe Biden for President
abstract: At a moment when Mr. Biden still faces deep skepticism from many younger progressive voters, Mr. Sanders’s support is a major step toward Democratic unity against President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the Democratic nominee for president on Monday, adding the weight of his left-wing support to Mr. Biden’s candidacy and taking a major step toward bringing unity to the party’s effort to unseat President Trump in November.

headline: Saudi Cup, Won by Maximum Security, Puts Hold on Prize Money
abstract: The horse, trained by Jason Servis, could lose his $10 million share of the purse as organizers investigate whether he was aided by performance-enhancing drugs.
lead_paragraph: The organizers of the inaugural Saudi Cup, the world’s richest horse race, are withholding the $20 million in prize money while they investigate whether the winner, Maximum Security, was aided by performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: A Letter From the Editors of the Book Review
abstract: We hope that you find time and space in this difficult moment to turn to books.
lead_paragraph: What an unusual and terrible time this is for all of us — with people’s lives at risk, and many lost so far; with the vast majority of us confined to our homes or, out of necessity, precariously trying to work outside our homes. There is much to mourn, much to be grateful for and much cause for worry and fear.

headline: How to Get to ‘Sesame Street’? These Days, It’s by Video Conference
abstract: As children stay home and viewing-time restrictions are abandoned, creators of child-focused content are taking on the coronavirus and the changes it has wrought for families.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy afternoon recently, Ernie the Muppet was trying to get through to his roommate Bert.

headline: Why New Orleans Pushed Ahead With Mardi Gras, Even as It Planned for Coronavirus
abstract: A cache of internal emails reveals city officials believed chances were “low” that the festivities would help spread the virus, a prediction that proved tragically off base.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Twelve days before New Orleans celebrated Mardi Gras Day, the citywide pre-Lenten bash that would pack thousands of visitors onto the streets, Sarah A. Babcock, the director of policy and emergency preparedness for the city health department, prepared a list of bullet points about the troubling disease that had already sickened thousands in China but had only infected 13 known patients in the United States.

headline: The Weeknd’s ‘After Hours’ Earns a Third Straight Week at No. 1
abstract: The album was aided once again by bundles of the music with sales of merchandise.
lead_paragraph: The Weeknd’s latest album, “After Hours,” has topped the weekly Billboard chart for a third time, beating out new releases from the Nashville star Sam Hunt and Rod Wave, an emerging singer and rapper.

headline: ‘Which Death Is Going to Be Worse?’ Coronavirus Invades a Conflict Zone
abstract: Libyans have been fleeing bombs and shells throughout the country’s six-year civil war. But with the arrival of the coronavirus, virtually nowhere is safe to hide.
lead_paragraph: Libyans have been fleeing bombs and shells throughout the country’s six-year civil war. But with the arrival of the coronavirus, virtually nowhere is safe to hide.

headline: Spain’s Lethal Secret: We Didn’t Have ‘the Best Health Care in the World’
abstract: It took Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez too long to bring coherence to the pandemic’s response. Overconfidence in our health care capacity took care of the rest.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — For years, we have heard Spain’s leaders say that we had “the best health care in the world.” This political fantasy has now met with a rude awakening. We have learned the hard way that being deemed the healthiest nation in the world by the World Economic Forum is not the same as having the best health care system.

headline: Did I Have the Coronavirus?
abstract: Antibody testing could provide an answer to the question millions of Americans have.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of this pandemic, millions of Americans who have had an upper-respiratory illness have one burning question on their mind: Was it the coronavirus or just a cold or flu?

headline: Our Cruel Treatment of Animals Led to the Coronavirus
abstract: The conditions that lead to the emergence of new infectious diseases are the same ones that inflict horrific harms on animals.
lead_paragraph: There is the obvious and then there is what should be obvious. The obvious is that the coronavirus pandemic has brought much of the human world to a standstill. Many countries are in lockdown. So far, more than 1.7 million have been infected, more than 100,000 have died, and billions live in fear that the numbers of sick and dead will rise exponentially. Economies are in recession, with all the hardship that entails for human well-being.

headline: ‘It’s a Time Bomb’: 23 Die as Virus Hits Packed Homeless Shelters
abstract: The virus is spreading where social distancing is nearly impossible. But there’s no staying at home when you do not have one.
lead_paragraph: Roy Coleman, a 69-year-old living in a homeless shelter on Wards Island, was taken away by ambulance after showing symptoms of Covid-19. The other shelter residents were relieved — until Mr. Coleman was allowed to return last week after testing positive at Harlem Hospital.

headline: Richard Brodsky, Legislator Known as Albany’s Conscience, Dies at 73
abstract: A 14-term Assemblyman from Westchester County, he was instrumental in empowering New York State to monitor its 700 quasi-public authorities.
lead_paragraph: Richard Brodsky, who persuaded his fellow state legislators to impose a monitor over 700 quasi-public authorities that had borrowed $150 billion on behalf of New Yorkers with no oversight, died on April 8 at his home in Greenburgh, N.Y. He was 73.

headline: How Native Americans Are Fighting a Food Crisis
abstract: As the coronavirus limits access to food, many are relying on customs, like seed saving and canning, that helped their forebears survive hard times.
lead_paragraph: For the roughly 20,000 members of the Oglala Sioux Tribe living on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation — a vast, two million-acre expanse in southern South Dakota — social distancing is certainly feasible. Putting food on the table? Less so.

headline: Lifting Lockdowns, #MeToo in China, Softbank: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Stream and Shout: 10 Underseen Rock Documentaries
abstract: Missing live music in person? Here are 10 films that will make you feel as if you are there, even on your couch.
lead_paragraph: As we all hole up, rock documentaries can perk up any living room. But in the list below, I opted to skip the well-known ones. Don’t look for stadium headliners or anything by Martin Scorsese. The emphasis is on lesser-known personalities whose energy is palpable through a screen of any size. Also required was a portrayal of community-building and togetherness — something many of us are craving right now — and a healthy amount of music, preferably loud, live and with a “you are there” quality. Minus the stinky bathrooms, of course.

headline: ‘I Just Want to Eat Her Up!’
abstract: Why do we compare babies and fetuses to food?
lead_paragraph: [This story was originally published on May 27, 2019 on NYT Parenting.]

headline: Shut by Virus, Met Opera Announces Starry ‘At Home’ Concert
abstract: More than 40 artists will participate in the April 25 event, which comes as the company faces up to $60 million in losses because of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Starry (and often epically long) concerts are a Metropolitan Opera stock in trade.

headline: Economic Pain Will Persist Long After Lockdowns End
abstract: President Trump has predicted an economic boom once stay-at-home and other restrictions are lifted. But economic activity is likely to remain subdued until the threat of the coronavirus recedes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Walter Isenberg is the sort of business owner President Trump has in mind when he talks about the need to start lifting coronavirus lockdowns and reopen the American economy. Mr. Isenberg’s hotel and restaurant group in Denver has seen its revenues drop from $3 million a day last year to $40,000 a day now.

headline: SoftBank’s Troubles Deepen With Warning of $16.7 Billion Writedown
abstract: The Japanese conglomerate, which bet big on tech start-ups with its $100 billion Vision Fund, also expects its first annual loss in 15 years.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — SoftBank warned investors on Monday that the value of its technology fund may have dropped by as much as $16.7 billion over the last fiscal year, as its investments have been hit hard by the fallout from the coronavirus and by big bets on unprofitable companies like WeWork.

headline: The Truth About Tummy Time
abstract: Pediatricians say it’s essential. But is it?
lead_paragraph: [This article was originally published on May 29, 2019, on NYT Parenting.]

headline: Live Analysis: Wisconsin Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the Wisconsin primary.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the Wisconsin primary.

headline: Katharine, the Great White Shark Who Ghosted Her Trackers, Resurfaces
abstract: The last that researchers heard from Katharine via her transmitter was nearly a year ago, leaving her fate a mystery. Recently, though, there came some weak pings.
lead_paragraph: In the making of “Jaws,” the three mechanical models of the shark, collectively known as Bruce, earned a reputation for being notoriously unreliable.

headline: The Big Deal to Cut Oil Production May Not Be Big Enough
abstract: Saudi Arabia, Russia and other oil-producing nations have pledged to cut about 10 percent of global production, but demand is down by much more than that.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The agreement by major oil producers on Sunday to reduce their daily production by 9.7 million barrels was the largest cutback in history and a feat of remarkable coordination by more than 20 nations led by Saudi Arabia and Russia with unusual mediation from the United States.

headline: Craig Gilbert, 94, Dies; Created Groundbreaking ‘American Family’
abstract: Airing in 1973 and making national stars out of the Loud family, it is now considered the first reality TV show. It had people buzzing then, and fighting.
lead_paragraph: Craig Gilbert, who created what is widely considered to have been the first reality television show, “An American Family,” in 1973 and then all but disappeared from public view amid a storm of criticism and lasting, bitter disputes among its participants, died on Friday at his home in Lower Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: What Should Baby Poop Look Like, Anyway?
abstract: A range of colors, textures, frequencies and volumes are considered normal. But there are some things to watch out for.
lead_paragraph: Baby poop is a source of great mystery — and often, concern — for many parents. Sometimes it’s green and mushy; other times it’s yellow and seedy. What does it all mean? “Baby poop is not like adult poop,” said Dr. Katie Lockwood, M.D., an attending physician at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia. “So there are lots of questions about it.”

headline: It’s a Streaming World After All: Scuttled Benefit Is Back.
abstract: The Broadway Cares fund-raiser, featuring a concert of Disney songs, has been rescheduled after the musicians union dropped a demand that members be compensated.
lead_paragraph: A Broadway fund-raiser to benefit entertainment workers whose livelihoods have been imperiled by the coronavirus will be rescheduled after a labor union retreated from a demand that musicians be paid for the streaming of the previously recorded event.

headline: Dozens Are Killed as Tornadoes and Severe Weather Strike Southern States
abstract: The storm carved a destructive path across six states on Sunday and Monday, causing widespread damage and cutting power to tens of thousands of customers.
lead_paragraph: BASSFIELD, Miss. — Like most Americans, Mamie Harper and her husband had tucked themselves away at home in an effort to keep the coronavirus at bay. On Easter Sunday, they listened to an audio feed of their church service while huddled indoors.

headline: How Often Should I Bathe My Baby?
abstract: Giving baby a bath without harming that delicate skin is one more minefield for new parents to traverse. Here are a few tips.
lead_paragraph: When you bring your baby home, you also bring home a bundle of new questions. Everyone has different opinions on the best way to do everything when it comes to raising babies; even a simple question like, “How often should I bathe this kid?” can turn into a heated debate. To help you navigate the minefield of parenting advice, I spoke to a few experts to get the dirt on keeping baby clean.

headline: Irene Inouye, 71, Fund-Raising Champion of Japanese-Americans, Dies
abstract: She headed two major foundations, established a Japanese-American museum and, the widow of a senator, quietly helped lift Detroit out of bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Irene Hirano Inouye, who established the nation’s premier Japanese-American museum, in Los Angeles, and who, as a philanthropic leader, helped leverage hundreds of millions of dollars to lift Detroit out of bankruptcy in 2014, died on April 7 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 71.

headline: The XFL Files for Bankruptcy After Canceling Season
abstract: The filing by the XFL’s parent company, Alpha Entertainment, came after Covid-19 forced the rebooted league to lay off staffers and suspend operations in its first season in 19 years.
lead_paragraph: Alpha Entertainment, the company that owns the XFL, filed for bankruptcy on Monday, three days after the league suspended operations and laid off its staff.

headline: Can’t Sleep While Pregnant?
abstract: Certain hormonal changes, along with other pregnancy-related discomforts can sink a good night’s sleep. Here’s how to snooze more soundly.
lead_paragraph: This guide was originally published on May 22, 2019.

headline: How to Be a Supportive Partner During Pregnancy (and Beyond)
abstract: The research is resoundingly clear: A strong mate is good for everyone involved, including the baby.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve watched any movies with birth scenes, you may have noticed that the partner’s role often fits into one of two categories: He — and it’s always a he — is a comically inept second fiddle, fainting just when he’s needed most, or else absent entirely, inhaling a cigar in a nearby pub.

headline: Pregnancy Pains Got You Down? Read This
abstract: Most cases of pain during pregnancy aren’t an emergency and can be managed, though there are some warning signs to watch out for.
lead_paragraph: I was 35 weeks pregnant with my first daughter when I began to feel an intense, intermittent pain that radiated from my lower back and pelvis and into my leg. Like a lightning rod, it would flare unpredictably, making it impossible to move without gritting my teeth. My physical therapist deduced that the combination of my expanding belly, my scoliosis (which I’d dealt with for decades) and the pregnancy hormones loosening the connective tissue of my pelvis had caused serious misalignment issues in my hip area. The result was pain in my pelvic joints and possibly some pinched nerves in my sacrum.

headline: Food Workers Say C.D.C. Guidelines Put Them at Greater Risk for Infection
abstract: The agency now says “critical infrastructure workers” who may have been exposed to the coronavirus can stay on the job under certain conditions, instead of isolating.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Harris, a cashier at a Kroger grocery store in Virginia, was surprised last week when a customer offered her a $5 bill as a tip. Ms. Harris, a Kroger employee for 13 years, cited store policy in declining the generous offer.

headline: Irena Chalmers, 84, Is Dead; Writer Anticipated a Food Revolution
abstract: She wrote her first cookbook, “Fondue Cook-In,” to help sell pots. She went on to discover chefs who would become well-known cooking authorities.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s, well before the era of celebrity chefs and the flood of cooking shows, Irena Chalmers found herself stuck with six fondue pots at La Bonne Femme, the cooking school and specialty food shop she opened in Greensboro, N.C.

headline: Sailor on Roosevelt, Whose Captain Pleaded for Help, Dies From Coronavirus
abstract: The death came as Navy officials continued to struggle to combat the infection that has crippled the nuclear-powered Theodore Roosevelt, now docked in Guam.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A crew member from the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt who had the novel coronavirus died on Monday, in a poignant punctuation to the plea from the ship’s captain two weeks ago for help from the Navy because “sailors don’t need to die.”

headline: He Was a Doctor Who Never Got Sick. Then the Coronavirus Nearly Killed Him.
abstract: Dr. Ryan Padgett, 45, once played in the Rose Bowl for Northwestern. He had rarely missed a day of work to illness. Then the coronavirus took him to the brink of death.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — At the end of February, Dr. Ryan Padgett’s colleagues in the emergency room called him over to share some news: A patient who had died the previous day had tested positive for the coronavirus — the first known death in the United States.

headline: Upset Victory in Wisconsin Supreme Court Race Gives Democrats a Lift
abstract: A liberal challenger’s surprise triumph over a Trump-backed incumbent demonstrated strong turnout and vote-by-mail efforts for the Democrats in a key general election state.
lead_paragraph: Democrats scored a significant victory in Wisconsin on Monday night when a liberal challenger upset a Trump-backed incumbent to win a State Supreme Court seat, a down-ballot race that illustrated strong turnout and vote-by-mail efforts in a presidential battleground state.

headline: Supreme Court Asked to Suspend Wealth Test for Green Cards in Light of Virus
abstract: New limits on the “public charge” rule will deter immigrants from seeking care during the pandemic, lawyers for New York and other states said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three states asked the Supreme Court on Monday to revisit a January ruling that allowed the Trump administration to move forward with plans to deny green cards to immigrants who make even occasional and minor use of public benefits like Medicaid.

headline: Knocked Off Track by Coronavirus, Census Announces Delay in 2020 Count
abstract: The Census Bureau said it would extend the deadlines for collecting census data and would ask Congress for a delay in providing final counts used for congressional redistricting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Conceding that its effort to count the nation’s population has been hamstrung by the coronavirus pandemic, the Census Bureau said on Monday it would ask Congress for a four-month delay in delivering the census data used to reapportion the House of Representatives and political districts nationwide.

headline: BAM Executives Take Steep Pay Cuts After Canceling Programs Through June
abstract: The president of the art center said that though other reductions may be necessary to offset millions in lost ticket sales, “we wanted to start at the top.”
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Academic of Music announced on Monday that it has canceled its programming and events through June because of the coronavirus pandemic. To help offset the lost ticket revenue, which BAM estimates will total $7.4 million, the organization’s president and executives have agreed to pay reductions of up to 40 percent.

headline: The Times Took 19 Days to Report an Accusation Against Biden. Here’s Why.
abstract: Dean Baquet, the executive editor of The New York Times, said the article was published when there was enough reporting “to present to readers for them to make their own judgment.”
lead_paragraph: On March 25, Tara Reade, a former Senate aide for Joseph R. Biden Jr., alleged in an interview on a podcast that Mr. Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, had sexually assaulted her in 1993.

headline: Watch This: ‘What We Do in the Shadows’
abstract: The FX vampire comedy returns this week, as does a critically acclaimed Israeli thriller.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter, aimed at your needs, desires and tastes. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Biden and Bernie, Bros
abstract: As Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders exchanged warm smiles today, Mr. Biden was also shifting his tone.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Republicans Don’t Want to Save Jobs
abstract: Billions for oil, nothing for nurses and teachers.
lead_paragraph: Recent job losses have been nothing short of apocalyptic. Almost 17 million workers — more than 10 percent of the work force — filed for unemployment benefits over the course of just three weeks. Independent economists suggest that the unemployment rate may already be close to 20 percent, which is similar to its level in the depths of the Great Depression.

headline: How a Supreme Court Decision Curtailed the Right to Vote in Wisconsin
abstract: The state’s final vote tallies show that the justices’ decision not to extend the mail voting deadline amid the coronavirus resulted in the disenfranchisement of thousands of voters.
lead_paragraph: The Wisconsin spring elections were less than a week away, and with the state’s coronavirus death toll mounting, Democrats were challenging Republican plans to hold the vote as scheduled.

headline: ‘Worst Is Over,’ Cuomo Says as States Snub Trump on Restarting Economy
abstract: Northeastern governors ally to plan for lifting virus restrictions, and Western states also announce they will work together to plan for the future.
lead_paragraph: With the number of new deaths and rate of hospitalizations falling in New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that “the worst is over” in the coronavirus pandemic, and he announced an alliance with six other Northeastern governors to explore how to eventually lift restrictions — a move that appeared to be an implicit rebuke to President Trump.

headline: Inmates at N.J. Women’s Prison Endured Years of Sex Abuse, Justice Dept. Finds
abstract: The assaults violated prisoners’ constitutional protections, investigators said, demanding that the prison immediately address the problems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Inmates at New Jersey’s only state prison for women were regularly sexually assaulted by guards and sometimes forced to engage in sex acts with other prisoners while staff members looked on, according to a Justice Department report released on Monday detailing widespread, pervasive sexual abuse at the facility.

headline: U.S. Food Supply Chain Is Strained as Virus Spreads
abstract: Disruptions are expected in the production and distribution of products like pork, and localized shortages could occur.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s food supply chain is showing signs of strain, as increasing numbers of workers are falling ill with the coronavirus in meat processing plants, warehouses and grocery stores.

headline: Despite Qualms, Arthritis Drug Is to Be Tested in Coronavirus Study
abstract: Even though it can make infections worse, it also may be able to keep the immune system from overreacting.
lead_paragraph: An Eli Lilly drug for rheumatoid arthritis carries a warning on its label saying patients with infections should not take it because it can make infections worse. Yet the National Institutes of Health is about to test it in people hospitalized with coronavirus infections.

headline: Fauci Defends Trump, Who Says He Has No Plans to Dismiss Him
abstract: The president had reposted a message on Twitter on Sunday calling for Dr. Fauci’s firing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the leading public health expert on President Trump’s coronavirus task force, sought on Monday to smooth over a growing rift with the president, taking the podium during the task force’s daily briefing to defend Mr. Trump, who has been enraged by reports that he was warned about the potential for a pandemic but oversaw a halting response.

headline: Reopening Plans, Bernie Sanders, Tornadoes: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Comfort Viewing: Why I Still Love ‘Grey’s Anatomy’
abstract: Nothing replaces the feeling — unique to television — of watching a show age in real time.
lead_paragraph: Stuck on a desert island or confined to a one-bedroom Brooklyn apartment, I will take the 15-year-old medical drama “Grey’s Anatomy” as distraction over any of its newer, shinier, more critically acclaimed, more endlessly dissected and meme-fueling competition.

headline: Israeli Election Rivals Seek Deadline Extension to Form Unity Government
abstract: Down to the wire in their negotiations, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his rival, Benny Gantz, asked for more time to resolve their differences.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With the negotiations over a unity government in Israel at a critical juncture, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his chief rival, Benny Gantz, asked the country’s president early on Tuesday to extend the deadline to form a joint coalition to midnight Wednesday.

headline: The Global Coronavirus Crisis Is Poised to Get Much, Much Worse
abstract: What happens when the pandemic strikes nations of millions of people that have only a half-dozen ventilators?
lead_paragraph: In some places in the United States and other developed countries hit hard by Covid-19, the question is when might it become possible to start getting back to work. For much of the rest of the world, the nightmare is yet to start. And part of the horror is that many poorer countries won’t have the means to do much about it. Nor, given the international community’s lack of organization and leadership in the face of a global crisis, can they count on richer nations to help them.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Governors plan to band together to decide when to reopen different regions of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Everyone is aching for all of this to be over — the sickness and the loss and the grief, of course, but also the hardships and the restrictions of life in limbo. And there are some hopeful signs that the coronavirus pandemic is leveling off in some areas — including in New York, where Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that “the worst is over.”

headline: Maida Heatter’s Baking Recipes Remixed
abstract: These books, focused on cookies and chocolate, would make a good Mother’s Day gift.
lead_paragraph: There’s time to bake these days, and appetite to enjoy the results. You might consider making extra for the workers who are keeping us safe. To help, there are two newly assembled collections of the much-loved recipes from the doyenne of baking and chocolate, or as she was often called the “Queen of Cake,” Maida Heatter, who died last year at 102, “Cookies Are Magic” and “Chocolate Is Forever.” They’d make a good gift for Mother’s Day.

headline: Mashed Potatoes, the Robuchon Way
abstract: To make the chef Joël Robuchon’s pommes purées, you’ll need butter, lots of it.
lead_paragraph: Mashed potatoes are right up there in the comfort food hall of fame. And none can measure up to pommes purées, the legacy of the chef Joël Robuchon, who died in 2018. They’re served at L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon in New York (and elsewhere around the world), but the restaurant is closed for the pandemic so you will just have to make them at home. To serve four generously (because they are very rich), boil a pound of unpeeled Yukon Gold potatoes until tender, drain, then peel and mash them using a ricer. Return them to the pot and heat them gently for a few seconds, then add half a pound of unsalted butter, bit by bit, mixing vigorously the whole time. Slowly mix in about four tablespoons of warm whole milk. Season with salt and pepper, give them a few turns with a whisk to lighten them and serve. They can be kept warm in the top of a double boiler.

headline: A Queens Caterer Delivers
abstract: Neuman’s Kitchen will send its homestyle food — lasagna, meatloaf and more — to Manhattan, Brooklyn and even the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: Paul Neuman, a caterer based in Long Island City, Queens, has started contactless delivery of prepared foods to locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Long Island and the Hamptons. The food is hearty and homestyle, and easy to reheat. Most of the items serve two and can be refrigerated for a few days or even frozen. Soups like chicken noodle and mushroom-barley; main courses like lasagna Bolognese and turkey meatloaf with spinach; and desserts, including a buttery croissant pull-apart loaf, available plain or threaded with chocolate, are on the menu, priced from $9 to $20. There’s a $125 minimum for New York City with no delivery charge and $300 for Long Island plus $50 delivery.

headline: Sales of This Apron Help Restaurant Workers
abstract: A bright blue apron from Bragard USA protects the cook, while helping restaurant employees in need.
lead_paragraph: A new apron from Bragard USA, a branch of the French company that makes chef’s clothing and gear, provides welcome protection against kitchen splatter while contributing to a good cause. It’s bright blue and decorated with a familiar dove of peace holding a toque; the design was adapted by Polonsky and Friends from the dove Picasso created for Matisse. All the profits from sales are being donated to the Restaurant Employee Relief Fund established by the National Restaurant Association Educational Foundation.

headline: Order Your Farmers’ Market Produce Online for Pickup
abstract: To keep social distance, the Greenmarkets are offering an online option to preorder from its vendors.
lead_paragraph: Social distancing rules at the city’s Greenmarkets. And to facilitate separation, GrowNYC, the organization that runs the farmers’ markets, has now set up an area on its website to help shoppers preorder from some of the vendors. It lists the vendors alphabetically, their websites and which ones will accept preorders for market pickup. Some also offer delivery.

headline: Cocktail Mixers Enter the Ice Age
abstract: For your next old-fashioned, margarita or cosmopolitan, reach for a Cocktail Cube, a premixed, frozen helper ready to shake.
lead_paragraph: Many prepared cocktail concoctions are shortcuts that shortchange the drink. Not these new frozen Cocktail Cubes. They’re made from straightforward organic ingredients that have been mixed and formed into the cubes to make fine classic cocktails like old-fashioneds, margaritas, bee’s knees and cosmopolitans, among others. Drop one, or two, into a shaker, add two ounces of spirits for each, then shake like the dickens, and you have your drink. Or nearly so: I found that they take more shaking than suggested to come close to dissolving. I got best results when I put them in the refrigerator for an hour or so to soften before use. They were devised by an Atlanta surgeon who approached Emily Silberman, an entrepreneur, and Jeremy Hawn, a New York mixologist, to create the company and develop the product.

headline: What to Do With Tara Reade’s Allegation Against Joe Biden?
abstract: A sexual assault accusation against the presumptive Democratic nominee is being used to troll the #MeToo movement.
lead_paragraph: It would be easier to know what to do with Tara Reade’s accusation that Joe Biden sexually assaulted her if her tale were more solid, or if it were less.

headline: Millions of Children Are at Risk for Measles as Coronavirus Fears Halt Vaccines
abstract: U.N. and global health experts warned that poor countries around the world were having to stop mass immunization programs to reduce the risk of spreading Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 million children could be at risk for measles because countries around the world are suspending national immunization programs in order to reduce the risk of coronavirus infection, international public health leaders warned on Monday.

headline: Trump Leaps to Call Shots on Reopening Nation, Setting Up Standoff With Governors
abstract: The president’s insistence that only he can decide if the country should reopen for business was disputed by constitutional scholars and contrasted with his earlier message that it was not for the federal government to take the lead in fighting the virus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There once was a time when President Trump made clear that governors were the ones mainly responsible for the fight against the coronavirus pandemic. But that was Sunday. On Monday, he declared that he was really in charge and would make the decision about when and how to reopen the country.

headline: Are We at the Start of a New Protest Movement?
abstract: The immediate immiseration of millions of people highlights our mutual bond.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus catastrophe shows that we need political protests more than ever. Tens of millions of citizens sit at home awaiting meager checks that may reach them by August. Countless people endure the bewilderment of navigating call centers that often fail to connect them to unemployment benefits. Donations to food banks have fallen while need rises. The inept federal response slows the arrival of aid, forcing people to defy the “social distancing” necessary to keep the virus at bay.

headline: Stalemate Over Small-Business Aid Deepens as Officials Warn of Funding Lapse
abstract: It is unclear if lawmakers will be able to reach a consensus this week even as the Trump administration says the program could run out of funds as early as Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A stalemate over an emergency infusion of cash to help small businesses battered by the coronavirus pandemic intensified on Monday after Democratic leaders doubled down on demands for additional money for state and local governments, hospitals, food assistance and rapid testing.

headline: Man Accused of ‘Swatting’ With White Supremacists Signs Plea Deal
abstract: John William Kirby Kelley, a former Virginia college student, suggested his school as a swatting target, according to court records.
lead_paragraph: A former Virginia college student and federal prosecutors have reached a plea deal after he was accused of reporting false bomb threats and active shootings, a potentially dangerous hoax known as “swatting,” in coordination with a nationwide ring of white supremacists.

headline: Trump Turns Daily Coronavirus Briefing Into a Defense of His Record
abstract: Also at the briefing on Monday, Dr. Anthony Fauci said a comment he made that was seen as critical of the president was taken out of context, and Mr. Trump said he did not intend to fire him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump turned Monday’s daily coronavirus task force briefing into an aggressive defense of his own halting response to the pandemic and used a campaign-style video to denounce criticism that he moved too slowly to limit the deadly spread of the virus.

headline: Talk to the Hand
abstract: Joe Hansen makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Ah, Tuesday. I think. For all I know, in this time of staying home, it could be Saturday. The only thing that differentiates the two days right now is which pair of sweatpants I’m wearing.

headline: Virginia’s New Laws on L.G.B.T. Protections, Guns and Marijuana Reflect a Shift in Power
abstract: The measures came about after Democrats took control of the Legislature for the first time in more than two decades last year.
lead_paragraph: The leftward transformation of Virginia since President Trump was elected crescendoed over the weekend, with the governor signing into law protections for L.G.B.T. residents, gun background checks, no jail time for simple marijuana possession and early voting.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 5, Episode 9 Recap: Bullet Holes
abstract: Jimmy’s newest client asks a lot of questions, a few of which he can’t quite answer. Thankfully, Kim can.
lead_paragraph: At last, proof positive: Kim is a much better liar than Jimmy.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Americans Salute Cashiers, Meat Packers and Others, but Their Risk Is Rising
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Chances are high that I will get this thing. It’s getting closer, and it’s terrifying.”

headline: Corrections: April 14, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the spread of the coronavirus by Biogen employees referred incorrectly to Jie Li, a statistician who fell ill with flulike symptoms and who was traveling to China. She told flight attendants she was unwell; she did not conceal her health condition from them.

headline: Trump Stops U.S. Funding of W.H.O.; U.K. Coronavirus Deaths May Be Higher Than Official Toll
abstract: Confirmed infections neared 2 million, with more than 120,000 dead, and the I.M.F. predicted the worst global downturn since the Great Depression. New York City passed 10,000 fatalities.
lead_paragraph: Britain, with the fastest-growing outbreak in western Europe, has understated the human and economic cost of the coronavirus, according to new information released on Tuesday.

headline: An Airline Bailout Is Taking Shape
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: Coronavirus Lockdowns, Russia, Donald Trump: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Elmo’s Playdate’ and ‘Fleabag’
abstract: Celebrities join “Sesame Street” muppets for a virtual special, while Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s one-woman show is available to rent on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: SESAME STREET: ELMO’S PLAYDATE 7 p.m. on Boomerang, Cartoon Network, HBO, HBO Latino, PBS Kids, TBS, TNT and truTV. As people around the world try to find creative ways to stay connected — through virtual dinners, watching parties and more — “Sesame Street” wants to do the same with its young viewers. In this half-hour special, Elmo, Grover, Cookie Monster and other furry muppets come together for a virtual play date, joined by the guest stars Lin-Manuel Miranda, Anne Hathaway and Tracee Ellis Ross. The gang celebrates emergency medical workers, doctors and others who are helping societies survive the health crisis. They also provide young fans a chance to escape from reality with dance breaks, songs and games, including “Elmo Says” and “Old McDonald Had a Farm.”

headline: Stigma Hampers Iraqi Efforts to Fight the Coronavirus
abstract: Religious beliefs and a deep suspicion of the government have made people ashamed and afraid of getting tested.
lead_paragraph: NAJAF, Iraq — The doctor paused before banging on the front gate, gesturing to companions who were wearing full hazmat suits, masks, goggles and gloves to stand back so they would not be the first thing the home’s occupants saw.

headline: There Are No Games. But Basketball Coaches Are Still Busy.
abstract: Coaching clinics that were supposed to happen during the Final Four have instead become very popular online.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma City Thunder Coach Billy Donovan invited about 1,000 people into his home recently while still practicing social distancing in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Pastor Who Defied Social Distancing Dies After Contracting Covid-19, Church Says
abstract: The death of Gerald O. Glenn, the bishop of the New Deliverance Evangelistic Church in Chesterfield, Va., was announced during Easter services.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia pastor who defied warnings about the danger of religious gatherings during the pandemic and vowed to keep preaching “unless I’m in jail or the hospital” died over the weekend after contracting Covid-19, his church said.

headline: Word + Quiz: filigree
abstract: This word has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Funny Flicks
abstract: What movies or shows do you turn to for laughs?
lead_paragraph: Now is an ideal time to escape into fictional worlds — and to indulge in laughter.

headline: N.F.L. Draft 2020: No Goodell Hugs? No Boos? No Problem
abstract: Commissioner Roger Goodell will announce picks from his basement, and players will miss out on the bear hugs that have become a tradition.
lead_paragraph: It is a ubiquitous sight at the N.F.L. draft in a normal year.

headline: How Bad Will the Economy Get? Companies Will Provide Clues
abstract: The quarterly parade of corporate earnings and management comments could reveal how much damage the pandemic will do and how long the pain will last.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has pushed the economy into a slowdown of unknown severity. It could be a long, drawn-out recession, or a sharp dip followed by a swift recovery.

headline: North Korea Fires Missiles as South’s Elections Loom
abstract: The tests of short-range missiles came a day before South Korea holds parliamentary elections amid the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea ​fired several short-range missiles off its east coast on Tuesday, a day before South Korea is scheduled to hold elections for its 300-seat Parliament.

headline: Trump Will Replace Fauci With First Fox News Guest He Sees, Colbert Says
abstract: “So get ready for new director of allergy and infectious disease, Kid Rock,” Stephen Colbert joked on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Five Takeaways on What Trump Knew as the Virus Spread’
abstract: In this lesson, students will analyze the causes and effects of the federal government’s response to the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Five Takeaways on What Trump Knew as the Virus Spread” by Michael D. Shear

headline: How to Drink Alone
abstract: Mix your drinks with half the alcohol. Turn the preparation into a project.
lead_paragraph: “Something that’s comforting and familiar is good, especially in a time like this,” says Shannon Mustipher, a former bartender and the author of “Tiki: Modern Tropical Cocktails.” As the pandemic keeps people inside — and makes bars and restaurants a far-off dream — we’re all looking for distraction and comfort: television bingeing, Instagram scrolling, drinking. If you’re a wine or beer drinker, stick to your regular. For those more adept at mixology, try taking one of your favorites and lightening up the pour: Make it with half the alcohol, or dilute it with sparkling water. Still, pay attention to how much you’re taking in, to avoid overdoing it. “If it’s on the lighter side, you can have a few and not get too tanked, which is good,” Mustipher says — especially in a time like this.

headline: When Has Starting Over Worked for You?
abstract: Do you tend to abandon an idea that hasn’t worked, or do you go back, improve it and try again?
lead_paragraph: Are you the kind of person who makes goals, plans and resolutions? What do you tend to do if they don’t work out?

headline: When Globalization Really Began
abstract: As Valerie Hansen shows in “The Year 1000,” the world was already genuinely interconnected a millennium ago.
lead_paragraph: THE YEAR 1000When Explorers Connected the World — and Globalization BeganBy Valerie Hansen

headline: Eat. Sleep. Swim. Repeat.
abstract: In her new book, “Why We Swim,” Bonnie Tsui considers the many benefits of submerging yourself in water. As her fellow swimmers say, why run when you can fly?
lead_paragraph: WHY WE SWIMBy Bonnie Tsui

headline: During a Weekend in the Country, Secrets Simmer Between Old Friends
abstract: Joanna Hershon’s fifth novel explores the binding nature of old ties.
lead_paragraph: ST. IVOBy Joanna Hershon

headline: A Poet Traces Her Personal Obsessions, in Prose
abstract: In the essay collection “Synthesizing Gravity,” Kay Ryan offers characteristically tart and idiosyncratic takes on writing, and on influences from Robert Frost to Marianne Moore.
lead_paragraph: SYNTHESIZING GRAVITYSelected ProseBy Kay Ryan

headline: In This Korean Best Seller, a Young Mother Is Driven to Psychosis
abstract: Cho Nam-Joo’s debut novel, “Kim Jiyoung, Born 1982,” is written as a case study on everyday sexism and misogyny. It helped propel a feminist wave in Korea.
lead_paragraph: KIM JIYOUNG, BORN 1982By Cho Nam-Joo

headline: The Struggle of Weight Loss Is Real. Companionship Helps.
abstract: In “This Is Big,” Marisa Meltzer writes about the bond she formed with Jean Nidetch, the long-ago founder of Weight Watchers.
lead_paragraph: THIS IS BIGHow the Founder of Weight Watchers Changed the World — and MeBy Marisa Meltzer

headline: Paulette Jiles’s New Novel Goes Deep in the Heart of Texas
abstract: In “Simon the Fiddler,” an itinerant musician roams the state with his band during Reconstruction, scratching out a living and pining for his true love.
lead_paragraph: SIMON THE FIDDLERBy Paulette Jiles

headline: New & Noteworthy, From Alexander Calder to a History of Poetry
abstract: A selection of recent books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: THE BOOK OF LONGINGS, by Sue Monk Kidd. (Viking, $28.) Kidd, the author of “The Secret Life of Bees” and other books, offers a feminist slant on Christian history in her audacious fourth novel, which opens: “I am Ana. I was the wife of Jesus ben Joseph of Nazareth.”

headline: What Street Names Say About Us
abstract: To write “The Address Book,” Deirdre Mask traveled the globe to probe the hidden histories and surprising implications of the names of our roads and thoroughfares.
lead_paragraph: THE ADDRESS BOOK What Street Addresses Reveal About Identity, Race, Wealth, and Power By Deirdre Mask

headline: Checking In on the Culture of Macaws, Sperm Whales and Chimpanzees
abstract: In “Becoming Wild,” the ecologist Carl Safina makes an argument that we should think of animals in terms of families and communities.
lead_paragraph: BECOMING WILDHow Animal Cultures Raise Families, Create Beauty, and Achieve PeaceBy Carl Safina

headline: We’re Not Going Back to Normal, but What Can We Go Back To?
abstract: Every question about the damage done by the coronavirus and a tanking economy is hard.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: To reopen, or not to reopen. Gail, that is the question.

headline: Scrolling Through the Rise, and Takeover, of Instagram
abstract: In “No Filter,” Sarah Frier goes behind the scenes of the billion-dollar deal between Kevin Systrom and Mark Zuckerberg.
lead_paragraph: NO FILTER The Inside Story of Instagram By Sarah Frier

headline: Coffee, Stretching, Epsom Salt Baths: Life in Megan Rapinoe’s Skin
abstract: And how the soccer star became something of a skin care fanatic.
lead_paragraph: Megan Rapinoe, the star midfielder of the United States women’s national soccer team, for whom she has taken home multiple golds in the Olympics and the FIFA World Cup, is almost as opinionated off the field as on … her nighttime skin care routine, on fragrance and on fresh hair color.

headline: When Coronavirus Lockdowns Go Too Far
abstract: The closures were necessary. Chasing picnickers and closing paint aisles is petty overreach.
lead_paragraph: The tweet shows two silhouettes, extending in familiar policeman shapes. The text is as cheery as a beat-walking bobby in an Edwardian children’s book: “If you think that by going for a picnic in a rural location no one will find you, don’t be surprised if an officer appears from the shadows!” And the message, directed in this case to the inhabitants of Central Bedfordshire in England, is an example of how even when they’re essential, anti-pandemic policies are always at risk of going a little bit insane.

headline: Why Can’t America Make Enough Masks or Ventilators?
abstract: The president has promoted himself as a champion of American manufacturing, but now he avoids addressing its shortcomings.
