lead_paragraph: Hundreds of companies across the United States are reinventing themselves to make equipment that is desperately needed to treat the coronavirus. That so many American manufacturers are rising to meet this pandemic with little coordination from the federal government reveals a deep altruism in our national character.

headline: My Roommate’s Boyfriend Still Visits Despite the Outbreak. Can I Object?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do when your roommate doesn’t understand that practicing social distancing means not seeing her boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: I am a woman in my mid-20s and live with a female roommate in Massachusetts. We have been under a stay-at-home advisory because of Covid-19, and we both now work remotely. For the past few weeks, I have been practicing social distancing, going out only to the supermarket and for walks and runs and keeping six feet between myself and others. Although I’m at a low (but not nonexistent) risk of falling seriously ill from the coronavirus, I don’t want to make more vulnerable members of the population sick, contribute to the spread of this virus or use up valuable health care resources.

headline: A Family of Three Gets Sick With Covid-19 Symptoms. Who Has It?
abstract: Her son’s skin and muscles are tender and sore. She has a cough and headache. Her husband has shortness of breath. Do any of them have Covid-19?
lead_paragraph: The 20-year-old man moved restlessly on a gurney in the emergency department at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn., on March 14. It was hard for him to get comfortable. His head ached; his lips and mouth felt as if they were on fire. His hands were too swollen to close, and the skin and muscles all over his body felt tender and sore. Two days earlier, his mother picked him up from his university just outside Philadelphia, which had closed because of the Covid-19 pandemic. Several of his friends had been showing signs of a Covid-like sickness, and the young man and his mother were worried that he was, too.

headline: Who Needs a Sweeping Epic About the Red Century? You Do
abstract: Nino Haratischvili’s “The Eighth Life” tells the story of a Georgian family over 100 years, from revolution to post-Soviet chaos.
lead_paragraph: THE EIGHTH LIFEBy Nino Haratischvili

headline: ‘Accelerate the Endgame’: Obama’s Role in Wrapping Up the Primary
abstract: The former president has kept his political distance from Joe Biden. But he’s been much more engaged in the race’s denouement than has been previously revealed.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, Joseph R. Biden Jr. and former President Barack Obama practiced a political distancing of sorts, with Mr. Obama maintaining a posture of public neutrality in the Democratic primaries, offering counsel to any candidate who called (most did), and Mr. Biden saying he wanted to win on his own.

headline: From Hollywood ‘Pretty Girl’ to Empowered Novelist
abstract: Susanna Moore’s memoir “Miss Aluminum” is a provocative look at the early circumstances that shaped her writing career.
lead_paragraph: MISS ALUMINUMBy Susanna Moore

headline: Reconnecting With the Past Over a Meal of ‘Braised Pork’
abstract: In this debut novel by the Chinese author An Yu, male characters propel the heroine into a journey of self-discovery.
lead_paragraph: BRAISED PORKBy An Yu

headline: You’re Not Flying, but You Can Still Think About Frequent Flier Miles
abstract: Once travel picks up again, there may be good news for member of loyalty programs. Here’s how to maximize your rewards.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Elgin’s only travel these days is a 15-mile commute by car to a hospital in the San Francisco Bay Area. She’s a pediatric nurse, and her days are long and stressful. “But when I clock out from my shift, my mind shifts seamlessly to that next perfect beach,” she said. And with good reason: Last year Ms. Elgin flew more than 100,000 miles on trips from San Francisco to destinations such as Bermuda, the Maldives and Sri Lanka. Most of her flights were virtually free, courtesy of her skills at redeeming frequent flier points.

headline: A Star of Y.A. Literature Returns. This Time, She’s Talking to Adults.
abstract: With her first adult novel, “Chosen Ones,” the “Divergent” author Veronica Roth delivers another dark tale.
lead_paragraph: CHOSEN ONESBy Veronica Roth

headline: It’s Obvious Whom Joe Biden Should Pick as Vice President
abstract: He needs a running mate who strengthens the ticket in the areas where he is weakest. One person stands out.
lead_paragraph: As Joe Biden formally begins his vice-presidential selection process, he needs to find a running mate who strengthens the Democratic ticket in the areas where he is weakest. The nomination contest has highlighted three sizable shortcomings that imperil his quest to defeat President Trump.

headline: We’re Holding Tight to Our Good Luck Talismans
abstract: When the drumbeat of bad tidings becomes overwhelming, people reach for the rabbit’s foot.
lead_paragraph: Last week Angela Missoni took a walk in the garden of her house in Sumirago, a snug town in Italy about an hour northwest of Milan. After a month in isolation, a difficult morning on Zoom and a steady drumbeat of bad tidings for business, she needed some air.

headline: ‘Overwhelmed and Frustrated’: What It’s Like Trying to Get an Abortion in Texas
abstract: Pregnant women are scrambling to get access to the procedure, driving hundreds of miles out of state. The fight has resulted in a flurry of court rulings.
lead_paragraph: The 31-year-old from Houston knew she did not want another baby. She already had three — her youngest, a boy, was just 6 months old. And she had just been laid off from her job in a medical billing office, another casualty of America’s growing unemployment crisis.

headline: Hello, What’s This? The Democrats Aren’t in Disarray
abstract: Many younger voters are not old enough to remember a Democratic presidential primary that ended so quickly and congenially. Could it help Joe Biden in the fall?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It may have taken a once-in-a-century pandemic, but the Democrats are not in disarray.

headline: Lesson From Singapore: Why We May Need to Think Bigger
abstract: A well-run system still led to a lockdown. Maybe the answer to the pandemic is a plan “on a scale that would previously be considered unimaginable.”
lead_paragraph: Many experts are beginning to coalesce around a set of benchmarks that could help determine when it might be safe to reopen parts of the country. But even though most areas of the United States are nowhere near achieving the goals necessary to do so, there has been a push to relax social distancing soon.

headline: America Can Afford a World-Class Health System. Why Don’t We Have One?
abstract: Our system takes from the poor and working class to generate wealth for the already wealthy.
lead_paragraph: In March, Congress passed a coronavirus bill including $3.1 billion to develop and produce drugs and vaccines. The bipartisan consensus was unusual. Less unusual was the successful lobbying by pharmaceutical companies to weaken or kill provisions that addressed affordability — measures that could be used to control prices or invalidate patents for any new drugs.

headline: Move Over, Unicorns. Llamas Rule the Toy Business Now.
abstract: How a less-than-magical creature became the it animal for kids.
lead_paragraph: At this year’s American International Toy Fair, which took place at the Javits Center in New York in mid-February, hundreds of buyers came in search of products to feed the fleeting desires of children all around the world. As they strolled up and down the aisles, perusing wares from hundreds of vendors, a clear theme emerged: llamas.

headline: New Role for New York Police: Breaking Up Crowds at Trader Joe’s
abstract: Crime has ebbed, but nearly 20 percent of the force is out sick. Officers have become public health police, breaking up crowds at stores.
lead_paragraph: A message popped up on Sgt. Joseph Rosso’s phone. It was not a robbery in progress, or a report of shooting, or a domestic dispute. The message said a small crowd had gathered outside a Trader Joe’s grocery store in Lower Manhattan.

headline: The Coronavirus Questions Our Science Journalists Are Following
abstract: Celia Dugger, Carl Zimmer and Sheri Fink discussed the latest science and medical news about the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: ‘What Disease Are We Treating?’: Why Coronavirus Is Stumping Many Doctors
abstract: Doctors say the coronavirus is challenging core tenets of medicine, leading some to abandon long-established ventilator protocols for certain patients. But other doctors warn this could be dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Doctors say the coronavirus is challenging core tenets of medicine, leading some to abandon long-established ventilator protocols for certain patients. But other doctors warn this could be dangerous.

headline: When Life Gives You Lemons, Make 19th-Century Lemon Cake
abstract: To stay connected with visitors under stay-at-home orders, the New-York Historical Society is curating a digital collection of archival recipes.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, in the mid-1800s, a New Yorker named Eliza Duane put pen to paper to record her most beloved recipes.

headline: ‘I Can’t Believe I Am Going to Say This, but I Would Rather Be at School’
abstract: We asked students, from kindergarten to 12th grade, what it’s like to learn from home. Here’s what they had to say, in their own words — and drawings.
lead_paragraph: Kids are getting more bored by the day. We wish we could go back to school to see our friends. But some of us are also really scared about getting the coronavirus, and we don’t want our friends and family to get it either.

headline: What Was Life Like for Sailors During the Battle of the Atlantic?
abstract: For those fighting the longest naval campaign of World War II, weather and German U-boats were constant threats.
lead_paragraph: In the latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from World War II, James Stavridis, a retired United States Navy admiral and former commander of the United States European Command, looks back on the lives of sailors during the long Battle of the Atlantic.

headline: ‘Pacing and Praying’: Jailed Youths Seek Release as Virus Spreads
abstract: While some states have moved to release adults from prisons where the coronavirus poses a threat, efforts to free juveniles from detention have met resistance.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — A 17-year-old girl spends nearly 24 hours a day in an 11-foot-by-11-foot room in the Lower Eastern Shore Children’s Center, the benignly named detention facility in rural Maryland where the coronavirus first entered the state’s juvenile justice system.

headline: What Doctors on the Front Lines Wish They’d Known a Month Ago
abstract: Ironclad emergency medical practices — about when to use ventilators, for example — have dissolved almost overnight.
lead_paragraph: Just about a month ago, people stricken with the new coronavirus started to arrive in unending ranks at hospitals in the New York metropolitan area, forming the white-hot center of the pandemic in the United States.

headline: Why Coronavirus Is Killing African-Americans More Than Others
abstract: Higher rates of infection and death among minorities demonstrate the racial character of inequality in America.
lead_paragraph: We know that Covid-19 is killing African-Americans at greater rates than any other group. You can see this most clearly in the South. In Louisiana, blacks account for 70 percent of the deaths but 33 percent of the population. In Alabama, they account for 44 percent of the deaths and 26 percent of the population. South Carolina and Georgia have yet to release information on death disparities, but in both states blacks are more likely to be infected than whites. The pattern exists in the North as well, where African-American populations in cities like Chicago and Milwaukee have high infection and death rates.

headline: Peter Beard Still Missing, Weeks After Disappearing on Long Island
abstract: No evidence has emerged to explain what happened to the artist, 82, who was last seen at his cliff-side estate on the water.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — Taking chances has long been second nature to Peter Beard, a photographer and artist who spent decades living and working at his rustic tent camp in Kenya, where he documented both Africa’s natural beauty and its environmental decay.

headline: ‘This Is Going to Kill Small-Town America’
abstract: Once the coronavirus reached rural Bristol, N.H., the effect on the local economy was devastating.
lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, N.H. — The coronavirus itself was slow to arrive in Bristol, a lakeside town of 3,300 people. The economic destruction came swiftly.

headline: Looking for a Full Sports Calendar? Try Nicaragua
abstract: Baseball and soccer leagues carry on in Nicaragua, whose public health officials report relatively few coronavirus cases. Many others have doubts.
lead_paragraph: All over the world, sports have shut down. Yet in one country, an alternate universe exists with a very full sports calendar.

headline: The Chelsea Townhouse Where “All of It” Happens
abstract: Thanks to the virus, Alison Stewart is broadcasting from home. But even with renovation No. 4 delayed, there’s still lots to love about her apartment.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the virus, Alison Stewart is broadcasting from home. But even with renovation No. 4 delayed, there’s still lots to love about her apartment.

headline: I’m an E.R. Doctor in New York. None of Us Will Ever Be the Same.
abstract: A Covid diary: This is what I saw as the pandemic engulfed our hospitals.
lead_paragraph: I am in Karachi, Pakistan, on March 2, when I read the news: New York City has its first patient hospitalized with the coronavirus. Though I am more than 7,000 miles away — reporting on a different disease outbreak — I am already worried about what I will face when I return home in two days to my job as an emergency-room doctor in the city. Even in the best of circumstances, the E.R. can be swamped, with patients doubled up in rooms and too few monitors and beds to go around. Doctors and nurses are always multitasking at the edge of their limits. “Damage control,” we call it.

headline: The Host of WNYC’s ‘All of It’ on Being a Homebody
abstract: Thanks to the virus, Alison Stewart is broadcasting from home. But even if renovation No. 4 had to be postponed, there’s still plenty to love about her Chelsea apartment.
lead_paragraph: This just in: Alison Stewart, the host of the arts and culture talk show “All of It” on WNYC, is a self-described stalker.

headline: Japan Needs to Telework. Its Paper-Pushing Offices Make That Hard.
abstract: The government says working remotely is crucial to halting the coronavirus, but a workplace culture of official seals, fax machines and face-to-face meetings hinders that effort.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Officially, Shuhei Aoyama has been teleworking for a month. But that doesn’t mean he can avoid going to the office.

headline: The Huge Cost of Waiting to Contain the Pandemic
abstract: As the numbers show, the timing of social distancing can have an enormous impact on death tolls.
lead_paragraph: During disease outbreaks, epidemiologists agonize about the timing and extent of interventions like social distancing to slow the spread. Their instincts are almost always to move sooner rather than later, because preventing new infections as early as possible can disrupt chains of transmission and save many lives. Our experience with Covid-19 makes that clear.

headline: ‘This Is Big: How the Founder of Weight Watchers Changed the World — and Me,’ By Marisa Meltzer: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “This Is Big: How the Founder of Weight Watchers Changed the World — and Me,” By Marisa Meltzer
lead_paragraph: It was the beginning of the fall in Queens in 1961. Jean Nidetch woke up feeling sylphlike even though she weighed 214 pounds. She put on a muumuu, a dress she considered a fat woman’s boon because it hung nicely over everything and in the pockets she could squirrel away pistachios. Her driver’s license weight was 145 pounds, which she hadn’t been since before high school. But nobody weighed you at the DMV.

headline: ‘Miss Aluminum,’ by Susanna Moore: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Miss Aluminum,” by Susanna Moore
lead_paragraph: I took nothing with me when I left. No photographs, no books, no souvenirs of childhood. Dressed by my stepmother in hand-me-downs, and oversized dresses from a thrift store, clothes that I vowed never to wear again, I arrived in Philadelphia in the summer of 1963 without a suitcase. My father and stepmother had been so eager to be rid of me, the potentially incendiary leader of a harmless gang of disconsolate children, that I was sent to my maternal grandmother, Mae Shields, the day after I graduated from Punahou, where I had been at school since I was a small child. I was seventeen years old.

headline: ‘The Address Book,’ by Deirdre Mask: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Address Book,” by Deirdre Mask
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Donald Trump threw a black-tie bash for his new building bordering Columbus Circle and Central Park West, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. “This is the most successful condominium tower ever built in the United States, did you hear me say that earlier?” he told a journalist. His own apartment was a nine-thousand-square-foot glass box in the sky. (“Nobody has ever seen a room this big, with this high a ceiling, with this much glass.”) Trump’s divorce lawyer came to the party, but Marla Maples, whom Trump had separated from, stayed home. The tower had been built into the skeleton of an old office building, swaddled in bronze reflective glass. “It looks cheap.” “It’s Miami Beach.” “It’s really awful.” “Why didn’t you warn us?” angry New Yorkers asked Herbert Muschamp, The New York Times’s architectural critic. Muschamp himself called it a 1950s skyscraper “in a 1980s gold lamé party dress.”

headline: 52 Places, Virtually
abstract: While you’re stuck at home waiting for travel restrictions to be lifted, we invite you on a virtual visit to each and every one of our Places to Go in 2020.
lead_paragraph: When we published our list of 52 places to visit in 2020 three months ago, no one could have guessed how much our world would change. And now, given our stay-at-home circumstances, we’d like to invite you on a series of virtual journeys: You can wander into the belly of an Egyptian pyramid, explore the house where Mozart was born, or fly over the rocky peaks of Glacier National Park. Sure, you’ll be looking at a screen, but you’ll see new places, hear new languages and pick up some interesting tidbits about other cultures. Call it a warm-up for that moment when you’ll actually be packing your bags and heading out for your next adventure.

headline: Coronavirus Updates: Trump Halts U.S. Funding of World Health Organization
abstract: New York deaths spike as the state releases a revised count, and California explores steps toward reopening. Trump announces his “opening the country” council.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus epidemic.

abstract: New York and six nearby states have created an alliance to plan for when the coronavirus lockdown eases.

headline: Coronavirus, Governors, Joe Biden: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Examining an Allegation Against Joe Biden
abstract: What we know about the police report filed by Tara Reade, who said the sexual assault complaint is about her former boss, now the prospective Democratic presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Bedtime Was Hard Enough. Then Came Quarantine.
abstract: Kids across the world are having trouble sleeping. There are ways to help.
lead_paragraph: I’ve noticed a trend in my sleep clinics over the last several weeks. Children who had previously been napping and sleeping through the night are suddenly having problems sleeping, and so are their parents. But it’s not just the sleep patients; I split my time between treating children with pulmonary and sleep issues, and lately everyone seems to be having sleep complaints.

headline: Does Private Equity Deserve a Public Bailout?
abstract: Whatever you think about it, public pensions are dependent on private equity investments for returns, and their portfolio companies employ millions.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: What Day Is It? You’re Not the Only One Asking
abstract: When no one’s leaving the house, what does time even mean?
lead_paragraph: A little over a week ago, a local news anchor in Cleveland, Todd Meany, got a call from his producer about an unusual problem created by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: In Pandemic’s Grip, Russia Sees Spike in Age-Old Bane: Drinking
abstract: The widespread, false belief that alcohol will protect drinkers from the coronavirus is helping drive an increase in liquor sales and domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Dr. Azat Asadullin, chief doctor at a clinic in south-central Russia, is scrambling to prepare for an influx of patients. He is ready to deploy spare beds and stocking up on medication and disinfectants.

headline: On Politics: An Eye Toward Opening for Business
abstract: East and West Coast governors unite, and so do Biden and Sanders: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony Fauci listened as President Trump spoke during the coronavirus briefing at the White House on Monday.

headline: Cuomo Insists He Doesn’t Want a Fight With Trump
abstract: Governor Cuomo, after appearing on four different television channels to spar with the president, said he wanted to work as partners.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Wednesday’s live coverage.]

headline: Trump Falsely Claims ‘Ultimate Authority’ to Override States’ Virus Measures
abstract: Constitutional experts, government agencies and Republican governors all say otherwise.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, in a combative news conference on Monday, falsely and repeatedly asserted that he had the unilateral power to compel states to lift stay-at-home orders and businesses to open. Here’s a fact check of that and other claims.

headline: ‘The Legend of Swee’ Pea’ Review: Obstacles Put Talent to the Test
abstract: This biographical documentary leaves viewers wondering to what degree Lloyd Daniels has come to terms with his past.
lead_paragraph: “The Legend of Swee’ Pea” is thornier than a conventional sports biography, mainly because of the figure it chronicles, the basketball player Lloyd Daniels. Daniels’s life — starting with a difficult upbringing, getting passed through the New York City educational system, and drug and alcohol abuse — has had so many wild swings and second chances that it’s tempting to leave them unspoiled. It is not even clear that Daniels has fully resolved his troubles at the point when the film ends. (With a 2016 copyright, the documentary is itself a few years out of date.)

headline: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Joe Biden, U.S. Infection Rates, Saturday Night Live
abstract: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

headline: Bernie’s Endorsement Matters
abstract: His voters may once again play a critical role.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Is California a Nation-State?
abstract: Tuesday: Gov. Gavin Newsom said he doesn’t mean “nation-state” literally. But he’s proud of it. Also: Remembering Rosary Celaya Castro-Olega.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The White House Blessed a War in Libya, but Russia Won It
abstract: Russia wanted more leverage over an aspiring Libyan strongman. The White House provided it by assenting to a disastrous civil war.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI — Early last spring, just before a planned American-backed peace conference between warring factions in Libya, the aspiring Libyan strongman Khalifa Hifter arranged a phone call with John R. Bolton, then the White House national security adviser.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
lead_paragraph: $14 MILLION

headline: Plunge in Convention Hotel Travel Puts Municipal Bonds at Risk
abstract: The industry can withstand a downturn of a month or two, experts say, but a longer delay could hamper financing for projects in development.
lead_paragraph: Confinement and social distancing mandates are taking a toll on business travel as airlines cut flight schedules and long-distance meetings are held with teleconferencing services like Zoom, putting cities around the nation in a bind.

headline: ‘Unbelievable’ Timing: As Coronavirus Rages, Trump Disregards Advice to Tighten Clean Air Rules
abstract: Despite an emerging link between air pollution and Covid-19 death rates, the Trump administration will decline to tighten standards on soot emissions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Disregarding an emerging scientific link between dirty air and Covid-19 death rates, the Trump administration declined on Tuesday to tighten a regulation on industrial soot emissions that came up for review ahead of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: He Tried to Change the System, Then Became It
abstract: Dalia Sofer’s novel “Man of My Time” traces a man’s path from “baffled revolutionary to aging captive of a life gone wrong.”
lead_paragraph: MAN OF MY TIMEBy Dalia Sofer

headline: Comic Creators Unite to Benefit Stores
abstract: A large group of comic book creators will be using Twitter to auction books, art and more to benefit stores upended by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A large group of comic book creators are banding together to help support comic book retailers whose business have been disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A Dancer’s Quarantine Diary: Coming Full Circle
abstract: The New York City Ballet principal Megan Fairchild has found shelter back at her childhood home in Utah. She tells us about her new normal.
lead_paragraph: SANDY, Utah — For ballet dancers, normal life means dancing and sweating very close to one another for up to 12 hours a day, six days a week. Typically, morning company class at New York City Ballet looks as crowded as the 42nd Street subway station after two trains have passed by without stopping. For dancers, six feet apart rarely happens.

headline: This Might Be the Longest Creature Ever Seen in the Ocean
abstract: Scientists spotted a swirling siphonophore off Western Australia that was 150 feet long.
lead_paragraph: Nerida Wilson couldn’t take her eyes off the computer screen. Some 2,000 feet beneath the research boat she was aboard, a creature drifted past in the shape of a vast, galactic swirl. By her team’s estimates, it was 150 feet long.

headline: ‘The Sopranos’ and Nina Simone Sustain ‘Unorthodox’ Star
abstract: Shira Haas also puts “Cold War,” Chava Alberstein and mandalas on her list of essentials.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, the Israeli actress Shira Haas was undergoing a transformation in Berlin. Call it a crash course — with lessons in Yiddish, English, piano and voice — in playing Esther “Esty” Shapiro, a fiercely independent 19-year-old woman who escapes her cloistered Hasidic community in Brooklyn, in Netflix’s “Unorthodox.”

headline: Camino Del Norte
abstract: Camino Del Norte
lead_paragraph: Camino Del Norte

headline: Don’t Fence Me In: The Comforts of a Sheep Video
abstract: It’s the virus-era version of the perpetual yule log — a six-hour loop of grazing livestock that provides soothing balm to the shut-in.
lead_paragraph: I had high ambitions for my time in lockdown. Finally, with no restaurants to check out and no one to check them out with, I would have my nights to myself.

headline: She Kept a Diary of China’s Epidemic. Now She Faces a Political Storm.
abstract: “If authors have any responsibilities in the face of disaster, the greatest of them is to bear witness.” Here are excerpts from the author Fang Fang’s controversial chronicle of life and death in Wuhan.
lead_paragraph: As Wuhan was engulfed by the coronavirus, the Chinese author Fang Fang worked late into the night, writing a daily chronicle of life and death in her home city that gave rise to a global pandemic.

headline: Barack Obama Endorses Joe Biden for President
abstract: In a video released on Tuesday, Mr. Obama endorsed his former vice president, saying the country needed a steady leader to combat the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama emerged from political hibernation on Tuesday to endorse Joseph R. Biden Jr. and urge the Democratic Party — including, explicitly, supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont — to unite behind its presumptive presidential nominee in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Coronavirus Tests Science’s Need for Speed Limits
abstract: Preprint servers and peer-reviewed journals are seeing surging audiences, with many new readers not well versed in the limitations of the latest research findings.
lead_paragraph: Early on Feb. 1, John Inglis picked up his phone and checked Twitter, as he does most mornings. He was shocked at what fresh hell awaited.

headline: Where to Order Fried Chicken for Takeout and Delivery
abstract: Spots across the city, including Adda, The Beatrice Inn and Peaches HotHouse, are all offering the dish.
lead_paragraph: As anyone who has packed some for a picnic can attest, fried chicken travels well. So it’s an excellent choice for takeout and delivery. Across the city, you can find fried chicken everywhere from chains to high-end restaurants. The majority are American, especially Southern-style, but there are also dishes from South Korean, Japanese and European spots, among others. Personally, I have always preferred to let others make my fried chicken, so I can avoid dealing with the clouds of flour, bowls of batter and pans and vats of fat or oil in my kitchen. Here is a selection of the scores of places that prepare fried chicken to go, for contactless takeout and delivery.

headline: How to Make the Most of Those Cans of Sardines
abstract: Alison Roman’s advice to eat these especially delicious little fishes: Add lots of herbs and something oniony, a little fat and tons of lemon.
lead_paragraph: Over the last three weeks or so, I’ve been fielding a lot of Q.C.Q. (Quarantine Cooking Questions), and while I am working overtime on “social media” trying to answer them, I thought it would also be useful to start using this column to answer the most frequently asked.

headline: For Black Men, Fear That Masks Will Invite Racial Profiling
abstract: African-American men worry that following the C.D.C. recommendation to cover their faces in public could expose them to harassment from the police.
lead_paragraph: When Allen Hargrove leaves his Brooklyn apartment to get groceries, he does so with an underlying feeling of worry. It’s not just the coronavirus pandemic: As a black man, he fears he could draw unwanted attention by wearing a mask in public.

headline: A Town Is Besieged by Children, Foreign and Violent
abstract: In Andrés Barba’s novel “A Luminous Republic,” a community is threatened by a pack of outsiders.
lead_paragraph: A LUMINOUS REPUBLIC By Andrés Barba

headline: The News Is Making People Anxious. You’ll Never Believe What They’re Reading Instead.
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has driven interest in uplifting headlines way, way up.
lead_paragraph: Though it can be hard to see past the daily deluge of devastating headlines, there is plenty of good news in the world right now — and a great deal of interest in reading it.

headline: Critiques of Joe Biden’s Coronavirus Plan
abstract: Readers discuss Mr. Biden’s Op-Ed about how he would safely reopen America.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hank Steinbrenner, an Heir to the Yankees, Is Dead at 63
abstract: After the death of their father, George, in 2010, he and his younger brother, Hal, took over the franchise. But Hal was given the bigger role.
lead_paragraph: It was late October 2007, and it was a very bad day for the Yankees. Their best player, Alex Rodriguez, had just opted out of his contract, and their fierce rival, the Boston Red Sox, had just won the World Series. Hank Steinbrenner decided to channel his father, George, who had never missed a chance to grab a headline. He called a reporter and challenged Rodriguez.

headline: California Set the Tone on Coronavirus Shutdowns. What’s Its Next Move?
abstract: A state once considered one of the most vulnerable to coronavirus infections has kept deaths comparatively low, and is cautiously looking at next steps.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — California has been ahead of the rest of America in confronting the coronavirus pandemic, locking down its citizens early and avoiding, so far, the worst-case scenarios predicted for infections and deaths.

headline: Will the Coronavirus End Israel’s Political Paralysis?
abstract: Benny Gantz, who had been seeking to unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, is now talking with his rival about forming a unity government amid the public health crisis.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After three inconclusive elections resulting in a yearlong impasse, Israel’s president has given Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his chief rival, Benny Gantz, until Wednesday midnight to form a unity government.

headline: World Wars Stopped the Tour de France. Now Coronavirus Has, Too.
abstract: The Tour de France will not start on time. But the N.F.L. will allow virtual workouts, and there are some 250 table tennis matches happening, too.
lead_paragraph: Another major world sports event has been disrupted by the coronavirus. This time, it’s the Tour de France.

headline: How ‘Fast Carbs’ May Undermine Your Health
abstract: Comfort foods like chips and cookies can short-circuit our biology and accelerate the onset of diabetes and heart disease.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, foods of all kinds have flown off the shelves at grocery stores as Americans stocked up to weather the coronavirus pandemic. But sales of “comfort foods” like potato chips, pretzels, pancake mix and cookies have seen a particularly dramatic surge. That may not be surprising: They are cheap, satisfying and shelf stable.

headline: Starved for Sports? Here Are 5 Options That Aren’t N.B.A. Classic
abstract: On the menu: trenchant documentaries from ESPN and HBO, dramas about Norwegian soccer and Korean baseball, and an addictive exploration of pro wrestling.
lead_paragraph: How are you scratching your itch for televised sports? (If you don’t have one, move along. I don’t comprehend you.) With no live competition to show, broadcasters are offering a buffet of leftovers — “classic” games, old poker tournaments, spelling bee marathons — and constantly replenished chatter about what’s not happening.

headline: China’s ‘Donation Diplomacy’ Raises Tensions With U.S.
abstract: New regulations in China are delaying its shipments of medical supplies around the world. And some American officials worry accepting donated gear helps China’s propaganda efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump spoke with Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader, late last month to reach a truce to the sniping over the coronavirus pandemic, he did so partly to pave the way for steady shipments of much-needed medical supplies from China.

headline: ‘We Can Do Better’: One Plan to Erase America’s Digital Divide
abstract: Never has the necessity of the internet been so clear, nor has the cost to those who go without.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: ‘See You on the Campaign Trail’: Obama Endorses Biden
abstract: Former President Barack Obama released a video throwing his support behind his former vice president, Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama released a video throwing his support behind his former vice president, Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: ‘Mrs. America’ Review: The Voice of an E.R.A.
abstract: Packed with stunning performances, the limited series tells a sweeping story of women’s rights revolutionaries — and a formidable counterrevolutionary.
lead_paragraph: “Mad Men” ended its timeline in late 1970, with the advertising patriarch Don Draper peaced out at a yoga retreat, om-ing his way to the inspiration for the classic 1971 Coca-Cola “Hilltop” ad. Since then, fans have dreamed about a follow-up, one focused not on the Don Drapers of the world, but on the women whose limitations and liberations were the through-line of the series.

headline: It’s the Worst Possible Time for Trump to Make False Claims of Authority
abstract: He does not have “total” authority over states.
lead_paragraph: I teach my law students that every so often in the law, the best way to understand the veracity of a claim is just to say it out loud. They got a great example of this on Monday when President Trump made a contribution to the legal lexicon: “When somebody is the president of the United States, the authority is total. And that’s the way it’s got to be. It’s total.”

headline: Our Best Recipes and Tips for Quarantine Cooking
abstract: This regularly updated list of articles will help you find what you need.
lead_paragraph: Cooking is a balm, and in this especially difficult time, it can keep us safe. With that in mind, we’ve made many more recipes than usual free for the using, even if you haven’t yet subscribed to NYT Cooking, and we’ve written articles to guide you, in finding recipes and in the act of cooking itself. (If you’d like to subscribe and support our work, please do.) We hope it’ll push you to cook, both as solace and as sustenance. We are all in this together.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: Connect Your Students to the World With Our ‘Lesson of the Day’
abstract: In this webinar, The Learning Network walks you through how to use our daily lesson plans from home and in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: Do you want to bring current issues and events to your students?

headline: Court Strikes Down Trump Rollback of School Nutrition Rules
abstract: A federal district judge has ruled that the Agriculture Department’s regulation easing sodium and whole-grain standards in school meals violated regulatory law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal court has struck down a 2018 Agriculture Department rule that reversed nutrition standards for sodium and whole grains in school meal programs once championed by the former first lady Michelle Obama.

headline: Even Google and Facebook May Face an Ad Slump
abstract: Though ad sales at the two companies are expected to be down, they are likely to fare better than smaller peers and publishers.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google’s and Facebook’s advertising businesses, which have roughly tripled in combined size over the last five years, may be headed for a rare stumble as the coronavirus pushes the global economy into a tailspin.

headline: If You Have Kimchi, You’re Steps Away From This Soup
abstract: This warming recipe is the perfect way to use up any jars of the condiment that may linger in your fridge.
lead_paragraph: One of necessities of infrequent grocery shopping is keeping a handle on what I’ve already got in the fridge, where real estate is limited. Over the weekend, I purged, and among the jars of half-eaten condiments were three containers of kimchi. It was obviously time to make kimchi soup.

headline: Wynn Handman, Influential Director and Teacher, Dies at 97
abstract: At the American Place Theater, he championed new works. In his acting classes, he nurtured countless future stars. His death was related to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Trump’s Claim of ‘Total’ Authority Over Reopening
abstract: The constitutional lawyer Floyd Abrams disagrees with the president’s view of his authority. Another reader says governors are the ones who should be trusted to make decisions about reopening.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: This 3-D Simulation Shows Why Social Distancing Is So Important
abstract: We visualized a cough to show how far respiratory droplets can spread. If you haven’t been keeping your distance to fight the coronavirus, this may persuade you.
lead_paragraph: We visualized a cough to show how far respiratory droplets can spread. If you haven’t been keeping your distance to fight the coronavirus, this may persuade you.

headline: Who Is Kyle Larson?
abstract: A NASCAR driver who was dismissed from his team after using a racial slur is a product of a diversity program.
lead_paragraph: Until Sunday, Kyle Larson was known as a talented and popular NASCAR driver who was quick with a joke.

headline: Answering Kids’ Questions About the Coronavirus, in Free Picture Books
abstract: Publishers and nonprofits are finding ways to get books and information to housebound children worldwide.
lead_paragraph: In “My Hero Is You,” a new illustrated book by Helen Patuck, a girl named Sara lies in bed at night, feeling scared and helpless. She misses seeing friends and going to school. As she drifts off, a dragon appears, and they fly all over the world together on a shared mission: teaching children how to keep themselves and their families safe from the novel coronavirus.

headline: Big Banks, Readying for a Recession, Set Aside Billions
abstract: First-quarter earnings reports from JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo showed the country’s largest banks were preparing for customer pain.
lead_paragraph: The economic shutdown the coronavirus has caused has already forced millions of Americans out of work and threatened the future of thousands of small businesses, and the country’s biggest banks are bracing for the fallout.

headline: Economists Aren’t the Ones Pushing to Reopen the Economy
abstract: On cronies, cranks and the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Paul Krugman’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Tuesday.

headline: New York Bridal Fashion Week Goes Virtual
abstract: Five fashion designers share their plans for showcasing their new bridal collections during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: By now, fashion designers would have been putting their final touches on dresses as they planned lavish runway shows and collection previews in preparation for New York Bridal Fashion Week, which runs April 16-20. But the coronavirus outbreak has forced them to rethink how they should present their latest fashions.

headline: A ‘Full Deck’ of Chekhov, With the Translators as the Wild Cards
abstract: In “Fifty-Two Stories,” translated by Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky, the vigorous soul of the Russian master’s writing shines through.
lead_paragraph: “Everywhere there is cholera, everywhere quarantine and terror.”

headline: Are Your Parents on TikTok?
abstract: When many of us are stuck at home, your folks are going online.
lead_paragraph: We spend a lot of our days thinking about things we see online, trying to make sense of it all. This week in the Styles newsletter, Wait …, Taylor Lorenz, a Styles reporter, brings us an update from the world of TikTok.

headline: Antonio Checo, Episcopal Priest Who Stressed Service, Dies at 67
abstract: His years as a social worker led him to preach community engagement as the rector of St. Mark’s Church in Jackson Heights, Queens.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Who Gets a Ventilator?
abstract: We don’t want doctors playing God. Here’s how we avoid that.
lead_paragraph: We don’t want doctors playing God. Here’s how we avoid that.

headline: Stay 6 Feet Apart, We’re Told. But How Far Can Air Carry Coronavirus?
abstract: Most of the big droplets travel a mere six feet. The role of tiny aerosols is the “trillion-dollar question.”
lead_paragraph: The rule of thumb, or rather feet, has been to stand six feet apart in public. That’s supposed to be a safe distance if a person nearby is coughing or sneezing and is infected with the novel coronavirus, spreading droplets that may carry virus particles.

headline: Bail Someone Out of Jail Today
abstract: Covid-19 is an unfolding catastrophe in America’s houses of detention.
lead_paragraph: For those who don’t wish to sit by helplessly during the coronavirus crisis, there is something you can do. You can very possibly save a life by bailing someone out of jail.

headline: Who Gets a Ventilator?
abstract: We don’t want doctors playing God. Here’s how we avoid that.
lead_paragraph: At some American hospitals, ventilators are already in short supply, as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. But what happens when there aren’t enough to go around? How do we decide who gets a chance to live and who dies? The video above argues that the United States needs a national rationing plan. Individual doctors and hospitals can’t be left to make these agonizing choices on their own, and the question of who lives and who dies should not depend on what state a patient lives in.

headline: ‘We Will All Die One Day,’ My President Said
abstract: We live in a time of more questions than answers. Beware anyone who thinks otherwise, especially presidents.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — My first symptoms started on a Monday morning, March 23. I was just getting over a random disease that my daughter had brought home from nursery school — we’re still not sure what — when I had a sudden fever. My husband was the culprit, we decided; my daughter and I had already been isolated at home sick with something else for 10 days. He, on the other hand, was still attending a few work meetings and leaving our house to buy groceries.

headline: What Is Missing From Afghan Peace Talks
abstract: A just political order in Afghanistan needs decentralization of power and an equitable distribution of resources among its people.
lead_paragraph: PANJSHIR VALLEY, Afghanistan — After four decades of conflict, Afghanistan seems poised to embrace superficial peace. The negotiations between the United States and the Taliban in Doha, Qatar, culminated in a peace agreement between the two sides. The agreement paved the way for a national peace dialogue between the Taliban and a conglomerate of Afghan political factions and figures led by the government of Afghanistan.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Alone in My Room, Crying, Eating Cake’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: “Daddy,” my middle daughter said, “for my birthday I want a pretty garden again.” Two years ago, a tiny lump and “Should I have this looked at?” ended with my wife’s memorial service just after Easter. With the time lost to treatment, arguments and constant worry, the garden had been abandoned. My daughter, with her late-April birthday, didn’t realize how painful the memories were. Yet, I began — pulling weeds, turning soil, planting seeds as my hands bled and I wept. Today, a daisy bloomed and tomatoes appeared. Though the garden is a gift for my daughter, I thank her. — Tom Sunstrom

headline: Will 2020 Be the Year That Medicine Was Saved?
abstract: The coronavirus is forcing reforms that could change America’s health care system forever if Congress requires it.
lead_paragraph: As it approves billions of dollars to support hospitals and health care workers besieged by Covid-19, Congress can reinforce some of the worst elements of America’s broken health care system or it can begin to transform the system by making permanent the reforms the pandemic has forced through.

headline: Police Handcuff Black Doctor Who Tests Homeless for Coronavirus
abstract: The Miami police chief promised an investigation after a video showed Dr. Armen Henderson being handcuffed outside his home on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The soundless video shows a man wearing a protective mask picking up bags and boxes outside a white van when a Miami police officer pulls up.

headline: Most Libraries Are Closed. Some Librarians Still Have to Go In.
abstract: Though many public libraries in the U.S. are completely shut, employees at some are concerned that they have been asked to continue showing up for work.
lead_paragraph: October Ramos, a library employee who lives in Harris County, Tex., was relieved on March 24 when the county ordered residents who did not work in essential services to stay home to limit the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: N.Y. Got $12,000 Per Virus Case, by One Count. Nebraska Got $379,000.
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New York lawmakers are taking issue with how much federal funding their state is receiving compared with those with fewer cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has repeatedly complained that his state has been shortchanged by the $2 trillion economic stabilization package passed last month.

headline: A Conversation With will.i.am on Achieving a More Just America
abstract: The music artist and education activist discusses the state of economic opportunity and the impact of the coronavirus .
lead_paragraph: The music artist will.i.am. hosted a discussion on Twitter on the coronavirus crisis and economic inequality in America.

headline: Bernie Sanders Pitches His Supporters a New Idea: Biden 2020
abstract: The Vermont senator’s devoted backers might come to embrace Joe Biden’s candidacy, but it’s going to take more than a joint appearance via live stream.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders could always draw a crowd — more than 20,000 in New York City at his campaign’s peak — and it could seem from the outside that his followers were supportive of his every move during his presidential runs. The most fervent mobilized quickly against his opponents, deriding Hillary Clinton, criticizing Pete Buttigieg as inauthentic and casting Senator Elizabeth Warren as insufficiently progressive. The small donations amounted to fund-raising records.

headline: Darius Swann, Plaintiff in Landmark Busing Case, Dies at 95
abstract: A former missionary, he sued the local school system in North Carolina when his 6-year-old son could not attend class two blocks away.
lead_paragraph: Darius Swann grew up in the racially segregated American South but only read about the civil rights advances of the 1950s and early ’60s from half a world away, in Allahabad, India.

headline: Grim Economic Predictions, India’s Lockdown, Li Wenliang: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The WWE Is Now Considered an ‘Essential Service’ in Florida
abstract: Officials in the state permitted “employees at professional sports and media production with a national audience” to hold an event if it is closed to the public.
lead_paragraph: In a pandemic, as state officials desperately shut down parts of society to keep people away from one another, there are some services that most would agree must go on: Grocery stores feed the public. Health care workers tend to the infirm. Others maintain law and order, deliver goods and keep the lights on.

headline: One Bright Thing
abstract: Need a little lift? Amid the bleakness, 18 Times writers shared moments that lightened their mood.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The Defiant Beauty of Cherry Blossom Season
abstract: Festivals might be canceled but the trees are still doing their thing. And you can see some of them from a safe distance.
lead_paragraph: The season of pink has arrived.

headline: Classic Board Games With a Touch of Tech
abstract: How to use video conferencing to play traditional, real-life board games with people who are sheltering in different places.
lead_paragraph: From November of 1955 to September 1957, my father played two games of chess with his friend Sam Frankenheim. My dad was in the Army, Sam was in the Air Force, and they mailed postcards back and forth detailing their moves. (Oh, to write the word “checkmate” before popping a triumphant card in the mail!)

headline: N.Y.C. Death Toll Soars Past 10,000 in Revised Virus Count
abstract: The city has added more than 3,700 additional people who were presumed to have died of the coronavirus but had never tested positive.
lead_paragraph: New York City, already a world epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak, sharply increased its death toll by more than 3,700 victims on Tuesday, after officials said they were now including people who had never tested positive for the virus but were presumed to have died of it.

headline: Feel Like You’re in Prison? These Trainers Actually Were
abstract: The formerly incarcerated have lessons to share about emerging from confinement fitter, in mind and body.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of self-isolating people, Madisen Li is vacillating between nervous, bored, grateful and irritable. One of her main forms of relief comes from her weekly training sessions over Zoom with her personal trainer of nine years, Hector Guadalupe.

headline: Albert K. Webster, Who Built Up the New York Philharmonic, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Webster, who had the coronavirus, lived and breathed the Philharmonic as a career orchestra administrator and consultant.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Robby Browne, Real Estate Player and Philanthropist, Dies at 72
abstract: As a top agent in New York City, he socialized with celebrities and the business elite. He also contributed to numerous AIDS- and gay-related charities.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Joseph Migliucci, Fixture at Storied Bronx Restaurant, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Migliucci’s family-owned restaurant on Arthur Avenue, Mario’s, celebrated its 100th anniversary last year. He fell victim to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: I.M.F. Predicts Worst Downturn Since the Great Depression
abstract: The global economy is expected to contract by 3 percent this year as quarantines and lockdowns cripple output.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund issued a stark warning on Tuesday about the coronavirus’s economic toll, saying that the world is facing its worst downturn since the Great Depression as shuttered factories, quarantines and national lockdowns cause economic output to collapse.

headline: Furloughs and Pay Cuts Hit The Los Angeles Times
abstract: A sudden drop in advertising, brought on by the pandemic, is leading to cost-cutting measures at Patrick Soon-Shiong’s California papers.
lead_paragraph: The parent company of The Los Angeles Times is furloughing 40 employees and cutting the pay of senior managers in an effort to make up for losses brought on by a pandemic-related decline in advertising revenue.

headline: Does Widespread Disinfecting Kill the Coronavirus? It’s Under Debate
abstract: Spraying streets and inside buildings might calm a worried public, but it’s too early to know whether such efforts reduce transmission.
lead_paragraph: The images are compelling: Fire trucks in Tehran or Manila spray the streets. Amazon tests a disinfectant fog inside a warehouse, hoping to calm workers’ fears and get them back on the job. TV commercials show health care workers cleaning chairs where blood donors sat. Families nervously wipe their mail and newly delivered groceries.

headline: After Mocking ‘King’ Trump, Cuomo Says Virus Should Be ‘No-Politics Zone’
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo attacked the president in a string of television appearances on Tuesday but then pulled back, saying the “president will have no fight with me.”
lead_paragraph: Since the coronavirus began to ravage New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has used a fine mix of outright flattery and back-room diplomacy to draw down a variety of federal support, preaching nonpartisanship while mostly avoiding direct attacks on President Trump.

headline: Is Britain Undercounting the Human and Economic Toll of Coronavirus?
abstract: According to new statistics, the death toll from the virus could be at least 10 percent higher than officially reported because of deaths in nursing homes and private residences.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Britain closes in on 100,000 reported cases of the coronavirus — a solemn milestone in a contagion that has ravaged its political leadership — a raft of new statistics suggests that the government is undercounting the human, and economic, cost of the epidemic.

headline: It’s Not Just You: In Online Meetings, Many Women Can’t Get a Word In
abstract: Overlapping chatter. Interruptions. Few nonverbal cues. For women, virtual meetings can mirror the inequities of in-person meetings.
lead_paragraph: — Deborah Tannen, professor of linguistics at Georgetown University

headline: Ready for Another Streaming Service? NBC’s Peacock Starts Rollout
abstract: NBCUniversal is offering its long-gestating platform to some Comcast subscribers before making it widely available this summer.
lead_paragraph: In what amounts to a sneak preview, Comcast’s NBCUniversal will offer its long-in-the-works streaming platform, Peacock, to some cable subscribers on Wednesday before making it widely available in the summer.

headline: As Bodies Accumulate, So Do Fears of a High Coronavirus Toll in Ecuador
abstract: In two weeks, 1,900 bodies were collected from Guayaquil’s hospitals and homes for burial, a fivefold increase in the city’s usual mortality rate, according to Ecuador’s government.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — Guayaquil, Ecuador’s business capital, has been the site of Latin America’s most aggressive outbreak of coronavirus, overwhelming its hospitals and burial system and causing bodies to be left in the streets.

headline: How to Help Those Weathering Financial Storms
abstract: It doesn’t always require money to help those facing financial shortages
lead_paragraph: I worry about my daughter’s dojo, where she’s studied for almost six years. Upper West Side Kenshikai in Manhattan, is owned by Jennifer and Matthew Fremon, who are parents. It’s a place of great spirit that has taught our child not just about martial arts, but life.

headline: Coronavirus Outbreak at Virginia Nursing Home Spirals Out of Control as 45 Die
abstract: The outbreak in Richmond has become the deadliest linked so far to a U.S. long-term care facility.
lead_paragraph: Even before a single resident tested positive for the coronavirus at a nursing home in Richmond, Va., staff members were worried. Triple rooms were not uncommon. Supplies were hard to come by. And there were not enough nurses for all the aging patients inside.

headline: Everyone Wants an Antibody Test. Everyone on This Private Island Can Get One.
abstract: The tests show whether someone has been exposed to the coronavirus. They’re being provided to everyone in an exclusive Florida community that was able to pay for them.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Things are different in Fisher Island, the exclusive enclave off Miami Beach that is one of the wealthiest places in America. No uninvited outsiders are allowed in. Entrance is permitted only by boat.

headline: Governors, Coronavirus, Llamas: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Valencia Took Swift Action on Coronavirus, Then Took a Lot of Heat
abstract: The Spanish soccer club pared back team activities well before authorities in Spain banned mass gatherings, and faced much criticism for it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anil Murthy had already been facing a barrage of criticism. But as a former diplomat for Singapore, Murthy, the president of Valencia, a top soccer team in Spain, was ready for most of the barbs directed his way for imposing restrictions on access to the club’s players.

headline: Some European Nations Ease Pandemic Rules, but Move Warily
abstract: The lifting of restrictions is an early test of whether democracies can restart their economies and restore basic freedoms without refueling the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Slowly, tentatively, a handful of European countries began lifting constraints on daily life this week for the first time since the start of the coronavirus crisis, providing an early litmus test of whether Western democracies can gingerly restart their economies and restore basic freedoms without reviving the spread of the disease.

headline: Crippled Airline Industry to Get $25 Billion Bailout, Part of It as Loans
abstract: Airlines will receive billions of dollars in grants and loans to pay flight attendants, pilots and other employees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has reached an agreement in principle with major airlines over the terms of a $25 billion bailout to prop up an industry hobbled by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Justice Dept. Voices Support for Church’s Drive-in Services Despite Virus Orders
abstract: Attorney General William Barr said in a statement on Tuesday that “even in times of emergency,” the First Amendment prohibits religious discrimination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department lent its support on Tuesday to a Mississippi church that was penalized for holding drive-in services in defiance of a local order to slow the spread of the coronavirus and said that the order was applied unevenly and infringed on the congregants’ First Amendment rights.

headline: Democratic Victory in Wisconsin Looms as ‘Clarion Call’ for Trump
abstract: There were worrisome signs for the president in a State Supreme Court race in a key battleground state, but also a few cautionary signals for Democrats looking to seize on the result as a glimmer of good news.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The surprise defeat of a conservative justice in a statewide Wisconsin election — despite a show of support from President Trump — drove Republicans and Democrats back to their 2020 electoral playbooks on Tuesday, as both parties examined whether a surge of enthusiasm and on-the-ground organization among Democrats could help them capture that critical battleground state in November.

headline: Democrats Bet on Biden to Beat Trump. Then Came the Coronavirus.
abstract: The pandemic has upended the 2020 election. Can Joe Biden adapt?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: ‘Nobody Cares About the Little People’: Cruise Crews File Covid-19 Suit
abstract: Nearly 80,000 crew members are stranded on 100 cruise ships amid the coronavirus pandemic. Many passengers have been evacuated.
lead_paragraph: KEY WEST, Fla. — As governments around the world have grappled with how to rescue cruise ship passengers stuck on board luxury vessels hit with the coronavirus, another group has remained largely forgotten: the marooned crews.

headline: Franklin Graham Says He Is Being Harassed Over Central Park Hospital
abstract: The evangelical leader’s relief group has been criticized for requiring workers at its field hospital to say they oppose same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Franklin Graham on Tuesday accused elected officials and others in New York of harassment over their criticism of his medical organization, which is operating a field hospital in Central Park for coronavirus patients that requires workers to sign a pledge that they are Christians who oppose same-sex marriage.

headline: Look to Wisconsin for Lessons on a Digital Campaign During a Pandemic
abstract: “Democrats were organizing with every tool that didn’t require crossing the six-foot social distancing barrier,” the chair of the state Democratic Party said.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.

headline: The Seductive Appeal of Pandemic Shaming
abstract: I can’t control who gets sick or when we might return to something that looks like normal. But judging a random guy on the sidewalk? That I can do.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The guy across the street coughed wetly into the air, ignoring both his elbow and his hand. He hawked loudly, spat on the sidewalk, and strolled away.

headline: Post-Pandemic, Here’s How America Rises Again
abstract: Congress needs to invest with an eye on the nation’s future.
lead_paragraph: Hopefully, when Congress gets done allocating several trillion dollars simply to keep the economy afloat, we will be able to have another discussion: What should we invest in so we don’t just burden young Americans with a mountain of new debt, but also arm them with the tools to grow out of it and still prosper in the 21st century?

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Scientists are trying to understand why California’s mitigation efforts were so successful at flattening the curve.
lead_paragraph: California could have been a catastrophe. It had some of the country’s first coronavirus cases, and its extensive ties to China — 150,000 people flew in from there in January alone — made it appear highly vulnerable.

headline: U.S. Governors, at Center of Virus Response, Weigh What It Will Take to Reopen States
abstract: Many governors say science will guide when they will allow a reopening, a choice they say belongs to them. “Normal it will not be,” Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In Oregon, Gov. Kate Brown said the move toward reopening her state would be a cautious and incremental one, guided by data on transmission of the coronavirus, availability of personal protective equipment and testing capacity, among other factors.

headline: Amy Klobuchar: The Right Way to Vote This November
abstract: If voting by mail is good enough for President Trump, it’s good enough for all Americans.
lead_paragraph: In a democracy, no one should be forced to choose between health and the right to vote.

headline: Sidelined by Coronavirus, Congressional Leaders Face Pressure to Vote Remotely
abstract: Rank-and-file lawmakers, scholars and good government groups say it is time for Congress to allow remote voting and virtual legislating.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Congress sidelined by the coronavirus pandemic and unable to return to the Capitol, House and Senate leaders are under increasing pressure from a bipartisan array of current and former lawmakers to shift to remote legislating, including using a secure online system to conduct votes.

headline: Trump’s Claim of Total Authority in Crisis Is Rejected Across Ideological Lines
abstract: Trading barbs with governors about their powers over when to ease restrictions on society, the president made an assertion that lacks a basis in the Constitution or federal law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s claim that he wielded “total” authority in the pandemic crisis prompted rebellion not just from governors. Legal scholars across the ideological spectrum on Tuesday rejected his declaration that ultimately he, not state leaders, will decide when to risk lifting social distancing limits in order to reopen businesses.

headline: Criticized for Pandemic Response, Trump Tries Shifting Blame to the W.H.O.
abstract: The president said he would halt funding for the organization because it caused “so much death” in the way it “pushed Chinese misinformation,” though he himself effusively praised China’s handling of the virus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For weeks, President Trump has faced relentless criticism for having overseen a slow and ineffective response to the coronavirus pandemic, failing to quickly embrace public health measures that could have prevented the disease from spreading.

headline: What’s an Essential Service in a Pandemic? The Post Office
abstract: From the census to the November election, the Postal Service is critical to American democracy.
lead_paragraph: America’s favorite government agency is on the brink of collapse, and Washington policymakers appear too mired in politics to save it.

headline: Hank Steinbrenner, the Yankees Owner Who Kept a Guitar in His Office
abstract: After George Steinbrenner’s older son died on Tuesday, people in baseball remembered him as a free-spirited character who once stepped aside from the Yankees to run the family’s horse farm.
lead_paragraph: In his 37 imperious years as the Yankees’ principal owner, George Steinbrenner regularly held meetings with the team’s brain trust at Malio’s, a steakhouse in Tampa, Fla., where Steinbrenner had a home and eventually set up the club’s spring training site. Team executives and scouts — as well as Steinbrenner’s sons, Hank and Hal — would scrutinize the roster, player by player, point by point. The gatherings were long. They were sometimes contentious.

headline: Masks of the Upper West Side
abstract: The various masks of the Upper West Side
lead_paragraph: We only go out with a purpose now, and with some apprehension.

headline: Mythical Beast
abstract: John-Clark Levin makes his New York Times Crossword debut, ably assisted by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When you are given instructions in a crossword puzzle, it’s very important to follow them. Or at least to heed them. Heeding might even be more important than following, in fact.

headline: C.D.C. Says More Than 9,000 Health Care Workers Have Contracted Coronavirus
abstract: The agency says the number is likely to grow as more information about patients’ occupational status is made available.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Tuesday that 9,282 health care professionals had contracted the coronavirus in the United States as of April 9 and that 27 had died from it.

headline: Trump Announces His ‘Opening the Country’ Council
abstract: He read off dozens of prominent names from Wall Street, Silicon Valley and the sports world. At least one person on the list was surprised to be on it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump stood in the Rose Garden on Tuesday evening and recited a list of dozens of prominent business and labor leaders who he said would be advising him in deciding when and how to reopen the country’s economy, even as governors made it clear they will make those decisions themselves.

headline: Getting a Stimulus Check? Trump’s Name Will Be on It
abstract: The decision to have President Trump’s name appear on the checks is a break in protocol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s name will appear on the economic stimulus checks that will be mailed to millions of Americans in the coming weeks, the Treasury Department confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In a Rising Food Crisis, Drawing On Survival Skills
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 15, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “You’re forced to stay in a specific area, you’re told to trust the government, you’re told food will be scarce — welcome to 1700s Native nation.”

headline: Corrections: April 15, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 15, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a liberal candidate’s upset victory over a conservative  incumbent endorsed by President Trump in the Wisconsin Supreme Court race referred incorrectly to the elections in Wisconsin won by a margin of about 30,000 votes or fewer. The most recent contests for president, governor and the State Supreme Court had such margins, not all races in the last four years.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Coronavirus, Britain’s death toll, W.H.O.: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The global economy is expected to contract by 3 percent this year because of economic damage from the coronavirus pandemic — the worst downturn since the Great Depression, the International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday.

headline: Worldwide Confirmed Coronavirus Cases Top 2 Million
abstract: As bleak a milestone in the pandemic as the new figures are, unconfirmed cases are believed to be far higher. More than 130,000 people have died from Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic passed 2 million confirmed infections and 130,000 deaths worldwide on Wednesday — bleak markers that experts say vastly understate the true spread and toll of the contagion because of a lack of testing.

headline: Bleak Data Shows Extent of Economic Damage
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: M.L.B. Employees Become the Subjects of a Huge Coronavirus Study
abstract: The testing, which will screen for antibodies in workers, is intended to provide a better understanding of how many people in various parts of America have been infected.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball employees, from players to stadium workers to executives, are participating this week in a 10,000-person study aimed at understanding how many people in various parts of the United States have been infected with the coronavirus.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Mrs. America’ and ‘The Main Event’
abstract: Cate Blanchett stars in a new mini-series on Hulu. And a family comedy on Netflix centers on an 11-year-old wrestler.
lead_paragraph: MRS. AMERICA Stream on FX on Hulu. Cate Blanchett plays the conservative activist Phyllis Schlafly in this new mini-series, which revisits the fights for and against the Equal Rights Amendment in the 1970s. On the “against” side is Schlafly, a self-described housewife who spent the decade campaigning against the E.R.A., which would have amended the Constitution to legally codify equality between women and men. Fighting her on the “for” side are a cadre of figures from the left, including Gloria Steinem (Rose Byrne), Shirley Chisholm (Uzo Aduba), Betty Friedan (Tracey Ullman) and Bella Abzug (Margo Martindale). The show tells stories from both sides, as it chronicles events leading up to the defeat of the E.R.A. — a defeat, led by Schlafly, that had lasting effects. “Love her or hate her, you cannot not take away that she was extraordinary,” the series’s creator, Dahvi Waller, a former “Mad Men” writer, said in a recent interview with The New York Times. “And if you find yourself rooting for her and hate yourself for it, that’s also fun.”

headline: Word + Quiz: gloaming
abstract: This word has appeared in 17 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Michael Angel Bastiaans, Beloved Indonesian Teacher, Dies at 31
abstract: He was the kind of teacher who gave his lunch to a hungry student and dug into his own pocket to help others in need.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Trump’s Coronavirus Briefings Are His ‘Little Rallies,’ Colbert Says
abstract: Stephen Colbert compared the president to a fireman doing “a one-man show about how it’s not my fault that your house is burning down.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Dinosaurs
abstract: What story does this image inspire for you?
lead_paragraph: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: Doping Tests Go Virtual. Is It Temporary or a Glimpse of the Future?
abstract: The antidoping officials who collect urine and blood samples from athletes can’t work as they usually do during the coronavirus pandemic. In the United States, the testers are trying to take their work online.
lead_paragraph: Antidoping experts had already been kicking around ideas about testing athletes without having to bang on their front doors at dawn or dinnertime.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Katharine, the Great White Shark Who Ghosted Her Trackers, Resurfaces’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about shark behavior and research — and consider why social media accounts for sea creatures may contribute to scientific research.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Katharine, the Great White Shark Who Ghosted Her Trackers, Resurfaces” by Christopher Mele

headline: Feminism Means a Lot of Things, and This Book Contains Them All
abstract: The anthology “Burn It Down!,” edited by Breanne Fahs, collects manifestos from a range of perspectives and voices.
lead_paragraph: Reading “Burn It Down!,” an anthology of feminist manifestos edited by Breanne Fahs, I couldn’t decide whether the book amounted to a celebration or an elegy. In her learned and impassioned introduction, Fahs starts out by enumerating a litany of feminist accomplishments only to pair most of them with their backlash. Federally supported family leave? Typically unpaid. Women’s studies programs? They exist, but they’re dwindling. Abortion access may have expanded worldwide; in the United States, though, it’s in jeopardy.

headline: Animals Are Rewilding Our Cities. On YouTube, at Least.
abstract: The videos of deer and elephants, whether or not they’re real, speak to a budding hope: that the pandemic might change society, and us, for the better.
lead_paragraph: At the end of March I was, like many people, spending hours each day on the internet, my attention glued to graphs of projected deaths, maps of infection hot spots, photos of masked travelers huddled in subway cars. But then new images appeared, and they were quite unlike the others. Here were maps showing improvements in air quality, photographs of deserted streets and squares bathed in sunlight and, most surprising, videos of wild animals thriving in newly deserted towns and cities.

headline: What Cancer Has Taught Me About Fear
abstract: Cancer patients deal daily with dread stirred by organisms produced by the body they attack.
lead_paragraph: Sequestered during the pandemic, I find myself thinking that cancer patients’ expertise in fear can help others heed its warnings. We all need tactics not only to overcome the destructive capacity of fear but also to tap its protective potential.

headline: Have No Fear, Sugar Is Here (Again)
abstract: Cheryl Strayed has revived her Sugar persona in a new podcast, “Sugar Calling,” which calls on authors for wisdom.
