lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Overweight at 4? Beware of Broken Bones
abstract: Overweight preschoolers had higher rates of broken arms and legs in childhood.
lead_paragraph: Obesity in preschoolers may be linked to bone fractures in childhood, scientists report.

headline: For Runners, Is 15 Feet the New 6 Feet for Social Distancing?
abstract: When we walk briskly or run, air moves differently around us, increasing the space required to maintain a proper social distance.
lead_paragraph: It may be a good idea to give one another more than six feet of space while exercising outside during the current coronavirus pandemic, according to a compelling new study that looked at how air flows around bodies in motion. The study has not yet been published in a peer-reviewed journal and the results need further confirmation. But they indicate that runners and brisk walkers may create a wake of air behind them that could carry exhaled respiratory droplets for 15 feet or more, meaning that the droplets could reach people walking or jogging well behind them.

headline: Give Yourself a Buzz Cut Now
abstract: Yes, you can use beard clippers. Yes, you will make a mess. Yes, it will grow back. And yes, you can use this to cut someone else’s hair.
lead_paragraph: How can you give yourself a buzz cut? Here, let us show you.

headline: Living Longer, and Better
abstract: Don’t smoke. Maintain a healthy weight. Exercise regularly. Use alcohol in moderation.
lead_paragraph: Everyone has heard the advice: Don’t smoke. Maintain a healthy weight. Exercise regularly. Use alcohol in moderation.

headline: How Will Covid-19 Affect Future Travel Behavior? A Travel Crisis Expert Explains
abstract: A conversation with Lori Pennington-Gray, director of the Tourism Crisis Management Initiative at the University of Florida, about travel anxiety in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Since 2007, the Tourism Crisis Management Initiative at the University of Florida has studied many disasters that have threatened the travel industry, from hurricanes to the Zika virus. Beginning in January, prompted by the coronavirus-related threat in China, it began a periodic survey of Americans who travel on their perceptions of risk and anxiety related to Covid-19, and the impact of those perceptions on future travel decisions. In the latest survey, taken by 517 respondents in the first week of April, about 74 percent reported feeling anxious about travel within the United States, up nearly 300 percent since the survey project began.

headline: Will the Coronavirus Delay My Cancer Surgery?
abstract: The threat of infection is forcing doctors to postpone operations or suggest other treatments.
lead_paragraph: After anxious weeks since learning that he had cancer, a man prepares for an operation that he hopes will give him a longer life. Then, days before, his surgeon tells him that plans have changed. His surgery will be put off because of concerns about the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: When Life Gives You Quarantine, Plant Potatoes
abstract: The pandemic separated my family from our neighbors. Could a network of backyard gardens bring us together?
lead_paragraph: Luke Ackroyd wandered his family’s backyard Sunday morning, surveying an expanding vegetable garden. Before him were rising arugula sprouts and the stiff green spikes of young onion plants.

headline: ‘Woe Is You,’ White People Say. What We Need Is a Remedy.
abstract: Think about why the virus is poised to rip through black neighborhoods like mine.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The 12-hour drive to Detroit is always a chore, but on the last day of March, the pandemic gave a sinister hue to even the most banal elements of a Midwest road trip. Every time we used a bathroom, grabbed a gas pump or bought a snack was an opportunity to get infected. Making things worse, Detroit was seeing an explosion of coronavirus cases.

headline: Surveillance Won’t Stop the Coronavirus
abstract: Access to adequate health care, including protective equipment and sufficient testing, will do more good than another hackathon.
lead_paragraph: In the Moria refugee camp in Greece, one tap is shared among 1,300 people. Social distancing is difficult to do. Refugee communities from Kenya to Bangladesh, Lebanon and Syria are vulnerable to the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Think This Pandemic Is Bad? We Have Another Crisis Coming
abstract: Addressing climate change is a big enough idea to revive the economy.
lead_paragraph: On the last Friday in March, I lost hope.

headline: The Heartbreaking Last Texts of a Hospital Worker on the Front Lines
abstract: Madhvi Aya worked long hours in the emergency room of a hospital in Brooklyn that was battered by the coronavirus. Then she caught the virus herself.
lead_paragraph: Lying in a hospital bed last month, Madhvi Aya understood what was happening to her.

headline: 7 Podcasts for Stir-Crazy Kids
abstract: If you’re searching for alternatives to TV and computer games for children stuck at home, these shows will entertain — and even educate.
lead_paragraph: The debate over how much screen time is healthy for children has been effectively obliterated by the coronavirus crisis. But if you’re seeking an alternative, look to podcasts.

headline: I Helped New York Rebound From 9/11. Here’s How to Recover After the Pandemic.
abstract: Use this crisis to build a more inclusive and sustainable city.
lead_paragraph: Just a few months after the Sept. 11 attack, I joined the office of Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York as deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, responsible for the city’s economic recovery. The predictions were dire. The New York Times warned of a return to the tough times of the 1970s, when austerity, crime and poverty led to a “plummet in the quality of life so sharp that people fled town.”

headline: The Virus Revealed Our Essential Tech (and Weeded Out the Excess)
abstract: A computer with a good internet connection, communication apps and entertainment are the only tech we really need, ever.
lead_paragraph: It has been weeks since the coronavirus brought our lives to a halt, shutting down our schools, offices and gyms. Stuck at home, we have had nothing but time to reflect on the things that matter.

headline: Trump Wanted a Radio Show, but He Didn’t Want to Compete With Limbaugh
abstract: President Trump said he envisioned a show running two hours a day, according to White House officials, and would do it were it not for the risk of encroaching on Rush Limbaugh, the conservative host.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday in early March, Donald J. Trump, clad in a baseball cap, strode into the Situation Room for a meeting with the coronavirus task force. He didn’t stop by the group’s daily meetings often, but he had an idea he was eager to share: He wanted to start a White House talk radio show.

headline: My Isolation Breaking Point
abstract: I can’t wait for social distancing to end, so I can be alone again.
lead_paragraph: In this endless war against Covid-19, I have tried to be a dutiful soldier. I’ve mostly stayed home to binge-watch and binge-eat (bad news and Fig Newtons, respectively). I’ve yet to poleax any octogenarians as they dive-tackle the last pack of Cottonelle. I only sneeze on immediate family. I’m a regular Audie Murphy.

headline: How the Government Pulls Coronavirus Relief Money Out of Thin Air
abstract: Once-fringe ideas in economic theory are now nearly official policy as government borrowing surges and the Federal Reserve signals it could buy unlimited debt.
lead_paragraph: The United States has responded to the economic havoc wrought by the coronavirus with the biggest relief package in its history: $2 trillion. It essentially replaces a few months of American economic activity with a flood of government money — every penny of it borrowed.

headline: How the World’s Squarest Fish Gets Around
abstract: The yellow boxfish is much more agile than it looks.
lead_paragraph: The yellow boxfish doesn’t look nimble. Squat and rectangular, it resembles a plastic storage bin with fins. Even its coloring suggests clumsiness — juveniles are hard hat yellow with black spots, as if to say “coming through!”

headline: Reese Witherspoon’s Fashion Line Offered Free Dresses to Teachers. They Didn’t Mean Every Teacher.
abstract: Draper James had a well-intentioned giveaway. But it went very wrong.
lead_paragraph: In mid-March, just around the time that American schools and offices started closing because of the coronavirus pandemic, not that long before numerous designers had suddenly become heroes for volunteering their services to hand-sew masks so that surgical-grade ones could go to those who needed them most, the staff at Draper James, Reese Witherspoon’s fashion label, started talking about doing something for teachers.

headline: Seeking New Businesses and Better Lives, Investors on the Coasts Move Inland
abstract: A wave of venture capitalists is heading to quieter, less-expensive locales, where they are helping fund start-ups.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.

headline: After Coronavirus, Colleges Worry: Will Students Come Back?
abstract: The pandemic has already cost universities millions of dollars. As they consider the possibility of remote classes into the fall, they’re worried about losing students, too.
lead_paragraph: For years, Claire McCarville dreamed of going to college in New York or Los Angeles, and was thrilled last month to get accepted to selective schools in both places. But earlier this month, she sent a $300 deposit to Arizona State University, a 15-minute drive from her home in Phoenix. “It made more sense,” she said, “in light of the virus.”

headline: Living In ... NoHo, Manhattan
abstract: A once-forgotten part of the city, this neighborhood north of Houston Street now has a vibrant retail and cultural scene — and some of the priciest housing.
lead_paragraph: A once-forgotten part of the city, this neighborhood north of Houston Street now has a vibrant retail and cultural scene — and some of the priciest housing.

headline: Shoulder-to-Shoulder, These Detroit Workers Have No Choice but to Ride the Bus
abstract: Some people can do their best to socially distance. But there’s no distance on a city bus full of people who, virus or no virus, have to get to work.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Paris Banks sprayed the seat with Lysol before sliding into the last row on the right. Rochell Brown put out her cigarette, tucked herself behind the steering wheel and slapped the doors shut.

headline: I Harvest Your Food. Why Isn’t My Health ‘Essential’?
abstract: We sacrifice so much for a country that doesn’t value our lives.
lead_paragraph: I am one of the thousands of farmworkers across the country making sure there is still food to put on your tables. Since I came to New York from Guatemala 11 years ago, I have cleaned cabbage in a packing shed, milked cows on dairy farms, trimmed apple trees in orchards and wrapped and pruned tomatoes in a greenhouse.

headline: Trump Has a Gut Feeling About What Covid-19 Means for 2020
abstract: It’s not too soon to wonder whether he’s on to something.
lead_paragraph: Evidence of President Trump’s mishandling of the current Covid-19 emergency has been building steadily. Most recently, The Washington Post on April 4 (“The U.S. was beset by denial and dysfunction as the coronavirus raged”) and The Times on April 11 (“He Could Have Seen What Was Coming: Behind Trump’s Failure on the Virus”) have put together a carefully constructed case against the administration.

headline: States Are in a Quandary as Taxes Evaporate and Virus Spending Soars
abstract: With businesses closed and obligations mounting, state governments are looking at a mix of remedies.
lead_paragraph: The ballooning costs of the coronavirus pandemic have put an unexpected strain on the finances of states, which are hurriedly diverting funds from elsewhere to fight the outbreak even as the economic shutdown squeezes their main source of revenue — taxes.

headline: Treating Coronavirus in a Central Park ‘Hot Zone’
abstract: They’ve set up field hospitals in wartime, after natural disasters and during disease outbreaks overseas. But this is a first.
lead_paragraph: Rubber boots hung from a tree of wooden pegs in soggy Central Park after being sterilized with chlorine. Workers observed a one-way flow into and out of what they referred to as “the hot zone” of patient treatment tents. Step by step, they removed their isolation suits in a designated area, as a monitor barked instructions.

headline: NoHo, Manhattan: A Place to ‘Live and Work and Create’
abstract: A once-forgotten part of the city, the neighborhood north of Houston Street now has a vibrant retail and cultural scene — and some of the priciest housing.
lead_paragraph: Ara Fitzgerald moved into a spacious apartment in NoHo in 1971, when the area north of Houston Street did not yet have that name and was considered dangerous territory.

headline: Testing Is Biggest Obstacle to Reopening States, Experts Say
abstract: Health, business and political leaders warn against a rush to lift restrictions. New Yorkers will have to wear face coverings in public, and California will extend aid to undocumented workers.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A Visual Trek Through the Sweltering Jungle: In Search of Colombia’s ‘Lost City’
abstract: Ciudad Perdida, an ancient city that predates Machu Picchu by several hundred years, has become one of South America’s most rewarding adventure destinations.
lead_paragraph: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’re turning to photojournalists who can help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. We’re calling this new series “The World Through a Lens.” This week, Stephen Hiltner, an editor on the Travel desk, invites you to join him on an arduous multiday hike to an archaeological site in Colombia.

headline: Rockefeller Center’s Art Deco Marvel: A Virtual Tour
abstract: When the complex opened in the 1930s, some mocked it. Now it’s a symbol of New York’s glory. Our critic chats with the historian Daniel Okrent.
lead_paragraph: With New Yorkers self-quarantining, Rockefeller Center conjures up the promise of life returning to normal someday and the unshakable glory of the city. It was New York’s Depression-era version of building the pyramids. When it opened during the 1930s, the critic Lewis Mumford heaped abuse on it, then seemed to forget that he had ever said anything bad after it became a beloved emblem of Art Deco-era Manhattan and a Midtown magnet.

headline: Coronavirus, World Health Organization, Retail Sales: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What Are the Songs That Are Helping You Survive?
abstract: A journal of the Plague Year: Week 5.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE LAKES, Maine — The pink moon shines down. Through the window I can see its reflection on the lake.

headline: N.Y.C.’s Death Toll Soars After Unconfirmed Cases Are Added
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has insisted on being above politics in the  outbreak, but he battled President Trump over who had the authority to reopen public life.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: What’s the Point of a Birthday Party Anyway?
abstract: Here are some ways people are solving birthdays in the age of coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode of “Together Apart,” there’s actually a lot of talk about tunnels and lights. How does this relate to celebrating a birthday right now?

headline: How to Celebrate a Birthday Now
abstract: The birthday party as we knew it is over. Here’s how to have a birthday gathering.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re turning 12, 42 or 92, inviting people to come together in a unique, specific way to celebrate your birth is actually a form of meaning-making for everyone else. Birthday celebrations, when designed well, are an opportunity to express love, to mark life and to ask people to do something adventurous. Your birthday is an excuse to elevate a day, not just for you but for everybody else. So let’s do it. Let’s have a birthday.

headline: 24 Hours Inside a Brooklyn Hospital
abstract: What “disaster mode” looks like on the front lines of the crisis.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Who Made My Puzzle?
abstract: This month’s constructor spotlight shines on Sande Milton.
lead_paragraph: Tallahassee, Fla.

headline: Is That Free Book Germ-Free?
abstract: The coronavirus has nearly eliminated the boxes of free discards that usually sprinkle Brooklyn stoops as people start their spring cleaning.
lead_paragraph: Every year, as the weather warms and New Yorkers get on with their spring cleaning, the stoops and sidewalks of the city fill with free piles — one of the true delights of living in a city of pedestrians and small apartments.

headline: As Online Buying Surges, So Do Noisy Cargo Flights
abstract: Cargo capacity has been expanding at some airports, disturbing the peace and routines of people who live nearby. Official channels offer scant recourse.
lead_paragraph: The last time Congress approved legislation dealing with airport noise complaints was 30 years ago, when the biggest concern was older, inefficient planes.

headline: You Can’t Visit the Museum. But Your Robot Can.
abstract: With arts institutions closed around the world, Hastings Contemporary museum in England is offering virtual tours using a telepresence robot.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a recent weekday morning, a robot was investigating the art on display at the Hastings Contemporary art museum.

headline: On Politics: Obama’s Back
abstract: A presidential endorsement and a Democratic messaging theme: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump spoke before reporters and officials practicing social distancing at the daily coronavirus briefing in the Rose Garden of the White House on Tuesday.

headline: Virus Is Costing N.Y.C. Billions
abstract: Mayor de Blasio said the city faces a revenue shortfall of up to $10 billion.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Thursday’s live coverage.]

headline: Who Tells Trump When to Restart the Economy
abstract: The president will take advice on reopening the economy from “Great American Economic Revival Industry Groups.” Some notable names are absent.
lead_paragraph: Tom Friedman, Times Opinion columnist, will join us on our next DealBook Debrief call, tomorrow at 11 a.m. Eastern. He will discuss his plan for making the American economy more resilient after the pandemic — make sure to read his latest column about it — and take your questions. For information about how to join this and future DealBook calls, sign up here. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: How to Avoid Burnout When You Have Little Ones
abstract: The burnout you feel as a parent and the burnout you feel at work are two separate phenomena with similar symptoms.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization added workplace burnout as an “occupational phenomenon” in the most recent edition of the International Classification of Diseases handbook. Read about identifying and easing burnout below.

headline: Fighting Constantly After Baby? Read This
abstract: Most research suggests that couples are less happy after they become parents, but there are ways to reorient your relationship after parenthood.
lead_paragraph: The lowest point of my marriage was probably when I was excessively pregnant with our second daughter. It was 90 degrees outside every day, and I had blown past my due date with no signs of labor. I had trouble falling asleep but had finally drifted off one night when my husband came home from a work event and woke me up. I had a brief and fleeting desire to bludgeon him with a bedside lamp.

headline: How to Ditch the Pacifier
abstract: Breaking the habit won’t be fun for anyone. But following a few tips — starting with keeping calm and consistent — will make the process smoother.
lead_paragraph: Binky, soother, paci, dummy — a pacifier has many names, but one purpose: comfort. The act of sucking seems to have powerful biological effects in babies: There’s evidence that pacifiers can reduce the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), shorten the length of a preemie’s stay in the neonatal intensive care unit, and even help to relieve pain during medical procedures. But at some point, your child has to give it up. After all, no one goes to high school with a binky.

headline: Is Your Child a Digital Addict? Here’s What You Can Do
abstract: It can be hard for children to move on from screen time, but it doesn’t always have to be a battle.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Aug. 6, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: 7 Fertility Myths That Belong in the Past
abstract: No, lying flat after sex won’t increase your chances of conception.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Nov. 14, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: An L.G.B.T.Q. Pregnancy, From D.I.Y. to I.V.F.
abstract: Our absurd, occasionally maddening, and ultimately successful path to parenthood.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Dec. 11, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Black Women Are Hit Hardest by Fibroid Tumors
abstract: And experts don’t know why.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Jan. 16, 2020 in NYT Parenting.

headline: What Should I Do with My Unused Embryos?
abstract: My husband and I have three fertilized eggs on ice, and we’re paralyzed.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Nov. 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: I Don’t Regret Podcasting About My Infertility
abstract: Talking through the pain of I.V.F. with an audience eased my sense of isolation.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Dec. 2, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: How to Teach Children About Healthy Eating, Without Food Shaming
abstract: Even the most well-meaning comments can have a big impact on a child’s body image and long-term relationship with food.
lead_paragraph: Caitlyn Hitt grew up in a household with “food issues,” where her family frequently talked about weight and dieting. She was urged not to eat certain foods because of how they might impact her appearance, she said, and had diets pushed on her at a young age. Hitt said that the experience gave her a complex about her weight and made her see certain foods as bad.

headline: How to Support Your Shy Kid
abstract: So she can embrace her strengths and emerge from her shell the healthy way.
lead_paragraph: Last July, I took my 5-year-old to her best friend’s birthday party. There was an entertainer, booming music and 20 dancing kindergarteners — and then there was my daughter, cowering behind a plant in the corner of the back room, terrified.

headline: How to Deal With Your Kid’s Annoying Habits
abstract: You might want to nag or scold, but positive reinforcement is more effective.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Nov. 1, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Obama Pivots Left
abstract: ‘The world is different.’
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: ‘Will We Die Hungry?’ A Teeming Manila Slum Chafes Under Lockdown
abstract: Life was already a struggle in the crowded shanties of San Roque. Then came the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Even before the coronavirus arrived in Manila, a saying in the capital’s sprawling San Roque slum — “no one dies from a fever” — crystallized the many threats that its residents faced in their daily lives.

headline: ‘Pretty Catastrophic’ Month for Retailers, and Now a Race to Survive
abstract: March brought a record sales plunge as the coronavirus outbreak closed stores. A long shutdown could leave lasting changes in the shopping landscape.
lead_paragraph: Retail sales plunged in March, offering a grim snapshot of the coronavirus outbreak’s effect on consumer spending, as businesses shuttered from coast to coast and wary shoppers restricted their spending.

headline: ‘Butt Boy’ Review: Compulsion as Comic Noir
abstract: A search for missing children leads to a man with a strange impulse in this wildly polarizing film.
lead_paragraph: To endorse a movie titled “Butt Boy” is to commit to its lunacy — and, dare I say, cheek — as fully as its makers. And maybe it’s the hell we’re all living through right now, but Tyler Cornack’s orificial fantasy struck me as a hilariously bawdy, intermittently inspired act of vivacious vulgarity.

headline: What You Get for $1.5 Million
abstract: A vintage clapboard house in Miami; a midcentury-modernist ranch in Highland Park, Ill.; and a 1959 beach house in Marin County, Calif.
lead_paragraph: A vintage clapboard house in Miami; a midcentury-modernist ranch in Highland Park, Ill.; and a 1959 beach house in Marin County, Calif.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in Florida, Illinois and California
abstract: A vintage clapboard house in Miami, a midcentury-modernist ranch in Highland Park and a 1959 beach house in Marin County.
lead_paragraph: This vintage property in Coconut Grove has been substantially remodeled. It is a half-mile southwest of the Kampong National Tropical Botanical Garden and two and a half miles southwest of the neighborhood’s business district, with its waterfront parks, raw bars, boutiques and luxury hotels. The house is five and a half miles southwest of downtown Miami. The analytical website FloodIQ rates this property at high risk of flooding from any category of hurricane and at minimal risk from tidal floods; it projects the risk of tidal flooding by 2033 as low.

headline: Newsom: ‘We’re Not Out of The Woods Yet’
abstract: Wednesday: Public health officials set a six-part framework for deciding how to slowly reopen the economy. Also: A dispatch from the U.S.N.S. Mercy.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Endorses Joe Biden: ‘When You Disagree, He’ll Listen’
abstract: She became the most high-profile progressive woman in the Democratic Party to expand the former vice president’s appeal among liberal voters.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday, becoming the most high-profile progressive woman in the party to try to help the former vice president expand his appeal among liberal voters.

headline: Why Is My Big Kid Acting Like a Toddler?
abstract: Regressions are normal during stressful events. Here’s how to identify and deal with them.
lead_paragraph: As we enter our second month of social distancing in the United States, I’m hearing reports from friends, readers and my own household about the different ways we fear our kids are regressing. There’s backsliding on potty use, and more tantrums. Bedtime is really going off the rails. So I wanted to ask the experts: Why is this happening, and can we do anything to help our children?

headline: Analysis: Will Pandemic Make Trump Rethink National Security?
abstract: The Cuban Missile Crisis forced Kennedy to begin an era of arms control, and Sept. 11 forced Bush to reinvent counterterrorism. Will the coronavirus change the priorities of the Trump administration?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump insists that choosing when to reopen the economy is “the biggest decision I’ve ever had to make,” and, in the short term, he is undoubtedly right. It is a perilous balance of public safety versus economic revival that would test any president, even one not consumed by a looming election.

headline: Should We All Be Able to Vote by Mail?
abstract: Faced with the coronavirus pandemic, many are pushing for alternatives to in-person voting. Is that the right thing to do? Or will it compromise the integrity of elections?
lead_paragraph: In the April 7 article “Voting in Wisconsin During a Pandemic: Lines, Masks and Plenty of Fear,” Astead W. Herndon and Alexander Burns write:

headline: A Former Shophouse on Penang Island
abstract: This restored 19th-century shophouse in George Town, Malaysia, is on the market for $1.88 million.
lead_paragraph: This restored 19th-century shophouse in George Town, Malaysia, is on the market for $1.88 million.

headline: House Hunting in Malaysia: A Restored Rowhouse in Penang
abstract: Before the pandemic froze its housing market, the Southeast Asian nation was luring foreign investment with price incentives.
lead_paragraph: This refurbished, three-story house dating from the early 19th century stands among the Colonial buildings in the historic city center of George Town, the capital of the Malaysian state of Penang and the country’s third-largest city, with about 700,000 residents.

headline: How to Stop Your Child From Tormenting Your Pet
abstract: Teaching children to respect pets’ feelings and needs will help establish a safe environment for all.
lead_paragraph: It was an unfamiliar, acrid stink that tipped me off. Each time I passed within a few feet of our gray tabby cat, Bumpus, the funk shocked my nostrils.

headline: Coronavirus Has Lifted Leaders Everywhere. Don’t Expect That to Last.
abstract: Popular support for nearly every head of government has risen during this crisis. History suggests harsh reckonings as the panic eases.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Emmanuel Macron, never very popular, has touched his highest approval ratings in France since the onset of the coronavirus. As Italy has been devastated, Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte has hit a remarkable 71 percent, up 27 points. Even in Britain, where Prime Minister Boris Johnson waffled over a strong response, then became seriously ill himself, the government is the most popular in decades.

headline: This Artist Proposes a Community Space ‘to Dream, to Imagine’
abstract: The poet and performance artist Jaamil Olawale Kosoko has reimagined his work “Chameleon” as a daylong virtual experience, “a global gesture in listening.”
lead_paragraph: Since New York theaters shut down in mid-March, creators of live performance have been quick to adjust: improvising on Instagram, reimagining dances for Zoom, uploading their archives to Vimeo.

headline: What We Know About the N.B.A., and What We Don’t
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein outlines six things to know about the suspended N.B.A. season and discusses ways the league can honor David Stern.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: More Colleges Are Waiving SAT and ACT Requirements
abstract: With high school disrupted, a growing number of schools — including Harvard and Cornell — are waiving standardized testing requirements for 2021 applicants.
lead_paragraph: They are a rite of passage as well as anxiety-inducing letters for millions of students: the SAT and ACT.

headline: Warren Releases Video Endorsing Biden
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren endorsed her one-time rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., for president, praising his decades in public service.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren endorsed her one-time rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., for president, praising his decades in public service.

headline: Six Tips for Listening to Original Cast Recordings
abstract: To begin with, don’t call them soundtracks!
lead_paragraph: Since you can’t attend any live performances at the moment, you have lots of hours to fill with show tunes. But before you combine the Polish recording of “Les Miz” on your playlist with the sad 2010 revival cast album of “A Little Night Music” and cherry-picked highlights from some random “Porgy and Bess,” please heed a few idiosyncratic words of advice from lifelong listeners on how best to make your way through our desert island cast recording lists.

headline: Want to Listen to Musical Cast Albums? Our Top 10 Desert Island Picks
abstract: What we plan to listen to in perpetuity (or right now) in our Spotify-enabled isolation.
lead_paragraph: After more than a month of quarantine culture, most of us have some sense of what being on a desert island feels like. So we’ve had plenty of time to consider what we’d like to hear in our infinite leisure, beyond the roar of the surf. It is, in fact, just what we’ve been listening to, with gratitude, during these many weeks. If you’re like us, you may have compiled your own lists already. See how they stack up against the 20 albums we’ve chosen.

headline: What Is the Sound of a Theater Season Interrupted?
abstract: A listening guide to the cast albums, playlists and video footprints left behind by 18 Broadway and Off Broadway musicals.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen musicals were scheduled to open during the 2019-20 Broadway season. Only seven did, and of those only a few released more-or-less traditional cast albums. But that doesn’t mean there isn’t plenty to listen to — including some Off Broadway highlights. Here’s what’s out there.

headline: Cooking With Condiments
abstract: Find inspiration in those jars of chile crisp or peanut butter, that bottle of ketchup or mirin.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I find it’s the condiments keeping me humming along in the kitchen these days, shortcuts to complexity, a way to bolster flavor with stuff from a jar. I wrote about them for The Times this week in an ode to chile crisp, a Sichuanese concoction that marries fire to texture with incredible results.

headline: Wildlife Collapse From Climate Change Is Predicted to Hit Suddenly and Sooner
abstract: Scientists found a “cliff edge” instead of the slippery slope they expected.
lead_paragraph: Climate change could result in a more abrupt collapse of many animal species than previously thought, starting in the next decade if greenhouse gas emissions are not reduced, according to a study published this month in Nature.

headline: Zoo May Feed Animals to Animals as Funds Dry Up in Pandemic
abstract: The zoo, in Germany, said its drastic plan would only be a last resort. One animal would be spared until the end, it said, a nearly 12-foot polar bear called Vitus.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The polar bear would be the last to go.

headline: What the W.H.O. Does, and How U.S. Funding Cuts Could Affect It
abstract: Though President Trump’s decision to halt funding centered on the W.H.O.’s response to the coronavirus, the cut could affect programs like polio eradication and developing vaccines.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s decision to halt funding for the World Health Organization, depriving it of its biggest funding source, could have far-reaching effects in efforts to fight diseases and make health care more widely available across the globe.

headline: Where the Very Rich Fly to Hide
abstract: Wyoming’s Jackson Hole has become a redoubt against the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A wall of jagged peaks rises nearly 14,000 feet, towering over the valley floor of Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming. Seeing it for the first time can literally be jaw-dropping as you fly into the valley of Jackson Hole, where private jets carrying wealthy passengers fleeing Covid-19 hot spots elsewhere have landed in recent weeks.

headline: Apple, in a Virtual Unveiling, Introduces a $399 iPhone
abstract: The new iPhone SE has the design of an older generation of iPhones, with the same computing power as newer ones.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In some ways, there couldn’t be a worse time than a pandemic to introduce a new gadget. But Apple unveiled its latest iPhone on Wednesday anyway, seizing on a time when many of us are sheltering indoors and glued to our devices.

headline: Why the Big Bang Produced Something Rather Than Nothing
abstract: How did matter gain the edge over antimatter in the early universe? Maybe, just maybe, neutrinos.
lead_paragraph: Scientists on Wednesday announced that they were perhaps one step closer to understanding why the universe contains something rather than nothing.

headline: 2 Art Gallery Shows to Explore From Home
abstract: Galleries and museums are getting creative about presenting work online during the coronavirus crisis. Here are two shows worth viewing virtually.
lead_paragraph: One source of comfort these days can be found in art history, which is filled with hundreds of examples of artists confronting pandemics, fear and isolation, and on the other hand, encountering heartening instances of cooperation, community and healing. Search the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s website using keywords like “plague” or “healing” and you will find an astonishing volume of objects devoted to these themes. Some recent examples are the textiles of the Paraguayan artist Feliciano Centurión (1962-1996), who died of complications from AIDS. They are on virtual display in the aptly titled show “Abrigo” at the Americas Society. Abrigo means “shelter” in Spanish, but also “overcoat,” “blanket,”

headline: Single or a Single Parent? Here’s How to Prepare for the Coronavirus
abstract: It’s possible to plan ahead so friends, neighbors and relatives can help if you wind up needing it.
lead_paragraph: For Americans who live alone, or are single parents, the prospect of getting coronavirus can be especially daunting. Without another adult to help, you could be left caring for yourself, your finances, your pets and your children while battling a serious and highly contagious disease.

headline: Trump’s Deadly Search for a Scapegoat
abstract: If the president had listened to the World Health Organization, American lives would have been saved.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Americans would be alive today if President Trump had spent more time listening to the World Health Organization instead of trying to destroy it.

headline: Four Swipes on Washing Your Hands
abstract: This video and explainer will show you how to properly wash your hands during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This video and explainer will show you how to properly wash your hands during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: How Bubonic Plague Has Helped Russia Fight the Coronavirus
abstract: A network of health centers formed by the Soviet Union in the 1920s is providing expertise in quarantines and epidemic response for Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a remote alpine meadow in Kyrgyzstan a few years ago, a teenage boy killed and skinned a marmot. Five days later, his parents carried the sweating, delirious boy to a village hospital where he died of bubonic plague.

headline: In Argentina, a Bid to Make Language Gender Neutral Gains Traction
abstract: A movement to make Spanish grammar less centered on male terms has gained broad adherence, including from President Alberto Fernández.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Three days into Argentina’s coronavirus lockdown, the country’s president called on men and women, Argentinos and Argentinas, to cooperate with the effort.

headline: Fighting Coronavirus Means I Haven’t Seen My Kids for a Month
abstract: A New York City doctor on sending her children away while she treats patients in the U.S. epicenter of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: It’s been four weeks since I’ve seen my kids, and I’m starting to miss them.

headline: Baghdad, a City Gone Still
abstract: The picnicking families are gone by the Tigris. So are the peddlers. But a twilight walk along the river still offers a sad solace.
lead_paragraph: Alissa J. Rubin, The Times’s Baghdad Bureau Chief, is on her fourth tour of Iraq since 2003. She was there when the country stopped flights in and out in mid-March to slow the coronavirus and declared a lockdown for all but trips to markets and doctors, or for short walks. We asked her to tell us about life in Iraq since then.

headline: How to Invest in the Military-Industrial Complex
abstract: Military contractors and aerospace companies could help hedge hard times, if you don’t mind what they are making. But it’s hard to find funds that focus on them.
lead_paragraph: When President Dwight D. Eisenhower spoke of the influence of the military-industrial complex nearly 60 years ago, he was issuing a warning, not giving investment advice. But he could’ve been, because, since then, military spending in the United States has remained as enormous as a giant aircraft carrier.

headline: Eating Is Weird Now. Here’s How to (Kind of) Get Back to Normal.
abstract: If the coronavirus has busted your diet — and you’ve busted out the fat pants — here are some tips to get back on track.
lead_paragraph: As the first shelter-in-place orders were spreading across the country, a popular tweet was going around: “Wear jeans for an hour or two in your house every day. You don’t want to get three or four weeks from now and go to put them on and have it be an absolute crisis.”

headline: Alex Trebek Memoir Is Coming in July
abstract: The book, “The Answer Is …,” arose from the “Jeopardy!” host’s desire to give fans more insight into his life after his pancreatic cancer diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: For years, “Jeopardy!” fans have yearned to learn more about the behind-the-scenes life of their beloved host, the silver-haired, even-toned Alex Trebek. But so far he has been relatively tight-lipped about it.

headline: A Frittata You Can Have for Lunch or Dinner
abstract: Tuck slices of this potato-studded dish between bread for a satisfying lunch, or serve it with a salad for a light dinner.
lead_paragraph: If cooking three meals a day has begun to wear on you, my mother has a suggestion: Take whatever you whipped up for dinner, and stick it between two pieces of bread for lunch the next day.

headline: ‘Joyful Participation in a World of Sorrows’
abstract: Cheryl Strayed calls the writer Pico Iyer to talk about forest fires, the Dalai Lama and losing what you love.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Biden Comes Out on Top. Now, the Really Hard Part.
abstract: Also this week, how to stay environmentally engaged
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. This week, we continue The Greenhouse, our digital event series on climate change. Join us for a live video call this Friday at 11:30 a.m. Eastern with Times journalists Josh Haner and Derek Watkins to discuss visual journalism and its power to document climate change. If you missed last Friday’s call on climate change in the age of the coronavirus, you can view it here.

headline: Fiona Apple’s Essential Songs
abstract: In anticipation of “Fetch the Bolt Cutters,” her first new album in almost a decade, hear a quick trip through some of her best tracks.
lead_paragraph: For an artist who has been releasing music for two and a half decades, Fiona Apple’s catalog has remarkably little filler.

headline: Now Arriving at La Guardia Airport: One Passenger
abstract: New York’s three major airports are operating at about 5% of their normal traffic, with terminals that are eerily silent.
lead_paragraph: Jim Mack had made several trips to New York City before, but had never been the only passenger on a commercial jet landing at a deserted La Guardia Airport.

headline: Why Apple’s New Phone Doesn’t Matter
abstract: New smartphones have become like refrigerators. They’re just not that exciting.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: For the Foreseeable Future, U.K. Parliament May Meet in Cyberspace
abstract: Few places are as ill suited to social distancing as the crammed chambers of the House of Commons, which is now looking for a digital alternative.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 1858, during what became known as the Great Stink, work was curtailed by an overpowering smell of sewage from the adjacent River Thames. During World War II, the threat from German bombers forced evacuation to a nearby building.

headline: The Buy-Nothing Home Office
abstract: Whether you are working, looking for work or simply absorbing a new reality, you should be comfortable. Here’s how to do it with stuff you may already have.
lead_paragraph: At its most luxurious, the home office is a subsidiary of leisure space: a sun-drenched room in a second home from which the boss can check in on everyone back at the office. In its more utilitarian form, it is, at least, personalized and private. There’s a chair, a desk and, ideally, a door. There’s probably other stuff in there too, like filing cabinets and unseasonal clothes and a guest bed. But it’s a place to work.

headline: Separated From Their Families, Parents Quarantine Apart
abstract: NYT Parenting readers share their coronavirus stories.
lead_paragraph: Once a week, Annie Cappiello watches her husband, Rodman, through a window. He leave bags of groceries outside their home, then returns to the empty house, a friend’s, where he’s been self-quarantined, away from Annie and their kids, ages 4 and 7, for the past few weeks.

headline: 12 Ideas for Writing Through the Pandemic With The New York Times
abstract: A dozen writing projects — including journals, poems, comics and more — for students to try at home.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has transformed life as we know it. Schools are closed, we’re confined to our homes and the future feels very uncertain. Why write at a time like this?

headline: Three-Ingredient Cookies, Fresh From Your Pantry
abstract: Bake your way to these sweet snacks using ingredients you’re likely to have on hand.
lead_paragraph: Cookies have great range: They can be complex and multidimensional, like a good Italian rainbow cookie, textured like chocolate chip, or trim and one-note, like English shortbread.

headline: Adding Trump’s Name to the Stimulus Checks
abstract: “No one action has better defined the Trump presidency and character,” a reader writes. Also: Recognizing essential workers; when anxiety is communal; remembering the time of AIDS.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Marking Notre-Dame Fire in a Locked-Down Paris
abstract: Events to pay tribute to the first anniversary of the catastrophic fire were canceled, and renovation work at the cathedral halted, because of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On the evening of April 15, 2019, the world watched Notre-Dame burn.

headline: Ultra-Orthodox Enclave in Israel Opens to Outsiders to Fight a Virus
abstract: When an insular religious community became an epicenter for the coronavirus, its leaders did the unthinkable, calling on the military to help turn things around.
lead_paragraph: BNEI BRAK, Israel — By the time the mayor of Bnei Brak grasped the deadly seriousness of the coronavirus pandemic, his city had already become Israel’s biggest center of contagion.

headline: Five Artists to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Avant-garde architecture, South African self-portraits and Neapolitan thirst traps: Here are the Instagram accounts that brighten our art critic’s daily feed.
lead_paragraph: Ask me most days what I think about Instagram, and I will tell you: a scourge. The social photo platform, and the cameraphone more generally, have produced a radical shift in the experience of art — turning virality into the principal marker of success, and laying waste to heritage sites worldwide. (Follow the viperous account @insta_wrecked, and you can gasp at images of thousands of tourists at the Trevi Fountain or Angkor Wat, all taking the same selfie.) Still, understanding art today means understanding Instagram, and in the last month it has been offering me a view of the world I cannot reach anymore: an imperfect but important means of global engagement that lets me drop into Indian museums or Nigerian photo shoots even as I keep my distance.

headline: The Future That Hollywood Feared Is Happening Now
abstract: The pandemic has hastened at-home viewing trends and will probably disrupt longtime traditions like the Oscars. Here’s a season-by-season look at the movie calendar.
lead_paragraph: The movie industry was already on a precipice. Did the pandemic just give it a push?

headline: Amazon to Suspend Operations in France Over Coronavirus Dispute
abstract: The move follows a French court order for the U.S. retailer to limit deliveries to essential goods amid controversy over virus safety measures.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Amazon said Wednesday that it would temporarily halt its operations in France after a court ruled the company had failed to adequately protect warehouse workers against the threat of the coronavirus and that it must restrict deliveries to only food, hygiene and medical products until it addressed the issue.

headline: Will ‘Big Data’ Restore Active Managers’ Mojo?
abstract: Sophisticated tech used to gather and analyze information may be able to improve returns, but the data isn’t showing it.
lead_paragraph: Thinking is expensive, and you often don’t get what you pay for.

headline: Trump Shifts Blame, to the W.H.O.
abstract: A former W.H.O. employee decries the president’s cutoff of funding; another reader decides to help provide funds herself with a small donation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: When Court Moves Online, Do Dress Codes Still Matter?
abstract: The legal profession is rooted in tradition, but social distancing is upending old norms. One judge in Broward County, Fla., asked lawyers to keep it professional during videoconferencing calls.
lead_paragraph: Justice is supposed to be blind. But in courtrooms, decorum matters.

headline: New York Orders Residents to Wear Masks in Public
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said all New Yorkers must wear face coverings when social distancing is not possible, including on public transport, in stores and on crowded sidewalks.
lead_paragraph: Imposing a stricter measure to control the spread of the coronavirus, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Wednesday that he would start requiring people in New York to wear masks or face coverings in public whenever social distancing was not possible.

headline: Get the NYT Parenting Newsletter
abstract: Get the NYT Parenting newsletter for the latest news and guidance for parents.

headline: Desperately Seeking a Black Sperm Donor
abstract: Two hopeful moms-to-be set out in search of a sperm donor with African origins and find the pickings slim.
lead_paragraph: [This story was originally published on May 8, 2019 on NYT Parenting.]

headline: Kenya Barris Plumbs His Id to Reinvent the Family Comedy
abstract: Freed from the creative shackles of the broadcast networks, the creator of “black-ish” stars as successful TV writer named Kenya Barris in Netflix’s “#blackAF.”
lead_paragraph: Kenya Barris is not an actor. A 45-year-old screenwriter, he has produced reality television (“America’s Next Top Model”), written movies (“Girls Trip”) and mined his own life for the long-running ABC show “black-ish.” Now freed from the constraints of network television thanks to a $100 million Netflix deal, Barris is aiming to reinvent the family comedy by taking a page out of Larry David’s playbook and turning the camera on himself with “#blackAF.”

headline: Swimming in the Alphabet Soup of Assisted Fertility
abstract: As my wife and I explore reproductive treatment options, we’re not putting all our eggs in one basket.
lead_paragraph: [This story was originally published on Aug. 5, 2019 on NYT Parenting.]

headline: A Ticking Clock and Anxiety on the Way to Motherhood
abstract: A queer couple pursuing assisted fertility discuss the judgment and self-doubt they’ve encountered along the way.
lead_paragraph: [This story was originally published on Oct. 7, 2019 on NYT Parenting.]

headline: We Tweeted Our Pregnancy the Day We Found Out
abstract: A same-sex couple discusses their long and public road to motherhood.
lead_paragraph: [This story was originally published on Dec. 9, 2019 on NYT Parenting.]

headline: When Older Relatives Shrug at Coronavirus Restrictions
abstract: Although the virus poses a heightened threat to older people, some of their middle-aged children feel they aren’t taking it seriously enough.
lead_paragraph: I went hoarse shouting at my mother last week.

headline: For My Mother’s FaceTime Burial, Lipstick and Howling Winds
abstract: In Jewish tradition the body must be buried within 24 hours. I fight with myself about whether to travel to Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: Day 20, or maybe 21. Days blur. Rituals: Like John Cheever who every morning, dressed in his suit and tie, rode down the elevator of his apartment building, and then took the stairs to his study in the basement, I crawl out of bed, dress and grab my coffee, and then off I go to my own newly formed study in our living room.

headline: How Do You Mourn During a Pandemic?
abstract: Readers, please share your stories of mourning during the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Have you lost someone you care about in the last month? Was a service held in his or her honor, either virtually or in a physical space? How has the experience of mourning or memorializing been for you? Please share your story, in no more than 200 words.

headline: My Toddler Survived Cancer. Then Came the Coronavirus.
abstract: We’re applying the lessons we learned when she was sick all over again.
lead_paragraph: Last April, my wife called me in tears from a hospital in Fairfax, Va., to tell me our 2-year-old daughter, Nusayba, had hepatoblastoma, a rare cancer that primarily affects children during the first 3 years of life. It was most likely stage 4, she said.

headline: This Is Not the Time to Let the Market Decide
abstract: When it comes to crucial medical supplies, cooperation, not competition, will save lives. History shows that it works.
lead_paragraph: One symptom of the coronavirus pandemic has been an explosion of economic nationalism around the world. Many countries, including the United States and members of the European Union, have erected export controls to prevent scarce goods like protective masks, gowns, gloves, ventilators and testing kits from being sold abroad. And global competition to purchase these goods is playing out like the plot of a bad action movie with accusations that planes full of Europe-bound masks have been diverted at the last minute to the United States. A German official has accused the United States of “modern piracy.”

headline: Kimarlee Nguyen, Writer Who Explored Cambodian Roots, Dies at 33
abstract: Ms. Nguyen’s writing career was budding; she was also an inspiring teacher of first-generation Americans. She died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Photojournalists Struggle Through the Pandemic, With Masks and Long Lenses
abstract: Assignments have dried up for many photographers. Others risk going into the fray to capture images of a changed world.
lead_paragraph: March was shaping up to be a good month for Brian Bowen Smith, a photographer in Los Angeles who has worked for Vogue and GQ. He had five big jobs lined up, including shoots for two movie posters. All five were canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: How Men’s Bodies Change When They Become Fathers

abstract: Don’t wait for the most convenient time to rebuild intimacy. You’ll be waiting a long time.

lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Nov. 15, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Stuart Cohen, Cabdriver Thirsty for Knowledge, Dies at 73
abstract: Collecting used books, he read voraciously when not having lively conversations with his passengers. He died in the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Let us help you start your day.
lead_paragraph: The head of the World Health Organization expressed dismay over President Trump’s declaration that he would halt U.S. funding to the agency as the number of cases of coronavirus worldwide neared two million.

headline: A Mesmerizing ‘India Song,’ Pulpy and Austere
abstract: Now streaming, Marguerite Duras’s hypnotic hothouse flower is as maddeningly beautiful as its star, Delphine Seyrig.
lead_paragraph: Spare, elegant, disjunctive, initially annoying and ultimately drop-dead beautiful, Marguerite Duras’s “India Song” (1975) was one of the great European art films of the post-art-film era. It followed the 1960s heyday of Michelangelo Antonioni, Ingmar Bergman and Alain Resnais, Duras’s one-time collaborator (she wrote the screenplay for his first feature, “Hiroshima, Mon Amour”), and was in some ways more radical than their work.

headline: How to Cope if You Haven’t Experienced Market Chaos Before
abstract: Three personal finance authors offer tips for young people to follow during this financial crisis, and after it is over.
lead_paragraph: I believe the technical term for what we have been experiencing in the financial markets is: Aargh! (“Bloodsuckingly bad” also works.)

headline: Willie Davis, Packers Hall of Famer, Is Dead at 85
abstract: In his 10 seasons with Green Bay, as its defensive anchor, he helped the team win three N.F.L. championships and the first two Super Bowls.
lead_paragraph: Willie Davis, the Hall of Fame defensive end who played on five Green Bay Packer championship teams and anchored one of pro football’s greatest defensive alignments, died on Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Inside the Public Hospitals Trying to Save New York
abstract: The city’s municipal hospitals are unified by a seemingly impossible mission: to care for everyone, regardless of their ability to pay. This is their moment.
lead_paragraph: The city’s municipal hospitals are unified by a seemingly impossible mission: to care for everyone, regardless of their ability to pay. This is their moment.

headline: The Key to Better Sleep When You Have a New Baby
abstract: Fatigue is a common side effect of parenthood. Here’s how to know when it’s a symptom of a bigger problem.
lead_paragraph: I pulled many all-nighters in college, but I didn’t know what it meant to be truly bone-tired until my daughter was born. The baby slept only an hour or two at a time. My husband helped, but in the early days, I was the only one who could feed her. Even after she started sleeping for longer stretches, my exhaustion seemed to grow worse. One day, I tried to start my car by clipping the dog’s leash to the ignition. “Is it normal to be this tired?” I wondered. I couldn’t find a clear answer. None of the baby sleep books I’d read mentioned parental fatigue.

headline: What to Do When Your Kids Fight
abstract: Sibling conflict is normal, but these mediation techniques will build empathy and help them settle disputes themselves.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Dec. 26, 2019 on NYT Parenting.

headline: Why Are Kids So Obsessed With Poop Jokes?
abstract: Toilet humor can be a powerful tool for children, but there are ways to limit the potty talk.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Nov. 5, 2019 on NYT Parenting.

headline: Why Do Kids Love Terrible Music?
abstract: It turns out there’s a good reason my children request songs that are repetitive, silly and lowbrow. I’m trying to get onboard.
lead_paragraph: [This story was originally published on Nov. 15, 2019 on NYT Parenting.]

headline: UnitedHealth Reports Profit, Citing Falling Demand for Elective Care
abstract: The health care insurance giant’s earnings is one of the first to offer a hint of how the health crisis is affecting the nation’s health care industry.
lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s major insurers, reported on Wednesday that its earnings actually increased this past quarter, adding that the costs of the coronavirus pandemic were offset by the cancellations of routine medical appointments and elective surgeries for hip replacements and other conditions.

headline: What Historians Will See When They Look Back on the Covid-19 Pandemic of 2020
abstract: Universities and institutions are inviting the public to share their experiences during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Sherri Denney was in the fourth day of quarantine in her home in Springboro, Ohio, when she thought about the toll the coronavirus was taking. She sat in her recliner chair and cried as the state’s governor checked off the number of dead and sickened, knowing there would be more the next day. Overwhelmed, Ms. Denney, 55, tried to put her feelings into words.

headline: From ‘Octonauts’ to ‘Bluey’: Your Favorite Kids’ TV Shows
abstract: NYT Parenting sent out a call for delightful children’s programming, and you answered.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on June 25, 2019 on NYT Parenting.

headline: Henry F. Graff, Columbia Historian of Presidents, Dies at 98
abstract: A professor and author, he had translated decrypted Japanese messages in World War II that revealed German defenses for D-Day and Tokyo’s imminent capitulation.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: John Horton Conway, a ‘Magical Genius’ in Math, Dies at 82
abstract: He made profound contributions to number theory, coding theory, probability theory, topology, algebra and more — and created games from it all. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Coronavirus Cases at D.C. Whole Foods Highlight Risks Facing Grocery Workers
abstract: A cluster of infections at the store in the heart of trendy downtown Washington is not an isolated episode, as the nation’s grocery workers increasingly fall ill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An outbreak of coronavirus infections at an upscale Whole Foods in the heart of the nation’s capital has focused attention on the plight of grocery store workers deemed essential to stay on the job during the pandemic but increasingly falling ill to its ravages.

headline: Conferences Petition N.C.A.A., Seeking to Cut Sports
abstract: Five college conferences have asked for a relaxing of requirements because of financial problems caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The commissioners of five college athletic conferences have asked the N.C.A.A. to relax some of its requirements because of financial problems caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Hailey Herrera, 25, Dies; Therapy Student Focused on Families
abstract: She was especially dedicated to working with Latino patients — and to organizing social events for friends.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: I Took the Antibody Test. And Yet.
abstract: I still don’t know what I need to about the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: After a lot of years, you tend to know a guy. And as it turned out, I know a guy who had antibody blood tests for the novel coronavirus.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: In an Altered World, Listeners Share Their Stories About Love and Life
abstract: How are people dealing with the impact of coronavirus? By adopting multiple personas, donating supplies, getting sober and, of course, FaceTiming their friends.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Soccer’s Business Hasn’t Stopped. It’s Just Waiting for the New Prices.
abstract: As a billion-dollar industry enters a second month in lockdown, scouts and sporting directors are finding they all need the same thing: patience.
lead_paragraph: As far as Rámon Rodriguez Verdejo — the man everyone knows as Monchi — is concerned, there is as much work to do as there ever was. The game of soccer is paused, indefinitely, placed in the same anxious limbo as every other sport, as every other industry. But on laptop screens and cellphones, the business of it rumbles on as best it can.

headline: Navy May Reinstate Fired Captain to Command of Roosevelt
abstract: Adm. Michael Gilday has indicated that he may reinstate Captain Crozier, who was removed from command after pleading for more help fighting a coronavirus outbreak on his ship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Navy is looking into whether it can reinstate Capt. Brett E. Crozier, who was removed from command of the carrier Theodore Roosevelt after he pleaded for more help fighting a novel coronavirus outbreak aboard his ship, Defense Department officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Small-Business Aid Funds Run Dry as Program Fails to Reach Hardest Hit
abstract: Lawmakers remain at odds on how to replenish a lending program meant to help companies and workers weather the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new federal program to help small businesses weather the coronavirus pandemic is running out of money and falling short in the industries and states most battered by the crisis, risking waves of bankruptcies and millions of additional unemployed workers.

headline: South Dakota Meat Plant Is Now Country’s Biggest Coronavirus Hot Spot
abstract: Refugees from around the world worked at the Smithfield pork factory in Sioux Falls. Now they face mounting illness and the sudden loss of their jobs.
lead_paragraph: An immigrant from El Salvador bought a three-bedroom home with a basement for her family. A single mother from Ethiopia sent her daughters to college. A refugee from Sudan bought bunk beds for her boys, new couches and a dining table.

headline: Fed Gives Banks a Break to Keep Markets Calm, Asking for Little in Return
abstract: The Federal Reserve is giving banks room to maneuver with regulatory tweaks. But it isn’t barring them from paying dividends, fueling concerns that it is ignoring the lessons of the last crisis.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, as the global financial system was melting down, America’s largest banks continued paying dividends.

headline: Students Might Have to Take College Admissions Tests at Home This Fall
abstract: The coronavirus is forcing the SAT and ACT to develop digital versions of the standardized tests in case schools remain closed. Critics fear that could deepen inequities.
lead_paragraph: Pencils down.

headline: W.H.O., Coronavirus, Boxfish: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Big Banks Get Ready for Rough Days Ahead
abstract: Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup, all reporting quarterly earnings, said they had set aside billions of dollars in preparation for loan defaults.
lead_paragraph: While many other industries are deeply threatened by the coronavirus outbreak, the country’s banks are still earning billions, in part because the market volatility it caused was a moneymaking opportunity for their trading divisions.

headline: One Person is Overseeing Congress’s Bailout Loans. He Wants Answers.
abstract: The Fed has authority to make trillions of dollars in loans. Concern is growing that taxpayers will be in the dark about how the money is being disbursed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The lone member of the nascent Congressional Oversight Commission created as part of President Trump’s $2 trillion economic stimulus law is calling on the Federal Reserve to release detailed information about which companies receive loans from its emergency lending facilities and how the money is being used.

headline: V.A. Health Care Workers Balk at Safety Practices
abstract: Officials at the Department of Veterans Affairs have denied that workers across their huge health care system — which serves nine million veterans and has 390,000 employees — have inadequate gear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Veterans Affairs had a problem: Some of its workers appeared to be taking home extra masks and other protective gear, most likely fearing that they might not have enough supplies to do their jobs. So the department decided it would start checking everyone’s bags before they left for the day, and officials drafted a memo to explain the new policy.

headline: Relying on Science and Politics, Merkel Offers a Cautious Virus Re-entry Plan
abstract: Shorn of any bravado, her announcement seemed again to make Germany, Europe’s biggest economy, a de facto leader on the Continent and something of an example for Western nations
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel on Wednesday set in motion a plan for Germany to begin lifting social and economic restrictions in place because of the coronavirus, even as she warned that the road ahead would look less like a return to normal than a way to live with a pandemic that has overturned ordinary life.

headline: U.S. Accuses North Korea of Cyberattacks, a Sign That Deterrence Is Failing
abstract: Through the attacks, a report says, the North steals and launders money, extorts companies and uses digital currencies to gain cash for its nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States accused North Korea on Wednesday of employing an array of old and new forms of cyberattacks to steal and launder money, extort companies and use digital currencies to gain cash for its nuclear weapons program.

headline: Washington: Where Everyone Votes by Mail
abstract: We spoke to the secretary of state to get her take on voting by mail and whether she thinks the balloting option could be implemented across the country.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Stop Dawdling. People Need Money.
abstract: An antiquated financial system is slowing distribution of federal stimulus to families. Policymakers are making things worse.
lead_paragraph: The economic shutdown caused by the coronavirus has left a growing number of American families desperately short of money. Images of hundreds of cars waiting in long lines at food banks across the country have become a symbol of the crisis, a contemporary equivalent of the old black-and-white images of Americans standing in bread lines during the Great Depression.

headline: To Beat the Virus, Colombia Tries Separating Men and Women
abstract: As the virus hits Latin America, countries are trying different approaches to keep people off the street. In Bogotá, men and women are only allowed out on alternate days.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — So many men. Men at the bakery, men on bikes, men in parks, men in the grocery aisles.

headline: ​In South Korea Vote, ​Virus Delivers Landslide Win to Governing Party
abstract: President Moon Jae-in’s left-leaning alliance in South Korea won a historic majority in Parliament thanks in part to the country’s largely successful handling of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Moon Jae-in’s governing party in South Korea won a landslide in parliamentary elections on Wednesday, as he leveraged his surging popularity over his country’s largely successful battle against the coronavirus to increase his political sway.​

headline: Florida Inmate Released Amid Pandemic Killed Someone the Next Day, Officials Say
abstract: Joseph Edward Williams shot and killed a man in Tampa, Fla., on March 20, the authorities said, one day after he was among more than 160 inmates released from Hillsborough County jails.
lead_paragraph: It was an effort, like many across the country, to try to slow the spread of the coronavirus in jails. But one day after officials in Hillsborough County, Fla., released more than 160 inmates, one of them shot and killed a man in Tampa, the authorities said.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: A severe lack of testing capacity is hampering efforts to slow the outbreak and reopen the economy.
lead_paragraph: Have we slowed the spread of the coronavirus? Are we past the peak? When can we safely ease restrictions? How can we head off a second wave of infections?

headline: Urged On by Conservatives and His Own Advisers, Trump Targeted the W.H.O.
abstract: But his announcement that he would freeze the U.S.’s contributions to the organization in the middle of a pandemic was denounced by Democrats as well as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fox News pundits and Republican lawmakers have raged for weeks at the World Health Organization for praising China’s handling of the coronavirus crisis. On his podcast, President Trump’s former chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon, urged his former boss to stop funding the W.H.O., citing its ties to the “Chinese Communist Party.”

headline: Trump’s Flounder Period
abstract: What this country needs is another group with a very long name.
lead_paragraph: Rest easy, people. We’ve got the Great American Economic Revival Industry Groups watching out for us.

headline: Trump’s ‘Opening Our Country Council’ Runs Into Its Own Opening Problems
abstract: Instead of a formal council, the president created several industry groups, and joined four calls with them. But some participants had no notice they would be included, and others could not join in.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some business leaders had no idea they were included until they heard that their names had been read in the Rose Garden on Tuesday night by President Trump. Some of those who had agreed to help said they received little information on what, exactly, they were signing up for. And others who were willing to connect with the White House could not participate in hastily organized conference calls on Wednesday because of scheduling conflicts and technical difficulties.

headline: After Anonymous Tip, 17 Bodies Found at Nursing Home Hit by Virus
abstract: There have been 68 recent deaths of residents and nurses from the facility in a small New Jersey town.
lead_paragraph: [The latest: 29 Dead at One Nursing Home From the Virus. Or More. No One Will Say.]

headline: Essence Festival Canceled in New Orleans
abstract: The annual event usually draws hundreds of thousands of people to New Orleans over the Fourth of July weekend.
lead_paragraph: Essence magazine’s annual festival, which draws hundreds of thousands of people to New Orleans over the Fourth of July weekend to celebrate black culture, was canceled Wednesday to prevent the further spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Testing Falls Woefully Short as Trump Seeks an End to Stay-at-Home Orders
abstract: Flawed tests, scarce supplies and limited access to screening have hurt the U.S.’s ability to monitor Covid-19, governors and health officials warn.
lead_paragraph: As President Trump pushes to reopen the economy, most of the country is not conducting nearly enough testing to track the path and penetration of the coronavirus in a way that would allow Americans to safely return to work, public health officials and political leaders say.

headline: ‘Trolls World Tour,’ a Kids’ Music Movie, Has Big Problems With Pop
abstract: Rock tries to rule the other genres in this sequel to “Trolls,” but the real lesson is about how pop has been a conqueror for generations.
lead_paragraph: The original “Trolls” movie in 2016 was about the unique privilege associated with being a Troll — kaleidoscopically colorful lives, unrelenting joy, hourly hug-a-thons. Chipper, loopy songs peppered the film, which presented pop music, and Pop Trolldom, as sources of joy that are unimpeachably good (if a little oblivious).

headline: Trump Threatens to Adjourn Congress to Install Nominees. McConnell Demurs.
abstract: The House and Senate have both taken extended recesses amid the pandemic, convening at least every few days for so-called pro forma sessions to keep their chambers technically in session.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, furious over government vacancies he said were hindering his administration’s coronavirus response, threatened on Wednesday to invoke a never-before-used presidential power to adjourn Congress so he could fill the positions temporarily himself.

headline: A True Soviet War Hero
abstract: The Russian ambassador to the United States takes issue with an obituary.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Way We Ration Ventilators Is Biased
abstract: Not every patient has a fair chance.
lead_paragraph: Update: After this essay was published, the model guidance for rationing ventilators was revised.

headline: Learn to Argue Productively
abstract: Arguments don’t have to be heated, explosive moments. As long as everyone’s in good faith, everyone can learn from one another.
lead_paragraph: Arguments and disagreements aren’t always bad. They can solve problems, show you sides of things you haven’t considered before, and even be fun. But unproductive arguments, or worse circular arguments that you keep having over and over again, are a time and emotional drain — which nobody needs right now.

headline: Virginia Nursing Home Had Plenty of Coronavirus Patients but Few Tests
abstract: “You can’t fight what you can’t see,” said the medical director of a Richmond nursing home where at least 46 residents have died.
lead_paragraph: After the first positive coronavirus test at a Virginia nursing home in mid-March, its administrator said, the staff restricted visitors, conducted temperature checks at the end of every worker’s shift and isolated residents who had tested positive into separate areas.

headline: New Details Hint at Risk of Russian Misinformation in Dossier
abstract: Footnotes were declassified from a watchdog report that found that the F.B.I. had reason to open the Russia inquiry but made errors in seeking approval to wiretap a former Trump adviser.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has declassified several footnotes from a report about the F.B.I.’s Trump-Russia investigation, providing details hinting anew at the possibility that Russia may have sown disinformation in a dossier used to investigate a former Trump campaign aide.

headline: A Birthday Cake Mystery
abstract: A bit of sweetness to give you a break from the bleak.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Well newsletter. Every Wednesday, we email readers with news and advice about living well every day. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: ‘Don’t Be a Stranger!’
abstract: Alan Arbesfeld fools us thrice.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — We are a social species, so the drive to keep up friendships and relationships while we are sheltering in place can be strong for some of us. Zoom and other video chat apps help us feel as if we are gathered together, and millions of people are beginning to remember that their smartphones were initially intended to make phone calls.

abstract: Helicopter parenting has become the American norm, but it may not be the best way to connect with our kids.
