abstract: When he was winning primaries, many in the Democratic Party were wary of the Vermont senator. Now, he’s a friend, chess-playing companion and “American original.”
lead_paragraph: It did not take much for Joe Biden to distinguish himself from his main rival for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Some Banks Keep Customers’ Stimulus Checks if Accounts Are Overdrawn
abstract: Financial institutions can use the government deposits to make up for recipients’ negative balances.
lead_paragraph: For some struggling Americans, the arrival of a deposit from the Treasury Department to help with basic expenses like rent and groceries during the coronavirus crisis was something to count on — until their financial institutions got in the way.

headline: Buy Now, Check In Later
abstract: Hotels are offering enticing deals in the form of discounted gift certificates for future stays. Yes, there’s risk involved, but some of these bargains may be hard to resist.
lead_paragraph: In the absence of travel during the pandemic, hotels are asking travelers to plan future trips and sweetening the incentive by offering discounted gift certificates.

headline: An Unproven Vaccine Is Too Risky
abstract: It’s tempting to speed up development in a pandemic, but there are good reasons to stick to scientific standards.
lead_paragraph: In the desperation to save lives in the coronavirus pandemic, we have already begun to relax scientific standards in the hope of finding a treatment without waiting to prove that it works.

headline: FEMA’s ‘Air Bridge’ to Coronavirus Hot Spots Leaves Other Regions on Their Own
abstract: The federal government’s system of directing medical supplies for the hardest-hit regions has left areas out of the spotlight scrambling to prepare as the outbreak spreads.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government’s program to expedite the shipping of valuable protective equipment to coronavirus hot spots has left hospitals that are out of the spotlight struggling to secure their own protective gear as they watch the outbreak creep closer.

headline: Feeding Essential Workers, and Putting Restaurants Back to Work
abstract: In response to the coronavirus outbreak, World Central Kitchen and fellow initiatives tap into the struggling restaurant industry to provide nourishment.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus outbreak took hold in America last month, volunteers in San Francisco and New York sprang to action to feed overwhelmed health care workers and help struggling local restaurant workers.

headline: Latinos Are Essential Workers. Will They Be Essential Voters?
abstract: The coronavirus is likely to hit the United States’ 60 million Latinos particularly hard, and political organizers face a dual challenge of energizing them and keeping them safe.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Héctor Sánchez Barba had been counting on Latinos to show up in record numbers in November’s election.

headline: A Reporter’s Challenge: Maintaining Distance in a Close Community
abstract: The logistics of working on an article in Amish country in Ohio proved trickier than expected.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Two Olympic Marathoners. Two Lives Turned Around, Then Turned Around Again.
abstract: Jacob Riley and Molly Seidel came out of obscurity to qualify for the Olympic Games. Everything about their lives changed. Then it changed again.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Riley celebrated the day he became an Olympic marathoner with a night out at an Atlanta bowling alley that had a long cocktail menu. He started with a local whiskey, drank a Moscow mule, and isn’t exactly sure where things went from there.

headline: Inside the Fringe Japanese Religion That Claims It Can Cure Covid-19
abstract: Happy Science, which boasts millions of followers, is led by a man who channels Buddha (and Jesus and Freddie Mercury) and says he can defeat the coronavirus. For a fee.
lead_paragraph: When New York went into lockdown last month, emissaries of a religious group called Happy Science showed up in a ghostly Times Square to deliver a peculiar end-of-days gospel. They wore ritual golden sashes and huddled in a semicircle.

headline: An Army of Virus Tracers Takes Shape in Massachusetts
abstract: Asian countries have invested heavily in digital contact tracing, which uses technology to warn people when they have been exposed to the coronavirus. Massachusetts is using an old-fashioned means: people.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Alexandra Cross, a newly minted state public health worker, dialed a stranger’s telephone number on Monday, her heart racing.

headline: Biden Is Losing the Internet. Does That Matter?
abstract: The coronavirus has forced the Democrats’ presumptive presidential nominee into an all-digital campaign, and he’s struggling to break through.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden is very famous, but you wouldn’t know it from looking at his YouTube channel.

headline: W.H.O., Now Trump’s Scapegoat, Warned About Coronavirus Early and Often
abstract: The World Health Organization, always cautious, acted more forcefully and faster than many national governments. But President Trump has decided to cut off U.S. funding to the organization.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 22, two days after Chinese officials first publicized the serious threat posed by the new virus ravaging the city of Wuhan, the chief of the World Health Organization held the first of what would be months of almost daily media briefings, sounding the alarm, telling the world to take the outbreak seriously.

headline: As Coronavirus Fades in China, Nationalism and Xenophobia Flare
abstract: Now that the pandemic is raging outside China’s borders, foreigners are being shunned, barred from public spaces and even evicted.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After 16 years in China, a Congolese businessman thought he knew what being black there entailed. He had been subjected to racial slurs and denied apartments, but he had also learned Chinese and made local friends. He loved the country; he called it his second home.

headline: How Democracy Won the World’s First Coronavirus Election
abstract: South Korea has been a model of testing and tracing during the epidemic. Now it is for voting, too.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The most important thing about this country’s legislative elections this week is the fact that they happened at all. They were the world’s first nationwide vote of the coronavirus era, and more than 29 million people — 66 percent of the electorate, the highest turnout in nearly three decades — cast ballots to choose 300 new members for the National Assembly.

headline: White House Offers Reopening Guidelines as U.S. Deaths Surge
abstract: President Trump says he will defer to governors about lifting restrictions. At least 30,000 patients have died, and 22 million Americans have filed for unemployment in four weeks.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus epidemic.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will now require people to wear face coverings in public places where they cannot keep six feet away from others
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: A Dissident Company Celebrates 15 Years Underground
abstract: The Belarus Free Theater had ambitious plans for its anniversary. The coronavirus stopped them, but the troupe is used to finding ways to keep going in tough times.

headline: Coronavirus, Distancing Guidelines, Unemployment: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Counting Bodies and Pointing Fingers as Spain Tallies Coronavirus Dead
abstract: No country is really sure how many people it has lost to the pandemic. But in Spain, it has become bitterly political.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain is recounting its dead.

headline: Bonds Started to Falter. Then, the Fed Came to the Rescue.
abstract: Core bond funds have made money for investors, but it has been anything but an effortless ride.
lead_paragraph: When seen from a distance, core bond funds lately have had the deceptive appearance of ducks serenely gliding along the waters’ surface.

headline: Kicked Out of China
abstract: As the coronavirus escalated to a worldwide crisis, China expelled our journalists — and surveilled our correspondents to thwart their reporting before they left.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Interested in a Short-Term Rental for Social Distancing? Be Prepared to Stay Longer
abstract: Despite executive orders for social distancing, Airbnb and other short-term rental platforms continue to offer homes and “quarantine apartments” as retreats.
lead_paragraph: As communities tighten rules on social distancing, the short-term rental has become a fraught piece of turf. In areas like the Jersey Shore and Newport Beach, Calif., and in states like Pennsylvania and Vermont, officials have severely restricted short-term rentals to discourage residents of urban hot zones from spreading the coronavirus to lower-density locations. Recent evidence has shown that their caution is justified.

headline: The Soundtrack to an Electric Car
abstract: The film composer Hans Zimmer is creating a sonic signature for BMW’s forthcoming electric i4 sedan.
lead_paragraph: When General Maximus — that’s Russell Crowe in “Gladiator” — leads his Roman legions into battle, Hans Zimmer’s bombastic, percussive score propels them to victory.

headline: ‘Charger Desert’ in Big Cities Keeps Electric Cars From Mainstream
abstract: For city dwellers who would love an E.V., the biggest hurdle might be keeping it juiced up without a garage or other convenient charging stations.
lead_paragraph: There are people across America who would buy an electric car tomorrow — if only they had someplace to plug it in. Forget oft-cited “range anxiety,” many experts say: The real deal-killer, especially for city and apartment dwellers, is a dearth of chargers where they park their cars.

headline: A Decade of Jobs Destroyed in a Month
abstract: The number of people in America who lost their jobs in the past four weeks is expected to surpass all of the jobs created since the last recession.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: ‘A White, White Day’ Review: Confronting Grief in a Frozen Landscape
abstract: A man finds coping with his wife’s death hard enough — and then learns she’d been having an affair.
lead_paragraph: The Icelandic director Hlynur Palmason, in his second feature-length film, shows an acute sensitivity to the potential relations between environment and cinematic pace. He exercises that quality in ingenious and galvanic ways in “A White, White Day,” an eerily gripping study of grief — and impotence in its face — with the trappings of a revenge thriller.

headline: ‘Abe’ Review: Food and Family, but No Fun
abstract: A feel-good setup turns out to be a recipe for a joyless production.
lead_paragraph: In the Brooklyn-set tween drama “Abe,” a 12-year-old boy (Noah Schnapp, of “Stranger Things” fame) tries a culinary solution to unite the Palestinian Muslim and Israeli Jewish sides of his family: fusion food. Directed by the Brazilian filmmaker Fernando Grostein Andrade, this is a maudlin and predictable film, with oversimplified, kid-friendly takes on complex political issues. It’s also a surprisingly joyless production, lacking the stylistic and emotional flair to deliver even on the cheesy, feel-good promise of the setup.

headline: ‘Bad Therapy’ Review: A Twisted Therapist Sinks In Her Hooks
abstract: Rob Corddry and Alicia Silverstone play an unhappily married couple in “Bad Therapy,” a new comedy-drama about treatment that’s worse than the condition.
lead_paragraph: This is a movie that can shake at least one of your fundamental beliefs to the core. If you consider “God Only Knows” by the Beach Boys a song you could never get tired of, its use over the opening credits — prefaced by that Frank Lloyd Wright quote about how if you tip the world over, everything loose would land in Los Angeles — might refute that. The song’s dulcet tones float over drone shots and other well-composed ground-level establishing views of middle-class L.A. There’s an instant “oh, this again?” feel to it.

headline: ‘The Quarry’ Review: Traveling With a Guilty Conscience
abstract: A killer assumes the identity of his victim, a preacher, and goes on to a new church where some of what he tells his flock rubs off on him.
lead_paragraph: In “The Quarry,” Shea Whigham stars as a fugitive wanted for murder and arson who, in a moment of anger, kills the preacher (Bruno Bichir) who picked him up on a West Texas roadside, trying to help. He then buries the body in a quarry and assumes the dead man’s identity, traveling to a tiny town where the reverend was to take charge of a sleepy church.

headline: I’m Working Remotely. Can I Keep Hiding My Secret Baby?
abstract: ‘I’m pretty sure he thinks it’s a cat.’
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

headline: How to Profit in a Stock Market Downturn
abstract: Funds managed to flourish with diverse bets on Treasury bonds and small Chinese companies — and against select American stocks.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus spreading around the world, the vast majority of mutual funds found few refuges, with some falling 20 percent or more.

headline: ‘Endings, Beginnings’ Review: Choose Me
abstract: Shailene Woodley plays the troubled center of a love triangle in this leisurely romantic drama.
lead_paragraph: Watching Shailene Woodley dither between two preposterously hot men — and steamily sample both — in “Endings, Beginnings” might not be the best choice for viewers whose libidos are on mandatory lockdown.

headline: On Politics: Vice-Presidential Chatter
abstract: Unusual candor from Georgia, and protests in Michigan: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump walked to the Rose Garden for the daily coronavirus briefing on Wednesday.

headline: Cuomo Extends Coronavirus Shutdown Order to May 15
abstract: New York State recorded its fewest deaths in 10 days, but the governor said more progress was needed before he would lift restrictions.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus, read Friday’s live coverage.]

headline: Boardroom Infighting in Barcelona Shakes Team
abstract: Six resignations, a social media scandal and accusations of corruption shine an ugly light on F.C. Barcelona, the Lionel Messi-led soccer team.
lead_paragraph: Something is rotten in Barcelona.

headline: China Post-Coronavirus: Signs of Life, Censorship and Paranoia
abstract: Hefei, an industrial city, offers tales of hope for a world battling the outbreak. The police tried to make sure they weren’t heard.
lead_paragraph: HEFEI, China — Once again, we were being followed.

headline: Falwell Focuses on Critics as Coronavirus Cases Near His University Grow
abstract: Jerry Falwell Jr. has tried to have journalists arrested as he maintains he has been unfairly maligned. But the coronavirus keeps spreading around Liberty University.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jerry Falwell Jr.’s angry counteroffensive against critics of his decision to invite Liberty University students back to its Lynchburg, Va., campus after spring break has played out in the media, the courts, even with the campus police.

headline: The Singapore Warning
abstract: Reopening the economy will be hard.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: ‘Nowhere to Hide’ as Unemployment Permeates the Economy
abstract: Jobless claims exceed 20 million in four weeks, inflicting a toll on the labor force not seen since the Great Depression.
lead_paragraph: Even as political leaders wrangle over how and when to restart the American economy, the coronavirus pandemic’s devastation became more evident Thursday with more than 5.2 million workers added to the tally of the unemployed.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Lessons in Constructive Solitude From Thoreau’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about Henry David Thoreau and why his two-year-plus experiment in self-isolation at Walden Pond is relevant today.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Lessons in Constructive Solitude From Thoreau” by Holland Cotter

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: A pajama designer’s easy but unexpected egg dish — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: My Friends Should Let Health Care Workers Stay in Their Empty Apartments. Right?
abstract: Doctors and nurses are heading to hot spots to provide front-line aid, and they need housing.
lead_paragraph: We live in a city that is a Covid-19 hot spot. When the news became alarming, many of our friends fled the city, leaving empty apartments behind them. We stayed. I am active on a few neighborhood social networking sites where I’ve seen posts about nurses and doctors coming from other cities to help patients in ours. But they need places to stay. I get choked up just thinking about them! Is there a nice way to ask friends who’ve left town if they would let medical personnel stay in their apartments while they’re away? A Facebook post yielded lots of likes, but no concrete offers.

headline: Art Recreation Is the Only Good Instagram Challenge
abstract: Around the world, people are posing as famous portraits with toilet paper, bedsheets, drawn-on unibrows, and did we mention toilet paper?
lead_paragraph: A woman with a roll of toilet paper around her neck. A man with lettuce on his head, bare-chested in a sheet, delicately holding a large goblet of red wine. A child with small lilac angel wings posed atop a mound of — again — toilet paper, with siblings and parents looking on in the background. For weeks, people have been recreating works of fine art using household items and posting their tableaus on social media.

headline: Who Is Likely to Become Unemployed?
abstract: Thursday: A report analyzes which workers are most vulnerable and what that says about California’s economy. Also: An update from the U.S.N.S. Mercy.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Murray Hill and St. George, Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Murray Hill and St. George, Staten Island.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Tenafly, N.J., and a three-bedroom in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Tenafly, N.J., and a three-bedroom in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan, Staten Island and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Murray Hill, St. George, and Crown Heights.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Tenafly, N.J., and a three-bedroom in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: A Frank Talk About Fat
abstract: The author of “This Is Big,” a history of Weight Watchers, comes to terms with a lifetime of dieting, a wavering self-image and the persistence of fat shaming in our society.
lead_paragraph: Marisa Meltzer will spare you the euphemisms. She’s not curvy or plus-size. Nor is she, as one of her dates genteelly put it, “carrying extra weight.” She is fat, she says plainly, a state she describes with a mixture of resignation and grit.

headline: The Galette Recipe One French Creative Director Grew Up On
abstract: At his grandmother’s cottage in Brittany, Pierre-Alexis Delaplace of Kerzon would wait, somewhat impatiently, for this savory treat.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: PGA Tour Announces Mid-June Return in Texas
abstract: Golf officials are preparing to restart the season by hosting a tournament in Fort Worth, Texas, without spectators.
lead_paragraph: The PGA Tour on Thursday announced it would resume its season in mid-June with a tournament in Fort Worth, Texas, which would most likely make men’s golf among the first major American professional sports to restart competition since the coronavirus pandemic halted most events in March.

headline: The Most Popular Properties of March
abstract: The most viewed listings on The New York Times’s 'Find a Home' site in March are an unusual collection of residential and business spaces
lead_paragraph: With many sellers pulling their homes from the market during the coronavirus pandemic, the most viewed listings in March on The New York Times’s Find a Home site are an unusual collection of residential and business spaces.

headline: Did You Get Married During the Coronavirus Pandemic?
abstract: If you were recently married or plan to get married during this outbreak, we want to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: Although many couples have postponed their weddings because of the coronavirus, others across America are still finding ways to get married, even with stay-at-home orders and countrywide lockdowns. We recently shared the stories of several couples married, against the odds.

headline: E.P.A. Weakens Controls on Mercury
abstract: The agency is changing the way it calculates the benefits of mercury controls, a move that would effectively loosen the rules on other toxic pollutants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Thursday  weakened regulations on the release of mercury and other toxic metals from oil and coal-fired power plants, another step toward rolling back health protections in the middle of a pandemic.

headline: ‘So … Who’s In?’
abstract: Robyn Weintraub is here with a bear, available for hugs.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — We’re all going through phases of coping right now, and it’s fascinating to be able to instantly see people’s emotional pulses because of modern technology. (Although, sampling — we’re mostly seeing the pulses of those who choose to broadcast them, which is a noisy minority.) I’m in the phase where all the clues relate to quarantine (um, “Who’s in?”) and all my puns go there too. EGRETS? I have a few — I have been obsessing over the muffin that I left on my desk “overnight” at work a month ago.

headline: There’s No Place Like Home (Theater)
abstract: With real theaters closed, our critic unlocked handcuffs, tried to land a plane and accidentally scalded herself, all while attempting immersive performances from her Brooklyn apartment.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, my best friend called and I let it go to voice mail. “Sorry,” I texted. “Rescuing a lady in Caracas.” Then I went back to Googling how to escape police handcuffs.

headline: Facebook-Backed Libra Cryptocurrency Project Is Scaled Back
abstract: After months of criticism, the cryptocurrency is moving ahead with significant revisions.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Facebook unveiled its Libra cryptocurrency project last June, the social networking company described it as a futuristic global money that could serve as the foundation for a new kind of financial system.

headline: Lee Konitz, Jazz Saxophonist Who Blazed His Own Trail, Dies at 92
abstract: He was a pioneer of the cool school, but he resisted pigeonholing and focused on “making a personal statement.” He died of complications of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: A Gloomy Prediction on How Much Poverty Could Rise
abstract: Researchers suggest the poverty rate may reach the highest levels in half a century, hitting African-Americans and children hardest.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic crippling the American economy portends a sharp increase in poverty, to a level that could exceed that of the Great Recession and that may even reach a high for the half-century in which there is comparable data, according to researchers at Columbia University.

headline: Italy Covid Map and Case Count
abstract: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
lead_paragraph: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.

headline: Roommates or Partner Getting on Your Nerves? Read This
abstract: Talk about things early and often so they don’t boil over.
lead_paragraph: With most of the country under lockdown, many of us are suddenly spending our entire day with the people we live with — meaning tensions can be running hotter than normal. While a small transgression, like an interruption during a work call, may not be a big deal on its own, in the pressure cooker of lockdown it can go from a minor annoyance to the source of real strife. And if social media posts are any indication, jigsaw puzzles are the new Ikea furniture: the truest test of a couple’s stress levels.

headline: I Always Wanted to Be a Stepmom
abstract: Despite negative cultural baggage, I find stepmotherhood to be the greatest privilege.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Aug. 19, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Is That Mom in the Mirror Really Me?
abstract: Accepting your new, postpartum body can be a struggle, but strive to avoid negative self-talk — and remember that self-care is not selfish.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Aug. 20, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Is Tongue-Tie Surgery Necessary for Breastfeeding Success?
abstract: A growing number of infants are undergoing corrective procedures for tongue-tie, but a new study suggests that surgery isn’t always ideal.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on July 11, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Asthma Is Absent Among Top Covid-19 Risk Factors, Early Data Shows
abstract: Despite warnings that asthmatics were at higher risk for severe illness from the coronavirus, asthma is showing up in only about five percent of New York State’s fatal Covid cases.
lead_paragraph: For people with asthma, the outbreak of a pandemic that can lead to respiratory failure has not been a welcome event. Many health organizations have cautioned that asthmatics are most likely at higher risk for severe illness if they get the coronavirus. There’s been a run on inhalers, and coronavirus patients like the actor Idris Elba have openly worried about their asthma.

headline: Israel Edges Closer to 4th Election as Unity Talks Falter
abstract: After a year of political deadlock, lawmakers have just 21 days to come up with a formula for a majority government.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli president on Thursday handed the task of forming a government to Parliament, starting a 21-day countdown that could lead to new elections, after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his chief rival, Benny Gantz, missed another midnight deadline to reach a power-sharing agreement.

headline: A Tale of Two Possible Recoveries
abstract: An economist sees two divergent pathways after the current downturn. Which is more likely? He doesn’t know, so here are both of them.
lead_paragraph: As an economist, I’m often asked during recessions to divine the path of the recovery that will follow. In the current Covid-19 downturn, I find myself of two minds on this question. I thought I would share them both.

headline: Music, Theater and More to Experience at Home This Weekend
abstract: Our writers offer suggestions for what to watch, read or listen to while we’re housebound.
lead_paragraph: The composer and multi-instrumentalist Arthur Russell, who died in 1992, is now firmly part of pop’s canon. Kanye West has sampled him. Dev Hynes (a.k.a. Blood Orange) has called Russell an inspiration. (You can see how that influence operates when Hynes moves between pop releases and collaborations with cutting-edge classical groups like Third Coast Percussion.)

headline: Reporters Grounded by Pandemic Lose ‘That Window Into the Campaign’
abstract: The boys (and girls) aren’t on the bus. That means no face-to-face interviews with swing-state voters, no hotel-bar meetings with political operatives and reports with less texture.
lead_paragraph: As the dedicated Bernie Sanders reporter for BuzzFeed News, Ruby Cramer spent months trailing the Vermont senator around the country, flying on his campaign plane, watching him kibitz with voters, and cultivating his political advisers over meals in more than a dozen states.

headline: Von Miller Is Second Active N.F.L. Player to Reveal He Has Coronavirus
abstract: On Thursday Miller, through an agent, publicly confirmed having tested positive for the virus, a day after Rams center Brian Miller did the same.
lead_paragraph: Von Miller, the Denver Broncos’ All-Pro linebacker and the winner of the Most Valuable Player Award in Super Bowl 50, on Thursday became the latest and most prominent N.F.L. player to reveal publicly that he had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Richard Passman, Space-Age Engineer Who Kept His Secrets, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Passman had a leadership role in many of the technologies that gave the United States strength in aircraft, spy satellites and missiles.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: United Kingdom Covid Map and Case Count
abstract: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
lead_paragraph: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.

headline: A Tiny Hospital Struggles to Treat a Burst of Coronavirus Patients
abstract: Rural hospitals have few or no intensive care beds, ventilators or critical care specialists. Here’s how one hospital, with a single doctor caring for inpatients, handled a Covid-19 surge.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Desmond Wah is used to being the only physician tending to patients during his shifts at Margaret Mary Community Hospital in Batesville, Ind., population 6,500, where at least half of the 25 beds are usually empty. But he was hardly prepared for the weeklong shift he started on March 20, when the two counties Batesville straddles became one of rural America’s worst coronavirus hot spots.

headline: How to Find (and Discuss) Natural Wines
abstract: These bottles are made in small lots and are difficult to find. But here are five importers and five American producers to seek out, and some terminology to know.
lead_paragraph: Natural wines don’t easily fit as quick recommendations. They are generally made in minute quantities, which makes specific bottles hard to find.

headline: France Defines Natural Wine, but Is That Enough?
abstract: The wine industry and many consumers have long sought a definition, but the adoption of a voluntary charter may not clarify anything.
lead_paragraph: Natural wine is healthy and pure; natural wine is wretched and horrible. It’s the future of wine; it’s the death of wine.

headline: ‘Bosch’ and ‘Fauda’: The Platonic Ideal of the Tough Guy
abstract: Harry Bosch, in Amazon’s Los Angeles cop procedural, and Doron Kavillio, in Netflix’s Israeli counterterrorism thriller, would have a lot to talk about if they weren’t so laconic.
lead_paragraph: It’s April, so I must be writing about “Bosch.” This is the fifth straight year I’ve taken note of a new season (now the sixth) of Amazon Prime Video’s Los Angeles cop show based on Michael Connelly’s Harry Bosch novels. It’s an indulgence in a time when many worthwhile series go unremarked. This year, I can rationalize it as coronavirus-related: “Bosch” is my comfort show, the one I binge the day it’s available. On Friday I’ll be quarantined in my happy place.

headline: Michael Che of ‘S.N.L.’ Wants to Pay Rent for 160 N.Y.C. Families
abstract: The comedian is offering help to residents in the public housing building where his grandmother, who died of the coronavirus, once lived.
lead_paragraph: Michael Che, a comedian who co-hosts “Weekend Update” on “Saturday Night Live,” has a close connection to New York City’s public housing system: He grew up in it, and last year, he organized a comedy show to raise money for its residents.

headline: Thomas Miller, Hit-Making TV Producer, Is Dead at 79
abstract: “Happy Days,” “Laverne & Shirley” and “Full House” were among his shows. And he found the right guy to play the Fonz.
lead_paragraph: Garry Marshall, the noted producer and director, was talking about the best-known character in one of his best-known television shows.

headline: Companies With High Debt Are Paying a Price
abstract: For years, corporations bolstered their share prices by buying back stock with borrowed money. That practice may be catching up with some of them.
lead_paragraph: With enormous daily declines and rallies in the stock market alternating with dizzying frequency, reliable conclusions about the market’s prospects are hard to come by.

headline: How to Substitute Flours
abstract: Can’t find all-purpose flour? Out of whole-wheat? Here’s what you can use instead.
lead_paragraph: Baking is a science, but that doesn’t mean it’s impossible to make substitutions. With some guidance, you’ll be able to substitute different flours into a single recipe. But you’ll just want to keep a few things in mind, notably protein content and the moisture. This guide is by no means comprehensive — it may not answer your questions about oat flour — but consider it a starting off point to help you understand what you’re working with.

headline: Obesity Linked to Severe Coronavirus Disease, Especially for Younger Patients
abstract: Young adults with obesity are more likely to be hospitalized, even if they have no other health problems, studies show.
lead_paragraph: Obesity may be one of the most important predictors of severe coronavirus illness, new studies say. It’s an alarming finding for the United States, which has one of the highest obesity rates in the world.

headline: I’ve Never Given Birth – But I’ve Done My Share of ‘Parenting’
abstract: In communities like the one I grew up in, nannies are a rarity, but a ‘village’ of neighbors and relatives can be counted on to pitch in with child care.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Oct. 14, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Add Some Tuna to Your Puttanesca
abstract: Throw a can into this classic pasta dish for a little more body.
lead_paragraph: An anchovy- and olive-laden pasta puttanesca lacks for nothing. It’s garlicky and deeply savory, and you can make it in well under 30 minutes. But adding a can of tuna gives it body and heft. Which means that, if you don’t have — or don’t like — anchovies, you can leave them out without making the sauce even a little less compelling.

headline: U.K. Paid $20 Million for New Coronavirus Tests. They Didn’t Work.
abstract: Facing a global scramble for materials, British officials bought millions of unproven kits from China in a gamble that became an embarrassment.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The two Chinese companies were offering a risky proposition: two million home test kits said to detect antibodies for the coronavirus for at least $20 million, take it or leave it.

headline: ‘Selah and the Spades’ Review: This Isn’t Your Average Teen Drama
abstract: New talent behind and in front of the camera elevates a familiar tale of high-school strife.
lead_paragraph: In the exceptionally composed drama “Selah and the Spades,” high school is a battleground where cliques are locked in a struggle for control of the social scene. For the moment, the Spades dominate a fictitious Pennsylvania boarding school called Haldwell, and they are effectively commanded by Selah (Lovie Simone), a senior gifted in strategic maneuvers.

headline: Disposable N95 Masks Can Be Decontaminated, Researchers Confirm
abstract: Several methods are effective at killing the new coronavirus on N95 masks — primary protective gear for health care workers — for two or three rounds of use.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have confirmed that there are several effective methods for decontaminating the N95 masks worn by health professionals so that they can be used more than once, the National Institutes of Health announced Wednesday.

headline: ‘There’s No More Water’: Climate Change on a Drying Island
abstract: A delicate ecosystem was disrupted in the Comoros, off East Africa, when forests were cleared to make way for farmland. The consequences offer lessons for other parts of the developing world.
lead_paragraph: COMOROS — Hundreds of brightly clad women flock to the banks of the river each week to scrub their way through bundles of laundry. Some of them travel hours from tiny villages to access a critical but increasingly endangered resource here on the island of Anjouan: water.

headline: FOMO Has Survived the Coronavirus
abstract: No one is going anywhere cool, and yet I still feel left out.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: George Soros’s Foundation Pledges $130 Million in Coronavirus Relief
abstract: The billionaire philanthropist is directing $37 million of the funds to programs to help at-risk populations in New York City.
lead_paragraph: George Soros, the billionaire philanthropist and liberal financier, is directing more than $130 million through his foundation to combat the effects of the coronavirus, with $37 million aimed to help at-risk populations in New York City, including undocumented families and low-wage workers.

headline: How to Name a Champion Without the Championship
abstract: Sports around the world may not be able to finish their seasons. Plus a plan to shorten cycling’s Grand Tour races, and celebrate an unconventional National Signing Day.
lead_paragraph: At some point, leagues and sports around the world may have to come to the reluctant conclusion that they will never finish their seasons. They will then have to determine what the final results are and who, if anyone, will be crowned champion.

headline: Viewing Party! Let’s All Watch ‘Groundhog Day’ Together!
abstract: OK, film fans, rise and shine. It’s a new movie day. Or is it?
lead_paragraph: What day is it? A lot of us are having trouble with that very basic question, since every day just seems to repeat the one before, from the moment the alarm clock goes off. Is this an elaborate existential joke, or some kind of moral test? Are we in a movie? Is it “Groundhog Day”? How many times have we seen that one? Maybe it’s time to see it again.

headline: U.S. Sends Funds to Needy Nations to Fight the Virus, but Maybe Not for Masks
abstract: The Trump administration is working to secure masks, plastic gloves and other protective medical equipment for Americans first as the pandemic sweeps around the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering new rules that would limit how American humanitarian aid is used to buy masks, plastic gloves and other protective medical equipment to combat the coronavirus in some of the world’s neediest nations.

headline: Why Michael Savage Is Blasting Hannity and the Right-Wing Media on the Virus
abstract: Mr. Savage, the conservative radio host, is still loyal to President Trump but says right-wing media got it all wrong by doubting the severity of the coronavirus early on.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of people who are ruining the country right now, according to Michael Savage. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. Liberal mayors in big cities like San Francisco. Undocumented immigrants. Homeless people.

headline: Find Cassavetes Confusing? Start Here
abstract: The director was a crucial influence in indie film. And there’s magic in his madness, as “A Woman Under the Influence” shows.
lead_paragraph: What on earth is going on in the films of John Cassavetes? Any movie lover is bound to confront that question, perhaps under a cloud of misconceptions and secondhand impressions. Maybe you heard that Cassavetes, a critical figure in American independent film, had ushered in a new era of realism in movies. Maybe you saw “Shadows,” which inaugurated the actor’s directorial career in the late 1950s, and believed its closing title card: “The film you have just seen was an improvisation.” (It wasn’t, at least in any meaningful sense; the “Shadows” most of us know revised an earlier feature.)

headline: Virus Forces a ‘Wartime’ Budget on N.Y.C., With $2 Billion in Cuts
abstract: With the city projecting a $7.4 billion loss in tax revenue, municipal services that “can’t be a priority right now” are being slashed, Mayor de Blasio said.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus pandemic ravaging New York’s economy, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Thursday that the city will be forced to slash more than $2 billion in municipal services over the next year.

headline: ‘#blackAF’ Review: A Second Portrait of the Artist, With More Scars
abstract: The creator of “black-ish” arrives on Netflix, playing “himself” in an outspoken show with a lot of familiar echoes.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, Kenya Barris premiered “black-ish,” an ABC comedy inspired partly by his own experience, in which Anthony Anderson plays a black Los Angeles advertising professional who grew up poor, grappling with raising privileged children in a not-really-postracial society. It generated spinoffs — “grown-ish” and “mixed-ish” — and Barris landed a deal with Netflix.

headline: Brian Dennehy, Tony Award-Winning Actor, Dies at 81
abstract: A versatile star, he had scores of television and film credits and made a searing impression on Broadway in “Death of a Salesman.”
lead_paragraph: Brian Dennehy, a versatile stage and screen actor known for action movies, comedies and classics, but especially for his Tony Award-winning performances in “Death of a Salesman” in 1999 and “Long Day’s Journey Into Night” in 2003, died on Wednesday in New Haven, Conn. He was 81.

headline: Southwest Drought Rivals Those of Centuries Ago, Thanks to Climate Change
abstract: The drought that has gripped the American Southwest since 2000 is as bad as or worse than droughts in the region over the past 1,200 years, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — A severe drought that has gripped the American Southwest since 2000 is as bad as or worse than long-lasting droughts in the region over the past 1,200 years, and climate change has helped make it that way, scientists said Thursday.

headline: 15 Documentaries That Get Inside an Artist’s Head
abstract: Kick back with these movies old and new — and gain a new appreciation for artists from Alice Neel to Mark Hogancamp and Sun Ra.
lead_paragraph: You can’t beat art documentaries for sheer relatability. Watch the artists work, watch them succeed or fail, and then listen to their friends sort through the details. The list that follows is hardly an exhaustive introduction to the genre, but it’s a good batch of films guaranteed to transport you out of your living room, whether it’s to the glamour of the Mediterranean coast, to the excitement of a contemporary art auction, to the otherworldly ecstasy of a Sun Ra concert, or even to the squalid claustrophobia of Edvard Munch’s Norwegian adolescence.

headline: Did Moms Exist Before Social Media?
abstract: How the “mamasphere” went from scrappy blogs to multi-platform personal brands in the past decade.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Dec. 5, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: How L.O.L. Dolls Became the Dopamine Hit of a Generation
abstract: Meet the man behind the $5 billion toy juggernaut.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Dec. 17, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Trump Considers Billionaire Investor for Intelligence Job
abstract: Stephen Feinberg, who backed the president’s campaign, is said to be in talks for a top post in the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top intelligence appointment that President Trump is considering for a billionaire investor and prominent supporter could be only a short-term one, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Nora Illi, Swiss Muslim Convert Who Sparked Controversy, Dies at 35
abstract: When the first Swiss canton banned full-body veils for Muslim women, Ms. Illi showed up wearing one, prompting the police to get involved.
lead_paragraph: Nora Illi, a Swiss convert to Islam who believed Muslim women should have the right to wear full-body veils and publicly challenged bans against them, died on March 23  in Bern, Switzerland. She was 35.

headline: Saying ‘No’ Is Self-Care for Parents
abstract: Facing parental burnout? Use the magic word.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Oct. 18, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: When Your Name Becomes ‘Mom,’ Do Your Other Identities Matter?
abstract: Finding the road back to yourself after parenthood takes over.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago — either I was pregnant with my son, Will, or he was a newborn; it all starts to blend together — our family went to visit friends, and my daughter, Maggie, was playing dress-up with her pal Sofia. Maggie was wearing an Elsa costume while Sofia was dressed like her Disney namesake, Sofia the First. I guess it was time to switch outfits, but I had been talking with my friend, so I didn’t notice when Maggie couldn’t get her arm into the sleeve of whatever princess gown she was fawning over at the moment. Suddenly, I felt a little hand tugging at my arm. It was Sofia. “Ummm, Maggie’s mom? She needs help.”

headline: This Simple Five-Ingredient Pasta Has Loads of Flavor
abstract: You don’t need much to yield a lot of deliciousness — just a creamy base and a willingness to experiment.
lead_paragraph: Every kitchen has at least one or two (or 10) specialty ingredients taking up space in the fridge or pantry. But if you broaden your scope, they can add layers to your cooking in new and unexpected ways.

headline: What Everyone Can Learn From Parents of Big Families
abstract: When you’re parenting at scale, keeping things simple is key.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Jan. 9, 2020 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Why Do Parents Keep Hearing About the Microbiome?
abstract: Some companies are marketing baby soaps, lotions, supplements and more as being ‘biome-friendly.’ But there’s reason to be skeptical.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Oct. 17, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: How to Learn From a Plague
abstract: We study the AIDS-epidemic documentary “How to Survive a Plague” — and apply its lessons to the Covid-19 crisis.
lead_paragraph: Activists stood up against the AIDS epidemic in the 1980s and 1990s, but the tools they used to make themselves heard are unavailable during our coronavirus pandemic. Still, many of that era’s strategies and warning signs seem alarmingly relevant now.

headline: Impersonating Motherhood
abstract: I felt like a fraud as a new mom, until I looked at my literary idols for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: I was scheduled to attend a work conference six weeks after my daughter’s due date.

headline: What New Parents Should Know Before Tax Season
abstract: Here’s an overview of the child tax credit and other things you should know about as a new parent during open enrollment season.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Oct. 16, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Parents of Extremely Premature Babies Face an Impossible Choice
abstract: New technologies are making it possible for children to survive ever-earlier births. But who should decide when to fight for survival?
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Feb. 27, 2020 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Why Is My Baby So Hairy?
abstract: And other newborn oddities — like acne and excessive sneezing — demystified.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Jan. 7, 2020 in NYT Parenting.

headline: When Your Experience of Childbirth Doesn’t Match Your Expectations
abstract: The way you give birth is largely controlled by biology and luck. What didn’t go as planned wasn’t your fault.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on May 6, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: Does Anything Actually Make You Go Into Labor?
abstract: Most of the popular legends are more myth than fact, but there are a couple of interesting exceptions.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on May 6, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I took a walk this morning under cold, clear skies on mostly deserted streets, and goggled appreciatively at some puffed-up sparrows shimmying in a birdbath beneath sprays of gaudy yellow forsythia. Then I came home and opened my email and promptly misread the phrase “self-isolating” as “self-immolating.”

headline: Zoom Shivas and Prayer Hotlines: Ultra-Orthodox Jewish Traditions Upended by Coronavirus
abstract: Hundreds of ultra-Orthodox Jews are estimated to have died in Brooklyn. Here’s how the pandemic is changing their longstanding rituals.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of ultra-Orthodox Jews are estimated to have died in Brooklyn. Here’s how the pandemic is changing their longstanding rituals.

headline: Cedric Dixon, Towering Detective in Harlem, Dies at 48
abstract: His death in March is believed to be the first of a sworn New York City police officer caused by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: What Do You Say When Someone Loses Their Job?
abstract: Until he was laid off, Clint was ranked No. 1 in the state among his employer’s sales personnel. He has bonuses and awards to prove it.
lead_paragraph: The gym where my partner worked closed its doors on March 17, the day Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona echoed to business owners in the state the social-distancing recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to limit gatherings to fewer than 10 people.

headline: Does the Pandemic Have a Purpose?
abstract: Only if we give it one. The coronavirus is neither good nor bad. It wants only to reproduce.
lead_paragraph: Nature doesn’t care about you. That may seem harsh, but strictly speaking, nature doesn’t care about anyone or anything, except passing genes into the next generation. We know this if we’ve studied evolution. It was Darwin’s great achievement to explain the adaptation of organisms without appeal to God’s design or mystical idealism. Darwinian evolution is true (corroborated by mountains of evidence), but it’s also a cold metaphysics. The biologist Stephen Jay Gould described it as a “cold bath view” of nature — not warm and fuzzy in the way religion characterizes nature.

headline: New York Lawmaker Asks for Probe Into Ticketing Refund Policies
abstract: As consumers seek refunds for events postponed because of the pandemic, one state senator has taken action, and the concert giant AEG has set a window for returning fans’ money.
lead_paragraph: A New York lawmaker on Thursday expressed concern about consumer accusations that Ticketmaster had changed its refund policy in the midst of the pandemic, and asked the state attorney general to open a formal investigation into the company.

headline: 31 Deaths: Toll at Quebec Nursing Home in Pandemic Reflects Global Phenomenon
abstract: Investigators are examining accusations of gross negligence after dozens of deaths at a residence where health care staff fled amid a coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Thirty-one people were found dead in less than a month at a nursing home in Montreal, at least five confirmed to have coronavirus — a powerful Canadian emblem of how nursing homes are among the places hardest hit by the pandemic.

headline: ‘Beyond the Visible: Hilma af Klint’ Review: What Did She See, and When?
abstract: How the rediscovery of a Swedish abstract painter changed the course of art history.
lead_paragraph: The career-spanning exhibition of the work of Hilma af Klint that toured the world a few years ago — including a sojourn at the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan — upended the conventional narrative of modern art history. This is hardly an academic matter. As Roberta Smith wrote in her review of the Guggenheim show, af Klint’s “paintings definitively explode the notion of modernist abstraction as a male project” — a revolution thought to have started with Vasily Kandinsky and Piet Mondrian in the years just before World War I and carried to heroic fruition by the likes of Mark Rothko and Jackson Pollock after World War II.

headline: I Used to Run 20 Miles at a Time. Now I’m Tracing a GPS Snail.
abstract: Thanks to France’s coronavirus rules, I’m trapped in a 0.6-mile radius. It’s not all bad.
lead_paragraph: FORCALQUIER, France — Last Saturday, I got pulled over by the police for the first time ever. I was running, not driving, when the dark blue van pulled up behind me and the officer told me to stop on the side of a dusty road in Provence. My heart was already pumping hard from the steady incline, but my breath quickened when they asked where I lived and requested my “attestation.”

headline: For Mark Meadows, Transition From Trump Confidant to Chief of Staff Is a Hard One
abstract: Weeks into the job, Mr. Meadows has confronted the same problems that frustrated his three predecessors. It hasn’t helped him with his new White House colleagues that he’s emotional and sometimes cries.
lead_paragraph: Mark Meadows has officially been President Trump’s fourth White House chief of staff for less than three weeks.

headline: Live From Her Kitchen, Pelosi Works to Counter Trump’s Coronavirus Show
abstract: The speaker and Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader, have begun a media blitz to present an alternative message to the president’s lengthy daily briefings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi doesn’t bother watching President Trump’s lengthy daily televised briefings on the coronavirus pandemic. “I don’t watch his shows,” she said in an interview Wednesday. “I don’t have time to watch him contradict himself from one day to the next.”

headline: Silent Signs Your Child Is Stressed
abstract: We asked experts which symptoms may indicate a kid is struggling — and how to treat them.
lead_paragraph: The day after her school closed its doors for social distancing, a canker sore developed in my daughter’s mouth.

headline: No Respite in Yemen War a Week After Saudi Cease-Fire Announced
abstract: Yemen’s warring parties have not stopped attacks, United Nations officials said, adding that aid money is running out even as the coronavirus emerges in what is the Arab world’s poorest country.
lead_paragraph: Despite some optimism for new talks, antagonists in Yemen’s five-year-old war have basically ignored a Saudi-led unilateral cease-fire announced a week ago, United Nations officials said Thursday, warning that relief money for Yemen is running out just as the coronavirus has invaded.

headline: Someone Has Died. That’s When Their Job Begins.
abstract: Funeral directors are risking their lives to care for Covid-19 victims.
lead_paragraph: It’s 8:30 p.m. and Sherry Bensimon, a funeral director at Riverside Memorial Chapels of New Jersey, in Hackensack, is still at work. A colleague who just returned from Hackensack University Medical Center tells her that the hospital’s refrigerated trailers, one of which arrived that day, were already at capacity. Each holds about 50 bodies — and that’s in addition to the hospital’s two morgues. “They’re full already?” Ms. Bensimon’s voice cracks. “Oh God.”

headline: One: Wonderland
abstract: A young man finds escape on the internet. He doesn’t realize that on the other side of the screen, a force is pulling him in.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Spotify

headline: Can’t Scout Players in Person? The N.F.L. Turns to a Brooklyn Start-Up
abstract: Ahead of the N.F.L. draft, which begins on April 23, teams are reaching out to the three-man team at Slants to provide tracking data based on college video footage.
lead_paragraph: For the past month, since the N.F.L. banned nonessential travel and shuttered team facilities, many coaches, scouts and other player evaluators have had to rely primarily on watching footage of college games in the hopes of finding a franchise-lifting selection in the N.F.L. draft that starts on April 23.

headline: Why Trump’s Threat to Adjourn Congress Is Dubious
abstract: The president made another attention-grabbing claim about his purported powers amid the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump made another head-turning claim of executive power in the middle of a briefing about the Covid-19 pandemic — threatening on Wednesday to force Congress to adjourn so that he may unilaterally install judicial nominees and other officials who would typically require Senate confirmation.

headline: Welcome to the ‘Rabbit Hole’
abstract: Introducing an audio series about how the internet is changing, and how it’s changing us.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I saw something on Twitter that annoyed me. It was an article from a local Ohio news site, describing a small crowd that had gathered outside the statehouse to protest the state’s coronavirus shutdowns. They were urging the governor to ignore social distancing guidelines and open the state for business, a move that could endanger public health and potentially put thousands of Ohioans’ lives at risk.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Japan's state of emergency, South Korea's elections, China's GDP
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan declared a nationwide state of emergency as coronavirus cases in the country continued a monthlong sharp rise that pushed its total past 8,000.

headline: ‘Corona-Shamed’: George Stephanopoulos, J. Lo — Maybe You?
abstract: Ivanka Trump, Chris Cuomo and all kinds of private citizens are getting roasted on social media for perceived failures of public hygiene.
lead_paragraph: On April 10, the television anchor George Stephanopoulos went to a pharmacy in East Hampton, N.Y., wearing a mask and gloves, nine days after his wife, the actress Ali Wentworth, revealed she had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: The Difference Between Copyrights, Trademarks and Patents
abstract: Whether you’re an inventor, a writer or an artist, you need to know what these each mean — and which you need to protect your work.
lead_paragraph: “It felt like my heart was being ripped out.”

headline: In Spain, Children Still Can’t Go Outside
abstract: Children have been kept in their homes since mid-March as the country battles the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: “Zizzer zay zay!” my toddler demands, running around the kitchen brandishing a wooden spoon. Since the lockdown, we’ve made lasagna twice. He became instantly addicted, except he can’t quite pronounce the word. “We’ll make more soon,” I promise. “Zizzer zay zaaaaaaay!” he shrieks, stomping with rage. If I remember one word from this pandemic, this will be the one.

headline: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Challenging Censorship of Writings by Ex-Officials
abstract: The plaintiffs will appeal. They argued that a system that requires review before publication is unconstitutionally “dysfunctional.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Thursday dismissed a novel lawsuit challenging a censorship system the government uses to ensure that millions of former military and intelligence officials disclose no classified secrets if they write articles and books after leaving public service.

headline: Brian Dennehy Found the Tragic Grandeur in Ordinary Lives
abstract: Remembering an actor of uncommon power who gave heroic stature to a character crippled by depression in “Death of a Salesman.”
lead_paragraph: On a November night, 22 years ago, fresh off a plane from New York, I walked into the Goodman Theater in Chicago and straight into the depths of depression. I felt privileged to be there. Because my guide that evening into the state of paralyzing unhappiness was Brian Dennehy, who was making one man’s inner darkness uncannily visible as the title character of Arthur Miller’s “Death of a Salesman.”

headline: U.K. Extends Lockdown 3 Weeks, With No Clear Exit Strategy
abstract: The government said lifting the lockdown now would risk the country’s progress, but its silence on how and when it would end sowed doubts about if there is a concrete plan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain confirmed on Thursday that it would prolong its lockdown for at least three more weeks as part of efforts to keep smothering the spread of the coronavirus. But the government was far less clear about the steps it is taking that would allow it to relax restrictions later without causing another outbreak.

headline: Doctors Press F.D.A. to Let More Gay Men Donate Blood
abstract: A letter signed by more than 500 medical professionals cited recent fears of a blood shortage during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: More than 500 doctors, researchers and public health specialists are calling on the Food and Drug Administration to eliminate constraints on blood donations by gay and bisexual men, saying the agency did not go far enough when it relaxed its restrictions earlier this month.

headline: Voting by Mail: Expand It for November?
abstract: Readers discuss Republican opposition to voting by mail, establishing online voting and recruiting younger poll workers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Behind the Cover: At the Epicenter
abstract: For this issue, a look inside the underfunded, overwhelmed public hospitals that are trying to save New York.

headline: Straggling in a Good Economy, and Now Struggling in a Crisis
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has shown how close to the edge many Americans were living, with pay and benefits eroding even as corporate profits surged.
lead_paragraph: An indelible image from the Great Depression features a well-dressed family seated with their dog in a comfy car, smiling down from an oversize billboard on weary souls standing in line at a relief agency. “World’s highest standard of living,” the billboard boasts, followed by a tagline: “There’s no way like the American Way.”

headline: Starve the Beast, Feed the Depression
abstract: Anti-government ideology is crippling pandemic policy.
lead_paragraph: So Donald Trump’s name will, in a break with all previous practice, appear on the checks that will slightly mitigate the Donald Trump depression caused by the Donald Trump pandemic. Hey, we’re supposed to put his name on everything, right?

headline: Glenna Goodacre, Created Vietnam Women’s Memorial, Dies at 80
abstract: A sculptor and one of the few women to make large public monuments, she also commemorated the Irish famine in a massive bronze piece in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: When Glenna Goodacre was a student and interested in becoming a sculptor, her art teacher discouraged her. He gave her a grade of “D,” told her that she had no ability to see in three dimensions and advised her to switch to painting.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Stuck inside? Of course you are. Our critic has recommendations based on the things you might be longing for.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter, aimed at your needs, desires and tastes. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Acts of Kindness, Internet Habits and Where They’d Like to Be Stranded
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to tell us about acts of kindness they have observed since the onset of the coronavirus. We also wanted to know how their internet habits have changed and where they would like to be stranded during the pandemic.

headline: A View From Qatar: How We’re Responding to the Coronavirus
abstract: The deputy director of the Government Communications Office details the country’s actions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Boeing to Restart Production in Washington State With 27,000 Workers
abstract: The aerospace giant said employees in the Puget Sound area would begin manufacturing commercial planes by the end of next week.
lead_paragraph: Boeing plans to resume commercial airplane production in Washington State by bringing about 27,000 employees back to work, the company said on Thursday. Most will return by the end of next week.

headline: Will There Be More Coronavirus Stimulus Checks?
abstract: Members of Congress are already talking about the next relief package. What should be in it?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Warming Climate in Norway Reveals Relics of Ancient Viking Trade Route
abstract: Melting ice has receded from a mountain pass, unearthing pelts, shoes and stone structures from thousands of years ago.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — Ice patches that melted from the slopes of a remote mountain pass in Norway have revealed artifacts that provide new insight into the livelihood of hunters, traders and travelers along a route thousands of years old, archaeologists said this month.

headline: Where Do You Go for a Walk?
abstract: Taking a walk is a good distraction from an endless stream of news about the coronavirus outbreak. How do you feel when you take a walk? We’d like to hear about it.
lead_paragraph: Gatherings are banned. Restaurants are closed. Concerts are canceled. States across the country have issued shelter-in-place orders, and illnesses and job losses continue to grow. Many Americans are spending most of their time at home with few options left to distract them from the relentless drumbeat of bad news, except for maybe a walk outside.

headline: Big Government or Big Hassle?
abstract: Democrats believe the pandemic could usher in a broad consensus around the need for more publicly funded programs, but there are some signs that the virus’s political impact could tip the other way.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Those We’ve Lost
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has taken an incalculable death toll. This series is designed to put names and faces to the numbers.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has taken an incalculable death toll. This series is designed to put names and faces to the numbers.

headline: Democrats Show Fund-Raising Energy in Key Senate Races
abstract: In contests in Kentucky, South Carolina, Kansas, Maine, Colorado and Arizona, Democratic candidates raised more money in the first quarter of 2020 than their Republican opponents.
lead_paragraph: Money poured into Senate contests across the country in the first three months of the year, bolstering some Democrats’ war chests in key races favoring Republicans, including those in which Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, and Senator Lindsey Graham, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, are seeking re-election.

headline: Jobs, Contact Tracing, Mercury Regulations: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Faces That Can’t Be Forgotten
abstract: How the Obituaries desk is memorializing victims of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Loan Money Runs Out While Small-Business Owners Wait in Line
abstract: Frustrated with the process and banks, they have to figure out how to stay afloat while Congress tries to come up with more funding.
lead_paragraph: The $349 billion government program meant to keep small businesses afloat during the pandemic and economic meltdown ran out of money on Thursday — even as many small-business owners were desperately trying to apply for loans. Now they are trying to figure out how to keep their businesses alive while Congress negotiates the possible release of additional rescue funds.

headline: Texas Republicans Have Spectacularly Failed the Coronavirus Test
abstract: My faith in their ability to fix this mess is lower than the water levels in West Texas creek beds in August.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Usually, I think the eternal optimism I inherited from my father is a blessing, especially now, when faced with many more weeks under pandemic house arrest. The memory of Dad’s perpetual hopefulness has helped me to remind myself that this, too, will pass, and that maybe we as a society will emerge stronger and wiser.

headline: The Age of Coddling Is Over
abstract: Learning what hardship has to teach us.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decades, a tide of “safetyism” has crept over American society. As Greg Lukianoff and Jonathan Haidt put it in their book “The Coddling of the American Mind,” this is the mentality that whatever doesn’t kill you makes you weaker. The goal is to eliminate any stress or hardship a child might encounter, so he or she won’t be wounded by it.

headline: Wisconsin Voters Faced an Impossible Choice. It Shouldn’t Happen Again.
abstract: Americans need not risk their health to cast their ballots.
lead_paragraph: It was as gratifying as it was unexpected to watch Wisconsin’s Republican lawmakers — who have repeatedly ignored if not erased the political voices of their own constituents — take a drubbing at the hands of the voters themselves.

headline: Judge Denies Roger Stone’s Bid for a New Trial
abstract: The judge rejected the defense’s argument of juror bias in a politically fraught case in which President Trump publicly attacked his friend’s conviction.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on Roger Stone’s sentence being commuted by President Trump.]

headline: Loyal Trump Backer Is Now a Face of the Administration’s Virus Response
abstract: The loyalty of the longtime Trump adviser Michael Caputo helped him secure a post as the top public affairs official at the Health and Human Services Department during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: He attacked allegations of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia and wrote a book and produced a documentary during impeachment that were both titled “The Ukraine Hoax.” He has accused former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son of profiting off his father’s name.

headline: 29 Dead at One Nursing Home From the Virus. Or More. No One Will Say.
abstract: What is happening inside a Queens nursing home hit by the outbreak? Relatives of residents said there was a disturbing lack of information.
lead_paragraph: Berna Lee got the call from the nursing home in Queens on April 3: Her mother had a fever, nothing serious. She was assured that there were no cases of coronavirus in the home. Then she started calling workers there.

headline: House Democrats Back Changing Rules to Allow Remote Voting During Pandemic
abstract: If approved by the House, the switch to proxy voting would be the first time in the history of Congress that lawmakers could cast votes other than in person.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday threw her support behind a plan to allow House members to cast votes by proxy, conceding for the first time that the coronavirus pandemic that has forced Congress into an extended recess would require historic modifications to how the institution has operated for centuries.

headline: Tracking Trump’s Promises on Responding to the Virus
abstract: The president has promised enhanced testing and monitoring capabilities, thousands of ventilators and millions of masks. Here’s a status report.
lead_paragraph: Coronavirus testing will be available in commercial parking lots and can be found through a few clicks on a website. Millions of masks and “more ventilators than we need” will be delivered imminently. Monitoring capabilities for the next phase of the pandemic are on the way.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Has a Plan for Joe Biden
abstract: To achieve affordable health care for everyone, he should look closely at the ideas of his former rival.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden has made overtures to progressive Democrats by saying he’ll upgrade his campaign’s health plan. Specifically, after peace talks with Senator Bernie Sanders, he vowed to add a provision to open up Medicare to Americans aged 60 and over (the current age is 65).

headline: Trump Says States Can Start Reopening While Acknowledging the Decision Is Theirs
abstract: The guidelines released by the president effectively mean that any restoration of American society will take place on a patchwork basis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump told the nation’s governors on Thursday that they could begin reopening businesses, restaurants and other elements of daily life by May 1 or earlier if they wanted to, but abandoned his threat to use what he had claimed was his absolute authority to impose his will on them.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Public health officials say robust contact tracing is a must for reopening the economy. It’s finally starting in the United States.
lead_paragraph: No matter how well we all practice social distancing, Covid-19 is unlikely to completely disappear. So to safely return to something like normalcy, society needs to be able to spot and swiftly contain new cases that pop up.

headline: Jimmy Webb, Purveyor of Punk Fashion, Is Dead at 62
abstract: He wasn’t a rocker himself, but as the manager of the East Village clothing emporium Trash and Vaudeville, he was a proud bearer of the punk-glam torch.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Webb, the kindly, spindly-legged, leather-vested East Village fixture who was the longtime manager of Trash and Vaudeville, the rock ’n’ roll clothiers that once ruled St. Marks Place, died on Tuesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 62.

headline: Comfort Viewing: Three Reasons I Love the Movie ‘Tangled’
abstract: A savvy princess, a swashbuckling thief and 70 feet of hair is exactly the fantasy we need right now.
lead_paragraph: Rapunzel is stuck at home. And she’s bored as hell.

headline: How to Get Your Partner to Take on More Emotional Labor
abstract: You can take concrete steps to more equitably divide emotional labor with your partner — starting with talking openly about the dynamic.
lead_paragraph: This guide was originally published on May 6, 2019.

headline: A Guide to the Universe of Milks
abstract: Whole or reduced-fat milk? Cow’s milk or plant-based milk? The options can be paralyzing when you need to feed your toddler. We’re here to help.
lead_paragraph: This guide was originally published on May 28, 2019.

headline: How to Safely Exercise During Pregnancy
abstract: The belief that it’s dangerous to exercise during pregnancy is common — but it’s wrong.
lead_paragraph: This guide was originally published on May 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: How to Feed a Combination of Breast Milk and Formula
abstract: New mothers hear so much about the advantages of breastfeeding over formula feeding that it can seem like a revelation to realize that you can do both at the same time.
lead_paragraph: This guide was originally published on May 5, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: When Do Babies Roll or Crawl?
abstract: Most parents track their children’s physical milestones, but may not know how much of a delay is too much.
lead_paragraph: This guide was originally published on May 13, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: How to Introduce Pets to Babies
abstract: Prepare your home and furry friends early on for the arrival of a new family member.
lead_paragraph: This guide was originally published on May 30, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Pandemic Consumer Spending
abstract: How has Covid-19 changed our spending habits?
lead_paragraph: The interactive graph above shows the percentage change in consumer spending by category for the week March 26 through April 1, 2020 over the same week in 2019. The graph is based on data on credit and debit cards purchases of nearly six million people in the United States, as tracked and analyzed by Earnest Research.

headline: Man Charged With Trying to Blow Up Jewish Assisted-Living Home
abstract: Federal prosecutors said that John Michael Rathbun tried to ignite a gas canister near the center in Massachusetts that had been targeted for attack on a white supremacist website.
lead_paragraph: A Massachusetts man was charged on Wednesday with trying to blow up a Jewish assisted-living center that had been targeted for attack on a white supremacist website that promoted a “Jew killing day,” federal prosecutors said.

headline: Understanding the Risks for Stillbirth, and Coping if It Happens to You
abstract: Stillbirth is rare but has a huge impact on families. It’s important to know the risk factors and warning signs.
lead_paragraph: While the risk of stillbirth is very low for average healthy mothers, statistics don’t matter if it’s your experience — or you fear it could be. It’s important to know the risk factors and warning signs.

headline: Yes, Even Introverts Can Be Lonely Right Now
abstract: Introverts crave connection, too — we just need more boundaries.
lead_paragraph: As an introvert, I thought I was immune to loneliness. I’ve been working remotely as long as I’ve been working. I enjoy the comfort of writing at home, the efficiency of not commuting and the freedom from interruptions by extroverted colleagues.

headline: How to Recognize Miscarriage Symptoms and Cope With the Aftermath
abstract: Miscarriage happens in up to 15 percent of pregnancies. Why aren’t we talking about it?
lead_paragraph: This guide was originally published on May 3, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

abstract: Maybe. Here’s what to know.

headline: China’s Economy Shrinks, Ending a Nearly Half-Century of Growth
abstract: The contraction comes at a time when the rest of the world needs an economic boost, underscoring how momentous the task of reviving the global economy will be.

abstract: And why there’s still a staggering lack of data for doctors to reference.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Dec. 17, 2019 on NYT Parenting.
