headline: What You Get for $3 Million in California
abstract: A cottage-style home in the Hollywood Hills, a Craftsman house in Santa Barbara and a midcentury-modern retreat in Ojai.
lead_paragraph: A cottage-style home in the Hollywood Hills, a Craftsman house in Santa Barbara and a midcentury-modern retreat in Ojai.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A cottage-style home in the Hollywood Hills, a Craftsman house in Santa Barbara and a midcentury-modern retreat in Ojai.
lead_paragraph: This cottage-style home in the Hollywood Hills is a 10-minute drive from the nightclubs and music venues of Hollywood, as well as the cafes and shopping of quieter Studio City. It is a five-minute drive from the base of the hiking trail at Runyon Canyon Park, one of the city’s most popular outdoor exercise spots.

headline: Singapore Seemed to Have Coronavirus Under Control, Until Cases Doubled
abstract: The spread suggests that it is unrealistic for the United States, Europe and the rest of the world to return to the way they were anytime soon, even if viral curves appear to flatten.
lead_paragraph: Singapore did almost everything right.

headline: Australia Moves to Force Google and Facebook to Compensate Media Outlets
abstract: The decision, announced after talks on a voluntary system stalled, is part of a global push to save local news organizations.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Australian government said on Monday that Google and Facebook would have to pay media outlets for news content in the country, part of an emerging global effort to rescue local publishers by moving to compel tech giants to share their advertising revenue.

headline: At Least 2 Dead as Severe Weather Sweeps Through the South
abstract: A 61-year-old man was killed in Alabama after his mobile home tumbled over, and one person died in Mississippi, officials said. Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas were in the path of strong storms on Monday.
lead_paragraph: At least two people died after severe weather brought hail and storms through Alabama, Mississippi and other Southern states on Sunday and Monday, the second consecutive weekend that dangerous storms swept through the region.

headline: Why Your Kid Cuddles Her Toothbrush
abstract: Or tissues, or a tin of Band-Aids, or a pile of pennies …
lead_paragraph: When my older daughter was 2, she would not fall asleep unless she had a “fresh tissue” balled up in each of her tiny fists. If she lost either tissue in the bedclothes, she would mewl, plaintively, “Fresh tisssuueeeeeeee,” until someone brought her a new one.

headline: Who Was Jerry Krause?
abstract: The villain of “The Last Dance” was a shrewd judge of talent who managed to antagonize many around him.
lead_paragraph: Every good narrative needs someone wearing the black hat, and in at least the first two episodes of “The Last Dance,” the ESPN documentary about Michael Jordan, that man is Jerry Krause.

headline: When Did We Start Taking Famous People Seriously?
abstract: Actors are giving us advice on parenting and politics — and vaccines?
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published on June 20, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

headline: A Hill of Beans
abstract: Pair them with rice, or with pasta, or as part of an avocado salad, or forgo them all together, and head to the grill.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’m lucky to have a grill out back, and it’s been put to good use of late: baby back ribs and beer-can chicken and hot slaw and glazed carrots and grilled peaches straight from the jar. Now it’s back to the uncomfortable chair and the rickety desk, my makeshift office a step from the bed, with sardines on crackers with a swipe of mayonnaise for lunch, and late dinners to follow: rice and beans; beans and rice; rice on beans (above). I play the legume catalog as if it were a binder of standards these days. I’m the Bucky Pizzarelli of beans.

headline: A Deep-Diving Sub. A Deadly Fire. And Russia’s Secret Undersea Agenda.
abstract: Few want to talk about how 14 sailors met their deaths on a Russian engineering marvel. Fewer still want to talk about what they were doing off Norway’s waters.
lead_paragraph: OFF THE COAST OF NORWAY — There could hardly have been a more terrifying place to fight a fire than in the belly of the Losharik, a mysterious deep-diving Russian submarine.

headline: Beware of Politicians Who Declare “War” on the Coronavirus
abstract: Leaders are turning to battlefield metaphors. But it’s your civil liberties that are under attack.
lead_paragraph: Leaders are turning to battlefield metaphors. But it’s your civil liberties that are under attack.

headline: Beware of Politicians Who Declare “War” on the Coronavirus
abstract: Leaders are turning to battlefield metaphors. But it’s your civil liberties that are under attack.
lead_paragraph: When heads of state start using wartime rhetoric to talk about coronavirus, should that make us feel safer and more secure … or nervous? The above video essay argues that yes, this rhetoric is meant to conjure a sense of solidarity — which we desperately need — but it can also provide cover for eroding our civil liberties.

headline: Help! My Mask Fogs My Glasses
abstract: Health workers have a few tricks for solving this vexing problem, but it will take trial and error to find the one that works for you.
lead_paragraph: In many parts of the world, nearly two out of three people wear corrective eyewear. And lately, many of us have the same complaint: Wearing a mask makes our glasses fog.

headline: What It’s Like Self-Isolating in a Studio Apartment
abstract: One-room dwellings have long been part of New York City’s hustle and hope. But how about when there’s nowhere else to go?
lead_paragraph: Paris has its garrets; London, its bedsits. In New York, it’s the studio apartment — and its grittier cousin, the tenement railroad flat — that has sheltered generations of strivers and makers.

headline: Breastfeeding May Lower Risk of Ovarian Cancer
abstract: Nursing for three months was associated with an 18 percent lower risk of ovarian cancer, and for more than a year with a 34 percent lower risk.
lead_paragraph: For new mothers, breastfeeding, even for a few months, is associated with a significant decrease in the risk for ovarian cancer years down the road, a review of studies has found.

headline: Can Investors Trust the Stock Market Rally?
abstract: After a swift rally, the market remains in limbo and investors are struggling to determine whether it’s a good time to buy stocks.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month ago, the stock market was in free fall, as a torrent of bad news about the coronavirus pandemic and its economic fallout drove investors to dump stocks. Just as swiftly, the market has rebounded, even as millions of people lose their jobs every week and the country is destined for a recession.

headline: Luis Sepúlveda, Chilean Writer Exiled by Pinochet, Dies at 70
abstract: His best-known work was “The Old Man Who Read Love Stories.” Mr. Sepúlveda was among the first people in Spain hospitalized with the new coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Harry and Meghan Cut Off U.K. Tabloids
abstract: A letter to four major newspapers criticized coverage as “distorted, false, or invasive beyond reason.” It was the latest twist in the couple’s poisonous relationship with some news outlets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, have all but vanished from the headlines in a world consumed by a catastrophic pandemic. But that did not stop the newly independent couple from notifying four leading British tabloid publishers on Sunday that they would no longer deal with them.

headline: ‘It’s Really a Gift’: Israeli Hospitals Let Relatives Say Goodbye Up Close
abstract: A hospital spokesman asked why family members were barred from coronavirus wards when journalists could visit in protective gear. His bosses had no good answer.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A few people had already died alone of the coronavirus at Tel Aviv’s Sourasky Medical Center when the hospital spokesman put to his bosses a question that had been gnawing at him.

headline: The Pandemic’s Hidden Victims: Sick or Dying, but Not From the Virus
abstract: As the coronavirus overwhelms the health care system, people with other illnesses struggle to find treatment.
lead_paragraph: Maria Kefalas considers her husband, Patrick Carr, a forgotten victim of the coronavirus.

headline: Sirio Maccioni, Whose Le Cirque Drew Manhattan’s Elite, Dies at 88
abstract: Dash, charm and matinee-idol looks helped make Mr. Maccioni an unusual sort of celebrity in New York City’s restaurant scene.
lead_paragraph: Sirio Maccioni, a Manhattan restaurateur who made Le Cirque a headquarters for Manhattan’s rich and powerful in the 1980s and ’90s, and put dishes like pasta primavera and crème brûlée on the culinary map, died on Monday in the town where he was born, Montecatini, in Tuscany, Italy. He was 88.

headline: Madeleine Albright Thinks It’s Good When America Gets Involved
abstract: “Democracy has to deliver. People have to recognize that other people not only want to vote but they want to eat.”
lead_paragraph: “Democracy has to deliver. People have to recognize that other people not only want to vote but they want to eat.”

headline: A City Ballet Season, but Online, With Bells and Whistles
abstract: The company will stream video of performances and offer movement classes for adults and children.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month after canceling its spring season because of the coronavirus pandemic, New York City Ballet is back with a six-week slate of online programing. The company announced on Monday that it would broadcast full ballets and excerpts twice a week, from Tuesday through May 29, for free on its YouTube channel, Facebook page and website.

headline: Richard Teitelbaum, Electronic Composer and Improviser, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Teitelbaum, whose sonic vocabulary emphasized otherworldly sounds and textures, worked with everyone from Karlheinz Stockhausen to Anthony Braxton.
lead_paragraph: Richard Teitelbaum, a composer and improviser widely admired in both contemporary classical and avant-garde jazz circles for his work with synthesizers and electronics, died on April 9 in Kingston, N.Y. He was 80.

headline: Turn Nearly Anything Into a Meal With This Simple Sauce
abstract: Salmon stars in this tonnato, an extremely simple sauce traditionally made with tuna, that lifts rich meat and crisp raw vegetables alike.
lead_paragraph: Next time you head to the market to restock your canned fish, here’s something to consider: Throw some salmon into your cart along with all that tuna.

headline: Two E.R. Workers Worry: If They Died, Who’d Take Care of Their Son?
abstract: A couple who both work in New York City public hospitals are facing unimagined strain as they fight the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A few nights ago, after their 18-month-old son, Nolan, went to sleep, Dr. Adam Hill and Neena Budhraja sat down on the living room couch in their apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Pen and paper in hand, they turned their attention to a pressing need: figuring out who would be Nolan’s legal guardian if the coronavirus swept them away.

headline: Netanyahu’s Power Is Extended as Rival Accepts Israel Unity Government
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, an embattled political survivor, persuaded Benny Gantz to join forces with him to combat the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his former challenger, Benny Gantz, agreed Monday night to establish a unity government, a deal that finally breaks a yearlong political impasse and keeps Mr. Netanyahu in office as he faces trial on corruption charges.

headline: Nina Balducci, Who Shaped a Famed Grocery Store, Dies at 91
abstract: She gave Balducci’s its polish and weathered an operatic family battle over the store’s ownership.
lead_paragraph: If you grew up as part of Nina Balducci’s clan, the rhythm of the week was set by meals orchestrated with equal parts panache and tradition. Friday night supper, in keeping with her Roman Catholic faith, was fish. Saturday was steak night. Sunday was pasta and red sauce.

headline: Earth Day As It Happened
abstract: A “secular revival meeting” with a lot of hot air from politicians: Read The New York Times’s coverage of the inaugural Earth Day in 1970.
lead_paragraph: A “secular revival meeting” with a lot of hot air from politicians: Read The New York Times’s coverage of the inaugural Earth Day in 1970.

headline: Frustrated by Lack of Coronavirus Tests, Maryland Got 500,000 From South Korea
abstract: Facing shortages, Gov. Larry Hogan and his wife, Yumi Hogan, negotiated with suppliers in South Korea to obtain the kits. “It should not have been this difficult,” he said.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump told governors that they needed to step up their efforts to secure medical supplies, Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland took the entreaty seriously and negotiated with suppliers in South Korea to obtain coronavirus test kits.

headline: Henry Grimes and Giuseppi Logan, Lost and Found Jazz Stars, Are Both Gone
abstract: The musicians were the two biggest disappearing acts on the jazz avant-garde. Now both have died of complications of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The lives of Henry Grimes and Giuseppi Logan already felt like the stuff of legend long before they came to an end last week — just two days and one borough apart — from complications of the coronavirus.

headline: More Puzzles to Pass the Time
abstract: An expanded space for games in our print edition is intended to challenge your brain but ease your mind.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Take YouTube’s Dangers Seriously
abstract: The website’s features can lead people unwittingly to scary places.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Does the Pressure of a Pandemic Transform a Cellist’s Bach?
abstract: Alisa Weilerstein is streaming one movement of the Bach cello suites a day, just as she has released a polished studio recording of them.
lead_paragraph: Back we go to Bach. Musicians everywhere seem to be turning to his music as the soundtrack of despair and hope, for both private solace and public streams.

headline: The ‘Open the Country’ Protesters
abstract: Readers discuss whether it’s time to begin lifting the coronavirus restrictions, and the president’s encouragement of right-wing protests.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Beryl Bernay, Children’s TV Host With a Varied Career, Dies at 94
abstract: Also an actor and painter, she assisted Margaret Mead and was an expert on Bali. She died of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: New York Needed Ventilators. So They Developed One in a Month.
abstract: The pandemic inspired an innovative project to design and make a low-cost ventilator in weeks, not years.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.

headline: How Sports Adapt: A Marathon Indoors and Drive-In Soccer
abstract: German Silva used his race winnings to bring electricity to his hometown. Now, he’s running to honor the medical personnel on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: German Silva of Mexico came to fame — and nearly infamy — when he turned prematurely into Central Park in the final mile of the 1994 New York City Marathon, realized his mistake, backtracked and still pulled off a victory with a display of calm persistence.

headline: Cancel the Trump TV Show
abstract: A reader says the daily briefings cause more harm than good. Also: Acts of kindness, everywhere; Joe Biden’s choice of running mate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ottolenghi’s Test Kitchen Is Closed. But the Recipes Keep Coming.
abstract: Away from their small North London hub, a six-member team still finds a way to share recipes, and feed loved ones.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Before our world was turned on its head so abruptly only a few (very long) weeks ago, the center of my universe outside home was my test kitchen. A modest space underneath a railway arch in Camden, north London, it doubles as a cooking hub and an office. Six of us spend most of our time there, thinking up ideas, testing dishes repeatedly and talking about them ad infinitum. It’s where concepts take shape and plans for future projects — recipes, articles, books and restaurant dishes, bagged products, cakes and treats of any shape or form — are developed. The general spirit of things to come is dreamed up in the test kitchen.

headline: Keep Calm and Draw Together
abstract: With assists from Shepard Fairey and Maira Kalman, graphic designers and illustrators are creating striking visual messages of safety and gratitude.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic reshapes huge swaths of society, the design world is responding by doing what it does best: grabbing our attention with striking images.

headline: Showtime, Suspended
abstract: Broadway was booming. Then the coronavirus turned New York’s theater district into a ghost town.
lead_paragraph: One month after Broadway shut down, I decided to take a walk.

headline: DC to Resume Sales of Some New Comic Books
abstract: The publishing home of Batman and Superman will sell some new comics to stores starting next week.
lead_paragraph: After an absence of nearly a month, some costumed superheroes are planning to return to the pages of  comic books and to the stores that can still sell them.

headline: Rubem Fonseca, Giant of Brazilian Literature, Dies at 94
abstract: A former police official, he wrote crime stories that titillated and shocked Brazilians and earned him prestigious awards.
lead_paragraph: Rubem Fonseca, one of Brazil’s leading literary figures whose flinty, obscenity-laden crime stories were seen as dark metaphors for the rot in Brazilian society, died on April 15 in Rio de Janeiro. He was 94.

headline: Celebrating Literature’s Slacker Heroes, Idlers and Liers-In
abstract: Dwight Garner surveys the varied and glorious classic works on indolence.
lead_paragraph: Not everyone is having a bad lockdown. In The Spectator, the English weekly, Tom Stoppard wrote, “This is the life I’ve always wanted — social distancing without social disapproval.” Me? I’ve grown twitchy. The song I can’t stop listening to is Cab Calloway’s “I Gotta Go Places and Do Things.”

headline: Can You Make Money in Live Comedy Right Now? Some Producers Say Yes
abstract: Experiments with online business models have led in at least one case to more tickets sold. And as the trappings change, the nature of the humor seems to be changing, too.
lead_paragraph: No one in live comedy is thrilled about moving shows online. “Doing standup without an audience is like sex without an orgasm,” quipped Felicia Madison, the booker for West Side Comedy Club. “Why bother?”

headline: Istanbul Death Toll Hints Turkey Is Hiding a Wider Coronavirus Calamity
abstract: Istanbul recorded 2,100 more deaths over recent years between March and April, The Times found, suggesting a hidden toll.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For weeks President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has presented Turkey’s performance in handling the coronavirus as one of the world’s most successful, as he maintained strict control over information about the outbreak.

headline: The World Has a $2.5 Trillion Problem. Here’s How to Solve It.
abstract: Poor countries are going to be decimated by the coronavirus. They need a serious rescue package.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has not yet exploded in the developing world, but poor countries are already suffering from the pandemic. Their economies have been battered by lockdowns, falling commodity prices, declining remittances, and unprecedented capital flight. Some $100 billion has fled emerging markets since January, five times more than in the 2008 crash.

headline: The Case of the Disappearing Exoplanet
abstract: Fomalhaut b was one of the first planets around another star to be directly imaged by telescopes. Some astronomers now say it was a cloud of asteroid debris.
lead_paragraph: Humanity’s growing tally of exoplanets — worlds seen orbiting other stars — stands at 4,151. Most were found indirectly, as they passed in front of their stars and cast a telltale shadow, or as they caused their star to wobble as they swung around it. Only 50 have been directly imaged through a telescope.

headline: Stacey Abrams Knows the Secret to Winning the White House
abstract: I ran her campaign for governor of Georgia in 2018 where more voters of color turned out than in the 2016 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Black voters have driven the trajectory of recent Democratic presidential nominating contests more than any other voting bloc. This was the case in 2008 and 2016 primaries, where they largely united behind a single candidate — Barack Obama and then Hillary Clinton. This year is no different. But the question is whether Democrats will earn enough of their support to win the White House.

headline: The Infection That’s Silently Killing Coronavirus Patients
abstract: This is what I learned during 10 days of treating Covid pneumonia at Bellevue Hospital.
lead_paragraph: I have been practicing emergency medicine for 30 years. In 1994 I invented an imaging system for teaching intubation, the procedure of inserting breathing tubes. This led me to perform research into this procedure, and subsequently teach airway procedure courses to physicians worldwide for the last two decades.

headline: When Crocodiles Once Dived Like Dolphins and Whales
abstract: They didn’t have blowholes, but an ancient lineage of crocodilians returned to the oceans in a manner similar to some marine mammals.
lead_paragraph: Some 400 million years ago, animals emerged from the ocean for the first time and began to thrive on land. But after eons of evolutionary experimentation, some lineages peaced out of the terrestrial world and embraced a full-time life at sea again. While whales and dolphins are among the best known marine creatures to follow this path, it turns out some ancient relatives of modern crocodiles, called thalattosuchians, took the same aquatic turn while dinosaurs roamed the planet.

headline: The Great American Divide
abstract: The coronavirus crisis has underscored our enduring inequalities in race, wealth and health.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to look hard to find inequality in America. For the past several weeks I have been sheltering with my family in Central New York, where even among the rolling hills and sweeping expanses of farmland, the vast divide between the haves and have-nots is as plainly visible as it is in New York City.

headline: Supreme Court Bans Non-Unanimous Jury Verdicts for Serious Crimes
abstract: The badly fractured decision, affecting defendants in two states, continued a debate among the justices over the power of precedent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that the Constitution banned non-unanimous jury verdicts in cases involving serious crimes. The decision will affect defendants and prisoners in Louisiana and Oregon, the only two states that have allowed such verdicts in recent years.

headline: Business Travel Has Stopped. No One Knows When It Will Come Back.
abstract: But one thing is certain: It will be changed. Airports, airlines and hotels will be taking new precautions, experts predict. And conferences will eventually return.
lead_paragraph: Business travel worldwide has basically come to a standstill in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: ‘I Don’t Think the New York That We Left Will Be Back for Some Years’
abstract: The features that made the city’s economy distinctive — Broadway, restaurants and museums — were hard hit and will take the longest to come back.
lead_paragraph: It took just a matter of days to shut down New York City, once the coronavirus took hold. Restarting it will take much, much longer.

headline: The Virus and the Press: Thailand’s View
abstract: The country’s acting consul general in New York takes issue with a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Easing lockdowns in Australia and New Zealand, a spike in cases in Singapore and plummeting U.S. oil prices.
lead_paragraph: Surfers returned to a few beaches in Sydney on Monday, and children in New Zealand will return to school in a week.

headline: The N.F.L. Figures Out How to Team-Build From a Distance
abstract: This week, some N.F.L. teams will have their first organized football activities, even as coronavirus guidelines keep personnel away from team facilities.
lead_paragraph: In any other year, N.F.L. facilities across the country would be buzzing this week, when teams are allowed to begin their off-season workout programs, the first organized football activities since they ended the prior season.

headline: ‘Why Don’t You Just Die!’ Review: Attempted Murder, but Make It Comedy
abstract: Kirill Sokolov’s debut feature is a bloody and often hilarious exercise in excruciating harm-doing among mendacious people.
lead_paragraph: There’s a sense in which this Russian film, a raucous, violent comedy of vengeance written and directed by Kirill Sokolov, may immediately feel familiar — at least if you’re a genre film aficionado. Its early shots show our hero, so to speak — Matvey (Aleksandr Kuznetsov), a young fellow with an unusually shaped nose wearing a sweatshirt with a Batman symbol on it — standing outside of an apartment, slightly nervous, and not without reason. He’s holding a new-looking steel hammer behind his back.

headline: Great Scented Candles, Recommended by T Editors
abstract: Suggestions for brightening your home — and filling it with fragrances that evoke faraway places.
lead_paragraph: During a time when many of us are compelled to remain within our homes, infusing a room with a fragrance, which has a famously powerful ability to evoke a specific place or memory, is one small way to help soothe frustrations and remind ourselves of the world beyond our walls. Here, T editors share the scented candles they’ve been burning lately, from a blend laced with Sicilian limes to one that evokes the Californian coast.

headline: How to Make One-Pot Pasta With Practically Any Pasta
abstract: Master this technique, and save yourself time at the stove — and the sink.
lead_paragraph: There’s one thing you can do to make any pasta dish easier, and arguably more satisfying: Cook the pasta and the sauce together in a single pot.

headline: What Causes Autism?
abstract: From genes to environment, experts have identified several factors that influence a child’s chance of having autism. But risk is not destiny, they say.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Smith had always wanted to have three children. Last April, as she was trying to get pregnant for a third time, she learned her youngest child was autistic. After she got over the initial shock, the news came as a relief. “I had known for months that something was wrong,” she said. “To finally have an answer, and to have a diagnosis that would afford us solutions and therapy to help, was definitely a relief.”

headline: Excluded From Bailouts, Mortgage Servicers Face Cash Crunch
abstract: Lawmakers and lobbyists warn that missed house payments could leave servicers insolvent but federal officials are not sold on the need for a rescue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal policymakers have rushed to backstop nearly every corner of the financial system as the coronavirus exacts a bruising toll on the U.S. economy. But there is growing concern that a critical corner of the housing industry has been overlooked, putting mortgage companies in a precarious position as millions of borrowers delay payments.

headline: Robert Loomis, Old-School Editor of Big-Name Books, Dies at 93
abstract: He wielded his pencil at Random House for more than 50 years, nurturing the work of Maya Angelou, William Styron and other literary lights.
lead_paragraph: Robert Loomis, an editor who bloodlessly transformed embryonic manuscripts by a pantheon of 20th-century American authors into award-winning and best-selling books, died on Sunday in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Landowners in Montana Superfund Fight
abstract: Landowners may not sue the Atlantic Richfield Company to force it to do more than a federal cleanup plan requires unless the Environmental Protection Agency consents, the court ruled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court dealt a setback on Monday to roughly 100 Montana residents who sought to sue Atlantic Richfield Company to help them restore property contaminated by arsenic and lead.

headline: Businesses Say Big Banks Flouted ‘First Come First Served’ for Aid
abstract: Small-business owners are suing, claiming that applications for stimulus loans weren’t processed in the order they were received.
lead_paragraph: Small-business owners have accused some of the country’s largest banks of unfairly favoring applications from their wealthiest clients for aid under a $349 billion government stimulus program.

headline: Is Michael Jordan Playing Defense in ‘The Last Dance’?
abstract: Jordan’s production company is a partner of the ESPN documentary, and the tone of the series so far bends toward reaffirming a legacy in the LeBron James era.
lead_paragraph: Michael Jordan seemingly has everything. He toppled almost all of his foes as a player. There was his individual greatness. Team greatness. Much business greatness.

headline: Noach Dear, Combative Brooklyn Councilman and Judge, Dies at 66
abstract: In pursuing his constituents’ Orthodox Jewish agenda, he opposed abortion rights and legislation to ban discrimination against gay people.
lead_paragraph: Noach Dear, who served nearly two decades on the New York City Council as an outlier, advocating on behalf of the conservative agenda of his Orthodox Jewish constituents in Brooklyn while defending himself against accusations of conflicts of interest, died on Sunday in Brooklyn. He was 66.

headline: In Old Cairo, a Subdued Ramadan Looms as Virus Shutters the City
abstract: The holiest month in the Islamic calendar promises this year to be the strangest ever for the world’s 1.8 billion Muslims. In Cairo, known as the city of a thousand minarets, the coronavirus has cast a long shadow.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — For over a thousand years, Cairo’s oldest mosques kept their doors open — through the Black Death of the 14th century, the devastating cholera epidemics of the 19th century and the Spanish flu in the winter of 1918 that claimed 140,000 Egyptian lives.

headline: ‘Let Me Work’: Protesters in Pennsylvania Want State Reopened
abstract: In Pennsylvania, hundreds of protesters gathered in Harrisburg to call for the loosening of stay-at-home orders so people could return to work.
lead_paragraph: In Pennsylvania, hundreds of protesters gathered in Harrisburg to call for the loosening of stay-at-home orders so people could return to work.

headline: NPR Cuts Executive Pay as Corporate Sponsors’ Payments Fall
abstract: The chief executive of the radio and podcasting giant said he hoped to avoid layoffs.
lead_paragraph: National Public Radio, the purveyor of “Morning Edition,” “All Things Considered” and “Planet Money,” is cutting executives’ pay to combat the effects of the economic collapse brought on by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Michelle Obama Is Reading Books to Children Stuck at Home
abstract: The former first lady said she would share some of her favorite children’s books and try to give families a much-needed break.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama read one of her beloved children’s books aloud on Monday, live streaming to hundreds of thousands of people stuck at home. The virtual story time was the first in a four-week series called “Mondays with Michelle Obama.”

headline: Walentyna Janta-Polczynska, Polish War Heroine, Dies at 107
abstract: She was a confidante of the prime minister of the Polish government in exile. In Queens, she was nicknamed the first lady of Polish Americans.
lead_paragraph: Walentyna Janta-Polczynska, among the last surviving members of the Polish government in exile, which was formed after Nazi Germany invaded Poland, died on April 2 in Queens. She was 107.

headline: Trump Exceptionalism
abstract: What happened to President Trump’s approval ratings?
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, as the president received some of the highest marks of his presidency, we wrote about a “Trump bump.”

headline: Georgia, Tennessee and South Carolina Say Businesses Can Reopen Soon
abstract: Even as some states move to restart their economies, coronavirus hot spots are emerging, including at a state prison in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Residents of Georgia will be allowed on Friday to return to the gym and get haircuts, pedicures, massages and tattoos. Next Monday, they can dine again in restaurants and go to the movies.

headline: Oil, Singapore, Nova Scotia: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Fed Gearing Up to Help Smaller Local Governments
abstract: The central bank hinted from the start that it could broaden its municipal debt purchases.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve could soon expand its plans to buy municipal bonds, as lawmakers from both parties pressure the central bank to do more to support smaller cities and counties suffering amid fallout from the coronavirus.

headline: Dispute Over Virus Testing Delays Deal on Aid to Small Businesses and Hospitals
abstract: Democrats are insisting that the legislation require the Trump administration to establish a national testing strategy, but the president wants states to take responsibility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A dispute between Democrats and the White House over how to handle coronavirus testing emerged on Monday as one of the most significant sticking points as negotiators struggled to finalize a nearly $500 billion bipartisan agreement to replenish a loan program for small businesses and provide more funding for hospitals and testing.

headline: How Coronavirus Infected Some, but Not All, in a Restaurant
abstract: A limited study by Chinese researchers suggests the role played by air currents in spreading the illness in enclosed spaces.
lead_paragraph: In January, at a restaurant in Guangzhou, China, one diner infected with the novel coronavirus but not yet feeling sick appeared to have spread the disease to nine other people. One of the restaurant’s air-conditioners apparently blew the virus particles around the dining room.

headline: ‘You’re On Your Own,’ Essential Workers Are Being Told
abstract: Workplace safety is now a matter of public health.
lead_paragraph: Shelter-in-place orders are an effective means to slowing the spread of the coronavirus, yet millions of Americans have no choice but to leave home to go to work every day. Deemed essential for their jobs in manufacturing, grocery stores, pharmacies, warehouses, retailing and restaurants, they face daily risks by working alongside colleagues and customers who may be carriers of the coronavirus.

headline: Too Much Oil: How a Barrel Came to Be Worth Less Than Nothing
abstract: One oil price went negative on Monday, signaling that there is no place to store all the crude the world is producing but not using.
lead_paragraph: Something bizarre happened in the oil markets on Monday: Prices fell so much that some traders paid buyers to take oil off their hands.

headline: How Abortion, Guns and Church Closings Made Coronavirus a Culture War
abstract: Flattening the curve is now one of the most contentious issues in politics.
lead_paragraph: This is what it looks like when a pandemic collides with the culture wars in America.

headline: Doctors and Governors Vie for Masks in Cloak-and-Dagger Deals
abstract: Despite plans to reopen states, equipment to protect workers from the coronavirus remains in high demand. “The need for an organized, equitable distribution system is dire,” a doctor said.
lead_paragraph: It was a stealth transaction, arranged through “someone who knew someone who knew someone,” taking place at an undisclosed location in an unnamed mid-Atlantic state. The getaway vehicles were disguised as food service delivery trucks, and they mapped out separate routes back to Massachusetts to avoid detection.

headline: Abigail Thernstrom, Scholarly Foe of Affirmative Action, Dies at 83
abstract: She supported civil rights, but later, with her husband, Stephan, concluded that colorblind policies worked better than preferential treatment.
lead_paragraph: Abigail Thernstrom, a social scientist whose colorblind remedies for racial disparities in educational achievement, voting and employment elevated her from a former red-diaper baby into a leading skeptic of affirmative action programs, died on April 10 in Arlington, Va. She was 83.

headline: Novak Djokovic Expresses Resistance to Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: Though Djokovic, in an online chat, expressed concerns about having to accept a vaccination in order to travel for the tennis tour, he said in a follow-up statement that he would keep an open mind.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic, the world’s No. 1 men’s tennis player, caused a stir with comments over the weekend suggesting he would have a difficult decision to make if receiving a coronavirus vaccine became mandatory to compete on the tennis circuit.

headline: We Need a More Resilient American Economy
abstract: With a sensible industrial policy, workers will take precedence over short-term corporate gain.
lead_paragraph: Americans are a resilient people. We persevere through difficult circumstances and arrive triumphant on the other side of adversity. It’s in our national DNA.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Disputes over testing availability and strategy in the U.S. impeded progress on several fronts.
lead_paragraph: When can stay-at-home orders be relaxed safely? Not until we get much more testing, many state governors say.

headline: A Biden Presidency Could Be Better Than Progressives Think
abstract: Campaign promises matter, and his platform shows a distinct leftward drift.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Mishel, a well-known labor economist, has been a critic of centrist Democrats for decades. “My adult lifetime has covered the Carter, Clinton and Obama years, and labor policy has never been a priority,” Mishel, the former president of the Economic Policy Institute, a progressive think tank, told me. In the 2016 primary, he voted for Bernie Sanders. This year he supported Elizabeth Warren. (So did I.)

headline: 11 New Cookbooks Worth Buying, Even in Quarantine
abstract: Our favorite releases of the season, selected by Food reporters and editors from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: These days, an uncommonly large number of people are cooking every meal, and while recipes are not in short supply, inspiration might be. Cookbooks are still one of the best ways to pull yourself out of meal-planning fatigue and find an idea — a pasta sauce, a flavor combination, a technique — that can change your cooking forever.

headline: The Right Sends In the Quacks
abstract: Covid-19 highlights the conservative reliance on fake experts.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few days there have been noisy, threatening demonstrations at various statehouses demanding an end to Covid-19 lockdowns.

headline: Buffalo Trace Releases Three Kosher Whiskeys
abstract: Created under the supervision of the Chicago Rabbinical Council, the Kentucky distillery has created two kosher bourbons and a rye whiskey.
lead_paragraph: Kosher wine is commonplace, and has been for some time. Kosher spirits, not so much. Many spirits are, in fact, technically kosher, but in most cases, they got there accidentally. The Buffalo Trace Distillery in Kentucky has taken a more proactive approach, working over the past 10 years with the Chicago Rabbinical Council on a line of purpose-built kosher American whiskeys. A bourbon (“Rye Recipe”), rye (“Straight Rye”) and wheated bourbon (“Wheat Recipe,” a whiskey made using a high percentage of wheat) were released on April 16, following the end of Passover. Every production step was overseen by the council, from barreling to bottling. So there is no mistaking their provenance, each bottle has the word “kosher” on the label in large letters. The limited-release line will be an annual event, arriving each year after Passover.

headline: Dessert Add-On
abstract: Andrew Kingsley treats us to a sweet puzzle.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Andrew Kingsley’s tasty puzzle reminded me why I no longer keep track of what I eat in fitness apps.For people who find it beneficial to keep track, more power to you. But I take issue with an app that counts the sugar grams from healthy food the same as those from junk food. An orange, for example, contains nine grams of sugar but is good for you in terms of fiber and vitamin C. A chocolate chip cookie, on the other hand, contains approximately the same amount of sugar as the orange according to this app, but has few nutritional redeeming qualities other than being insanely delicious.

headline: Once Upon a Timeline in America
abstract: “The Plot Against America” on HBO is the latest production to reimagine the past. These alternative histories tell us both what could have been — and what might be.
lead_paragraph: “What happens now?” 8-year-old Philip Levin wonders after Charles Lindbergh wins the 1940 presidential election in the HBO mini-series “The Plot Against America.” Later on, as the shadow of government-sanctioned anti-Semitism falls over his family and their Newark neighborhood, he’ll ask, “What does it mean?”

headline: Corrections: April 21, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 21, 2020.

headline: More Shelf-Stable Foods From Patagonia
abstract: The company has expanded its Provisions line to include pasta, grains and baby food.
lead_paragraph: For several years, Patagonia, the outdoor gear company, has been selling a line of packaged shelf-stable, backpack-friendly foods like hot-smoked fish, dried fruit, snacks and soup mixes. Now they have expanded it to include pasta and sauces, nuts, grains and even baby food, not all of it packaged to carry on the trail.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Solitary Prayers, Stifled Festivals: An Unusual Ramadan
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 21, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “When I call people, nobody can come. It feels like God is refusing us.”

headline: Rezdôra Sells Its Pastas to Go
abstract: The three-star restaurant is packaging homemade pastas with sauces for two, with some of the proceeds going to a restaurant workers charity.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, a reservation at Rezdôra was a challenge, and now it’s not possible to dine at Stefano Secchi and David Switzer’s year-old restaurant, featuring the food of Emilia-Romagna. But you can try a plate of the highly regarded homemade pasta, which impressed Pete Wells to the tune of three stars. Mr. Secchi is making it, along with sauces and even tiramisù, to go. The pastas include thick spinach pappardelle, thinner tagliatelle, eggless radiatore, classic spaghetti and pork-filled anolini, among others. Tomato sauce, and ragùs Modenese-style — with prosciutto, with duck or with wild boar — are some of the sauces, all in portions to serve two for $40. A lasagna Bolognese for two to bake at home is $38. Ten percent of the sale price is being donated to ROAR, a restaurant industry relief organization. Quantities are limited, and when something sells out, that’s it for the day. Pickup and delivery are available, and nationwide shipping is coming.

headline: Ashkenazi Foodways Explored in Online Course
abstract: The YIVO Institute for Jewish Research in Manhattan looks at the history of Jewish food through a seven-week course.
lead_paragraph: A new online course from the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research in Chelsea explores the history of Jewish food through the lens of Ashkenazi traditions. It features personalities and scholars in the Jewish food world, like Darra Goldstein, Lior Lev Sercarz, Adeena Sussman, Leah Koenig and Niki Russ Federman, along with materials from YIVO’s archives. Recipes are demonstrated. The course, in seven sessions will be available starting May 1, with a new session released each week so that the complete program will be online by mid-June. Because of the coronavirus pandemic, the course will be free of charge.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 5 Finale Recap: Close Calls
abstract: In the season finale, Lalo turns the tables on the men sent to kill him, using kitchenware and cunning. Also, Kim hatches a very devious plan.
lead_paragraph: Viva Lalo.

headline: Tony Dalton Talks ‘Better Call Saul’: Sympathy for el Diablo
abstract: Ahead of the Season 5 finale, the Mexican actor talked about playing Lalo Salamanca, a killer with charisma to spare.
lead_paragraph: This interview contains spoilers for the Season 5 finale of “Better Call Saul.”

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’: Rhea Seehorn on Kim’s Dark Turn
abstract: The Season 5 finale turns Jimmy and Kim’s dynamic on its head, and sets up a possible mortal threat for next season, the show’s last.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for Season 5 of “Better Call Saul.”

headline: A Glass to Keep Half Full
abstract: This stemless glass, in pale salmon, brings some springtime color to your table.
lead_paragraph: Even that pour of club soda will take on a springtime rosé hue in this new glass. It comes in a stemless shape, now something of a classic, and has a bubbly pattern in pale salmon pink that deepens from top to bottom. It’s a fairly substantial glass, holding 16 ounces, and could even be used for flowers or a votive candle.

headline: When E.V.O.O. Met Chocolate
abstract: A sweet confection was born. Kosterina now sells dark chocolate bars blended with olive oil.
lead_paragraph: Kosterina, an olive oil company in the Peloponnese region of Greece that uses native koroneiki olives, has introduced chocolate bars, the dark chocolate blended with the extra-virgin olive oil. The result is rich, silky chocolate in some uncommon Mediterranean flavors like fig and balsamic vinegar; almond butter with vanilla; and nuts, including walnuts and pistachios, with cinnamon and honey. The 2.1-ounce bars are sold in sets of six. The olive oil is also available online.

headline: Is Kim Jong-un Ailing? South Korea Disputes Report Saying He Is
abstract: The report said North Korea’s leader underwent a cardiovascular procedure earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean officials on Tuesday disputed a news report that North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, was receiving treatment after undergoing heart surgery.

headline: Trump Plans to Suspend Immigration to U.S.
abstract: The president portrayed the measure, his most wide-ranging attempt yet to seal off the country from the world, as a bid to save Americans’ jobs amid the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday evening that he intended to close the United States to people trying to immigrate into the country to live and work, a drastic move that he said would protect American workers from foreign competition once the nation’s economy began to recover from the shutdown caused by the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Joe Biden Starts General Election Nearly $187 Million Behind Trump
abstract: New fund-raising figures show the depth of the financial hole in which Mr. Biden finds himself against a president and Republican Party that have built up a huge war chest.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the Democratic Party could raise almost $1 million every single day between now and November, and he would still barely catch up to what President Trump and the Republican Party had in the bank at the start of April — let alone what Mr. Trump will have by Election Day.

headline: U.N. Warns World Hunger Could Double as Coronavirus Hurts Global Economy Crashes
abstract: In southern Italy, the pandemic is choking an already fragile economy. Protests erupt in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: 新冠病毒疫情最新消息

headline: Pastor Faces Assault Charge After Dispute With Protester Over Social Distancing
abstract: Tony Spell backed up a church bus toward a man who had been protesting outside Life Tabernacle Church, which has defied Louisiana’s ban on public gatherings, the authorities said. He did not hit the man.
lead_paragraph: A pastor at a Louisiana megachurch who was previously cited for defying the state’s coronavirus stay-at-home orders is facing an aggravated assault charge after he backed up a bus toward a protester outside the church on Sunday, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Coronavirus, Oil Prices, U.S. Immigration: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: U.S. Orders Chevron to Stop Producing Oil in Venezuela
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Empire’ and a Tribute Concert
abstract: The Fox hip-hop drama comes to an abrupt end, and celebrities commemorate Prince in a televised concert.
lead_paragraph: EMPIRE 9 p.m. on Fox. The past year has not been easy on “Empire,” a drama about the family of a hip-hop mogul (Terrence Howard). Before the sixth and final season debuted last fall, the writers wrote off one of the main characters, played by Jussie Smollett, who is being investigated for potentially staging a hate crime he himself reported. Now, the series is ending earlier than planned because production shut down before the final two episodes could be completed. This episode will have to tie up a few loose ends: While Bossyfest opens, Cookie (Taraji P. Henson) tries to regain control of Empire. Lucious (Howard) contemplates his feelings for her while still supporting Yana (Kiandra Richardson). And, since flashbacks from earlier episodes showed grim endings for Cookie and Lucious, it’s clear the Lyon family is still in hot water.

headline: In India, a Pandemic of Prejudice and Repression
abstract: The coronavirus outbreak has allowed authoritarianism and anti-Muslim sentiment to flourish.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — For decades, India embraced many of the ideals that are the hallmarks of a liberal democracy. But since the election of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Hindu fundamentalist Bharatiya Janata Party in 2014, we have experienced a breathtaking erosion in the rule of law and civil and political rights and the unleashing of a wave of intolerance against religious minorities.

headline: Word + Quiz: chiasmus
abstract: This word has appeared in one article on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Australia’s Fire Season Ends, and Researchers Look to the Next One
abstract: With its otherworldly conditions, Australia has become a testing ground for fire-prediction technology.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — On March 2, for the first time in 240 days, not a single bush fire burned in the state of New South Wales. The state’s Rural Fire Service declared the worst fire season in history, during which 25 people in NSW were killed, officially over. In those eight months, 6 percent, or 13.6 million acres, of the state that a third of Australians call home had been incinerated.

headline: The Sound of One Shrimp Snapping
abstract: How climate change is altering nature’s sonic landscape.
lead_paragraph: Spring in Sugarloaf Ridge State Park, in Northern California, is typically a natural symphony. Streams whoosh, swollen with winter rains, and birds — robins, sparrows, grosbeaks, woodpeckers and hawks — trill and chatter.

headline: A Bridge for Tamarins
abstract: One of the world’s most spectacular primates has become a symbol of conservation in Brazil, where an overpass is being built over a major highway to keep the species going.
lead_paragraph: The golden lion tamarin, one of the world’s most charismatic primates, has a dark face that can look inquisitive, challenging, almost human, framed in an extravagant russet mane.

headline: Lockdown Protesters Would’ve Wanted Titanic to Sink Sooner, Kimmel Says
abstract: Trump supporters like the ones calling for an end to stay-at-home orders “seem to fight hardest for the things that will kill them,” Jimmy Kimmel said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Instagram Challenges
abstract: Which current social media challenges are you enjoying most right now?
lead_paragraph: For weeks, people have been recreating works of fine art using household items and posting their tableaus on social media, as the example above shows. You can see many more by scrolling through this related article.

headline: What Will Endurance Races Look Like When They Come Back?
abstract: Marathons. Cycling Races. Triathlons. So many have been wiped out, but organizers are already planning how to bring them back.
lead_paragraph: July 1.

headline: Pandemic’s Costs Stagger the Nursing Home Industry
abstract: Even before the coronavirus swept through care facilities, many were struggling with thin profit margins. Now they could be wiped out.
lead_paragraph: Even before they became deadly petri dishes for the worst pandemic in generations, many nursing homes were struggling to stay afloat and provide quality care.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Daily | The Next Year (or Two) of the Pandemic’
abstract: What is next for the United States? In this lesson, students will consider the possible paths out of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Featured Podcast: “The Daily | The Next Year (or Two) of the Pandemic” hosted by Michael Barbaro with special guest Donald G. McNeil Jr.

headline: Liu Ouqing, Civil Servant Who Helped Feed Wuhan, Dies at 78
abstract: As China was opening up its centrally planned economy, Mr. Liu was party secretary of the Wuhan Grain Bureau, and he later helped establish Wuhan Business University.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: How to Talk to Yourself
abstract: Start by paying attention to what you’re already telling yourself. Try exploring more deliberate self-talk, but keep it simple.
lead_paragraph: “You can change your behavior by talking to yourself,” says Judy L. Van Raalte, a professor of psychology and director of the athletic-counseling program at Springfield College, in Massachusetts. What sports psychologists call self-talk is one of the field’s central tenets, which they divide into two types: spontaneous (called System 1) and intentional (System 2). Start by paying attention to what you’re already telling yourself. Such System 1 self-talk can often be critical (“You suck at free throws”). Once you know what you’re unconsciously saying, start exploring more deliberate self-talk.

headline: How Scientists Could Stop the Next Pandemic Before It Starts
abstract: Researchers believe they could pre-emptively create vaccines and drugs to fight a wide range of viral threats — if they can get sufficient funding.
lead_paragraph: On a cold morning in February 2018, a group of 30 microbiologists, zoologists and public-health experts from around the world met at the headquarters of the World Health Organization in Geneva. The group was established by the W.H.O. in 2015 to create a priority list of dangerous viruses — specifically, those for which no vaccines or drugs were already in development. The consensus, at least among those in the room, was that as populations and global travel continued to grow and development increasingly pushed into wild areas, it was almost inevitable that once-containable local outbreaks, like SARS or Ebola, could become global disasters.

headline: Still Lives
abstract: In this unnatural state of isolation, photographers show us the things that bind.
lead_paragraph: In this unnatural state of isolation, photographers show us the things that bind.

headline: Coronavirus Is Forcing Medical Research to Speed Up
abstract: What does it mean for science — and public health — that scientific journals are now publishing research at warp speed?
lead_paragraph: As scientists race to understand the coronavirus, the process of designing experiments, collecting data and submitting studies to journals for expert review is being compressed drastically. What typically takes many months is happening in weeks, even as some journals are receiving double their normal number of submissions. Science, one of the world’s most selective research outlets, published the structure of the spiky protein that the virus uses to enter host cells — crucial knowledge for designing a vaccine and antiviral drugs — nine days after receiving it, according to Holden Thorp, the journal’s editor in chief. “It’s the same process going extremely fast,” he says. Is there precedent in Science’s 140-year history? “Not that anybody can remember.”

headline: How Can You Tell a Story About Your Life Right Now Through a Few Simple Numbers?
abstract: Number of times you opened the refrigerator today? TikTok videos watched? Different outfits worn this week? Show us what your day or week looks like right now by giving us some numbers.
lead_paragraph: What big and small things have changed in your life over the last few weeks? How can numbers express that?

headline: Who Is Really Running the Government?
abstract: With his new book, “In Deep,” David Rohde argues that there is no “deep state,” but that Donald Trump may be creating one of his own.
lead_paragraph: IN DEEPThe FBI, the CIA, and the Truth About America’s “Deep State”By David Rohde

headline: What Are We Watching in the White House’s Coronavirus Briefings?
abstract: They aren’t very informative. You can still learn a lot from them.
lead_paragraph: Not long into this crisis, I went to YouTube to watch a live­stream of the daily White House coronavirus news briefing. It was a few minutes before the scheduled start time, and I was surprised to find myself looking at an empty stage, watching the preparatory goings-on: collegial banter, photographers fiddling with cameras, reporters I vaguely recognized from TV adjusting earpieces and coordinating with producers. Here was a scene that had just recently become tantalizing — a bunch of people together in a room. We were only a few days into our stay-at-home order in California, and already my cabin fever had reached the point where the idea of sharing space with so many other humans had achieved the allure of an exotic sexual fantasy.

headline: Where Lonely Refugees Learn English From Daytime Soaps
abstract: “How to Pronounce Knife,” a debut story collection by Souvankham Thammavongsa, features dislocated characters forced to reinvent their lives in unnamed North American cities.
lead_paragraph: HOW TO PRONOUNCE KNIFEStoriesBy Souvankham Thammavongsa

headline: From Saigon to the Suburbs, a Vietnamese-American’s Struggle to Assimilate
abstract: In “Sigh, Gone,” Phuc Tran recalls his coming-of-age in a white world with an Asian face.
lead_paragraph: SIGH, GONE A Misfit’s Memoir of Great Books, Punk Rock, and the Fight to Fit In By Phuc Tran

headline: In a New Collection of Old Stories, Madeleine L’Engle Is Back
abstract: This posthumous collection shows the evolution of one of the world’s most beloved writers.
lead_paragraph: THE MOMENT OF TENDERNESSBy Madeleine L’Engle

headline: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From Betsey Johnson to Pot in San Francisco
abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: BETSEY: A Memoir, by Betsey Johnson with Mark Vitulano. Read by the author. (Penguin Audio.) From youthful escapades with the Velvet Underground to adult ones cartwheeling down fashion runways, the designer recounts a life spent building her personal brand.

headline: Dancing With My Mortality
abstract: I’ve been dying for a long time. Here’s what I’ve learned about how it’s done.
lead_paragraph: Who would have thought we’d all be living in fear of making a grocery run, picking up a package or accidentally getting closer than six feet to another human?

headline: An Unlikely Romance Blooms in a Hospital Room, Then Metastasizes
abstract: The novel “Reproduction,” by Ian Williams, is a bold experiment in form, a love story that grows malignant over time.
lead_paragraph: REPRODUCTIONBy Ian Williams

headline: Helping Teens Make Room for Uncomfortable Emotions
abstract: Psychological health includes being able to bear unpleasant feelings.
lead_paragraph: A new poll conducted by Common Sense Media and Survey Monkey shows, not surprisingly, that most adolescents are worried that the coronavirus will affect their family’s physical or financial health. Further, nearly half of the teenagers surveyed say that they are lonelier than usual, and they fear that they are losing ground academically or in their extracurricular activities.

headline: In the Canyons of Southern California, a Rocky Coming-of-Age
abstract: Kate Milliken’s debut novel, “Kept Animals,” follows the tangled lives of a ranch hand, an equestrienne and a movie star’s daughter in a relationship as fraught as the landscape.
lead_paragraph: KEPT ANIMALSBy Kate Milliken

headline: Daily Aspirin Tied to Lower Risk of Various Digestive Cancers
abstract: Regular aspirin use was associated with a reduced risk for colon, rectal, stomach, esophageal, liver, gallbladder and pancreatic cancers.
lead_paragraph: Regular aspirin use has been associated with a reduced risk for colorectal cancer. Now a review of studies has found that it may reduce the risk for several other digestive tract cancers as well.

headline: Maybe Consider Shaving That Pandemic Beard
abstract: At the very least, stop rubbing your fingers through your new-found facial hair.
lead_paragraph: On March 6, Michael Wade, a student at the College of William and Mary, found out all his MBA classes would move online because of the coronavirus lockdown. On March 7, Mr. Wade quit shaving.

headline: ‘Gracias China!!!’
abstract: While the U.S. leadership in Latin America is being called into question, Beijing is positioning itself to carry the mantle.
lead_paragraph: “Gracias China!!!,” Marcelo Ebrard, the foreign minister of Mexico, posted on Twitter on April 1, along with a photo of the plane that carried 100,000 masks, 50,000 test kits and five ventilators donated from China. Mexico may see as many as 700,000 cases of Covid-19, while the country has a mere 5,500 ventilators. Even though this will without a doubt have an impact on the United States, which shares a 2,000-mile border and robust trade with Mexico, it’s Beijing, not Washington, that is fast-tracking hundreds of ventilators to help the country meet its vulnerability.

headline: If Liquor Stores Are Essential, Why Isn’t Church?
abstract: The new conundrums created by the coronavirus can be addressed by some very old materials: the principles of the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: Churches and synagogues were tragically empty two weekends ago, among the holiest days of the year for America’s Christians and Jews. With few exceptions, the nation’s faithful found solace via computer screens and in solitary prayer, acquiescing to restrictions on their constitutional liberty that would have seemed unthinkable a few months ago.

headline: The Fragile Festival Economy
abstract: They draw crowds, generate income and play a unique role in spurring creativity. Now the coronavirus threatens the future of this tenuous ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: South by Southwest was an early sign that things were getting serious, fast. In early March, the massive multimedia festival held in Austin, Tex. was canceled by city officials just a week before it was scheduled to begin, out of concern for the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: FOMO Is Over. Give In to the Joy of Letting Go.
abstract: As the days of quarantine drag on, many women are reveling in the relinquishment of high heels, painful waxes and constricting garments.
lead_paragraph: Self-seclusion, Week 1. I’d been planning to watch over the health of loved ones. But I’d also been looking forward to having time on my hands: long idle hours during which I’d administer liberal doses of self-love.

headline: What the Negative Price of Oil Is Telling Us
abstract: We’re in a deflationary moment that surpasses anything seen in most people’s lifetimes.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has caused a series of mind-bending distortions across world financial markets, but Monday featured the most bizarre one yet: The benchmark price for crude oil in the United States fell to negative $37.63.

headline: Coogan’s Is Closing. This Is the New York That We’re Losing.
abstract: It was an Irish pub in Upper Manhattan that pulsed with the heartbeat of the world. It shut its doors because of the virus lockdown, and now they won’t reopen.
lead_paragraph: One month ago, to meet the last payroll before the pandemic shut their restaurant, the three owners of Coogan’s in Upper Manhattan got a beverage supplier to take back cases and kegs of beer. Their insurance company would not budge on the quarterly premium, charging the same price to cover the risk of an empty bar and restaurant as one throbbing with people having fun.

headline: Online School Demands More of Teachers. Unions Are Pushing Back.
abstract: Educators say they want to teach from home during the pandemic, but are fighting to limit work hours and counter demands that they consider unreasonable.
lead_paragraph: If it’s naptime and Becky Atherton Dukes’s 2-year-old won’t lie down, she bribes him to stay quiet with the promise of a Matchbox car. She has 380 other children depending on her.

headline: Villanova Still Won’t Have Its First One-and-Done in Decades
abstract: The freshman Jeremiah Robinson-Earl was one of several high-profile college basketball players to withdraw from the N.B.A. draft or to not enter it at all, citing uncertainty related to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When forward Jeremiah Robinson-Earl, a freshman at Villanova, announced last week that he would pull out of the N.B.A. draft and return for his sophomore season, he kept alive a streak that has been running for nearly 25 years.

headline: How The Times Covered the First Earth Day, 50 Years Ago
abstract: For the first Earth Day, on April 22, 1970, The New York Times went big.
lead_paragraph: For the first Earth Day, on April 22, 1970, The New York Times went big.

headline: Why Apple’s iPad Is the Gadget of the Pandemic
abstract: Shelter-in-place orders have transformed the tablet computer from a superfluous device into a must-have.
lead_paragraph: In a flatlining economy, the $399 iPhone that Apple introduced last week might sound attractive. But there’s a better gadget deal in the pandemic: the iPad.

headline: Why Aren’t We Excited About Earth Day Anymore?
abstract: Three organizers from the first event in 1970 remind us that we still have a lot of work to do.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, environmental destruction was upfront and personal. It was in your face. Los Angeles was shrouded in smog. The Cuyahoga River in Cleveland caught fire. Three million gallons of oil spilled off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif. New York City dumped raw sewage into the Hudson River. Bald eagles were teetering near extinction in the lower 48 states because of the ravages of DDT. Leaded gasoline poisoned children.

headline: A Wealth Tax Is the Logical Way to Support Coronavirus Relief
abstract: A onetime assessment of the 5 percent at the top would do wonders — and help prove that we are all in this together.
lead_paragraph: The calamitous coronavirus pandemic has befallen an America afflicted by massive, entrenched economic inequality. The resulting hardships — both present and still to come — fall most heavily on the already disadvantaged. This terrible suffering demands an exceptional response, and policies that were controversial just months ago are common sense today, or ought to be. Our extraordinary battle against the pandemic should draw on the immense reserves that the most privileged among us have accumulated over decades of abundance. To achieve this goal, America should institute a wealth tax.

headline: Roommates in Coronavirus Era: ‘Friends’ It Isn’t
abstract: Living with a roommate has always included some drama. But these days, once petty grievances about cleanliness or visitors have morphed into arguments over safety.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a week, a single flight of stairs in a two-story home in Rolla, Mo., became a no man’s land — the only thing that separated the sick from the healthy. On the dozen or so steps, the healthy roommates left takeout orders and paper plates, and the sick ones returned used plastic utensils and other trash from their bedrooms.

headline: Gaming Sales Are Up, but Production Is Down
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic is offering mixed news and new challenges for gaming companies, both independent and corporate.
lead_paragraph: During the early days of self-quarantine at Larian Studios, the independent video game developer founded in Ghent, Belgium, morale remained high. Designers and engineers, many of whom worked remotely (the company has 300 employees across five countries), were able to continue to do so, building levels and writing code from their homes.

headline: The Politics of Sanity Are Within Our Grasp
abstract: But is Joe Biden too low key for this high-key moment?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I’ve finally figured out who Joe Biden should pick as his running mate. Trust me, she’s perfect.

headline: Vote by Mail in Wisconsin Helped a Liberal Candidate, Upending Old Theories
abstract: A large shift from in-person to mail voting, as happened in the state because of the coronavirus, had been thought to create little advantage for either party. A Times analysis found otherwise.
lead_paragraph: The liberal candidate in Wisconsin’s hard-fought State Supreme Court race this month prevailed in voting by mail by a significant margin, upending years of study showing little advantage to either party when a state transitions from in-person to mail voting.

headline: Pregnant and Scared of ‘Covid Hospitals,’ They’re Giving Birth at Home
abstract: Midwives are seeing a surge in demand from pregnant women who want to deliver their babies at home or in birthing centers.
lead_paragraph: With less than three weeks to go until her baby was due, Aziza Hasanova packed her bags and prepared for what she expected to be a relatively smooth delivery at a Brooklyn outpost of one of New York City’s leading hospitals.

headline: A Museum Devoted to Survivors Now Faces Its Own Fight to Live
abstract: Like other small, endangered arts organizations, the Tenement Museum in Manhattan has drastically cut its budget as it tries to weather the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The Tenement Museum, on Manhattan’s Lower East Side, has always seemed fragile, with its creaky floors and cramped rooms in which striving immigrants once made their homes. Now it seems downright breakable.

headline: ‘Making Family Memories, Living in Lockdown’
abstract: Heide Hendricks and Rafe Churchill have lived in their 1871 Connecticut farmhouse for over a year, but the past month has been the most rewarding.
lead_paragraph: Heide Hendricks and Rafe Churchill have lived in their 1871 Connecticut farmhouse for over a year, but the past month has been the most rewarding.

headline: After Years of Watching It Fall Apart, the Home Was Finally Theirs
abstract: The farmhouse in Sharon, Conn., was ‘impossibly perfect.’ All they had to do was fix 150 years’ worth of damage and bad renovations.
lead_paragraph: Heide Hendricks and Rafe Churchill first saw their new home in the early aughts: an 1871 farmhouse with a big red barn and stone walls, sitting on 33 acres of field and forest so idyllic it looked like something out of a storybook.

headline: Past Into Present: 4 Journeys That Changed Us
abstract: We asked four of our contributors to write about trips that shaped who they are today, and that inspire them now, in these housebound days.
lead_paragraph: An African-American resort town in Michigan, circa 1970; a raucous family road trip from Kansas City, Mo., to New York state; a bittersweet return to Hyderabad, India; and a college student’s self-discovery in Australia: Four New York Times Travel contributors share their memories of trips that still impart a sense of wonder and hope.

headline: ‘How to Pronounce Knife,’ by Souvankham Thammavongsa: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “How to Pronounce Knife,” by Souvankham Thammavongsa
lead_paragraph: The school bus driver was named Jai. It rhymed with chai. He was looking at his wife’s breasts in a photograph. They were tight and perky in the white spandex top she wore. Below that, her bikini bottom was just a patch of cloth in the front, held up by thin strings tied into a small bow. She was sitting on the white sheets of an unmade hotel bed and looking straight at the camera, her knees tucked underneath her. The school bus driver thought his wife looked odd in these vacation pictures. She’d never posed this way before, for him. Her black hair was set in big soft curls and she looked like a child’s doll: blue eyelids, long artificial eyelashes, round rosy cheeks, red lips. She would never, on her own, make herself up like this. This bikini would never be something she’d choose for herself. “Hee keyow,” she would say, shaking her head in disapproval if he ever suggested she wear anything even slightly revealing. This bikini must have been Frank’s idea.

headline: ‘The Moment of Tenderness,’ by Madeleine L’Engle: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Moment of Tenderness,” by Madeleine L’Engle
lead_paragraph: I was about nine years old, curiously but quietly poking about my grandmother Madeleine L’Engle’s manuscripts so as not to disturb her writing and risk losing the privilege of keeping her company in her “Ivory Tower” while she worked. The Tower was just a room over the garage in the eighteenth-century New England farmhouse where she and my grandfather had lived and raised three children during the 1950s and where they still spent weekends, holidays, and long stretches of summer. I’m not sure who christened it “the Tower,” but the name was used ironically by both her and the rest of the family, an acknowledgment of the privilege of solitude and time. The manuscripts I was poking about in were housed in repurposed ream boxes with words like “Eaton” and “Corrasable Bond” on the sides, and in black three-ring binders whose leather casings were beginning to crack. There were dozens of boxes and binders, including ones with A Wrinkle in Time, The Arm of the Starfish, and A Wind in the Door written on them, but I wasn’t interested in the manuscripts of stories that could be read as real books: I was more curious about the scraps and stories and studies in the other boxes. I came across “Gilberte Must Play Bach” in one of those. I’m not sure why I stopped to read this particular one, but I liked the French name in the title, and the imperative. The story was strange to me, and sad, and although the girl in the story was named Claudine, I understood it to be autobiographical. The sadness of the story—and its unresolvedness—shook me and gave me a glimpse at the depth of things we might discover about the people we love.

headline: 382,000 Missing Deaths: Tracking the True Toll of the Coronavirus Outbreak
abstract: Far more people have died over the past months than have been officially reported, a review of mortality data in 32 countries shows.
lead_paragraph: Far more people have died over the past months than have been officially reported, a review of mortality data in 32 countries shows.

abstract: In most zombie movies, there’s usually someone who endangers the lot. Don’t let that be you.
lead_paragraph: Bad roommates can take a toll even in normal times. During a pandemic, they can drive you up a wall.

headline: In a Chaotic Season, Where to Begin Your Spring Cleanup?
abstract: This year, even the easy parts of gardening are challenging. A veteran gardener offers advice and encouragement.
lead_paragraph: Despite my decades of gardening practice, I feel frantic every April — and never more so than in the chaotic spring of 2020, when the normally simple parts of the equation, like acquiring supplies or hiring a helper, present their own challenges on top of the anticipated eruption of perennial weeds like garlic mustard.

headline: You Have to Pay to Give Oil Away
abstract: The price of a barrel of oil dropped below zero, reflecting both short-term technical factors and long-term fundamentals. A recovery seems remote.
lead_paragraph: Our next DealBook Debrief call is about the fallout for the retail industry, which has been hit particularly hard by the pandemic. We’ll be joined by Vanessa Friedman, The Times’s fashion director and chief fashion critic, to discuss how the fashion and luxury industries are coping, and the possible lasting effects. We hope you’ll join us on Thursday, April 23, at 11 a.m. Eastern — R.S.V.P. here. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: Justin Herbert, Homegrown Football Hero, Looks to Relocate
abstract: The Oregon quarterback has leaned on his brothers and the comforts of home to stay ready for the N.F.L. draft.
lead_paragraph: Justin Herbert grew up in Eugene, Ore. He went to college down the street at the University of Oregon. He and his family still live there, a mile from Autzen Stadium, where he set passing records as the Ducks quarterback. And unless an N.F.L. team relocates before the start of this season, Herbert will have to flee the nest.

lead_paragraph: President Trump during the daily coronavirus briefing at the White House on Monday.
