abstract: Governor Cuomo said President Trump had offered federal assistance so the state could do 40,000 tests a day, hopefully within several weeks.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Wednesday’s live coverage.]

headline: Speculation Over Kim Jong-un’s Health Is Fueled by North Korea’s Own Secrecy
abstract: South Korean officials questioned the accuracy of news reports that Mr. Kim was recovering from heart surgery. But rumors persist.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — There was one state event that the secretive leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, never missed: a visit to the Kumsusan Palace of the Sun every April 15 to mark the birthday of his grandfather, the founder of the dynastic regime. In the mausoleum, both his grandfather and his father lie in state.

headline: Earth Day’s Gone Digital. Here’s Where to Find It.
abstract: New York offers many ways to celebrate online. You can hike, play environmental games, conduct experiments, meet scientists and blast into space — all without leaving home.
lead_paragraph: It seems hard to celebrate the natural world when you’re sheltering in place. But even though many Earth Day events have been canceled, several New York institutions are honoring the holiday’s 50th anniversary online. Here you can learn how to raise butterflies indoors, compete in an Earth trivia contest, join citizen science projects and tour sites as close as the city forests and as distant as other planets. These virtual festivities are free, and some last more than a day. Below are select highlights; more possibilities nationwide are at earthday.org.

headline: Twist, Bend, Reach, Step: A Merce Cunningham Solo Anyone Can Try
abstract: Though Cunningham is known for his tricky coordinations, the solo “50 Looks” is possibly his plainest. And it is being taught online.
lead_paragraph: These days, thanks to the cornucopia of online dance classes and tutorials, you can almost imagine yourself to be a dancer. Go ahead, take morning class with Sam Black of the Mark Morris Dance Group, or follow along with New York City Ballet’s Megan Fairchild, even if you don’t have her marvelous turnout. I’ve been doing both. In the real world, it might feel intimidating; online, why not? After all, no one can see you.

headline: Under Cover of Coronavirus, Hong Kong Cracks Down on Protest Movement
abstract: The antigovernment demonstrations that shook the Chinese territory last year have eased since the coronavirus outbreak, but a spate of arrests and Beijing’s assertive rhetoric could revive them.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As the world has been engulfed by the coronavirus pandemic, the authorities in Hong Kong have arrested prominent pro-democracy figures in politics, civil society and the media, waging a broad crackdown on the demonstrations that convulsed the city last year.

lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

abstract: Home-buyers look south of Interstate 10 find something that fits.
lead_paragraph: Home-buyers look south of Interstate 10 find something that fits.

headline: West Adams, Los Angeles: Prices Rise With the Neighborhood’s Popularity
abstract: Priced out of other neighborhoods in the city, home buyers look south of Interstate 10 to find something that fits.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “We kind of followed the typical American dream,” says Paula Henderson, 37. “Got married and decided to start a family, and we wanted a house where a kid could run around and our dog could run around outside.”

abstract: Mr. Alvarez escaped the brutal regime by fleeing to the United States, where he helped organize the opposition Movement for a Free Philippines.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

abstract: Here’s how to create a space and habits that keep kids engaged with schoolwork at home.
lead_paragraph: I’m fairly sure teachers weren’t bribing our kids with cookies and electronics.

headline: What Will Our New Normal Feel Like? Hints Are Beginning to Emerge
abstract: Fear of others may linger long after the pandemic is over. But so may a new sense of community.
lead_paragraph: For all the attention to the science and politics of the coronavirus, another factor may be just as important in shaping life under the pandemic: the ways that people will change in response to it.

headline: Falling in Love Again With ‘All About Eve’
abstract: The magical kingdom of Broadway is shuttered, but our critic returned to it — or rather a version of it that opened his eyes, Bette Davis wide, to New York theater.
lead_paragraph: A month into my time of enforced isolation, the hunger hit me hard, as I knew it would sooner or later. I had to revisit the vipers’ nest, that dangerous and glamorous cradle of illusions found within one square mile of the cold, concrete heart of Manhattan. I’d been away from my people for too long.

headline: Spectrum Employees Are Getting Sick Amid Debate Over Working From Home
abstract: More than 230 workers at Charter Communications, the cable and internet giant known as Spectrum, have tested positive for Covid-19, as employees question how many of them must work in the office.
lead_paragraph: Employees at Charter Communications, the internet, cable TV and phone giant known as Spectrum, have been getting sick while adhering to a company policy that has required thousands of them to work in offices and call centers rather than from home.

headline: I Have Made Gut-Wrenching Choices to Keep People Safe
abstract: The actions Republican and Democratic governors have taken have been done to protect families from the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Since the first positive coronavirus cases were discovered in the United States, governors across the country have made tough choices to protect their citizens. From the beginning, Democratic and Republican governors took action because the health and well-being of our families and neighbors are our No. 1 priority.

headline: Marina Abramovic Just Wants Conspiracy Theorists to Let Her Be
abstract: “I am an artist, not a Satanist,” the performance artist said after an online outcry prompted Microsoft to take down a video of her. It’s not the first time she’s faced the accusation.
lead_paragraph: On April 10, Microsoft uploaded a film to its YouTube account about Marina Abramovic, the Serbian performance artist known for pushing her body to the limit.

headline: F.D.A. Authorizes First In-Home Test for Coronavirus
abstract: The test, sold by LabCorp, would first be made available to health care and other front-line workers, the company said.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday said it had granted emergency clearance to the first in-home test for the coronavirus, a nasal swab kit that will be sold by LabCorp.

headline: Finding the Magic of Cinema in the Tedium of Quarantine
abstract: A Greek festival invited some top art-house filmmakers to create short movies about the lockdown experience. Here are five.
lead_paragraph: For weeks now, billions of people around the world have been quarantined at home, many confined to a routine of cleaning and scrubbing, checking the news and exercising to workout videos. It’s hardly the stuff of great cinema. And yet a group of filmmakers, including some prominent international names, has been making movies about the lockdown experience.

headline: Artists Are Hunkered Down, but Still Nurturing Their Inner Visions
abstract: Artists and architects may be sheltering at home, but their creativity still flows — and the results surprise even them. Here’s what 10 famous makers are looking at, reading, and sketching now.
lead_paragraph: Under most circumstances, the life of an artist or architect requires a lot of solitary time. But none of the 10 artists and architects I spoke to expected to be sheltering somewhere, hiding out from a deadly pandemic with a small number of family members or close friends.

headline: At Least 7 in Wisconsin Got Coronavirus During Voting, Officials Say
abstract: Milwaukee health officials said six voters and one poll worker contracted the coronavirus from participating in Election Day, which was held despite a stay-at-home order issued throughout the state.
lead_paragraph: Milwaukee health officials said they had identified at least seven people who contracted the coronavirus from participating in Election Day on April 7, which was held despite a stay-at-home order issued throughout the state.

headline: In Poland, Communist-Era Restaurants Are Perfect for the Moment
abstract: The simple cafes known as milk bars have regained popularity in recent years. Under lockdown, they’re providing affordable food and the comfort of nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The Polish milk bar is remarkably well suited to the coronavirus lockdown.

headline: ‘Plague on a Biblical Scale’: Hasidic Families Hit Hard by Virus
abstract: In the New York area, the epidemic has killed influential religious leaders and torn through large, tight-knit families.
lead_paragraph: One of the first people Shulim Leifer knew who died of the coronavirus was his great-uncle. Then his grandmother fell ill, as did two of his cousins. The man who lived next door to his childhood home died on a Tuesday, and by Friday the neighbor on the other side was dead as well.

headline: As Coronavirus Spreads, Poison Hotlines See Rise in Accidents With Cleaning Products
abstract: A new study suggests a link between the increase and recommendations to clean and disinfect.
lead_paragraph: As awareness of the coronavirus pandemic has spread throughout the United States, doctors who monitor activity at poison call centers have noticed an alarming trend: a significant increase in accidental exposures to household cleaners and disinfectants.

headline: Lyrid Meteor Shower 2020: Watch It Peak in Night Skies
abstract: Meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
lead_paragraph: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.

headline: Lucinda Williams Is Raw, Riled Up and Ready to Speak Her Mind
abstract: The singer and songwriter’s 14th studio album, “Good Souls Better Angels,” is stocked with fuzzy guitars and pointed political lyrics.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In more than four decades of making music, Lucinda Williams has learned to roll with sizable disruptions. Seated in front of a laptop for an early April video interview in a conspicuously empty room, she quickly dispensed with her latest two challenges: a March tornado that left its mark on her roof, and the self-quarantine that’s kept her and her husband and manager, Tom Overby, inside the sparsely furnished house they moved into shortly before the storm.

headline: Sheriff Told Teen to Take Down Posts About Coronavirus, Family’s Lawsuit Says
abstract: Amyiah Cohoon, 16, was asked to remove Instagram posts about what she believed was her experience with Covid-19 because it upset some parents at her school, the lawsuit said.
lead_paragraph: A few days after Amyiah Cohoon returned to Wisconsin from a school band trip to Florida in the middle of March, she developed a dry cough, a high fever and breathing problems. Amyiah, 16, was taken to the hospital twice, before being sent home and told to stay inside despite testing negative for the coronavirus.

abstract: Selections from Ed’s Lobster Bar, Del Frisco’s Double Eagle Steakhouse, Goldbelly and more.

abstract: There’s a reason the city never sleeps.
lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers, the ritual of grabbing a daily coffee is one of the last luxuries they are holding on to while social distancing.

headline: Jaroslava Brychtova, Creator of Monumental Glass Art, Dies at 95
abstract: Working with her husband, Stanislav Libensky, she made sculptures that pushed the boundaries of glass, winning international acclaim.
lead_paragraph: Jaroslava Brychtova, an internationally acclaimed Czech artist who made large-scale glass sculptures with her husband and collaborator, Stanislav Libensky, pioneering new ways to work with glass, form and light, died on April 8 in Jablonec nad Nisou, a town in the Czech Republic. She was 95.

headline: Weddings Are Their Job. What Happens When Everyone Postpones?
abstract: One month into the pandemic, checking in with event planners, venues, photographers and florists who make up the multibillion dollar wedding industry.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be the start of the busy season for wedding vendors — a time to freshen floral bouquets, ask guests to take their seats and wrangle wayward bridesmaids into picture-perfect arrangements.

headline: This Pandemic Exposes the Downsides of Cheap Uber Rides
abstract: An economic and health crisis is exposing how vulnerable Uber workers really are.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: For Southern Italy, the Coronavirus Becomes a War on 2 Fronts
abstract: As it confronts the ravages of the virus, Italy’s less developed south also faces economic carnage not seen since just after World War II, with the poor turning to handouts.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The coronavirus was already a disaster for Meorina Mazza. In March, it sickened her brother, killed her cousin and prompted officials in Italy’s southern region of Calabria to quarantine her seaside town of San Lucido.

headline: The Death of the Department Store: ‘Very Few Are Likely to Survive’
abstract: Shuttered flagships. Empty malls. Canceled orders. Risks of bankruptcy. The coronavirus has hit the behemoths of the retail world.
lead_paragraph: American department stores, once all-powerful shopping meccas that anchored malls and Main Streets across the country, have been dealt blow after blow in the past decade. J.C. Penney and Sears were upended by hedge funds. Macy’s has been closing stores and cutting corporate staff. Barneys New York filed for bankruptcy last year.

headline: Coronavirus Testing and Tracing: The Path to Normalcy?
abstract: Doctors discuss antibody testing and contract tracing as possible strategies for “eventually returning to life as we once knew it.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Republican-Led Review Backs Intelligence Findings on Russian Interference
abstract: A new Senate report undercuts claims by President Trump and his allies that Obama-era officials sought to undermine him while investigating Russia’s 2016 election meddling.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, President Trump has derided the assessment by American intelligence officials that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election to assist his candidacy, dismissing it without evidence as the work of a “deep state” out to undermine his victory.

headline: Times Theater Fans on Their Favorite Musical Cast Albums
abstract: Our critics picked their 10 desert island cast albums. Our readers had some thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Under normal circumstances cast albums are used by musical theater fans to experience shows that are no longer running, playing too far away or prohibitively expensive. But with live theater currently on hiatus, these recordings are now one of the few ways that musicals remain accessible.

headline: What’s That Racket on the Roof?
abstract: An improvised tennis court above the streets of Italy, a Tom Brady sighting and one-liners on Twitter. Here’s your day of (no) sports.
lead_paragraph: Roof. Set. Match.

headline: A Pandemic Bonus: Catch These TV Shows While They’re Still Free
abstract: Networks and streaming services are putting some high-profile series in front of their paywalls to tempt homebound viewers to subscribe.
lead_paragraph: Like those people in aprons at the big-box store passing out little squares of cheese, a number of streaming services have responded to the Covid-19 pandemic by giving out free television samples. The series they’re putting in front of their paywalls are a loss leader, a handful of candy to get you to subscribe. And therefore their availability is temporary: HBO’s free series will require a subscription again in just over a week, and others, while technically open-ended, won’t be around forever. Here’s a look at the best series on offer and how long you have to watch them free. (And in most cases without registering for a free trial and surrendering your credit-card information.)

headline: Yup, Our Writers Are Still Stuck at Home
abstract: Jennifer Senior, David Brooks, Kara Swisher and other Opinion columnists and writers will be chatting every day at 1 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: It has been well more than a month since stay-in-place orders started taking effect across the country because of the coronavirus crisis. In some places, the curve mercifully seems to be flattening, and staying at home has been a crucial factor — combined with the contributions of our essential workers.

headline: Senate Approves Aid for Small-Business Loan Program, Hospitals and Testing
abstract: The Senate passed a $484 billion relief package, after Democrats and Trump administration officials finalized an agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved a $484 billion coronavirus relief package on Tuesday that would revive a depleted loan program for distressed small businesses and provide funds for hospitals and coronavirus testing, breaking a partisan impasse over the latest infusion of federal money to address the public health and economic crisis brought on by the pandemic.

headline: Christian Health Sharing Group Is Target of Customer Lawsuits
abstract: State regulators in New York and elsewhere are also trying to stop the marketing of plans they say look like health insurance but offer no guarantees of coverage.
lead_paragraph: A major Christian group is being sued by former customers in at least three states who claim it sold them an alternative to health insurance that misled them about protections against large medical bills.

headline: Dementia Patients Aren’t in Their ‘Perfect Mind.’ Then Again, Who Is?
abstract: In “On Vanishing,” Lynn Casteel Harper argues that society needs a better approach to understand and care for people who are suffering cognitive decline.
lead_paragraph: In her 70s, Iris Murdoch began documenting the fraying of her memory in her journals. “Find difficulty in thinking and writing,” she noted. “Be brave.” She would write one more novel, “Jackson’s Dilemma,” before receiving a diagnosis of Alzheimer’s in 1997. Drafts of a letter from that year were later discovered among her papers. “My dear,” she wrote, “I am now going away for some time. I hope you will be well.” A following version was just scrawls.

headline: U.S. Warships Enter Disputed Waters of South China Sea as Tensions With China Escalate
abstract: The move comes as a war of words between the United States and China over the coronavirus pandemic intensifies.
lead_paragraph: American warships have sailed into disputed waters in the South China Sea, according to military analysts, heightening a standoff in the waterway and sharpening the rivalry between the United States and China, even as much of the world is in lockdown because of the coronavirus.

headline: Managing Patient Load
abstract: Doctors discuss the pressing need for a reallocation system among hospitals. Also: Children and screens; the youth vote in November.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Negative Oil Prices Mean and How the Impact Could Last
abstract: The strange thing that happened in oil markets does not mean you can make money storing oil, or that gasoline will cost nothing.
lead_paragraph: A main benchmark for the price of oil fell negative for the first time ever this week. The decline —  more than 300 percent in daily trading — raised fresh questions about the damage the coronavirus is having on the global economy.

headline: Berlin Marathon Is Canceled as Germany Extends Ban on Large Events
abstract: The marathon, scheduled for Sept. 27, became one of the first major fall sports events to be lost.
lead_paragraph: The Berlin Marathon announced it was canceling its race scheduled for late September after the German government said it was banning all events of more than 5,000 people through Oct. 24.

headline: Trump (the Company) Asks Trump (the Administration) for Hotel Relief
abstract: The president’s family business pays at least $3 million a year to the federal government for the lease on its D.C. hotel, which is all but empty because of the virus. The next monthly payment is coming due.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s signature hotel in the nation’s capital wants a break on the terms of its lease. The landlord determining the fate of the request is Mr. Trump’s own administration.

headline: Don’t Think You Need a Coronavirus Test? What if I Paid You?
abstract: Economists say rewards could overcome hurdles in gauging the overall infection and mortality rates from a limited population sample.
lead_paragraph: In March, Andrew Atkeson, an economics professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, tried to assess the mortality rate from the new coronavirus based on what is known about its spread.

headline: How the World of ‘Selah and the Spades’ Was Created
abstract: The writer and director Tayarisha Poe discusses the influences behind her boarding school drama streaming on Amazon Prime.
lead_paragraph: The secret to “Selah and the Spades,” Tayarisha Poe’s incisive debut feature streaming on Amazon Prime, lies in its meticulous presentation of the director’s personal experiences and her pop culture obsessions. “It’s a combination of everything I’ve ever loved,” Poe said during a recent phone interview. Nearly every element of the film, which follows the drama surrounding its titular character and the boarding school faction she leads with unnerving authority, can be traced back to a text, a photograph or a concept she immersed herself in while writing, thinking and shooting. “It’s hard for me not to get into the details really early on, because it is world building for me,” Poe said. Here is a closer look at the influences that shaped the movie’s distinctive world.

headline: Can You Make a Mask Out of Jeans? Bra Pads? Reusable Grocery Bags?
abstract: More researchers are studying everyday materials for homemade masks. Here are the latest findings.
lead_paragraph: With fabric stores closed for the pandemic, crafty consumers have begun scavenging around the house for potential materials to make their own masks. What about using denim jeans? Or bras?

headline: Israelis Find Little to Love in Their New Government, Except No More Elections
abstract: Right-wingers felt betrayed by Netanyahu’s surrender of half the government. Gantz voters felt betrayed by almost everything else in a power-sharing deal.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — At least there won’t be a fourth election.

headline: 5 Rules for Sheltering in Place With Cockroaches, Spiders and Turtles
abstract: Coronavirus has prompted many scientists to make space in their homes for their lab animals.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the coronavirus pandemic prompted universities and museums around the world to dial down their operations, leaving scientists to make difficult decisions about the animals they work with. While some released or culled their specimens — or set up a visitation schedule — others decided to take theirs home, embarking on a different sort of relationship. We checked in with half a dozen scientists about how they’re making it work with their new roommates in this time of social distancing.

headline: How to Care for Your Furry Friends Under Lockdown
abstract: Drop your vanities about their looks, and make your priorities keeping them safe and healthy.
lead_paragraph: Many of us are locked in our houses with our furry best friends, but what happens when that pet gets sick? Or needs a haircut? Or starts to sleep more during the day when we just want to play with them?

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Let us help you start your day.
lead_paragraph: South Korean officials are questioning the accuracy of a report by Daily NK, a website based in Seoul that relies on sources in North Korea, that Kim Jong-un, 36, is recovering from heart surgery performed on April 12.

headline: The Small-Business Aid Program Has Been a Fiasco
abstract: Fortunately, there’s an easy fix.
lead_paragraph: When the federal aid package for small businesses known as the Paycheck Protection Program was announced last month, it seemed to offer a lifeline for modest enterprises in dire need of help because of the coronavirus crisis. Passed by a bipartisan majority in Congress, the program offered $349 billion in forgivable loans — essentially bridge loans — to provide the liquidity needed until the economy recovers. Unlike big-industry bailouts, which generate both moral hazard and public anger, the plan held out the attractive promise of providing relief for the smallest shops on Main Street.

headline: Will the Coronavirus Crush the Resistance?
abstract: Liberal activists rallied, marched and knocked on doors. Now they’re stuck inside.
lead_paragraph: The activists popped into frame a few at a time, the shadowy rectangles of the videoconferencing app Zoom opening grainy windows into their kitchens, bedrooms and livelihoods. A chat icon at the bottom of the screen glowed orange as they said hello.

headline: That Show You Love? There’s No One on Set for It
abstract: My colleagues in the film industry are among the millions of idled workers in America.
lead_paragraph: Some five weeks ago those film companies that take your parking spaces, block your sidewalks and keep you awake at night shut down everywhere in the country and in most places in the world. “I’m in between jobs” is a timeworn Hollywood deflection to avoid admitting that you’re out of work. But now I’m part of an entire industry that is in between jobs.

headline: Puerto Rico Lags Behind Everywhere Else in U.S. in Virus Testing
abstract: A strict lockdown has required much sacrifice from Puerto Ricans, whose patience with the slow pace of testing is running out.
lead_paragraph: Hobbled by government scandal and dysfunction at the start of the pandemic, Puerto Rico has done tests to diagnose the coronavirus at a far lower rate than anywhere else in the United States, a situation that public health experts fear could leave the island uniquely vulnerable once it attempts to reopen.

headline: Mortgage Firms Get a Reprieve on Paying Investors
abstract: The Federal Housing Finance Agency said mortgage servicers must make four months of payments to investors. Then Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will cover them.
lead_paragraph: A federal housing regulator announced a plan on Tuesday to provide financial relief to dozens of mortgage servicing firms caught between investors looking to get paid and homeowners who don’t have money because of the coronavirus crisis.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘In Her World, There’s No Pandemic Outside’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: I call my grandma, haunted by the image of her in assisted living without visitors. “You sound even more beautiful than last time I saw you,” she says. Because of her Alzheimer’s, she forgets when that was, but she never forgets her adoration for my sister, Marissa, and me, her “M&Ms.” In her world, there’s no pandemic outside. For our seven-minute conversation, there’s none in mine either. “I’m so happy you called,” she says. “Now I can go to bed with a smile.” Four days later, she’s gone. Coronavirus I didn’t even know she had. — Meredith Lawrence

headline: Deirdre Bair, Beckett and de Beauvoir Biographer, Dies at 84
abstract: She was an unknown writer with no experience in biographies when she wrote to the elusive Samuel Beckett. To her surprise, he wrote back.
lead_paragraph: Deirdre Bair, who as an unknown writer a half-century ago scored a coup by getting the reclusive Samuel Beckett to agree to let her write his biography, then secured the same permission from another towering literary figure, Simone de Beauvoir, died on Friday at her home in New Haven, Conn. She was 84.

headline: Gunman Kills 9 in Lebanon Mountain Town
abstract: The killings were a rare mass shooting in Lebanon during a time of economic and political crisis.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A gunman went on a rampage in a mountain town in Lebanon on Tuesday, killing nine people, including his wife and brother, before fleeing into the surrounding wilderness, Lebanon’s state-run National News Agency said.

headline: Protesters Pushing to Reopen Economy Are ‘Idiots,’ Says Top Manufacturing Lobbyist
abstract: In a Facebook post and an interview, Jay Timmons, the head of the National Association of Manufacturers, sharply criticized demonstrators who have defied social distancing protocols.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of Jay Timmons’s Facebook friends invited him last week to attend a “Reopen Virginia” rally in Richmond, a protest against the stay-at-home order issued amid the coronavirus by the state’s Democratic governor. Mr. Timmons unfriended the sender, then published a searing retort, criticizing the protesters and accusing them of putting manufacturing workers’ lives at risk by defying rules meant to limit the spread of the virus.

headline: The Reason Hospitals Won’t Let Doctors and Nurses Speak Out
abstract: I know what it’s like to face a gag order after calling attention to life-threatening problems.
lead_paragraph: During the Covid-19 pandemic, it’s not just the risk of disease that has nurses and doctors worried. Across the country, thousands fear that speaking up about shortages of personal protective equipment and staff will lead to disciplinary action and possibly get them fired. Many hospitals have instituted gag orders to make it clear that publicly advocating for safer working conditions could lead to losing one’s job — and as Nicholas Kristof and others have demonstrated, dozens have already been punished.

headline: Someday My Prince Will Leave Me for Someone More Low-Key
abstract: Don’t hate the uptight women dumped by rom-com heroes. They’re high-strung, but they’re assertive. Are they monsters just because they know what they want?
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, on the advice of a colleague, I air-popped some popcorn, squeezed onto the sofa between squabbling children and clicked a “Play” icon, summoning that afternoon’s movie: “Enchanted,” a 2007 Disney release. It stars Amy Adams as Giselle, a fairy-tale princess stranded in contemporary New York. Patrick Dempsey plays Robert, the divorce lawyer whose heart she manually defrosts. “Enchanted” has catchy songs, poufy dresses, a chipmunk sidekick. It is, in most meaningful ways, delightful.

headline: More Than $6 Million in Relief Coming for Lower-Ranked Tennis Players
abstract: The funds, from the Grand Slam tournaments and the sport’s governing bodies, are needed for players who have a difficult time making a living even in ordinary times.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of tennis’s governing bodies announced the creation of a relief fund on Tuesday to help lower-ranked players weather the crisis created by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Dan Scavino Promoted as Meadows Shuffles White House Communications Team
abstract: Mr. Scavino, who is said to be the only White House aide with access to the president’s personal Twitter account, will now be deputy chief of staff for communications.
lead_paragraph: Dan Scavino, the White House director of social media who sometimes operates President Trump’s Twitter feed, has been promoted to deputy chief of staff for communications, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: How Ecuador’s Port City Became a Coronavirus Epicenter
abstract: Ecuador took early aggressive measures to stop the coronavirus, but ended up becoming an epicenter of the pandemic in Latin America. How? We revisit the first confirmed case and what led to the disease’s spread.
lead_paragraph: Ecuador took early aggressive measures to stop the coronavirus, but ended up becoming an epicenter of the pandemic in Latin America. How? We revisit the first confirmed case and what led to the disease’s spread.

headline: Martin Douglas, Who Set Tone for Steel-Pan Brooklyn, Dies at 71
abstract: A deft musician and beloved mentor, he helped keep steel-pan music — his bridge to the Caribbean — a vibrant part of New York life. He had the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Help Is On the Way, Restaurants Are Told. But Will It Work?
abstract: Owners of many small, independent restaurants were passed over by a federal loan program. Now they fear that a new round may not solve their problems.
lead_paragraph: There are days lately when Renato Poliafito feels he is reliving a familiar old nightmare.

headline: Coronavirus Infections May Not Be Uncommon, Tests Suggest
abstract: Two preliminary efforts to survey citizens for antibodies to the virus have produced controversial results.
lead_paragraph: Two new studies using antibody tests to assess how many people have been infected with the coronavirus have turned up numbers higher than some experts had expected.

headline: Rob Gronkowski to Reunite With Tom Brady in Tampa Bay
abstract: The New England Patriots agreed to trade the tight end to the Buccaneers.
lead_paragraph: Rob Gronkowski, the All-Pro tight end who left the N.F.L. after the 2018 season, plans to return to the league, this time with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

headline: Ann Sullivan, Animator of Disney Hits, Dies at 91
abstract: She contributed to modern favorites like “The Little Mermaid” and “The Lion King.” She succumbed to complications of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: The Quiet Hand of Conservative Groups in the Anti-Lockdown Protests
abstract: Groups in a loose coalition have tapped their networks to drive up turnout at recent rallies in state capitals and financed lawsuits, polling and research to combat the stay-at-home orders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An informal coalition of influential conservative leaders and groups, some with close connections to the White House, has been quietly working to nurture protests and apply political and legal pressure to overturn state and local orders intended to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Everyone You Know Just Signed Up for Netflix
abstract: The streaming giant added nearly 16 million new subscribers in the first three months of the year.
lead_paragraph: Netflix has become one of the nation’s all-around distractions, acting as both a supercharged nanny and a nightly balm during the coronavirus crisis.

headline: ‘I’m Just Living a Nightmare’: Oil Industry Braces for Devastation
abstract: Across the United States, companies are laying off workers, shutting down wells and preparing for a prolonged slump as oil prices tumble.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Workers at Marathon Petroleum’s refinery in Gallup, N.M., are turning off the valves. Oil companies in West Texas are paying early termination fees to contract employees rather than drill new wells. And in Montana, producers are shutting down wells and slashing salaries and benefits.

headline: Here Is What We Know About Victims of Canada’s Worst Mass Shooting
abstract: Nova Scotians are grieving amid a coronavirus lockdown the deaths of at least 22 people killed by a gunman. Among the dead: an elementary schoolteacher, a cancer survivor and a family of three.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — One was a 23-year veteran police officer, and mother of two young children, responding to a call about a shooting. Another had just survived her second bout of brain cancer. A third was out for a walk.

headline: Coronavirus Threatens Press Freedom Around the World, Report Says
abstract: The United States, which ranked 45th out of 180 countries and territories, and Brazil were becoming models of hostility toward the news media, according to the World Press Freedom Index.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic may threaten press freedom and worsen the crises that reporters around the world are facing, according to this year’s World Press Freedom Index, which evaluates the landscape for journalists in 180 countries and territories.

headline: Cheryl A. Wall, 71, Dies; Champion of Black Literary Women
abstract: An author and longtime professor at Rutgers, she pressed for the inclusion of black authors in curriculums and was an expert on Zora Neale Hurston.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl A. Wall, an author and longtime Rutgers University professor who helped elevate Zora Neale Hurston and other black women into English literature curriculums, died on April 4 at her home in Highland Park, N.J. She was 71.

headline: When Your Phone Says You’ve Been Exposed to the Coronavirus
abstract: Silicon Valley wants to help end the pandemic. Is that a good thing?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: So You’re Having a Baby During a Pandemic
abstract: First: Congrats! Now: How do you celebrate? How do you talk about it? What does a baby shower look like today?
lead_paragraph: I recently heard from a woman who didn’t plan anything for her niece’s birth date. She said she’s been feeling regretful that, because of the coronavirus pandemic, her family wasn’t able to come together to welcome this new child. I told her: It isn’t too late! She could still organize an event. It just might look a little different than a typical baby shower or sip-and-see.

headline: Overlooked No More: Eunice Foote, Climate Scientist Lost to History
abstract: Foote’s ingenious experiment more than 150 years ago yielded a remarkable discovery that could have helped shape modern climate science had she not been overshadowed.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: House Readies Historic Changes to Allow Remote Voting During Pandemic
abstract: Democratic leaders plan to temporarily dispatch with two centuries of precedent as the coronavirus upends American life and government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic leaders plan to move this week to change the rules of the House of Representatives to allow lawmakers to cast votes remotely for the first time in its 231-year history, a major concession to the constraints created by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Green Cards, Oil Markets, Netflix: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Iraq Resists Iranian Pressure to Reopen Border Closed to Slow Covid-19
abstract: With the coronavirus raging in Iran, a push to distance their country from their neighbor has gained broader appeal in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Truck by truck, border post by border post, a power struggle is unfolding between Iraq and Iran over when to reopen the frontier between the two countries, which Iraq closed five weeks ago to limit the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: New U.S. Treatment Guidelines for Covid-19 Don’t See Much Progress
abstract: A panel of experts said there was insufficient evidence about many drugs that have been considered as possible remedies for coronavirus patients, including some President Trump has advocated.
lead_paragraph: The federal agency led by Dr. Anthony Fauci issued guidelines on Tuesday that stated there is no proven drug for treating coronavirus patients, a finding that essentially reinforces Dr. Fauci’s dissent from President Trump’s repeated promotion of certain drugs without evidence to support their use.

headline: We Need Great Leadership Now, and Here’s What It Looks Like
abstract: These times are testing leaders from the schoolhouse to the White House, from city halls to corporate suites.
lead_paragraph: In a time of crisis, like we are in now, with people feeling frightened and uncertain, leadership doesn’t just matter more. It matters exponentially more.

headline: Upright Citizens Brigade to Close Its Permanent Locations in New York
abstract: The group, which has incubated a generation of star comedians, is shutting down its theater in Hell’s Kitchen and its training center on Eighth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: In another cultural casualty of the pandemic, the Upright Citizens Brigade is planning to close its two Manhattan locations, leaving the storied improv and sketch comedy hub without its own permanent space in the city.

headline: In the Netherlands, the Dance Festivals Have Gone Dark
abstract: The Dutch dominated a global, multibillion-dollar industry employing tens of thousands and spawning millionaire D.J.’s. On Tuesday, it was shuttered.
lead_paragraph: AMSTELVEEN, the Netherlands — It would have been a routine gig, playing electronic dance music in a sports stadium filled with 40,000 fans at a festival in Chengdu, China, last weekend.

headline: Trump and Cuomo Put Aside Disputes During White House Meeting
abstract: After alternating praise and quarrels for weeks, President Trump and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York had what the governor called “a good conversation” over testing and aid to states and localities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, two New Yorkers who have alternately praised and quarreled with each other during the coronavirus pandemic that has ravaged their mutual home state, met in person on Tuesday to try to resolve differences over testing and financial relief.

headline: How Cancer Prepared Me for Life Under Coronavirus
abstract: On savoring the glories of just one future summer.
lead_paragraph: Surely more than once you have hiked atop mountains spilling to the sea or downed a glass of wine that had no equal or plunged from a dock into an emerald bay and thought: “This is so perfect. If I never do this again in my life, I will be satisfied.”

headline: Coronavirus Takes Over Political Advertising
abstract: Political campaigns were reluctant to focus too heavily on the coronavirus outbreak. What changed?
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: New Immigration Limits Cause Anxiety in Families and Businesses
abstract: President Trump’s move to suspend some green cards could make it harder for many immigrants to reunite with loved ones or work in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Families that have waited years to be reunited, businesses that rely on foreign workers, universities that recruit international students with the promise of high-paying American jobs — all of their plans faced new uncertainty on Tuesday as the Trump administration announced new temporary restrictions on permanent residency in the United States.

headline: ‘I Am Beyond Disturbed’: Internal Dissent as States Reopen Despite Virus
abstract: Several mayors and employers have asked residents to ignore the Georgia governor’s declaration that some businesses can resume operation while the coronavirus lingers.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The decision by Gov. Brian Kemp to begin restarting Georgia’s economy drew swift rebukes on Tuesday from mayors, public health experts and some business owners, with skeptics arguing that the plan might amplify another wave of coronavirus outbreaks.

headline: The Census Needs to Count Women. The Pandemic Makes That Harder.
abstract: After noticing a gender gap in intention to participate, the Census Bureau kicked off a campaign this year to encourage more women to take part.
lead_paragraph: — Maria Olmedo-Malagon, a Census Bureau employee, on what could happen if women aren’t counted

headline: Don’t Celebrate Earth Day. Fight for It.
abstract: The 1970 gathering ushered in significant achievements in protecting our environment. Now Trump is destroying them.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, millions of people took to the streets to protest the air and water pollution that were making us sick. Today, millions are sheltering inside to try to stem the spread of a very different kind of sickness, Covid-19.

headline: Trump Halts New Green Cards, but Backs Off Broader Immigration Ban
abstract: After pledging on Twitter to end immigration during the pandemic, President Trump moved to block new green cards but stopped short of ending all work visas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Tuesday that he would order a temporary halt in issuing green cards to prevent people from immigrating to the United States, but he backed away from plans to suspend guest worker programs after business groups exploded in anger at the threat of losing access to foreign labor.

headline: There’s a Common Thread Tying Together 2019’s ‘Most Challenged’ Books: L.G.B.T.Q. Issues
abstract: Eight of the 10 titles identified in the American Library Association’s annual ranking of the most frequently banned or protested books featured L.G.B.T.Q. subject matter.
lead_paragraph: Eight of the 10 most challenged books last year were based on L.G.B.T.Q. subjects or narratives, the American Library Association said in its annual ranking of books that were banned or protested in schools and public libraries.

headline: England’s Premier League Becomes Latest Proxy for Saudi-Qatar Dispute
abstract: A Qatar broadcast company that has accused Saudi Arabia of pirating its signals is asking the league to block a sale of the Newcastle United team to a Saudi-led group.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The proxy war between Saudi Arabia and Qatar has spilled over into England’s Premier League, with a Qatari broadcast company seeking to block a Saudi Arabia-backed takeover of the Newcastle United team.

headline: Where Is Trump’s Plan to Test Millions of Americans a Day?
abstract: Testing is how we let people start returning safely to work, to school, to stores.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York offered a blunt and troubling summary of America’s coronavirus predicament on Friday. To revive the economy, he said, “You have to develop a testing capacity that does not now exist.”

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: As some states ease restrictions, they are meeting resistance from mayors, health experts and business leaders who say it’s too soon.
lead_paragraph: The governors of some states, including Georgia, are easing stay-at-home orders and allowing some businesses to reopen, despite immense criticism and loud warnings from public health experts that the coronavirus outbreak has not leveled off.

headline: Virginia Savage McAlester, ‘Queen of Dallas Preservation,’ Dies at 76
abstract: Her book “A Field Guide to American Houses,” published in 1984 and revised in 2013, made her a household name among preservationists and architecture buffs.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Savage McAlester, an architectural historian, author and preservationist who was widely known as the “Queen of Dallas Preservation,” died on April 9 in Dallas. She was 76.

headline: Corrections: April 22, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about Israeli hospitals’ decision to allow family members to visit coronavirus wards misspelled part of the name of a coronavirus patient and her daughter. The patient is Batsheva Vita, not Zita, and her daughter is Rinat Vita-Dishlo, not Zita-Dishlo.

headline: Former Head of XFL Sues Its Controlling Owner
abstract: The former commissioner said the football league, which filed for bankruptcy, breached the terms of his contract.
lead_paragraph: The former commissioner of the XFL recently filed a wrongful-termination lawsuit in federal court against the football league’s controlling owner, Vince McMahon, three days after the short-lived sports venture filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Chipotle to Pay $25 Million Fine for Tainted Food
abstract: The charges in the case stemmed in part from incidents related to norovirus outbreaks, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Chipotle Mexican Grill on Tuesday agreed to pay $25 million to resolve criminal charges accusing the fast food company of serving tainted food from 2015 to 2018, sickening over 1,100 people in the United States, federal prosecutors said.

headline: How Many More Weeks (Years)? Watching ‘Groundhog Day’ Together
abstract: It’s the same thing every day. Clean up your room. Stand up straight. Sit down for a classic comedy while we’re in quarantine. Here’s what happened at our viewing party.
lead_paragraph: OK, readers, rise and shine — Sonny and Cher are on the radio!

headline: 50 Years of Earth Day: What’s Better Today, and What’s Worse
abstract: Here are 10 big environmental victories — and 10 big failures.
lead_paragraph: Here are 10 big environmental victories — and 10 big failures.

headline: Location, Location, Location
abstract: Jules Markey gives us some good advice.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Jules Markey, he was shouting at us, in a way that spoke volumes, but we won’t hold that against him. Not when he has returned with some good advice and a puzzle with some superfun, midweek-level clues.

headline: Facebook Invests $5.7 Billion in Indian Internet Giant Jio
abstract: It was the largest bet by the social network on the developing market, where millions of people have gone online in recent years.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook on Tuesday made its largest single investment by putting $5.7 billion into Jio Platforms of India, an enormous bet on the developing market and a sign of how large tech companies are forging ahead in the pandemic.

headline: Trump Says Harvard Must Pay Back Relief Money He Signed Into Law
abstract: Joining a chorus of critics, the president appeared not to realize that Harvard had received $8.6 million in stimulus funding as part of a federal aid package to universities.
lead_paragraph: President Trump joined mounting criticism of Harvard on Tuesday, saying the richest university in the country would pay back $8.6 million in relief money from a coronavirus stimulus package that the president himself signed last month.

headline: Quotation of the Day: They Amplify Fight Against Lockdowns, Quietly
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “We have a lot of wind and the wind has pretty much helped us here.”

headline: When You Need a Break From Beans, Crab on Toast Is the Answer
abstract: After my wife and I both lost our jobs, we diligently conserved our resources — until we didn’t. Then a splurge brought us back to life.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I, both restaurant chefs who have abruptly lost our jobs, have been living for more than a month soberly and devoutly conserving our resources. You could mistake us for back-to-the-land homesteaders. I gave her a haircut, and she sprouted the scallions on the windowsill. I’ve learned to make the cottony Kaiser rolls my kids love that we usually buy from the deli. She has rigged the dining-room maple table into a hacked Ping-Pong surface for our nightly tournament because even movie rentals for $4.99 seem irresponsible. So I hope it will make sense why, recently, I went out and spent $56 on a tub of fresh-picked crab meat.

headline: Live Events This Week: Earth Day, NYT for Kids and More
abstract: Here’s how Times journalists can help you stay connected and understand our changing world.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has transformed nearly every aspect of daily life, but New York Times journalists are here to keep you informed and connected while you’re at home. Below is a selection of our live events this week and how to join (all times are Eastern Standard). You can find the full calendar here.

headline: Economic Chaos Fuels Hunger and Strongmen
abstract: The E.U. accused Poland and Hungary of undermining democracy — and gave them billions in aid. Iran may be executing prisoners who feared infection.
lead_paragraph: From Iraq to Venezuela, nations reliant on oil sales have seen the combination of the price collapse and the coronavirus pandemic create new threats of poverty and political instability.

headline: With Selective Coronavirus Coverage, China Builds a Culture of Hate
abstract: The state propaganda machine highlights other countries’ mistakes while suppressing China’s, fueling anger toward foreigners and domestic critics alike.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Noah, the host of “The Daily Show,” has won praise on the Chinese internet for his searing criticism of the Trump administration’s mishandling of the coronavirus pandemic. So has Jerry Kowal, an American who makes Chinese-language videos chronicling the dire situation in New York.

headline: Coronavirus, Italy’s Economy, Earth Day: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: State by State: Comparing Coronavirus Death Rates Across the U.S.
abstract: Even as governors look to lift restrictions, the country continues to see spikes in deaths from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Even as governors look to lift restrictions, the country continues to see spikes in deaths from the coronavirus.

headline: Airlines and Automakers Consider How to Reopen
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: On Earth Day, a Cartoonist Glances Back at Rachel Carson’s Classic
abstract: A graphic review of “Silent Spring,” the book that helped launch the environmental movement.

headline: Europe Needs to Come Together. But Not Like This.
abstract: It’s neither necessary nor prudent to distribute debt across the continent.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Spider-Man, that force for good, taught us that with great power comes great responsibility. That’s especially true in times of strife. So in the midst of arguably Europe’s worst crisis since 1945, is Germany — the continent’s powerhouse — living up to its great responsibility?

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘She Walks with Apes’ and ‘Fauda’
abstract: A documentary about pioneering primatologists airs on BBC America. And a new season of an Israeli action series is on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: SHE WALKS WITH APES (2020) 9 p.m. on BBC America. “As a kid, I was really desperate to find strong women role models that I could look up to,” Iulia Badescu, a Canadian primatologist, says in this documentary. She went through a Joan of Arc phase, and a Queen Elizabeth I phase. And then she found Jane Goodall. The documentary looks at the legacies of Goodall, Dian Fossey and Birute Galdikas, three women who found fame doing groundbreaking primatology work in the 20th century. It explores the influence of their studies on three younger researchers, including Badescu. The documentary is narrated by the actress Sandra Oh.

headline: Coronavirus Death in California Came Weeks Before First Known U.S. Death
abstract: The earliest U.S. deaths publicly attributed to the virus had been on Feb. 26, when two people died in the Seattle area. Santa Clara County said an autopsy showed a Feb. 6 death was also related.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Officials in Santa Clara County, Calif., announced late Tuesday that two residents there died of the coronavirus in early and mid-February, making them the earliest known victims of the pandemic in the United States.

headline: Word + Quiz: flak
abstract: This word has appeared in 49 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Some Bake During Lockdown. Trump Bans Immigrants, Trevor Noah Notes.
abstract: Trevor Noah joked that Trump is finding ways to keep busy while Americans are “finally getting around to watching ‘Ozark’ and trying to bake bread for the first time.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Protesting
abstract: What is this image saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? What is your opinion of its message?
lead_paragraph: What is this image saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Canada Will Have a Big Say on the Return of Major Sports in the U.S.
abstract: President Trump is pushing for the return of sports soon in the United States. Up in Canada, that’s not happening.
lead_paragraph: As North America’s professional sports leagues try to figure out how to restart their games, they have to consider a factor that isn’t getting a lot of attention in the United States at the moment: Canada.

headline: Covid-19 Arrived in Seattle. Where It Went From There Stunned the Scientists.
abstract: Scientists traced the virus brought to the Seattle area in January. They were astonished to learn that the same branch of the virus traveled on through at least a dozen states and to other parts of the world.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — As the coronavirus outbreak consumed the city of Wuhan in China, new cases of the virus began to spread out like sparks flung from a fire.

headline: The Mortuary Science Professor Who Came ‘Out of Nowhere’ to Help N.Y.C.
abstract: With New York City funeral homes overwhelmed by the coronavirus, a professor from an upstate town has been transporting bodies so families don’t have to wait weeks for cremation services.
lead_paragraph: David Penepent walked into the back chapel of a funeral home in Queens on Thursday and surveyed a scene unthinkable before the coronavirus epidemic. Thirty people had been laid out in the chilled room, the bodies held in boxes made of cardboard and wood with “handle with extreme care” printed on the sides in bold, green letters.

headline: Oil Collapse and Covid-19 Create Toxic Geopolitical Stew
abstract: For nations reliant on oil sales, the combination of the price collapse and the coronavirus pandemic has created new threats of poverty and political instability from Iraq to Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: Iraq cannot afford to pay millions of workers and pensioners. Mexico’s grand plans to develop the country have been thrown into disarray. Ecuador is cutting government salaries, and Venezuela is on life support. Nigeria is seeking a nearly $7 billion emergency loan.

headline: We’re All Grieving. This Is How We Get Through It.
abstract: As the coronavirus robs us of the life we cherish, a renowned therapist has some advice.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus robs us of the life we cherish, a renowned therapist has some advice.

headline: What It’s Like Inside a Bronx Apartment During Coronavirus
abstract: Tanya Denise Fields documented what her life has been like while under quarantine during the coronavirus outbreak. She lives in a three-bedroom apartment in the Bronx and has to care for a family of eight.
lead_paragraph: Tanya Denise Fields documented what her life has been like while under quarantine during the coronavirus outbreak. She lives in a three-bedroom apartment in the Bronx and has to care for a family of eight.

headline: Afghanistan’s Next War
abstract: What happens when the pandemic comes to a country in conflict?
lead_paragraph: What happens when the pandemic comes to a country in conflict?

headline: We’re All Grieving. This Is How We Get Through It.
abstract: As the coronavirus robs us of the life we cherish, a renowned therapist has some advice.
lead_paragraph: Anxiety, dread, depression — these are just some of the emotions that hit us as we shelter in place and as death tolls rise. In the Video Op-Ed above, the psychotherapist Esther Perel coaches us through the losses and collective grief we are experiencing.

headline: How Do I Deal With a Friend Who Thinks Covid-19 Is a Hoax?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do when a friend believes the coronavirus pandemic is a worldwide conspiracy — and more.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine whom I’ve kept in contact with over text message (we live in different countries) does not believe the Covid-19 pandemic is real. He is taking precautions and practicing social distancing, but he told me that he believes Covid-19 is a political, worldwide hoax to control people. I was flabbergasted to hear this. I tried to explain to him that the disease is no hoax: I know doctors fighting it, I know people who have contracted the virus and so on. But nothing has persuaded him.

headline: How Bird-Watching Prepared Me for Sheltering in Place
abstract: I’ve learned to pay attention, to seek solace in the act of looking, again and again.
lead_paragraph: Chimney Rock, on the eastern spur of the Point Reyes headlands in California, is well known for the elephant seals that congregate there. One afternoon, while walking down the path overlooking them, I saw a woman looking through a spotting scope on a tripod, directed out toward the water. It turned out she was watching seabirds. She told me she started bird-watching as she got older because she was analytically minded, loved numbers and words, but struggled with visual memory and acuity and wanted to strengthen those faculties. Having similar proclivities, I listened closely. Eventually, she asked me if I wanted to look.

headline: Simplify Even More? Yes, It’s Possible
abstract: These books offer suggestions for distilling your life down to its essence.
lead_paragraph: Months ago, when I decided to review books that would show us how to simplify our lives, I didn’t anticipate I’d be writing during a pandemic, where we’d have nothing to do except send our friends memes of quarantine drinking, irritated pets and desperate mothers hiding from their children in their cars. Somehow, I was scooped by nature.

headline: What Does Your Accent Say About Who You Are?
abstract: Are you proud of your accent? Do you have favorite slang or expressions from your city or town? How important is your accent to your identity?
lead_paragraph: Note to Teachers: Some of the videos embedded in the Times article include profanity that has been beeped out. Please preview if you are using this prompt with students.

headline: Older and Stuck at Home? Expert Advice on Fitness
abstract: Experts who study exercise and aging offer tips for older adults during the coronavirus lockdown.
lead_paragraph: When we asked readers what they want to know about exercise and the coronavirus, many of you wrote that you were concerned about how to exercise and maintain fitness if you or someone you love is older or has functional limitations, such as arthritis or joint replacements. Experts who study exercise and aging had a lot to say.

headline: When You’re Not a ‘Math Person’ and Your Kid Needs Help
abstract: How to support your children in home-school lessons that may be outside your skill set.
lead_paragraph: Nearly all schoolwork is now homework, and many parents are struggling to support their kids at home.

headline: The Coronavirus Makes Our Old Culture Wars Seem Quaint
abstract: There are fights worth having. These are some of them.
lead_paragraph: Most of the time, when I think back to the world before, I feel longing. I miss everything. I miss dinner parties and swimming laps. I miss bars. I miss being close enough to eavesdrop. The idea of walking into an office building thrills me.

headline: Pandemic Propaganda Is Coming. Be Ready for It.
abstract: Americans will have to choose what to believe in a swelling sea of disinformation.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a viral post attributed to Stanford University circulated on social media claiming that if you can hold your breath without coughing for more than 10 seconds, you most likely don’t have Covid-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus. I initially believed it was credible and forwarded it to friends before I learned it was fake. I have studied influence campaigns for most of my career. How could I have been so foolish?

headline: Only Bill Belichick Knows What’s Next for the New England Patriots
abstract: Whatever his plan for the Patriots’ new era, the taciturn coach is not tipping his hand. “Not sure exactly how that’s going to go,” he said about finding a quarterback to replace Tom Brady.
lead_paragraph: Even the tight-lipped Bill Belichick admits that this week’s N.F.L. draft, and this year’s off-season, will be vastly different from any other for the New England Patriots in this century.

headline: Before Coronavirus, Theater Was My Salvation. Where Do I Turn Now?
abstract: The live-streamed performances and online group chats have been useful, but I miss the joy that comes with being in a theater.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I quietly (and socially distantly) celebrated my 88th birthday. Some people might say that, even in good times, looking toward the future at my age is an act of optimism. But a life in the theater is built on exactly that kind of blind confidence, and I’ve spent my life pretty much always looking forward to whatever was the next thing: the next role, the next milestone, the next great show to see.

headline: States Are Being Crushed by the Coronavirus. Only This Can Help.
abstract: Congress must step in and offer quick and generous aid to states before they must slash services and drag down the economy.
lead_paragraph: State governments are facing a fiscal crisis born of collapsing revenues, increased demand for safety-net programs like Medicaid and the direct costs of leading the Covid-19 response. If nothing changes, states will soon be forced to make deep cuts in vital public services, worsening the recession and slowing the ensuing recovery.

headline: Making the Most of Hotel Loyalty Programs When You’re Not Traveling
abstract: Some loyalty programs are extending customers’ elite status, lengthening expiration dates on rewards and more. Here’s how to navigate them.
lead_paragraph: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.

headline: Canada Goose Will Stop Buying Fur — Sort Of
abstract: As of 2022, the luxury outerwear brand will no longer purchase new coyote fur. But it is not giving up fur entirely.
lead_paragraph: Canada Goose has long stood by its use of fur, even as fashion’s biggest names have vowed to stop selling it. It’s hard to imagine the company’s signature $1,000 (or so) parkas without their coyote fur-trimmed hoods cocooning city dwellers in Arctic-grade warmth every winter.

headline: Two Parents. Two Kids. Two Jobs. No Child Care.
abstract: And no end in sight.
lead_paragraph: Things are starting to break down. I don’t just mean psyche and soul and social bonds and sense of self. I mean ordinary, overworked things around the house: the dishwasher, the garage-door opener, the fridge door, the faucet in the kids’ bathroom, the towel hanger in the kids’ bathroom, the toilet in the kids’ bathroom. (Don’t ask.)

headline: Imagine Online School in a Language You Don’t Understand
abstract: The parents of millions of American schoolchildren are not fluent in English, presenting an extra challenge to learning at home.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Like many parents, Zainab Alomari has spent the last month trying to help her children learn at home. But unlike most, she has been talking to teachers and working through lessons in a language she barely understands.

headline: Is Biden Gaining Older Voters, and Losing Young Ones?
abstract: Even modest differences could prove crucial in an election that begins with numbers and coalitions very similar to those in 2016.
lead_paragraph: After impeachment, a coronavirus pandemic and four years of tweets, the early national polls show that the 2020 presidential campaign begins almost exactly where it left off in 2016.

headline: It’s OK to Find Humor in Some of This
abstract: Laughter, however hollow, is one of the main coping mechanisms during periods of sickness, death and anxiety. So don’t feel guilty.
lead_paragraph: “Unreasonably dark joke,” read a coronavirus meme circulating on social media in recent weeks. “Shouldn’t we wait until after the pandemic to fill out the census?”

headline: Should Masks Be a Fashion Statement?
abstract: Capitalist opportunities often emerge from times of trauma. That doesn’t make the origin stories any less uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: Almost as soon as Louis Vuitton, Gucci, Prada and Brooks Brothers announced earlier this month that they would be repurposing parts of their factories to make masks and hospital gowns, the memes and comments started flying.

headline: No, Mr. President, Your Immigration Powers Are Not Unlimited
abstract: Freezing immigrant admissions won’t protect public health or save American jobs.
lead_paragraph: A president has broad powers over immigration under the Constitution and federal laws, but they are not unlimited. At the very least, there must be a reasonable basis for restrictions on immigration. None exists for President Trump’s threat to temporarily ban all immigrant visa admissions to the United States.

headline: Jay Inslee Endorses Biden, Citing Private Conversations on Climate Policy
abstract: The governor of Washington State, one of the Democratic Party’s most prominent environmentalists, urged progressives to get on board with the presumptive presidential nominee’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington State, one of the Democratic Party’s most prominent environmentalists, endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. for president on Wednesday after extensive private conversations in which Mr. Biden signaled he would make fighting climate change a central cause of his administration.

headline: A Closed Border Can’t Stop This Elderly Couple: ‘Love Is the Best Thing in the World’
abstract: The coronavirus crisis has separated families and severed supply chains. But a pair of lovers, 89 and 85, have found a romantic way to keep (almost) in touch.
lead_paragraph: MOLLEHUSVEJ BORDER CROSSING — She drives from the Danish side, in her Toyota Yaris.

headline: Protecting Workers From Coronavirus: OSHA Leaves It to Employers
abstract: Critics say the federal agency charged with protecting worker safety has played a conspicuously small role during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Adam Ryan, a Target employee in Christiansburg, Va., has felt unsafe at work in recent weeks. He finds it difficult to follow the recommendation that he stay six feet away from others because the store is often crowded and customers linger closely while he restocks shelves.

headline: Chinese Agents Helped Spread Messages That Sowed Virus Panic in U.S., Officials Say
abstract: American officials were alarmed by fake text messages and social media posts that said President Trump was locking down the country. Experts see a convergence with Russian tactics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The alarming messages came fast and furious in mid-March, popping up on the cellphone screens and social media feeds of millions of Americans grappling with the onset of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Trump Reaches Back Into His Old Bag of Populist Tricks
abstract: The president wants 2020 to be a replay of 2016, thematically speaking. In that sense, the coronavirus has changed nothing.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has chosen his pandemic re-election strategy. He is set on unifying and reinvigorating the groups that were crucial to his 2016 victory: racially resentful whites, evangelical Christians, gun activists, anti-vaxxers and wealthy conservatives.

headline: An ESPN Commercial Hints at Advertising’s Deepfake Future
abstract: With the pandemic having shut down production, companies are asking ad agencies to create commercials made up of digitally altered footage.
lead_paragraph: Unable to film new commercials during the coronavirus pandemic, advertising agencies are turning to technologies that can seamlessly alter old footage, sometimes putting viewers in a position of doubting what they are seeing.

headline: Food, Rent, Health Insurance? Tough Choices in Pandemic Economy
abstract: As items that were once necessities become luxuries, increasingly strapped Americans are re-evaluating what they spend and how.
lead_paragraph: Two days before learning that she would lose her job, Lissa Gilliam spent hundreds of dollars online on baby products.

headline: When Mom’s Zoom Meeting Is the One That Has to Wait
abstract: “The way we’ve been able to MacGyver a career as a woman is completely under attack by a global pandemic.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As soon as she began planning to work from home, Saba Lurie knew she would need to make major adjustments in how she operates her private psychotherapy practice, from counseling patients through a screen to managing her staff remotely.

headline: 7 Travel Stories to Help You Celebrate the 50th Anniversary of Earth Day
abstract: Confined to the great indoors on Earth Day? These stories will help remind you of the natural world’s many splendors — and why environmental protections are of crucial importance for the future of the planet.
lead_paragraph: Because of coronavirus restrictions, many of the celebrations for the 50th anniversary of Earth Day have been forced indoors and online. To help offset the isolation of worldwide social-distancing measures, the Travel desk has collected a series of stories to help recall the spirit of the annual event.

headline: ‘This Is Crazy’: 6 Kids, 1 Dog and a Mom With Covid-19
abstract: This is what it's like inside a South Bronx apartment when you have Covid-19 and a family of eight to care for.

headline: Living In ... Stonington, Conn.
abstract: New Yorkers seeking respite from the city have long gravitated to Connecticut’s easternmost shoreline town, with its 18th- and 19th-century homes.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers seeking respite from the city have long gravitated to Connecticut’s easternmost shoreline town, with its 18th- and 19th-century homes.

headline: Stonington, Conn.: A Waterfront Community With a Colonial Vibe
abstract: New Yorkers seeking respite from the city have long gravitated to Connecticut’s easternmost shoreline town, with its 18th- and 19th-century homes.
lead_paragraph: Karen von Ruffer Hills and Francis Hills discovered the coastal town of Stonington, in southeastern Connecticut, when friends invited them for a weekend getaway at a local inn in 2009.

headline: Classic Skyscrapers Define New York. Take a Virtual Tour.
abstract: The epitome of the ‘Mad Men’ era, the sleek midcentury buildings of Park Avenue glimmer. Our critic strolls with the architect Annabelle Selldorf.
lead_paragraph: It’s a metaphor for Manhattan, a synonym for “Mad Men,” the apex of midcentury modernist New York. It supplanted some of the city’s stateliest mansions with corporate palaces in blue glass and bronze. The Park Avenue School of Architecture is the term the critic Ada Louise Huxtable employed to define the “sleek and shiny” postwar skyline, which moved the concept of elegance, as she put it, “from domestic to professional life, from the apartment house to the office building.”

headline: What Is the Coronavirus Doing to North Korea?
abstract: There are no cases here, Kim Jong-un’s government claims, while acting as if its survival were at stake.
lead_paragraph: Three generations of totalitarian misrule have left North Korea woefully incapable of containing, or even suppressing, a coronavirus epidemic. The same intelligent (and malevolent) design that has turned the country into the world’s most exquisitely oppressive police state has also inadvertently converted it into a prospective infection deathtrap.

headline: What You Get for $600,000
abstract: A 1725 cottage in Newport, a ranch house in Denver and a Queen Anne Victorian in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: A 1725 cottage in Newport, a ranch house in Denver and a Queen Anne Victorian in Baltimore.

headline: Vaccine Chief Says He Was Removed After Questioning Drug Trump Promoted
abstract: The first known U.S. death from the illness came in early February in California. Trump says he ‘strongly’ disagrees with Georgia’s governor on reopening some businesses.
lead_paragraph: The doctor who led the federal agency involved in developing a coronavirus vaccine said on Wednesday that he was removed from his post after he pressed for rigorous vetting of hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malaria drug embraced by President Trump as a coronavirus treatment, and that the administration has put “politics and cronyism ahead of science.”

headline: Trump Says He’ll Help N.Y. Double Its Testing
abstract: Governor Cuomo said President Trump had offered federal assistance so the state could do 40,000 tests a day, hopefully within several weeks.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Coronavirus, Oil, Earth Day: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Who’s Organizing the Lockdown Protests?
abstract: An informal coalition of influential conservative leaders and groups has been quietly encouraging demonstrations against stay-at-home orders across the country.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: How Coronavirus Has Made Us All Very Handy
abstract: As we hunker down in our homes, many of us are finally taking on those D.I.Y. projects we had been putting off.
lead_paragraph: Wesley Storey has been documenting on Instagram the home repair tasks he’s attended to since he and his husband, Martin Esqueda, started working from home last month.

headline: Coronavirus Crisis Offers Taiwan a Chance to Push Back Against China
abstract: Saying “Taiwan Can Help,” the island is resisting China’s efforts to isolate the self-ruling democracy that Beijing claims as its territory.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — They are sending millions of masks, emblazoned with the words “made in Taiwan,” to the United States, Italy and other countries hit hard by the coronavirus. They are denouncing Taiwan’s exclusion from the World Health Organization. They are flaunting celebrity endorsements and creating hashtags like #TaiwanCanHelp.

headline: Will ‘Real’ Small Businesses Get the Money This Time?
abstract: Congress is shoring up its small-business rescue fund. Expect a closer eye on who takes loans, after outrage that big companies tapped the first round.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: On Politics: Trump Gives Green Cards a Red Light
abstract: Can he even do that? His administration isn’t sure. This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin during the coronavirus briefing at the White House on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Circus of Books’ Review: A Community Takes Pride in Its Porn Store
