abstract: Getting shots is part of the military. But an influenza vaccination Pfc. Monroe Scherer received in late 1945 made him sick for a week.
lead_paragraph: This account is from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series from The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war. After graduating from Stuyvesant High School in New York, Monroe Scherer, 18, was drafted into the Army. After the Japanese surrendered, his unit was sent to Korea, where the men were made to participate in an early influenza vaccination that caused unintended side effects.

headline: The New Face of Car Seat Headrest
abstract: Will Toledo is leaning into his ambitions and leading his band into new territory on “Making a Door Less Open,” an album that comes with a new look — and a mask.
lead_paragraph: Will Toledo, the founder and principal songwriter of Car Seat Headrest, sat in his Seattle apartment, looking into his iPhone camera through the eyes of a modified gas mask.

headline: Use the Coronavirus Shutdown to Train Workers
abstract: We can use this stoppage in the economy to upgrade our nation’s productivity.
lead_paragraph: In manufacturing, plant shutdowns occur frequently. Sometimes they are scheduled for planned maintenance. In other instances, equipment fails. The best manufacturers use shutdowns not only to fix what’s broken but also to upgrade their entire system. This is how we need to approach our economy right now.

headline: If We’re Giving Trump a Show, We Should Give Biden One, Too
abstract: The president is hitting the virtual campaign trail every night.
lead_paragraph: Let’s drop all pretenses, shall we? The president has decided he’s had enough of running the country and is running full time for re-election instead.

headline: How Joe Biden Should Pick His Running Mate
abstract: Focus first on the office. Then think about the campaign.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden intends to name a woman as his running mate. Selecting that woman, however, is a much harder decision, almost certainly the most consequential he will make this year, revealing much about his values and his judgment.

headline: Sports Without Games? The N.F.L. Is Made for That
abstract: America’s most popular sport is chugging along through an off-season of events. On the eve of the N.F.L. Draft, a reporter discusses how the league has managed to do so.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: ‘We Will Make the Best Out of It’: Ramadan Amid a Pandemic
abstract: Some Muslim doctors are saving lives while fasting. For the rest of us, this holy month won’t be heroic but it will be enough.
lead_paragraph: The Prophet Muhammad once told his followers never to enter or leave a town that has the plague, to avoid spreading the disease.

headline: As Coronavirus Threatens, Teenage Migrants ‘Age Out’ Into ICE Jails
abstract: Those initially detained by the government’s Office of Refugee Resettlement are being held until their 18th birthday, then transferred to ICE custody.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Isaac, a 17-year-old Guatemalan, crossed the U.S. border nearly eight months ago and was detained as a minor by the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement, long before the novel coronavirus existed.

headline: Risky Strategy Has Produced Wins for Democrats in Fights Over Pandemic Aid
abstract: Now another struggle looms as Senator Mitch McConnell threatens a go-slow approach on the next round of economic stimulus, including aid to states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In January 2018, Senate Democrats took a politically risky stand, shutting down the government to insist on protections for hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants. Gleeful Republicans saw the obstruction strategy as a huge blunder and pounded the Democrats, who caved after only a few days of sharp attacks and cut a deal to reopen.

headline: New Yorkers Want Cheap Wine, and Lots of It
abstract: Pandemic drinking has changed what liquor stores are selling and how they are conducting business.
lead_paragraph: Since New Yorkers were told to stay inside, Amanda Shy and her husband, Matthew McCurdy, both actors, have altered the way they make purchases from their local liquor store, Whiskey and Wine. First, they no longer go twice a week; they shop there every day. Second, they no longer visit the store in person.

headline: New York and Boston Pigeons Don’t Mix
abstract: The East Coast is made up of two pigeon genetic megacities, and a patch of Connecticut seems to be what’s keeping them apart.
lead_paragraph: Almost one in five Americans lives in the megacity that is the Northeast, a sprawling cluster of paved surfaces, bitter sports rivalries and clashing opinions about which city’s drivers are rudest.

headline: Few Travelers, Few Flights and Now, a Total Airport Shutdown
abstract: Westchester County Airport, north of New York City, is closing temporarily, using the time to complete long-planned construction.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus pandemic brought air travel to a near standstill, airlines operated 40 daily flights from Westchester County Airport.

headline: What the Great Pandemic Novels Teach Us
abstract: People have always responded to epidemics by spreading rumor and false information, and portraying the disease as foreign and brought in with malicious intent.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For the past four years I have been writing a historical novel set in 1901 during what is known as the third plague pandemic, an outbreak of bubonic plague that killed millions of people in Asia but not very many in Europe. Over the last two months, friends and family, editors and journalists who know the subject of that novel, “Nights of Plague,” have been asking me a barrage of questions about pandemics.

headline: A Precedent Overturned Reveals a Supreme Court in Crisis
abstract: Separate opinions in a case show nine justices pursuing agendas far removed from the dispute at hand.
lead_paragraph: The country wasn’t exactly holding its breath for the Supreme Court’s decision this week that the Constitution requires juror unanimity for a felony conviction in state court. The case promised little change. Unanimity has long been understood as constitutionally required in federal court as a matter of the Sixth Amendment right to trial by jury.

headline: Hidden Outbreaks Spread Through U.S. Cities Far Earlier Than Americans Knew, Estimates Say
abstract: New York, Boston, San Francisco, Chicago and Seattle had undetected outbreaks long before testing showed a major problem, according to a model.
lead_paragraph: By the time New York City confirmed its first case of the coronavirus on March 1, thousands of infections were already silently spreading through the city, a hidden explosion of a disease that many still viewed as a remote threat as the city awaited the first signs of spring.

headline: ‘Staying Nimble’: How Small Businesses Can, and Do, Shift Gears
abstract: With the coronavirus restrictions, entrepreneurs are learning in real time just how they need to adapt to survive.
lead_paragraph: The first week after Cristina McCarter closed her Memphis food tour company, a casualty of the pandemic, she had only tears.

headline: Vaccine Rates Drop Dangerously as Parents Avoid Doctor’s Visits
abstract: Afraid of Covid-19, parents are postponing well-child checkups, including shots, putting millions of children at risk of exposure to preventable deadly diseases.
lead_paragraph: As parents around the country cancel well-child checkups to avoid coronavirus exposure, public health experts fear they are inadvertently sowing the seeds of another health crisis. Immunizations are dropping at a dangerous rate, putting millions of children at risk for measles, whooping cough and other life-threatening illnesses.

headline: 11 Books to Watch For in May
abstract: A prequel to “The Hunger Games,” a love letter to French cooking, a novel by Curtis Sittenfeld that reimagines Hillary Clinton’s life and much more.
lead_paragraph: Was the Arab Spring a failure? There is a sense that the protests across the Middle East in 2011 failed to bring about any enduring, positive change, except in Tunisia. But Feldman, a Harvard professor, argues that the uprisings marked a significant cultural and political shift empowering people in the region — even if they brought about tragic outcomes in some countries, including the Syrian war and the rise of ISIS.

headline: Death Toll Climbs in California; House Passes Aid Package
abstract: President Trump said he would sign the $484 billion package, which replenishes a depleted small-business loan program. Another 4.4 million people filed for unemployment.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Virus Relief Plan Has a Workers’ ‘Bill of Rights’
abstract: The City Council introduced a virus relief package that included measures to protect tenants, small businesses, essential workers and homeless people.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Coronavirus, Tornadoes, N.F.L. Draft: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Can I Have Friends Over for Dinner?
abstract: Tensions can flare as apartment residents and building managers navigate the rules of social distancing.
lead_paragraph: In New York City apartments, behaviors that were once perfectly normal — a Friday night dinner party, taking the dog for a walk, or inviting a sibling to visit for a while — are suddenly deviant, and potentially dangerous, leaving property owners and building managers struggling to figure out when and how to keep tenants in line as they attempt to reduce the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Getting Off Rikers Island
abstract: We spoke to a Rikers Island resident who has the coronavirus. “They are killing us,” he said. “What are we supposed to do?”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: 7 Things You Need for Better Video Calls
abstract: Remote video meetings are now inescapable, but they can be awkward and glitchy. Investing in a few tools can make the experience much better.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been sharing my home office with my daughter for the past couple of weeks, and I cringed at her first few eighth-grade remote-learning sessions done over video: the teacher repeatedly asking: “Can you see me now,” the students inaudible or unable to turn on their cameras, the complaints about connection problems, and me trying to hide in the background. It’s almost comical, but these days it’s a common experience.

headline: A Trip to the Garage, for an Electric Switch
abstract: A growing array of specialty shops are turning classics into silent brutes with tire-burning torque and vintage style.
lead_paragraph: When Prince Harry married Meghan Markle, it wasn’t the romance or the pageantry that set automotive hearts aflutter. It was the couple’s Jaguar E-Type Zero, a classic E-type body fitted with a modern electric drive, that caused a swoon.

headline: Victoria’s Secret and Sycamore Partners Play ‘Let’s Break a Deal’
abstract: The investment firm that agreed to buy Victoria’s Secret is now trying to back out. It could embolden others to scrap deals agreed before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: On Politics: ‘Politics and Cronyism Ahead of Science’
abstract: A top federal doctor rebukes Trump: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and Dr. Deborah Birx, the White House coronavirus response coordinator, during Wednesday’s daily briefing.

headline: ‘1BR’ Review: Losing Much More Than the Security Deposit
abstract: A young woman’s starter apartment turns into a roach motel in this psychologically nuanced thriller.
lead_paragraph: A group of crazies tries its hand at social engineering in “1BR,” a claustrophobic thriller set in a Los Angeles apartment complex whose evils the sun never comes close to disinfecting.

headline: ‘True History of the Kelly Gang’ Review: a 19th-Century Outlaw Tale
abstract: A new cinematic story about the legendary Australian outlaw Ned Kelly, directed by Justin Kurzel, has a lot of visual pizazz and a lot of tiresome clichés.
lead_paragraph: Ned Kelly is a legendary figure in Australian history, a 19th-century outlaw of Irish descent who came to symbolize the struggle of oppressed people on that continent. (Oppressed white people, that is.) “True History of the Kelly Gang” takes the form of Kelly’s story as told by Ned himself. While not well versed in letters, he writes a lengthy missive to his child as his hour comes nigh, recounting his ultra-hardscrabble childhood.

headline: Ricky Gervais on ‘After Life’ and Life After the Golden Globes
abstract: The co-creator of “The Office” says that viewers can handle his dark Netflix comedy series: “We worry about what the people at home can take. Real life’s worse.”
lead_paragraph: Ricky Gervais generally has reliable comic timing. He helped usher in a renaissance of documentary-style cringe comedy as a creator and star of the original British version of “The Office.” And he has successfully positioned himself against the well-heeled Hollywood crowd that occasionally invites Gervais to mock them to their faces as host of the Golden Globes. (In his routine in January, Gervais roasted his celebrity peers for their displays of social consciousness while they worked for corporations like Amazon, Apple — “a company that runs sweatshops in China” — and Disney. “If ISIS started a streaming service you’d call your agent, wouldn’t you?” he taunted.)

headline: How N.F.L. Draft Day Began the End of My 22-Year Football Career
abstract: Toby Gerhart, a former N.F.L. running back, reflects on how he went from one in a million to one of a million.
lead_paragraph: I stared at the TV screen in disbelief. My replacement had just been chosen. I could hear it in the echo of these words: “With the 36th pick of the 2015 N.F.L. draft, the Jacksonville Jaguars select T.J. Yeldon, running back from Alabama.”

headline: China Imposes New Limits as Coronavirus Fears Return
abstract: Some northern cities have reported fresh cases and put restrictions on movement, a sign of how hard it will be for China to fully recover from the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Chinese officials have imposed new limits on movement in some northern parts of the country following a spate of new coronavirus infections, in a sign of how difficult it will be to fully recover from an outbreak that virtually paralyzed the country.

headline: Cuomo Says 21% of Those Tested in N.Y.C. Had Virus Antibodies
abstract: The preliminary data suggests that many more New Yorkers may have been infected than was previously believed.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Friday’s live coverage.

headline: How Do You Greet Your Friends and Family?
abstract: Do you hug friends or use handshakes? How have your greetings changed in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic?
lead_paragraph: How important is physical contact to the way you greet your friends? Do you dread having to shake hands or hug someone, or do you embrace it? How have your greetings changed as the coronavirus pandemic has continued?

headline: Goggles, Masks, Ponchos: Air Travel in the Thick of a Pandemic
abstract: Some people who have had to board commercial flights in recent weeks have taken elaborate precautions to protect themselves from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The thought of getting on a plane is far from most people’s minds at the moment, as they shelter in their homes. But some people have no choice but to fly now, whether it is returning from a long trip or rushing to leave a country as a visa expires.

headline: Inside the Bay Area’s Geriatric Homeless Shelter
abstract: Thursday: Homeless shelters, like elder care homes, have seen outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Jobless Numbers Are ‘Eye-Watering’ but Understate the Crisis
abstract: With 4.4 million added last week, the five-week total passed 26 million. The struggle by states to field claims has hampered economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a month after Washington rushed through an emergency package to aid jobless Americans, millions of laid-off workers have still not been able to apply for those benefits — let alone receive them — because of overwhelmed state unemployment systems.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘50 Years of Earth Day: What’s Better Today, and What’s Worse’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the impact and legacy of Earth Day, and consider the changes they would like to see in the next half-century.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “50 Years of Earth Day: What’s Better Today, and What’s Worse”

headline: ‘Robert the Bruce’ Review: The Return of the King
abstract: Angus Macfadyen, who first played the medieval Scottish king in “Braveheart,” reprises his role in this introspective historical drama.
lead_paragraph: I could have forgiven the non-Scottish actors in “Robert the Bruce” for torturing my native tongue had the filmmakers not also wrapped this sort-of appendage to Mel Gibson’s “Braveheart” in a caul of Celtic fairy dust. The result is a picture that feels more Walt Disney than George R.R. Martin, a strangely subdued and sluggish game of thrones more focused on convalescence than conflict.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Aluminum-free ways to handle sweat — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenpoint, Battery Park City and Jackson Heights.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Greenpoint, Battery Park City and Jackson Heights.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenpoint, Battery Park City and Jackson Heights.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Locust Valley, N.Y., and Ridgefield, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Locust Valley, N.Y., and Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Locust Valley, N.Y., and Ridgefield, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Hollywood Beacons in the Night
abstract: The great movie palaces of Los Angeles have withstood much upheaval over the decades. Now closed because of the coronavirus, they await their fate in silence.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They survived the Great Depression, when tickets cost a dime. Neither earthquake nor greedy developer has been able to topple them. Over the decades, they have endured the rise of the VCR and the indignity of showing “Cats.”

headline: Criticism Is My Love Language
abstract: Nine years into my marriage, it’s taken a global crisis to make me a nicer person.
lead_paragraph: I have filled a spray bottle with vinegar, like the instructions said, and coated the shower with it, but nothing is happening.

headline: What to Say (and Not Say) to Workers on the Front Lines
abstract: Send messages of support, without the expectation of a reply.
lead_paragraph: “How are you doing?” a text message alert on my phone reads. “Thinking of you.”

headline: 3,000 Interviews. 50 Years. Listen to the History of American Music.
abstract: Vivian Perlis founded Yale’s Oral History of American Music in 1968. Today, the project continues her mission to record the voices of American composers.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, Vivian Perlis, a research librarian at Yale, knew that she needed to talk to Julian Myrick. A man who had spent his life in the insurance business was not the most likely of musicological sources. But Myrick’s business partner had not only been significant in the field of life insurance, but was also one of the most important figures in American music history: the composer Charles Ives, who had died 14 years earlier.

headline: Hospitals Play ‘Songs of Hope’ as Virus Patients Go Home
abstract: Anthems like “Don’t Stop Believin’,” the “Rocky” theme and “Every Breath You Take” have been adopted by hospitals to celebrate each victory in the battle against coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: In the 11 days he spent fighting Covid-19 at Montefiore Nyack Hospital, there was one thing Mark Schwarz couldn’t figure out.

headline: E.U. Moves to Shore Up Economies Reeling From Virus
abstract: As the leaders of the European Union’s 27 countries approved a half-trillion euro bailout package Thursday night, their attention immediately turned to what to do next, where much disagreement remains.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When European finance ministers agreed on a half-trillion euros’ worth of joint measures to shore up their economies in the face of the coronavirus, it felt like an accomplishment. But two weeks later, when European Union leaders met to approve that package, the deal already looked like too little, too late.

headline: Monitoring the Coronavirus Outbreak in Metro Areas Across the U.S.
abstract: In many places across the U.S., cases and deaths appear to have peaked or are starting to flatten. But there is a lot of regional variation.
lead_paragraph: In many places across the U.S., cases and deaths appear to have peaked or are starting to flatten. But there is a lot of regional variation.

headline: Here’s How Coronavirus Could Raise Cities’ Risk for Climate Disasters
abstract: Faced with falling revenue and virus-related burdens, local officials are delaying sea walls and other projects to protect cities from climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The economic toll of the coronavirus is forcing cities and states to redirect money away from projects that provide climate resilience, in a shift that threatens to tackle one crisis at the expense of another.

headline: Overheard on Zoom: Co-Workers Talking About My ‘Weird’ Habits
abstract: I’m embarrassed, but also: What can I do differently?
lead_paragraph: I had two Zoom meetings at the same time at the university where I work. I told my boss I wasn’t sure how long the first one would last, but I doubted I would make his meeting. As it happened, the first one was short, so I popped into my boss’s meeting. When I got there, my co-workers were screaming with laughter, and I heard my boss say: “The other weird thing Lauren does is….” But then he realized I was there and stopped. My co-workers looked uncomfortable, and my boss pivoted quickly by asking about my first meeting. I was mortified! It was all I could do not to cry. How can I find out what weird things I do, so I can stop? I don’t want to be the office weirdo.

headline: Brazil Covid Map and Case Count
abstract: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
lead_paragraph: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.

headline: ‘To the Stars’ Review: Rebels in Bobby Socks, Yearning for More
abstract: In a claustrophobic small town in the early 1960s, two teenage girls find friendship and maybe even a way out.
lead_paragraph: It’s the early 1960s in rural Oklahoma, where the wind really does sweep down the plain, just like the song says. There, the teenage Iris (Kara Hayward), a bookish introvert, is trying to keep her head down. The only child of a rancher and a bored, restless housewife (Shea Whigham and Jordana Spiro), Iris is a loner, though it’s unclear if that’s by choice or inclination. Some nights, she runs off to a swimming hole, where she floats under a canopy of stars. She’s primed for some kind of change, which arrives with Maggie (Liana Liberato), a spirited newcomer with a murky past.

headline: Fossil Shows Cold-Blooded Frogs Lived on Warm Antarctica
abstract: The specimen is some 40 million years old, and is probably related to species currently living in South America.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, Thomas Mörs reached for a frog in the sand — but the frog didn’t hop away. That’s because the frog had been fossilized 40 million years ago. Nevertheless, Dr. Mörs knew that the frog would soon be hopping into history books, because it was the first fossil frog from Antarctica ever found.

headline: As Coronavirus Eases, More Italians Say, ‘I Want Justice’
abstract: “The pandemic is going to turn into a big collective trial,” one journalist predicted as the hardest-hit country in Europe assesses the fallout.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — As the infection curve in Italy flattens and the government moves gingerly toward reopening the country, more Italians, fueled by growing anger over thousands of deaths and what they see as health officials’ failures in handing the crisis, are seeking to hold someone accountable.

headline: Be a Friend to the Elderly, Get Paid
abstract: Combating loneliness is vital work. Services that offer “grandkids on demand” are doing just that.
lead_paragraph: Bill Rodger, 91, often finds himself sitting on a worn flower-print couch in his living room in North Hollywood, Calif., facing a wall of accolades that document his long life.

headline: ‘Florida Is a Terrible State to Be an Unemployed Person’
abstract: Florida has emerged as one of the slowest states in the nation to process an avalanche of unemployment claims since the coronavirus hit.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — After Ernst Virgile lost his job at the Fort Lauderdale airport, he sat up late at the computer in his living room night after night, trying to apply for unemployment, refreshing his browser again and again while his wife was sleeping.

headline: Spain Plans to Play Soccer Again … Very Carefully
abstract: Spain’s top leagues will create a hygienic cocoon for teams readying for a return to action.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Daily tests for coronavirus. Only two people in the gym at a time. Players dressing for practice at home.

headline: Donald Reed Herring, Brother of Elizabeth Warren, Dies of Coronavirus
abstract: Mr. Herring, 86, was a career officer in the Air Force, reaching the rank of lieutenant colonel, and flew combat missions in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Influencing? In This Economy? It’s Only Gotten More Competitive
abstract: Josh Zimmerman is a life coach for creators, whose careers have become ever more consuming, uncertain and subject to scrutiny under coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Alyson Stoner, 26, is an actress whose credits include various Disney and Nickelodeon productions. She has also independently developed an online audience of over one million who turn to her for advice about wellness and creativity.

headline: 5 Games to Play on Video Chat During Quarantine
abstract: Yes, you’re stuck at home. But you can also (somewhat) keep up your social life.
lead_paragraph: Social connection right now can come with a bit of a learning curve.

headline: How to Trim Your Bangs at Home
abstract: This is a tutorial for people who have straight or wavy bangs. If you don’t already have bangs, stop reading now.
lead_paragraph: We can help you trim existing straight or wavy bangs. Come watch Lily Benson, our off-platform visual editor, as she takes these tips for a test drive.

headline: ‘Bad Education’ Review: Adding Fraud to the Curriculum
abstract: Hugh Jackman is darkly charismatic as the real-life schools superintendent who admitted to stealing $2 million from his Long Island district.
lead_paragraph: “Thoroughbreds,” the 2018 debut feature of the playwright Cory Finley, was not to every taste, but for acid wit and gliding camera moves, it could hardly be beat. Finley’s second feature, “Bad Education,” which airs Saturday night on HBO, traffics in a kindred casual misanthropy. The movie offers an agreeably slick account of an early-2000s scandal in which a former superintendent of schools in Roslyn, N.Y., pleaded guilty to stealing $2 million from his district.

headline: The Pandemic Has Turned Los Angeles Into a Walking City
abstract: A visual diary by the artist Geoff McFetridge.
lead_paragraph: A visual diary by the artist Geoff McFetridge.

headline: The Secretive Group Guiding the U.K. on Coronavirus
abstract: The British government frequently says it’s “guided by the science,” but the members of its scientific advisory group, SAGE, are a secret.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the British government comes under mounting criticism for its response to the coronavirus — one that has left Britain vying with Italy and Spain as the worst hit countries in Europe — Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his aides have defended themselves by saying they are “guided by the science.”

headline: Craft Distillers Were Booming. Now They Face Bust.
abstract: In recent years, sales for small liquor makers have been surging, but coronavirus has shuttered tasting rooms and disrupted distribution.
lead_paragraph: For Todd Thrasher, it seemed like a sure bet. In October 2018, he opened a sprawling bar and rum distillery along the newly revitalized District Wharf in Washington, D.C., with three floors, space for 300 diners and 56 employees. He figured that with the area’s heavy foot traffic and a booming local economy, his wager would pay off quickly.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Global Temperature Change
abstract: How do global temperatures compare to mid-20th century average temperature?
lead_paragraph: This graph above and map below, both showing the global temperatures since 1880 as compared to the average global temperature for the mid-20th century years of 1951 – 1980, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. All temperatures are in degrees Celsius.

headline: In Wisconsin, Virus Creates New Front in Long-Simmering Partisan Wars
abstract: Protests planned for Friday continue a decade-long partisan cleaving in the state and serve as a stand-in for the general election battle to come.
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin had barely finished its fight over whether to hold an election in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic before America’s foremost battleground state began another political brawl over the pandemic itself.

headline: What to Do When Your Uncle Believes Coronavirus Conspiracies
abstract: Believing in online hoaxes can be dangerous now. Here’s how we can all help.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Now Virtual and in Video, Museum Websites Shake Off the Dust
abstract: Homebound and feeling the wanderlust? Our critic’s guide to the best online presentations from the world’s leading art palaces and picture galleries.
lead_paragraph: In times of adversity, we look to art to give form to chaos. But where do you go when the chaos keeps you from art entirely? It will have to be online. As the coronavirus pandemic stretches into yet another month, keeping arts institutions closed across the globe, museums’ websites are now posting traffic numbers that were once unimaginable.

headline: Music, Theater and More to Experience at Home This Weekend
abstract: Our writers offer suggestions for what to watch or listen to while we’re housebound. (And some things for children to create.)
lead_paragraph: When the saxophonist and composer Steve Lehman realized he wouldn’t be able to travel from Los Angeles to Brooklyn for his mother’s 80th birthday this month, he decided to send her a sonic greeting instead. Recording in his car during breaks from home schooling his children, Lehman produced an EP of solos, “Xenakis and the Valedictorian.”

headline: The Oil Industry’s Glut Has a Bright Spot: Tanker Storage
abstract: Shipping companies, which can command more than $200,000 a day for a vessel, are cashing in on increased demand.
lead_paragraph: The price of oil has plunged, but the price of finding a place to put it has soared. And if you are in the business of providing a temporary home for the world’s glut of crude, you’ve hit the jackpot.

headline: Chardonnay the Oregon Way
abstract: In the short wine history of the Willamette Valley, the grape has played third fiddle to pinot noir and pinot gris. Now, it is coming into its own.
lead_paragraph: Long ago in ancient times, before the pandemic, I decided that the next topic for Wine School would be chardonnays from the Willamette Valley of Oregon.

headline: Amid the Coronavirus Pandemic, Looking to the Future
abstract: Readers discuss an article that asked experts to speculate about the next year or two.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Pairing Wine and Food, Experience Is the Best Teacher
abstract: Books, websites and apps promise to take the guesswork out of choosing a bottle, but nothing is better than experimenting for yourself.
lead_paragraph: Pairing wine with food has come to symbolize much of the intimidation, apprehension and pretension that, for many people, intrude on the elemental enjoyment of a good bottle.

headline: Los Angeles Dealers Create Their Own Virtual Gallery
abstract: The pandemic led art dealers to band together as Gallery Association Los Angeles, to help each other out in the short and long term.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Art fairs have over the last three decades become the great organizers or aggregators of the art market, bringing mom-and-pop galleries and their bigger counterparts together under one roof — or these days, given the coronavirus outbreak, one website with multiple viewing “booths.”

headline: Review: ‘Defending Jacob’ Asks, Could Our Son Be a Killer?
abstract: An Apple TV Plus mini-series with a stellar cast also raises another question: Does everything need to be this long?
lead_paragraph: “Defending Jacob” is an eight-episode murder mystery from Apple TV Plus with a full catalog of twists and an impressive cast that includes Chris Evans, Michelle Dockery, Cherry Jones and J.K. Simmons. It’s also Exhibit A for a question that’s becoming increasingly unavoidable: Why does everything have to be a television series?

headline: 10 Playwrights Script a Web Series. Is It Theater?
abstract: “Homebound” is one company’s attempt to give structure and meaning to the worries and what-ifs of the strange new present. But these aren’t plays, the artistic director says.
lead_paragraph: If the Washington Post political humor columnist Alexandra Petri could give her pre-pandemic self a piece of advice, she might suggest skipping the play she went to write about in late February at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Maryland.

headline: Donald Kennedy, Who Led Stanford in 1980s, Dies at 88
abstract: As president, he expanded the university and battled a government inquiry into its research expenses. He also headed the F.D.A. under President Carter.
lead_paragraph: Donald Kennedy, a neurobiologist who headed the Food and Drug Administration before becoming president of Stanford University, where he oversaw major expansions of its campus and curriculum and weathered a crisis over research spending, died on April 21 in Redwood City, Calif. He was 88.

headline: 1 in 5 New Yorkers May Have Had Covid-19, Antibody Tests Suggest
abstract: Accurate antibody testing is a critical tool to determine if the pandemic has slowed enough to begin restarting the economy.
lead_paragraph: One of every five New York City residents tested positive for antibodies to the coronavirus, according to preliminary results described by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday that suggested that the virus had spread far more widely than known.

headline: World Chess Moves Online. But Check, Don’t Cheat, Mate.
abstract: Grandmasters compete from the safety of their own homes. But it’s now much easier for players to cheat. Plus, the slow return of sports in some parts of the world, and auto racing in South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: After the world chess championship qualifying match was halted because of the pandemic, the world champion, Magnus Carlsen, gathered top players for a virtual event beginning last Saturday.

headline: Hubris, a Case Study
abstract: Tune in tonight.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: A Cast Album I Love: ‘Hair’
abstract: We continue our cast album series with more recommendations for wonderful musicals to listen to at home.
lead_paragraph: Recently, The Times’s co-chief theater critics put together a musical cast recording starter kit for those of us stuck at home — 10 cast albums they’d take with them to a desert island. We asked some of their fellow critics to pick one cast album each and extol its pleasures. On Wednesday, Laura Collins-Hughes wrote about the Shakespeare in the Park production of “Twelfth Night.”

headline: Why These Protesters Aren’t Staying Home for Coronavirus Orders
abstract: A vocal minority is pressing for an end to restrictions despite the continued spread of the virus. “Not everybody can put on their fashionable loungewear and get on Zoom,” a protester said.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A plumber in Washington State who believes government overreach might lead to violent conflicts. A teacher in Texas who is fed up with the closures of small businesses and popular hiking trails. A farmer in Wisconsin seeing demand for the food that he produces hollowed out along with the restaurant industry.

headline: 26,453,000 Jobs: See the Scope of the Unemployment Crisis
abstract: The number of U.S. jobs lost already during the coronavirus outbreak is roughly equal to the working populations of 25 states.
lead_paragraph: The number of U.S. jobs lost already during the coronavirus outbreak is roughly equal to the working populations of 25 states.

headline: The Firing of the Vaccine Official
abstract: A doctor calls the reassigning of Rick Bright “among the worst decisions ever.” Also: Trump the landlord, Trump the tenant; a resurgence of family life.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Learning Bulletin Board
abstract: Virtual study abroad, video skills and more: a collection of views and news from our special report.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Nearly All Patients Hospitalized With Covid-19 Had Chronic Health Issues, Study Finds
abstract: Only 6 percent of patients at one New York area health system had no chronic conditions. Hypertension, obesity and diabetes were common.
lead_paragraph: A new study of thousands of hospitalized coronavirus patients in the New York City area, the epicenter of the outbreak in the United States, has found that nearly all of them had at least one major chronic health condition, and most — 88 percent — had at least two.

headline: Clean Water Act Covers Groundwater Discharges, Supreme Court Rules
abstract: In a 6-to-3 ruling, the court rejected arguments by a county in Hawaii and the Trump administration that only pollution discharged directly into navigable waters requires permits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the Clean Water Act applies to some pollutants that reach the sea and other protected waters indirectly through groundwater.

headline: Teachers and Students Describe a Remote-Learning Life
abstract: They talk about how the change to online instruction has affected them.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Google Will Require Proof of Identity From All Advertisers
abstract: A slew of scams and misleading ads pushed the search giant to expand its verification policy.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to fight off fraudulent or misleading online ads, Google will require that all advertisers across its sprawling network prove who they are and where they operate, the company said in a blog post on Thursday.

headline: How Would You Like to Live in the Nation of New England?
abstract: Regional partnerships may offer a new framework for dealing with urgent issues on which Washington has failed to lead.
lead_paragraph: Three groups of governors in the East, West and Midwest announced that they would work together on plans to lift the lockdowns in their states once the peak of the coronavirus outbreak has passed. At a time of federal abdication, these state leaders are thinking seriously about alternatives to the existing model of American federalism.

headline: Coronavirus in China, Pakistan, Afghanistan: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: As China reopens factories and eases travel restrictions in efforts to recover after the outbreak that shook Wuhan and spread across the country, some northern cities are reporting new cases of coronavirus.

headline: Welcome to the Skype Pandemic
abstract: The rough-and-ready video quality of journalism during the coronavirus crisis is changing the way we engage with the media.
lead_paragraph: National crises are often identified by the media innovations they engender. The Persian Gulf war of 1991 was the turning point for CNN, the 10-year-old cable-news network that broadcast live the first United States bombs falling in Baghdad. The 2016 presidential contest will forever be remembered as the election when Twitter and other social media platforms became an irresistible force in national politics.

headline: Honest Apologies for Why I Couldn’t Talk During Quarantine
abstract: Time really flies when you’re disassociating.
lead_paragraph: Hey, I’m so sorry I didn’t text you back this afternoon. I was finishing a 1,500-piece puzzle of a basset hound wearing a cowboy hat for the second time.

headline: No Two Rooms Are Alike in Ukrainian Prisons
abstract: Personalized spaces of the incarcerated.
lead_paragraph: I first visited Ukrainian prisons in 2009, while working on a project for Doctors Without Borders. I remember seeing the conjugal rooms and being struck by how no two rooms were alike.

headline: R0, the Messy Metric That May Soon Shape Our Lives, Explained
abstract: ‘R-naught’ represents the number of new infections estimated to stem from a single case. You may be hearing a lot about this.
lead_paragraph: World leaders and public health experts are poised to spend the coming months or years obsessed with a variable known as R0.

headline: Drivers With a Mission: To Feed the City’s Hungry
abstract: New York City’s pantries for low-income residents and meal-delivery services for shut-ins are dependent, now more than ever, on drivers who keep the food moving.
lead_paragraph: “A lot of my clients don’t get to interact with people unless it’s me,” said Mr. Gumbs, 48, who drove a school bus for 10 years before becoming a driver for God’s Love We Deliver (how to donate), which caters mostly to older New Yorkers. “Sometimes, they have no one to talk to.”

headline: How to Make America 2.0 a More Equitable Society
abstract: The tech industry can play a pivotal role in shaping our post-pandemic world.
lead_paragraph: So, what exactly is “America 2.0”? And, more important, who gets to decide?

headline: How a Rhode Island College Was Forced to Adapt
abstract: Well-run colleges are known for thoughtful planning and execution. The pandemic made the Community College of Rhode Island work in a new way, instantaneously.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: When Mental Distress Comes Home
abstract: The pandemic has closed many mental-health residential centers, sending residents home to families ill equipped for the challenges.
lead_paragraph: The panic spirals up from somewhere in Connor Langan’s midsection, and so quickly that his face changes; wild in the eyes, his upper lip trembling, he sometimes punches a wall in frustration. Such episodes resulted in Connor, 17, being placed on leave from high school late last year, and in early March he agreed to enroll at Mountain Valley, a New Hampshire residential program well known for addressing anxiety problems in young people.

headline: Ecuador’s Death Toll During Outbreak Is Among the Worst in the World
abstract: A New York Times analysis suggests that Ecuador’s death toll is 15 times higher than its official tally of coronavirus deaths, highlighting the damage the virus can do in developing countries.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — With bodies abandoned on sidewalks, slumped in wheelchairs, packed into cardboard coffins and stacked by the hundreds in morgues, it is clear that Ecuador has been devastated by the coronavirus.

headline: Spelman College Faces a Redefined Reality
abstract: The school, which was designed for the success of black women and cherishes close relationships among its Spelman Sisters, is dealing with distance and separation.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Class Is in Session Everywhere Now
abstract: Around the country, museums, libraries, zoos and even federal agencies are offering lessons, activities and fun for learners of all ages.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Rule No. 1 for Parents Doing ‘Crisis Schooling’: Take a Deep Breath
abstract: It’s not like you have to worry about teaching calculus or advanced biology. Not yet, at least.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: How to Stay Creative While Stuck at Home
abstract: The pandemic has disrupted the creative lives of everyday Americans who used to spend untold hours together singing, dancing and making art. But creativity finds a way.
lead_paragraph: In a few short months, the Covid-19 pandemic has shut down movie sets, stopped global concert tours and pushed famous names to the sidelines. And it has also disrupted the creative lives of millions of others whose names might never have appeared on a marquee.

headline: Marine Corps Bans Public Display of Confederate Flag
abstract: In a letter, Gen. David H. Berger, the Marine commandant, said the symbol had “the power to inflame division.”
lead_paragraph: The commandant of the Marine Corps has banned the public display of the Confederate battle flag, a symbol that he said had the “power to inflame” division.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A writer I follow on Twitter recently put out a call for novels that distill a “sense of pure consciousness” onto the page, with little regard for scene or setting or traditional character. It’s a fun challenge, and the example he provided — “Wittgenstein’s Mistress,” by David Markson — is a great book, perfectly chosen. But my immediate reaction, on seeing the tweet, was: “You don’t want a novel, you want poetry.”

headline: Teachers of Special-Needs Students Struggle With Feelings of Helplessness
abstract: Remote learning has proved challenging for students who need intensive one-on-one guidance.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Two: Looking Down
abstract: “The truth is down there, and you’ve got to go down and dig for it.”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Spotify

headline: Richard Sobol, Civil Rights Lawyer in the South, Dies at 82
abstract: Unlike other Northern lawyers who joined the struggle in the South, he stayed, and won a landmark case.
lead_paragraph: In 1966, on a swampy strip of land south of New Orleans, a young black man named Gary Duncan was defusing a potential fight between white and black teenagers outside a newly integrated school when he touched an arm of one of the white boys, who recoiled. The police later arrested Mr. Duncan on a charge of battery. His request for a jury trial was denied, and he was sentenced to 60 days in prison and fined $150.

headline: Will the Coronavirus Forever Alter the College Experience?
abstract: The answer so far appears to be no. But some online education tools are likely to stick around.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Family Conflict in Quarantine, Starting Over and Health Care Heroics
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we’re highlighting teenagers’ thoughts on isolating with their families, beginning again after a setback, and the role of health care workers during the pandemic.

headline: U.S. Aid for Greenland Prompts Praise and Suspicion in Denmark
abstract: The offer of $12.1 million in support revived memories of President Trump’s suggestion last year that the United States could simply buy the semiautonomous island.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Denmark said no, emphatically, when President Trump expressed interest last year in purchasing Greenland. But that doesn’t mean the Danish government would rebuff a little American help for its semi-autonomous territory.

headline: Cheap Oil Poses New Quandary for Iran as It Relaxes Virus Lockdown
abstract: The country has been hit with a triple-whammy: raging coronavirus, American sanctions and, now, oil so cheap that it’s barely profitable.
lead_paragraph: Selling Iran’s oil in defiance of an American embargo was already a risky and complicated venture for Iranian brokers. Then came the precipitous plunge in prices because of the global coronavirus clampdown, which has shriveled demand.

headline: John Pfahl, Photographer Who Played With Landscapes, Dies at 81
abstract: Long before Photoshop, he manipulated landscapes with everyday objects, and found beauty in compost piles and other peculiar places.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: How School Districts Are Outsmarting a Microbe
abstract: Schools thrust into turmoil by the coronavirus are slowly finding ways to cope.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Learning special report, which focuses on the challenges of online education during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Abba Kyari, Nigerian President’s Right-Hand Man, Dies
abstract: As chief of staff to President Muhammadu Buhari, Mr. Kyari was a “gatekeeper” and “loyal friend.”
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Antibodies, Stimulus, Angela Merkel: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: C.D.C. Stresses Need for Coronavirus Testing at Homeless Shelters
abstract: A study of four cities suggested that those living in close quarters in shelters can spread the virus at high rates even when asymptomatic.
lead_paragraph: According to a new study of homeless shelters in four major American cities, it is crucial to broadly test residents and staff for the coronavirus at the detection of the first case — or sooner — and to isolate those who test positive in order to prevent a wide spread of infection.

headline: From Afar, a Fugitive in the Knoedler Art Fraud Gives His Defense
abstract: Until now, little has been heard from José Carlos Bergantiños Diaz, whom the authorities charged in connection with the sale of $80 million in phony works.
lead_paragraph: He was accused of having been a central figure in one of the largest art world scandals of recent times, but little has been heard from José Carlos Bergantiños Diaz, who the authorities say helped orchestrate the sale of $80 million in phony works.

headline: McConnell to Every State: Drop Dead
abstract: Blocking federal aid is vile, but it’s also hypocritical.
lead_paragraph: Covid-19 has killed tens of thousands of Americans, and will clearly kill many more. The lockdown needed to contain the coronavirus is causing an economic slump several times as deep as the Great Recession.

headline: Halle Berry? Hallelujah.
abstract: We come to terms with Halle Berry’s “Catwoman.”
lead_paragraph: We’re trying something new this week. We want you to watch a movie with us. And not just any movie, but the 2004 superhero bomb “Catwoman,” starring two of our favorites: Halle Berry and Sharon Stone. We’ve got fun facts, some questions and a little bit of, um, cattiness.

headline: Coronavirus Critics’ Picks
abstract: Now is an excellent time to read about the 1918 flu. Or maybe just watch the Fast & Furious movies.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Full Round 1 2020 N.F.L. Picks and Analysis
abstract: Going through all the selections of the first round, from Joe Burrow at No. 1 to his Louisiana State teammate Clyde Edwards-Helaire at No. 32.
lead_paragraph: Live, from Roger Goodell’s basement, the first round of the N.F.L. draft offered something of a surprise gift on Thursday night: A chance to focus on selections over spectacle with a smooth run through the top 32 picks.

headline: He’s Got Fries, Beer and Video Chat. Tell Us How You’re Watching the N.F.L. Draft
abstract: The drinking games and broadcaster clichés live on. But parties will happen virtually. How are you watching? Send us a tweet @nytsports to show us your set up.
lead_paragraph: It’s been roughly a month and a half since the last pro basketball or hockey game. March Madness was canceled. Baseball never started. For my group of childhood friends and me, and surely for plenty of others, this year’s N.F.L. draft has become the most important sporting event since the Super Bowl.

headline: Movie Theaters, Urged to Open, Want to Delay Showtime
abstract: The major chains, with no new releases to show and a fear of being singled out as virus hot spots, are worried about coming back too early.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In recent weeks, a tentative timeline for reopening America’s movie theaters began to take shape. It involved pushing to get 75 percent of the country’s 5,548 cinemas selling tickets again this summer, enough to justify the wide release of two potential blockbusters: Christopher Nolan’s mind-bending “Tenet,” scheduled for July 17, and Disney’s mega-budget “Mulan,” set for July 24.

headline: Financial Aid to Struggling States Is Next Big Congressional Battle
abstract: Mitch McConnell said states should file for bankruptcy, but there is broad agreement that Washington will have to bail out local governments suffering economic pain from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With congressional approval of the latest emergency pandemic measure sealed on Thursday, the focus is quickly shifting to an escalating battle over whether Congress will provide hundreds of billions of dollars to states staggering under the costs of the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: House Passes Relief for Small Businesses and Aid for Hospitals and Testing
abstract: The chamber also established a special committee to investigate the Trump administration’s response to the coronavirus pandemic and the multitrillion-dollar government rescue effort enacted to address it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House gave resounding approval on Thursday to a $484 billion coronavirus relief package to restart a depleted loan program for distressed small businesses and to provide funds for hospitals and coronavirus testing, and it moved to ramp up oversight of the sprawling federal response to the pandemic.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Probably plenty. This weekend our TV critic recommends a gentle comedy, a supernatural period piece and a juicy returning drama.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Your View of Staying Home
abstract: We heard thoughts from readers across the country about efforts to reopen states that are currently social distancing to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Treasury Clarifies Small-Business Loans as Fed Vows Transparency
abstract: The two institutions, actively deploying hundreds of billions of dollars in taxpayer funding, moved to assuage concerns about where the money is going.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration moved on Thursday to ensure that large corporations with access to capital are not improperly taking emergency small-business loans and the Federal Reserve committed to greater immediate transparency about how its bailout funds are deployed, amid growing concerns about how hundreds of billions of dollars of economic relief money are being allocated.

headline: Iris Love, Stylish Archaeologist and Dog Breeder, Dies at 86
abstract: She was once known as the archaeologist in a miniskirt, a scion of old New York whose second career was raising Westminster Kennel Club champions.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: A Breath of Fresh Air
abstract: A program first founded to help city children escape tuberculosis finds new purpose during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: For Karen Arroyo, a medical assistant at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, the night hours now seem to collapse into one another. She moves among Covid-19 patients who are too weak to speak to her. She checks their vital signs and cleans them off when they’re soiled. She wraps up those who are deceased and prepares them to be transported to the morgue. When Ms. Arroyo gets home at 7 a.m., she sprays her clothes down with Lysol so as not to expose her family.

headline: Amid Signs Coronavirus Came Earlier, Americans Ask: Did I Already Have It?
abstract: New revelations have left people wondering about ailments early this year. Doctors are thinking back to unexplained cases. Medical examiners are looking for possible misdiagnosed deaths.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In January, a mystery illness swept through a call center in a skyscraper on Michigan Avenue in Chicago. Close to 30 people in one department alone had symptoms — dry, deep coughs and fevers they could not shake. When they gradually returned to work after taking sick days, they sat in their cubicles looking wan and tired.

headline: 2 Brothers Died of Covid-19. They’re Being Denied Their Last Wish.
abstract: More than 250 Mexican immigrants have died from the virus in the New York area. Many of them longed to be buried in their birthplace.
lead_paragraph: When Javier Morales, 48, died at a hospital in Hackensack, N.J., his family decided not to tell his brother Martin right away. Martin Morales was also battling the coronavirus, and they worried about how he would handle the news.

headline: We’re Stuck in Coronavirus Limbo
abstract: A mix of dread and hope. Of reopening and distancing. Of living in two worlds at once.
lead_paragraph: You may remember the chilling warning from Italian journalists and doctors in early March: The United States is two weeks behind where we are. The message was disorienting — a dispatch from a dystopian future, delivered in the present. The evidence in Italy was undeniable and yet in an America before lockdowns, their crisis was, for many, an abstraction. Even medical professionals preparing for the worst in America seemed to struggle to hold the coming devastation in their minds. “We are starting to see some cases in our hospitals, but it’s nothing like what doctors in Italy are describing,” New York City E.R. doctor Helen Ouyang wrote in a diary during the second week of March. “They warn me that we are about two weeks behind them. Could we really get to where they are in such a short time?”

headline: John Houghton, Who Sounded Alarm on Climate Change, Dies at 88
abstract: He led the United Nations panel on global warming that won a Nobel Peace Prize; he died from complications of the coronavirus
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Home Alone at the White House: A Sour President, With TV His Constant Companion
abstract: As his administration grapples with reopening the economy and responding to the coronavirus crisis, President Trump worries about his re-election and how the news media is portraying him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump arrives in the Oval Office these days as late as noon, when he is usually in a sour mood after his morning marathon of television.

headline: Who Is Driving Inequality? You Are
abstract: How to rebuild social solidarity.
lead_paragraph: Who is driving inequality in America? You are. I am. We are.

headline: No One Deserves to Die of Covid-19 in Jail
abstract: But more than 100 inmates already have.
lead_paragraph: On March 28, Patrick Jones became the first inmate in a federal prison known to have died  of Covid-19. He was a worker at a prison textile factory at the Oakdale Federal Correctional Complex in Louisiana, where he was serving time for a nonviolent drug offense. By the third week of April, seven more inmates at Oakdale had died. Meanwhile, prison factories around the country have stayed open, subjecting inmates who work there to packed conditions even as the virus spreads.

headline: Don Campbell, Hip-Hop Dance Innovator, Is Dead at 69
abstract: He invented the Campbellock, better known as locking, an idiosyncratic style that became one of the first street dances to gain widespread attention.
lead_paragraph: Don Campbell invented locking, a style that eventually permeated hip-hop dance, because he had a hard time doing the robot.

headline: When Trump Is Watching, Governors’ Decisions Are Never Open-and-Shut
abstract: The president’s criticism of Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia, a Republican reopening the state amid a viral pandemic, sent a confusing message to governors considering similar moves.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia announced this week that he would soon allow restaurants, barbershops and other businesses to reopen, the Republican governor’s plan seemed in tune with a president who had openly encouraged protesters of social distancing restrictions.

headline: House to Examine Ouster of Health Official Who Doubted Drugs Trump Pushed
abstract: The chairwoman of the Energy and Commerce health subcommittee said she planned to hold hearings on Rick Bright’s dismissal as the head of an agency helping to develop a coronavirus vaccine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A key House subcommittee chairwoman said on Thursday that she planned to hold hearings into the departure of Rick Bright, who said he was removed as the head of an agency involved in developing a coronavirus vaccine after he pressed for rigorous vetting of unproven drugs embraced by President Trump to combat the virus.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: With evidence mounting that the coronavirus was circulating undetected for weeks, Americans are wondering whether they may already have had Covid-19 and not known it.
lead_paragraph: Now that we can be pretty sure the coronavirus was loose in the U.S. much earlier than anyone previously knew, quite a few Americans are recalling that nasty bug that walloped them over the winter and asking, could that have been Covid-19?

headline: Bodies of 2 Transgender Women Found in Badly Burned Car in Puerto Rico
abstract: Activists said that the women, who were from New York City, were the third and fourth transgender people to be killed in Puerto Rico in the last two months.
lead_paragraph: The bodies of two transgender women were found inside a charred car in Puerto Rico on Wednesday, outraging activists who said the killings were part of a disturbing history of violence against L.G.B.T.Q. people on the island.

headline: Corrections: April 24, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: The Spotlight feature on Thursday about the 50th Earth Day anniversary misstated which celebration was marked on Wednesday. While it was the 50th anniversary of the event, it was the 51st celebration of Earth Day.

headline: Prepares for the Bar
abstract: John Guzzetta opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Are you hankering for a lively and crunchy Friday puzzle? Because this puzzle by Jim Guzzetta is lively and crunchy. You’ll wrestle with it, but I’m betting you’ll come out of it feeling really good about yourself.

headline: Giants and Jets Take Offensive Tackles Early in the N.F.L. Draft
abstract: The Giants chose Georgia’s Andrew Thomas at No. 4, and the Jets picked Mekhi Becton in the 11th spot.
lead_paragraph: Making protection for quarterback Daniel Jones a priority, the Giants on Thursday selected Andrew Thomas, a Georgia offensive tackle, at fourth over all in the N.F.L. draft.

headline: Coronavirus, Italy, Ramadan: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: When It’s Either Your Ex, or Nobody, for Months
abstract: People have worse problems, but mine is having my boyfriend break up with me at the start of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend broke up with me the week before they found my neighbor. The breakup happened in the evening; I had spent the day grocery shopping because the World Health Organization had just declared a pandemic.

headline: Vanquish the Virus? Australia and New Zealand Aim to Show the Way
abstract: The two countries, led by ideological opposites, are converging on an extraordinary goal: eliminating the virus. Their nonpolitical approach is restoring trust in democracy.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Thousands of miles from President Trump’s combative news briefings, a conservative leader in Australia and a progressive prime minister in New Zealand are steadily guiding their countries toward a rapid suppression of the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: E.U. Waters Down Report on China’s Coronavirus Propaganda
abstract: Belgium said it would start gradually lifting lockdown measures in May.
lead_paragraph: 新冠病毒疫情最新消息

headline: Wall Street Rallies, Bucking Drop in Global Stocks
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: Trump Muses About Light as Remedy, but Also Disinfectant, Which Is Dangerous
abstract: At a briefing, the president promoted unproven treatments and asked Dr. Deborah Birx if she had heard of the success of sunlight as a tool against viruses.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has long pinned his hopes on the powers of sunlight to defeat the Covid-19 virus. He returned to that theme at the White House coronavirus briefing on Thursday, bringing in a science administrator to back up his assertions and eagerly theorizing about treatments involving the use of household disinfectant that would be dangerous if put inside the body, as well as the power of sunlight and ultraviolet light.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Beastie Boys Story’ and ‘The Hottest August’
abstract: Two Beastie Boys ponder their past on Apple TV Plus. And other New Yorkers ponder their future in a documentary streaming on PBS.org.
lead_paragraph: BEASTIE BOYS STORY (2020) Stream on Apple TV Plus. The two surviving members of the Beastie Boys, Adam Horovitz and Michael Diamond, walk an audience through their band’s history in this unconventional documentary. Think of it like a Beastie Boys TED talk: Directed by Spike Jonze, the film shows the present-day Horovitz and Diamond onstage, telling their story as archival footage and video is projected behind them. (The documentary is an adaptation of a stage show Horovitz and Diamond hosted in 2019.) The setup allows for some entertainingly peculiar moments, as when the elder Horovitz interrupts footage of the band’s early shows, where his younger self is reading rap lyrics off a crumpled piece of paper. Turning from the projected video to the audience with apparent embarrassment, Horovitz asks, “Most rappers hold their rhymes in little pieces of paper, right?”

headline: Watching America in Horror From a Curve-Flattened Australia
abstract: There’s an extreme emotional dissonance in feelings of gratitude for Australia’s relative safety, when so many people I know and love are in the United States where things seem out of control.
lead_paragraph: This past week, I’ve had multiple stressful dreams involving my friend Debbie, who lives in Atlanta. I couldn’t figure out why until the most recent dream, in which Debbie was in Melbourne, stranded because international flights were suspended due to the coronavirus.

headline: Late Night Feels for Doctors Working Under Trump
abstract: “Their only option is to play dumb and hope Trump gets distracted by a Filet-O-Fish or something,” Jimmy Kimmel joked Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Word + Quiz: castanets
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: What Does Isolation Look Like? Photographers Had the Perfect Subjects: Themselves
abstract: As they sheltered during the pandemic, photojournalists turned the cameras on their own lives to document the anxiety, fear and, yes, even joy of life at a standstill.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Who’s Making Hong Kong’s Ubiquitous Face Masks? Prisoners, Among Others
abstract: To ensure that city workers have enough surgical masks, an army of inmates works around the clock for pennies.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When word came that a dangerous new virus was killing people in mainland China, the people of Hong Kong sprang into action. Virtually overnight, the schools were closed, posters appeared around the city reminding residents to wash their hands, and seemingly everyone on the street was wearing a face mask.

headline: Dollar Bills
abstract: What story does this image inspire for you?
lead_paragraph: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: ‘They Want to Forget Us’: Psychiatric Hospital Workers Feel Exposed
abstract: At least 30 people have died of the coronavirus at New York’s psychiatric centers, and staff members say patients and workers have not been sufficiently protected.
lead_paragraph: By mid-March, the staff at the Rockland Psychiatric Center in Orangeburg, N.Y., was growing frustrated.

headline: 2020 N.F.L. Draft: What We Learned
abstract: Green Bay delivered the shock of the night drafting Jordan Love as a potential successor to Aaron Rodgers, Miami’s rebuild is coming to fruition and New England is still New England.
lead_paragraph: The 85th N.F.L. draft might have lacked the glitz of the Las Vegas Strip and bro-hugs with Roger Goodell, but the first virtual draft in league history still had its football pyrotechnics. There were a few chip shots, like quarterback Joe Burrow getting picked first overall by the Cincinnati Bengals. But there were also plenty of other surprises and intrigue — not all of it generated by the Raiders.

headline: New York Put Recovering Virus Patients in Hotels. Soon, 4 Were Dead.
abstract: The deaths revealed lapses in the monitoring of people sent to isolation, a critical part of the city’s efforts to slow the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Rowe Jr. was discharged from the hospital this month after testing positive for the coronavirus, he needed a place to stay so he would not put his 84-year-old father at risk. New York City health officials put him up at a three-star hotel in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Trump Is Harsh on Immigration. That Doesn’t Mean Biden Has the Latino Vote.
abstract: Some Democrats worry that their party is taking a crucial bloc for granted in 2020.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There’s talk of protecting the country from the “Invisible Enemy” by temporarily blocking people from receiving green cards. New footage of the construction of the southern border wall is available to stream online from a government website. If there was any doubt, this week made it clear: President Trump is making his anti-immigration message a cornerstone of his re-election campaign.

headline: Missouri Pork Plant Workers Say They Can’t Cover Mouths to Cough
abstract: A lawsuit filed against a Smithfield Foods plant claims it has created a public nuisance by failing to protect workers from coronavirus infection.
lead_paragraph: Workers at a Smithfield Foods pork plant in Milan, Mo., say that for years they have endured repetitive stress injuries on the meat processing line — and urinary tract infections because they had so few bathroom breaks.

headline: ‘Extraction’ Review: All Fight, No Fun
abstract: The debut feature by Sam Hargrave serves up a barrage of bullets and blown-up cars in a properly global thriller.
lead_paragraph: An action thriller powered by brute force rather than ideas or style, “Extraction” stars Chris Hemsworth as Tyler Rake, a mercenary dispatched to Dhaka, Bangladesh, to retrieve the kidnapped son of a crime lord (the Bollywood stalwart Pankaj Tripathi) from a competing gang. After a perfunctory setup — the criminals are all in cahoots with the cops, and the kingpin is up to his own manipulative tricks — the film gets right down to business, serving up a relentless barrage of blood, bullets and blown-up cars.

headline: In Reversal, California Farm Town Approves ICE Detention Centers
abstract: Two privately run state prisons in the town of McFarland, many of whose residents are undocumented field workers, will be converted to hold immigrants.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Leaders of a cash-strapped California farm town, home to many undocumented immigrants, have voted to convert two privately run state prisons into immigration detention centers, just two months after public opposition appeared to have derailed the proposal.

headline: News Quiz: Coronavirus, Canada, N.F.L. Draft
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: Frantic for Coronavirus Gear, Americans in Need Turn to China’s Elite
abstract: People and companies with vested interest in sustaining the U.S.-China relationship are stepping in as ties fray between the two countries.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — U.S. hospitals and state officials face desperate shortages of the masks, ventilators and other gear they need to fight the coronavirus. Chinese factories can make the equipment and sell it to them, but huge obstacles stand in the way — and Washington’s stumbles and growing hostility with Beijing aren’t helping.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Imagine Online School in a Language You Don’t Understand’
abstract: In this lesson, students will consider the challenges of remote learning when you don’t speak the same language as the teacher. As a Going Further option, they can research what their school district is doing to support English-language learners.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Imagine Online School in a Language You Don’t Understand” by Rikha Sharma Rani

headline: Isolating the Sick at Home, Italy Stores Up Family Tragedies
abstract: “Stay home” measures have helped Italy control the coronavirus, but home is also a dangerous place that may be propping up the infection curve the lockdown was meant to suppress.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When her middle-aged son got sick, Ruffina Pompei did what she had done for decades, bringing vegetable soup and freshly squeezed orange juice to his room. She slept in an armchair outside his room and changed his clothes. She told her husband, 89, to steer clear.

headline: Why Georgia Isn’t Ready to Reopen, in Charts
abstract: It’s among the states least ready to roll back restrictions.
lead_paragraph: It’s among the states least ready to roll back restrictions.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Running to the Edge’ and ‘The Queen’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE DEATH AND LIFE OF AIDA HERNANDEZ: A Border Story, by Aaron Bobrow-Strain. (Picador, 432 pp., $20.) Our reviewer, Michelle Goldberg, called this “novelistic” real-life tale of a dreamer/deportee who ricocheted between the United States and Mexico “searing” and “illuminating.” “If the book rings true,” Goldberg wrote, “it’s because Aida is such a complex and imperfect figure; she is not whom you’d invent if you wanted to write a social justice parable.”

headline: Buying Dora Maar’s Diary on eBay and Other Classy Tales From France
abstract: A father-son love story, a memoirist’s account of her first affair and a journalist’s chronicle of the life of Picasso’s lover through the addresses in her Hermès diary.
lead_paragraph: SCHRÖDINGER’S DOGBy Martin Dumont Translated by John Cullen 150 pp. Other Press. Paper, $14.99.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: We're All Learning More About Coronavirus
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news

headline: The Case of the Fit Bookworm of Brooklyn
abstract: How I found hope in a stranger’s set of keys during the coronavirus shutdown.
lead_paragraph: While out for some air near Prospect Park in Brooklyn, I looked down at the sidewalk and discovered a lost set of keys. Lockdown in a pandemic was not a time to lose your keys. I wondered how this would disrupt the already disrupted life of the owner. Did they have a roommate or family to let them in? Are locksmiths considered essential workers?

headline: How to Create Screen-Life Balance When Life Has Shifted to Screens
