abstract: Being thoughtful about our use of screens can help us emerge from this crisis empowered and in control, and with more self-awareness.
lead_paragraph: If you’re like most people right now, you are spending a lot of time in front of screens. This makes sense: In a time of social distancing, screens have become our portals to the outside world.

headline: Stuck in the Past on the Climate
abstract: Shareholders at JP Morgan Chase should block a former Exxon chief from another term on the bank’s board.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know why young people increasingly despair that the rest of us will leave them without a habitable world, consider the case of Lee Raymond.

headline: Minutes Before a Lockdown, a Civil Ceremony in France
abstract: Victoria de Lambilly and Oscar de Poncins married at 11 a.m. on March 17 in a small town south of Paris. They then boarded a 1:30 p.m. train back to London.
lead_paragraph: Victoria de Lambilly remembers the exact day in September 2017 when she and Oscar de Poncins met at her London home — it was also the same day that her family’s new puppy, a three-month-old Border terrier named Brexit, had arrived.

headline: Guerrilla Golfers Sneak Onto Greens Closed by Pandemic
abstract: Half of all golf courses are shut down. But across America — and especially in Florida — renegades are still getting their fix.
lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — The 18 holes of the Boca Delray Golf and Country Club have been closed since late March, when administrators of Palm Beach County, Fla., decided to shutter every business and activity deemed nonessential.

headline: If We Can’t Test Everyone for Coronavirus, This Is the Next Best Thing
abstract: Random sampling is the quickest, most feasible and most effective means of assessing the U.S. population.
lead_paragraph: We are flying blind in the fight against Covid-19. The number of cases is surely much greater than what we see and what is being relied on to provide direction for devising and implementing policy.

headline: Canceled Spelling Bee? Not if These Siblings Can Help It
abstract: Shobha and Shourav Dasari have organized a national spelling bee after the Scripps tournament was canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic. It will take place online.
lead_paragraph: The words, equal parts obscure and baffling, torment her to this day.

headline: ‘I Like It, Actually’: Why So Many Older People Thrive in Lockdown
abstract: Amid reports of death and isolation, some older New Yorkers are modeling strength and resilience.
lead_paragraph: In a building for older residents of Lower Manhattan, Sterling Lord, 99, is using his lockdown time to start a new literary agency. Like agents everywhere, he said he was about to seal a “huge television deal” for one of his authors. He could not talk about it yet, he said.

headline: Women Are ‘Claiming Their Power’ in Investment Clubs of Their Own
abstract: Traditional financial channels, women say, have often been blind to their needs. Meetup groups and other organizations are filling a void.
lead_paragraph: During the 2008 financial crisis, Lauren Winfield found herself starting over in Austin, Texas, without a job, a network or a nest egg.

headline: Some Companies Seeking Bailouts Had Piles of Cash, Then Spent It
abstract: They poured the money into stock buybacks and dividends. Now, those hurting from the pandemic want government aid.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the top executives of KFC, Wendy’s, Papa John’s and other large restaurant chains held an urgent call with President Trump about the coronavirus crisis.

headline: Shangela Cooks Wiener Schnitzel While ‘Quaranqueening’
abstract: The “Drag Race” veteran, who is sheltering in Texas, stars in the new unscripted show “We’re Here.”
lead_paragraph: D.J. Pierce, better known to his TV fans as Shangela, snapped a pair of tongs as if he were playing castanets and executed a high kick to show off his neon-yellow sneakers.

headline: Are People Who Live in Dog-Friendly Buildings Happier?
abstract: The answer is a no-brainer for dog owners, although some of their neighbors might still be on the fence.
lead_paragraph: People who own dogs live longer. They’re healthier. They’re calmer. Their children are less prone to allergies. And they have government-sanctioned reasons to leave the house while sheltering in place.

headline: How a Triage Nurse Spends Her Sundays
abstract: One of the hardest parts of Marina DiMattia’s day is separating patients from loved ones, who are no longer allowed in the hospital.
lead_paragraph: “The amount of people who can’t breathe, who are coming in with respiratory issues, is overwhelming,” said Marina DiMattia, a triage nurse at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. But, she added, “in between gasps of air, they thank us.” The gratitude among patients “has been remarkable,” she said. “It makes me think I can keep doing this.”

headline: The Lab That Discovered Global Warming Has Good News and Bad News
abstract: The good news is that the pandemic shows “science works.” The bad news? Global warming may be far more dangerous than a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Nestled in the forest behind a guard house just north of the border between New York and New Jersey off Route 9W is one of the world’s greatest meccas for climate change research.

headline: Black Leaders Want a Black Woman as Biden’s Running Mate. But Who?
abstract: Among black leaders close to Joe Biden, a commitment to selecting a woman is not enough. They have publicly and privately pushed him to select a black woman to fuel black voter enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey made his vice-presidential pitch to Hillary Clinton at her Washington home, months before she faced Donald J. Trump in the November election.

headline: Do You Want to Die in an I.C.U.? Pandemic Makes Question All Too Real
abstract: Sobering statistics for older patients sharpen the need to draw up advanced directives for treatment and share them with their families.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Cheryl Goldman, a retired high school teacher living on Long Island, called her son, Edo Banach, in Maryland. It seemed a routine chat until Ms. Goldman announced that if she became ill with Covid-19, she would decline a ventilator.

headline: What Is Convalescent Blood Plasma, and Why Do We Care About It?
abstract: Blood plasma from people who have recovered from Covid-19 may help others fight the disease.
lead_paragraph: A medical procedure doctors have used to treat novel diseases for a century has emerged as a focal point in the fight against Covid-19: convalescent plasma.

headline: Mitch McConnell Is Not as Clever as He Thinks He Is
abstract: Leaving states to fend for themselves is a shocking abdication of responsibility that may haunt his party in November.
lead_paragraph: When banks, corporations and wealthy individuals need bailouts, the Republican Party is there, pen in hand. The $2 trillion CARES Act reserved $500 billion for aid to large industries as well as $90 billion in tax breaks for owners of “pass-through” businesses — a benefit that overwhelmingly aids rich hedge fund investors and owners of real estate businesses. Even the small business fund ($350 billion for firms with fewer than 500 employees) has mostly benefited larger companies.

headline: Did America Learn Anything From the Last Economic Crisis?
abstract: Bailout fatigue is already starting to appear, particularly among Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Those who do not remember history are condemned to repeat it. Even when that history is only a decade old, evidently.

headline: A Stripped-Down N.F.L. Draft Turns Out to Be Pretty Special
abstract: Cut off from its usual pomp, the draft gave viewers some memorable snapshots: a general manager’s children, a coach’s sublime landscape and some curious decorations, like a team-branded surfboard.
lead_paragraph: At the start of a most unusual N.F.L. draft on Thursday, Commissioner Roger Goodell looked like an amateur actor trying to pull off a “Saturday Night Live” monologue on a wood-paneled set from “Kiner’s Korner.” Gone were the joyous players and jeering fans who usually surround him at the draft.

headline: What the Honeybees Showed Me
abstract: The colony entered my dreams, my thoughts, my conversations. Something about me had changed.
lead_paragraph: When I first became keeper of a colony of honeybees, I was thinking more than anything of escape. I’d just turned 30 and had recently moved from Brighton to Oxford, having taken a job on a whim, again, moving out of one rented house in one city and into another as I had done throughout my 20s. But the new job was stressful. I spent long hours at the office in front of a screen. I was under pressure from company targets and deadlines, thrown into frenetic communications with colleagues who sounded as stretched as I felt, and disconnected from the world — the world! — I glimpsed as I cycled to and from work each day.

headline: ‘It’s a Slap in the Face’: Victims Are Angered as Jails Free Inmates
abstract: More people are being released as outbreaks spread behind bars. But there is a growing conflict over who should be let out.
lead_paragraph: Her cellphone buzzed with a new text message, and Tracy Fehrenbacher grew furious. An alert from the circuit court notified her that the man accused of a hit-and-run that left her daughter dead was being released from a St. Louis jail.

headline: Take It From Me, Voter Fraud Is Part of the G.O.P. Playbook
abstract: Republicans look the other way when electoral cheating helps them.
lead_paragraph: By now most of us have seen the photos from the Wisconsin primary, where voters had to stand for hours in lines that wrapped around city blocks in cold, pouring rain. To exercise what was supposed to be their most sacred democratic right, people had to risk catching the deadly coronavirus — and several did.

headline: The Nude Selfie Is Now High Art
abstract: It has become an act of resilience in isolation, a way to seduce without touch.
lead_paragraph: Before face-touching became potentially lethal, my friend Dave had a lot of lovers. Now he makes do with nude selfies. He doesn’t even request them, he said. They appear as if by magic: “I wake up and they are just there.”

headline: How Republicans Became the Party of Death
abstract: People are disposable. So is income. For the ‘pro-life’ party, one is more important.
lead_paragraph: I look at the numbers every day, sometimes every hour, sometimes before dawn. China is not to be trusted. Nor is Russia. I’m always curious about the latest death toll out of Sweden, a country with a riskier, more self-regulated approach to keeping people apart. And cheers for long-suffering bell’Italia, finally seeing a drop in active Covid-19 cases.

headline: Martin Luther King Jr. Predicted This Moment
abstract: The coronavirus shows us clearer than ever before that “all labor has dignity.”
lead_paragraph: Fifty-two years ago, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. famously asserted the dignity of all work, he seemed to foresee this moment when it would become so clear that the labor of everyone — farmworkers, grocers, delivery drivers, caregivers, nursing assistants — was essential to all of our health and well-being.

headline: How to Make It in America as a Professional Falconer
abstract: The job promises flexible hours, a connection to nature and irresistible Instagram content. But is it recession-proof?
lead_paragraph: Across all industries, workers are struggling through the economic slowdown. In California, urban falconers are hoping their jobs will be recession-proof.

headline: When Life Felt Normal: Your Pre-Pandemic Moments
abstract: Readers share memories, images and videos from before the coronavirus became a pandemic, and reflect on what they mean now.
lead_paragraph: Our lives have been forever changed by the coronavirus pandemic. Hundreds of thousands of people around the world have died. Millions in the United States alone have lost their jobs.

headline: Trump’s Remarks Prompt Warnings on Disinfectants
abstract: Several states take tentative steps to reopen businesses. The Navy recommended reinstating the captain of an aircraft carrier who had sought help as the virus spread on his ship.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: Coronavirus, Congress, N.F.L. Draft: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
abstract: Preliminary data suggested that many more New Yorkers may have been infected than was previously believed.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: A New Way to Mourn
abstract: A funeral, punctuated with technical difficulties and expressions of deep love, reveals the new rituals we are creating in crisis.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: A Dark Debut Propels a Dutch Writer to Reluctant Fame
abstract: Marieke Lucas Rijneveld’s novel “The Discomfort of Evening” was a best seller in the Netherlands. Now, it’s been nominated for the Booker International Prize.
lead_paragraph: Marieke Lucas Rijneveld is an author who confides in their reader, rather than family or friends. “I am a private person,” the writer, who identifies as male and uses the pronouns they and them, said on a recent video call from their home in Utrecht, the Netherlands.

headline: The Next Round of Bailouts Will Name Names
abstract: The Treasury and the Fed vowed to crack down on companies taking advantage of rescue funds with new guidelines and measures to increase transparency.
lead_paragraph: Our next DealBook Helpline call is on Tuesday at 11 a.m. Eastern. Join us to discuss the day-to-day challenges of running a business during the pandemic, and ask a panel of experts your questions. R.S.V.P. here. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: Could the Power of the Sun Slow the Coronavirus?
abstract: A study suggests that ultraviolet rays could slow the virus, though not enough to wipe it out, and not as a treatment.
lead_paragraph: Will summertime slow the virus that causes Covid-19, as it has done with many other viruses that sow flu, colds and pneumonia? A new study finds that it may, though not enough to wipe out the pathogen or keep the pandemic from resurging in the fall.

headline: Biden Leads Trump in Key States. But Hillary Clinton Led by More.
abstract: While polling shows Joe Biden narrowly ahead in states like Michigan, things looked considerably rosier for Hillary Clinton in many swing states at this point in 2016.
lead_paragraph: If the presidential election were held today, polls in crucial swing states like Florida, Michigan and Pennsylvania suggest that Joseph R. Biden Jr. would be in position for a narrow victory.

headline: Virus Deaths in New York Hit Lowest Level Since April 1
abstract: The number of coronavirus patients in hospitals in the state was down almost 25 percent since last week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Deaths from the coronavirus continued their gradual descent, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday, with the state recording 422 more deaths, the least since April 1. The state death toll now stands at 16,162.

headline: Library of Congress Unveils New Digital DJ Tool
abstract: Citizen DJ brings the library’s archive to hip-hop lovers’ fingertips.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress is challenging hip-hop fans and music lovers to remix sounds from its extensive archive. A new digital tool called Citizen DJ, created by one of the library’s Innovators in Residence, Brian Foo, will allow users to explore the library’s recordings to create and download original beats and sounds.

headline: I Used to Make Fun of Silicon Valley Preppers. Then I Became One.
abstract: In tech circles, gearing up for the apocalypse was a cliché. Now it’s a credential.
lead_paragraph: For years, one of the most smirked-at subspecies in the technology ecosystem was that of the Silicon Valley Prepper. You were always hearing about them, these men with soft jobs and hardened paranoia. The $0.99 game developer with a bug-out bag; the venture capitalist with a bunker in New Zealand; the cloud administrator learning to bowhunt for a survivalist future. The preppers were living in flush times in a beautiful region, but it seemed like the first thing they did with money was steel for the apocalypse.

headline: What to Know About California’s Testing Expansion
abstract: Friday: Testing capacity is still a major hurdle to reopening, but California is getting closer. Also: PG&E’s chief executive said he’ll retire.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Film Club: ‘Earthrise: 50 Years Since Apollo 8’
abstract: How did a photograph from space help inspire the environmental movement?
lead_paragraph: Earth Day turned 50 this week.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Games?
abstract: Cooped up and quarantined, what games are you turning to for fun?
lead_paragraph: Do you ever feel cooped up during this time of self-quarantine?

headline: Midwest Mayors Debated When to Reopen in a Frank Call
abstract: A sometimes tense conference call among Missouri and Kansas leaders provided a rare look at how discussions about lifting coronavirus restrictions are unfolding nationwide.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When should businesses reopen? What should be done about residents who ignore stay-at-home orders? Is it possible to balance the restlessness of those stuck inside with the dire predictions of public health experts?

headline: There Are More Cases Than We Thought. Is That Good News?
abstract: Not really. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Trump’s Suggestion That Disinfectants Could Be Used to Treat Coronavirus Prompts Aggressive Pushback
abstract: Responding to the criticism from public health officials around the country, the president said he was playing a trick on reporters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Maryland, so many callers flooded a health hotline with questions that the state’s Emergency Management Agency had to issue a warning that “under no circumstances” should any disinfectant be taken to treat the coronavirus. In Washington State, officials urged people not to consume laundry detergent capsules. Across the country on Friday, health professionals sounded the alarm.

headline: ‘Extraction’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Sam Hargrave narrates a sequence from his Netflix action film starring Chris Hemsworth.
lead_paragraph: Sam Hargrave narrates a sequence from his Netflix action film starring Chris Hemsworth.

headline: You’re Quarantined. Is It Time to Get a Puppy?
abstract: New pets can offer companionship, but don’t forget to provide proper care and to socialize them even while you’re maintaining social distance.
lead_paragraph: How many weeks of social isolation does it take to crave a puppy? For Julie Taylor, a TV writer and producer in Glendale, Calif., the answer was two.

headline: The Easier Way to Make a Garden Bed
abstract: It might seem like the lazy gardener’s approach, but it also happens to be the most economical.
lead_paragraph: I’ve tried various methods of making a garden bed.

headline: Beware the Fees That Come With Some Money Transfers on Apps
abstract: Banks may now charge for payments that are linked to credit cards, treating them as cash advances with interest accruing immediately.
lead_paragraph: Money transfer apps, which allow you to quickly pay friends and family through your smartphone, have grown in popularity in recent years. And the coronavirus pandemic has only expanded their use — to pay gig workers, make donations or simply avoid using cash.

headline: The Rent Is Too Damn Harrowing
abstract: Already a source of acute anxiety, rent has become a paralyzing, panic-inducing subject for many New Yorkers.

headline: How ‘Extraction’ Leaps Into Action
abstract: The director Sam Hargrave discusses how he jumped across a building with his camera to capture energetic stunts for his debut feature.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: How to Make (and Use) a Disinfectant Against Coronavirus
abstract: Here’s a guide to working with sprays, wipes and a bleach-based solution to clean surfaces of the pathogen.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus that causes Covid-19 may survive for several days on some surfaces. Estimates of its life span vary, but the virus can clearly hang around long enough to make disinfecting frequently touched surfaces a priority.

headline: A Cast-Iron SoHo Facade and Its Odyssey to New Jersey and Back
abstract: The new building at 74 Grand Street will feature the 1886 front of the previous building on the site — but, oh, what a trip it’s been!
lead_paragraph: After a heavy rain in 2004, the iron-fronted 1886 loft building at 74 Grand Street suddenly began listing to starboard, terrifying the people inside and earning the five-story structure the nickname the Leaning Tower of SoHo. Over time, the tilt toward Wooster Street grew to an alarming 30 inches or so, and in 2010 the troubled building was demolished by order of the Buildings Department.

headline: Opposed to Bailouts, but in This Case Willing to Take One
abstract: Some conservative nonprofit groups are seeking financial help to weather the coronavirus crisis. Some liberal organizations are putting aside different qualms to make the same request.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Among the applicants for loans from the Small Business Administration’s stimulus package is the foundation arm of FreedomWorks, a conservative operation that advocates small government and made its name opposing bailouts.

headline: How New Mexico, One of the Poorest States, Averted a Steep Death Toll
abstract: New Mexico showed how a state can fight the coronavirus with aggressive social distancing, free testing and scientific expertise. But contagion threats are building.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — New Mexico has fewer hospital beds per capita than nearly every other state. It has a rapidly aging population and widespread poverty. Its residents have the highest rate by far of chronic liver disease — just one of the underlying medical conditions that are widespread in New Mexico that heighten the risk of dying from Covid-19.

headline: If Camp Is Canceled, Will I Get My Money Back?
abstract: Policies are all over the map.
lead_paragraph: Summer is just around the corner, but this one could be quite a letdown. Many warm-weather joys may be impossible this year because of the coronavirus: pool parties, beach vacations, cones at the local ice cream shop. And camp. If camp doesn’t happen, kids are going to be heartbroken, and working parents are going to be left without essential child care.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Dying in Hotels After New York Tried Isolation
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “This was his city, and it failed him. New York failed him.”

headline: Brené Brown Is Rooting for You, Especially Now
abstract: The vulnerability researcher, TED Talk star and new podcast host was urging people to face their deepest fears long before the world fell apart.
lead_paragraph: Brené Brown’s voice, that of a teacher and a Texan, is amicably upbeat and frays a little at the edges. When she speaks, the combination of her mild Southern twang, propulsive intellect and swear-jar cordiality can be hypnotic. Brown, a research professor who holds a doctoral degree in social work, is famous for her viral talks on a range of uncomfortable emotions most people prefer not to think about. In the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, and with the help of a new podcast called “Unlocking Us,” she’s teaching an attentive audience to navigate the ones it can’t escape.

headline: In ‘Penny Dreadful: City of Angels,’ California Dreaming, Darkly
abstract: In this new “Penny Dreadful” series, the creator John Logan imagines a lost Los Angeles of cops, pachucos, Nazi sympathizers and a slinky chaos demon.
lead_paragraph: NEWHALL, Calif. — On a sun-drunk afternoon in late February, John Logan tramped down the middle of a deserted street, passing an empty nightclub, a shuttered cinema, a vacant rooming house — relics of a past that never quite existed.

headline: The Ballet World Needs Robert Garland. Why Isn’t It Calling?
abstract: Creating steps is no problem for the resident choreographer of Dance Theater of Harlem. But he does more: He makes ballet relevant.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Robert Garland knows it might sound crazy, but for him the introduction of the clock radio was everything.

headline: Fred the Godson, Nimble New York Rapper, Dies at 41
abstract: The Bronx musician was a forceful presence on mixtapes, filling his rhymes with clever punch lines.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Cook to transport yourself, whether it’s to the English countryside (scones) or a lodge house in southern Quebec (salted maple pie).
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’d like to eat croissants this weekend, slather them with strawberry jam in my imaginary hotel room overlooking Sydney Harbor in Australia before heading north along the shoreline to walk the wind-swept beaches: Bilgola, Avalon, Whale, Palm. I’d like to return in the afternoon, then have a drink at the imaginary hotel, sitting at the bar, with strangers, before heading over to the Star for dinner at the actual Momofuku Seiobo, last seat at the counter.

headline: We Don’t Just Need to Connect — We Need to Reconnect
abstract: Rekindling dormant ties can bring unexpected benefits to our lives.
lead_paragraph: As unemployment climbs to its highest rate in nearly a century, many people are searching for work. Our natural instinct is to go to our strong ties — the people we know well and see regularly. But classic evidence suggests we’re more likely to get a job through our weak ties. It’s not just because we have more acquaintances than friends and family. It’s because our strong ties tend to give us redundant information: They know many of the same things and the same people as we do. Weak ties open up access to new people and new leads.

headline: AT&T Names John Stankey C.E.O. as Randall Stephenson Plans to Retire
abstract: The longtime telecommunications executive, who led the company’s move into the entertainment industry, will take the top job July 1.
lead_paragraph: AT&T, the telecommunications giant that has moved into media and entertainment, announced a changing of the guard on Friday.

headline: What Is a Conservative? And Other Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What’s a Pulse Oximeter, and Do I Really Need One at Home?
abstract: A tiny fingertip device can give you valuable information about your health during a bout of Covid-19 or any respiratory illness.
lead_paragraph: After working for 10 days at Bellevue Hospital in New York, Dr. Richard Levitan decided to share what he had learned about Covid-19. Too many patients were showing up at the hospital with perilously low oxygen levels, putting them at risk for severe complications and death.

headline: Taliban Ramp Up Attacks Even as Coronavirus Spreads in Afghanistan
abstract: With peace negotiations apparently stuck, the insurgents are killing dozens of Afghan government forces every day.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have returned to an all-out offensive on the battlefield, killing dozens of Afghan security forces each day, officials say, even as American officials try to keep alive a scuttled peace deal to end the long war in Afghanistan.

headline: Biden Will Fund-Raise With D.N.C. and His Appointee Will Lead the Committee
abstract: Joe Biden’s presidential campaign is beginning to consolidate control over the Democratic National Committee and will have the ability to raise badly needed cash.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign and the Democratic National Committee have agreed to a joint fund-raising accord and installed the Biden campaign’s choice as the D.N.C.’s chief executive, the latest signs that the party’s presumptive presidential nominee has consolidated control over its broader functions.

headline: Turmoil in Brazil: Bolsonaro Fires Police Chief and Justice Minister Quits
abstract: Sergio Moro, the justice minister who became the face of a powerful anti-corruption crackdown in Brazil, resigned in protest after President Jair Bolsonaro fired the head of the national police.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s justice minister, Sergio Moro, a former federal judge who became the face of a powerful anti-corruption crackdown that swept Latin America, resigned Friday after accusing President Jair Bolsonaro of seeking to assert improper control of the federal police for political gain.

headline: Denied, Deferred and Ignored: 13 Applications, and No Relief
abstract: Fearing they might lose their business, Graceann Dorse and her husband have applied for aid from federal, state, city and private groups, but they have had little success so far.
lead_paragraph: In 17 years, Graceann Dorse and her husband, Christopher Webb, have built their cinematography and special effects firm, FX WRX, into a significant creative and economic force in New York, navigating natural and financial disasters along the way.

headline: Cozy Campfires. Capture the Flag. Coronavirus Tests?
abstract: Across the country, parents, children and counselors are wondering if a treasured summer rite can possibly proceed.
lead_paragraph: “Ten for two” is an unofficial rallying cry for many lovers of sleepaway summer camps. In three words it reveals an unspoken bargain agreed upon for generations by many American children.

headline: The Rolling Stones Still Miss You, and 13 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Juice WRLD, Evanescence, Jónsi and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: California cases rewrite virus’s timeline. A mortuary professor comes “out of nowhere” to help N.Y.C. The untold story of social distancing. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Where I am, the sound of construction is in the air for the first time in a few weeks and traffic is up. Signs, perhaps, that some things are beginning to move forward. It’s a tricky path, one that will include masks and learning to navigate sidewalks, parks and grocery stores with a six-foot buffer. But we can do it! Let’s start with some amazing journalism.

headline: The Most Comforting Chicken
abstract: Diana Henry’s one-pot chicken thighs with black beans, rice and chiles is full of flavor, and so satisfying.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to Five Weeknight Dishes. This was the week I killed the sourdough starter. We were close during the first month of quarantine, but with humans to feed, provisioning enough flour and time to keep the relationship alive was getting harder. It was giving me reproachful vibes from the counter every time I passed through the kitchen. I also felt reproached by some scallions in the kitchen of the chef David Chang, who was cooking on Instagram this week. He is saving the root ends of his scallions, cutting off only the green parts and regrowing new ones in water glasses. Damn, I thought. That is how a real cook does it.

headline: I Was Ready to Help Fight the Pandemic. Then I Got Sick Myself.
abstract: As a surgeon, I anticipated seeing Covid-19 through the eyes of a medical professional. But being a patient was a different matter.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Dr. David Hirsch, a maxillofacial surgeon, performed pro bono reconstructive surgery on Dustin E. Kirby, a Navy corpsman who was struck in the face by a bullet while serving in a Marine Corps infantry battalion in Iraq in 2006. In March he contracted Covid-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. While recovering at home he shared the experience of his infection, and what he learned from it, by narrating to C.J. Chivers, who traced Dustin Kirby’s medical journey in a book, “The Fighters.”

headline: The Tax-Break Bonanza Inside the Economic Rescue Package
abstract: As small businesses and individuals struggle to obtain federal aid, the wealthiest are poised to reap tens of billions of dollars in tax savings.
lead_paragraph: As the federal government dispenses trillions of dollars to save the economy, small businesses and out-of-work individuals are jostling to grab small slices of aid before the funds run out.

headline: Considering Melatonin for Sleep? Here’s a Guide to Help
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the pros and cons of using melatonin supplements for sleeping difficulties.
lead_paragraph: It’s understandable that you may be struggling to fall asleep these days. Our world has been turned upside down, so it is especially hard to unplug from the day and get the high-quality sleep your body needs.

headline: When Hugs Can Kill: Mourning Nova Scotia’s Mass Shooting in a Pandemic
abstract: The coronavirus has destroyed most of our rituals to cope with death.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Soon after his neighbors were gunned down in rural Nova Scotia, Cees van den Hoek started a memorial site near an old church.

headline: Behind the Cover: Afghanistan’s Next War
abstract: For this issue, a look at Afghanistan as the virus threatens to explode with few resources to contain it.

headline: Our Ingenuity Shapes Facebook
abstract: We mortals are showing one of the internet era’s mightiest companies how it should evolve.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Two Exhibitions Respond to Art in the Age of Anxiety and Distance
abstract: George Condo and Rashid Johnson talk about their new simultaneous digital shows, politics and how the role of artists has changed.
lead_paragraph: The artists George Condo and Rashid Johnson are old friends who both debuted new work in simultaneous online exhibitions for Hauser & Wirth gallery that opened last week. Condo, 62, first emerged in the early 1980s as a figurative painter whose portraits walked a line between realism and sardonic conceptualism. His new show, “Drawings for Distanced Figures,” explores how changes in perspective distort his subjects. Johnson, 42, first gained attention in the early 2000s for photographs, sculptures and paintings that explored identity in 21st-century America. His show, “Untitled Anxious Red Drawings,” revisits his “Anxious Men” figures — square-jawed faces with wide eyes and chattering teeth — which have become a staple of his work. (A portion of proceeds from both shows will benefit the World Health Organization’s Covid-19 Solidarity Response Fund.) Like everyone, both artists have had to adapt to a new set of circumstances in the last few months that has made them see their art — not to mention their respective creative processes — differently. This interview, which has been condensed and edited for clarity, took place via Google Hangouts (Condo and Johnson were both at “undisclosed locations on Long Island,” as Condo put it). The artists discussed producing art while sheltering in place, the virtues of online exhibitions and how they think the Covid-19 pandemic will change their profession.

headline: A Big, Once-Reliable Source of Investor Cash Is Drying Up
abstract: The losses aren’t coming just from the drop in stock prices. The effect of the dividend cuts sweeping through the market will hurt, too.
lead_paragraph: The swings of the stock market have been painful enough lately. But on top of the price declines that have kept many investors awake at night, another insult is on the way: Stocks will be providing much less income.

headline: Injections of Bleach? Beams of Light? Trump Is Self-Destructing Before Our Eyes
abstract: The notion that he is bound for four more years is pure superstition.
lead_paragraph: “And he’s going to get re-elected.”

headline: Britain Is Sticking to Brexit Plans Despite Virus Upheaval
abstract: The government is adamant that it will not seek an extension, saying it will reject the idea even if the European Union asks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With governments distracted by the battle with the coronavirus, many analysts have assumed that Britain and the European Union will be forced to extend their year-end deadline for reaching a post-Brexit trade deal.

headline: A Few Thousand Protest Stay-at-Home Order at Wisconsin State Capitol
abstract: The protest was one of the nation’s largest gatherings to date to condemn lockdown orders enacted by state and local governments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A crowd of a few thousand gathered at Wisconsin’s State Capitol on Friday, the latest demonstration by conservative activists against statewide stay-at-home orders meant to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: A Vital Stand-Up Special for the Social Distancing Era
abstract: Ted Alexandro’s free YouTube hour largely succeeds with an urgent brand of observational humor and shows how online comedy can speak to pandemic anxieties.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in his Queens apartment, the stand-up comic Ted Alexandro counts every cough and constantly is convinced he just contracted the coronavirus, at least, he says, for 10 minutes. Then he shifts gears: “Oh, I guess I was just belching.”

headline: Trump Speech to Bring 1,000 West Point Cadets Back to Campus
abstract: The president’s off-again, on-again speech in June will bring back cadets who had scattered across the country to help counter the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Trump, who adores the pomp and precision of military ceremonies, this was the year he would finally get one of the special perks of being president — delivering the commencement address at West Point, the only service academy where he has not spoken.

headline: As States Take Steps Toward Reopening
abstract: Readers are dubious about how social distancing would work for dining out and getting a haircut (Edward Scissorhands?) and stress the value of unions in protecting workers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How the Met Opera Is Throwing a Gala Concert With Smartphones
abstract: Closed by the coronavirus, the company is streaming its biggest stars, performing live across nine time zones.
lead_paragraph: “Is this enough light?” asked the baritone Peter Mattei.

headline: How to Stock Your Liquor Cabinet
abstract: The trick to drawing out your inner bartender while staying home is to improvise and innovate, and above all keep it simple.
lead_paragraph: So you want to start a home bar. Maybe it’s a lifelong dream; maybe it’s all those quarantinis on Instagram. Maybe you’re looking to master the art of the cocktail; maybe you just want something to sip after a long day spent social distancing. Whatever your goal, the trick to drawing out your inner bartender while staying home is to improvise and innovate, and above all, keep it simple.

headline: Revisiting the Posy in Our Current Moment
abstract: Once thought to protect against disease, the small bouquets can at least provide a bit of beauty.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a month ago, as the pandemic was taking flight here in America, I found myself, like so many other nouveau preppers, cruising around my local grocery store in search of provisions. On my way to the checkout, I passed a tiered display of flowers and plants — funnel-shaped bouquets of carnations; potted pastel tulips; lone orchids, their delicate flamingo-neck stems held gracefully aloft — and was snagged by a flash of waxy green leaves and umbels of tiny magenta flowers. The plant was a Kalanchoe blossfeldiana, a blooming succulent that flowers in the winter months. “But I am here to buy coffee and Clorox wipes,” I told myself, as “My Misspent Youth” (1999), that Meghan Daum essay about going broke while buying fresh-cut flowers every week, flashed in my mind. And yet, at this sad moment, these bright cheerful blossoms hit me in the gut, stirring up a tangle of emotions: joy, hope, yearning for a time when I would have bought them without worrying they were frivolous, sadness for all the florists and vendors whose businesses are now shuttered. Suddenly I had to have them. The plant felt like a signifier of my past self, and a talisman against palpable, creeping despair. The purchase seemed almost utilitarian.

headline: How Should You Stock Your Medicine Cabinet?
abstract: We asked pharmacists and doctors what they would want in the house for their own families. Here’s what they suggested.
lead_paragraph: Right now, there is no cure for the coronavirus. And although doctors and researchers are making progress on different ways to treat the illness, much remains uncertain.

headline: Love Letter: What Are the Rules of a Pandemic Breakup?
abstract: Plus: A love beyond borders.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: He Got Off the Table After Cancer Surgery to Take On the Virus
abstract: Gov. Philip Murphy of New Jersey is skipping a restful recovery to lead the state in the crisis, even as he remains in Andrew Cuomo’s shadow.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey arrives for his daily media briefings by himself. Clad in a mask, he keeps space between those who walk in before him and sits well beyond the six feet recommended for social distancing.

headline: Pressured by China, E.U. Softens Report on Covid-19 Disinformation
abstract: A revised report shows how Beijing reacts swiftly and effectively to tamp down Western criticism of its pandemic response.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Bowing to heavy pressure from Beijing, European Union officials softened their criticism of China this week in a report documenting how governments push disinformation about the coronavirus pandemic, according to documents, emails and interviews.

headline: VOD, Streaming or Virtual Cinema? Your Guide to Digital Movie Options
abstract: With theaters shut, online outlets have proliferated. Here’s how to make sense of all your choices. (Hint: it depends on the kind of film you’re looking for.)
lead_paragraph: With most movie theaters closed for the foreseeable future, new releases have migrated to virtual cinemas or to video on demand. If you thought choosing a film at the multiplex was difficult, finding that same new movie in the current hodgepodge is potentially paralyzing. Distributors are only releasing a handful of titles, and the kind of film you’re interested in — mainstream, art house, revival — affects where you ought to look.

headline: Don’t Inject Disinfectants!
abstract: A doctor warns against President Trump’s suggestion that disinfectant use inside the body might be a treatment for coronavirus. Also: Portrait of a president; Mitch McConnell on bailout partisanship.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hubble Marks 30 Years of Seeing a Universe Being Born and Dying
abstract: A new image reminds us of what the orbiting observatory has let us see.
lead_paragraph: “He not busy being born is busy dying.” So said Bob Dylan in “It’s Alright Ma (I’m Only Bleeding).”

headline: Coronavirus Interrupts, but Doesn’t End, an Arctic Research Expedition
abstract: The Polarstern, a science ship, will have to temporarily break out of polar ice because supply flights are no longer possible.
lead_paragraph: With a scheduled mission to resupply a research icebreaker in the remote frozen Arctic scuttled by the coronavirus pandemic, organizers have devised a new plan to continue the yearlong expedition studying climate change in the region.

headline: Zoom’s Biggest Rivals Are Coming for It
abstract: Facebook, Google and other behemoths are training their sights on Silicon Valley’s company of the moment.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As people turned in droves to the video chatting app Zoom in recent weeks, the buzz caught Facebook’s attention. Inside the social network, that immediately set off a scramble.

headline: Navy Leaders Recommend Reinstating Roosevelt Captain Fired Over Virus Warning
abstract: Capt. Brett E. Crozier, who was removed from command after sending a letter pleading for help to fight the coronavirus on his aircraft carrier, was largely cleared after Navy review.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Capt. Brett E. Crozier should be restored to command of the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, the Navy’s top officials recommended on Friday.

headline: Denuded of Tourists, Paris Reveals Its Old Beating Heart
abstract: With the mobs of visitors gone, the city once again belongs to the Parisians. And, of course, to “les microbes.”
lead_paragraph: Adam Nossiter, The Times’s Paris bureau chief, first moved to the city at the age of 3 when his father, Bernard Nossiter, was assigned to cover the European economy for The Washington Post. He moved back in 1983, in 1999, and then in 2015, when The Times posted him there. We asked him to share his thoughts on a Paris transformed by the pandemic.

headline: Newcastle, Saudi Arabia and the Power of Words
abstract: All too often, sports blurs the frivolous and the significant. Why should there be a higher moral burden on fans to draw bright lines?
lead_paragraph: Enjoying this newsletter every Friday? Send it to a friend and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: The Lockdown Isn’t So Simple for Conservatives
abstract: An extended shutdown is not without enormous consequence.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus sweeps the globe, and as the number of cases nationwide approaches the one million mark, most American towns and cities are under shelter-in-place orders, while a few states remain largely open for business or announce plans to lift restrictions. Discontent with stay-at-home rules has begun bubbling up, leading to large protests in Michigan and beyond, as states and the federal government attempt a delicate balancing act between blunting the virus’s spread and avoiding economic collapse.

headline: Henry Geller, Who Helped Rid TV of Cigarette Ads, Dies at 96
abstract: While at the F.C.C., he used the fairness doctrine to challenge the tobacco industry. He also helped pave the way for televised presidential debates.
lead_paragraph: John F. Banzhaf III was watching football on television with his family in the Bronx on Thanksgiving 1966 when he realized that the most strategic plays were being made off the field — in the cigarette commercials whose jingles, gags, slogans and images of virile cowboys and urbane women glamorized smoking.

headline: Amazon Loses Appeal of French Order to Stop Selling Nonessential Items
abstract: The ruling is another court victory by French unions against Amazon in a battle over workplace safety.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Amazon lost an appeal on Friday of a French court decision ordering the e-commerce giant to stop delivering nonessential items in France during the coronavirus crisis to protect workers, raising questions about the immediate future of its business in the country.

headline: Durham Inquiry Includes Scrutiny of a Media Leak
abstract: The attorney general has suggested that the Justice Department review of the Russia investigation has uncovered “troubling” findings without going into details.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, President Trump has complained bitterly about F.B.I. officials who investigated his campaign’s ties to Russia, and about the “rogue bureaucrats of the Deep State” at the intelligence agencies, portraying them as enemies out to delegitimize his presidency.

headline: Want Relationship Advice From Esther Perel?
abstract: Submit a question about your personal relationships during the pandemic, and the therapist and author may answer it in a future episode of “The Daily” podcast.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic continues to reshape our lives and our routines, many of us are facing unexpected challenges in our personal relationships. If you have a question you’d like to ask a therapist right now about a relationship in your life, we want to hear from you.

headline: How They Keep the Flavored Water and Veggie Burgers Coming
abstract: Larry Praeger of Dr. Praeger’s Purely Sensible Foods and Kara Goldin of Hint Water have each had to navigate challenges for their companies during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Grocery stores have bare shelves. Consumers are hoarding. Supply chains are disrupted. As the coronavirus upends the business world, few sectors have been more affected than food and beverage manufacturing. Small and medium-size companies were particularly vulnerable, yet some have managed to thrive.

headline: What Georgia Residents Are Saying About Easing Coronavirus Measures
abstract: Some businesses in Georgia reopened on Friday, a decision that is being watched closely and one that has divided the state’s residents.
lead_paragraph: Some businesses in Georgia reopened on Friday, a decision that is being watched closely and one that has divided the state’s residents.

headline: A One-Time Rebel of Colombia’s War Seeks Her Place in Peacetime
abstract: María Alexandra Marín says she joined the leftist FARC guerrillas at age 15 to escape machismo. Adjusting to civilian life has not been easy.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — María Alexandra Marín lives with her cat Marx and two dogs in a small apartment in a working-class neighborhood in Colombia’s capital, Bogotá. She has an enviable view of the Andes, a breeze in the evening and a patio from which she photographs the moon. She recently adopted a new kitten.

headline: Despotism and Democracy in the Age of the Virus
abstract: The battle for humanity and solidarity in the post-American world.
lead_paragraph: The first major crisis of the post-American world is ugly and is going to get worse. A pandemic required a pan-planet reaction. Instead it found Pangloss in the White House blowing smoke and insisting, as disaster loomed, that it was still the best of all possible worlds in America.

headline: These Women Were Told Their Help Wasn’t Needed. They Didn’t Listen.
abstract: A women’s group in Shanghai started donation drives to get health care workers with crucial personal hygiene supplies. But wary hospitals, hard-to-get road passes and online backlash made the process difficult.
lead_paragraph: — Sakura Chan, founder of the nonprofit GirlsUp

headline: ‘Playing Russian Roulette’: Nursing Homes Told to Take the Infected
abstract: California, New Jersey and New York have made nursing homes accept Covid-19 patients from hospitals. Residents and workers fear the policy is risking lives.
lead_paragraph: Neal Nibur has lived in a nursing home for about a year, ever since he had a bad bout of pneumonia. Now, the 80-year-old man has not only his own health to worry about but that of his neighbors at the Poughkeepsie, N.Y., residence. Four new patients recently arrived from the hospital with Covid-19.

headline: Please Do Not Eat Disinfectant
abstract: There is no evidence that sunlight, bleach or any disinfectant can cure coronavirus in the body.
lead_paragraph: There is no evidence that sunlight can cure coronavirus on the human body. Same for disinfectant and bleach. So, do not drink bleach. Do not inject disinfectant. And do not believe there is some cure for coronavirus coming from ultraviolet light.

headline: You Don’t Need a Mixer (Just a Whisk!) for This One-Bowl Shortbread
abstract: Melted butter makes this the easiest-ever version of the recipe.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent a lot of time baking over these many socially distant weeks, but only very rarely pulled out the electric mixer or food processor. Somehow, the simplicity and intimacy of whisking everything by hand has been extremely satisfying.

headline: The Shocks and Aftershocks of the Great Alaska Quake of 1964
abstract: Jon Mooallem talks about “This Is Chance!” and Elisabeth Egan discusses Charlie Mackesy’s “The Boy, the Mole, the Fox and the Horse.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: A Funeral, Reinvented for the Pandemic
abstract: We set out to tell the story of how grieving is changing in this moment.
lead_paragraph: Many reporters at The Times have specialties beyond their official assignments. Catherine Porter’s is death.

headline: Live Alone? We Want to Hear From You
abstract: Now that millions of people are isolated at home, Modern Love is seeking personal stories of lives transformed by sudden solitude.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: We are no longer accepting submissions.

headline: Biden Steps Up Warnings of Possible Trump Disruption of Election
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has increasingly speculated that President Trump may try to delay or disrupt the election in some way, sending a warning signal that attempts to frame the president as desperate.
lead_paragraph: For months, Joseph R. Biden Jr. has argued that under pressure and political duress, President Trump may pursue increasingly extreme measures to stay in power.

headline: Mario César Romero, 78, Art Historian of East Harlem, Dies
abstract: He celebrated the neighborhood’s artists, including Alice Neel and James de la Vega.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Kenneth Saunders III, Civic Leader with a Mediating Touch, Dies at 43
abstract: He joined his first local board at 18 and never stopped trying to improve his suburban Atlanta community. Mr. Saunders died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: The Hong Kong Government’s View
abstract: The government’s commissioner in the United States says the arrests of people “in unauthorized assemblies” have nothing to do with the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Islamic Center Damaged in ‘Suspicious’ Fire at Start of Ramadan
abstract: The police said the fire, at the Islamic Center of Cape Girardeau in Missouri, was being investigated as possible arson.
lead_paragraph: The authorities said they were investigating a fire that significantly damaged an Islamic center in Missouri on Friday, the first day of fasting in the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, as possible arson.

headline: Edward James Olmos on Hollywood’s View of Latino Actors
abstract: Whether in his new movie “Windows on the World” or his work with children, the actor aims to give voice to the marginalized, something he thinks the film world should consider.
lead_paragraph: In the new drama “Windows on the World,” Edward James Olmos plays an undocumented busboy working at the restaurant that was destroyed on 9/11. The moving immigration story, which debuted for free this week on the Latino-focused streaming site Vix, is just the latest turn in a storied career that includes an Oscar nomination for Olmos’s work in “Stand and Deliver” (1988), making him one of the few American-born Latino actors ever to be nominated for an Academy Award.

headline: N.F.L. Drafts Players, but Will They Play in the Fall?
abstract: “We’ll go anywhere the science takes us and nowhere the science doesn’t,” said the medical director of the players’ union.
lead_paragraph: There he was in his basement, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell, like a mirage in a sports-starved desert, to announce that the first pick of the 2020 league draft would be Louisiana State quarterback Joe Burrow, joining the Cincinnati Bengals. It was one of a handful of events to have summoned sports fans en masse since the coronavirus pandemic shut down the United States.

headline: F.D.A. Warns of Heart Problems From Malaria Drugs Used for Coronavirus
abstract: The drugs, hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine, have been repeatedly promoted by President Trump. But they should be used only in clinical trials or hospitals, the agency said.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration issued a safety warning on Friday about hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine, malaria drugs that have been promoted by President Trump repeatedly and widely used to treat coronavirus patients despite the lack of evidence that they work.

headline: France Covid Map and Case Count
abstract: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
lead_paragraph: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.

headline: U.F.C. Says Its Fights Are Back On, Next Month in Florida
abstract: The mixed martial arts organization, which had to cancel plans to stage fights in California, said it would hold at least three events in May.
lead_paragraph: The Ultimate Fighting Championship plans to hold at least three events in Florida in May with the blessing of state regulators and elected officials. They would be the mixed martial arts organization’s first fights since the widespread shutdown of sports because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Hawaii to Visitors: We’ll Pay You to Leave
abstract: Visitors who break Hawaii’s 14-day quarantine rule may get an unwelcome gift: A free flight home.
lead_paragraph: In Hawaii, the spirit of aloha normally greets visitors with warmth and welcome. Now, while the state has discouraged visitors by requiring them to self-quarantine for 14 days, that culture of generosity might extend to a free return ticket home.

headline: As Ramadan Begins, Muslims (Mostly) Accede to Pandemic Orders
abstract: Islam’s most sacred sites were largely deserted as the holy month started, but Muslims in some places were resisting in ways that could spread the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — It was a rare moment in the 1,400-year history of Islam, and another sobering milestone in the march of the coronavirus.

headline: Philip Kahn, 100, Dies; Spanish Flu Took His Twin a Century Ago
abstract: Aware of the irony of dying during a pandemic, he said history repeats itself. A family member called the brothers “pandemic bookends.”
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Georgia, Coronavirus, Spelling Bee: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Don’t Try This at Home’: Even ‘Fox & Friends’ Balked at Trump’s Advice
abstract: Fox News anchors conceded that injecting disinfectant would be “poisonous.” But Rush Limbaugh and Breitbart defended Trump.
lead_paragraph: Even Steve Doocy had to admit it wasn’t a great idea.

headline: A Bit of Relief: I Forgive You, New York
abstract: A columnist for The Times shares his ode to the city: I was in a hurry. I was forgetful. Please forgive me as I forgive you.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Nova Scotia Mourns In an Uneasy Time
abstract: The most deadly mass shooting in Canada’s history came in the midst of a public health crisis that the nation has never seen before.
lead_paragraph: For Canada and particularly Nova Scotia, it was a terrible week in the midst of an uneasy time. A village that was once best known for a dance hall became a scene of horror and the starting point for the most deadly mass shooting in the country’s history: 22 victims plus the killer.

headline: Failing to Help Those Who Need It Most
abstract: The distribution of coronavirus bailout funds requires more attention.
lead_paragraph: As the federal government hastens to distribute trillions of dollars to soften the economic pain of the coronavirus pandemic, a troubling pattern is increasingly clear: Money is not reaching many of those Americans who are in greatest need.

headline: Congress Shovels Trillions at Virus, With No Endgame in Sight
abstract: As lawmakers scramble to assemble the largest government relief effort in decades, they are locked in a cycle of reacting to events and hoping for better economic news.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is a growing list of detailed plans for how the federal government can bring the United States economy safely out of lockdown and back on a path to normalcy amid the coronavirus pandemic. Congress is not following any of them.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Don’t ingest bleach.
lead_paragraph: Public health officials and private companies have been frantically trying to tell the public not to ingest or inject disinfectants after President Trump, during his daily news conference on Thursday, suggested that an “injection inside” the human body with a disinfectant such as bleach or isopropyl alcohol could help combat the virus.

headline: This Focaccia Isn’t Your Garden-Variety Flatbread
abstract: For some, sourdough is the baking king of social media. For others, there are these beautifully decorated focaccia, dotted with vegetables.
lead_paragraph: In kitchens across the world, focaccia gardens are blooming. On top of the flatbreads, cherry tomatoes open like petals, with long scallion stalks for stems. Yellow-pepper sunflowers stand tall with Kalamata olives at their center. Red onions bud in bushes made from fresh herbs.

headline: Coronavirus Antibody Tests: Can You Trust the Results?
abstract: A team of scientists worked around the clock to evaluate 14 antibody tests. A few worked as advertised. Most did not.
lead_paragraph: The researchers worked around the clock, in shifts of three to five hours, hoping to stave off weariness and keep their minds sharp for the delicate task.

headline: California Lifts Ban on Plastic Bags Amid Virus Concerns
abstract: For the next 60 days, supermarkets in the state can hand out single-use bags without charging. Some are skeptical that suspending the ban will protect anyone’s health.
lead_paragraph: Retailers in California can once again hand out free single-use plastic bags under an executive order announced on Thursday by Gov. Gavin Newsom, the latest turn away from reusable bags amid the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Trump’s Temporary Halt to Immigration Is Part of Broader Plan, Stephen Miller Says
abstract: “The first and most important thing is to turn off the faucet of new immigrant labor — mission accomplished,’’ Mr. Miller told conservatives allies, according to an audio recording.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to suspend family-based immigration because of the coronavirus is the beginning of a broader strategy to reduce the flow of foreigners into the United States, Stephen Miller, the architect of President Trump’s immigration agenda, told a group of conservative allies on Thursday.

headline: Businesses Tiptoe Into a World of Masks, Gloves and Wary Customers
abstract: Some states have taken tentative steps toward reopening businesses shuttered by the coronavirus. In Georgia, it meant a few residents were out getting haircuts and their tongues pierced.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Weeks after a deadly virus reordered daily life in America, shuttering most businesses and forcing most people indoors, three states on Friday took tentative steps toward something resembling normalcy. But across Georgia, Alaska and Oklahoma, it was anything but business as usual.

headline: Gene Deitch, Prolific Animator, Is Dead at 95
abstract: In a six-decade career, he created Tom Terrific, revived Tom and Jerry and won an Academy Award for a cartoon based on a Jules Feiffer story.
lead_paragraph: Gene Deitch, an Oscar-winning animator who created the early television cartoon “Tom Terrific” and went on to make countless cartoons and film versions of popular children’s books for more than a half-century, died on April 16 in Prague, where he lived. He was 95.

headline: America Shouldn’t Have to Play by New York Rules
abstract: A national lockdown is bad medicine and worse politics.
lead_paragraph: In 1976, the artist Saul Steinberg drew a cover for The New Yorker — “View of the World from Ninth Avenue” — that became an instant classic. You know the one: Manhattan heavily in the foreground, the Hudson River, a brownish strip called “Jersey,” the rest of the America vaguely in the distance.

headline: See Coronavirus Restrictions and Mask Mandates for All 50 States
abstract: Many states are considering fresh restrictions on business and in some cases urging residents to stay home to stop the spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Many states are considering fresh restrictions on business and in some cases urging residents to stay home to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: What One Might Be Represented By
abstract: Andrew J. Ries drops a puzzle full of double takes.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a unique grid from Andrew J. Ries, a weekend regular, and it makes a very interesting contrast to last Saturday’s Ryan McCarty puzzle. They both have vertical center “staircases,” but where last weekend we had to solve four very separate quadrants, which made things challenging, today the stairs, combined with some strategic span entries, serve to connect the entire grid very intricately. That certainly doesn’t make today’s solve any easier! It’s a toughie, and ridiculously entertaining.

headline: Health Officials Responding to Coronavirus Lacked Proper Gear and Training, Investigation Finds
abstract: Lawyers at the Department of Health and Human Services reported that protocols “temporarily broke down” when employees were working with people in quarantine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal health employees without adequate protective gear or training interacted with Americans quarantined at a military installation in California for possible exposure to the coronavirus, the top lawyer at the Department of Health and Human Services concluded on Friday.

headline: Corrections: April 25, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 25, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about how President Trump is spending his time in the White House misstated which position with the Federal Reserve that Mr. Trump had proposed for his outside economic adviser Stephen Moore. The president had chosen him to serve on the Federal Reserve Board, not to serve as its chairman.

headline: Americans Stranded Abroad Weigh Options; Spain Announces Easing of Restrictions
abstract: Belarus, led by a virus-denying autocrat, has imposed no lockdowns. Brazil’s leader, who has played down the virus, faces an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans who had assumed they could stay overseas till the pandemic ebbed now face an unnerving choice: either prepare for the possibility of being infected and treated in foreign hospitals, or risk infection on the way back to the United States.

headline: Michael Cogswell, 66, Dies; Sustained Louis Armstrong’s Legacy
abstract: He turned the jazz giant’s trove of memorabilia into a scholarly archive and created a popular museum at Armstrong’s house in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cogswell, who turned Louis Armstrong’s trove of memorabilia into a scholarly archive and transformed the joyful trumpeter’s two-bedroom brick house in Queens into a popular museum, died on April 20 in Manhattan. He was 66.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Bad Education’ and ‘Hustlers’
abstract: Real-life scandals are dramatized in HBO’s “Bad Education” and the Jennifer Lopez crime drama “Hustlers.”
lead_paragraph: BAD EDUCATION (2020) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. Hugh Jackman and Allison Janney star in this dark comedy-drama, a cross between “Election” and “The Wolf of Wall Street.” The movie, directed by Cory Finley (“Thoroughbreds”), reimagines a multi-million-dollar embezzlement scandal that rocked a high school on Long Island in 2004. The mastermind behind the scheme is Frank Tassone (Jackman), the superintendent of the school district, who wins over parents and students alike with his good-natured charm. His machination lasts years, and it slowly starts to crumble only after he encourages a student journalist (Geraldine Viswanathan) to dig deeper into a puff piece she’s working on. (Big mistake.) In his review for The New York Times, Ben Kenigsberg wrote that Jackman steals the show. His role is “a plum part” and “a chance for the actor to channel his charisma toward dark, mischievous ends.”

headline: March, April, May: City’s Mood Darkens as Crisis Feels Endless
abstract: With no clues about when the pandemic might subside, short-term discomfort is becoming long-term despair: “I feel like I have accepted this, and given up.”
lead_paragraph: A walk in the park brings tense flare-ups: Back off, you’re too close. Oh really? Then stay home. A loud neighbor, once a fleeting annoyance of urban life, is cause for complaint to the city. Wake at noon, still tired. The city’s can-do resilience has given way to resignation and random tears.

headline: Jailed Huawei Workers Raised a Forbidden Subject: Iran
abstract: China arrested five former employees who had discussed the tech giant’s Iranian sales in a chat group, raising questions about its government ties.
lead_paragraph: The five men were all locked in disputes with their onetime employer, the Chinese technology giant Huawei. And they had all joined a group on the social app WeChat to organize.

headline: A Free Wedding in the Nick of Time
abstract: Maggie Moore and Brandon Baez married at Glencliff Manor, which offered to help couples whose weddings were upended because of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Moore and Brandon Baez may be young, but waiting to get married until the world got a handle on the coronavirus was not in their plans.

headline: The Role of Restaurant Critics in an Uncertain Time
abstract: Sam Sifton, the food editor at The New York Times, spoke with the writers Pete Wells, Tejal Rao and Besha Rodell about how their jobs have changed.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Scene 1: City Hall. Scene 2: Rooftop Overlooking City.
abstract: Amanda Jane Cooper and Andrew Bell met at church, and then married in New York when the coronavirus seemed likely to foil their wedding plans.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Jane Cooper was new to New York when she first attended the Church of the City New York, to which a friend had referred her. She is an actor and was in the starring role of Glinda in “Wicked” at the time.

headline: Making Marines Without Making Them Sick
abstract: After a brief pause, Parris Island is once again taking Marine recruits, with some modifications to the grueling 13-week boot camp.
lead_paragraph: Like countless parents before her, LaTasha Webber worried about her 17-year-old after she signed an age waiver allowing him to enlist in the U.S. Marine Corps. Her son, Charlie Jennings, left for boot camp at Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island in South Carolina on Feb. 24, following in the footsteps of his father, who was also a Marine.

headline: Why Cocktail Hour Is Back
abstract: We need the ritual; we have the time. And during lockdown, it’s 5 o’clock everywhere.
lead_paragraph: “Is it too early to drink?”

headline: How to Livestream Your Wedding
abstract: Thanks to video-streaming apps and services, couples who choose to get married while self-isolating can share their special moments with family and friends.
lead_paragraph: While social distancing and restrictions on travel and large gatherings have forced many couples to postpone their wedding celebrations, some are still choosing to marry and are inviting guests to witness their union from the comfort of their own homes via live video streams.

headline: The Paramedics Couldn’t Find Lysol. They Turned to Their Congressman.
abstract: “They don’t know who else to come to.” Members of Congress have overhauled their offices to answer increasingly desperate calls from constituents in search of a lifeline and unsure of who can help.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The messages clog their offices’ phone lines and inboxes by the thousands, each a snapshot of someone’s lived nightmare — the wife whose husband is on a ventilator and getting worse by the day, the small-business owner who desperately needs a loan, the paramedic who wants disinfectant to clean his ambulance between shuttling the ill to the hospital.

headline: The N.F.L. Draft Adds More Stars to the Cool Kids’ Conference
abstract: The N.F.L. is a quarterback’s league and one conference has the edge in exciting young stars.
lead_paragraph: The A.F.C. was already where the fresh-faced cool kids hung out: Patrick Mahomes, Lamar Jackson, Deshaun Watson.

headline: How to Ask a College for More Financial Aid
abstract: It’s an admissions season unlike any other, with uncertainty for students and their families — and the colleges that want to get them in the door.
lead_paragraph: It is rarely easy to summon the will to ask for help, especially if you’re seeking more financial aid from what you believe to be your first-choice college.

headline: You Missed a Spot: How Not to Groom Your Dog During Lockdown
abstract: Clipping your dog’s coat is not exactly a fetch in the park.
lead_paragraph: As someone who often walks his dog — in this case an energetic white miniature schnauzer named Gogo — I occasionally find myself in a familiar conversation with other dog owners: where and how to groom the dog. Asking “where” implies that we go to a groomer to get the job done — but I don’t. Thus we proceed to how.

headline: Economic Freeze Cuts Remittances, a Lifeline for Migrants’ Families
abstract: Migrant workers globally send hundreds of billions of dollars home every year. The economic paralysis with the coronavirus pandemic threatens that.
lead_paragraph: ÁPORO, Mexico — The money would arrive like clockwork: $300 every couple of weeks, sent by her husband, a day laborer and undocumented immigrant living in Indianapolis.

headline: Reopening Has Begun. No One Is Sure What Happens Next.
abstract: The heated debate over when to restart the economy has obscured an issue that could prove just as thorny: How to do it.
lead_paragraph: The economy shut down almost overnight. It won’t start back up that way.

headline: Tux, Gown, Masks: Arab Couples Scramble to Marry During a Pandemic
abstract: Undeterred by the coronavirus, couples across the Middle East are pressing ahead with scaled-back weddings. The authorities aren’t always thrilled.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Carfuls of hooting men careened through the half-empty streets of Cairo, then skidded to a halt on Qasr el Nil, the most famous bridge over the Nile. A newly married couple leapt out, trailed by festive relatives, hoping for a coveted photo at an iconic beauty spot.

headline: Nervous Republicans See Trump Sinking, and Taking Senate With Him
abstract: The election is still six months away, but a rash of ominous new polls and the president’s erratic briefings have the G.O.P. worried about a Democratic takeover.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s erratic handling of the coronavirus outbreak, the worsening economy and a cascade of ominous public and private polling have Republicans increasingly nervous that they are at risk of losing the presidency and the Senate if Mr. Trump does not put the nation on a radically improved course.

headline: A Candidate in Isolation: Inside Joe Biden’s Cloistered Campaign
abstract: Walled off from voters in a distinctive kind of lockdown, Mr. Biden has developed a routine, of sorts, as he seeks the presidency from his basement.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. usually rises before 8 a.m. at his home in Wilmington, Del., and starts his day with a workout in an upstairs gym that contains a Peloton bike, weights and a treadmill. He often enjoys a protein shake for breakfast and puts on a suit or blazer much of the time. In the evenings, he and his wife, Jill, sit down together for dinner, a ritual that was absent for much of the last frenzied year on the campaign trail.

headline: ‘My World Is Shattering’: Foreign Students Stranded by Coronavirus
abstract: When the pandemic shuttered colleges, many international students had no idea where to live or whether they would ever be able to return to class.
lead_paragraph: When universities abruptly shut down last month because of the coronavirus pandemic, many students returned to their parents’ homes, distraught over having to give up their social lives and vital on-campus networking opportunities. Graduating seniors lost the chance to cross anything but a virtual commencement stage.

headline: Bored Russians Posted Silly Art Parodies. The World Has Joined In.
abstract: Frozen dumplings as skulls and A/C ducts as fashion accessories. A Facebook group for art re-enactors has gained 540,000 followers across the locked-down globe.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Under lockdown, the banal melds with the sublime.

headline: 12 Rangers Among 17 Killed in Congo Park Ambush
abstract: The attack at Virunga National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage site in eastern Congo, was among the deadliest in its recent history.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Twelve rangers were among 17 people killed in Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said, in one of the worst massacres in the park’s recent history. The park blamed members of a Rwandan rebel group for the attack.

headline: Family Over Flowers
abstract: Sarah Fagan and Ohmar Bogle opted for a scaled-down event at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Fagan’s marriage to Ohmar Bogle on April 18 at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan went on as planned, though the coronavirus forced their wedding to become “a very, very, very, very scaled-down event,” said the groom, who was among a group of nine people at the church.

headline: A Man and Woman of Letters (Many of Them)
abstract: Logan Sachon and Matthew Davis met in 2008 while working together, but they didn’t become friends — correspondents, really — until years later. Love came later still.
lead_paragraph: Logan Sachon and Matthew Davis initially met in 2008, when she became an intern at an alternative weekly publication in Oregon; he was the news editor. They knew each other only casually.

headline: Rave Reviews at the Salon
abstract: Ellyna Larson and Kristi Bogart met at Ms. Bogart’s hair salon, after both had heard many good things about the other.
