lead_paragraph: Ellyna Larson, a Federal agent with Homeland Security, walked through the front door of Eli’s Roots Hair Studio in Manassas, Va., in search of its owner, Kristi Bogart, a person of interest.

headline: German Trial Accuses Iraqi of Genocide in Killing of Yazidi Girl
abstract: The Frankfurt trial of the 27-year-old man accused of being an ISIS member is believed to be the first that carries the charge of genocide in relation to the Yazidis.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — An Iraqi man accused of being an Islamic State terrorist has gone on trial in a high court in Frankfurt accused of genocide, human trafficking, and the torture and murder of a 5-year-old Yazidi girl he had held as a slave in Falluja, Iraq.

headline: Air France-KLM Gets €10 Billion Bailout as Coronavirus Hits Travel
abstract: It is the third multibillion-euro lifeline extended this past week by the French government to companies battered by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France and the Netherlands will provide an unprecedented taxpayer-funded bailout of 10 billion euros, about $10.8 billion, to salvage Air France-KLM as the fallout of the coronavirus on the travel industry exacts a devastating toll on global air carriers.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Fraying Nerves Dishearten City As Crisis Drags
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 25, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “This is the week where I feel like I have accepted this, and given up. My daily commute to the couch feels ‘normal.’”

headline: Trump Suggests Daily Briefings No Longer Worth His Time as White House Considers Replacing Health Secretary
abstract: States move to reopen as the U.S. nears a sobering 50,000 deaths from the virus. U.S. scientists join the World Health Organization in calling for better antibody tests.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: Cuomo Announces Expanded Virus Testing in New York
abstract: In addition to allowing all pharmacies in the state to administer tests, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced new antibody testing for front-line health care workers at four New York City hospitals.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers anxious to learn if they have the coronavirus will soon be able to get tested at any local pharmacy, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced Saturday.

headline: Will a Pandemic Shatter the Perception of American Exceptionalism?
abstract: Politicians extol it. Scholars debate it. The past decade has battered it. Will the coronavirus crisis finish off this country’s golden view of itself?
lead_paragraph: “It can’t happen here” is an enduring refrain in American culture, a reflection of the idea — whether invoked ironically or in earnest — that the United States has a special destiny, and stands apart from the forces shaping the rest of the world.

headline: Boris Johnson Aide Attended Secretive U.K. Coronavirus Panel
abstract: Dominic Cummings, a major Brexit strategist, took part in Britain’s top scientific advisory group, but only to listen and offer help, the government said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government came under heightened pressure to disclose details about a secretive scientific advisory group after a report on Friday that a top political aide to Prime Minister Boris Johnson had taken part in the group’s meetings on the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Could a Merger of Men’s and Women’s Tennis Come Out of This Hiatus?
abstract: The idea of combined tours has been around since at least the 1970s. But with the sport shut down, Roger Federer made a suggestion that could lead to a complex and ego-bruising endeavor.
lead_paragraph: When Roger Federer, with time on his hands in the midst of tennis’s shutdown, floated the prospect this week of merging the men’s and women’s tours, Billie Jean King saw potential for her 50-year dream to come true.

headline: Revelry on the Rooftops
abstract: Ashley Johnson and Eddie Zhang, both doctors, were married atop their apartment building in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The drone heard on the rooftop of the Philadelphia apartment building where Dr. Ashley Johnson and Dr. Eddie Zhang live was not the kind created by the couple bemoaning their circumstances in the presence of the coronavirus.

headline: Saudi Arabia Abolishes Flogging as a Punishment for Crime
abstract: The most high-profile flogging in recent years was of the Saudi blogger Raif Badawi, who was sentenced to 10 years in prison and 1,000 lashes on charges of insulting Islam.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For decades, if someone in Saudi Arabia got drunk in public or wrote an article that provoked the kingdom’s ultraconservative judges, that person could have been flogged in a public square.

headline: In a Crowded City, Leaders Struggle to Separate the Sick From the Well
abstract: Chelsea, Mass., has an infection rate higher than any other community in the state. With families in cramped housing, it is difficult to contain the spread.
lead_paragraph: CHELSEA, Mass. — Paul Nowicki, the director of operations for the housing authority in this small, crowded immigrant city, walked the halls of the Buckley Apartments last week in a plastic face shield and white gown, trying to stop an invisible predator.

headline: Is It Unethical to Ask My Roommate to Move Out Right Now?
abstract: It’s a tough time to be stuck with a roommate you don’t get along with.
lead_paragraph: Q: As my roommate and I follow New York’s stay-at-home orders, it’s painfully clear that I can no longer live with her. I’ve been looking at other apartments for a few weeks, and would like to move out as soon possible. I want to ask her to find her own place. Since I’m the sole leaseholder and we’re on a month-to-month rental agreement, this shouldn’t be a legal problem — but is it an ethical one? Is it fair to ask her to move out in the middle of this unusual situation?

headline: Post Malone Covering Nirvana for Virus Relief? Bring on the ‘Bleach’
abstract: The woozy-singing pop superstar performed a faithful set of covers to raise money for the W.H.O.’s Covid-19 Solidarity Response Fund, and won over the band’s bassist, Krist Novoselic.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, in a brief, vague video teaser, the immensely popular rap-adjacent superstar Post Malone announced that something called the “Post Malone Nirvana Tribute Livestream” would be happening on his YouTube channel on Friday evening.

headline: Sheet-Pan Chicken With Jammy Tomatoes Forever
abstract: Pasta with garlicky spinach, curry chicken breasts and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Melissa Clark’s sheet-pan chicken with jammy tomatoes and pancetta (above); pasta with garlicky spinach and buttered pistachios; and roasted tomato and white bean stew. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Who Belongs In America?
abstract: For many, the recent harassment of Asian-Americans has been a stunning reminder that your face can still mark you as foreign.
lead_paragraph: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more provocative stories on race from The Times, sign up here for our weekly Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: ‘There Are No Viruses Here’: Leader of Belarus Scoffs at Lockdowns
abstract: Under the autocratic rule of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, Belarus has yet to impose any restrictions to slow the virus. No, everything is not fine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As he headed off the ice after playing a hockey game in an amateur tournament in late March, the leader of Belarus brushed aside reporters’ anxious questions about the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Bertha Laforest, Canadian Nun Who Found Refuge in Her Convent, Dies At 94
abstract: Sister Laforest was one of at least 36 of the 47 nuns in her Quebec convent to become infected with the coronavirus. Three others have died.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon bring us another flabbergasting, incredible, gasp-worthy, amazing acrostic.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Superficially, today’s puzzle is fabulous, of course, but easy to put on the same shelf as the other enlightening and entertaining acrostics we’re used to getting from Team Cox/Rathvon. There's something special about the passage’s author today, Arthur Schulman. He was an old-school constructor! A prolific one at that, with a six-decade run of contributions to The Times. (I must give a heartfelt shout-out to Jeff Chen and David Steinberg here, as without their efforts this kind of information would simply be too hard for me to gather).

headline: For Many Immigrants, an Even Greater Risk
abstract: I’m among the New Yorkers adjusting to working from home during the pandemic. But I’m the exception in my family.
lead_paragraph: I call my mother every afternoon to check in on her. She lives in a three-story Section 8 building in East New York, Brooklyn, in the apartment my siblings and I grew up in. Three of her neighbors died from Covid-19 in the last two weeks, and more than half of the families in her 12-unit building are sick. Through the walls she could hear the wails of the family who lost a loved one to the virus next door: “Don’t go! Please don’t leave us!” Another neighbor on the second floor, a middle-aged Ecuadorean man who lived with his elderly mother, died the day before Easter. The worst part, she said, is not being able to pay her respects in person, to say goodbye to the neighbors that over the years have become her family. I feel my stomach turn with guilt.

headline: The Curious Incident of No Dog in the White House
abstract: What if Donald Trump had become the owner of a goldendoodle?
lead_paragraph: It was Orson Welles’s idea, the Fala Speech.

headline: China Has a Post-Pandemic Dream for Hong Kong
abstract: Anticipating a hostile world, Beijing feels that it needs to control the city absolutely.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus epidemic may have momentarily dampened the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, but not the repression. The Chinese authorities in Beijing, after threatening to impose “complete-control governance” (全面管治) over the city in recent years, have in the course of a week taken several major steps toward that goal.

headline: Coronavirus and the Price of Trump’s Delusions
abstract: A cult of personality is no match for a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In an interview with The Washington Post on Tuesday, Dr. Robert Redfield, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, warned that a second wave of coronavirus infections this coming winter “will actually be even more difficult than the one we just went through,” because it will coincide with flu season. He also called the protests against stay-at-home orders “not helpful.”

headline: Gear to Bring the Outdoors Inside
abstract: Here are five items that Wirecutter editors use to remind themselves of the outdoors while they are cooped up at home.
lead_paragraph: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.

headline: Prescriptions Surged as Trump Praised Drugs in Coronavirus Fight
abstract: Prescriptions for two antimalarial drugs jumped by 46 times the average when the president promoted them on TV. There’s no proof they work against Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: It was at a midday briefing last month that President Trump first used the White House telecast to promote two antimalarial drugs in the fight against the coronavirus.

headline: Building a Better, Fairer Nation
abstract: Readers discuss issues of inequality raised by the “The America We Need” series of articles.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Testing Remains Scarce as Governors Weigh Reopening States
abstract: In both red and blue states, governors, health departments and hospitals are finding innovative ways to cope, but still lack what experts say they need to track and contain outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About a week after the first report of a Covid-19 case at a meatpacking plant in southwest Kansas in early April, the state’s governor, Laura Kelly, issued a pointed warning to President Trump: Without test kits to separate the well from the sick, a fast-moving outbreak could idle facilities that produce roughly one-quarter of the nation’s meat supply.

headline: The Apple Family’s Checking In on Zoom. You’re Invited, Too.
abstract: Richard Nelson’s new play, “What Do We Need to Talk About?” will be performed online, but live, restoring some of theater’s ephemerality.
lead_paragraph: Has anyone checked on the Apples? Do they have enough groceries? Are they working remotely? And what do they think about all those Manhattanites fleeing upstate?

headline: Tim Duncan to Springfield? Take It to the Bank
abstract: During his Hall of Fame career, Duncan was called the Big Fundamental largely because of his signature shots off the backboard, which were as mundane as they were effective.
lead_paragraph: On one of his recent podcast episodes, C.J. McCollum of the Portland Trail Blazers engaged in a discussion about the five most unstoppable moves in N.B.A. history. Allen Iverson’s crossover dribble, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar’s sky hook, Manu Ginobili’s Eurostep, Hakeem Olajuwon’s “Dream Shake” and, of course, Michael Jordan’s fadeaway jumper were all featured.

headline: Live Nation Closes Gap in Refund Policy After Fan Complaints
abstract: The company, which operates Ticketmaster, will now allow refunds for the thousands of concerts that have yet to be rescheduled.
lead_paragraph: Live Nation Entertainment, the biggest power in the concert industry, closed a gap in its ticket refund policy on Friday, after weeks of criticism that the company, and its Ticketmaster subsidiary, were not returning hundreds of millions of dollars that fans had spent on concerts postponed by the pandemic.

headline: A Ramadan Like No Other: Images From Around the World
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic is forcing Muslims to adapt, observing the holy month more at home than in the mosque, more online than in person, and with greater uncertainty about the future.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Sprawling banquets that convened crowds of relatives have shrunk to modest meals for immediate family. Imams who led prayers in packed mosques have been addressing the faithful over Zoom. And stay-at-home orders and social distancing guidelines have sapped the nighttime jubilance of cities with large Muslim populations, from Cairo to Jakarta to Dearborn, Mich.

headline: Americans Abroad Ask Whether to Stay, and Risk Infection, or Fly Home, and Risk Infection
abstract: As virus cases increase, Americans overseas wonder if it is better to take a commercial flight back to the United States — even if it means interacting with people who could infect them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The travel plan was as exhausting as it was risky for the 77-year-old cancer survivor wondering how to leave self-isolation in Ecuador and return home to New Hampshire without catching the coronavirus.

headline: When a Coronavirus Lockdown Resembles an LSD Trip
abstract: All it took was a Dylan song to bring back memories of a summer in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: It was Day 8 of quarantine for me and my family. My son had returned from his semester abroad in Europe, and so we were all hunkered down in our Brooklyn house, cooking, eating, working together and listening to music. Dean, 20, was mostly in charge of the soundtrack and had just put on Bob Dylan’s “Tonight I’ll Be Staying Here With You” on Spotify.

headline: An Obituary for an Extraordinary Ordinary Man
abstract: Cesar Quirumbay worked for some of America’s most prominent men. Very few blessed by his handiwork ever knew his name.
lead_paragraph: Cesar Quirumbay, who succumbed to Covid-19 on Monday morning at the age of 60, touched the lives of some of America’s most prominent actors, billionaires and businessmen. Yet very few people blessed by his touch ever knew his name.

headline: The Day the Household Appliances Quit
abstract: They should have been pleased they were getting so much work. Instead they revolted.
lead_paragraph: The kettle was the first to go.

headline: Here’s How You Can Change Lives in the Pandemic
abstract: These causes will make great use of your money or your time.
lead_paragraph: Readers keep asking in this age of Covid-19: How can I help?

headline: ‘A Perfect Storm’ in Brazil as Troubles Multiply for Bolsonaro
abstract: President Jair Bolsonaro was already struggling to govern effectively when his star minister resigned and accused him of criminal conduct. Whether he can overcome the latest challenge remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil was struggling to govern effectively long before the explosive resignation speech of his star cabinet minister, who basically called his soon-to-be former boss a criminal.

headline: How to Save Summer 2020
abstract: A balance can be found to be both safe and outdoors.
lead_paragraph: One evening in mid-March, looking to scratch a creative and social itch, the photographer John Martin texted his neighbors in Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., to come outside for a socially distanced photo shoot. The street, he said, seemed to light up with cheer.

headline: Amid the Coronavirus Crisis, Heart and Stroke Patients Go Missing
abstract: Emergency physicians are seeing declines in the number of patients arriving with cardiac problems. Some say they were afraid to go to the hospital.
lead_paragraph: Bishnu Virachan was a bicycle deliveryman for a grocery store in Queens. With New York City locked down, he was busier than ever.

headline: We Need Herd Immunity From Trump and the Coronavirus
abstract: It will take more care than the president is currently demonstrating to loosen restrictions but still protect the vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: With each passing day it becomes more obvious how unlucky we are that one of the worst crises in American history coincides with Donald Trump’s presidency. To get out of this crisis with the least loss of life and least damage to our economy, we need a president who can steer a science-based, nonpartisan debate through the hellish ethical, economic and environmental trade-offs we have to make.

headline: Boeing Terminates $4.2 Billion Deal to Buy Stake in Embraer Unit
abstract: The U.S. aviation giant, struggling with the 737 Max crisis and canceled orders, no longer wants Embraer’s commercial jet business.
lead_paragraph: Boeing, which is contending with the economic fallout from the pandemic and the grounding of its 737 Max jets, said Saturday that it had terminated an agreement to buy 80 percent of Embraer’s commercial jet business for $4.2 billion.

headline: F.T.C. Warns 10 Companies About Virus-Related Health and Business Claims
abstract: In warning letters sent on Friday, the agency cracked down for the first time on claims about earnings opportunities amid the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has warned 10 companies to stop making health claims about treating and preventing the coronavirus or pitching business opportunities amid the pandemic, the agency announced on Friday.

headline: Turn, Turn, Turn
abstract: Royce Ferguson whips around the bend with a smashing debut.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s so fun when someone roars into the crossworld out of nowhere with an inspired puzzle like this! According to Will Shortz’s print introduction, Royce Ferguson is an American living in London, who got the idea for this puzzle while in Switzerland, “a nation known for its 47-Acrosses.” Mr. Ferguson notes that he solves both his weekend puzzles on paper on Saturday because of the International New York Times publishing schedule, so he’s a binger and a paper solver.

headline: Richard Hake, Longtime WNYC Radio Reporter and Host, Dies at 51
abstract: Mr. Hake produced and created live radio feature segments that focused on breaking news, culture and artistic sound portraits.
lead_paragraph: Richard Hake, a WNYC news host, reporter and producer for the past 28 years, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 51.

headline: Serving Wings and a Prayer: It’s Back to Business for Fairbanks Restaurants
abstract: The Alaskan city 200 miles from the Arctic Circle was one of the first in the country to reopen restaurants after a long coronavirus shutdown.
lead_paragraph: FAIRBANKS, Alaska — Most of America now eats at the dining room table, or at the kitchen table, or on the couch, or in bed, or out on the front stoop. But in Alaska, at a place called the Roundup Steakhouse and Saloon, something remarkable happened in this age of infection.

headline: Where Is Kim Jong-un? How Experts Track North Korea’s Leader
abstract: Rumors are swirling about Kim Jong-un’s location and health. These North Korea experts showed us how they collect information about his secretive regime.
lead_paragraph: Rumors are swirling about Kim Jong-un’s location and health. These North Korea experts showed us how they collect information about his secretive regime.

headline: Chicago Bans Horse-Drawn Carriages Starting in 2021
abstract: After the City Council’s vote on Friday, operators will be unable to renew their licenses and the city will stop issuing new ones.
lead_paragraph: The steady sounds of clip-clopping hooves pulling creaking carriages will be absent from the streets in Chicago starting next year after the City Council on Friday voted to ban horse-drawn carriages.

headline: Corrections: April 26, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the artwork of the chef Ficre Ghebreyesus misidentified the area where he spent his childhood. It was in Eritrea, in East Africa, not in North Africa.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Draft Filled a Void, but What Happens Next?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “We’ll go anywhere the science takes us and nowhere the science doesn’t.”

headline: Jessica Murray, Joshua Sheppard
abstract: The couple kept their wedding date, but changed the location because of the effects of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Treanor Murray and Joshua Aaron Sheppard were married April 18 at the home of the bride’s parents in Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Hollis H. Galgano, an Episcopal deacon, and a friend of the bride’s family, officiated. The celebration was to have taken place on the same date at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, a restaurant in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., before the effects of the coronavirus outbreak led to a change of plans.

headline: Emily Herzberg, Samuel Dowd
abstract: The couple met on the dating app Bumble, and, boldly, spent their second and third dates answering “36 questions that lead to love.”
lead_paragraph: Dr. Emily Marie Herzberg and Samuel William Dowd were married April 25 at the home of the groom’s parents in Dennis, Mass. The groom’s father, William F. Dowd, officiated, having received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to solemnize the marriage.

headline: Global Virus Death Toll Crosses 200,000; Italy to Ease Restrictions in May
abstract: Boris Johnson is back at Downing Street and will return to work Monday after recovering. Cuba is sending doctors around the world.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Penny Dreadful: City of Angels’ and ‘Vida’
abstract: A new supernatural horror series and a returning drama highlight very different experiences of Mexican-Americans in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: PENNY DREADFUL: CITY OF ANGELS 10:10 p.m. on Showtime.  John Logan, the creator behind the fantasy horror series “Penny Dreadful,” which ended in 2016, follows it up with this spinoff. Set in 1938 Los Angeles, “City of Angels” delivers a packed narrative: A Mexican-American detective, Tiago Vega (Daniel Zovatto), and his partner, Lewis Michener (Nathan Lane), investigate the grisly murder of a prominent Beverly Hills family. Their search plays out while the city is building its freeway system and displacing Chicano families in the process. A shape-shifting demon inspired by Mexican folklore (played by Natalie Dormer of “Game of Thrones”) somehow ties into all of this, while subplots involving Nazi insurgents and police brutality bring the series, or at least its themes, to the present. “Even though our show is set in 1938, it has to be about 2020 or it has no reason to exist,” Logan said in a recent interview with The New York Times. “Race relations, social engineering, politics, espionage — all of that was bubbling away exactly the way it’s bubbling away now.” The series finale of HOMELAND leads in at 9 p.m.

headline: Brad Pitt Plays Dr. Anthony Fauci in an At-Home Edition of ‘S.N.L.’
abstract: The latest remotely produced episode of “Saturday Night Live” also featured appearances from Miley Cyrus and Adam Sandler, among others.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, “Saturday Night Live” returned to television with its first new episode of the at-home era: a collection of remotely produced sketches that were low on production value but high on spirit and innovation. It offered a window into what the show could do without most of its resources — and into the homes of its cast members, for those of us who always wondered what they looked like.

headline: ‘He Continued to Stand With His Back to Me While I Awaited His Attention’
abstract: Seeking alterations for a new pair of pants, an exchange at a deli and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Katie Ledecky Is Swimming, and Studying
abstract: The five-time Olympic gold medalist is taking an infectious diseases class at Stanford and still finding a way to train.
lead_paragraph: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff members, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: One Rich N.Y. Hospital Got Warren Buffett’s Help. This One Got Duct Tape.
abstract: The inequities of New York City’s health care system are clear at a public hospital in a section of Brooklyn hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: It has been hours since the 71-year-old man in Room 3 of the intensive care unit succumbed to Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus. His body has been cleaned, packed in an orange bag and covered in a white sheet, but the overextended transport team from the morgue has yet to arrive.

headline: Kim Jong-un’s Absence and North Korea’s Silence Keep Rumor Mill Churning
abstract: Rumors about the North Korean leader’s health — and speculation over his possible death — have only increased over the past two weeks.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea is still sending letters and gifts to foreign leaders and domestic workers in the name of its leader, Kim Jong-un. Its news media brims, as usual, with panegyrical propaganda extolling Mr. Kim’s leadership. South Korea reiterates that it has detected “nothing unusual” in the North. President Trump has called “incorrect” and “fake” a report that Mr. Kim was “in grave danger” after surgery.

headline: Where Americans Live Far From the Emergency Room
abstract: In large swaths of the U.S., people have a hard time reaching a hospital that offers the kind of inpatient care needed to treat the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: In large swaths of the U.S., people have a hard time reaching a hospital that offers the kind of inpatient care needed to treat the coronavirus.

headline: Closed Hospitals Leave Rural Patients ‘Stranded’ as Coronavirus Spreads
abstract: A for-profit company bought three struggling hospitals in West Virginia and Ohio. Doctors were fired, supplies ran low and many in need of care had to journey elsewhere. Then the doors shut for good.
lead_paragraph: Michael Nuzum had spent weeks fighting coronavirus-like symptoms — a wracking cough, terrible chills, an exhausting fever — before collapsing at his home in rural West Virginia.

headline: You Might Be Surprised at What Restaurants Are Selling These Days
abstract: Need some flour? Try the local wine bar.
lead_paragraph: Where there was once a collection of plants and a dart board above the wooden counter at Glou + Glick, a wine bar in Prospect Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, there is now a shiny new shelf stocked with pancake mix, kosher salt, tomato paste and hand soap.

headline: ‘Heck Yeah, We’re Dancing’: It’s Diplo, Live From His Living Room
abstract: The popular D.J. is streaming music and memes to thousands with a fog machine from Target — and “having the best time ever,” he reports.
lead_paragraph: Around 10 p.m. on a recent Saturday night, the party really found its groove. Diplo, the D.J., songwriter, and record producer, was holding court behind a pair of Pioneer decks, wearing a Kermit green poncho and matching bucket hat, manipulating an undulating, underwater-sounding dance track with buttons and knobs.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: U.K. Coronavirus Briefings Offer a More Genteel Spin Than Trump’s
abstract: Downing Street’s daily updates are worlds away from the White House’s in tone, but they share a purpose: to control the narrative and deflect blame over a heavily criticized response.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Each evening at the stroke of 5, a British cabinet minister and two expert advisers walk into a clubby, wood-paneled room at 10 Downing Street and take their places behind three socially distanced lecterns.

headline: An Artist’s New Migration Song
abstract: Serge Alain Nitegeka can’t leave South Africa, but his art, on the refugee condition, is traveling.
lead_paragraph: Serge Alain Nitegeka hasn’t been free to roam in a while. For over five years, the Johannesburg artist has been unable to leave South Africa as he waits for his case for citizenship there to be resolved. (He was born in Rwanda.)

headline: Trump Turns Shared American Experiences Into Us vs. Them
abstract: Nostalgia for a time when Democratic leaders could embrace Republican leaders in a moment of crisis — and when a bipartisan group would gather for an annual roasting in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last weekend, an anniversary of the kind that would have once united the country in reflection — the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, 25 years ago — passed without much in the way of comment. As the days inside pile up, our usual approach to a national moment of remembrance appeared lost to the fog of time, germs and Trump era news cycles.

headline: For Pop Stars in Their 20s, It’s Totally the ’90s All Over Again
abstract: Every two decades or so, the old becomes stylishly new. And now the pop artifacts of the Y2K era — winking futurism, loads of glitter, “TRL”-style videos — are back, with an update.
lead_paragraph: The bright, aerodynamic video for Dua Lipa’s “Break My Heart” seems to take place in an indiscriminate time period — or perhaps just in the floating, eternal hyper-now of the pop music video.

headline: Volunteer Emergency Responders Face a Dilemma: Save Lives or Stay Safe
abstract: The coronavirus has overwhelmed scores of volunteer emergency response units, many of which are the sole responders across America.
lead_paragraph: In Teaneck, N.J., half of the town’s volunteer ambulance corps is out sick, in quarantine or staying home to avoid potential exposure to the coronavirus. The remaining 25 are responding to double the usual number of daily calls, racing from one high fever or respiratory distress emergency to the next.

headline: Safe Dining? Hard to Imagine, but Many Restaurants Are Trying
abstract: Though widespread reopenings may be a long way off, chefs and health officials have begun studying how a post-pandemic restaurant might look.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — This week, a restaurant here intends to sell what will likely be America’s first dry-aged porterhouse steak served by a waiter at a white-tablecloth restaurant in the midst of a global pandemic.

headline: High School Sports Pushed Out of Bounds by the Pandemic
abstract: The cancellation of the Texas state basketball tournament hit a small town hard and reflected the wave of spring sports shutdowns in all 50 states during a normally busy playoff season.
lead_paragraph: The girls’ basketball team at Gruver High School in the Texas panhandle won its first state title in early March. A week later came the boys’ opportunity in this tiny agricultural community, where 400 acres of corn on the school farm finance college scholarships and sports provide a galvanizing sense of identity. Well-wishers parked along Broadway Street at dawn and waved as the Greyhounds’ team bus rolled toward San Antonio on a 10-hour trip to the state semifinals. Providing escort were police cruisers and fire trucks, their lights flashing, and a procession of semitrailers and galloping riders carrying flags on horseback.

headline: As States Push to Reopen, Business Leaders Say Not So Fast
abstract: “Shutting down was hard, but opening up is going to be harder,” one C.E.O. said of balancing public health and a damaged economy.
lead_paragraph: Companies in a handful of states have begun taking tentative steps to reopen stores, offices and factories that were closed by the coronavirus. Yet as the first employees and customers return, interviews with roughly 30 major employers show that businesses are confronting deep uncertainty, and many say it is simply too soon to come back.

headline: How to Make an Illustrated Map in 8 Steps
abstract: Release your inner explorer. Here’s a way to relive, commemorate or envision a favorite place in the world by creating an illustrated map.
lead_paragraph: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.

headline: Kashmir, Under Siege and Lockdown, Faces a Mental Health Crisis
abstract: Years of strife left a generation traumatized. India’s clampdown disrupted daily life. Now the battle against the coronavirus has further isolated and scarred a people with little access to help.
lead_paragraph: PAHOO, Kashmir — Sara Begum’s suffering began on Aug. 3, when masked policemen barged into her home, badly roughed up her son and whisked him away.

headline: Reopening, Coronavirus, N.F.L. Draft: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Trump Suggested ‘Injecting’ Disinfectant to Cure Coronavirus? We’re Not Surprised
abstract: False “bleach cures” have been touted for autism, cancer — and now Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: At a news conference on Thursday, President Trump surprised nearly everyone when he suggested using powerful cleaning agents, through an injection, as a possible Covid-19 cure.

headline: Giants Draft Pick Andrew Thomas Is ‘Everything You Want in a Left Tackle’
abstract: Thomas, the No. 4 overall pick in the N.F.L. draft, described the opportunity to block for Saquon Barkley and Daniel Jones as a “blessing.”
lead_paragraph: Six days before the first round of the N.F.L. draft, Chris Slade, the head football coach at Pace Academy in Atlanta, took a phone call from someone in the Giants organization who wanted to know if there was any reason the team should not select Andrew Thomas, a former Pace player.

headline: The Week in Business: Not Enough Meat, and Too Much Oil
abstract: Jobs keep disappearing. Victoria’s Secret gets left out to dry. And do you know where your advertisers are?
lead_paragraph: Another week of pandemic news, another 4.4 million jobs gone. Here’s the latest from the business and tech worlds, plus what you need to know for the week ahead. (What day is it, again?)

headline: Coronavirus Live Updates: Summer Is Coming. Some States Are Reopening. Can We Keep Our Distance?
abstract: Nevada is one especially thorny example because of its dependence on tourism. But everywhere, faster and more widespread testing will be vital.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Closing the Restaurant That Was My Life for 20 Years’
abstract: One restaurateur asks: Will there be room for reopening or reinvention in the New York City of the future?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: New York’s Leaders Elaborate on Plans to Reopen as Virus Death Toll Drops
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that construction and manufacturing businesses in less hard-hit regions of the state might reopen in May.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Monday’s live coverage.]

headline: College Campuses Must Reopen in the Fall. Here’s How We Do It.
abstract: It won’t be easy, but there’s a path to get students back on track. Higher education will crumble without it.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, college campuses have become ghost towns. Students and professors are hunkered down inside, teaching and learning online. University administrators are tabulating the financial costs of the Covid-19 pandemic, which already exceed the CARES Act’s support for higher education.

headline: Is the Light at the End of This Tunnel the Beam of an Oncoming Train?
abstract: A Times correspondent, now in New York, compares the fight against the coronavirus with other wars he has known.
lead_paragraph: Having been a war correspondent much of my life, I can’t shake the feeling that the war against the coronavirus is a lot like the real thing.

headline: The Street That Still Offers Paris Hope
abstract: Fishmongers, butchers, neighbors and friends. The Rue des Martyrs village lives on.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Even as suffering and sadness envelop Paris these days, there is a street that offers a respite, however brief: the Rue des Martyrs.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Treat yourself to a cauliflower Parmesan, chicken thighs with rice and chiles, or burgers (beef, black bean, even seafood).
lead_paragraph: Good morning. My friend Ashley Merriman fashioned a Ping-Pong table out of her dining room table recently, because, as her wife, Gabrielle Hamilton, wrote for The Times this week, they had to close their restaurant, they’re both out of work and renting movies for the family at $4.99 a throw seemed irresponsible. Then Gabrielle went out and spent $56 on a pound of fresh crab meat, to make crab toast (above).

headline: A New Print Section for a New Way of Life
abstract: To help readers thrive in a world where work, family, school and recreation are confined to one space, The Times introduces At Home.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.Times journalists have always dedicated themselves to guiding readers on how to live richer lives out in their world. The mission remains unchanged, but for millions now sheltering in place because of the pandemic, that world is largely confined to what’s under their roof.

headline: Most Americans Who Carry the Coronavirus Don’t Know It
abstract: To suppress Covid-19, we need to test those with no symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Almost the only people who are being tested for the coronavirus are those who have symptoms of Covid-19, an approach endorsed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which provides guidance for states.

headline: There’s Really Only One Way to Reopen the Economy
abstract: The way forward in the coronavirus crisis keeps getting framed as a false choice between saving lives or the economy.
lead_paragraph: The way forward in the coronavirus crisis keeps getting framed as a choice between saving lives or saving the economy. It’s a false choice. The only way to save the economy is to take the steps that will also save lives.

headline: Dozens of Gay Men Are Outed in Morocco as Photos Are Spread Online
abstract: The idea was to show the hypocrisy of Moroccan society by showing how many gay men are living quietly in straight society. It backfired badly.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — At least 50 to 100 gay men were outed in Morocco over the last two weeks, rights activists say, after the men were identified on location-based meeting apps while sheltering at home amid a coronavirus lockdown.

headline: Gay Literature Is Out of the Closet. So Why Is Deception a Big Theme?
abstract: Until recently, gay literary characters had to hide their identities. But even now the closet — and the lies and concealment it implies — remains a surprisingly potent metaphor.
lead_paragraph: Near the beginning of James Baldwin’s 1956 novel “Giovanni’s Room,” the narrator, David, recalls the moment at which he became conscious of his homosexuality. He was a teenager, in bed with another boy — the bed itself a testament to “vileness” — and made what he calls a “decision” to live as a straight man.

headline: The Kids Are All Right, Not ‘Coddled’
abstract: Young readers say their experience of life has hardly been easy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Drug Approval: Holding Big Pharma to Account
abstract: The author of a book about the pharmaceutical industry discusses Gilead’s antiviral drug remdesivir. Also: No bailout for airlines; returning to the workplace.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 32 Days on a Ventilator: One Covid Patient’s Fight to Breathe Again
abstract: Jim Bello, 49 and healthy, fell gravely ill, highlighting agonizing mysteries of the coronavirus. Doctors’ relentless effort to save him was a roller-coaster of devastating and triumphant twists.
lead_paragraph: HINGHAM, Mass. — “Is he going to make it?” Kim Bello asked, clutching her phone, alone in her yard.

headline: Comic Insults Aside, Mayors Act as Sentinels in Italy’s Coronavirus Tragedy
abstract: They have launched insult-armed drones. They have confronted scofflaws on the streets. They have gone incognito. And now they will enforce the rules for how Italians can resume their lives.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In a sort of coronavirus edition of “Undercover Boss,” the mayor of the northern Italian town of Asti this past week surreptitiously inspected supermarkets for the illegal sale of inessential products.

headline: As Coronavirus Strikes Prisons, Hundreds of Thousands Are Released
abstract: The virus has spread rapidly in overcrowded prisons across the world, leading governments to release inmates en masse.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Prisons across the world have become powerful breeding grounds for the coronavirus, prompting governments to release hundreds of thousands of inmates in a mad scramble to curb the spread of the contagion behind bars.

headline: The Met Opera’s At-Home Gala: Informal Yet Profoundly Moving
abstract: For four hours, more than 40 of the company’s stars performed live from their homes around the world.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera has reserved sprawling gala performances, with dozens of singers, for festive milestones: the retirement of a longtime general manager, say, or the company’s 50th anniversary at Lincoln Center.

headline: Betsy Wyeth, Andrew Wyeth’s Widow and Collaborator, Dies at 98
abstract: She was just 17 when she met her future husband. She went on to guide his career and became an avid preservationist of vernacular architecture.
lead_paragraph: Betsy James Wyeth, the indomitable widow, collaborator and muse of the painter Andrew Wyeth, died on April 21 at her home in Chadds Ford, Pa. She was 98.

headline: Wuhan, Kim Jong-un, Ramadan: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: I Never Planned to Be a Front-Line Worker at Dollar General
abstract: No barriers, not enough staffing, low wages. They seem to not know there’s a danger to employees.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, La. — I’ve been working at Dollar General here for more than two years. My manager is wonderful, and I have a great relationship with my customers. But when I took this job I never planned to become a worker on the front line of a pandemic.

headline: A Constitutional Right to Literacy for Detroit’s Kids?
abstract: They deserve better schools, but the courts don’t offer much hope.
lead_paragraph: Already ravaged by poor health outcomes and joblessness before a crushing wave of Covid-19 cases, the people of Detroit received welcome news Thursday in the form of a long-awaited ruling from a federal Court of Appeals. In Gary B. v. Whitmer, a three-judge panel on the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals held that Detroit’s students enjoy a “fundamental right” to literacy under the United States Constitution. If allowed to stand, this landmark ruling could force the State of Michigan to dramatically improve the quality of education offered to thousands of Detroit’s most disadvantaged students.

headline: The N.F.L. Draft Pics You Haven’t Seen
abstract: In its remote broadcast format, the N.F.L. gave sports fans something to talk about until games begin this fall. Here are some of the most interesting moments, through the eyes of an illustrator.
lead_paragraph: Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, did not get any hugs from the players selected at the N.F.L. draft this year, but the traditional draft day “boo birds” still made it onto the broadcast.

headline: Needing At-Home Workers, Call Centers Turn to People With Disabilities
abstract: Companies caught short by the pandemic are hiring from a pool that was already prepared to handle a surge in phone traffic away from offices.
lead_paragraph: A workplace injury two decades ago when she was newly pregnant left Robin Ervin with neuropathy in her left leg and without a functioning bowel or bladder. She has been living on disability benefits since.

headline: Steve Dalkowski, Model for Erratic Pitcher in ‘Bull Durham,’ Dies at 80
abstract: Known for his extraordinary fastball, Dalkowski never made it to the major leagues, walking batters almost as often as he struck them out.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Michigan Senator Apologizes for Mask That Looked Like Confederate Flag
abstract: “My actions were an error in judgment for which there are no excuses and I will learn from this episode,” State Senator Dale Zorn said of his homemade face mask.
lead_paragraph: A Republican state senator in Michigan apologized for wearing a homemade mask that resembled the Confederate battle flag on the Senate floor on Friday.

headline: Can Antibody Tests Help End the Coronavirus Pandemic?
abstract: The tests are not reliable enough to guide policy on lockdowns and reopenings, experts said. But they can help model the spread of the virus.
lead_paragraph: A survey of New Yorkers last week found that one in five city residents carried antibodies to the new coronavirus — and in that, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo saw good news.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 27, 2020
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Students

headline: Reopening of New York Could Begin Upstate After May 15, Cuomo Says
abstract: The governor outlined a plan to restart the economy, beginning with manufacturing and construction, and suggested professional sports could resume without fans.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — With promising indications that the coronavirus contagion has passed its peak, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York laid out a broad outline on Sunday for a gradual restart of the state that would allow some “low-risk” businesses upstate to reopen as soon as mid-May.

headline: This Florida Student Was Accepted at All 8 Ivy League Schools. (He Chose Yale.)
abstract: Craig McFarland, the valedictorian of his high school in Jacksonville, Fla., received acceptance letters from 17 colleges and universities in all.
lead_paragraph: Most high school seniors hope to be accepted by their top two or three choices for college.

headline: How Las Vegas Became Ground Zero for the American Jobs Crisis
abstract: As the U.S. economy has shut down, the burden is falling hardest on those least prepared to handle it.
lead_paragraph: When Valicia Anderson starts to count the people she knows in Las Vegas who have lost their jobs, she runs out of fingers fast.

headline: Trump’s Disinfectant Remark Raises a Question About the ‘Very Stable Genius’
abstract: The president has often said he is exceptionally smart. His recent suggestion about injecting disinfectants was not.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s self-assessment has been consistent.

headline: To Pressure Iran, Pompeo Turns to the Deal Trump Renounced
abstract: The secretary of state is preparing an argument that the U.S. remains a participant in the Obama-era nuclear deal, with the goal of extending an arms embargo or destroying the accord.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is preparing a legal argument that the United States remains a participant in the Iran nuclear accord that President Trump has renounced, part of an intricate strategy to pressure the United Nations Security Council to extend an arms embargo on Tehran or see far more stringent sanctions reimposed on the country.

headline: ‘That Sure Hits the Spot!’
abstract: Ed Sessa encourages us to hoist one.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — We talk about this concept a lot in solving, but anything I say here will be a spoiler. Enjoy this puzzle by Ed Sessa.

headline: Small-Business Loan Program, Chaotic From Start, Gets 2nd Round
abstract: The Paycheck Protection Program distributed $349 billion in less than two weeks, but lenders and borrowers confronted confusion at every step.
lead_paragraph: One day before the federal government’s $349 billion aid program for small businesses was set to go live, the chief executive of a Minnesota bank was frantically dialing officials in Washington. Grand Rapids State Bank needed more time to understand the program, said the executive, Noah W. Wilcox, even as it faced a crush of borrowers. His pleas went unheeded.

headline: Large, Troubled Companies Got Bailout Money in Small-Business Loan Program
abstract: Companies with accounting problems or in trouble with the government received millions in federal loans.
lead_paragraph: A company in Georgia paid $6.5 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation — and, two weeks later, received a $10 million federally backed loan to help it survive the coronavirus crisis.

headline: Two Weapons, a Chase, a Killing and No Charges
abstract: A 25-year-old man running through a Georgia neighborhood ended up dead. A prosecutor argued that the pursuers should not be arrested.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Gregory McMichael and Travis McMichael Have Been Charged with Murder in Killing of Ahmaud Arbery]

headline: Trump Called the Postal Service a ‘Joke.’ I’m Trying to Save It.
abstract: The Postal Service should be allowed to deliver low-cost financial services to poor and rural communities. And vote-by-mail should be universal.
lead_paragraph: The United States Postal Service is an institution whose roots are older than the Constitution itself. Not only has it survived through snow, rain, heat and gloom of night, but it has also endured a civil war, two world wars, the Great Depression, the Cold War and numerous long recessions.

headline: In Praise of Pessimism
abstract: This country is going to need its Eeyores.
lead_paragraph: Confession: I have a secret talent for making lemons out of lemonade. It may not be readily apparent. I smile a lot and make cheerful conversation; my end of the dinner table is not some horrible event horizon beyond which all sunlight disappears. But tucked inside me, almost always, is a grumbling Eeyore.

headline: Patriots Draft Kicker With Tattoo of a Militia Group
abstract: The kicker, Justin Rohrwasser, out of Marshall University, said that he did not support the far-right group, the Three Percenters, and also that he would cover the tattoo.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. teams are sometimes criticized for drafting kickers, particularly if they take them as early as the fifth round.

headline: For Trump, Lying Is a Super Power
abstract: He will use deception to keep his bungled response to Covid-19 from ruining his re-election chances.
lead_paragraph: After Donald Trump’s ridiculous and dangerous suggestion last week that household disinfectants injected into people’s bodies might be a treatment for Covid-19, Republicans intensified their hand-wringing over whether his daily briefings were doing more harm — to his political fortunes and theirs — than good.

headline: Governors, Facing Pressures on All Sides, Weigh Reopening Their States
abstract: In Colorado, Georgia, Oklahoma, Michigan and elsewhere, they face the same question: how and when to restart parts of their economies.
lead_paragraph: Facing the same competing pressures between keeping people safe in a pandemic and reviving some elements of a more functioning society, governors around the country Sunday made their case for steps they were taking — or not taking — to begin reopening.

headline: Anna Wintour Made Condé Nast the Embodiment of Boomer Excess. Can It Change to Meet This Crisis?
abstract: The theatrical flourishes and lavish lifestyles of the great media figures of a generation seem ill suited to the moment.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus chased the fashion industry across Europe in February, from fashion week in Milan to fashion week in Paris, where designers handed out masks and some nervous fashion editors left early.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 3, Episode 7 Recap: The Regressive Path
abstract: Caleb learns the truth about his past with some help from another outlier.
lead_paragraph: Or something to that effect.

headline: 260,000 Words, Full of Self-Praise, From Trump on the Virus
abstract: Three journalists from The New York Times reviewed more than 260,000 words spoken by President Trump during the pandemic. Here’s what we learned.
lead_paragraph: Three journalists from The New York Times reviewed more than 260,000 words spoken by President Trump during the pandemic. Here’s what we learned.

headline: ‘Homeland’ Showrunner Declassifies the Series Finale
abstract: The series’s co-creator Alex Gansa talks about last-minute decisions, adjusting to criticism and the role of Edward Snowden as the writers crafted an ending.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the series finale of “Homeland.”

headline: In ‘Run,’ Archie Panjabi Sees Shades of Her Most Famous Role
abstract: The actress’s part in the comic thriller, one of two HBO shows she is joining this spring, reminds her of Kalinda, her beloved character in “The Good Wife.”
lead_paragraph: In the final seconds of HBO’s romantic thriller “Run” on Sunday night, Archie Panjabi’s heat-seeking-missile Fiona steadily lowers to her knees and ever-so-gently slides her phone underneath a hotel door to record her targets, Domhnall Gleeson and Merritt Wever’s irresponsibly-reunited former lovers Billy and Ruby, (loudly) going at it. If that move reminded you of a certain leather-jacketed, high-booted, and brilliantly sly investigator from “The Good Wife,” you’re not the only one.

headline: South Korea Confident That Rumors of Kim Jong-un Illness Are Wrong
abstract: Comments by the country’s unification minister represent the South’s most categorical rebuttal of reports that the North’s leader may be incapacitated.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea is confident that there is no basis to the recent swirl of rumors that the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, ​is gravely ill, ​the South’s chief policymaker on the North​ said in comments reported on Monday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Mayors Press Case in Inventive Ways
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 27, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “We needed to send a clear message, with slightly brutal language. We brought people back to reality.”

headline: Dennis Rodman’s College Coach Recalls Recruiting Him Over H-O-R-S-E
abstract: Lonn Reisman, who coached Rodman at Southeastern Oklahoma State, said he dreamed of wooing the “raw” elite rebounder from junior college but figured it wasn’t possible.
lead_paragraph: The telephone calls from reporters and television producers are more sporadic now. But Lonn Reisman still hears from people who want to know more about Dennis Rodman, and that has been the case again thanks to “The Last Dance,” ESPN’s 10-part documentary series on Michael Jordan’s final season with the Chicago Bulls.

headline: Scientists Race For a Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: Even as the global death toll passed 200,000, countries are mapping out a return to public life. Health care workers in Mexico, India and other countries are facing attacks.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: No Corrections: April 27, 2020
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 27, 2020.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 27, 2020.

headline: Stocks Rise as Oil Prices Plunge
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline: Coronavirus, Italy, Kim Jong-un: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Deaf Girl Finds Her Voice on Martha’s Vineyard in the 19th Century
abstract: “Papa was right,” Mary Lambert tells herself and the world in Ann Clare LeZotte’s “Show Me a Sign.” “We are fine as we were made.”
lead_paragraph: Life on Martha’s Vineyard has been mostly ideal for 11-year-old Mary Elizabeth Lambert, the protagonist of Ann Clare LeZotte’s historical novel SHOW ME A SIGN (Scholastic, 288 pp., $18.99; ages 8 to 12).

headline: Amid Family Upheaval, a Heroine Finds Comfort in the Concrete
abstract: The protagonist of Rebecca Stead’s “The List of Things That Will Not Change” ends in a different place than she began, but her essential self remains.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, Rebecca Stead’s THE LIST OF THINGS THAT WILL NOT CHANGE (Wendy Lamb Books, 224 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12) is a book about complicated circumstances.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Breeders’ and ‘Never Have I Ever’
abstract: The Martin Freeman comedy comes to a close. And a new Netflix series from Mindy Kaling makes its debut.
lead_paragraph: PRODIGAL SON 9 p.m. on Fox. There are few subjects as rich in storytelling potential as parent-child conflict and law enforcement. This series, which wraps its first season tonight, includes a lot of both. It follows Malcolm Bright (Tom Payne), an N.Y.P.D. investigator who is trying to evade the legacy of his serial killer father, Martin Whitly (Michael Sheen). His attempts to distance himself from his paternal inheritance were stymied when a copycat case required him to turn to Martin for help. Last week’s episode ended with Malcolm being arrested and charged with an offscreen murder. In the finale, perhaps we’ll see if he has followed in his father’s bloody footsteps.

headline: Word + Quiz: badinage
abstract: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Can Estrogen and Other Sex Hormones Help Men Survive Covid-19?
abstract: Men are more likely than women to die of the coronavirus, so scientists are treating them with something women have more of: female sex hormones.
lead_paragraph: As the novel coronavirus swept through communities around the world, preying disproportionately on the poor and the vulnerable, one disadvantaged group has demonstrated a remarkable resistance. Women, whether from China, Italy or the U.S., have been less likely to become acutely ill — and far more likely to survive.

headline: He Found One of Stalin’s Mass Graves. Now He’s in Jail.
abstract: The discovery by Yuri Dmitriev, after years of searching, “has clearly made some people very uncomfortable,” his daughter says.
lead_paragraph: SANDARMOKH, Russia — The day began, like many others in her childhood years, with hours of tramping through an insect-infested forest with the family dog while her eccentric father, Yuri Dmitriev, wandered off to hunt in vain for corpses buried among the trees.

headline: How I Found Common Ground With My Immigrant Dad on a Tennis Court
abstract: Our writer was not much of an athlete growing up but long pined to connect with his father through sports. It took 30 years and a humid day on a tennis court in India.
lead_paragraph: Most of my childhood friends from our predominantly white New Jersey suburb have a story about how their love of sports began — usually involving their fathers. Shaun’s played catch with him for hours in the backyard and took him to baseball card shows, hence Shaun’s love of baseball. Matt’s brought him up watching Knicks games in the basement, so Matt loved basketball.

headline: ‘Possible Covid’: Why the Lulls Never Last for Weary E.M.S. Crews
abstract: New York’s ambulance workers have weathered the peak of the coronavirus epidemic, but their ordeal is not over yet.
lead_paragraph: For seven and a half hours, the two New York City paramedics had worked a surprisingly normal shift: a few people with difficulty breathing, one trip to the hospital — and, miraculously it seemed, no clear cases of coronavirus.

headline: After Closing for the Virus, Is Michelin Moving Too Quickly?
abstract: The tire maker’s C.E.O. says the company must be ready for the end of quarantine, but French unions are wary.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent weekday, while France was still under one of Europe’s tightest lockdowns, mammoth six-foot tractor tires were rolling off the assembly line at a Michelin factory in northeast France. Farther south, other Michelin plants turned out tires for ambulances and fire trucks as fast as small skeleton crews could make them.

headline: What My Spacewalk Taught Me About Isolation
abstract: Feel as if you’re drifting in space? I know what that’s like.
lead_paragraph: Feel as if you’re drifting in space? I know what that’s like.

headline: A Virus Upends the World in a Sweeping New Novel
abstract: Lawrence Wright’s “The End of October” is about the scientific challenge, political turmoil and social horror of a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The sweeping, authoritative and genuinely intelligent thriller — the sort of novel in which the author employs a bulldozer and a scalpel at the same time — is a rare specimen. Lawrence Wright’s second novel, “The End of October,” is one of these. The fact that it’s about the world in shock and ruin because of a virus similar to Covid-19 makes it read as if it’s been shot out of a cannon.

headline: Stephen King Has an Idea for the Story Joe Biden Could Be Telling
abstract: “Do you want somebody who’s capable of dealing with a situation like coronavirus or do you want somebody who’s so focused on his self-image that he’s not able to do that?”
lead_paragraph: “Do you want somebody who’s capable of dealing with a situation like coronavirus or do you want somebody who’s so focused on his self-image that he’s not able to do that?”

headline: What My Spacewalk Taught Me About Isolation
abstract: Feel as if you’re drifting in space? I know what that’s like.
lead_paragraph: We’re over a month into social distancing and many of us are feeling that time and space have lost all meaning. Perhaps no one understands this better than astronauts, who spend months drifting in isolation.

headline: Live Events: Learn How to Tawk Like a New Yawker and More
abstract: Vote for the ultimate New York accent. Cook creatively with what’s already in your kitchen. Here’s how to join our virtual events this week.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has transformed nearly every aspect of daily life, but Times journalists are here to keep you informed and connected from home. Below is a selection of our live events this week (all times are Eastern Standard). You can find the full calendar here.

headline: Coronavirus as a Reminder of the Urgency of Getting Your Vaccines
abstract: Even before the pandemic, many parents rejected readily available, safe and effective immunizations that can protect their children.
lead_paragraph: While the new coronavirus, against which there is currently no vaccine, causes global economic chaos, illness and death, there are other serious infections that are too often ignored or dismissed. Experts say that, before the disruptions caused by Covid-19, most American parents were diligent about keeping their kids’ immunizations up-to-date, but too many others have rejected readily available, safe and effective vaccines that can protect their children against potentially life-threatening diseases.

headline: Three Things Lockdowns Have Exposed About Working and Parenting
abstract: For one thing, with children popping up in Zoom meetings, it’s impossible to hide that raising children is a round-the-clock responsibility.
lead_paragraph: If you’re an involved parent, especially a mother, you’re supposed to play down that fact at work or risk being penalized — at least at many American workplaces. Family caregiving has been considered a private matter, one that should not interfere with job responsibilities.

headline: The Clean Queen Talks Quarantine
abstract: What the “The Joy of Cooking” was to the culinary arts, “Home Comforts” was to keeping house. Now, five weeks into lockdown, it’s freshly relevant.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, Cheryl Mendelson shocked Americans by informing us that there is a right and a wrong way to use a broom. She did this in a book that was scholarly, opinionated and too big to throw at the cat.

headline: Saudi Arabia Must Suspend the Hajj
abstract: The presence of millions of pilgrims in Mecca and Medina will have lethal consequences.
lead_paragraph: Despite the pandemic gripping the world, the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia, the holiest site in Islam, is still officially scheduled for late July. Although the kingdom has asked Muslims to postpone their trips, unless it suspends the hajj, it poses devastating health risks.

headline: A Survey of Essential Workers Shows a Political Divide
abstract: Most of them worry about contagion, but there’s a partisan difference in concern levels and workplace safety actions.
lead_paragraph: Democrats and Republicans differ on attitudes toward coronavirus risks and in workplace behaviors meant to reduce them, according to a new survey. This partisanship has the potential to hurt efforts to stop the spread of the virus.

headline: We Know Crowding Affects the Spread. It May Affect the Death Rate.
abstract: Densely populated areas can have nearly twice the rate of transmission, and can make Covid-19 more deadly. Other areas can open more quickly.
lead_paragraph: Ever since a new coronavirus emerged in China late last year, public health experts have debated why it was so dangerous. Now, as we consider how to reopen communities in the United States and across the world, we’re learning that the closer people live and work together, the more threatening and deadly the virus can be.

headline: A High-End Building That Seemed Ideal for Young Performers
abstract: A mother and her professional, home-schooled children were drawn to the building’s amenities. But now they’re stuck in their apartment.
lead_paragraph: For Shannon Guse and her children, Ignacio Rosado, 12, and Liliana Rosado, 11, it was the over-the-top amenities that clinched it. The children were adamant: They wanted to live at 400 West 61st Street, a new rental development in Lincoln Square that opened last year, even if it meant bunking in a closet.

headline: Trump’s Contempt for the Ex-Presidents Is Costing Us Right Now
abstract: A sitting commander in chief used to call on predecessors to provide a sense of national unity. Not this one.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, in an interview in the Oval Office, I asked President Trump if his years behind the storied Resolute desk had made him empathize with his predecessors. In the very room where most of them had called on one another in times of crisis for years —  and well before the novel coronavirus pandemic changed the country, and the world — Mr. Trump was dismissive of the men who came before him.

headline: We Need a New Kind of National Guard
abstract: One that mobilizes scientists.
lead_paragraph: In normal times, clinical microbiologists are often invisible. They’re hidden away in hospital laboratories developing and overseeing diagnostic tests, and so are the bench technologists who run those tests. That’s different now. These scientists are on the front lines of the pandemic, testing patients’ samples for the coronavirus. But there are not enough of them.

headline: The Last Remnants of the Israeli Left
abstract: If you seek the socialist vision of this country’s founders, it’s no longer in the Knesset — it’s on the wall.
lead_paragraph: MA’ALEH HA-HAMISHA, Israel — In a modest building at this kibbutz in the hills outside Jerusalem, brawny workers in strong colors labor across three high walls, breaking rocks and plowing dark earth. Forgotten, then rediscovered, they’ve been here since 1953. They stare back at you, confident and grave, like saints in a medieval church. They want to tell you something.

headline: There Is a Better Way for Democrats to Win in Wisconsin
abstract: Latinos are far more effective than any TV ad at convincing their friends and family to vote.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Despite their best efforts, Republicans were not able to steal a State Supreme Court election here on April 7. That’s all the more reason Democrats should double down on this crucial battleground state if they want to win in November.

headline: ‘Risking My Life’ to Truck In Milk, Wine and Hand Sanitizer
abstract: Essential workers in the pandemic, truck drivers are moving the groceries and supplies New York needs to weather the crisis.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Morales puts on a mask and gloves whenever he is delivering truckloads of wine, vodka and gin to a thirsty city.

headline: It Calls Itself the Energy Capital. Now It Faces 2 ‘Horrifying’ Crises.
abstract: Houston has been reeling from oil-market chaos on top of a coronavirus shutdown. Job losses could reach 300,000.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — On the same day that the price for U.S. crude oil fell to about $30 below zero — a mind-bending concept and the first time oil prices had ever turned negative — Mayor Sylvester Turner of Houston, the self-proclaimed energy capital of the world, stood before reporters. His words were grim and muffled by the black mask covering his face.

headline: Now We Know How Quickly Our Trashed Planet Can Heal
abstract: Clean air, wandering goats. The pandemic is teaching us that all is not yet lost.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — “Sam is being too day-dreamy in class,” began the note that came home in our oldest child’s grammar-school backpack. Sam understood the lessons, it turns out, but he wasn’t completing his worksheets on time because he kept staring out the classroom windows.

headline: How Do You Sign ‘Don’t Drink Bleach’?
abstract: Sign language interpreters are sharing lifesaving information and becoming part of a visible pantheon of essential workers.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — “Coronavirus” is one fist nestled against and behind the other, then opened, fingers spread like a sunburst or a peacock tail.

headline: Start-Ups Pursue ‘Free Money’ With Relief Funds, Prompting Backlash
abstract: Some young companies have turned to the government loans not for day-to-day survival but simply to buy useful time.
lead_paragraph: Domio, a start-up that offers short-term rentals, has its headquarters in a New York City loft that features beer on tap, a game room and a wall of house slippers for visitors. The fast-growing and unprofitable company has raised $117 million in venture capital, including $100 million in August.

headline: Europe’s Privacy Law Hasn’t Shown Its Teeth, Frustrating Advocates
abstract: Nearly two years in, there has been little enforcement of the General Data Protection Regulation, once seen as ushering in a new era.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Europe enacted the world’s toughest online privacy law nearly two years ago, it was heralded as a model to crack down on the invasive, data-hungry practices of the world’s largest technology companies.

headline: I’m the Judge Who Won in Wisconsin. This Principle Is More Important Than Winning.
abstract: We must get away from a partisan view of the law.
lead_paragraph: On April 7, I was on the ballot in an election that should not have happened.

headline: Reveling in the Enigmatic Beauty of Easter Island
abstract: Some 2,200 miles off the coast of Chile, Rapa Nui, also known as Easter Island, is among the world’s most remote — and mysterious — inhabited islands.
lead_paragraph: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’ve launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Benjamin Lowy shares a collection of photographs from Easter Island.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that construction and manufacturing businesses in some upstate regions might be able to reopen after May 15.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Texas and Ohio Push to Reopen; White House Promises to Help States Test
abstract: More states gradually lift restrictions on some businesses even as cases remain high. A new testing plan falls short of what public health experts say is necessary.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Coronavirus, Lockdown, Kim Jong-un: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Glut of Oil
abstract: This is the energy crisis nobody saw coming.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: On Politics: Rattling Money Out of Congress’s Piggy Bank
abstract: States plead for coronavirus aid, and another partisan fight looms: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump after signing the latest coronavirus relief package in the Oval Office on Friday.

headline: The Loans and the Fury
abstract: As the U.S. government’s small-business rescue fund reopens today, outrage remains about bigger companies that tapped the first round of loans.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: Deaths Dip in N.Y. and N.J. as Reopening Plans Take Shape
abstract: Governor Cuomo said some businesses in parts of New York might restart after May 15, though much of the state will remain shut down.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that 337 more people had died of the virus in New York State, and Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey reported an additional 106 deaths.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Endorses Joe Biden
abstract: The House speaker described the former vice president as “a leader with the humility to seek expertise and science, and the confidence to act upon it.”
lead_paragraph: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday as the Democratic Party continued to coalesce around its presumptive presidential nominee.

headline: Running Backs, Drafted Late, Are Still Coveted in the N.F.L.
abstract: Seven teams, most with already strong rushing attacks, selected a running back in the second or third round of last week’s N.F.L. draft.
lead_paragraph: As the A.F.C.’s top seed last season, the Baltimore Ravens charged into the postseason as Super Bowl favorites with a 14-2 record built on a distinct run-first offensive mentality. The Ravens rushed the football 57.5 percent of the time, easily the league high.

headline: What Do You Miss Most About Your Life Before the Pandemic?
abstract: Are there moments of “normalcy” that you feel nostalgic for? Is there anything from life a few months ago that you took for granted?
lead_paragraph: In “When Life Felt Normal: Your Pre-Pandemic Moments,” Hannah Wise writes:

headline: Why Did Cruise Ships Keep Sailing?
abstract: A timeline.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: What You Get for $700,000
abstract: A Long Beach condo in a former Masonic temple, a 1922 bungalow in Petaluma and a cottage in Monrovia.
lead_paragraph: A Long Beach condo in a former Masonic temple, a 1922 bungalow in Petaluma and a cottage in Monrovia.

headline: $700,000 Homes in California
abstract: A condo in a former Masonic temple in Long Beach, a 1922 bungalow in Petaluma and a cottage in Monrovia.
lead_paragraph: After sitting empty for a number of years, this 1927 Greek Revival building was converted into condominiums in 2005, and two additional towers were added to form a complex. This unit, on the top level of the 1927 building, has a number of original architectural features, including an exposed-brick wall and a skylight over the master sleeping loft.

headline: Louisiana Police Officer Killed in Shooting Before 4-Hour Standoff
abstract: A second officer was shot and remained in critical condition. After negotiations with SWAT teams, the gunman eventually surrendered to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: One police officer was killed and a second critically injured by a gunman in Louisiana on Sunday, in a shooting that started a four-hour standoff between the suspect, SWAT teams and the police, officials said.

headline: California Beaches: A (Photo) Study in Contrasts
abstract: Monday: The weekend’s heat wave may be a window into the future. Also: A talk with Marin County’s health officer, and the closure of the Noriega Hotel.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Marry Someone Nicer Than You
abstract: And more guidance from NYT Parenting.
lead_paragraph: The No. 1 piece of marriage advice I give to my friends is: Marry someone who is nicer than you are. In an ideal world, it means that over time, your natural edges will be sanded down by their kindness.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘New York and Boston Pigeons Don’t Mix’
abstract: In this lesson, students will consider geographic factors that may explain why the pigeons in one part of the East Coast are genetically different from the rest.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “New York and Boston Pigeons Don’t Mix” by Joshua Sokol

headline: How Much Do You Know About Myanmar?
abstract: Can you find Myanmar on a map? What else do you know about this Southeast Asian nation with a population of more than 50 million people?
