lead_paragraph: Can you find Myanmar on a map? What else do you know about this Southeast Asian nation with a population of more than 50 million people?

headline: A Pandemic Gives the Funny Pages a Jolt of Reality
abstract: Daily newspaper cartoonists have finally caught up with the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: As the Covid-19 pandemic spread across the world, many in the United States self-quarantined, and thousands of people died, one section of the daily newspaper seemed wholly untouched by the cataclysmic events: The comics pages. Characters carried on much as they ever did — car-pooling, going to school, wandering into neighbors’ houses. Each comic strip felt like a time capsule from the impossibly faraway era of 2019.

headline: C.D.C. Adds New Symptoms to Its List of Possible Covid-19 Signs
abstract: Chills, muscle pain, sore throat and headache are among the ailments now considered potential indicators of the disease.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has expanded its list of possible symptoms of the coronavirus, a step that reflects the broad variation and unpredictability in the way the illness can affect individual patients.

headline: Jakarta’s Trash Mountain: ‘When People Are Desperate for Jobs, They Come Here’
abstract: The scavengers who make a living picking plastic, metal and even bones from a huge landfill face additional misery as the global economic slowdown closes the recycling centers they count on.
lead_paragraph: BEKASI, Indonesia — Even in the pouring rain, in the middle of the night, they are out scavenging, wearing headlamps to scan a mountain of rotting garbage more than 15 stories high.

headline: Cook Anyway
abstract: One-pot pasta with chicken, tomato risotto, overnight oats: We’ve got recipes for cooking even when you don’t want to cook.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. One of the greatest first lines of a novel, ever: “One evening, it was toward the end of October, Harry Arno said to the woman he’d been seeing on and off the past few years, ‘I’ve made a decision. I’m going to tell you something I’ve never told anyone before in my life.’ ”

headline: Soccer Coach in El Paso Shooting Dies 9 Months Later
abstract: A soccer coach whose extensive injuries kept him hospitalized died nearly nine months after the shooting, the deadliest anti-Latino attack in modern American history.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A soccer coach who was among those shot at a Walmart in El Paso last year in the deadliest anti-Latino attack in modern American history has died nearly nine months later, bringing the death toll from the shooting to 23.

headline: Broadway Adjourns, but the ‘Sing Street’ Band Plays On
abstract: How does a two-and-a-half-hour show become a half-hour online event? Deliberately, haltingly, and with a few technical glitches.
lead_paragraph: “Explode the computer with energy, you beautiful people,” the director Rebecca Taichman said.

headline: Sympathy Cards Are Selling Out
abstract: “It seems just about everyone knows someone who has died,” one maker said, helping to explain why the cards are now hard to find at many stores.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has left retailers scrambling to meet a crushing demand for everything from milk to toilet paper to flour and yeast.

headline: Tracking the Coronavirus
abstract: These eight charts can help us understand the past, present and future of the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.
lead_paragraph: These eight charts can help us understand the past, present and future of the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.

headline: Supreme Court Dismisses Challenge to New York City Gun Ordinance
abstract: Instead of ruling in its first Second Amendment case in a decade, the court found it moot after the city repealed the challenged regulation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would not decide what would have been its first decision on the scope of the Second Amendment in almost a decade, finding that New York City’s repeal of the gun control regulation under challenge had made the matter moot.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The animation that television and movie viewers see today — where individual hairs can be distinguished on a character’s head — is a far cry from the flat, painted cel images people might remember from the cartoons of the 1970s.

headline: A Major Trial for Voting Rights in Florida Is Happening on Video Chat
abstract: A closely watched trial will determine whether felons who have served their time should have to pay outstanding fines before regaining the right to vote.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Only the judge and a couple of his staff members were in the courtroom when he called the trial to order. The plaintiffs, witnesses and lawyers were at home in front of webcams, awaiting their turns to speak.

headline: ‘Afraid to Be a Nurse’: Health Workers Under Attack
abstract: Stigmatized as vectors of contagion in some countries, health care workers have been assaulted, abused and ostracized.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The senior nurse went on national television to make a plea on behalf of her fellow health care workers: Please stop assaulting us.

headline: New York Board of Elections Cancels Democratic Presidential Primary
abstract: The State Board of Elections scrapped the state’s June 23 Democratic nominating contest, citing the risk of spreading coronavirus, in a move opposed by supporters of Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: New York officials canceled the state’s Democratic presidential primary on Monday, prompting an immediate backlash from the campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders and his legion of progressive supporters who had hoped to amass convention delegates and help shape the party’s platform in August.

headline: Supreme Court Rules for Insurers in $12 Billion Obamacare Case
abstract: In an 8-to-1 decision, the court said the government must shield insurers from losses under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled Monday that the federal government must live up to its promise to shield insurance companies from some of the risks they took in participating in the exchanges established by President Barack Obama’s health care law, the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Review: For Sondheim’s 90th Birthday, a Collage of Aching Voices
abstract: The streaming concert “Take Me to the World,” featuring a gallery of musical stars, honors the probing ambivalence of a master songwriter.
lead_paragraph: These ever-surprising songs, mostly written for big Broadway stages, turn out to thrive in close quarters. That was the happy discovery of “Take Me to the World: A Sondheim 90th Birthday Celebration,” a starry, streaming tribute to Stephen Sondheim that began catastrophically and blossomed into something beautiful.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Memoir ‘Becoming’ Will Be a Netflix Documentary
abstract: The film, which follows the former first lady’s book tour after the release of her memoir in 2018, will premiere May 6.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama has worn a number of hats over the past several years: first lady, film producer, best-selling author. She now adds a new title to her résumé: Netflix documentary star.

headline: No, the Best Doesn’t Win
abstract: “It just works” are some of the most powerful words in technology.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Detroit Students Have a Constitutional Right to Literacy, Court Rules
abstract: A major ruling in a lawsuit involving the Detroit public schools comes at a time when school shutdowns are expected to affect poor children most adversely.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in decades, a federal court has declared that American public school students have a constitutional right to an adequate education.

headline: Will Returning Players Be Out of Shape? Soccer May Need More Subs
abstract: FIFA suggested a rule change for when play returns. Plus: bull riding, Formula One and rugby in Australia and New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: When sports do come back, leagues will be trying to pack in as many revenue-generating games as possible. At the same time, many of the players coming out of quarantine may not exactly be in tiptop shape. That combination could prove troublesome.

headline: Top E.R. Doctor Who Treated Virus Patients Dies by Suicide
abstract: “She tried to do her job, and it killed her,” said the father of Dr. Lorna M. Breen, who worked at a Manhattan hospital hit hard by the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: A top emergency room doctor at a Manhattan hospital that treated many coronavirus patients died by suicide on Sunday, her father and the police said.

headline: DaBaby Unseats the Weeknd at No. 1
abstract: The rapper’s latest album, “Blame It on Baby,” opened at the top of the Billboard chart with the equivalent of 124,000 sales.
lead_paragraph: When the North Carolina rapper DaBaby first reached No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart last fall, it was the triumph of a fast-moving newcomer who was a master of meme-ready marketing — that album, “Kirk,” was the third project in 12 months from a musician who had gotten attention by walking the streets of South by Southwest wearing only jewels and an adult diaper.

headline: This Larb Couldn’t Be Easier or More Adaptable
abstract: Use ground pork or chicken, chopped fish fillets or mushrooms in this herby Thai favorite.
lead_paragraph: After a slow, rainy start to the Brooklyn backyard growing season, the mint on my deck is finally powering its way back, taking over the herb box with vim and vigor. I clipped it back to make room for the slower-moving lemon thyme, and ended up with enough to season a batch of Thai larb.

headline: In Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine, an Oxford Group Leaps Ahead
abstract: As scientists at the Jenner Institute prepare for mass clinical trials, new tests show their vaccine to be effective in monkeys.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — In the worldwide race for a vaccine to stop the coronavirus, the laboratory sprinting fastest is at Oxford University.

headline: Arthritis Drug Did Not Help Seriously Ill Covid Patients, Early Data Shows
abstract: The drug, sarilumab, sold as Kevzara, didn’t show benefits to patients who were hospitalized but not on ventilators. The study will continue with critically ill patients.
lead_paragraph: Doctors around the world, trying to save seriously ill coronavirus patients, have been dosing them with rheumatoid arthritis drugs that can squelch immune responses. The theory was that many were dying because their immune systems went into overdrive, creating a fatal storm that attacked their lungs.

headline: Harland Svare, 89, Giants Linebacker and Young Head Coach, Dies
abstract: Brainy more than brawny, he helped put New York in three title games, then became, with the Rams, the youngest head coach in modern N.F.L. history at the time.
lead_paragraph: Harland Svare, who played linebacker in the celebrated defense that helped take the Giants to three N.F.L. championship games in the 1950s and became, at the time, the youngest head coach in the N.F.L.’s modern history when the Los Angeles Rams hired him in 1962, died on April 4 at a nursing home in Steamboat Springs, Colo. He was 89.

headline: Remembering Mike Huckaby, a Towering Figure in Detroit House Music
abstract: The widely beloved D.J., producer and booster championed the sounds of his hometown and served as a trusted tastemaker, in Michigan and around the globe.
lead_paragraph: The death of the Detroit house-music D.J. and producer Mike Huckaby on Friday, at 54, sent a shock wave through the music community he called home. Huckaby — who died from complications of a stroke and Covid-19 at Beaumont Hospital in Detroit’s Royal Oak suburb — was one of global dance music’s most widely beloved figures.

headline: Mindy Kaling’s Netflix Show Tells a New Kind of Story: One Like Hers
abstract: The new series “Never Have I Ever” is a comedy about a first-generation Indian-American teenage girl much like Kaling, updated to a 2020 setting.
lead_paragraph: Mindy Kaling isn’t trying to tell everyone’s story — she’s had to break a lot of boundaries just to tell her own.

headline: Georgia Can’t Copyright Its Entire State Code, the Supreme Court Rules
abstract: In a 5-to-4 ruling with unusual alliances, the court said that annotations cannot be copyrighted if they are the official work of state lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Georgia may not copyright its entire official code, which includes both the state’s laws and annotations interpreting them, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday. The 5-to-4 decision featured unusual alliances and would most likely be widely felt, as about 20 other states have claimed that parts of similar annotated codes are copyrighted.

headline: Samin Nosrat Wants Us to Make Lasagna Together
abstract: The “Salt Fat Acid Heat” author has long gathered people around a table. But what will happen when the festivities move to that sometimes-terrible place, the internet?
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — For as long as I can remember, gathering people around a table has been a sacred act for me.

headline: Boris Johnson, Back on the Job, Urges Caution in Easing Covid-19 Rules
abstract: The British prime minister, newly recovered from the coronavirus, says easing social-distancing rules too quickly would be dangerous.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A pale but vigorous-sounding Prime Minister Boris Johnson returned to work on Monday, declaring that the coronavirus that nearly killed him was like an “unexpected and invisible mugger” the British people had begun to wrestle to the floor but had not yet fully disabled.

headline: New Jersey Governor Offers Timeline to Begin Reopening Within Weeks
abstract: Gov. Philip Murphy warned that the state faces financial “Armageddon” — and could be unable to pay teachers, firefighters and police officers.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Philip D. Murphy on Monday sketched out benchmarks New Jersey will have to reach before the coronavirus lockdown can be lifted, even as he warned of a financial “Armageddon” that could leave the state unable to pay its teachers, firefighters and police officers.

headline: Diagnosing and Treating Covid-19
abstract: Readers urge caution in the use of oximeters, see promise in a new kind of UV lamp and lament the surge in prescriptions of two antiviral drugs touted by the president.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Films to Heal a Broken Moment
abstract: These characters find reasons to carry on in the face of hardship or crisis — examples that can help in our own difficult time.
lead_paragraph: As endings go, the one invented by the Swedish director Lukas Moodysson for his gentle, unassuming comedy “Together” (2001) is just about perfect. It’s not a spoiler to share it: Already, the members of a 1975 commune have squabbled over everything from eating meat to owning a TV and the need for wearing underwear in the kitchen. Their children, often the most mature people in the room, look on, mortified. One morning after the worst of the infighting has ended, everybody heads outside for a sloppy, impromptu soccer match under a light snowfall — adults and kids, women and men, socialists and materialists. In the chaos of the game, all is forgiven.

headline: Covid-19: Lessons From the Yanomami
abstract: The tragedy unfolding in the Amazon echoes what all human inhabitants of the planet are suffering.
lead_paragraph: The Yanomami people are no strangers to fatal epidemics, and yet on April 9, many around the world were shocked to learn that Covid-19 had taken its first victim among this relatively isolated Indigenous people of the Amazon rainforest along the Brazil-Venezuela border.

headline: We Can’t Police Our Way Out of a Pandemic
abstract: Punitive responses will just burden those who have already been hit hard by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This month, Philadelphia transit police officers violently forced a man off a bus for not wearing a mask. In New York, Gov. Andrew Cuomo raised the maximum fine from $500 to $1,000 for breaking social-distancing protocols, and Mayor Bill de Blasio has deployed Police Department officers to enforce them and make arrests. In Kentucky, judges are ordering people who have tested positive for the coronavirus and have broken quarantine to be fitted with ankle monitors — with the threat of arrest if they leave their homes. In Florida, a judge ruled that people arrested for breaking quarantine can be held without bail.

headline: Mitch McConnell Has No Idea What Bankruptcy Actually Means
abstract: Cities should avoid bankruptcy. It hasn’t helped Detroit.
lead_paragraph: Cities across the country are facing a red-ink cascade. On April 22, Mitch McConnell recommended that cities and states try bankruptcy if they’re struggling during the coronavirus pandemic. This is a terrible idea, and we don’t need to look farther than Detroit to see why.

headline: Hurricanes Are Reshaping Evolution Across the Caribbean
abstract: A new study of lizards in countries struck by hurricanes suggests cataclysmic weather can reshape entire species.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Colin Donihue, a biologist, released a sober scientific paper along with a series of endlessly GIF-able videos. They showed Caribbean anole lizards flailing in the wind from a leaf blower, holding on to a stick for dear life, not unlike the kitten in the classic “Hang In There, Baby” poster.

headline: Commissioner Resigns After He Threw a Cat During Zoom Meeting
abstract: “OK, first, I’d like to introduce my cat,” said a planning commissioner in Vallejo, Calif., lifting it close to the camera and then, with two hands, tossing it off screen.
lead_paragraph: The city Planning Commission meeting in Vallejo, Calif., last week followed the same humdrum pattern of so many municipal meetings: There was the Pledge of Allegiance and a roll call, followed by various reports.

headline: Bernard Gersten, Offstage Star of Nonprofit Theater, Dies at 97
abstract: He helped run Joseph Papp’s Public Theater (shepherding “A Chorus Line”) and the New York Shakespeare Festival, then helped revive Lincoln Center Theater.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Gersten, a canny executive who helped turn two of New York’s nonprofit theater companies into powerhouse producers and presenters of award-winning plays and musicals, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 97. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his daughter Jenny Gersten said.

headline: New Zealand, U.S. Coronavirus Deaths, Kim Jong-un: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: In Rare Admission, U.S. Military Says Strikes Killed 2 Civilians in Somalia
abstract: The statement was a rare acknowledgment from the military of civilian casualties in its campaign against the Shabab extremist group. The airstrike was in February 2019.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon acknowledged on Monday that an American military strike in Somalia more than a year ago killed two civilians and injured three more.

headline: The Lightest, Brothiest Soup for When You Can’t Eat Another Bite
abstract: Kind of hungry, but exhausted by the mere thought of eating? Alison Roman has the perfect thing for when you’re in appetite purgatory.
lead_paragraph: Even a person as enthusiastic as I am about home cooking can feel fatigue, and six going on seven weeks of this quarantine, I am feeling it. It’s not so much the cooking. It’s the eating — probably because I am doing it all day long.

headline: Francisco Mendez, Boxing Gym Owner and Mentor, Dies at 61
abstract: Arriving from Mexico, he found his calling outside the ring and attracted a following of clients with different backgrounds and goals.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: In Seoul, the Art World Gets Back to Business
abstract: Art galleries remain shuttered around the world but in South Korea, they reopen — with contact tracing and masks. Welcome to the post-Covid-19 world.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — “I wouldn’t say things are totally back to normal,” explained Passion Lim, taking in the scene on Thursday at the opening for Billy Childish paintings at the Lehmann Maupin gallery. “But it’s a start,” he added.

headline: Only Children Are Not Doomed
abstract: Some parents think siblings make kids happier. Others say singletons are better off. Emily Oster looks at what the data says.
lead_paragraph: In the home school I’m running here in quarantine, recess starts at 9:30 a.m. sharp. My two kids go outside while I watch them through a window on conference calls. Every day, I spend about half the time thinking it’s so great they have each other (during the game “try to distract mom”) and half the time forcibly separating them (during the game “fight with sticks”).

headline: Get the Kids Back to School. Please!
abstract: A parent wonders what happens if schools don’t reopen in the fall. Also: A 9/11-type compensation fund for medical workers; Christian health care sharing ministries.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bruce Myers, Actor With Voice of a ‘Stradivarius,’ Dies at 78
abstract: He was a stalwart member of the group of actors who worked with the director Peter Brook. Mr. Myers died of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Airlines and Hotels Reach Out to Their Top Spenders
abstract: They’re giving those customers an extra year to accumulate the points that result in free upgrades, breakfasts, club access and other perks. And that may be just the beginning.
lead_paragraph: Let’s just say that no one is likely to earn airline or hotel elite status this year, not with travel dropping to near nothing and no resumption in sight.

headline: Win 30 Minutes With a Chef
abstract: The #AskChefsAnything auction will give bidders a chance for a one-on-one with their favorite chef, writer or other food expert, with the proceeds benefiting immigrant workers.
lead_paragraph: Chefs and food writers are up for grabs, for a price. Winners in this online auction will get a 30-minute one-on-one with the chef or writer. The #AskChefsAnything auction starts Wednesday at 10 a.m. and continues through 8 p.m. on May 3, when the winning bidders will be announced. The minimum bid is $100. The funds raised in New York will be used to help immigrant workers and their families in the Bronx (through the Mercy Center). Other cities have come onboard, including Los Angeles (auction begins May 6) and Philadelphia (May 13), and their aid workers will also be beneficiaries. Among the experts up for auction are Eric Ripert, Enrique Olvera, Alex Raij, Danny Bowien, Dana Cowin, Jody Williams, Riad Nasr, Dan Kluger, Dan Barber, Einat Admony and Justin Smillie.

headline: A Cast Album I Love: ‘The Secret Garden’
abstract: We continue our cast album series with more recommendations for wonderful musicals to listen to at home.
lead_paragraph: Recently, The Times’s co-chief theater critics put together a musical cast recording starter kit for those of us stuck at home — 10 cast albums they’d take with them to a desert island. We asked some of their fellow critics to pick one cast album each and extol its pleasures. Laura Collins-Hughes wrote about the Shakespeare in the Park production of “Twelfth Night” and Elisabeth Vincentelli sang the praises of “Hair.”

headline: N.Y.C. Deaths Reach 6 Times the Normal Level, Far More Than Coronavirus Count Suggests
abstract: There have been some 20,000 more deaths than would be expected over all, and thousands more than have been captured in the city’s official coronavirus statistics.
lead_paragraph: There have been some 20,000 more deaths than would be expected over all, and thousands more than have been captured in the city’s official coronavirus statistics.

headline: Brooklyn Kitchen Takes Its Cooking Classes Online
abstract: Brunch is the next course on offer, with a real-time Zoom tutorial, just in time for Mother’s Day.
lead_paragraph: For the pandemic, Taylor Erkkinen, an owner of the Brooklyn Kitchen, has taken her cooking classes online. But, like the hands-on courses she was giving in her Industry City kitchen studio, they are limited to 20 students. They’re held on Zoom so students can ask questions and get answers in real time. On Saturday at noon, she’ll teach a brunch class with a menu of granola, poached eggs with hollandaise, hash, Dutch baby pancakes and Bloody Marys. Before you sign up, you are told what ingredients and equipment you’re required to have on hand.

headline: Marmalades Make a Mother’s Day Gift
abstract: Josephine’s Feast sells the preserves, in four citrus flavors, in gift boxes or individually.
lead_paragraph: Marmalade lovers can rejoice. Even in pandemic seclusion, the morning toast or late afternoon plate of cheese can glow with the citric sunshine of bittersweet Seville orange, rich blood orange, fragrant Cara Cara orange or tangy Meyer lemon. Laura O’Brien, the preserver who owns Josephine’s Feast, has introduced a gift box with 8-ounce jars of all four varieties, suitable for Mother’s Day.

headline: Chocolates for Quarantine Teatime
abstract: Chocolat Moderne sells bonbons flavored with the tastes of England.
lead_paragraph: The theme that the Manhattan chocolatier Joan Coukos, of Chocolat Moderne, has selected for this collection of bonbons is English desserts. Each of the candies, decorated with a flower, has a creamy filling to evoke teatime at Claridge’s: sticky toffee; trifle, with raspberry and marzipan; and banoffee pie, with salted caramel and banana ganache.

headline: Stocks and a Jar Full of Soup Mix-Ins
abstract: The chef Marco Canora’s broth restaurants are shipping brodos nationwide, and delivering jars of prepared ingredients for its broths locally.
lead_paragraph: The chef Marco Canora, who owns Hearth in the East Village and who has also opened a string of Brodo storefronts selling broth (brodo in Italian), has created new soup kits for pickup and limited delivery from the Brodo shops. They consist of big Instagram-friendly jars layered with ingredients like cooked grains, pulses, vegetables, greens and seasonings, including sofrito, the base made with carrots, celery onions and garlic. Add them to a simmering pot of one of Mr. Canora’s plain beef, chicken or mushroom broths, and you have hearty soup for two to four. Bolster them with slivers of meat, tofu or chicken, if you like. Individual containers of Brodo broths are also sold frozen for delivery nationwide.

headline: Job or Health? Restarting the Economy Threatens to Worsen Economic Inequality
abstract: The coronavirus recession has exacerbated the racial and income divides in America. Lifting restrictions too soon will make them worse and leave workers with a bleak choice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Efforts to quickly restart economic activity risk further dividing Americans into two major groups along socioeconomic lines: one that has the power to control its exposure to the coronavirus outbreak and another that is forced to choose between potential sickness or financial devastation.

headline: Attorney General Sees Too Much Secrecy in Epstein Estate
abstract: The top prosecutor in the U.S. Virgin Islands says the estate needs to provide more detail about Jeffrey Epstein’s finances and is insisting on clauses that could protect others from wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: Some of the same furtive techniques that Jeffrey Epstein employed in life are showing up in the litigation over dividing up the wealth he left behind when he died.

headline: The Chef Hooni Kim Discusses His New Book
abstract: The author of “My Korea” will talk with the food writer Andrew Friedman in an online event sponsored by the Korea Society.
lead_paragraph: The Korea Society, a New York-based nonprofit organization that promotes cultural exchange with South Korea, is celebrating the chef Hooni Kim, who owns Danji and Hanjan in Manhattan. The food writer Andrew Friedman will interview Mr. Kim about his new book, “My Korea: Traditional Flavors, Modern Recipes,” on a free webcast Thursday at 6:30 p.m., hosted by the society.

headline: Everyone Is Giving Away Cash on Instagram
abstract: As the coronavirus continues to disrupt lives and livelihoods, influencers are offering free money to followers — and gaining a lot more in return.
lead_paragraph: On March 18, as states sent nonessential workers home and companies prepared to cut costs, the fitness influencer Paige Hathaway posted a message to her more than 4 million followers on Instagram.

headline: Behind the Wheel, Women Are Safer Drivers Than Men
abstract: Compared with women, male drivers of cars and vans were involved in twice as many fatal accidents.
lead_paragraph: Women tend to be better drivers than men — much better, judging by the number of deaths they cause on the road.

headline: Leandro Barbosa’s Family Grew During the Pandemic
abstract: Barbosa, a Brazilian basketball player and one-time N.B.A. champion, and his wife found out they had the coronavirus shortly before she gave birth to their daughter.
lead_paragraph: Leandro Barbosa had lofty goals for 2020. After playing 14 seasons in the N.B.A., Barbosa had hoped to make one more trip to the Olympics with Brazil’s national basketball team — his third — at age 37.

headline: Watch This: ‘Never Have I Ever’
abstract: The new Netflix series was cocreated by Mindy Kaling. Or watch another, albeit darker, new coming-of-age story on Hulu, “Normal People.”
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Remember the Slain, Home Alone or Online En Masse
abstract: With Israel’s cemeteries closed, Memorial Day mourning had to adapt to the coronavirus lockdown. An alternative ceremony bringing together Israelis and Palestinians attracted 170,000 people online.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Civil-defense sirens sounded at 8 p.m. to mark the start of Israel’s solemn Memorial Day observance, but unlike in ordinary years, when the moment is marked by a sudden halt to traffic and an abrupt quieting of nightlife, Monday night’s remembrance of fallen soldiers or victims of terrorism came with most of the country already on lockdown.

headline: ‘It Was Just Too Much’: How Remote Learning Is Breaking Parents
abstract: For the adults in the house, trying to do their own jobs while helping children with class work has become one of the most trying aspects of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Levin’s son, Linus, 7, was supposed to be doing math. Instead, he pretended to take a shower in the living room, rubbing a dry eraser under his arms like a bar of soap, which upset his 5-year-old sister, distracting her from her coloring.

headline: Donald Trump: Who He Is and What He Stands For
abstract: The 45th president, a deeply divisive leader, was running for re-election on immigration, trade and the economy. Then the coronavirus crisis hit.
lead_paragraph: The 45th president, a deeply divisive leader, was running for re-election on immigration, trade and the economy. Then the coronavirus crisis hit.

headline: ‘Quarantine Fatigue’ Has More People Going Outside
abstract: New research shows that people are venturing out more frequently, and traveling farther from home.
lead_paragraph: For more than a month, governors in a vast majority of states have urged people to stay indoors and away from one another, critical measures needed to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Driver Rams 2 Police Motorcyclists in a Paris Suburb
abstract: The collision was intentional, and the officers were gravely injured, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A motorist deliberately drove his car into two police motorcyclists on patrol in a Paris suburb on Monday, gravely injuring both, police unions said. One of the officers sustained a fractured skull and has been placed in a medically induced coma.

headline: Harold Reid, Bedrock Voice of the Statler Brothers, Dies at 80
abstract: With his resonant bass, comic timing and business acumen, he was the Statlers’ de facto leader as they climbed the country music charts for decades.
lead_paragraph: Harold Reid, whose resonant bass, comic touch and business acumen helped make the Statler Brothers a top-grossing touring act and a steady presence on the country music charts for decades, died on Friday at his home in Staunton, Va. He was 80.

headline: Small Business, Texas, Vaccine: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Peacocks and Vultures Are Circling the Deficit
abstract: The only fiscal thing to fear is deficit fear itself.
lead_paragraph: Almost a decade has passed since I published a column, “Myths of Austerity,” warning that deficit alarmism would delay recovery from the Great Recession — which it did. Unfortunately, that kind of alarmism seems to be making a comeback.

headline: Bankers Rebuke S.B.A. as Loan System Crashes in Flood of Applications
abstract: The government started taking applications Monday for a further $310 billion in emergency funds, and quickly ran into technical problems.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after a $310 billion aid program for small companies opened for business on Monday, the online portal for submitting applications crashed. And it kept crashing all day, much to the frustration of bankers around the country who were trying — and failing — to apply on behalf of desperate clients.

headline: Does the Biden Bump Have More to Do With Trump?
abstract: Polling in two states that many Democrats assumed were lost shows Joe Biden with a narrow lead over President Trump. But the race is moving toward Democrats for reasons that have very little to do with Mr. Biden.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: In Kayleigh McEnany, Trump Taps a Press Fighter for the Coronavirus Era
abstract: Kayleigh McEnany saw Donald J. Trump as her ticket to stardom. She has been fighting for him for much of her adult life, now as the president’s fourth press secretary.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]

headline: Republicans, Who Do You Think Is Bailing Out Your State?
abstract: State and local costs of dealing with the pandemic are skyrocketing as revenues plunge.
lead_paragraph: As negotiations over the next coronavirus relief package heat up, a key point of contention — perhaps the key point — is whether Congress will provide meaningful aid to struggling state and local governments.

headline: Briefings Were ‘Not Worth the Time,’ Trump Said. But He Couldn’t Stay Away.
abstract: Just hours after his own White House officially canceled his planned appearance on Monday, the lure of the cameras in the Rose Garden proved too hard to resist.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To the surprise of exactly no one, President Trump resumed his daily coronavirus news briefings on Monday, just two days after tweeting that they were “not worth the time & effort” and just hours after his own White House officially canceled the planned appearance.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: A promising vaccine in development at Oxford University could be distributed as soon as September.
lead_paragraph: Here’s promising news in the worldwide race to develop a vaccine to ward off the coronavirus. The Jenner Institute at Oxford University has one that seems to work in lab animals and is ready to test its effectiveness in humans, if regulators approve.

headline: Reopening Plans Across U.S. Are Creating Confusing Patchwork
abstract: Several states, including Texas and Florida, have stay-at-home orders expiring this week. “That executive order has done its job to slow the growth of Covid-19,” Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Governors across the country forged ahead Monday with plans to reopen their economies, even as the nation hit a grim milestone of 50,000 deaths from the coronavirus and public health experts warned against lifting stay-at-home orders too quickly.

headline: Officials Say Limits on Virus Relief Funds for States Are Too Tight
abstract: Lawmakers and other officials are seeking more flexibility in spending federal emergency aid even as Republicans resist allocating more dollars.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers and state officials say the Trump administration is unreasonably restricting how local governments can spend federal aid as they struggle to stay afloat during the pandemic and Republicans raise doubts about providing added financial relief to hard-pressed communities.

headline: Trump Disinfectant Remarks Echo Claims by Miracle-Cure Quacks
abstract: Doctors and public health officials fear the attention could boost purveyors of dangerous elixirs who push ‘miracle cures’ with no basis in science.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s public statements about using disinfectants to potentially treat the coronavirus have put him in the company of pseudoscientists and purveyors of phony elixirs who promote and sell industrial bleach as a “miracle cure” for autism, malaria and a long list of medical conditions.

headline: Trump Vows More Coronavirus Testing, but Less Than What May Be Needed
abstract: The president’s announcement came after weeks of him insisting that states had plenty of tests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, under growing pressure to expand coronavirus testing as states move to reopen their economies, unveiled a new plan on Monday to ramp up the federal government’s help to states, but his proposal runs far short of what most public health experts say is necessary.

headline: John Grisham Returns to Camino Island, This Time in Hurricane Season
abstract: In “Camino Winds,” a bookstore owner and two other characters team up to solve a murder and the mystery behind it.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, John Grisham came up with a new formula for success. He ditched the lawyers to write an actual beach book, sand and all. This wouldn’t be much of a departure for some authors, but coming from Grisham it was a delightful surprise — all the more so because the sand was on the fictitious Camino Island, a Florida resort featuring one of the world’s great bookstores, stolen F. Scott Fitzgerald manuscripts, a colony of gossipy writers and a lot of languid vacation time. It also starred a woman, Mercer Mann, who put the book squarely in Reese Witherspoon country.

headline: ‘La Vie en Rose’
abstract: Joel Fagliano plays with sound.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Maybe you solve your crossword puzzles and then just go about your day, but I am a highly suggestible person and find that all sorts of things bubble up for me as I fill in the squares. And they tend to stay with me.

headline: New York Attorney General Scrutinizes Amazon for Firing Warehouse Worker
abstract: The attorney general said in a letter that Amazon may have violated laws in firing a Staten Island worker who led a protest against the company.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon may have violated federal worker safety laws and New York State’s whistle-blower protections when it fired an employee from its Staten Island warehouse who protested the company’s response to the coronavirus outbreak, according to a letter the office of the New York attorney general, Letitia James, sent the company last week.

headline: Corrections: April 28, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 28, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on April 19 about life during the next year of the pandemic misidentified the source of an epidemiological model that estimated the United States would suffer 100,000 to 240,000 deaths during the coronavirus epidemic. The estimate was made by the White House, not the University of Washington’s Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Truly in the Trenches,’ Doctor Dies by Suicide
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 28, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Make sure she’s praised as a hero, because she was. She’s a casualty just as much as anyone else who has died.”

headline: 2 Sought $4 Million for Face Masks That Didn’t Exist, U.S. Says
abstract: Two Southern California men face fraud charges after putting fake 3M labels on empty boxes that they said were filled with masks, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: They wanted $4 million for a stockpile of face masks, but prosecutors say that the protective gear advertised by two Southern California men did not exist, and that they went as far as to put fake 3M labels on empty boxes.

headline: European Soccer Tries to Find a Way Back, or a Way Out
abstract: The Netherlands has canceled its season. Germany wants to play again next month. But European soccer is finding that clarity tends not to last long.
lead_paragraph: At least, it seemed, the Dutch had made a decision. Alone among Europe’s soccer leagues, they now had some clarity about what the immediate future held. On Friday morning, the Netherlands became the first country in Europe to call off its soccer season. There would be no champion crowned, no teams condemned to relegation. It was over.

headline: ‘Blood Quantum’ Review: Inspired Splatter
abstract: This Canadian zombie movie is more notable for its cultural backdrop and moody vibe than for its gore.
lead_paragraph: You think you’ve seen every way to dispatch a zombie, and then someone applies a chainsaw to a skull in a particularly satisfying manner.

headline: Study Finds Coronavirus in Tiny Airborne Droplets in Wuhan
abstract: Even when governments don’t force people to stay home, fear does. Spain, France and Greece have announced plans to restart daily life, with caveats.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.

headline: Consumer Survey Shows Continued Concern
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Coronavirus, Vaccine, U.S. Death Toll: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘The Assistant’ and ‘Coronavirus: Explained’
abstract: Julia Garner stars in a #MeToo thriller, while a new limited series examines the current health crisis.
lead_paragraph: THE ASSISTANT (2020) Rent or buy on Amazon or iTunes. In this low-key thriller by the filmmaker Kitty Green, Jane (Julia Garner) is an aspiring film producer working as a junior assistant to a major entertainment mogul, who remains unseen but is clearly based on Harvey Weinstein. Jane spends her days doing menial tasks while two other male assistants casually dismiss and disrespect her. The movie slowly simmers with tension as she becomes aware of the abuse and oppression going on in the office and works up the courage to take a stand. Jeannette Catsoulis named the movie a Critic’s Pick in her review for The New York Times, describing it as “a painstaking examination of the way individual slights can coalesce into a suffocating miasma of harassment.”

headline: A Time to Save the Sick and Rescue the Planet
abstract: With closer cooperation among nations, the head of the United Nations argues, we could stop a pandemic faster and slow climate change.
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic is the biggest test the world has faced since World War II. There is a natural tendency in the face of crisis to take care of one’s own first. But true leadership understands that there are times to think big and more generously. Such thinking was behind the Marshall Plan and the formation of the United Nations after World War II. This is also such a moment. We must work together as societies and as an international community to save lives, ease suffering and lessen the shattering economic and social consequences of Covid-19.

headline: Word + Quiz: harridan
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Trevor Noah Doesn’t Think Trump Knows What Bleach Is
abstract: The “Daily Show” host says the reason the president doesn’t understand disinfectants is that he’s never personally cleaned anything.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now..

headline: Abortion by Telemedicine: A Growing Option as Access to Clinics Wanes
abstract: The coronavirus has created a surge in demand for telemedicine of all types — including for a quietly expanding program for terminating pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Dale was grateful she could end her pregnancy at home.

headline: Ramadan in Isolation
abstract: Coronavirus is transforming Ramadan this year. How has it affected the religious or spiritual traditions you or your community observe?
lead_paragraph: For the world’s 1.8 billion Muslims, the holy month of Ramadan, which began last week, is a social and spiritual high point, a time to gather with friends and family, and to focus on fasting, prayer and scripture.

headline: Mekhi Becton, the Jets’ Top Draft Pick, ‘Moves People Like Furniture’
abstract: Becton is 6-foot-7 and weighs 364 pounds, but his array of skills tipped the scales for the Jets.
lead_paragraph: When Mekhi Becton signed up for the football team at Highland Springs High School in Virginia, he picked wide receiver and tight end as his positions. He was 6 feet 3 inches tall and weighed 215 pounds.

headline: Peru’s Queen of Quechua Rap Wants to Rescue Indigenous Culture With Her Music
abstract: Renata Flores, 19, is part of a generation of Peruvian musicians combining the bouncing beats of Latin trap, rap and reggaeton with the sounds, and language, of the Andean countryside.
lead_paragraph: The music video begins with the sweeping views of the snow-capped Andes Mountains and the whistle of the region’s traditional wind instruments.

headline: Marc Benioff’s $25 Million Blitz to Buy Protective Gear From China
abstract: A call from a university chancellor set in motion a private-sector effort to procure 50 million masks, gowns and swabs for American medical facilities.
lead_paragraph: Sam Hawgood, the chancellor of the University of California, San Francisco, was getting concerned.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Reopening Has Begun. No One Is Sure What Happens Next.’
abstract: In this lesson, students will explore the challenges that come with gradually restarting businesses and evaluate their state’s plan to address them.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Reopening Has Begun. No One Is Sure What Happens Next.” By Ben Casselman

headline: Unified in Coronavirus Lockdown, India Splinters Over Reopening
abstract: As India starts loosening restrictions, a once-broad consensus among leaders on how to proceed has weakened — and many people are staying home anyway.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When the Indian government eased coronavirus restrictions last week, allowing many shops to reopen in rural parts of the country, Uday Shankar Sharma, a retail store owner in a small farming village, said he had no intention of complying.

headline: What Are Your Hopes for Summer 2020? What Are Your Worries?
abstract: As the coronavirus pandemic continues, how do you think this summer will be different from others? What are you still looking forward to doing this summer? What possible changes are you concerned about?
lead_paragraph: How do you typically spend your summer?

headline: New & Noteworthy, From Galileo to ‘Dunces’
abstract: A selection of recent books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: WHITEOUT CONDITIONS, by Tariq Shah. (Two Dollar Radio, paper, $14.99.) “Funerals are kind of fun,” the narrator of Shah’s debut admits in the opening pages. “I’ve cultivated a taste.” Then his childhood friend dies, and the narrator must brave a blizzard to pay his respects.

headline: This Is What It’s Like to Be Homeless in New York City
abstract: A journalist introduces readers to a new mother struggling mightily, against all odds, to find a permanent place to live.
lead_paragraph: THIS IS ALL I GOTA New Mother’s Search for HomeBy Lauren Sandler

headline: When Airplanes and Zeppelins Competed to Conquer the Skies
abstract: Alexander Rose’s “Empires of the Sky” recounts the race to dominate the air.
lead_paragraph: EMPIRES OF THE SKYZeppelins, Airplanes, and Two Men’s Epic Duel to Rule the WorldBy Alexander Rose

headline: When the Town’s Future Is an Obsolete Factory
abstract: Robert Perisic’s novel “No-Signal Area” is set in an unnamed Balkan country struggling to recover after war.
lead_paragraph: NO-SIGNAL AREABy Robert Perisic

headline: How Do You Explain Henry Kissinger?
abstract: In “The Inevitability of Tragedy,” Barry Gewen traces the roots of political realism to the generation of Jewish intellectuals who fled Nazi Germany.
lead_paragraph: THE INEVITABILITY OF TRAGEDYHenry Kissinger and His WorldBy Barry Gewen

headline: What Phone Calls Have Given Me That Video Chat Can’t
abstract: Just as I’m imagining their environment, their clothes, their gestures, they’re imagining me. We’re making a cocoon where only the two of us live.
lead_paragraph: My friendship with Alex began as most still do: in person. We met as volunteers at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in SoHo, where we talked about novels while alphabetizing the shelves. Before long, we were in friend-love: walking my dog together in Central Park, working together in coffee shops and going on movie dates — until a little over a year ago, when Alex and her husband moved back to Australia. This had always been their plan, yet anticipating the loss didn’t dull the experience of it. Our friendship could have transitioned to a neutered, text-only version of itself at that point, as many do, or even ended altogether.

headline: Amid Covid-19, Should I Shop for Myself or Opt for Delivery?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether you’re helping more people by having goods delivered or by going to the store yourself — and more.
lead_paragraph: In this time of lockdown, is it more ethical to order necessary items for delivery or to go get them myself? There are risks to others in both scenarios — whether to the workers or myself and my family. Is ordering for delivery helping to provide work for the delivery people or burdening that system by taking time away from those at higher risk than me? Anne, Boston

headline: A Writer Pursues His Subjects as a Hunter Stalks His Prey
abstract: “The Celestial Hunter,” the eighth volume in Roberto Calasso’s ongoing literary project, is an exploration of hunting via literature and mythology.
lead_paragraph: THE CELESTIAL HUNTERBy Roberto Calasso

headline: How to Get Your Balance
abstract: Let go of the agitation from distraction. Trust your body.
lead_paragraph: “Your head is extremely heavy,” says Mia Noblet, 25, who holds multiple world records for slacklining, including one for walking blindfolded on a one-inch-wide nylon strap stretched 1,539 feet between two towering rock formations in Moab, Utah. To get your balance, stretch out your arms loosely to either side like wings, elbows bent, palms forward. If you’re becoming off-kilter, feel free to wave your arms, jut a hip to one side or even kick a leg out — but always keep your head directly above your line. Where your head goes, the rest of your body will follow.

headline: A Novel Imagines the Life of the Man Who Discovered Camus
abstract: In “Our Riches,” the Algerian novelist Kaouther Adimi revisits Edmond Charlot and his legendary bookshop, as well as her country’s turbulent past.
lead_paragraph: OUR RICHES By Kaouther Adimi

headline: Can the Trump Campaign Rewrite the Story of the Trump Presidency?
abstract: Brad Parscale sees a path to victory through discounted Facebook ads and keeping Trump on TV.

headline: Ohio’s G.O.P. Governor Splits From Trump, and Rises in Popularity
abstract: Mike DeWine, a low-key career politician, has followed health experts’ guidance as Ohio confronts the coronavirus. His constituents are overwhelmingly appreciative.
lead_paragraph: For 40 years, Mike DeWine rose steadily if blandly up the ladder of Ohio politics, finally landing his dream job as governor. He took office last year as a familiar figure in the state, not because of any indelible political identity, but because, at 72, he had been around forever.

headline: A Letter From the Contents of My Bra Drawer
abstract: It’s been weeks since we’ve seen each other.
lead_paragraph: Dear Elizabeth,

headline: Here’s What to Trim (and What Not to Touch) From Your Budget Right Now
abstract: Your finances may be tight, but there are helpful changes you can make during the coronavirus lockdown.
lead_paragraph: So much has already been cut out of my life in the past month. Restaurant meals, birthday parties, a trip to Joshua Tree, haircuts, yoga classes — even a priceless hug from a friend. But when my work dried up overnight in early April, I realized that one more thing needed to be cut: my expenses.

headline: Tuesday’s Livestreaming Events: ‘Melrose Place’ Reunion and Story Time With Tom Hardy
abstract: Appointment viewing is back. Find out what online events to look for today, and when to tune in.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the best events happening on Tuesday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern Standard). Updated daily.

headline: With Campuses Closed, College Tours Move Online
abstract: Colleges are ghost towns, but officials are trying to reach prospective students with virtual visits and Zoom meetings. Can they replicate that face-to-face feeling?
lead_paragraph: Virtual coffees with college students for high school juniors. Zoom sessions between applicants and admissions officers. Student guides offering welcoming messages in video selfies and scenic views of university campuses captured by drones.

headline: Coming Soon: New Fiction From Simone de Beauvoir
abstract: “The Inseparables,” a novel Beauvoir abandoned in 1954, tells the story of a doomed friendship based on one from her own childhood.
lead_paragraph: In her 1963 memoir, “Force of Circumstance,” Simone de Beauvoir made a fleeting and tantalizing reference to a work of fiction she had abandoned. She described her attempt to write a story centered on her best friend Zaza, who died young of viral encephalitis.

headline: Jodie Comer on Her Killer Beauty Regimen
abstract: Pilates and chocolate are keeping the “Killing Eve” actress serene while she shelters in place.
lead_paragraph: Killer acting role leads to killer skin care? Not exactly, but both are true for Jodie Comer, who is known for her role as the sociopathic but charismatic assassin Villanelle on the darkly comic “Killing Eve,” just back for Season 3. These days, Ms. Comer, 27, is sheltering in place with her family in Liverpool, England, where she grew up. Hear what she’s putting on and also cooking up.

headline: A ‘Little Family’ Against the World
abstract: In Ishmael Beah’s new novel, a makeshift home of adolescents is forced to confront the ugliest side of adulthood.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE FAMILYBy Ishmael Beah

headline: How Congress Can Vote Remotely
abstract: The people’s voice must be heard through Congress, no matter the crisis.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has caused unprecedented change to every facet of our lives. Millions of Americans are working remotely, performing the essential functions of their jobs away from their workplaces, often at home. But right now members of Congress can’t perform some of the key functions of their job because they are back in their home states and districts, unable to cast votes, debate or hold remote hearings.

headline: A Mother, a Pandemic and Scorched Rice
abstract: “You have an American amount of rice,” my mother told me as news of the coronavirus intensified. “Go get the biggest bag you can find.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m sending you money to buy rice,” my mom texted me in early March. She had gone to the West Coast to help my sister with her new baby and stayed when it became too risky to fly. As news of the coronavirus intensified, so did her fretting.

headline: Let’s Get Real About Coronavirus Tests
abstract: There aren’t enough. Many are shoddy. Most aren’t even designed to tell us what we really want to know.
lead_paragraph: In the world’s ongoing quest to respond to the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, one of the tools most often invoked and hailed is testing — testing for current infections, to determine who is ill and contagious, and testing for antibodies, a sign of past infection and possibly, too, of future immunity.

headline: How Trump and His Team Covered Up the Coronavirus in Five Days
abstract: The president and senior officials manipulated Americans and played down the severity of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The strongest critics of the Trump administration’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic point to its flat-footedness and the consequences of time lost.

headline: My 4-Year-Old Thinks She’s a Sous Chef. I’m Trying to Remain Calm.
abstract: On trying to shape a happy childhood out of hard times.
lead_paragraph: I am what you might generously call “a skilled home cook.” I can follow recipes, copy pictures, execute a modest range of techniques and improvise a little with decent results. But I am no virtuoso; I have no particular talent for inventing dishes or harmonizing flavors, and even less for creating food that, arriving on the plate, looks appetizing. But it’s all edible, and for a good stretch of years it was my most reliably relaxing hobby.

headline: The Community Cookbook Is Reborn for a Time of Scarcity and Sharing
abstract: Cobbled-together home recipe collections were once the province of church groups and Scout troops, but now they’re uniting Americans of all stripes.
lead_paragraph: The chef and artist Krystal Mack’s favorite cookbook has no beautiful photos of food. Its recipes aren’t professionally tested. Its authors aren’t food writers or restaurateurs.

headline: Nursing Homes Were a Disaster Waiting to Happen
abstract: Long before Covid-19, poor care and lax standards were widespread and well known.
lead_paragraph: It was clear almost from the outset that the elderly and frail were in the greatest danger from Covid-19. And it was clear to anyone familiar with American nursing homes that they would not be up to the task of protecting their older and infirm residents.

headline: Want to Learn French? Italian? Russian? There’s No Time Like the Present
abstract: We may not be thrilled with our housebound conditions, but what better opportunity for learning a foreign language?
lead_paragraph: It’s a classic travel fantasy: flying to another country to learn a language through a combination of classes and swanning around, ordering meals at sidewalk cafes, shopping at street markets, slipping into darkened theaters. Yet with much of the world under stay-at-home orders, that dream may seem more distant than ever.

headline: Finally There’s Time to Read (or at Least Organize Your Books)
abstract: Books tell a story about who you are. Here’s how to make it an interesting one.
lead_paragraph: Looking to make the most of time spent stuck at home, many of us are turning to books.

headline: Hundreds of Miles From Home, Nurses Fight Coronavirus on New York’s Front Lines
abstract: “Every day you go in and you’re like, ‘Can I do this for one more day?’’’ a nurse from North Carolina said.
lead_paragraph: Each night at dusk, in an otherwise desolate Times Square, hundreds of nurses in blue scrubs gather to board buses that take them to hospitals across New York City.

headline: They’re Still Working at the Airports, and They’re Scared
abstract: At least 17 workers at New York’s airports have died from the coronavirus, and dozens more have been infected.
lead_paragraph: Since the coronavirus outbreak began, dozens of workers from the three major airports in the New York City area have been infected, and at least 17 have died, union officials said.

headline: There Is No Perfect Way Out of This
abstract: In the absence of a coordinated federal response, fits and starts may be all we have.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, do you listen to Andrew Cuomo’s daily pandemic press conferences?

headline: Don’t Be Afraid of Giving Birth in a New York Hospital
abstract: At this point, it’s safer than going elsewhere or giving birth at home.
lead_paragraph: “Two of us enter the hospital, three of us leave, and you tell us how it’s done safely.”

headline: Endless Summer Puts Homebound Kids at Risk for Weight Gain
abstract: With schools shuttered, the inactivity and snacking typical of summer breaks puts more students at risk of obesity and health ills.
lead_paragraph: With tens of thousands of schools in dozens of states now shuttered through the remainder of the school year because of the coronavirus pandemic, an estimated 55 million students will be home from school for double the length of their normal summer vacations, if not longer.

headline: Fired in a Pandemic ‘Because We Tried to Start a Union,’ Workers Say
abstract: Employees who were in unions or pushing to join them have been laid off and replaced by nonunionized labor. It’s part of a pattern stretching back decades, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Truck drivers and warehouse workers at Cort Furniture Rental in New Jersey had spent months trying to unionize in the hopes of securing higher wages and better benefits. By early this year, they thought they were on the cusp of success.

headline: How a Digital Ad Strategy That Helped Trump Is Being Used Against Him
abstract: A former Facebook employee is using a tool he employed to help President Trump win to conduct tests for a progressive group, Acronym, dedicated to ousting Mr. Trump from office.
lead_paragraph: Facebook users in five key swing states have been seeing a peculiar sequence of political ads pixelating their news feeds for the past six months.

headline: Rhode Island Pushes Aggressive Testing, a Move That Could Ease Reopening
abstract: The state has seen a rise in cases of the coronavirus, in part, experts say, because it is testing more than many states.
lead_paragraph: Rhode Island gives the appearance of a state where the coronavirus is a fire raging, the average number of daily infections more than quadrupling since the start of this month.

headline: For Some Holocaust Survivors, Even Liberation Was Dehumanizing
abstract: “If their eyes were mirrors, it seems I’m not far from dead.” After being freed by Allied troops, some former prisoners continued to be mistreated.
lead_paragraph: The latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series from The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war, explores the complex and sometimes dehumanizing interactions between the concentration camp prisoners and the Allied soldiers who liberated them.

headline: Coronavirus Diplomacy: How China’s Red Cross Serves the Communist Party
abstract: The Red Cross in China seems like any other humanitarian group. But there is one crucial difference: it is funded and directed by the Chinese Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: Donations flooded in to fight the virus devastating the city of Wuhan, and the ruling Communist Party directed them to a group it could trust: the Chinese Red Cross.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Opera
abstract: We asked Patti Smith, John Turturro, Renée Fleming and others to pick the music that moves them. Listen to their choices.
lead_paragraph: In the past, we’ve asked some of our favorite artists to choose the five minutes or so they’d play to make their friends fall in love with classical music and the piano.

headline: The Marine Corps Battles for Its Identity, Over Women in Boot Camp
abstract: Keeping men and women in separate platoons during recruit training is the last stand for the Marine Corps, which has been slow to move toward gender integration.
lead_paragraph: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C. — Stretched above the main boulevard on this historic training base in the Mid-Atlantic marsh is a white and black-lettered sign: WE MAKE MARINES.

headline: ‘The Celestial Hunter,’ by Roberto Calasso: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Celestial Hunter,” by Roberto Calasso
lead_paragraph: In the time of the Great Raven even the invisible was visible. And it continually transformed itself. Animals, at that time, were not necessarily animals. They might happen to be animals, but sometimes they were humans, gods, lords of a species, demons, ancestors. And humans weren’t necessarily humans but could also be the transient form of something else. There were no tricks for recognizing those that appeared. They had to be already known, as one knows a friend or an adversary. Everything, from spiders to the dead, occurred within a single flow of forms. It was the realm of metamorphosis.

headline: ‘Little Family,’ by Ishmael Beah: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Little Family,” by Ishmael Beah
lead_paragraph: If you are to walk toward a field that lies at the edge of the small town of Foloiya when the sun is awake in the sky, you will hear the breeze whistling through the grasses, parting the dry and green strands as it makes its way to you. Or maybe you will think it is the rustling of someone hiding under the vast shrubs. At the end of the field, your eyes will light upon the face of a boy among the grasses, peering intently at something. You try to see what it is by following the trail of his gaze, but you see nothing.

headline: Should People Without Coronavirus Antibodies Be Second-Class Citizens?
abstract: Let’s stop and think before we start issuing “immunity passports.”
lead_paragraph: One of us tested positive for the coronavirus. The other one probably had it, too — we are married and live together — although symptoms were mild. We both were fortunate to recover.

headline: Spiking Death Rates Suggest Pandemic Toll Is Undercounted
abstract: A mall operator plans to reopen shopping centers, government officials debate whether some pro sports could resume, and schools balk at spring reopenings.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Shopping Your Garden
abstract: Why make a trip to the nursery when you may have everything you need in your own backyard?
lead_paragraph: Armed with a Japanese weeding knife and my favorite trowel, I’m currently shopping in my own garden, as I do each spring, carefully scouting for the raw material of more cohesive, eye-catching beds and borders — all at no charge.

headline: The State of Testing
abstract: Rigorous testing has been key to reopening economies in Asia. So why is the U.S. lagging behind?
