abstract: An ex-nominee backs a presumptive one, and a third-party bid looms: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump met with Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and Dr. Deborah Birx, the White House coronavirus response coordinator, in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

headline: Should There Be Deals During a Pandemic?
abstract: Elizabeth Warren and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez escalated a Washington pushback against M.&A., introducing a bill to block many corporate acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Paul Krugman, the Times Opinion columnist and Nobel Prize-winning economist, is the special guest on our next DealBook Debrief call, tomorrow at 11 a.m. Eastern. He will discuss deficit spending, the debate over bailouts and take your questions. R.S.V.P. here to join. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: Mayor Defends Handling of Crowd at Rabbi’s Funeral
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio also defended using the phrase “Jewish community” in criticizing the event, as some accused him of a double standard.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Thursday’s live coverage.]

headline: Baby Boomers Were Blasé About the Coronavirus? Why Did We Believe That?
abstract: How an online trope can become mainstream news.
lead_paragraph: By now you may have heard that baby boomers were slow to take seriously the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Is It OK to Laugh During Dark Times?
abstract: Humor is one of the main coping mechanisms during periods of sickness, death and anxiety. Is it appropriate to make jokes in a pandemic?
lead_paragraph: It is often said that “laughter is the best medicine.” Do you find this to be true in your own experience? What role do laughter and humor play in your life during these difficult times?

headline: Online Auction to Aid Comic-Book Shops Raises Over $430,000
abstract: Comic-book creators contributed their work, and buyers made their bids on Twitter, to help employees and businesses upended by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A grass-roots charity auction on Twitter in support of comic-book retailers whose businesses have been disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic has netted more than $430,000.

headline: How to Stay Optimistic When Everything Seems Wrong
abstract: Optimism isn’t about ignoring negative feelings. It’s about being hopeful about the future, even when the present seems wholly negative.
lead_paragraph: With the endless stream of urgent news pushing the boundaries of our mental health, it seems laughable to suggest optimism right now. Maybe you’re worried about losing your job, losing your home or losing a loved one. Maybe you already have. Maybe you’re worried about your own health, and maybe you feel helpless or doomed. Whatever it is, optimism feels like a luxury that few of us can afford.

headline: I Don’t Want to Be a Fun Mom
abstract: It’s OK to hate capture the flag.
lead_paragraph: At dinner we go around and tell one another our favorite part of the day. Most days, my daughters both say the highlight is “Capture the flag with Daddy.” The bigger part of me is so pleased to hear that they have a new ritual they adore, one that gets their yayas out so they might actually go to sleep at a reasonable hour.

headline: Together Apart? How About Totally Losing It?
abstract: After over a month of social-distancing requirements, New Yorkers are beginning to turn on each other.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the arguments take place on the street. More often, they appear to occur in a supermarket.

headline: China Sets Date for Congress, Signaling Coronavirus Is Under Control
abstract: The Communist Party is eager to use its most important political spectacle to project confidence in the face of economic challenges and foreign criticism.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China delivered its strongest statement of confidence yet that it has tamed the country’s coronavirus epidemic, announcing on Wednesday it would hold a much-delayed top political gathering late next month and ease quarantine restrictions in the capital.

headline: Worst Economy in a Decade. What’s Next? ‘Worst in Our Lifetime.’
abstract: U.S. gross domestic product declined in the first quarter, dragged down by the pandemic’s grip in March. Don’t even ask about this quarter.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic officially snapped the United States’ economic growth streak in the first three months of the year. The question now is how deep the damage will get — and how long the country will take to recover.

headline: How Do I Get My Neighbors to Respect Social Distancing?
abstract: Social-distancing rules are evolving quickly, and our sense of safety often depends on how people around us interpret those rules.
lead_paragraph: Q: My West Orange, N.J., house is on the quiet side of a narrow traffic island. Two families have been treating it like a park. Their children play on the island and the street in front of my house, while the parents crowd around. No one wears masks. The space gets so crowded that my children cannot safely play on our lawn. Today, I came home to find the neighbors’ children playing on my front lawn. How do I ask them to respect social-distancing rules?

headline: What You Get for $1.3 Million
abstract: A 1910 Craftsman in Portland, Ore.; a modern house in Charlotte, N.C.; and an Italianate Victorian in Savannah, Ga.
lead_paragraph: A 1910 Craftsman in Portland, Ore.; a modern house in Charlotte, N.C.; and an Italianate Victorian in Savannah, Ga.

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in Oregon, North Carolina and Georgia
abstract: A 1910 Craftsman in Portland, a modern house in Charlotte and an Italianate Victorian in Savannah.
lead_paragraph: This property is in the Irvington neighborhood of northeast Portland, which was developed in the late 19th century, and is one of an important collection of Queen Anne, Colonial Revival and Craftsman homes in the landmark district. It is about two and a half miles northeast of the Pearl district, across the Willamette River, and one-half mile west of Grant Park, a green space with recreational facilities that is the setting for a number of scenes in Beverly Cleary’s children’s books. The Irvington Tennis Club is four blocks west.

headline: Reopening California
abstract: Wednesday: A look at the four phases state leaders laid out to lift stay-at-home orders. Also: Getting creative for gatherings.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: N.C.A.A. Outlines Plan to Let Athletes Make Endorsement Deals
abstract: The changes, with some big restrictions, would go into effect at the start of the 2021-22 academic year, after consideration and adoption by the three divisions of college sports.
lead_paragraph: As the star quarterback at the University of Alabama, Tua Tagovailoa was a marketer’s dream: He had charisma, a million social media followers and a championship pedigree he earned as a freshman by throwing the winning touchdown in the national title game.

headline: Mediterranean Style on the Coast of Grenada
abstract: This three-bedroom, Mediterranean-style villa, situated on a peninsula jutting from the southeast coast of Grenada, is on the market for $2.5 million.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, Mediterranean-style villa, situated on a peninsula jutting from the southeast coast of Grenada, is on the market for $2.5 million.

headline: House Hunting on Grenada: Caribbean Views for $2.5 Million
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has stalled the island nation’s recent progress, but ‘most buyers and sellers have remained committed to ongoing sales,’ agents say.
lead_paragraph: This Mediterranean-style villa, on a one-acre hillside lot sprinkled with tropical fruit trees, is situated on a narrow peninsula jutting from the southeastern coast of Grenada. The three-bedroom main house, built in 1995 and renovated in 2009, and its one-bedroom guesthouse, share a 30-foot dock and views of Westerhall Bay, which feeds into the Caribbean Sea.

headline: Protecting the Ones I Love, With Flour, Sausage and Cheese
abstract: A journal of the Plague Year: Week 7.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t a pizza, and it wasn’t a calzone.

headline: Remdesivir Shows Modest Benefits in Coronavirus Trial
abstract: Hope soared nonetheless. The F.D.A. is likely to issue an emergency approval, a senior official said.
lead_paragraph: Modest results from a federal trial of an experimental drug helped send the stock market soaring on Wednesday, another sign of the desperation for a viable treatment against the coronavirus.

headline: A Father’s Love, Whether He Says Too Much or Not Enough
abstract: In “A River Runs Through It,” a loving patriarch can’t find the words to rescue his wayward boy. Years later, another dad sees words as the best way to help his son.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic goes on, stay-at-home guidelines are forcing many families into day upon day of togetherness. Might some families at least be making the best of things by talking to each other more? Really talking?

headline: Portraits That More Than Meet the Eye
abstract: Jordan Casteel’s vibrant colors capture the spirit and humanity of her subjects: black and brown people who have often been excluded from art institutions.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Casteel’s exhibition “Within Reach” is currently hanging on the second floor of the temporarily shuttered New Museum. The situation is somewhat paradoxical, given that the show’s most prominent theme is closeness — something that’s been severely disrupted by the coronavirus crisis. Yet that also makes it a good time to look at Ms. Casteel’s work however we can — in a digital walk-through and in the catalog — and think about the vision of community it offers.

headline: The Passion of Perfume Genius
abstract: The musician Mike Hadreas wanted “new rules” for himself. After a pivotal collaboration with a dance group, he’s returning with a thrilling album, “Set My Heart on Fire Immediately.”
lead_paragraph: One Friday last month, Mike Hadreas fell asleep in a “Cruel Intentions” T-shirt and got up later that morning for a Zoom interview. He’d been up late, in his Los Angeles home, so he took the call in bed. Not something he’d normally do. The Zoom, the wee hours.

headline: The City That Never Sleeps Is Waking Up Later
abstract: Some 400 special electric meters in New York apartments provide a shifting view of power use while people are stuck inside.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has transformed the ebb and flow of daily life in countless ways. Americans are comfort-eating,  cringe-watching and using their phones for actual  voice-calling. And, in New York City (and no doubt other places under stay-home orders), people are also staying under the covers a little bit longer.

headline: Substitution City
abstract: You’ve probably gained a lot of confidence in the kitchen lately. Keep on riffing, whether you’re making soup, fried rice, or a comforting lasagna.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ve been writing no-recipe recipes for a long time now — narrative prompts for freestyle cooking, encouragements to engage creatively with ingredients. I used to do it weekly. But now a no-recipe recipe is, like, every recipe we have. With everyone out of this pantry item or that one, recipes have become mere suggestions of where you might start. They’re like assembly charts from Ikea when you have only 60 percent of the fasteners. “I have tons of overripe bananas and no baking powder. And store is out,” a pal texted me over the weekend. “What can I substitute for baking powder in banana bread? You know it’s dark times when I’m baking, so help a girl out.”

headline: Navy Secretary Orders Deeper Inquiry Into Virus-Stricken Ship
abstract: The investigation delays a decision on whether to reinstate the captain of the aircraft carrier Roosevelt, Brett E. Crozier, who has assumed the role of an unlikely hero.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The acting secretary of the Navy on Wednesday ordered a wider investigation into events aboard the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, shelving for now a recommendation by the Navy’s top admiral to restore Capt. Brett E. Crozier to command the virus-stricken warship.

headline: France’s Prime Minister Shut Down Soccer. That Surprised Teams Restarting.
abstract: France is the first of Europe’s big five soccer leagues to declare the season over. Now, its clubs are facing the financial consequences.
lead_paragraph: At their board meeting on Friday, the decision makers of France’s top professional soccer league were making plans for the resumption of their competition: plans for safety protocols, training schedules and possible dates for when the first games could be played.

headline: Europe’s Strong Labor Laws Aren’t a Guarantee for Lower-Wage Workers
abstract: Some European companies seem to be targeting workers who are the easiest to fire or have the least bargaining power, even as the firms seek government help.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — As the German airline Lufthansa struggles to stay in business, it’s no surprise that its employees are suffering, too. But as is the case at other struggling companies, some workers are suffering more than others.

headline: Nothing Can Keep Real Madrid’s Thibaut Courtois Away From the N.B.A.
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein talks with Thibaut Courtois of Real Madrid about his N.B.A. fandom and revisits what Stein says is the best decade of basketball: the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: Boeing, Expecting a Long Slump, Will Cut 16,000 Jobs
abstract: The company, which saw sales plunge in the first quarter, said air travel might not recover for years.
lead_paragraph: The breathtaking slowdown in global aviation is taking a huge toll on Boeing, which said on Wednesday that it would slash about 16,000 jobs after reporting that revenue tumbled by 26 percent in the first three months of the year.

headline: ‘This Isn’t the Time for Caviar’: A Chef Finds New Flavors in a Pandemic
abstract: After the coronavirus lockdown, a chef in Bangkok and his migrant staff started cooking a whole new menu and delivering food to the poor.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — When the coronavirus struck, desperate chefs in Bangkok’s fine-dining scene began offering sea urchin on toast and Wagyu katsu sandwiches for delivery since eating in was banned.

headline: Your Energy Bill Is Probably Climbing. Here’s Why.
abstract: Also this week, rethinking the way we shop
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter! Join us Friday at 1 p.m. Eastern for the final video call in our Greenhouse series. Our global climate reporter, Somini Sengupta, will talk with the chefs Marcus Samuelsson and Matthew Orlando about cooking creatively and sustainably. You can RSVP here. If you missed last week’s call, you can watch it here.

headline: With Pro Sports Paused, a Women’s Hockey League Expands
abstract: The N.W.H.L. announced a new Toronto franchise with all-female leadership.
lead_paragraph: While many professional sports leagues have paused operations during the coronavirus pandemic, the National Women’s Hockey League is forging ahead with ambitious plans for growth.

headline: Five Artists to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Photographs that capture our image-saturated times, biting cartoons and unusual regional architecture: Here are some of the Instagram accounts brightening our art critic’s daily feed.
lead_paragraph: Instagram reminds me of a strobe-lit party sprawling down an infinite corridor. Frankly, I find it a little overwhelming. You may start off somewhere familiar, with a small group of friends, but before you know it, you’re bumping into famous photographers, stumbling upon a lecture about women in art history or an archive of public-domain art works, or getting lost amid imagery that swings rapidly from cheerful to moody and back again.

headline: Arlene Saunders, Soprano With a Dramatic Flair, Dies at 89
abstract: Ms. Saunders, who had the coronavirus, was a charismatic performer who could sing “as easily as if she were conversing.”
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: ‘This Terrible Thing Is Happening, but the World Goes On.’
abstract: Cheryl Strayed talks with the author Judy Blume about raising teens, losing religion and writing it all down.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Quibi, JetBlue and Others Gave Away Email Addresses, Report Says
abstract: Personal data from millions of customers ended up with Google, Facebook and other trackers, making it easier for them to be tracked online and targeted with ads, according to a study.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people gave their email addresses to Quibi, JetBlue, Wish and other companies — and those email addresses got away.

headline: They Didn’t Drink the Bleach, but They’re Still Drinking the Kool-Aid
abstract: Is the Republican indulgence of the president bottomless?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Frank Bruni’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Wednesday.

headline: Transgender Man in U.K. Loses Appeal to Be Listed as Father
abstract: Freddy McConnell, who gave birth after transitioning, unsuccessfully appealed a court decision that he could be registered only as his son’s mother. He now wants to take his case to Britain’s Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A transgender man in Britain lost an appeal on Wednesday to be registered as his son’s father, rather than mother, on the child’s birth certificate. He now wants to take his case to the Supreme Court.

headline: ‘Patients Have Panic in Their Eyes’: Voices From a Covid-19 Unit
abstract: Nurses from N.Y.U. Langone Health describe the toll the coronavirus is taking on their patients, and on themselves.
lead_paragraph: There is little respite for the nurses working with coronavirus patients at N.Y.U. Langone Health.

headline: Video Shows California Boy, 14, Being Punched by Police Officer
abstract: The police in Rancho Cordova, Calif., and the Sacramento County Sheriff’s Department are investigating the incident, which was captured in a video that was widely shared on social media.
lead_paragraph: A police officer in the Northern California city of Rancho Cordova is being investigated by law enforcement authorities after he was recorded on a widely circulated video punching a 14-year-old boy while pinning him to the ground on Monday as he tried to detain him.

headline: Tadashi Tsufura, Internment Survivor and New York Principal, Dies at 89
abstract: During World War II, he and his family were forcibly relocated to Arizona. He later became a beloved educator in New York City.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Scott Perry Keeps Knicks General Manager Job for One More Year
abstract: Perry, the Knicks’ general manager since 2017, will be staying in his role for a bit longer. But as the coronavirus continues to spread, what moves will he be able to make?
lead_paragraph: Scott Perry will remain the general manager of the Knicks for at least another year after his contract was extended under Leon Rose, the recently hired team president, a source with knowledge of the matter said Wednesday. The extension was first reported by Newsday.

headline: The Easiest Roast Chicken (and Even Easier Stock)
abstract: Master this before-bedtime stock, and you, too, can be one of those cooks who always has it on hand.
lead_paragraph: Even in pre-quarantine days, whenever I roasted a chicken, I always saved the bones for stock.

headline: Technology Will Not Save Us
abstract: To fight the pandemic, we need to focus more on unglamorous, human-powered tactics.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: L.P.G.A. Shifts Schedule Once Again
abstract: Plus the future of the spitball in cricket and a backyard pole vault runway and pit that meets competition standards.
lead_paragraph: The L.P.G.A. Tour rescheduled its tentative events to July from June on Wednesday because of the coronavirus pandemic, and the P.G.A. of America announced that the Women’s P.G.A. Championship, a major, was moving to October from June. Five other L.P.G.A. events were canceled.

headline: Terry Lenzner, Sleuth With a Wide-Ranging Career, Dies at 80
abstract: He prosecuted civil rights violators, investigated the Nixon administration during the Watergate scandal and worked for Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Terry F. Lenzner, a bulldog investigator with a Harvard pedigree whose career took him from pursuing civil rights violators in the South through the Watergate hearings and decades of sometimes controversial private investigations, died on April 23 in Washington. He was 80.

headline: Airbus, a Jewel of the European Economy, Signals Distress
abstract: Europe’s giant plane maker, thriving just months ago, is now warning of the “gravest crisis.”
lead_paragraph: Airbus, the European aircraft giant, could not make planes fast enough earlier in the year. But the coronavirus pandemic has forced it to face a devastating fact: Some airlines that put in orders do not want its planes now.

headline: Fed Suggests Tough Road Ahead as It Pledges to Help Insulate Economy
abstract: The Federal Reserve left rates unchanged near zero at its April meeting and suggested it would not be raising them anytime soon as the virus takes a huge toll on economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, struck a worried tone at his first regularly scheduled news conference since the coronavirus shuttered the United States economy, calling the job losses taking hold “heartbreaking” and predicting a long road ahead.

headline: Biden’s Choice for Vice President: What Matters Most?
abstract: Readers debate whether Joe Biden “ought to choose competence to govern over political appeal” and the pressure to pick a black woman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Brian Eno’s 15 Essential Ambient Works
abstract: Listen to atmospheric soundtracks for uneasy times.
lead_paragraph: Amorphous, open-ended, unstructured time, with undercurrents of foreboding, pockets of boredom and fleeting interludes of peace or reassessment. That’s what Covid-19 has brought to many people — and it’s a mental state that Brian Eno’s vast recorded catalog has been prepared for since he first popularized the term “ambient music” in the 1970s. The long days and featureless nights of self-quarantine offer an opportune moment to revisit — or get acquainted with — Eno’s time-warping music.

headline: Trump Administration Signals Support for Allies’ Fight Against Virus Orders
abstract: Conservative groups making a legal assault against state and local coronavirus restrictions are backed by the Justice Department’s willingness to “take action.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A network of conservative leaders, donors and organizations has launched a legal onslaught against state and local restrictions intended to slow the spread of the coronavirus, pushing to allow churches to hold services, businesses to reopen and people to be able to visit with family and friends.

headline: Berlin’s Newest Airport Prepares for Grand Opening. Again.
abstract: After nearly a decade of delays, Germany’s third-largest airport plans to open its doors to travelers. If only there were any.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After nine years of delays, Germany’s third-largest airport, in Berlin, is set to open — just as the global coronavirus pandemic is vastly reducing air traffic.

headline: Watch This: John Krasinski’s Feel-Good Take on the News
abstract: With “Some Good News,” Krasinski does his best Walter Cronkite for the more than 2 million subscribers to his new YouTube channel.
lead_paragraph: John Krasinski — who gave us the all-purpose incredulous stare as Jim Halpert on “The Office” and who currently plays the C.I.A. analyst Jack Ryan on Amazon Prime’s political thriller by the same name — could be considered an unlikely YouTube star.

headline: Trump Appointees Manipulated Agency’s Payday Lending Research, Ex-Staffer Claims
abstract: A former economist at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau accused Trump appointees of steering the bureau’s reversal on payday lending rules to gut a key provision.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, on his final day of work at the nation’s consumer finance watchdog agency, a career economist sent colleagues a blunt memo.

headline: Jameis Winston’s Next Act: Where Else but New Orleans?
abstract: Displaced by one great quarterback, Winston will now back up another with the Saints. How he reinvents himself there depends entirely on him.
lead_paragraph: In the video, posted three weeks ago on Twitter, Jameis Winston has his right arm cocked, feet shuffling as if he’s moving around the pocket, as his trainer launches an oversize speed bag at him, again and again. The drill, it seems, is intended to simulate defensive pressure, and Winston, looking trim and coiled, evades the bag each time.

headline: When Mourning Is at a Distance
abstract: In response to our query, readers discuss how they have marked the deaths of loved ones: struggling with not saying goodbye, not being comforted in person, but also finding some solace in the collective virtual grieving.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: You Don’t Have to Emerge From Quarantine a Beautiful Butterfly
abstract: Here’s a chill, no-frills, take-it-or-leave-it guide on how to distract yourself in a pandemic — without home gyms, heavy reading or juice cleanses.
lead_paragraph: For those of us fortunate enough to quarantine, sheltering in place for the foreseeable future, time has begun to pass ever so strangely. The days oozing on by, unfurling on top of one another, without the clear distinctions of commutes, errands, routines and workplaces to orient us. Unable to dine out, or see friends, extended family or even those three people at work you actually like, we’re aching for alternative outlets.

headline: After Real Loss, Virtual Comfort Must Do
abstract: Readers talk about mourning loved ones from afar.
lead_paragraph: In an essay about attending via video the burial of her mother, Jill Bialosky, a poet and an executive editor at W.W. Norton & Co., describes mourning at a time when travel isn’t safe and services are limited to a few family members.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: China’s parliament, Irrfan Khan, South Korea: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Beijing set a date for its much-delayed top political gathering, the annual session of the National People’s Congress, sending its strongest signal that things were getting back to normal as the outbreak slows.

headline: At Least 89 Vaccines Are Being Developed. It May Not Matter.
abstract: A coronavirus vaccine won’t stop the pandemic without all countries having access to it.
lead_paragraph: If an effective and safe coronavirus vaccine were available today, would it be enough to stop this pandemic? That would depend on whether everyone who needs it can get it. But if what took place during the 2009 H1N1 pandemic happens again, then the answer is no.

headline: Maskless Mike Pence
abstract: Readers are disturbed that the vice president would set such a bad example while visiting the Mayo Clinic. Also: The president at West Point; how universities struggle during the crisis.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Milena Jelinek, Screenwriter and Educator, Dies at 84
abstract: She was thrown out of her film school in Prague for a movie called “An Easy Life.” After landing in New York, she became a tough-love screenwriting professor at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: Milena Jelinek spent her youth in Czechoslovakia learning to write under the tutelage of novelists like Milan Kundera and protesting Communism with friends like Vaclav Havel.

headline: Eight Photographers’ Pictures From Isolation
abstract: Joel Meyerowitz, Renée Cox, Asako Narahashi and more share visual diaries of the present moment.
lead_paragraph: “Like a high-strung racehorse who needs extra weight in her saddle pad, I like a handicap and relish the aesthetic challenge posed by the limitations of the ordinary,” writes the photographer Sally Mann in her memoir, “Hold Still” (2015). In our stilled, stalled time, her words ring especially true. Here we all are, burdened by untold fears, forced to make do, to essentialize, to improvise. And also, within all of this, to open our eyes and attend to new possibilities.

headline: Just Spit and Wait: New Coronavirus Test Offers Advantages
abstract: Saliva tests like the one developed by Rutgers are less painful for patients and less risky to medical workers.
lead_paragraph: A new test for the coronavirus is so simple and straightforward, almost anyone could do it: Spit a glob of saliva into a cup, close the lid and hand it over.

headline: Fed Chair to Congress: Do Whatever It Takes to Keep the Economy From Collapse
abstract: It’s a reversal of the usual relationship between elected officials and independent central bankers.
lead_paragraph: There were many thousands of viewers watching Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s news conference on Wednesday afternoon, between various online feeds and financial news networks. But his most important message was directed at just 536 people.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Daisy Edgar-Jones Reads ‘Years Ago, My Sister Vanished. I See Her Whenever I Want.’
abstract: The “Normal People” star reads an essay about the benefits and detriments of legacies online.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Democratic Frustration Mounts as Biden Remains Silent on Sexual Assault Allegation
abstract: Activists and women’s rights advocates have urged Mr. Biden to address a former aide’s allegation that he sexually assaulted her in 1993. His lack of response has angered them.
lead_paragraph: For more than three weeks, progressive activists and women’s rights advocates debated how to handle an allegation of sexual assault against Joseph R. Biden Jr. The conversations weren’t easy, nor were the politics: Mr. Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, faced one allegation; his opponent, President Trump, at least a dozen.

headline: The Coronavirus Stimulus Package Is a Mess
abstract: Congress gets an A+ for speed but a B- for quality.
lead_paragraph: The next round of economic stimulus has now emerged from Congress’s sausage factory, with more rescue efforts inevitably to follow.

headline: Barney Ales, Indispensable Motown Executive, Is Dead at 85
abstract: In the 1960s, he promoted the black-owned company’s music to the white-dominated music industry, helping to make it a ubiquitous force in American pop culture.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1964, Motown was in a bind. Its biggest female star, Mary Wells, had just reached No. 1 with “My Guy,” and then quit the label — the first major defection from the young company, which had set itself up in Detroit as a flawless factory of black pop.

headline: Ricardo Brennand, Brazilian Entrepreneur and Collector, Dies at 92
abstract: He amassed a vast trove of art and artifacts and built a castle-like repository so the public could see it, partly because his family wasn’t happy with his collecting.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Is Justin Amash a Threat to Biden or to Trump?
abstract: Democrats shouldn’t freak out just yet. It’s just as likely that in November he could hurt the president.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Justin Amash, a Republican-turned-independent from Michigan, started a presidential exploratory committee on Tuesday, he caused immediate head-exploding from partisans on both sides. Mr. Amash, 40, intends to seek the Libertarian Party nomination.

headline: Elite Prep Schools, Set Back by Virus, Face a Quandary on Federal Aid
abstract: The loans were meant as a payroll lifeline for small businesses. Many of the schools had endowments in the tens of millions. Their administrators grappled with a question: to take or not to take?
lead_paragraph: The Latin School of Chicago, which has counted the Illinois governor’s children among its students, returned the money. Sidwell Friends in Washington, the alma mater of President Obama’s daughters, decided to keep it. So did others, like St. Andrew’s Episcopal School in Potomac, Md., where President Trump’s youngest son is a student.

headline: As Fighting Surges, Yemen Is Hit With 1st Cluster of Covid-19 Infections
abstract: A handful of coronavirus cases in Aden appeared to confirm fears that the virus has been spreading, stoking concerns of an outbreak that could quickly overwhelm Yemen’s devastated health system.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The first confirmed expansion of the coronavirus in Yemen was reported on Wednesday, prompting renewed calls from aid groups and the United Nations for a humanitarian cease-fire to help combat the infection at a time when the country is mired in increased fighting, widespread hunger and a major cholera outbreak.

headline: With Little Hesitation, Struggling News Outlets Accept Federal Aid
abstract: Ravaged by the pandemic, newspapers have taken millions in Paycheck Protection Program loans. Editors and publishers say they see no real conflict of interest.
lead_paragraph: Is it a conflict of interest for news outlets to accept federal money under the Paycheck Protection Program? Will taking government funds cause them to go soft in their coverage of those in power?

headline: Alaska School District Votes Out ‘Catch-22,’ ‘Gatsby’ and Other Classics
abstract: School board members in Palmer, Alaska, raised concerns about language and sexual references in five books deemed too controversial.
lead_paragraph: An Alaska school board voted last week to remove five books, including classic American works like “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings” and “The Great Gatsby,” from its curriculum for high school English electives because of sexual references, graphic language and other concerns.

headline: Pondering ‘Sex Education’ When Touching Is Off-Limits
abstract: As Laurie Nunn plans the new season of her hit Netflix comedy, she reminds herself that, “despite this horrible pandemic, teenagers will still have a lot of sex and relationship questions.”
lead_paragraph: At a time when the world has become defined by unsettling news and social distancing, how is a writer supposed to focus on telling a funny story about physical intimacy?

headline: Some Pros Let It Go on TikTok: ‘Is This the Future?’
abstract: Low pressure, low stakes, low toil: Professional dancers with time on their hands are learning the pleasures of TikTok challenges.
lead_paragraph: At this time of year, the dancer Erica Lall, a member of the corps of American Ballet Theater, would normally be preparing for eight weeks of performances at the Metropolitan Opera House. But in mid-March, as the company moved toward calling off its spring season, she found herself back in her hometown Cypress, Tex., with some extra time on her hands.

headline: Coronavirus Casts Unwelcome Spotlight on Trump’s Health Secretary
abstract: Alex M. Azar II has long been seen as a difficult personality in President Trump’s cabinet, but the pandemic has heightened personal clashes, putting him on thin ice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of President Trump’s top health officials were stewing last month in a drab room at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta as Mr. Trump and his health secretary, Alex M. Azar II, were concluding a laboratory tour, one that they had been left off of.

headline: Teachers, Do Children’s ZIP Codes Determine Their Destiny?
abstract: If you teach in a U.S. city, we want to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: America’s teachers are some of the best front-line observers of the extent to which communities are creating opportunities for children, and to what extent schools are helping that happen.

headline: 3 Baltic States Announced a ‘Travel Bubble.’ What Is It and Could It Work in the U.S.?
abstract: Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania announced a plan to allow for internal travel, and Australia and New Zealand are likely to follow suit. But in other parts of the world, establishing such a bubble would be tricky.
lead_paragraph: Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania plan to open their internal borders for citizens to travel between the three countries beginning on May 15, a decision that creates the first “travel bubble” among European Union countries as coronavirus-related travel restrictions begin to ease.

headline: Remdesivir, Coronavirus, Met Gala: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Polls Had Trump Stewing, and Lashing Out at His Own Campaign
abstract: The president erupted recently at his campaign manager, Brad Parscale, after seeing polling data that showed Mr. Trump trailing Joe Biden in several states.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated by a faltering economy that is out of his control, and facing blowback for his suggestion that disinfectants could potentially combat the coronavirus, President Trump had sunk to one of his lowest points in recent months last week. And he directed his anger toward the one area that is most important to him: his re-election prospects.

headline: Facebook Points to ‘Signs of Stability’ as Ad Declines Flatten
abstract: The company reported rising revenue and profit in the first quarter and said it was also saving on expenses.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook cautioned Wall Street on Wednesday that it could face intensifying difficulties in its advertising business from the coronavirus pandemic, but also indicated that the toll would not be deep.

headline: Samuel Hargress Jr., Owner of a Beloved Harlem Bar, Dies at 84
abstract: He ran Paris Blues, a throwback to the ’60s that attracted locals and tourists alike and seemed to be an extension of himself. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: 2,500 Mourners Jam a Hasidic Funeral, Creating a Flash Point for de Blasio
abstract: The event showed the challenges that officials have faced in addressing the flouting of social distancing in close-knit ultra-Orthodox neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Soon after a revered Hasidic rabbi died of the coronavirus in Brooklyn on Tuesday, his fellow congregants informed the Police Department of an unexpected decision: Despite the coronavirus restrictions now in place, they would hold a public funeral.

headline: Roger Stone Was in Contact With Julian Assange in 2017, Documents Show
abstract: Mr. Stone, a longtime friend of President Trump, had denied such a relationship, but newly revealed court documents unveiled private exchanges.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on Roger Stone’s sentence being commuted by President Trump.]

headline: The Bad News Won’t Stop, but Markets Keep Rising
abstract: Trillions in stimulus dollars have convinced Wall Street that the government has its back, and investors are seizing on even glimmers of good news about the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The government said on Wednesday that the U.S. economy had suffered its worst contraction since the last recession. The head of the Federal Reserve later said he didn’t know how bad this downturn would be, or how long it would last.

headline: Q.&.A. With Justin Amash
abstract: “What we need in Washington is a little more humility and trust of the people,” said Mr. Amash, a Michigan congressman and former Republican. He told us why he was seeking the Libertarian Party’s presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Dozens of Decomposing Bodies Found in Trucks at Brooklyn Funeral Home
abstract: The funeral home director said that he used the trucks for storage after he ran out of space in his chapel. “Bodies are coming out of our ears,” he said.
lead_paragraph: The call came in at shortly after 11 a.m. on Wednesday: A terrible stench was coming from a pair of trucks parked outside a funeral home on Utica Avenue in Brooklyn.

headline: Powerful Meat Industry Holds More Sway After Trump’s Order
abstract: The executive action signals that decisions around whether to close or reopen plants should be driven by the federal government, not local authorities.
lead_paragraph: Ever since slaughterhouses became coronavirus hot spots, the meat industry has been asking the Trump administration for help.

headline: This Luxury Tower Has Everything: Pools. A Juice Bar. And Flood Resilience.
abstract: Unless we learn to adapt, only the rich will be able to avoid the ravages of climate change.
lead_paragraph: At Monad Terrace, a new high-end development in Miami South Beach, luxury isn’t just about uninterrupted views and a juice bar. The developers behind the 14-floor tower, designed by the Pritzker Prize-winning French firm Ateliers Jean Nouvel, are marketing its readiness to survive the oncoming impact of climate change.

headline: Two of My Colleagues Died of Covid-19
abstract: In a meatpacking plant, changes were made too late.
lead_paragraph: SOUDERTON, Pa. — On a normal day, work at a meatpacking plant is not easy. The slaughterhouse is boiling hot. People who aren’t used to the temperature can feel as if they are experiencing high blood pressure. The freezer is super cold and will amplify any flulike symptoms. Workers wear as many layers as they can to stay warm, but it is difficult.

headline: Trump and Kushner Engage in Revisionist History in Boasting of Success Over Virus
abstract: “We did all the right moves,” the president said Wednesday. “The federal government rose to the challenge, and this is a great success story,” said his son-in-law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The total number of coronavirus cases in the United States exceeded one million. The American death toll surpassed that of the Vietnam War. And the economy was reported to have shrunk by nearly 5 percent. But the White House on Wednesday declared its response to the crisis “a great success story.”

headline: Trump Seeks Push to Speed Vaccine, Despite Safety Concerns
abstract: The president wants a coronavirus vaccine widely available by the end of the year, even though his public health experts say it will take at least a year to 18 months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is pressing his health officials to pursue a crash development program for a coronavirus vaccine that could be widely distributed by the beginning of next year, despite widespread skepticism that such an effort could succeed and considerable concern about the implications for safety.

headline: The Trump Administration’s Legal Moves to Prevent a Meat Shortage, Explained
abstract: Contrary to misunderstandings, the actions fall short of ordering meatpacking facilities to reopen despite Covid-19 outbreaks among workers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration moved this week to try to mitigate the effects from the shutdowns of beef, pork and poultry processing facilities amid the Covid-19 pandemic that have potentially endangered an important part of the nation’s food supply chain. But the policy moves have generated confusion.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The drug of hope. Can remdesivir help?
lead_paragraph: A federal trial suggests it might help people recover from the coronavirus a lot faster. But a study found it had no benefit for severely ill patients. The F.D.A. is likely to authorize its emergency use, an administration official told The New York Times.

headline: Corrections: April 30, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on Wednesday about the former NASA administrator James M. Beggs misidentified the president under whom he served as under secretary of transportation. It was Richard M. Nixon, not Lyndon B. Johnson.

headline: Irrfan Khan: Mira Nair Remembers Her ‘Namesake’ Star
abstract: The friendship and collaboration between director and actor endured for decades, and she was a steppingstone in his transition from India to Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Mira Nair first tried to get Irrfan Khan to appear in one of her movies when he was a drama student in Delhi. And while the substantial part she offered him in “Salaam Bombay!” (1988) ended up being downsized, she promised him the lead in a feature film — one day. Nearly 20 years later, she kept her word, casting him as Ashoke Ganguli, the patriarch of an immigrant Bengali family in “The Namesake,” based on Jhumpa Lahiri’s novel. She gave him, she said, his “first gateway to the world.”

headline: Prisoner With Coronavirus Dies After Giving Birth While on Ventilator
abstract: Andrea Circle Bear, the first female federal prisoner to die after getting the coronavirus, had just started serving a two-year drug sentence for selling methamphetamine.
lead_paragraph: The first female federal prisoner to die after contracting the coronavirus was a 30-year-old mother who had just weeks earlier given birth while on a ventilator.

headline: F.A.A. Investigates Harrison Ford and His Plane Again
abstract: The episode was being investigated by the Federal Aviation Administration, which ordered the actor to complete awareness training in 2017.
lead_paragraph: The single-engine plane had just landed at Hawthorne Municipal Airport outside Los Angeles when the tower instructed the pilot to wait for another aircraft to make a touch-and-go landing before taxiing across the runway.

headline: A Strange Dinosaur May Have Swum the Rivers of Africa
abstract: The Spinosaurus possessed a long, powerful tail. Paleontologists think the dinosaur used that to propel itself through water.
lead_paragraph: An enigmatic predatory dinosaur that lived in northern Africa about 95 million years ago possessed a long, powerful tail that may have propelled it through water, new fossils suggest.

headline: Goal-Scoring Opportunities
abstract: Caitlin Reid foots it to the intersection.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Want to see something frustrating? I will understand if the answer is a resolute “No thank you, things are weird enough for me right now,” but I’m going to ask you to bear with me.

headline: Maggie Haney, Elite Gymnastics Coach, Is Suspended for 8 Years
abstract: Haney was accused of verbal abuse and mistreatment of athletes, which included forcing them to train through injuries.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Haney, an elite gymnastics coach in New Jersey who was accused of verbally abusing and mistreating athletes, has been suspended from the sport for eight years by U.S.A. Gymnastics after a weekslong disciplinary hearing.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Pandemic Is Further Eroding France’s Trust in Central Government
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “France can’t compare itself to South Korea or Taiwan; it can only compare itself to another great power. To compare itself to countries that are not great powers is in some ways unbearable.”

headline: 21-Year-Old Man Charged in Fatal Shooting of Indianapolis Postal Worker
abstract: Angela Summers, 45, was delivering mail along her route when she was shot by an upset customer on Monday, court documents show.
lead_paragraph: An Indianapolis man was accused on Wednesday of killing a postal worker while she was delivering mail on his street, after he confronted her about mail not being delivered at his home, court documents show.

headline: Emissions Declines Will Set Records This Year. But It’s Not Good News.
abstract: An “unprecedented” fall in fossil fuel use, driven by the Covid-19 crisis, is likely to lead to a nearly 8 percent drop, according to new research.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Global greenhouse gas emissions are on track to plunge nearly 8 percent this year, the largest drop ever recorded, as worldwide lockdowns to fight the coronavirus have triggered an “unprecedented” decline in the use of fossil fuels, the International Energy Agency said in a new report on Thursday.

headline: U.S. Stocks Have Their Best Month Since 1987
abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Stocks fell on Thursday, giving up some of their gains from the day before, after reports that showed millions more Americans applied for weekly unemployment benefits and consumer spending collapsed.

headline: Flynn Lawyers Seize on Newly Released F.B.I. Documents
abstract: The documents show details of a debate among F.B.I. officials before interviewing Michael T. Flynn in 2017, days after he lied to the vice president about his talks with a top Russian diplomat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s allies cheered new documents unsealed on Wednesday in the criminal case of his former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, saying that internal investigative notes showed that Mr. Flynn was set up by F.B.I. officials intent on undermining the president.

headline: As Coronavirus Sickens Mexican Workers, U.S. Presses Their Factories to Stay Open
abstract: The pandemic threatens to plunge half a billion people into poverty. The U.N. says it has raised just $1 billion of the $90 billion needed to aid poor regions.
lead_paragraph: 新冠病毒疫情最新消息

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in May
abstract: Our picks for May, including ‘Hollywood,’ ‘Upload,’ ‘Billions’ and ‘Hannah Gadsby: Douglas’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for May.

headline: Boris Johnson, France, Remdesivir: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Parks and Recreation’ and ‘Circus of Books’
abstract: The cast of “Parks and Recreation” reunites for a virtual special. And a documentary on Netflix looks at a West Hollywood pornography shop.
lead_paragraph: A PARKS AND RECREATION SPECIAL 8:30 p.m. on NBC. What does “Parks and Recreation” look like with social distancing in place? Can Amy Poehler and the rest of the cast recreate the show’s distinctive energy remotely? And what’s the status of Nick Offerman’s ever-changing facial hair? Get answers to these questions and more in this half-hour special, a benefit to raise money for the national food-bank network Feeding America. In addition to Poehler and Offerman, the program is set to include appearances from Rashida Jones, Aubrey Plaza, Chris Pratt, Aziz Ansari, Retta, Adam Scott, Rob Lowe and Jim O’Heir.

headline: Late Night Isn’t Buying Pence’s Reason for Not Wearing a Mask
abstract: The vice president said he wanted to look Mayo Clinic workers in the eye. More than one host noted that surgical masks cover the mouth.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Highways of Peru Swell With Families Fleeing Virus
abstract: Fear of the virus and job loss in cities are pushing many back to the countryside, reversing a decades-long trend of urban migration and raising alarm about a public health crisis in rural areas.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — The bus terminals in Lima are so crowded with people waiting to escape to the countryside that families are sleeping outside, side by side.

headline: Millions Had Risen Out of Poverty. Coronavirus Is Pulling Them Back.
abstract: Experts say that for the first time since 1998, global poverty will increase. At least a half billion people could slip into destitution by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: She was just 12 when she dropped out of school and began clocking in for endless shifts at one of the garment factories springing up in Bangladesh, hoping to pull her family out of poverty.

headline: Chinese Coffee Chain’s Scandal Renews U.S. Calls for Oversight
abstract: The implosion of a Chinese competitor to Starbucks has bolstered the cause of American politicians aiming to stop opaque Chinese companies from raising money in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Luckin Coffee had an audacious goal: take on Starbucks in China. Last year, unprofitable, burning through cash and not even two years old, it went to Wall Street to raise over half a billion dollars. Just a few months ago, it was valued at $12 billion.

headline: In Canada, Watches From Wood
abstract: Companies like Tense Watches use small pieces that otherwise might be thrown away.
lead_paragraph: Residents of British Columbia are known throughout Canada for their fierce protectiveness of the province’s natural resources, so it should come as no surprise that a watch company based there prides itself on creating timepieces from reclaimed wood.

headline: In Denmark, Young Watch Brands Focus on Design
abstract: Businesses use flair, modest prices and ecological practices to attract buyers.
lead_paragraph: Danish design may soon have a watch industry moment. And it’s not just that the Copenhagen architect Bjarke Ingels designed the new Audemars Piguet museum, scheduled to open in June.

headline: Rishi Kapoor, Leading Man From a Bollywood Dynasty, Dies at 67
abstract: Best known as a romantic hero, he had a charm and charisma that made him one of India’s most popular actors of the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Rishi Kapoor, a widely popular film actor from one of Bollywood’s most celebrated families, died on Thursday in Mumbai. He was 67.

headline: Her M.R.I. Came Back Normal After a Seizure. Could It Be Covid-19?
abstract: Her urine showed what might be an infection, but despite antibiotics, the patient spiked a fever two days later.
lead_paragraph: “Honey” — the woman could hear fear tightening her husband’s voice as he called out to her — “I think your mother just died.” She ran into the living room. Her 78-year-old mother sat rigid in a chair, her skin gray and lifeless. Her eyes were open but all white, as if she were trying to see the back of her own skull. Then her arms started to make little jerking movements; her lips parted as saliva seeped out the corner of her mouth onto her chin. Then her body slumped. She seemed awake but confused after this seizure-like episode.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Keeping a Record Player and Its Records Separate
abstract: 1970s radio station vibes or a higher step count?
lead_paragraph: Philip writes: My wife, Kimla, and I have an amazing record player and sound system in our living room. But she insists that her record collection remain down in our rec room. As a result, we rarely use the record player. Please order her to store her collection in the living room.

headline: In the Kitchen and on the Best-Seller List, Young Cooks Take the Lead
abstract: Who cares if there’s tomato sauce on the ceiling? Middle schoolers are making dinner.
lead_paragraph: ORDER UP They specialize in brownies, cake pops and whipped hot chocolate. They make a respectable chili, diner-worthy scrambled eggs and pizza with the optimal cheese-to-sauce ratio. Meet the celebrity chefs of the great pause: kids. For the first time in recent memory, youthful enthusiasm has propelled three cookbooks to the top of the children’s middle grade hardcover list.

headline: 178 Hours in Milan During the Lockdown
abstract: A visual diary by the artist Olimpia Zagnoli.
lead_paragraph: A visual diary by the artist Olimpia Zagnoli.

headline: Michael Cunningham Thinks Most People Misunderstand ‘Lolita’
abstract: Granted, it’s “about a sociopathic predatory pedophilic rapist.” But it’s also “a messed-up love story right out of ‘Beauty and the Beast.’”
lead_paragraph: Granted, says the author of books including “The Hours” and “A Wild Swan,” it’s “about a sociopathic predatory pedophilic rapist.” But it’s also “a messed-up love story right out of ‘Beauty and the Beast.’”

headline: How Do You Run for President During a Pandemic?
abstract: Joe Biden’s primary victory seemed like a vindication of the idea that in politics, the internet isn’t real life. What happens now that it is?

headline: With Mothers and Daughters, It’s Always Complicated
abstract: Two memoirs and a novel explore one of the deepest, most powerful relationships there is.

headline: Can Genetic Engineering Bring Back the American Chestnut?
abstract: The tree helped build industrial America before disease wiped out an estimated three billion or more of them. To revive their lost glory, we may need to embrace tinkering with nature.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in 1989, Herbert Darling got a call: A hunter told him he had come across a tall, straight American chestnut tree on Darling’s property in Western New York’s Zoar Valley. Darling knew that chestnuts were once among the area’s most important trees. He also knew that a deadly fungus had all but wiped out the species more than a half-century earlier. When he heard the hunter’s report of having seen a living chestnut whose trunk was two feet thick and rose to the height of a five-story building, he was skeptical. “I wasn’t sure I believed he knew what one was,” Darling says.

headline: Poem: Zodiac
abstract: Who are we? Who are we not? What contradictions do we carry?
lead_paragraph: How would we describe ourselves? Who are we not? What contradictions do we carry? Dilruba Ahmed’s luminous second book of poems, “Bring Now the Angels,” considers layered relationships and identities: adults to parents and children; bystanders as public witnesses; humans to angels, to water, or bureaucracy — or, as in “Zodiac,” to the self. The “tightly locked heart” clinking back to back with the “longing to be known” offers a deeply sympathetic voice, honest as a friend, endearing from opening to end. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Three Roommates Scraped Together Enough for a Brooklyn Rental. Which One Did They Choose?
abstract: For about $1,000 each, they hoped to find a decent place near a good bagel store. Now they’re stuck there as they wait out the lockdown.
lead_paragraph: For about $1,000 each, they hoped to find a decent place near a good bagel store. Now they’re stuck there as they wait out the lockdown.

headline: This Book Will Take You to Beautiful Places With Palm Trees
abstract: By the end, you’ll return to your home and see it with new eyes.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions, and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.

headline: In My Small Town in Alaska, I Miss Small-Town Life
abstract: Before the pandemic, I sometimes would choose not to go out because I didn’t want to run into certain people. Now I realize how lucky we were.
lead_paragraph: HAINES, Alaska — When I first saw the big electronic sign at the corner by the school and Mountain Market flashing “Stay Home” and “Save Lives,” it was like a warning light for my heart. When a refrigerated shipping container was placed behind the fire hall to serve as a temporary morgue (our regular one can hold only two people), I felt I couldn’t breathe. The fire chief said he didn’t mean to frighten anyone.

headline: Weighing Risks for My Patients at a Time of Covid-19
abstract: When should the fear of catching a virus, and one that usually causes a mild infection, outweigh the need to address urgent medical issues?
lead_paragraph: My patients continue to have medical problems that are not related to the coronavirus. But now, when I offer recommendations — especially those that possibly involve putting themselves at risk of contracting a Covid-19 infection — they often reject my advice.

headline: In Psychotherapy, the Toilet Has Become the New Couch
abstract: Virtual sessions offer the intimacy — and comedy — of seeing patients and therapists in their personal environments.
lead_paragraph: Every day since the onset of the coronavirus outbreak, friends and family have been checking in on me — and not just in the general way that we all seem to be checking in on the people we love. They worry that the kind of work I do might make me sick — emotionally, that is.

headline: No One to Hunker Down With
abstract: Three days before we were told to stay home, the man I’d been dating for a month told me he was self-isolating.
lead_paragraph: Three days before the governor of my state issued his stay at home order, the 45-year-old man I’d been dating for a month told me he was self-isolating.

headline: Turn Your Demanding Child Into a Productive Co-Worker
abstract: All it takes are a few lessons from global cultures that raise remarkably cooperative and generous kids.
lead_paragraph: At 10 a.m. on a Tuesday morning, I lock myself in our bedroom, slide down the back of the door and begin to cry. “But Mama, but Mama,” my 4-year-old daughter screams from the hallway. “Just one video! One more video! One more!”

headline: States Made It Harder to Get Jobless Benefits. Now That’s Hard to Undo.
abstract: Systems that were devised to treat each case as potentially fraudulent are now rushing to deal with millions of newly unemployed people.
lead_paragraph: The state unemployment systems that were supposed to help millions of jobless workers were full of boxes to check and mandates to meet that couldn’t possibly apply in a pandemic.

headline: The Science on Coronavirus Is Topsy-Turvy. That’s Fine.
abstract: Urgency demands patience, because advancement is always a product of missteps.
lead_paragraph: Contradiction seems the only constant in the Covid-19 crisis.

headline: Trapped at Home? Board Game On!
abstract: Rolling dice, dealing cards and moving game pieces: Our writer and her family are playing board games as a survival strategy. Why are these games so soothing right now?
lead_paragraph: I am, in the best circumstances, a poor loser. I’m also a clumsy, fidgety winner.

headline: Thursday’s Livestreaming Events: Benedict Cumberbatch in ‘Frankenstein,’ and Remembering Amy Winehouse
abstract: Appointment viewing is back. Find out what online events to look for today, and when to tune in.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the best events happening Thursday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern Daylight).

headline: This ‘Big Oil’ Bust Is Killing My Town
abstract: I want us to pursue paths to cleaner, renewable energy. But not like this.
lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Texas — I cried the day I moved to Midland, the capital of our nation’s oil and gas industry. Back then, almost 10 years ago, my husband’s new job designing control systems for natural gas processing plants wasn’t the sort of work I wanted him to take.

headline: Will Warm Weather Slow Coronavirus?
abstract: It’s hard to know yet. But there are many things we can do to flatten the next wave of the contagion.
lead_paragraph: Will there be another wave of Covid-19? And if so, how big will it be, and will there be more waves after it?

headline: An Arrest at St. Patrick’s, a Struggle for Help, Then a Suicide
abstract: A New Jersey man charged with attempted arson was released from jail because of coronavirus fears. But he had to wait to begin psychiatric treatment.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after Marc Lamparello was released early from Rikers Island jail because of concerns over the coronavirus, he drove his parents’ van to the George Washington Bridge and tried to climb over an 11-foot fence intended to prevent suicides. The police stopped him.

headline: When Science Is Partisan
abstract: A conversation with National Affairs editor Yuval Levin.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: Why the Global Debt of Poor Nations Must Be Canceled
abstract: Delaying the repayments to the Group of 20 is not enough.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — On April 15, Group of 20 countries offered temporary relief to some of the world’s lowest-income countries by suspending debt repayments until the end of the year. It is a step in the right direction and provides an opportunity to redirect financial resources toward dealing with the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Trump Officials Are Said to Press Spies to Link Virus and Wuhan Labs
abstract: Some analysts are worried that the pressure from senior officials could distort assessments about the coronavirus and be used as a weapon in an escalating battle with China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Trump administration officials have pushed American spy agencies to hunt for evidence to support an unsubstantiated theory that a government laboratory in Wuhan, China, was the origin of the coronavirus outbreak, according to current and former American officials. The effort comes as President Trump escalates a public campaign to blame China for the pandemic.

headline: Justin Amash, Third-Party Spoiler? Michigan Experts Are Skeptical
abstract: Democrats worry that if the congressman runs for president, he could siphon votes in a state Donald Trump narrowly won four years ago. But strategists say this election is much different.
lead_paragraph: If a third-party presidential candidate were going to have a spoiler effect anywhere in 2020, it would seem to be in Michigan, after Representative Justin Amash, a five-term congressman from Grand Rapids, said this week he was preparing a bid for the Libertarian nomination in the November election.

headline: As Georgia Reopens, Virus Study Shows Black Residents May Bear Brunt
abstract: A C.D.C. report released Wednesday suggests that the African-American community in the state is especially vulnerable to infection.
lead_paragraph: As Georgia reopens many businesses over objections from President Trump and others, a new study illustrates the high rates of coronavirus infection among black people in the state.

headline: Should the Virus Mean Straight A’s for Everyone?
abstract: Schools nationwide are debating whether to issue grades to high school students during the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: As high schools approach the end of an academic year without proms or field trips or graduation ceremonies, another fundamental part of American education is being transformed: the report card.

headline: Putin, Russia’s Man of Action, Is Passive, Even Bored, in the Coronavirus Era
abstract: The pandemic has derailed Vladimir V. Putin’s plans for a big military parade and a referendum extending his rule — and now knocked out his prime minister — as the Russian leader struggles to find his stride.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — This was supposed to be a moment of triumph for President Vladimir V. Putin, a celebration of his grand successes in restoring the Russian state to a place of pride in the world and consolidating his grip on power, all topped off by a glorious military parade in Red Square on May 9, the 75th anniversary of the Red Army’s victory over Nazi Germany.

headline: PG&E’s Settlement With Wildfire Victims Faces Crucial Vote
abstract: Some victims think the $13.5 billion deal is flawed and are worried that a lawyer who negotiated it has a conflict of interest.
lead_paragraph: Pacific Gas & Electric and thousands of California families who lost homes or loved ones in fires caused by the utility’s equipment reached a $13.5 billion settlement in December, seemingly putting off a lengthy and fraught legal battle. The deal would allow the company to resolve its bankruptcy and provide homeowners money to rebuild.

headline: Georgia Went First. And It Screwed Up.
abstract: Here’s what other states can learn from our inept reopening.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Last week was a bad one for Georgia, and an especially bad one for our governor, Brian Kemp. On April 20, he announced that he would allow Georgia’s tattoo parlors, hair and nail salons and other “high touch” businesses to reopen as early as April 24, ahead of even President Trump’s ambitious plans. In the days since, the state has reverberated with political turmoil. Even the president rebuked Mr. Kemp for moving too fast.

headline: Trump’s Disinfectant Talk Trips Up Sites’ Vows Against Misinformation
abstract: Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have declined to remove the president’s statements about unproven coronavirus treatments.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, said in March that promoting bleach as a cure for the coronavirus was “misinformation that has imminent risk of danger” and that such messages would immediately be removed from the social network.

headline: People Have Gone Full 1800s
abstract: In the midst of quarantine, flower pressing, natural dyeing and other activities from Victorian times have made a comeback.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve gone full Victorian,” said Rhian Rees, 34, of flower pressing, a childhood hobby she’s rediscovered in quarantine. “It feels like we’re back in the old days when life felt more fragile.”

headline: Samanta Schweblin Talks About Her Creepy New Novel
abstract: “How can we talk about technology without getting tangled up in technical terms?” the Argentine author asks. “Little Eyes,” about stuffed animals operated remotely by strangers, is her answer.
lead_paragraph: Samanta Schweblin’s writing straddles the unsettling border between the real and the surreal. Her novel “Fever Dream” takes place in a hospital where a dying woman narrates episodes from her past to a strange young boy who is missing part of his soul. Her short story collection “Mouthful of Birds” features a woman who falls in love with a merman, an expectant mother who shrinks her fetus to the size of an almond and spits it out, and a teenage girl who devours live birds.

headline: What Do Famous People’s Bookshelves Reveal?
abstract: In quarantine, people are inadvertently exposing their reading habits — embarrassing, surprising and impressive.
lead_paragraph: Bibliophiles do not approach bookshelves lightly. A stranger’s collection is to us a window to their soul. We peruse with judgment, sometimes admiration and occasionally repulsion (Ayn Rand?!). With celebrities now frequently speaking on television in front of their home libraries, a voyeuristic pleasure presents itself: Are they actually really like us?

headline: Food Lines a Mile Long in America’s Second-Wealthiest State
abstract: “We’ve never had to rely on anyone else,” said one food bank visitor. But now, pushed to the edge of hunger, many unemployed New Jersey residents are asking for help for the first time.
lead_paragraph: EGG HARBOR, N.J. — Jean Wickham’s two sons are in college. Her husband has worked at the same New Jersey casino for 36 years.

headline: How Coronavirus Mutates and Spreads
abstract: The virus has mutated. But that doesn’t mean it’s getting deadlier.
lead_paragraph: The virus has mutated. But that doesn’t mean it’s getting deadlier.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
abstract: The mayor defended his handling of a crowd at a rabbi’s funeral in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: As Several States Loosen Rules, California Closes Some Beaches
abstract: New Jersey is now reporting more daily deaths than any other state. The federal government will increase inspections of nursing homes after a series of outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Biden Reveals Allies Who Will Help Pick a Running Mate
abstract: Announcing the leaders of his vice-presidential selection committee, Joe Biden moved his search for a running mate into a new phase, with a vetting process that might last until July.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign on Thursday announced the leaders of his vice-presidential selection committee, moving his search for a running mate into a new and more serious phase.

headline: Coronavirus, Remdesivir, Unemployment: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Long Will a Vaccine Really Take?
abstract: Experts say at least 18 months. Here’s how to shorten the timeline.
lead_paragraph: Experts say at least 18 months. Here’s how to shorten the timeline.

headline: Biden’s Campaign of Isolation
abstract: Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee, is struggling to attain the same visibility as the president. But is that a good thing?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Two Women, Two Career Paths and a Shared Passion: Cars
abstract: The hall of famer and the young gun. How two enthusiasts have carved a life in racing.
lead_paragraph: Sue Mead wasn’t always a hall-of-fame automotive journalist. She started her career, in fact, as a floral designer before stints in the mental health care field.

headline: When Can I Start Using My Building’s Gym Again?
abstract: Luxury apartment buildings in New York City are starting to reopen their amenity spaces, with limits.
lead_paragraph: Summer is coming. And for the New Yorkers who live in buildings with gyms, roof decks, pools and playrooms, reopening these spaces could mean the difference between a grueling summer and a bearable one.

headline: As Premier League Weighs Saudi Bid for Newcastle, It Criticized Kingdom
abstract: The Premier League wrote a letter to a U.S. trade body, urging it to keep Saudi Arabia on a list of nations that breach intellectual property rules.
lead_paragraph: Well, this is awkward.

headline: ‘We Are Not Learning Lessons’: South Korea Mourns an Avoidable Disaster
abstract: Major fires, many of them linked to lax safety standards, have plagued South Korea for decades. The latest, on Wednesday, killed 38.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Seventy-eight workers, from nine different subcontractors, were busy Wednesday laying tiles and installing cargo elevators to meet a June deadline for completing a four-story cold-storage warehouse. Another crew was coating underground walls with polyurethane foam — a cheap but efficient insulator that can easily catch fire and then emit extremely toxic fumes.

headline: Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg Aren’t on the Same Page
abstract: On earnings calls with investors, executives are addressing the effects of the pandemic in radically different ways.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: ‘Bull’ Review: A Lot to Wrangle With
abstract: A worn-out bull rider and a troubled teenager form an improbable connection in this low-key, naturalistic drama.
lead_paragraph: Set in the unfamiliar world of African-American backyard rodeos, Annie Silverstein’s “Bull” handles hot-button issues with a cool eye and a calming tone. Racism, opioid use, poverty and pain weave gently in and out of her story (co-written with her husband, Johnny McAllister) without distracting us from either its primary concerns or central relationship.

headline: ‘Capital in the Twenty-First Century’ Review: Economic History, Illustrated
abstract: Justin Pemberton’s documentary version of the Thomas Piketty best seller is best regarded as a supplement or potential gateway to the book.
lead_paragraph: You need read only a small portion of “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Thomas Piketty’s towering 2013 economic and historical survey of the dynamics of inequality, to know that Piketty, a French academic, is not only a brilliant economist but also one with a gift for making complicated ideas accessible. But the text runs around 750 pages, and not everyone is prepared to plow through Piketty’s methodical analysis of capital-income ratios from 1700 to the near-present.

headline: ‘15 Years’ Review: On the Run From a Midlife Crisis
abstract: A gay Israeli architect in a committed relationship is undone when the specter of parenthood is raised.
lead_paragraph: A sinister opening set to a pulsating score establishes a misleading tone for the Israeli domestic drama “15 Years” (out now on DVD and VOD): A man in his 40s nervously jogs alone at night until something startling makes him halt in his steps. Cloaked in dim, ambient lighting, this chain of events recurs throughout the film, though some of his late-night forays, on foot or by bicycle, are actually dreams while others are revealed as cruising. They all reflect the midlife crisis of Yoav (Oded Leopold), a Tel Aviv architect.

headline: ‘Liberté’ Review: A Miserable Orgy From the Provocateur Albert Serra
abstract: Exiled aristocrats go on a tear of strained debauchery in Serra’s new film.
lead_paragraph: At times, critics’ own words may fail them. In trying to find a proper description for “Liberté,” the new film from the provocative and occasionally (but not in this case!) sublime Catalan director Albert Serra, the words that most often sprang to mind were from Mel Brooks. That is, the hunchbacked hangman’s line from “Blazing Saddles”: “This one is a doozy.”

headline: ‘Until the Birds Return’ Review: Algerian Life, and Nothing More
abstract: This tender, ruminative drama about contemporary life traces the singular moments that form the nodes of a shared national history.
lead_paragraph: “Until the Birds Return” opens with a car cruising down a winding, sun-dappled city street. This image becomes the connective tissue between three otherwise divergent stories in Karim Moussaoui’s tender, ruminative drama about life in contemporary Algeria.

headline: ‘Closeness’ Review: A Russian Kidnapping Drama Unsettles in Unexpected Ways
abstract: The first feature film from Kantemir Balagov arguably commits an egregious breach of cinematic ethics.
lead_paragraph: The early scenes of “Tesnota (Closeness)” — the first feature directed by Kantemir Balagov, whose subsequent “Beanpole” was Russia’s 2019 entry for the international feature Academy Award — convey unsettling sexual intrigue and old-fashioned exuberance. The tomboyish Ilana (Darya Zhovner) and her brother David (Veniamin Katz), part of a working-class Jewish family living in the Russian town of Nalchik in 1998, have an unusually close relationship. A little before David’s engagement party, the siblings have a cheeky discussion on how “lucky” David’s betrothed is, given his sexual equipment. Whoa.

headline: ‘The Wretched’ Review: Don’t Go Into the Basement
abstract: A teenager suspects that the woman next door has supernatural origins in this atmospheric chiller.
lead_paragraph: Things go missing in “The Wretched” — a bunny, a baby, assorted children — and hardly anyone seems to notice. A darkened basement reverberates with eerie, snap-crackle-pop sounds and images that feature ghostly shots of a child’s crib. Something ancient and evil is crawling out of a butchered deer carcass. And it’s hungry.

headline: ‘The Infiltrators’ Review: Immigrant Activists Slip Into Detention
