abstract: Re-enactments are combined with documentary footage to tell the story of people who get detained on purpose, to help immigrants on the inside.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, a group of activists who were undocumented immigrants willingly got themselves sent to detention facilities, where they worked from the inside to free people who were scheduled for deportation. The docu-thriller “The Infiltrators” depicts their feat, following Marco Saavedra and Viridiana Martinez, both of whom had protected status through the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA. As part of a rigorous strategy, these two and their comrades targeted the Broward Transitional Center in Florida, where men and women were being held in custody despite their lack of criminal records.

headline: On Politics: Pressure Grows on Biden
abstract: Calls to respond to an allegation, and promising coronavirus news: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence participated in a meeting on Wednesday with industry executives about reopening the economy.

headline: Subway to Stop for 4 Hours Every Night So Cars Can Be Cleaned
abstract: The interruption of service from 1 a.m. to 5 a.m. is believed to be the first regularly scheduled systemwide halt in 52 years.
lead_paragraph: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Friday’s live coverage.]

headline: Word + Quiz: chignon
abstract: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: I’m Sorry
abstract: What story does this image inspire for you?
lead_paragraph: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: While at Home, Let’s Color the World
abstract: With the coronavirus confining people to their homes, coloring books for both children and adults have experienced a renewed popularity. Here are some pages inspired by a few of our favorite travel photos.
lead_paragraph: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.

headline: Joy Harjo Is Named U.S. Poet Laureate for a Second Term
abstract: The first Native American to hold the position, Harjo will be developing an interactive map of contemporary Native poets.
lead_paragraph: Joy Harjo has been appointed to a second term as the nation’s poet laureate, the Library of Congress announced on Thursday.

headline: How to Feel Together When You Are Apart
abstract: For couples physically separated by coronavirus, here are a few strategies to make your newly long-distance relationship feel a little bit closer.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus lockdown has separated many of us from our loved ones — in some instances, even our partners and spouses. As a relationship and sex therapist, I’ve been working with a number of clients who are living separately from their partners. One patient is a medical worker who treats coronavirus patients every day and has chosen to live separately from his spouse so as not to expose his family to the disease. In another relationship, the couple were traveling separately when the crisis struck, and they did not have the ability to get back to the same location, so they now reside 50 miles apart, with one partner living with her elderly parents.

headline: How Do You Connect With Your Parents?
abstract: Are there shared interests or hobbies, such as sports, books, movies or games, that bring you closer together?
lead_paragraph: What do you share in common with your parents, or guardians? Are there any interests or activities that you enjoy doing, watching or discussing together? For example, do you both play Minecraft, listen to Beyoncé, love soccer, watch reruns of “The Office,” enjoy Irish dancing or relish baking? Have you ever wished that your parents cared about one of your sports or interests as much as you do?

headline: Stymied in Seeking Benefits, Millions of Unemployed Go Uncounted
abstract: As state agencies grapple with new guidelines and sheer volume, many workers are frustrated in filing claims and omitted from jobless tallies.
lead_paragraph: With a flood of unemployment claims continuing to overwhelm many state agencies, economists say the job losses may be far worse than government tallies indicate.

headline: ‘Deerskin’ Review: Swayed by Suede
abstract: Jean Dujardin convincingly plays a man whose love for his jacket becomes a dark and dangerous obsession.
lead_paragraph: The plot of “Deerskin” could fit on a postage stamp, but the titular obsession of its antihero only grows with every scene. Initially, when we accompany Georges (Jean Dujardin) as he buys a woefully unflattering vintage suede jacket from a private seller, his near-erotic delight in the fringed relic seems rather sweet. By the end, though, we suspect that Georges’s love for animal hide conceals a loathing for his own.

headline: I Need a Vacation From Parenting in Isolation
abstract: Can I ask my ex to take the kids, even though his girlfriend doesn’t want them?
lead_paragraph: My ex-husband, the father of my two young children, moved to the Catskills with his girlfriend. He hasn’t been seeing our kids during the pandemic because he says his girlfriend is “terrified she will die if they visit.” She claims to have a lung issue (that he only learned about recently). The kids and I have been staying at home in Brooklyn for over a month. No one is sick. And I’ve been on my own with them this whole time. I could use a little break. Can I ask my ex to take them to the Catskills for a visit?

headline: Which Cities Offer Renters the Least and Most Personal Space?
abstract: A new study looks at average household and apartment sizes to find out.
lead_paragraph: People everywhere are stuck inside waiting out the Covid-19 pandemic — but of course, some are more cramped than others. A new study by RentCafé offers insight into where American renters have the least amount of personal space.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: A tote to feel good about — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Old Drugs May Find a New Purpose: Fighting the Coronavirus
abstract: A “drug repurposing” strategy uncovers dozens of compounds that have the unexpected potential to combat the virus.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1950s, psychiatrists began treating schizophrenia with a new drug called chlorpromazine. Seven decades later, the drug is still used as an anti-psychotic.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom in Hopewell, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Centerport, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom in Hopewell, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Centerport, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom in Hopewell, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Centerport, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Brooklyn Heights, Astoria and Harlem.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Brooklyn Heights, Astoria and Harlem.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Brooklyn Heights, Astoria and Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Why the People Harvesting Californians’ Food Can’t Afford It
abstract: Thursday: A look at how Covid-19 is compounding struggles to buy food. Also: Free testing in Los Angeles, and the Bay Area loosens sheltering orders.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: To Restart After Lockdown, Theaters Need to Think Small
abstract: Theatrical extravaganzas could be a long time returning. But until then, there are plenty of great plays with tiny casts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Right now, it feels like time’s been put on hold. Or so I thought one recent afternoon as I walked the quiet streets of London and passed my local playhouse, the Hampstead Theater.

headline: Why Days 5 to 10 Are So Important When You Have Coronavirus
abstract: Tracking your daily symptoms can help you and your doctors make better decisions about whether a hospital visit is needed.
lead_paragraph: When a relative of mine recently became seriously ill with what seemed to be a coronavirus infection, my first question was about timing. How many days ago did your symptoms start?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Now Virtual and in Video, Museum Websites Shake Off the Dust’
abstract: In this lesson, students will take a virtual field trip through some of the world’s greatest museums.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Now Virtual and in Video, Museum Websites Shake Off the Dust” by Jason Farago

headline: A New Mother’s Search for Home
abstract: In “This Is All I Got,” the writer Lauren Sandler follows a young woman through homelessness, welcoming new life and the search for stability.
lead_paragraph: When I was reporting “This Is All I Got: A New Mother’s Search for Home,” my intention was to offer a keyhole view into a life familiar to many people in poverty, but unknown to most people outside it. My book is the story of a tenacious young woman and the constellation of factors that led to her homelessness. Little did I know how widespread those factors would become, how many more Americans would find themselves facing their own versions of what I witnessed.

headline: ‘Our Mothers’ Review: Uncovering Atrocities in Guatemala, Bone by Bone
abstract: A young anthropologist is on a mission in this feature debut from César Díaz.
lead_paragraph: The fiction feature directorial debut of the Guatemalan filmmaker César Díaz is a modestly scaled picture with massive implications. Díaz’s background is in editing, and there’s a strong documentary component in his filmography. So it’s fitting that in this picture the protagonist is a forensic anthropologist — one who is working on a project that goes back decades rather than centuries, which is usually what we see in movies featuring anthropologists.

headline: Alice Trumbull Mason: America’s Forgotten Modernist
abstract: The first monograph of a painter’s painter brings a jolt of new insight and a confident show of her works’ mindfulness and beauty.
lead_paragraph: Alice Trumbull Mason, a painter who never got her due, turned to abstraction at 25, in 1929, when its American adherents were few and it was viewed as a foreign, even Communist element. She was inspired by the art of Wassily Kandinsky and by Arshile Gorky, one of Abstract Expressionism’s founders, with whom she studied. Her belief that abstraction was, in her words, “the true realism” never wavered — nor did she ever run out of ideas over her 40-year career.

headline: Mark Ruffalo Fights (and Comforts) Himself for ‘I Know This Much Is True’
abstract: The actor, who plays twin brothers in this new HBO series, and the director Derek Cianfrance discuss why this dark story of family bonds and mental illness is right for right now.
lead_paragraph: “I Know This Much Is True,” an HBO limited series based on Wally Lamb’s 1998 brick of a book, begins when Thomas Birdsey enters a public library and amputates his right hand. This is only the first calamity.

headline: Texas Man Is Accused of Opening Fire at the Cuban Embassy in Washington
abstract: There were no reports of injuries, the authorities said. The man was charged with assault with intent to kill.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man accused of opening fire outside the Cuban Embassy in Washington early Thursday morning was arrested and charged with assault with intent to kill, the authorities said, reporting damage to the building but no injuries.

headline: Will the Food Habits of Scallion Nation Outlast Quarantine?
abstract: The Great Depression and other hardships made lasting changes, but the recent boom in sourdough starters, vegetable gardening and buying local may not be as permanent.
lead_paragraph: I’ve charted the microtrends on social media — scraggly scallion butts taking root in water; hungry sourdough starters burping on kitchen counters; more and more dishes built sensibly, and creatively, from scraps that some home cooks once considered garbage.

headline: Bollywood Reels From Deaths of 2 Stars in 2 Days
abstract: Irrfan Khan, a beloved actor, had cancer and died of an infection. Another movie giant, Rishi Kapoor, who had leukemia, also died. The coronavirus lockdown ruled out big funerals for either.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In less than 24 hours, Bollywood has lost two legends, back to back.

headline: The Virus vs. Journalism
abstract: The disappearance of local information.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Review: ‘Hollywood’ Gives Movie History a Sudsy Rewrite
abstract: Ryan Murphy’s latest for Netflix starts an intriguing journey into an alternative 1940s Tinseltown, then swerves into schmaltz.
lead_paragraph: At the Golden Tip service station, somewhere in Los Angeles in the late 1940s, they pump more than gas. Drive up, tell the handsome attendant “I want to go to Dreamland,” and he’s yours, for a fee.

headline: The Triumphant Return of Fiona Apple, Pop Music Renegade
abstract: A conversation about everything “Fetch the Bolt Cutters” and beyond.
lead_paragraph: This month Fiona Apple released her fifth album, “Fetch the Bolt Cutters,” an event that was received with significant awe and rapturous praise. Apple often takes her time between records — her previous one, “The Idler Wheel …,” was released in 2012 — but the greeting she received was about much more than a long absence.

headline: Pegu Club, a Pioneering Manhattan Cocktail Bar, Won’t Reopen
abstract: The SoHo bar kicked off the craft cocktail movement in New York, and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Pegu Club, the SoHo bar that kicked the cocktail revival in New York City into high gear when it opened in 2005 and quickly became one of the most influential cocktail bars in the world, will not reopen, a victim of the citywide restaurant and bar shutdown in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: What Should I Do if I Think My Child Has Autism?
abstract: Autism spectrum disorder affects about one in 54 children. An early diagnosis can mean quicker access to the medical, behavioral and social services that a child may need.
lead_paragraph: Tiffany Lewis didn’t need a doctor to tell her that her son’s speech was delayed. As a special education tutor, she knew he should have been able to say more than two or three words at 18 months. He couldn’t say “Mama” or anything close to it. When a pediatrician told her that toddlers at his age typically used dozens of words, she became anxious.

headline: Should You Give Your Kid CBD?
abstract: More Americans are using the hemp (or marijuana) extract on their kids, but experts aren’t sold on its efficacy.
lead_paragraph: Priscilla Batista is stuck at home in Charlotte, N.C., with a highly emotional 4-year-old.“Every toddler obviously is emotional, but she’s a pretty constant, volatile child,” she said. “It doesn’t allow her to focus. She’s just struggling.” Batista doesn’t yet have an official diagnosis for her daughter, but, suspecting an attention deficit disorder, she has turned to CBD (cannabidiol) for help.

headline: ‘Parks and Recreation’ Is Back. Here’s Where We Left Off.
abstract: The beloved NBC sitcom is returning Thursday for a reunion special to benefit Feeding America. Here’s where things stood the last time we were in Pawnee.
lead_paragraph: This preview includes spoilers for “Parks and Recreation.”

headline: European Slump Is Worst Since World War II, Reports Show
abstract: The European Central Bank will pay banks to lend money after the economy shrank the most in decades. The worst is yet to come, the eurozone’s top central banker warned.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Europe is in the midst of a downturn not seen since the end of World War II, and the worst is yet to come, Europe’s top central banker said Thursday as she painted a scenario that will test how far the continent’s political leaders are willing to go to preserve their fractured union.

headline: David Toren, Who Fought to Recover Nazi-Looted Art, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Toren, who died of the coronavirus, was a patent lawyer who recovered a relative’s stolen painting amid a large cache of works discovered in Germany.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: A New Affliction for Restaurant Owners: Burglars
abstract: Emboldened by the vacant streets and empty dining rooms, thieves in some cities are targeting restaurants.
lead_paragraph: In New Haven, Conn., a man broke into a Cuban restaurant and spent days drinking his way through the liquor selection. In San Jose, Calif., a restaurant owner watched from his phone as security cameras recorded a burglar’s helping himself to the best bottles in the bar. And in San Francisco, a restaurant in the city’s wholesale Flower Mart was robbed or vandalized four times in less than a month.

headline: Germany Hardens Ban on Hezbollah
abstract: The United States and Israel welcomed Berlin’s move to effectively outlaw all activity by the militant group and called on the rest of Europe to follow suit.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany on Thursday banned the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah from carrying out any activity on its soil and declared the group a terrorist organization, in a move, long sought by Israel and the United States, that deals a blow to its ability to operate in Europe.

headline: Why Won’t TV News Book Tara Reade?
abstract: The stakes are high for the media in the case of a sexual assault allegation against Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: There were good reasons to be skeptical of her 20-year-old allegations: She’d changed her story and said some weird stuff, and even denied the whole thing under oath.

headline: National Security Surveillance on U.S. Soil Fell Amid Scrutiny of Russia Inquiry
abstract: But overseas targets of the government’s warrantless surveillance program continued to soar in 2019, a new report disclosed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of people targeted for court-approved surveillance by counterterrorism and counterintelligence investigators in 2019 plunged to its lowest level in at least seven years, a drop that coincided with intense scrutiny on the F.B.I.’s use of its national-security wiretapping power in the Trump-Russia investigation.

headline: Music, Theater and More to Experience at Home This Weekend
abstract: Our writers offer suggestions for what to watch, read or listen to while we’re housebound.
lead_paragraph: Audience participation may be one of the less lamented live experiences we’re missing out on now. No matter how brilliant a play is, interaction is a deal breaker for a good number of the theater faithful.

headline: Four Amish Children Dead and One Is Missing After Buggy Overturns
abstract: A deputy coroner in northeastern Kentucky said their mother was able to reach the banks of a waterway and summon help on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Four Amish children were dead and one was missing on Thursday after the horse-drawn buggy they were riding in with their mother overturned on a bridge in northeastern Kentucky, the authorities said.

headline: Review: Same Apple Family, New Kind of Theater
abstract: In Richard Nelson’s “What Do We Need to Talk About?,” a familiar clan poses resonant questions about how we connect in the age of social distancing.
lead_paragraph: When your world has turned strange and scary, sometimes just seeing a beloved face from your past is enough to bring tears to your eyes. That was how I felt when Barbara Apple — looking a bit pale and careworn, but unmistakably herself — materialized on my computer screen on Wednesday night.

headline: 2002: When the Rock Went Hollywood and Movie Stars Still Ruled
abstract: Two decades ago, the box office glittered with Sandra Bullock, Ben Affleck, Jodie Foster and a certain pro wrestler. Now it’s all about the franchise.
lead_paragraph: With no box office to sift through during this pandemic, we’re making do, once again, with old numbers. And the top movies for the weekend of April 19, 2002, are loaded with stars. That’s worth mentioning because it wouldn’t happen now on any weekend, really. We used to rely on these people to shine in anything — gold or crap, in January, December or July (although, with January, a real star should never want his bluff called). That weekend was loaded with stars in the good and godawful but mostly the so-so.

headline: I’m Grateful for Bad Virtual Life
abstract: Thank goodness for crummy video conferencing.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: N.Y.C.’s Subway, a 24/7 Mainstay, Will Close for Overnight Disinfection
abstract: The system has fully shut down only twice in the past decade, both times as a result of hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: New York has long prided itself on its 24-hour subway, one of the world’s few round-the-clock transit systems and a symbol of the city’s relentless energy. But since the coronavirus outbreak began, the subway has reflected the city’s deterioration: Ridership has plummeted by more than 90 percent, thousands of sick workers have hobbled the ability to run service, and the number of homeless people on trains has grown.

headline: He Indicted Netanyahu, but Sees No Reason to Bar Him From Office
abstract: Israel's Supreme Court is to hear arguments on petitions to disqualify the prime minister, who faces trial on corruption charges, and against a coalition deal.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s attorney general said Thursday that neither the criminal charges Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is facing nor the unusual terms of the coalition deal he struck with a former rival should disqualify him from forming a new government.

headline: Viewing Party! Let’s All Watch ‘Do the Right Thing’ Together!
abstract: Gather at the cool-out corner and speak your mind about Spike Lee’s 1989 portrait of a neighborhood — and country — on the boil.
lead_paragraph: Looking ahead to the long, hot, socially distanced summer and to the new Spike Lee joint (“Da 5 Bloods”) coming to Netflix, we found ourselves thinking about “Do the Right Thing.” When Lee’s once-incendiary, now-classic fourth feature was released in 1989, it caused some hand-wringing among critics and commentators, who worried that its unflinching portrayal of violent racial tension might lead to riots. Those fears looked silly then (still do), but the nerves that the movie touched are as raw as ever.

headline: The F.B.I.’s Director, a Critic of Strong Encryption, Once Defended It
abstract: Christopher Wray has said tough encryption offered by companies like Facebook and Apple blinds law enforcement. But his law firm defended it five years ago.
lead_paragraph: As recently as last month, Christopher A. Wray, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was pushing tech companies like Facebook to give law enforcement access to what he called “warrant-proof encryption.”

headline: NASA Picks Moon Lander Designs by Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos Rocket Companies
abstract: It seems unlikely the space agency will meet President Trump’s goal of a return to the lunar surface by the end of 2024.
lead_paragraph: NASA announced on Thursday that it had picked three designs for spacecraft to take astronauts back to the surface of the moon.

headline: How A.I. Steered Doctors Toward a Possible Coronavirus Treatment
abstract: Specialists at the London start-up BenevolentAI helped identify the arthritis drug baricitinib, which is now part of a clinical trial.
lead_paragraph: In late January, researchers at BenevolentAI, an artificial intelligence start-up in central London, turned their attention to the coronavirus.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in May
abstract: Additions include “Space Force” starring Steve Carell and stand-up comedy specials from Jerry Seinfeld and Hannah Gadsby.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of TV shows and movies to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for May, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes schedules without giving notice.

headline: High School Seniors Are Making Yearbooks on Instagram
abstract: The class of 2020 has given up prom, graduation and other rites, but they’re sharing memories and celebrating each other’s achievements online.
lead_paragraph: As high school seniors across the country mourn the loss of year-end rituals like dressing for prom and walking across the stage at graduation, at least one tradition is alive and well: yearbook signing, though not with a pen.

headline: Helping Artists and Social Services Survive the Crisis
abstract: A special Covid-19 fund is supporting hundreds of nonprofits providing cultural programming and essential services in New York.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus crisis struck New York, four young adults with autism had come to rely on vocational training they attended every weekday through Quality Services for the Autism Community.

headline: The Tricky Dance of Sharing a Winery in the Pandemic Era
abstract: For six producers who form a mutually beneficial winemaking community in Sonoma, Covid-19 poses practical and financial obstacles beyond health.
lead_paragraph: SEBASTOPOL, Calif. — No business is built to withstand the physical distancing demands of the coronavirus pandemic. But Pax Mahle Wines here in western Sonoma County is less equipped than most.

headline: Same Winery, Separate Labels
abstract: These six producers share a common point of view and work in the same facility, yet they are each making distinctive, individualistic wines.
lead_paragraph: I was surprised to learn in the last few years that six of the California producers whose soulful wines speak most clearly to me all worked in the same winery in Sebastopol, Calif.

headline: Want to Be an Instant Expert on Film Noir? Watch This Drama
abstract: For a crash course on a category that can be hard to pin down, Nicholas Ray’s psychologically complex “In a Lonely Place” has it all, starting with a sneering Bogart.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s our gloomy national mood, the programming on Turner Classic Movies or the Columbia Noir series currently streaming on the Criterion Channel. But cinephiles have been chattering again about film noir, a category that is notoriously difficult to define but about which every movie lover has an opinion. Say you’ve heard the term, but you don’t know quite what it means — well, you have good company. Here’s a quick rundown.

headline: Coronavirus Rules: Should Other States Still Follow New York?
abstract: Readers differ about Bret Stephens’s opinion that a New York-style order doesn’t need to be applied in less affected areas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ava DuVernay and Patty Jenkins Get the Funko Pops Treatment
abstract: The collectible figurines have long included directors, but until now they were always male. A plea for inclusion changed that.
lead_paragraph: There are more than 9,000 editions of Funko Pops, those ubiquitous vinyl figurines with their black, saucerlike eyeballs and oblong heads. There are likenesses of Michael Jordan and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sailor Moon and the Incredible Hulk, Hermione Granger and Ned Stark. Recent releases include a Filipino fast-food mascot (Jollibee) and a TV egghead (Bill Nye); to date, there are 34 distinct figures of Conan O’Brien, in assorted costumes and looks.

headline: Macy’s Plans to Reopen All of Its 775 Stores in 6 to 8 Weeks
abstract: The chain’s plans also brought into sharper focus what the pandemic-era shopping experience may look like.
lead_paragraph: “No touch” consultations will be the rule at beauty counters. Ear piercing, bra fittings and alterations will be temporarily suspended. Fitting rooms will be limited. Employees will wear company-issued cloth masks. And trying on dress shirts? Forget about it.

headline: A Satellite Lets Scientists See Antarctica’s Melting Like Never Before
abstract: NASA's new ICESat-2 satellite provides the most detailed look yet of where the continent is losing and gaining ice.
lead_paragraph: NASA's new ICESat-2 satellite provides the most detailed look yet of where the continent is losing and gaining ice.

headline: There’s Something Special About the Sun: It’s a Bit Boring
abstract: The sun seems a little less active than hundreds of similar stars in our galaxy, which could play a role in why life exists in our solar system.
lead_paragraph: The sun, like all stars, is a blazing ball of fusion-powered plasma. From its surface emerge magnetic field lines that can cause dark patches known as sunspots. Turn up the activity of these magnetic whorls, and you get more solar storms flinging deadly charged particles and radiation throughout our solar system. If enough of these punishing waves hit a rocky planet, that planet might end up microwaved into a dreary condition where nothing could live.

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago I was on the subway — you remember subways? — and I noticed one of those scruffy model types who are so good looking that the disheveled hair and torn T-shirt only serve to accentuate it. The whole thing adds up, somehow, to style. I might not have remembered this, in the course of a day’s routine people-watching, except for one too-perfect-to-be-true detail: He was reading “Middlemarch,” a book whose first chapter begins, “Miss Brooke had that kind of beauty which seems to be thrown into relief by poor dress.”

headline: How to Choose Colleges With Virtual Tours
abstract: A guide to some of the tour sites that aim to help students feel as if they are walking around campuses without leaving home.
lead_paragraph: With college campuses closed because of the coronavirus pandemic, free virtual tours have grown in popularity. High school juniors hoping to begin college in the fall of 2021 are not able to visit campuses in person, but they and their families have many ways to explore their options while staying safe at home.

headline: Madeline Kripke, Doyenne of Dictionaries, Is Dead at 76
abstract: A woman of many words, mostly unspoken, she amassed a lexicographic trove of some 20,000 books, much of it crammed into her Greenwich Village apartment.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Trump’s Order to Keep Meat Plants Operating
abstract: A reader criticizes the move, saying it puts workers at risk and is a wrongheaded use of the Defense Production Act. Also: Visiting coronavirus patients in the hospital; Bernie Sanders’s supporters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: This Should Be V.R.’s Moment. Why Is It Still So Niche?
abstract: Virtual escapism is perfect for a pandemic, but V.R. still seems far from a mainstream technology.
lead_paragraph: I have wanted to love virtual reality for a really long time.

headline: Top E.U. Diplomat Says Disinformation Report Was Not Watered Down for China
abstract: Josep Borrell said that China expressed its concerns over the report, but he would not explain how. European lawmakers appeared skeptical.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Facing pointed criticism from lawmakers on Thursday, the European Union’s top diplomat denied that Chinese officials had pressured his team to soften language in a recent report on disinformation about the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Quarantini Anyone? When Everyday Drinking Becomes a Problem
abstract: As weeks in lockdown pile up, what started out as a way to unwind may start to feel like an unexpectedly stubborn habit.

headline: Frustrated by Crowds, Coastal States Weigh What to Do About Beaches
abstract: Images of packed shores have prompted a furor against officials in coastal states like California and Florida, who have resisted statewide beach closure orders.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The salty breeze and ocean waves have beckoned stir-crazy residents of the coast back to their beloved beaches, social distancing norms be damned.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Immigration Shifts
abstract: How has the foreign-born share of the U. S. population changed over time?
lead_paragraph: This graph and map, showing immigrants’ share of the U. S. population, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com.

headline: Latest Tactic to Push Migrants From Europe? A Private, Clandestine Fleet
abstract: The government of Malta enlisted three privately owned fishing trawlers to intercept migrants in the Mediterranean, and force them back to a war zone,  officials and a boat captain say.
lead_paragraph: With the onset of the coronavirus, Malta announced that it was too overwhelmed to rescue migrants making the precarious crossing of the Mediterranean Sea, where the tiny island nation has been on the front line of the maritime migration route over the past decade.

headline: Oh, Rats! Finally Moving Your Car? You May Get a Surprise.
abstract: Yes. There might be a rat nest in the engine.
lead_paragraph: You might want to make sure there’s not a rat living (or recently dead) in your car’s engine.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Coronavirus milestones, South Korea fire, Rishi Kapoor: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: After months of imposing social distancing, a few governments are now reporting remarkable milestones: recording zero new domestically transmitted coronavirus cases, or no new cases at all.

headline: Valentina Blackhorse, Navajo Pageant Winner With Dreams, Dies at 28
abstract: She nurtured political aspirations while raising her 1-year-old daughter. Then she tested positive for the novel coronavirus. The next day she was dead.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Valentina Blackhorse, the winner of one pageant after another in the Navajo Nation, was known for helping others. When the coronavirus began tearing across her reservation, she counseled family members to stay home, wash their hands and wear masks.

headline: The Hollywood Reporter Names a New Top Editor
abstract: Nekesa Mumbi Moody, an Associated Press editor, will fill the role that Matthew Belloni left after a dispute with the publication’s parent company.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood Reporter has a new boss.

headline: Now Is as Good a Time as Any to Start a Family
abstract: On affirming life, in all its uncertainty and suffering.
lead_paragraph: I had a carefully laid out plan. On June 26, we would get married. Then we would begin trying to have a baby. If we were lucky, I would get pregnant sometime before we took up our new jobs in the fall, my husband in Jerusalem and me in Philadelphia, on a one-year academic fellowship. I would visit him for Christmas, and he would come for the final months of my pregnancy and the birth. I would use this time to write my book and I would join him in Jerusalem a year later, when I would begin a philosophy professorship, baby in tow.

headline: Get Ready for the Global Fight Over Vaccines
abstract: This isn’t just about saving lives. It’s also about power, profit and national prestige.
lead_paragraph: All the world agrees: We need a vaccine for the coronavirus. But as soon as we get one, it’s going to open up a geopolitical can of worms.

headline: What Students Are Saying About ‘Life by the Numbers,’ Accents and Pandemic Protests
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to share stories about their current lives using numbers, explain what their regional accent means to them and share their thoughts on protesting during a pandemic.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: The New York Times Summer Reading Contest
abstract: In this webinar, The Learning Network discusses ways to keep teenagers reading, writing, thinking and learning on their own this summer.
lead_paragraph: Every year since 2010 The Learning Network has invited teenagers around the world to add The New York Times to their summer reading lists and, so far, over 60,000 have.

headline: Virus Pushes the Bang on a Can Marathon Online
abstract: The beloved New York musical event was set to expand this year, but will instead be livestreamed on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: It was already going to be a year of transformation for the beloved Bang on a Can Marathon. A New York new-music institution since 1987, the annual event was set to expand into a new three-day festival, Long Play, spread over several Brooklyn performance spaces.

headline: ‘We Ran Out of Space’: Bodies Pile Up as N.Y. Struggles to Bury Its Dead
abstract: The coronavirus crisis is overwhelming New York’s system for burying the dead.
lead_paragraph: The 40-foot trailer has been there for weeks, parked outside the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home in Queens. Its refrigerator hums in an alley next to a check-cashing establishment. Thirty-six bodies, one atop the other, are stacked on shelves inside.

headline: Tim Brooke-Taylor, a Mainstay of British Comedy, Dies at 79
abstract: The humor on the BBC sketch show “The Goodies,” of which he was a creator and star, was visual, anarchic and very silly. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: The Coronavirus Could Rewrite the Rules for Silicon Valley
abstract: Amazon may be bigger than ever, but change is coming for the tech giants, too.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Amazon reported blockbuster first-quarter sales. This week Microsoft, Facebook and Google showed robust gains of their own. Supply chain disruptions and slowing ad revenue have put little dent in these cash-rich giants that, together with Apple, account for 20 percent of the S&P 500 index. Amid the biggest economic crisis since the Great Depression, Big Tech is roaring ahead.

headline: Billions in Clean Energy Loans Go Unused as Coronavirus Ravages Economy
abstract: As Congress rushes out trillions of dollars to prop up businesses, the Energy Department is holding on to tens of billions in clean energy loans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the government struggles to keep businesses afloat through the pandemic, the Trump administration is sitting on about $43 billion in low-interest loans for clean energy projects, and critics are accusing the Energy Department of partisan opposition to disbursing the funds.

headline: Three: Mirror Image
abstract: Five years into a rabbit hole, Caleb goes from one side of the screen to the other.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Spotify

headline: How Lobbyists Robbed Small Business Relief Loans
abstract: Years of lavish political spending by special interest groups were all in anticipation of a time like this.
lead_paragraph: As the unemployment rate threatens to surge toward 20 percent, billionaires and corporations clearly aren’t the ones hurting the most from the economic shock caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. But they are the ones who can afford to write super PAC checks and hire lobbyists. And that has allowed them to shape aspects of Congress’ $2 trillion relief package in their favor.

headline: Biden Will Address Tara Reade’s Allegation on MSNBC on Friday
abstract: After weeks of silence that prompted Democratic frustration, Joe Biden will discuss a former Senate aide’s allegation of sexual assault on “Morning Joe.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. will publicly address an allegation of sexual assault for the first time in an appearance on morning television on Friday, after weeks of silence on the issue that had prompted frustration from Democrats and attacks from Republicans seeking to weaken him for a general election contest against President Trump.

headline: Local journalism helps tell the full story
abstract: Local journalism is in crisis and at risk of disappearing. These vital resources are critical to the safety, security and knowledge of our communities, never more so than in these difficult times. On World Press Freedom Day and every day, we encourage you to find a local news organization you trust and support it.
lead_paragraph: Local journalism is in crisis and at risk of disappearing. These vital resources are critical to the safety, security and knowledge of our communities, never more so than in these difficult times. On World Press Freedom Day and every day, we encourage you to find a local news organization you trust and support it.

headline: Andy Dalton Joins Crowded N.F.L. Free Agent Pool
abstract: After nine years starting at quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals, Dalton joins two former No. 1 draft picks — Cam Newton and Jadeveon Clowney — among veteran players searching for jobs.
lead_paragraph: The Cincinnati Bengals cut quarterback Andy Dalton on Thursday one week after drafting his replacement, Joe Burrow of Louisiana State, with the first overall pick. Dalton spent nine seasons as their starter and will now head into a free agent market that is already crowded with talent and offers very few landing spots for veteran passers.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Whether you have a half-hour or several, our TV critic has recommendations, including a new afterlife comedy and a travelogue about barbecue.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: As Workers Fall Ill, U.S. Presses Mexico to Keep American-Owned Plants Open
abstract: Multinational corporations with factories in Mexico have remained open, even after coronavirus outbreaks hit their facilities.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Trump administration and major U.S. manufacturers have successfully pressured Mexico to keep factories that supply the United States operating during the coronavirus pandemic, even as outbreaks erupt and waves of cases and deaths sweep the companies.

headline: Sister Patricia McGowan, Dedicated Teacher, Dies at 80
abstract: She joined the Sisters of Charity in New York in 1956 and taught at her alma mater, the College of Mount Saint Vincent, until 2019. She died from complications of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Willie Levi, 73, Dies; He Escaped a Life of Servitude
abstract: He was one of a group of men with disabilities who worked for substandard wages at a turkey plant but found justice. He succumbed to the new coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Crashing Economy, Rising Stocks: What’s Going On?
abstract: What’s bad for America is sometimes good for the market.
lead_paragraph: The economic news has been terrible. Never mind Wednesday’s G.D.P. report for the first quarter. An economy contracting at an annual rate of almost 5 percent would have been considered very bad in normal times, but this report only captured the first few drops of a torrential downpour. More timely data show an economy falling off a cliff. The Congressional Budget Office is projecting an unemployment rate of 16 percent later this year, and that may well be an underestimate.

headline: Lockdown TV: Netflix Dominates, News Surges and Bea Arthur Is Still Golden
abstract: But after a peak in March, the audience has started to shrink. “There’s only so much content people can consume,” a Nielsen executive says.
lead_paragraph: To get through the stuck-at-home days of the coronavirus pandemic, Americans have spent significantly more time than usual in front of the TV, gorging on streaming shows, news programs, old sitcoms and video games. But new data shows that, little by little, they have started to wean themselves from their favorite lockdown diversion.

headline: Idris Bey, an N.Y.C. Emergency Worker, Dies at 60
abstract: Mr. Bey, who died of the coronavirus, was a popular instructor at the Fire Department’s Emergency Medical academy.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: There May Be a Dangerous Shortcut to a Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: Should we take it?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Reopening, Joe Biden, Antarctica: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why the Trump Ploy Stopped Working
abstract: As the nation unifies, divisiveness falls flat.
lead_paragraph: Even in a pandemic there are weavers and rippers. The weavers try to spiritually hold each other so we can get through this together. The rippers, from Donald Trump on down, see everything through the prism of politics and still emphasize division. For the rippers on left and right, politics is a war that gives life meaning.

headline: Who Should Wear Masks on Planes? More Airlines Say Everyone
abstract: Major carriers are requiring masks on their flight crews. United, Delta and American decided that passengers must cover their faces, too.
lead_paragraph: After flight attendants and pilots criticized them for not doing more to protect employees, large airlines in the United States and around the world announced this week that they would require their crews and passengers to wear masks.

headline: Former Honduras Police Chief Charged With Drug Offenses
abstract: The police chief was charged in federal court in New York with helping to ship tons of cocaine into the United States at the behest of the Honduran president and his brother.
lead_paragraph: A former police chief in Honduras was charged Thursday in federal court in New York with helping to ship tons of cocaine into the United States at the behest of the Honduran president and his brother.

headline: Germano Celant, Curator Behind Italy’s Arte Povera, Dies at 79
abstract: He identified the “poor art” avant-garde movement and was an internationally renowned curator at the Guggenheim Museum in New York and the Fondazione Prada in Milan.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Pence Visits Ventilator Plant in Indiana, This Time Wearing a Mask
abstract: The vice president had been sharply criticized for visiting the Mayo Clinic this week and violating its requirement to wear one.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence was photographed on Thursday wearing a mask while visiting a General Motors plant in Indiana in what appeared to be a tacit acknowledgment of the criticism he has received for traveling the country without one.

headline: Writing Rich Reading Responses: Participating in Our Summer Contest
abstract: Four key elements that can make a short response sing, with work from previous teenage winners as inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

headline: Apple’s First-Quarter Sales Are Up Despite Coronavirus Slowdown
abstract: The tech giant signaled confidence by announcing another big stock buyback, but it declined to forecast sales for the current quarter.
lead_paragraph: The global economy is showing signs of collapse, yet Apple said that its sales continued to rise and that it was buying back another $50 billion in stock.

headline: Unit 7: Independent Reading and Writing
abstract: Honoring “voice and choice” all summer long, with help from our 10-week contest and many other Times and Learning Network resources.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our seventh and final writing unit of the school year. Below, you will find a description of each element and an invitation to put them together to help guide your students to learn on their own now, during the summer, or even in the fall when a new school year — whatever it may look like — begins.

headline: Amazon Sells More, but Warns of Much Higher Costs Ahead
abstract: Jeff Bezos, the chief executive, said the company could spend up to $4 billion to handle the effects of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Online shopping during the coronavirus pandemic drove sales at Amazon far higher, the company said on Thursday. But the cost to deliver those products, and to keep its workers safe, is taking a big bite out of the company’s profits.

headline: Trump Attacks Flynn Inquiry Amid New Revelations on F.B.I.
abstract: The bureau was on the verge of closing its investigation into Michael Flynn in early 2017 when new evidence prompted agents to keep it open, newly disclosed court papers showed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump revived his attacks on law enforcement on Thursday as a pair of former advisers, Roger J. Stone Jr. and Michael T. Flynn, renewed their fights against their criminal convictions.

headline: After Decades of Service, Five Nuns Die as Virus Sweeps Through Convent
abstract: The coronavirus outbreak was difficult to trace in the Wisconsin convent, which specializes in care for aging nuns with dementia.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Our Lady of the Angels Convent was designed as a haven of peace and prayer in a suburb of Milwaukee, a place where aging, frail nuns could rest after spending their lives taking care of others.

headline: Amid a Rising Death Toll, Trump Leaves the Grieving to Others
abstract: President Trump has led no national mourning for the more than 63,000 Americans who have died from the coronavirus, emphasizing confidence about the future rather than dwelling on the present.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One morning this week, President Trump called food sector executives. That afternoon, he met with corporate leaders at the White House. The day before, he paraded small-business owners in the East Room, and the day before that, he showcased executives from retail giants like Walgreens and Walmart in the Rose Garden.

headline: Republicans, It’s Too Late to Back Away From Trump
abstract: G.O.P. lawmakers have enabled all of the president’s misadventures up to now. They can’t disavow his response to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic creeps deeper into the election cycle, President’s Trump campaign team has a message for Republican lawmakers: Don’t even think about trying to socially distance yourself from the president’s handling of the crisis.

headline: In a Victory for Women in Sudan, Female Genital Mutilation Is Outlawed
abstract: A new law criminalizes genital cutting, a harmful practice that nine in 10 Sudanese women are said to have endured. But some warned laws alone cannot eliminate the practice.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Sudan’s new government has outlawed the practice of female genital mutilation, a move hailed as a major victory by women’s rights campaigners in a country where the often dangerous practice is widespread.

headline: Democrats Assail McConnell for Bringing Senate Back Amid Pandemic
abstract: The majority leader’s plan to reconvene next week carries dangers for lawmakers as well as workers at the Capitol, where many low-level employees are minorities and at greater risk from Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats assailed Senator Mitch McConnell on Thursday for insisting on bringing the Senate back to Washington in the thick of the coronavirus pandemic, saying it could imperil not only senators and their aides, but also large numbers of low-level employees, including racial minorities at higher risk of infection and death from Covid-19.

headline: In a Crisis, True Leaders Stand Out
abstract: Swift action, compassion and trust in science mark the most effective responses to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Leadership may be hard to define, but in times of crisis it is easy to identify. As the pandemic has spread fear, disease and death, national leaders across the globe have been severely tested. Some have fallen short, sometimes dismally, but there are also those leaders who have risen to the moment, demonstrating resolve, courage, empathy, respect for science and elemental decency, and thereby dulling the impact of the disease on their people.

headline: Scrambling the Political Divide: ‘No Normal Recession’
abstract: When a Republican senator shops a stimulus plan that has more common ground with a leading progressive.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Peter Hunt, Who Directed the Broadway Hit ‘1776,’ Dies at 81
abstract: The musical about the founding fathers, his Broadway directorial debut, scored three Tonys. He was also a mainstay of the Williamstown Theater Festival.
lead_paragraph: Peter H. Hunt, who had a triumphant success with his directorial debut on Broadway, the musical “1776,” which ran for almost three years and won the Tony Award for best musical, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.
